webTitle: Excluded pupils 'twice as likely to end up criminals'

fields.headline: Excluded pupils 'twice as likely to end up criminals'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Children excluded from school are almost twice as likely to end up with criminal convictions as those who have been in care, a new study has found.
fields.body:
Children excluded from school are almost twice as likely to end up with criminal convictions as those who have been in care, a new study has found.

The findings, which contradict traditional beliefs about adolescent delinquent behaviour, emerged by chance during a study called 'The Cost Of Failure' which examined a group of youths excluded from schools between 11 and 15.

One of the study's authors, Professor Colin Pritchard of the Department of Mental Health, Royal South Hants Hospital, told The Observer: 'We expected the kids who had been excluded and were also in care to have far worse criminal records. That was not the case. In fact, when we separated the figures we found that 43 per cent of the children in care went on to be involved in crime, compared to 71 per cent for the excluded pupils.'

A major contributing factor is lack of aftercare given to excluded pupils. While those in care are often referred to a range of agencies to meet their needs, excluded children are generally left to fend for themselves after leaving pupil referral units aged 16. On average, such units offer only 10 hours of education per week.

Pritchard is completing a new study which uses a large sample of both excluded pupils and children in care for a more thorough comparison. The results, to be published later this year, are expected to support the initial findings. With eight out of 10 excluded pupils being involved in violence against teachers, the new study is also expected to show that the level of violent crime among former excluded pupils is significantly higher, not just when compared to children in care but when compared to the rest of the population as a whole.

Pritchard's research will inflame the row between the Government and many teachers over current policy on exclusions. David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, has said that he wants to reduce the number of pupils expelled from schools by a third by 2002. The unions say this puts teachers and other children at risk.

Last week Blunkett announced a major expansion in the number of special learning centres for persistently disruptive pupils - so-called 'sin bins' - and extra funds for 800 'learning mentors' to patrol school corridors and remove disruptive pupils from classrooms.

However, many in the teaching profession accuse the Government of not supporting staff faced by the threat of physical violence.

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: A collection of essays that celebrates 'the excellence of Story' from the creator of Narnia
fields.body:
Of This and Other Worlds
C.S. Lewis
Edited by Walter Hooper
HarperCollins £6.99, pp166
Buy it at BOL

'Everything began with a faun; a faun carrying an umbrella...' The author of the Chronicles of Narnia addresses the role of 'story' in fairy tales and science fiction and compares The Hobbit to Alice in Wonderland in this rare and revealing collection of occasional journalism. Lewis was, of course, not known to his contemporaries as a literary critic, but this surprising volume reveals him as an astute reader of many popular twentieth-century English writers, including his Oxford colleague and fellow 'Inkling' J.R.R. Tolkien, George Orwell ('Animal Farm is a work of genius'), Rider Haggard and Dorothy L. Sayers.

As such a list implies, Lewis is concerned here to celebrate 'the excellence of Story', an unfashionable point of view today but one that takes the reader to the roots of his inspiration. 'On Three Ways Of Writing for Children' also considers the work of Lewis Carroll, E. Nesbit and Kenneth Grahame and contains an impassioned plea for the 'fantastic' stories that Lewis particularly loved to read and write. It would be interesting to know what he would make of J.K. Rowling's Harry Potter.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A perfect collection of short stories from Alice Munroe, plus Nathaniel's Nutmeg, Stolen Marches, Living on Thin Air, The Marriage of Souls and Departures & Arrivals
fields.body:
The Love of a Good Woman
Alice Munroe
Vintage £6.99, pp340
Buy it at BOL

The long first story in this collection could stand alone and show any number of novels how it should be done. In a small town in Fifties Canada, three boys find an upturned car with a drowned man in it floating in the river; the body is that of the local optometrist, Mr Willens. The subsequent action of the story swirls and eddies disconcertingly around his absent figure, as Munroe's almost casually exquisite prose dissects the events leading up to his death. Like the others in this perfect collection, this quiet tale of an unlikely death reveals the conventional to be a thing of malice and sadness and unexpected beauty.

Nathaniel's Nutmeg
Giles Milton
Sceptre £6.99, pp388
Buy it at BOL

Packaged like Longitude and titled to attract those with fond memories of mandolins, Nathaniel's Nutmeg, an engaging book, isn't, in fact, particularly reminiscent of either of its predecessors. Instead, it's a personable history of the sixteenth-century competition between the English and the Dutch for monopoly of the lucrative East Indies spice trade.

Many adventures preceded that of the eponymous Nathaniel Coulthorne; Milton's use of contemporary sources makes each voyage intimately real and affecting. Beset by 'blody flux', 'mighty stormes', 'naughtie aire' and quite understandable attacks of 'melancholie' en route , things rarely improved much for the sailors - or the natives - on arrival. Nathaniel's (island of) nutmeg, a tiny speck of a place called Run, turns out to have played an improbably important role in the history of New York.

Stolen Marches
David Crackenthorpe
Review £6.99, pp345
Buy it at BOL

Stephen Seagrave, an Englishman, has spent the Second World War in Nîmes as a member of the French Resistance. When the reader first encounters him he is wearing a dress; disguised as a cleaning woman, he has been taking clandestine photographs of the enemy. When peace is declared, Seagrave resumes his trousers and sets out to try and locate Ida, the gypsy prostitute with whom he fell in love at the height of the war. A relentlessly thickening plot of pursuit and blackmail follows. The novel is weakest when dealing with the tricky business of amour - 'her breasts, like trained pigeons, alighted on his shoulder' - but it's a fine enough evocation of the awful, bloody muddle of postwar affairs.

Living on Thin Air
Charles Leadbeater
Penguin £6.99, pp264
Buy it at BOL

An original and witty analysis of the so-called 'intangible' economy in which we now increasingly live, where 'knowledge' is upstaging the manufacture of things, and airy concepts such as branding and fashion have acquired terrific financial clout. As Tony Blair remarks on the jacket, Leadbeater is 'an extraordinarily interesting thinker' - sharp and informative, with a good line in unlikely metaphors. If the book has a fault, it's one it shares with its well-known endorser: an irrepressibly upbeat outlook which expresses itself in the generous use of hyperbole. Perhaps the proliferation of exclamation-mark adjectives is meant to distract our attention from the rust spots still marring this brave new world.

The Marriage of Souls
Warwick Collins
Phoenix £6.99, pp482
Buy it at BOL

In the late eighteenth century, the Hampshire town of Lymington made its living from the declining industry of salt-making. Excess water was boiled off from the brine in great furnaces stoked by the sea breeze. Against this darkly beautiful industrial background the story of physician Silas Grange's failed love affair unfolds. The drama of the salt furnaces is interwoven with the novel's painstaking interrogation of its characters' interior lives; explosions in the former; smouldering repression in the latter.

 Sophie Harrison

Departures & Arrivals
Eric Newby
Picador £6.99, pp192
Buy it at BOL

'Whatever else we remember of our travels, we remember our departures and arrivals.' In this edition Newby pastes together a fabulously colourful collage of short pieces in which he reflects on an eclectic selection of beginnings and endings, ripe with humorous in-betweens. Simple tales from childhood compete with exotic travelogue. From his early adventures in Hammersmith to opal mines in Australia, to the camel fair at Pushkar or the eccentric building of a grotto in his back garden in Devon, Newby delivers all with an incisive eye, wit and joie de vivre .

 Caroline Furneaux

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Be warned: this is one hell of a scary book... Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Thomas Friedman sings the praises of globalisation
fields.body:
The Lexus and the Olive Tree
Thomas Friedman
HarperCollins £8.99, pp490
Buy it at BOL

Be warned: this is one hell of a scary book. For those concerned that today's world is being manipulated by unaccountable multinationals, foreign currency speculators and e-entrepreneurs, then this book explains - in an astonishingly readable way - how they do it.

But this is not a critique of the system. This book is praise of the highest order. The frightening bit is that Thomas Friedman, a Pulitzer Prize-winning foreign correspondent for the New York Times, has written a paean to globalisation that is utterly compelling. There is no Third Way for Friedman, a concept he dismisses with contempt. You must either ride on the super-turbo-charged capitalist highway or be run over on it.

In Friedman's world, there are no longer superpowers but super-markets, the stock exchanges where the 'financial herd' offer countries salvation and prosperity as long as they play by their rules. Any country that fails to adapt is doomed. Those that open up will be blessed. It is a world where those nations not sufficiently wired up have microchip immune deficiency syndrome and where currency speculators are not demons, but providers of democracy and human rights across the globe.

The Lexus in the title of Friedman's book is the Japanese luxury car largely made by robots which represents all the best things about modernisation. The olive tree is the metaphor for tradition, which will always lose out. It leads him to his Golden Arches theory, which states that no two countries that have a McDonald's have ever been to war. Unfortunately for Friedman, since the hardback was published, the Kosovo conflict erupted, which disproved this.

fields.headline: Devon can wait
fields.standfirst: Polly Samson burnishes a familiar tale in Out of the Picture
fields.trailText: Polly Samson burnishes a familiar tale in Out of the Picture
fields.body:
Out of the Picture
Polly Samson
Virago £15.99, pp256
Buy it at BOL

Polly Samson's first novel, Out of the Picture, coming after an acclaimed collection of stories (Lying In Bed), tells a standard tale with just a little extra polish.

Teenage Lizzie leaves home in Devon without a word to her mother and takes an office job in London. Soon, she is having an affair with her boss, a man whose car is worth more than the Paddington flat she rents, and trying to make sense of the past. Her father, a famous artist now in eclipse, left home when she was tiny, a fact which seems to explain her vulnerability to a lover who is anything but dependable.

Her stepfather tried to be a father figure, but spoilt everything with some terrible behaviour which left her with no choice but to leave. If she stayed, she'd have to tell her mother - and Cordelia deserves 'something better than the truth'.

Out of the Picture is set in 1980, but resists the temptation of becoming no more than a period piece. The year is fixed by such details as the death of John Lennon and a sudden rush at Lizzie's place of work, a photo agency, on pictures of an unexceptional, well-born virgin called Diana, and also by a mass of subtler touches, from 'white-with-green Plymouth Argyle sportsbags' to Alberto VO5 green apple shampoo.

Only the reference to a lull in a family quarrel appearing to Lizzie like a cartoon video on pause is a little anachronistic - a video doesn't seem like a bit of technology with which a country child with a hippyish mother would be familiar so early.

The pleasure of reading is supplied largely by Polly Samson's descriptive talents, with any suspense in the story coming from the two sets of secrets, one recent (what was the stepfather's sin?) and the other lying at the root of Lizzie's history (what was the real story behind her father's leaving?).

It would be easier for the reader to take a proper interest in the second, deeper set of secrets if Samson didn't milk the first, by withholding from us information that Lizzie knows perfectly well.

It makes it hard to be fully absorbed in a book when the writer puts half her energy into building tension ('She didn't have time to look in the middle drawer. She will be less forgiving when she does.') and the other half giving other people's points of view rather than Lizzie's - mainly her mother's but sometimes her ghastly boss's too - to dissipating it.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: The delicate skein of Kate Atkinson's narrative has suffered from abrigement, plus Marrying The Mistress
fields.body:
Emotionally Weird
Kate Atkinson
Read by Frances Tomelty
Running time 3hrs
Harper Collins£8.99
Buy it at BOL

A teasing interlacing of narrative threads and playing with coincidence, chronology and fantasy are Kate Atkinson's hallmarks. But they also make her latest novel a poor choice for abridgement since the result is confusion. Central to the story is Effie's narrative set in Dundee University in the Seventies, peopled with a bewildering range of no-hope students and staff.

Characters are allusively named, like the beautiful young Ferdinand; others come back from the dead or turn out to be other than they seem. Frances Tomelty does her best but actually adds to the confusion: she intends to be Scots, English and South African, but often sounds Irish.

Marrying The Mistress
Joanna Trollope
Read by Patricia Hodge
Running time 3hrs
Harper Collins Audiobook £8.99
Buy it at BOL

In this story of middle-class angst, 'Grando' shocks them all by dumping his loyal wife of 40 years to marry a barrister half his age. Predictably, shock ricochets through the family: gay son (understanding), teenage grandson (admiring), mistress's Welsh mother (horrified), married son (protective of his aggrieved mother).

At the end, which is obvious from the beginning, there is no marriage and they all slip back into their altered lives. Trivial it may be, but with its insights into relationships, it makes a compulsive in-car listen and Patricia Hodge, impeccable accented and politely controlled, is exactly right.

fields.headline: Decade of dictators
fields.standfirst: Were politicians any better in the good old days? Piers Brendon tells the story of Thirties depression and oppression in The Dark Valley
fields.trailText: Were politicians any better in the good old days? Piers Brendon tells the story of Thirties depression and oppression in The Dark Valley
fields.body:
The Dark Valley: a Panorama of the 1930s
Piers Brendon
Jonathan Cape £25, pp880
Buy it at BOL

Which was the most bleakly terrible decade of the twentieth century? The obvious answer must be that the decades of the First and Second World Wars tie for first place: the Somme, the Holocaust, the atomic bomb and unprecedented loss of life. But at least the outcomes of these great conflicts were clear and, from the British perspective, the right side won on both occasions.

The Thirties were very different, Piers Brendon suggests, in The Dark Valley, a lively, fascinating but compulsively gloomy book. It may have been the decade of vintage P.G. Wodehouse, classic Noël Coward and of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers dancing cheek to cheek. But sandwiched as it was between the great crash of 1929 and the renewal of hostilities 10 years later, the Thirties witnessed what Churchill called 'the long, dismal, drawling tides of drift and surrender', and Britain's part in these international affairs was neither decisive nor glorious.

Of course, and as Brendon takes pains to point out, the previous 15 years had scarcely been a bed of roses. The First World War had left Europe materially, politically and spiritually impoverished, as the old landmarks and certainties had dissolved in the trenches, as Germany was left embittered and resentful at the punitive terms of the Treaty of Versailles, and as the politicians and the public in Britain and France vowed that they would go to any lengths to avoid such carnage again.

Add to this the advent of Bolshevism in Russia, fascism in Italy, inflation in Germany and isolationism in the United States and the prospects did not look exactly alluring. Then came the collapse of the American stock market, which ushered in the greatest economic crisis the world had ever seen, and wrecked whatever lingering hopes there might be that the planet had been made safe for democracy.

In many countries in Europe and elsewhere, the scales of economic devastation and human misery were such that it seemed clear democracy could not cope and should therefore be dispensed with. In Italy, Mussolini strengthened his position by reaching a concordat with the Pope. In Germany, Hitler seized power from the ageing President Hindenburg. In Japan, the military machine became increasingly uncontrollable by the government or the emperor. In Spain, General Franco overthrew the Republic.

The resulting authoritarian regimes sought distraction from domestic difficulties by staging extravagant foreign adventures: the Japanese invaded Manchuria, Mussolini annexed Ethiopia and Albania, while Hitler reoccupied the Rhineland, seized Austria and eviscerated Czechoslovakia. And these acts of aggression went unchecked because the powers which might have stopped them had (or made) problems of their own.

Of course, the depression which brought Hitler to power in Germany also brought Roosevelt to power in the United States. But FDR was too concerned with implementing the New Deal and in not offending isolationist opinion at home to do anything about the deteriorating state of Europe.

In Russia, Stalin was preoccupied by collectivisation (which ruined Soviet agriculture) and by purging the high command of the army (which gravely weakened his country's power to defend itself). In France, the Third Republic degenerated into chaotic irresolution: the Maginot Line was an expensive white elephant, the Popular Front achieved nothing, and no one was willing to contemplate the prospect of another war.

As for Britain, the economy was weak, the Empire was overextended and the idea of waging war simultaneously in Europe and Asia was almost too terrible to contemplate.

Under these circumstances, where no nation seemed willing or able to stand firm against the Axis powers, the policy of appeasement made extremely good sense, provided that you did not live in Austria, Ethiopia or Manchuria, and provided that the fascist leaders could be trusted. But could they? Baldwin was too lethargic to worry about this, and Neville Chamberlain was convinced, almost to the end, that they could.

In this, Chamberlain was terribly mistaken. Evil and amoral, living in fantasy worlds of their own creation, and buoyed up by their carefully-orchestrated cults of personality, neither Hitler nor Mussolini (nor, come to that, Stalin) were people to go tiger-shooting with, let alone to be trusted with the fates of nations and peoples. By the end of the decade, things were thus so bad that many Britons, who had previously opposed another war, now saw it as the only hope and the only solution.

In telling his tale of the Thirties, Brendon paints a vivid and vigorous canvas. He follows the (in)action back and forth from London to Berlin to Washington to Tokyo in an assured manner reminiscent of a Frederick Forsyth novel. His character sketches of the principal players are sharp, perceptive and often very funny. In a world which was increasingly spinning out of control, he finds few, if any, heroes.

We are often told that the politicians of yesteryear were greater figures than the politicians of today. This book provides an unanswerable riposte to such nostalgic nonsense. As a result, The Dark Valley is not an uplifting account. On the contrary, it is almost invariably depressing. But the book should be read by anyone who wants to understand the terrible harm that world recession, allied with fanatical ideology in some quarters, and feeble leadership in others, did then - and could yet do again.
fields.bodyText: The Dark Valley: a Panorama of the 1930s Piers Brendon Jonathan Cape £25, pp880 Buy it at BOL Which was the most bleakly terrible decade of the twentieth century? The obvious answer must be that the decades of the First and Second World Wars tie for first place: the Somme, the Holocaust, the atomic bomb and unprecedented loss of life. But at least the outcomes of these great conflicts were clear and, from the British perspective, the right side won on both occasions. The Thirties were very different, Piers Brendon suggests, in The Dark Valley, a lively, fascinating but compulsively gloomy book. It may have been the decade of vintage P.G. Wodehouse, classic Noël Coward and of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers dancing cheek to cheek. But sandwiched as it was between the great crash of 1929 and the renewal of hostilities 10 years later, the Thirties witnessed what Churchill called 'the long, dismal, drawling tides of drift and surrender', and Britain's part in these international affairs was neither decisive nor glorious. Of course, and as Brendon takes pains to point out, the previous 15 years had scarcely been a bed of roses. The First World War had left Europe materially, politically and spiritually impoverished, as the old landmarks and certainties had dissolved in the trenches, as Germany was left embittered and resentful at the punitive terms of the Treaty of Versailles, and as the politicians and the public in Britain and France vowed that they would go to any lengths to avoid such carnage again. Add to this the advent of Bolshevism in Russia, fascism in Italy, inflation in Germany and isolationism in the United States and the prospects did not look exactly alluring. Then came the collapse of the American stock market, which ushered in the greatest economic crisis the world had ever seen, and wrecked whatever lingering hopes there might be that the planet had been made safe for democracy. In many countries in Europe and elsewhere, the scales of economic devastation and human misery were such that it seemed clear democracy could not cope and should therefore be dispensed with. In Italy, Mussolini strengthened his position by reaching a concordat with the Pope. In Germany, Hitler seized power from the ageing President Hindenburg. In Japan, the military machine became increasingly uncontrollable by the government or the emperor. In Spain, General Franco overthrew the Republic. The resulting authoritarian regimes sought distraction from domestic difficulties by staging extravagant foreign adventures: the Japanese invaded Manchuria, Mussolini annexed Ethiopia and Albania, while Hitler reoccupied the Rhineland, seized Austria and eviscerated Czechoslovakia. And these acts of aggression went unchecked because the powers which might have stopped them had (or made) problems of their own. Of course, the depression which brought Hitler to power in Germany also brought Roosevelt to power in the United States. But FDR was too concerned with implementing the New Deal and in not offending isolationist opinion at home to do anything about the deteriorating state of Europe. In Russia, Stalin was preoccupied by collectivisation (which ruined Soviet agriculture) and by purging the high command of the army (which gravely weakened his country's power to defend itself). In France, the Third Republic degenerated into chaotic irresolution: the Maginot Line was an expensive white elephant, the Popular Front achieved nothing, and no one was willing to contemplate the prospect of another war. As for Britain, the economy was weak, the Empire was overextended and the idea of waging war simultaneously in Europe and Asia was almost too terrible to contemplate. Under these circumstances, where no nation seemed willing or able to stand firm against the Axis powers, the policy of appeasement made extremely good sense, provided that you did not live in Austria, Ethiopia or Manchuria, and provided that the fascist leaders could be trusted. But could they? Baldwin was too lethargic to worry about this, and Neville Chamberlain was convinced, almost to the end, that they could. In this, Chamberlain was terribly mistaken. Evil and amoral, living in fantasy worlds of their own creation, and buoyed up by their carefully-orchestrated cults of personality, neither Hitler nor Mussolini (nor, come to that, Stalin) were people to go tiger-shooting with, let alone to be trusted with the fates of nations and peoples. By the end of the decade, things were thus so bad that many Britons, who had previously opposed another war, now saw it as the only hope and the only solution. fields.headline: 'I never was a hero'
fields.standfirst: Viktor Pelevin
fields.trailText: Viktor Pelevin was born in 1962. He is the author of several acclaimed novels, including Omon Ra, The Life of Insects and The Clay Machine Gun. His latest, Babylon, sold more than 200,000 copies on publication last year. Among the post-Soviet generation of readers, he has both a popular following and intense critical attention as a serious writer.
fields.body:
Viktor Pelevin was born in 1962. He is the author of several acclaimed novels, including Omon Ra, The Life of Insects and The Clay Machine Gun. His latest, Babylon, sold more than 200,000 copies on publication last year. Among the post-Soviet generation of readers, he has both a popular following and intense critical attention as a serious writer.

Observer: In Russian, your new novel, Babylon, is called Generation P. What is Generation P?

Viktor Pelevin: There are so many meanings. First, it's Generation X. Second, it's connected with this Russian term that was used in the end of the book. It's an obscene Russian term, pizdets, a really rude word. So it's Generation Pizdets, which means a generation that faces catastrophe. And now, you know, some of our newspapers think that this is Generation Putin. So it's like whatever you like.

Obs: In Russia, you have the popularity of a film star.

VP: A film star who is never seen. I do my best to avoid the limelight.

Obs: What is the reason for your celebrity ?

VP: Well, I don't know. People just like my books. I'm not a public person. I never appear on television and never give interviews. Well, sometimes I do, but it's not a normal thing. I really don't know. I'm just trying to write good books.

Obs: When did you first start to write?

VP: When I was in my late twenties. First, I had another education.

Obs: As?

VP: An engineer in electronics.

Obs: Did you always want to be a writer?

VP: In the Soviet era, being a writer meant being a real scoundrel. People like Solzhenitsyn were actually fighting the system. I never was a hero. I would never be able to do that. So I'm not really sure that I would have been writing if the Soviet Union had not collapsed. Perhaps I would be writing something, but I would never try to publish it.

Obs: Your emergence as a writer coincided with the collapse of the Soviet Union. Your work seems to be an exploration of that.

VP: I think you're right - post-Soviet Russia. But I'm not interested in the Soviet past. There are so many writers who are still doing that. That's pretty understandable. For people of the older generation, who lived their entire conscious life under Soviet power, it still remains the only thing they still can think about.

Obs: Are there earlier Russian writers who influenced you?

VP: There were so many. I guess every writer that I have ever read. When I was about seven or eight years old, I started to read Chekhov's funny stories. You know, he started as a writer by writing short, funny stories for magazines in Moscow and St Petersburg.

Obs: Do you have a belief in the purpose of fiction?

VP: No. I think if you're a writer you'd rather not think about general issues. If you are not creative, you could have thoughts like that, but if you're a writer they won't help you. The more general ideas you have, the worse it is for what you write. I'm not into the theory of literature.

Obs: You're also a Buddhist?

VP: I'm a student. I practise and quite often I go to the Zen retreats. The last one, in South Korea, lasted for three months last winter. It was the finest way to enter the millennium. For the entire time, you are given only rice and seaweed; for the New Year party, we were given a slice of pizza and a can of Coke.

Obs: How would you judge the Russian literary scene at the moment?

VP: I really don't consider myself a part of the literary scene. It's something that is really harmful for a writer to establish and maintain any contact with the so-called literary scene.

A literary scene is something that never produces literature. It only produces the so-called literary life, which has nothing to do with books. If you want to write books, you've got to keep as far from it as you can. So I never mix in literary circles. I don't spend my time talking with other writers.

Obs: What are you working on now?

VP: I'm writing short stories and considering my next novel.

Obs: What do you feel about your new President?

VP: My new President? Actually, the funny thing about it was that I found out that Russia's having a new leader two months after you did, because I was in Korea. We didn't have any link with the outside world. Even talking is prohibited in that retreat. You don't talk; you write notes. So I didn't know anything about it. I don't think much about Mr Putin.

The only thing I can tell you is that I think he was elected for two reasons. First, because he's a very fresh face for the average Russian. Though he was KGB director, he wasn't in the media. He was in the shadows. If you live in Russia, after a while you start to perceive all active politicians as members of the same gang of crooks, like some rabble on the station.

In Russia, it happens there are crooks who are playing cards. Some people play with them and they pretend that they lose. Some people pretend that they win. But actually, they're in the same game; they're just cheating people; they're trying to make you play. You'll never win. So I think all our politicians, whether they are communists, the so-called liberal democrats, the so-called Right, they're all perceived as members of the same company of crooks. But Putin was something fresh, something new. That was one reason.

The second is that he's a very good communicator, Russian-style. He really can make it. He has this instant access to your attention. I think it's just his natural leadership. Russians perceive Putin pretty much like Americans perceived Reagan.

And then perhaps this Chechen war helped. He was very belligerent and many Russians took a view that maybe he solved that problem. Actually, you know, I invented a good term about the Russian society to come. I love it. It's called dot.communism.

fields.headline: Injustice of the peace
fields.standfirst: William Shawcross makes a powerful case against the leaders of the new world disorder in Deliver Us From Evil
fields.trailText: William Shawcross makes a powerful case against the leaders of the new world disorder in Deliver Us From Evil
fields.body:
Deliver Us From Evil: Warlords and Peacekeepers in a World of Endless Conflict
William Shawcross
Bloomsbury £20, pp440
Buy it at BOL

Just after the war ended in Kosovo, I found myself at a party in Pristina talking to a diplomat who had followed the recent wars in the Balkans since their beginning. His view rejected the existing culture of armed humanitarian intervention by bodies such as the United Nations.

Instead, he had concluded, the best answer would have been for the war and ethnic cleansing to run their course, to separate out the ethnic factions like some vast, human refinery. And then - and only then - go in to mediate and pick up the pieces.

It is a refrain that was recently given a public persona by theorist Edward Luttwak writing about the Kosovo conflict in the journal Foreign Affairs. In an essay entitled 'Give War a Chance', quoted by William Shawcross in his new book on the past decade of peacekeeping operations, Luttwak argues that governments and the international community should resist 'the emotional impulse to intervene in other people's wars - not because they are indifferent to human suffering but precisely because they care about it and want to facilitate the advent of peace'.

As someone who would fit into the description of a 'cruise-missile liberal', I find Luttwak's view, and that of the diplomat, impossible to agree with, but it usefully underlines the emerging policy of 'armed humanitarianism' that has appeared in the past 10 years.

The doctrine of armed humanitarianism, as framed in UN Security Council resolution 794 in December 1992 to deal with the crisis in Somalia, was to define the post-Cold War landscape of the new world disorder.

But it was to be doctrine that was inconsistently applied and was as ill-conceived as it was often ill-considered in its application. And in its shortcomings, it was a policy that would lead to a series of disasters - in Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia, where the most powerful nation on Earth was humiliated and humbled by lightly-armed hoodlums in pick-up trucks, and in Rwanda, where more than 800,000 people died as the world sucked its collective thumb.

The case of Somalia is emblematic in Shawcross's book. For long before the United States was forced to confront the horror of its dead servicemen being dragged naked through the dusty streets of Mogadishu, 'the crossing of the Mogadishu line' came to be a test of the international community's resolve in dealing with intractable violence of the post-Cold War era. The belated response in Somalia, like so many of the crises described in this book, given impetus by the international media to 'do something', was summed up memorably by the then secretary general of the UN, Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

Comparing the response to Bosnia to that in Somalia, where thousands were dying from the starvation, to which the the collapse of civil order into tribalism had contributed, he accused the Security Council of 'fighting a rich man's war in Yugoslavia while not lifting a finger to Somalia'.

Shawcross does not leave it there, quoting Boutros Boutros-Ghali's complaint to the British ambassador to the United Nations that the crises in Bosnia and Somalia were similar, 'except for the fact that the parties in Somalia are not sophisticated and did not wish the UN to become involved, whereas those in Bosnia are sophisticated, welcome the UN, but violate the agreements the UN helps them conclude'.

In the end, it would turn out to be an important distinction as the belated - and largely US mission - trundled up Somalia's beaches and headed towards disaster. But Boutros Boutros-Ghali's point was - and remains - a crucial one, underlined more recently by the international community's attitude towards crises in East Timor, Chechnya, the Congo and Kosovo.

Put at its simplest, if you are white and living on the edge of Europe, the world is prepared to move mountains. If you are not, or live within the field of influence of a decrepit B-list superpower (Russia), then you can simply forget it.

And it is not just in the question of 'armed humanitarianism' that Shawcross finds the West apparently incapable of getting to grips with the contradictions of helping keep the peace. In post-conflict settlements, the West is found equally wanting. In Cambodia and in Sierra Leone, to mention two examples, the assistance of the international community in attempting to forge a new civic society after long periods of bloodletting also saw an insistence on the accommodation of those who, in the former Yugoslavia, would be indicted as war criminals.

Shawcross's book is long overdue, if demanding in attention, as he relates his series of nasty, murky wars. The case he makes is a good one, too. For with the best will in the world, it is difficult to ignore his conclusion - that the old pragmatism and partialism of the countries who claim moral leadership of the world lives on.

fields.headline: What happens next
fields.trailText: Sequels are a nearly impossible genre. Writers who try to revisit imaginative territory in which, perhaps not five years before, they had a huge success, invariably seem to come unstuck.
fields.body:
Sequels are a nearly impossible genre. Writers who try to revisit imaginative territory in which, perhaps not five years before, they had a huge success, invariably seem to come unstuck.

This thought occurred to me this week as I wrestled with Joe Klein's new novel, The Running Mate (Chatto £16.99, pp405), the follow-up to his mega-bestselling Primary Colors or, as his publishers would have it, 'the sensational new political novel'.

Well, if only. There is something avaricious about a sequel that spells doom to the whole enterprise. With the best creative will in the world, the sequel-bound author rarely rekindles the white heat of inspiration that fired the composition of the original. When all is said and done and the sequel, or follow-up, is finally out there in the bookshops, the public is strangely less interested in a second look at last year's fashion.

That's not the whole story, either. The plain fact is that the reading public does not love opportunism. Say what you like, the smell of opportunism clings to a sequel like cigar smoke to silk pyjamas. This, I guess, is what has happened to Joe Klein. Primary Colors was a well-deserved hit. It was brilliantly plotted, supremely well written, sharp, satirical, pacy and, best of all, absolutely of the moment.

It captured a widespread American cynicism about the primary election process during Bill Clinton's rise to power, fictionalised it deftly and supplied the East Coast political establishment with some much-needed summer reading. The further contrivance of having a tantalising and near-libellous roman à clef written by 'Anonymous' (someone obviously well-informed) was a masterstroke that kept the wheels of publicity spinning long after the reviewing cycle was over.

The success of Primary Colors is explicable with hindsight, but at the time it was the classic example of a literary lightning strike. The Running Mate is emphatically not a sequel to Primary Colors, but it inhabits the same narrative milieu and even has a walk-on part for Governor Jack Stanton.

It mixes fact and fiction in the same teasing way and invites us to speculate about the real-life identities of its protagonists. Is Charlie Martin, who is running for office, Al Gore, John McCain or Senator Kerrey? Who is Donna Mendoza? Is Hillary Clinton to be detected in Charlie Martin's Nell?

Perhaps if you live in Washington DC, living and breathing politics, this is intriguing, but where Primary Colors had the great advantage of fictionalising an already sensational story, this time around we have the fascinating paraphernalia of the campaign trail, but nothing like a compelling natural plot. The primaries of 1992 were gripping in a way that's impossible to repeat. Klein has mixed together many of the ingredients that worked so well for Primary Colors, but the taste of The Running Mate, at least to my palate, is as sawdust after the gourmet delights of the first helping.

Perhaps the best way to write a sequel is to make no bones about your intentions and to declare your ambition to write a series at the outset. This, it seems, is what Bernard Cornwell (another pseudonymous author) has triumphantly done with his Sharpe books.

Part of the key to his success lies in his unabashed delight in, and passion for, things Napoleonic. When Richard Sharpe was just a landlubbing Hornblower, fighting his way with Wellington's army through the Peninsula War, his adventures (and I've only read Sharpe's Eagle and Sharpe's Company) were always characterised by an attention to detail that in the hands of a writer less sure-footed than Cornwell would have made for the deadliest of reads. But passion tells.

Sharpe has now featured in some 17 adventures and in his latest, Sharpe's Trafalgar (HarperCollins £16.99, pp275), the old rogue not only manages to seduce the wife of Lord William Hale, a fellow voyager on a homebound ship of the line, but manages to get himself comprehensively mixed up in the Battle of Trafalgar.

Cornwell's narration of this epic sea-battle is quite masterly and supremely well-researched. When, at the very end, he tells us that Sharpe will be 'back on land soon, where he belongs, and will march again', you feel that here is one writer who has got that old sequel problem licked.

Perhaps if you live in Washington DC, living and breathing politics, this is intriguing, but where Primary Colors had the great advantage of fictionalising an already sensational story, this time around we have the fascinating paraphernalia of the campaign trail, but nothing like a compelling natural plot. The primaries of 1992 were gripping in a way that's impossible to repeat. Klein has mixed together many of the ingredients that worked so well for Primary Colors, but the taste of The Running Mate, at least to my palate, is as sawdust after the gourmet delights of the first helping. Perhaps the best way to write a sequel is to make no bones about your intentions and to declare your ambition to write a series at the outset. This, it seems, is what Bernard Cornwell (another pseudonymous author) has triumphantly done with his Sharpe books. Part of the key to his success lies in his unabashed delight in, and passion for, things Napoleonic. When Richard Sharpe was just a landlubbing Hornblower, fighting his way with Wellington's army through the Peninsula War, his adventures (and I've only read Sharpe's Eagle and Sharpe's Company) were always characterised by an attention to detail that in the hands of a writer less sure-footed than Cornwell would have made for the deadliest of reads. But passion tells. Sharpe has now featured in some 17 adventures and in his latest, Sharpe's Trafalgar (HarperCollins £16.99, pp275), the old rogue not only manages to seduce the wife of Lord William Hale, a fellow voyager on a homebound ship of the line, but manages to get himself comprehensively mixed up in the Battle of Trafalgar. Cornwell's narration of this epic sea-battle is quite masterly and supremely well-researched. When, at the very end, he tells us that Sharpe will be 'back on land soon, where he belongs, and will march again', you feel that here is one writer who has got that old sequel problem licked. robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: The new battle of Britain
fields.standfirst: Yasmin Alibhai-Brown foresees a Britain which will be radically changed by voices from beyond the white establishment in Who Do We Think We Are?
fields.trailText: Yasmin Alibhai-Brown foresees a Britain which will be radically changed by voices from beyond the white establishment in Who Do We Think We Are?
fields.body:
Who Do We Think We Are? Imagining the New Britain
Yasmin Alibhai-Brown
Allen Lane £18.99, pp274
Buy it at BOL

'There are of late divers blackamoors brought into this realme, of which kinde of people there are already to manie consyderying howe god hath blessed this land with great people of our nation...'

Not some semi-literate racist seething with worry about asylum-seekers in a letter to the Sun, but Queen Elizabeth I, writing to the mayors of England's major cities in 1596, urging a policy of repatriation of English blacks. 'Too many' even then.

On the cover of Yasmin Alibhai-Brown's new book, the second Queen Elizabeth is shown not whited-up like her predecessor, but delicately browned, making her a rather attractive Asian matriarch. The point is not simply to shock, but to ram home the truth that this country is forever changed. The long consequences of having large and settled Muslim, Hindu and black Caribbean communities here are only beginning to unfold.

So the 'we' in the title is deliberately ambiguous. The author came to Britain from Uganda in 1972, and her 'we' is often black and Asian, or black women or Muslims, but this is also a handbook for the rest of us. Her overarching 'we' means 'we British'.

Yasmin Alibhai-Brown is the leading black female commentator in the British media - 'Leading? Only!' she might tartly reply - and she fully shares the unease and cultural uncertainty about the family, social cohesion, materialism, community values and gender of most of her peers. Her distinguishing mark is that she is not a fully paid-up member of the current cliques. Her faith, gender and colour mean she lives not only in newspapers and policy-wonking but also in a saltier environment which is mostly unheard in the national conversation and which is far more critical of white liberal Britain.

Thus, at one point, she quotes a distant uncle: 'The greatest country in the world, even God could not defeat them. Today look at them. Sinking into the ocean. Wriggling like small fish inside the net of destiny. No discipline, no more the courage of empire. No more the big ambitions. I don't know if I am more sad at losing beautiful Kampala or finding this destroyed country.'

And, again, a thirtysomething optician, a British woman of Indian descent: 'Is this progress and do I want it? They carry on destroying the world. I see them drowning in drugs, divorce and depression. I see them unable to control their children. I see them producing filth and violence and claiming it is some kind of freedom. I see love between men and women evaporating. Why should I take this road in the name of progress?'

There is much more in a similar vein. It must have taken some courage to remove the veils of caution, politeness and language that have tended to hide such critiques from white eyes. Since she is equally tough on many aspects of Asian and black life, it explains why this very courageous and combative woman sounds so often so lonely. One of the most moving sentences of the book was her wry reflection on the Salman Rushdie fatwa and its aftermath: 'We became orphans, simultaneously losing liberalism - until then the rock of our education - and Islam, because of the insane way it was manifesting itself.'

It cannot be said that these tensions are finally resolved here. She sways from optimism of the will to pessimism of the facts, but this is an intensely useful, interesting book precisely because of its inner coils of anger and doubt. Alibhai-Brown is living through the difficult and painful process of being both centrally British and female and black and Asian. She is a first, highly articulate draft of a new kind of Briton.

And her core message is that this New Britain will not be a place in which white liberalism tidily smooths out imported differences, smothers other cultures and makes everything, finally, like itself. No, there are other British voices now and in time they will change even the white, liberal journalists around her. It's going to be a brave new island.

In general, Alibhai-Brown is more pessimistic about the new, mixed-up country than I am, but then again, this may be because, unlike her, I don't have to go to bed placing a bucket of water behind the front door to catch burning rags thrust through the letterbox.

fields.headline: The seven-year glitch
fields.standfirst: Michael Ondaatje's new novel, Anil's Ghost, is... pretty much what you'd expect
fields.trailText: Michael Ondaatje's new novel, Anil's Ghost, is... pretty much what you'd expect
fields.body:
Anil's Ghost
Michael Ondaatje
Bloomsbury £16.99, pp312
Buy it at BOL

It has been seven years since Michael Ondaatje published The English Patient. Prior to that book, prior to the Booker Prize and to Ralph Fiennes and the seven Oscars, Ondaatje had written two other novels, as well as a critically successful memoir and 10 volumes of poetry, including his stunning Collected Works of Billy the Kid. He was a writer widely, and perhaps primarily, admired by other writers for the way in which he could find hard-edged lyricism in the most startling of places, for the formal risks he took with his prose.

In search of a way of marketing him, publishers and critics often bracketed Ondaatje with the pre-fatwa Salman Rushdie or with Anita Desai or Shiva Naipaul, a 'commonwealth' author, in the patronising term of the time, an explorer of the post-colonial realities he inhabited as a fact of his upbringing in Sri Lanka. But The English Patient changed all of that; The English Patient has made Ondaatje a name that does not require any categorisation. And it has also left him with the best kind of problem: what a studiously 'poetic' novelist should do with a guaranteed six-figure print run.

What he has done, it appears, is to spend those seven years in something of a wilful spirit of retrenchment. He has returned to his native Sri Lanka, first to write a volume of poetry, Handwriting, which coolly adventured in some of the island's legends, and now to write a novel which deals with the more extreme realities of the time long after his leaving: the worst of the three-way civil war that took hold in the mid-Eighties and the early Nineties. Both projects seem an effort to unearth and re-examine some of the legacy of his birth, but in this case it is a literal exhumation: Anil's Ghost is told primarily through the eyes of a forensic pathologist.

Ondaatje has always been a writer who looks for ways beneath the skin of the subjects of his novels. In The English Patient, he explored the question of how to begin to feel when the skin has been burnt away; here he peels back yet another layer and sifts through the bones of his incendiary native island. Anil, through whom most of the story is told, arrives in Colombo after an absence of 15 years spent first in the calm lecture halls of Guy's Hospital and latterly in Oklahoma where she established the 'Fuck Yorick School of Forensics'.

She has invented for herself a series of protections - not least the man's name she 'bought' long ago from her brother for 100 rupees and an unnamed sexual favour - to guard against the cruelties to which her profession exposes her. In any case, she believes she has been away long enough 'to interpret Sri Lanka with a long-distance gaze'. She comes home as a one-woman envoy of the UN with the brief to expose some of the truth of the island's untold murders by studying what corpses she can find.

In the West, Ondaatje writes, Anil 'had come to expect clearly marked roads to the source of most mysteries'. But here there is no signposting. Anil is often in the dark in this book; she pokes about by the light of flickering matches in ancient caves; she works in the holds of abandoned ships and in the ballrooms of derelict mansions. As she becomes ever more wary of the gaze of the authorities, the Moon takes on the shape of a laboratory light and under its dim glow she tries to make one corpse in particular, a man she suspects has been murdered by the government, offer up its secrets. Anil is aided in her work by a local archaeologist, Sarath. Sarath gives Ondaatje licence to wander through Sri Lanka's mythic past and excavate parallels with its present carnage.

Thus ancient stone Bodhisattvas with missing limbs spread around the world's museums conjure the bloody reality of landmine victims; the tortured bodies of disappeared political activists lie hidden in sacred burial grounds. 'Archaeologists can read a bucket of soil like a good historical novel,' says Anil of Sarath; but a soil narrative comes as a series of fragments. Ondaatje's novel mimics this reading of history, and as his tale progresses it also becomes more diffuse.

At its margins are the ghosts of characters whose histories are related in hushed italics: the schoolgirl who walks the same way to school each day and one morning sees the heads of four students on stakes at a familiar bridge; the socialite doctor kidnapped by insurgents and forced to face the dawn-to-dusk reality of each day's new set of casualties.

Murders occur like whispers: monks are shot as they sleep; men are quietly strangled and bundled out of windows as trains pass through tunnels. Like The English Patient, Anil's Ghost is in part a novel about numbness in the face of these horrors of war, and the strategies by which the mind retains its humanity: a concentration on fine detail, a love of ancient words, the possibilities of love.

As she digs for truth, Anil turns up lives like her own that are pregnant with unspoken sadnesses, in particular the inscrutable loneliness of Sarath and the curious Ananda, arrack drinker, painter of the eyes of the Buddha and modeller of human skulls.

The danger of delineating numbness is that it can spread; Ondaatje has never been lost for an elegant phrase but here some of his more lugubrious imagery chloroforms his narrative. At one point, taping up the charred corpse, Sarath suggests a trip to the local temple as the sun goes down. Anil, writes Ondaatje, 'didn't like the abrupt switch to something aesthetic'. Her disquiet could equally apply, on occasion, to the author's own methods. Metaphors sometimes seem to be sunning themselves on rocks in this book; patients have a tendency to lie etherised on tables while the author gets on with describing the evening spreading out against against the sky.

At times - and who wouldn't want to write another English Patient? - it seems like Michael Ondaatje has set out to write a Michael Ondaatje novel, and as a result there is a self-consciousness in the lyricism that was absent from the author's earlier work. There is too much poetry in this book and in some distinct ways there is also not quite enough.

webTitle: IRA let off the hook over arms

fields.headline: IRA let off the hook over arms
fields.standfirst:
British change tack to keep agreement alive

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The British Government has accepted that demands for the IRA to surrender its arms are no longer tenable if the Good Friday Agreement is to be saved.
fields.body:
The British Government has accepted that demands for the IRA to surrender its arms are no longer tenable if the Good Friday Agreement is to be saved.

It recognises that any initiative to save the Agreement must involve a change in the concept of decommissioning, replacing the demand for the surrender of arms to stipulating they be put 'beyond use'.

In the next few weeks the British and Irish governments will also put forward a more flexible timetable on decommissioning.

Informed sources said yesterday that while London is not 'running away from decommissioning' it now saw the need to persuade unionists that Sinn Fein and the IRA should not be pressurised into disarmament.

'We can't let the Provisional IRA hold up devolution, and perhaps it's time to separate devolution and decommissioning. What we need is clarity from the IRA that their war is over and that they will deal with decommissioning,' the sources said.

They also made clear that Peter Mandelson will stay as Northern Ireland Secretary until at least the autumn. Last week The Observer reported that David Trimble had told colleagues he thought Mandelson would leave in the summer.

Sources close to Bertie Ahern, the Irish Prime Minister, also suggested Mandelson was set to leave, although they said that it wouldn't happen until the Assembly had been revitalised. 'Tony Blair would be sending out a very negative message if he removed someone of Mandelson's stature while there is still time to revive the Agreement,' they said.

London believes there are still two 'windows of opportunity' to revive the power-sharing executive at Stormont - May, and the early autumn following Ulster's marching season.

All the main pro-Agreement parties, including Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists, will hold talks with Tony Blair on Tuesday. The Prime Minister may travel to Northern Ireland at the end of this week if there is tangible progress.

The delay in the publication of a joint British/Irish position paper on the way forward is partly due to serious disagreements between Dublin officials and their counterparts in London and Belfast. Sources said there were 'tensions over the details' of the initiative. It is also understood that the relationship between Mandelson and the Irish Foreign Minister Brian Cowen has become extremely frosty.

Senior British Cabinet Ministers believe the key to unlocking the current deadlock is still an unequivocal IRA statement that its 'war' is over for good.

However there is no guarantee that the Provisionals will provide such a statement on such clear terms as it would be a measurable shift in ideology - namely, the IRA's self-proclaimed 'right' since 1916 to wage war on behalf of the Irish people.

A spokesman for the Ulster Unionists said the party's 'absolute minimum' is an IRA statement that the threat of war is over for good and 'visible and credible evidence of decommissioning.'

Irish government sources were pessimistic last night about the prospects of progress over the next month, claiming that the main parties were 'on an election footing'.

Even though a general election in the UK is at least a year away, Trimble faces an early test. The death last week of south Antrim UUP MP Clifford Forsythe means a by-election in June which opponents of the Agreement will turn into a referendum on his leadership.

webTitle: Dewar: Hands off my job, I'm still in charge

fields.headline: Dewar: Hands off my job, I'm still in charge
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Donald Dewar has moved to quell the brewing battle to succeed him as Scottish Labour leader by flatly denying that he has nominated any of his Cabinet colleagues as his favoured choice to take over.
fields.body:
Donald Dewar has moved to quell the brewing battle to succeed him as Scottish Labour leader by flatly denying that he has nominated any of his Cabinet colleagues as his favoured choice to take over.

The announcement last week that the First Minister will be out of action for up to three months while he recovers from heart surgery prompted a frantic round of leadership speculation as senior Ministers manoeuvred themselves into the starting line-up for the undeclared race. Henry McLeish, the Enterprise Minister, emerged as the front-runner amid claims that he had been given 'special responsibilities' in Dewar's absence.

But in a move which deals a severe blow to McLeish's leadership ambitions, Dewar used his first interview since news of his heart problem broke to insist that none of his Cabinet colleagues had been promoted or received his endorsement.

He also ruled out any contest to fill the vacant post of Labour deputy leader 'in the immediate future'.

'I am not picking and choosing,' he said in an interview to mark the first anniversary of the Holyrood election. 'This is neither the place nor the time for that. I am going away for a very limited period of time.'

He denied his remarks would damage McLeish. 'I've no intention of laying on hands. The danger is that you will assume I am snubbing Henry. I'm neither snubbing or promoting any of my colleagues.'

But there is little doubt in Holyrood that McLeish has suffered a major setback. With press reports heralding him as 'Henry the First' last week, he is now facing accusations that he attempted to use Dewar's enforced absence to steal a march on his main rivals, Finance Minister Jack McConnell, Communities Minister Wendy Alexander and Health Minister Susan Deacon.

To the dismay of some Labour backbenchers, the constitutional position is that Jim Wallace, the Deputy First Minister, will hold the reins while Dewar recovers from surgery to replace a faulty heart valve. Some Labour figures resent the fact that the Liberal Democrat leader will be running the Executive while his party has only 17 MSPs.

Wallace's standing also took a knock last week with his handling of the Executive's failed attempt to block Socialist MSP Tommy Sheridan's Private Member's Bill to abolish warrant sales and poindings. Amid impassioned opposition from Labour backbenchers during the debate on the Bill last Wednesday, Wallace was left looking humiliated and out of his depth as the Executive was forced to back down.

But this weekend Dewar insisted that there was 'no controversy' over Wallace taking charge during his absence.

I'm neither snubbing or promoting any of my colleagues.' But there is little doubt in Holyrood that McLeish has suffered a major setback. With press reports heralding him as 'Henry the First' last week, he is now facing accusations that he attempted to use Dewar's enforced absence to steal a march on his main rivals, Finance Minister Jack McConnell, Communities Minister Wendy Alexander and Health Minister Susan Deacon. To the dismay of some Labour backbenchers, the constitutional position is that Jim Wallace, the Deputy First Minister, will hold the reins while Dewar recovers from surgery to replace a faulty heart valve. Some Labour figures resent the fact that the Liberal Democrat leader will be running the Executive while his party has only 17 MSPs. Wallace's standing also took a knock last week with his handling of the Executive's failed attempt to block Socialist MSP Tommy Sheridan's Private Member's Bill to abolish warrant sales and poindings. Amid impassioned opposition from Labour backbenchers during the debate on the Bill last Wednesday, Wallace was left looking humiliated and out of his depth as the Executive was forced to back down. But this weekend Dewar insisted that there was 'no controversy' over Wallace taking charge during his absence.

webTitle: Holyrood finds its feet amid a heart crisis

fields.headline: Holyrood finds its feet amid a heart crisis
fields.standfirst:
Scotland's fledgling Parliament matured suddenly when Dewar's absence forced its members to stand up and be counted

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland's fledgling Parliament matured suddenly when Dewar's absence forced its members to stand up and be counted
fields.body:
In the week before its first birthday, Holyrood finally learnt to walk through a maze of confusion and incompetence, emerging stronger.

In five extraordinary days, ministerial reputations have been damaged and the Executive made to look confused. First Minister Donald Dewar and his Lib Dem deputy, Jim Wallace, have both wilted in the heat. And the man who would be Dewar's dauphin, Henry McLeish, has suffered a significant setback.

Two political dramas ran in tandem throughout the week. The first was a leadership tussle that emerged after Donald Dewar announced he would need a heart operation. The second was the vote on the first Private Member's Bill to come up for debate in the Scottish Parliament - Tommy Sheridan's move to abolish warrant sales.

Dewar rang his colleagues on Monday night to tell them what he'd known for weeks - that he was to go the Glasgow Royal Infirmary the next day for tests on his heart after a medical check-up had shown irregularities.

He spoke to Tony Blair and Gordon Brown. He also rang the Minister for Parliament Tom McCabe and McLeish, the Enterprise Minister. He told both he was relying on them to back up Wallace.

Wallace, the Lib Dem leader, had known of Dewar's heart condition since Friday, when it had been made clear that he was to take charge. On Tuesday morning, Wallace chaired the Cabinet meeting in Bute House where he read a short statement on the First Minister's health.

By this time the news had broken, and the media gave Dewar almost presidential treatment in its analysis of his condition and its impact on his office. The First Minister could be out of action for up to three months after the operation. But the papers were also quick to raise the question of who should lead the Executive in the meantime. The press reported that many Labour MSPs were seething about the idea that Wallace, leader of 'a rump 17 MSPs', should take charge.

An undeclared leadership race was suddenly front-page news. In Wednesday's papers, profiles of the front-runners jostled for space besides diagrams of heart valves and get-well-soon messages. Ministers Wendy Alexander, Susan Deacon and Jack McConnell were all in the frame, alongside McLeish.

While three of the candidates played it cool, McLeish saw an opportunity. He 'held court' in the Parliament canteen on Wednesday afternoon. The Daily Record took the hint. It proclaimed him 'Henry the First' as Labour backbenchers declared war.

But the strategy backfired. 'Who does he think he is? He's going to be leader over my dead body,' said one influential backbencher. Cabinet members were suddenly briefing that Dewar could be back sooner than thought.

The Labour parliamentary group has never discussed the question of a deputy leader. McLeish was never asked to do any more than help in Dewar's absence.

'He overplayed his hand entirely,' said one junior minister of McLeish. 'There's a strong feeling it's damaged his chances.' Asked if Dewar had at any point entrusted McLeish with further responsibility, the First Minister's spokesman, David Whitton, said emphatically there had been 'no meeting of that kind at all'.

Worse was to come for Labour. Last June the Scottish Socialist MSP Tommy Sheridan proposed the first Private Member's Bill. With the support of John McAllion of Labour and Alex Neil of the SNP, he wanted to abolish poindings and warrant sales, debt recovery methods long detested by Scotland's political Left. Unlike Westminster, Holyrood was meant to respond to proposals like Sheridan's.

The Bill passed through three of the Parliament's committees. As each one gave their approval, so the Labour MSPs on each committee signed up to support the plan.

The Executive wasn't so enthusiastic. There is animosity in senior Labour ranks towards Sheridan, partly because of his role in encouraging people not to pay poll tax and partly because he since created a party that challenges Labour's electoral grip.

The Executive also had much more immediate worries. Significant increases in water charges are about to be introduced across the country. Sources in the Executive say they didn't want Sheridan to abolish warrant sales and then call for a campaign of non-payment of water charges. This is why they were opposed to 'the method, not the principle' of Sheridan's Bill, according to a spokesman.

Wallace, who is also Justice Minister, told the Cabinet that the Executive would propose an amendment in Thursday's debate on the Bill, calling for an alternative method of debt recovery. Labour backbenchers were not pleased.

As Johanna Lamont, the MSP for Glasgow Pollock, says: 'We are not going to say one thing in one place and another somewhere else'.

Two group meetings on Wednesday failed to persuade the backbenchers to support the amendment. Another meeting was called for 12.30 on Thursday lunchtime when Dewar made a personal plea that they should support the amendment. It fell on deaf ears. Afterwards the decision was taken either to withdraw the amendment no matter what - or to listen to the debate and then decide.

Dewar says Wallace knew the amendment was to be withdrawn before he spoke in the debate. 'It would be inconceivable that that decision would be taken without discussion with Jim'. He added a 'categorical' denial that Wallace didn't know.

But at the media briefing after the debate, Tom McCabe said the Executive was 'minded to withdraw' the amendment but would decide once it had listened to the 'tenor of the debate'.

If the Executive was at one on its tactics, it failed to convey a sense of unity to the Parliament. The Observer has confirmed from impeccable sources that Wallace rose to speak knowing there was 'every likelihood' the amendment would be withdrawn. He had persuaded his own MSPs to back the amendment - but had to speak knowing Labour could not deliver its own troops.

It was a circle he found himself unable to square. He gave a poor speech. Flustered by interventions, he gave no signal that the debate was a foregone conclusion. His heckling of other speakers - he shouted 'bullshit!' twice - suggested that here was a man who was either off the pace, struggling to think on his feet, or just in a fog.

But the Parliament itself produced a stirring and impressive debate, with good speeches from all sides calling for the end to warrant sales.

Senior Liberal Democrat sources say that Wallace merely had the misfortune to be the designated ministerial speaker on a day when Labour imploded. They say there are issues to be learnt from the 'cock-up'. On Wednesday four backbenchers from each of the coalition parties met in a newly formed liaison group. Executive sources say had this been up and running sooner, it might have removed some of the misunderstanding.

As Wallace left the chamber afterwards, he met Dewar waiting in the corridor.

'Well done,' Dewar said as he leant in to offer words of support to his beleaguered Deputy Minister. Both seemed immune to the euphoria elsewhere in the building.

Upstairs McAllion left the Parliament building and walked into a knot of supporters. Placards that called for the abolition of warrant sales were waved with glee as the Labour backbencher was slapped on the back. Later Tommy Sheridan would be met with even greater warmth. As Johanna Lamont walked down the Grassmarket, having delivered an impassioned speech in favour of the Bill, she said: 'It's not that the Executive is arrogant, this is about the power of the [Labour] group. We have had to struggle to get here, especially the women, and we are determined to do the right thing'.

Last week was a victory for backbenchers and minority parties. Sheridan went further, describing it as a 'victory for Scotland' and called on councils to end all warrant sales immediately. His joymay be short-lived.

The Executive has made it clear that it plans to go 'beyond the Scottish Law Commission's recommendations [for reforming the law on debt recovery] only on hardship cases'.

webTitle: Gunman smirks as race hate murders shock US

fields.headline: Gunman smirks as race hate murders shock US
fields.trailText: The goateed gunman was methodical and unhurried. In 72 minutes he calmly drove 20 miles across four Pittsburgh suburbs and carefully picked out his victims.
fields.body:
The goateed gunman was methodical and unhurried. In 72 minutes he calmly drove 20 miles across four Pittsburgh suburbs and carefully picked out his victims.

First he went to the old-money area of Mount Lebanon, then an Indian grocery, a Chinese restaurant and a karate school.

By the end of his journey, a Jewish woman, a black man, two Asian women and an Indian man were dead and a second Indian man wounded.

Two synagogues were damaged by bullets, one spray-painted with swastikas and the word 'Jew'.

When police caught Richard Scott Baumhammers, 34, an immigration lawyer of Latvian descent who lived in Mount Lebanon, they found spent bullets and a .357-calibre gun in his black Jeep Grand Cherokee. Bomb experts were investigating a suspected incendiary device.

'We are taking a tack of ethnic intimidation - a hate crime,' said Paul Wolf, acting Allegheny County Police superintendent.

Outside Baumhammers's arraignment in Beaver Falls, about 25 miles northwest of Pittsburgh, a crowd jeered and called for his execution. He smirked as police led him past in a bulletproof vest.

The FBI was called in on the crime, the area's second race rampage in two months.

On 1 March three people were killed and two wounded at an apartment block and two fast-food restaurants in Wilkinsburg. The victims were white; the suspect, Ronald Taylor, found incompetent to stand trial due to schizophrenia, is black and is being held at Mayview State Hospital. He was also charged with ethnic intimidation.

Police received first word of Friday's shootings when they responded to a small fire at the home of Anita Gordon in Mount Lebanon, next door to the home of Baumhammers's parents. Gordon, 63, was found shot dead inside.

While at her house, police got a call of gunfire at the nearby Beth El Con synagogue, where Gordon was a member. Glass doors were shot out, 'Jew' and swastikas daubed on its outside walls.

Police then received reports of two men shot at an Indian grocery store in Carnegie. Anil Thakur, 31, died at Allegheny General Hospital four hours after he was shot. Sandip Patel, 25, was in critical condition, shot in the neck and facing possible permanent paralysis.

Then shots were fired at another synagogue in Carnegie. Fifteen minutes later, police had a call reporting that two employees shot at a Chinese restaurant in a McKees Rocks shopping plaza. Killed were Thao Pham, 30, a Vietnamese deliveryman, Ji-Ye Sun, 34, Chinese manager of the Ya Fei restaurant.

Then police were told of a man shot at a karate school in a Monaca shopping plaza. Garry Lee, 22, was killed.

Baumhammers was arrested 15 minutes later. His parents, Inese and Andrejs, are both dentists and his father taught at the University of Pittsburgh.

'It was an attack against us all, because it sought in its violence to divide us by the colour of our skin,' Gov. Tom Ridge said. 'We are struggling to make sense of yet another brutal racist rampage.'

webTitle: Riot fear in London's May Day protests

fields.headline: Riot fear in London's May Day protests
fields.trailText: Anti-capitalist protesters last night warned that tomorrow's demonstrations in London would descend into riots. As anarchists from around the country began arriving in the capital, leading figures told The Observer they were gearing up for violence.
fields.body:
Anti-capitalist protesters last night warned that tomorrow's demonstrations in London would descend into riots. As anarchists from around the country began arriving in the capital, leading figures told The Observer they were gearing up for vio lence.

'It's going to happen. We will be disrupting the City by blocking streets and digging them up. Even if the police leave us alone - which is doubtful - there will be some people who want to pick a fight,' one unofficial organiser said. 'We don't like it or condone it but it will kick off.'

Last summer's City of London protest ended in riots, bringing devastation to the capital's financial heart and leaving protesters and police seriously injured. This week's Mayday2K demonstrations are expected to be far bigger.

Yesterday Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, said that this year the police would be prepared. 'Everybody has a right to demonstrate, nobody has a right violently to demonstrate or to attack people or property,' he said.

Speaking at an anti-capitalist conference in north London, organisers claimed a repeat of the 18 June London riots was not inevitable. John Jordan, whose pressure group Reclaim the Streets is planning to dig up streets, said it was a celebration of the anti-capitalism movement rather than a protest.

webTitle: Child porn found at Orangeman's house

fields.headline: Child porn found at Orangeman's house
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A prominent Orangeman from South Down is at the centre of one of Ireland's largest child pornography investigations.
fields.body:
A prominent Orangeman from South Down is at the centre of one of Ireland's largest child pornography investigations.

Searches at the man's home last weekend also allegedly uncovered ammunition and detonators.

RUC officers took away three car-loads of home-made videos, CDs, photographs and computer equipment. One officer said the unit was overwhelmed at the amount of material found at the home of the Orangeman and former soldier in the now defunct Ulster Defence Regiment following complaints.

'This may turn out to be the largest amount of paedophile material found on either side of the border,' the officer said, 'The quantity was enormous and it's unlikely that this man was operating on his own. We believe he might have been part of a much wider ring involving people across Northern Ireland and beyond.'

He added that the investigation would be extended to see if others were working with the man in the production, distribution and sale of paedophile material.
