webTitle: Now BMW set to axe Mini plant

fields.headline: Now BMW set to axe Mini plant
fields.standfirst:
Car jobs meltdown if Rover quits Cowley
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW has drawn up secret plans to switch production of the new Mini to Germany and close Rover's Oxford factory - a final twist in the catastrophe that is likely to see Rover doomed within a week at a cost of 120,000 British jobs.
fields.byline: Joanna Walters, Kamal Ahmed and Denis Staunton, Berlin
fields.body:
BMW has drawn up secret plans to switch production of the new Mini to Germany and close Rover's Oxford factory - a final twist in the catastrophe that is likely to see Rover doomed within a week at a cost of 120,000 British jobs.

The news comes amid reports in Germany that Downing Street contacted the office of German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder to plead for more time for bids for Rover's Longbridge factory to be considered.

Sources revealed this weekend that if Rover at Longbridge closes, as now seems likely, the new Rover 75 executive saloon - the flagship car that was meant to revive the fortunes of the troubled manufacturer - would be axed at Oxford, threatening an extra 3,000 workers and up to 10,000 jobs across the region.

The closure of Longbridge and Oxford and the semi-closure of factories at Swindon and Hams Hall would cost 13,000 jobs directly at the plants, more than 60,000 component supply jobs across Britain and up to 50,000 jobs indirectly reliant on Rover. It could lead to a political crisis for the Government and increase pressure on Stephen Byers, the Trade and Industry Secretary.

Reports in German newspapers upped the political ante last night. Welt am Sonntag said sources at Alchemy - whose bid for Rover collapsed amid bitter recriminations on Friday - had revealed the Downing Street telephone call. They claimed the call and the Friday breakdown are linked.

When Byers last week asked BMW for an extension to allow the Phoenix consortium more time to put a financial package together for Rover last week, BMW refused - to the anger of the Government.

Senior BMW sources warned this weekend that they do not believe the Phoenix rescue consortium, run by ex-Rover boss John Towers, has any significant funding nor any chance of getting any.

It has officially been given a month to make a bid but if there is no sign of a solid plan by this Friday, then Rover is almost certainly finished, the sources said.

Rover chairman Werner Samann said yesterday that talks between Phoenix and BMW will begin on Tuesday, warning that if they were not successful, 'closure is unavoidable'. In his first public statement since the debacle unfolded, Byers said: 'It's not the role of Government to run the commercial negotiations between the interested parties, and while recognising that ultimately the final decision will be a commercial one to be taken by BMW, there is a role for the Government in bringing parties together and in leaving no stone unturned in trying to achieve a successful outcome for the workers at Longbridge and the people of the West Midlands. That is exactly what we shall be doing in the days ahead.'

As unions called for further action and planned trips to Munich to apply pressure to BMW, the car giant made it clear it is fighting for its independence in the face of global predators such as Ford, General Motors and Volkswagen. With Rover losing £2 million a day, BMW is under intense pressure from shareholders to dump the company.

If Phoenix cannot raise the money and the Government does not pump survival funding into Rover or buy a stake in the company within days, then it is facing the devastating scenario of losing the entire Rover cars business and Ford's plant at Dagenham within the next three weeks.

It is understood that West Midlands police are putting extra officers on standby at Longbridge on Tuesday in case workers come back from the Easter shutdown to find BMW has already closed the factory and locked them out - sparking a riot.

BMW and Alchemy blame each other for the breakdown of talks, with sources citing a £200m shortfall in what either side was prepared to pay to cover redundancy payments and ongoing liabilities.

If Phoenix also fails, BMW executives and senior sources from across the UK car industry have warned it is the end for Rover.That would mean the closure of all car- and engine-making at Longbridge, where 8,000 people work, and the shutdown of half and possibly all of the Swindon body-pressing plant, which employs 3,000 people making body panels for Rover, MG and Land-Rover. Ford is in the process of buying Land-Rover and could choose to supply its own body shells in future. GMB union general secretary John Edmonds warned: 'There will be jobs lost in every county in the country if this happens.'

BMW insisted this weekend that it is still planning to move the new Mini production line, which was being installed in Longbridge before the latest crisis, to Oxford to build an updated version of the Mini for sale next year. This would keep the 3,000 shopfloor workers employed but, without the Rover 75, would still cost thousands of component industry jobs because BMW plans to source 65 per cent of the parts for the Mini outside Britain in order to avoid the high pound. But officials at the Department of Trade and Industry say they fear BMW has plans to shut down all operations in the UK and take the Mini project back to Germany.

The BMW board of directors is riven with disagreements about how to deal with Rover and save BMW's independence. Strong voices within the Munich HQ are calling for rapid closure of Rover in a desperate attempt to cut its losses and save the German company from takeover. BMW sources have indicated that, although they have now given Phoenix access to Rover's financial records, the consortium needs to show very rapidly that it has at least £1 billion of funding up front to get into serious negotiations to buy Rover.

BMW fears that if the Phoenix bid is underfunded and Towers's plan to build 200,000 cars at Longbridge failed within months, then BMW would be landed with far greater liabilities than it is currently facing. BMW has put aside £2bn to pay for the cost of shutting down Rover.

The news comes amid reports in Germany that Downing Street contacted the office of German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder to plead for more time for bids for Rover's Longbridge factory to be considered. Sources revealed this weekend that if Rover at Longbridge closes, as now seems likely, the new Rover 75 executive saloon - the flagship car that was meant to revive the fortunes of the troubled manufacturer - would be axed at Oxford, threatening an extra 3,000 workers and up to 10,000 jobs across the region. The closure of Longbridge and Oxford and the semi-closure of factories at Swindon and Hams Hall would cost 13,000 jobs directly at the plants, more than 60,000 component supply jobs across Britain and up to 50,000 jobs indirectly reliant on Rover. It could lead to a political crisis for the Government and increase pressure on Stephen Byers, the Trade and Industry Secretary. Reports in German newspapers upped the political ante last night. Welt am Sonntag said sources at Alchemy - whose bid for Rover collapsed amid bitter recriminations on Friday - had revealed the Downing Street telephone call. They claimed the call and the Friday breakdown are linked. When Byers last week asked BMW for an extension to allow the Phoenix consortium more time to put a financial package together for Rover last week, BMW refused - to the anger of the Government. Senior BMW sources warned this weekend that they do not believe the Phoenix rescue consortium, run by ex-Rover boss John Towers, has any significant funding nor any chance of getting any. It has officially been given a month to make a bid but if there is no sign of a solid plan by this Friday, then Rover is almost certainly finished, the sources said. Rover chairman Werner Samann said yesterday that talks between Phoenix and BMW will begin on Tuesday, warning that if they were not successful, 'closure is unavoidable'. In his first public statement since the debacle unfolded, Byers said: 'It's not the role of Government to run the commercial negotiations between the interested parties, and while recognising that ultimately the final decision will be a commercial one to be taken by BMW, there is a role for the Government in bringing parties together and in leaving no stone unturned in trying to achieve a successful outcome for the workers at Longbridge and the people of the West Midlands. That is exactly what we shall be doing in the days ahead.' As unions called for further action and planned trips to Munich to apply pressure to BMW, the car giant made it clear it is fighting for its independence in the face of global predators such as Ford, General Motors and Volkswagen. With Rover losing £2 million a day, BMW is under intense pressure from shareholders to dump the company. If Phoenix cannot raise the money and the Government does not pump survival funding into Rover or buy a stake in the company within days, then it is facing the devastating scenario of losing the entire Rover cars business and Ford's plant at Dagenham within the next three weeks. It is understood that West Midlands police are putting extra officers on standby at Longbridge on Tuesday in case workers come back from the Easter shutdown to find BMW has already closed the factory and locked them out - sparking a riot. BMW and Alchemy blame each other for the breakdown of talks, with sources citing a £200m shortfall in what either side was prepared to pay to cover redundancy payments and ongoing liabilities. If Phoenix also fails, BMW executives and senior sources from across the UK car industry have warned it is the end for Rover.That would mean the closure of all car- and engine-making at Longbridge, where 8,000 people work, and the shutdown of half and possibly all of the Swindon body-pressing plant, which employs 3,000 people making body panels for Rover, MG and Land-Rover. Ford is in the process of buying Land-Rover and could choose to supply its own body shells in future. GMB union general secretary John Edmonds warned: 'There will be jobs lost in every county in the country if this happens.' BMW insisted this weekend that it is still planning to move the new Mini production line, which was being installed in Longbridge before the latest crisis, to Oxford to build an updated version of the Mini for sale next year. This would keep the 3,000 shopfloor workers employed but, without the Rover 75, would still cost thousands of component industry jobs because BMW plans to source 65 per cent of the parts for the Mini outside Britain in order to avoid the high pound. But officials at the Department of Trade and Industry say they fear BMW has plans to shut down all operations in the UK and take the Mini project back to Germany. The BMW board of directors is riven with disagreements about how to deal with Rover and save BMW's independence. Strong voices within the Munich HQ are calling for rapid closure of Rover in a desperate attempt to cut its losses and save the German company from takeover. BMW sources have indicated that, although they have now given Phoenix access to Rover's financial records, the consortium needs to show very rapidly that it has at least £1 billion of funding up front to get into serious negotiations to buy Rover. BMW fears that if the Phoenix bid is underfunded and Towers's plan to build 200,000 cars at Longbridge failed within months, then BMW would be landed with far greater liabilities than it is currently facing. BMW has put aside £2bn to pay for the cost of shutting down Rover.

webTitle: Mugabe's grim new threat to farmers

fields.headline: Mugabe's grim new threat to farmers
fields.standfirst: War veterans' chief wields the stickZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: As the tensions over Zimbabwe heightened yesterday, Britain condemned plans by President Robert Mugabe to use powers to seize white-owned farms without compensation within 10 days.
fields.body:
As the tensions over Zimbabwe heightened yesterday, Britain condemned plans by President Robert Mugabe to use powers to seize white-owned farms without compensation within 10 days.

The increased belligerence of Zimbabwe's government was also highlighted by the continued use of violence by Mugabe's supporters on white-owned farms and new threats to foreign journalists who did not portray the land seizures in a positive light.

Justice Minister Emmerson Mnangagwa, one of the architects of the land-grab policy, said yesterday that the farms would soon be distributed among land-less blacks.

'Within 10 days, the legal framework to take land and redistribute it to the people will be in place,' Mnangagwa said. He said Mugabe would use the Temporary Powers Act to install new legislation to seize land without compensation.

The British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, said the move was unjustified and would jeopardise help from those - including Britain - who wanted to fund land reform. 'The confiscation of farms without compensation would be a big step backwards,' he said.

Britain last week told a delegation of three Zimbabwean ministers that it would not release £37 million for Zimbabwe's land redistribution until all violence ceased, free and fair elections were held and a well-planned redistribution programme was set up.

'Britain's stance is not our problem,' Mnangagwa told the state news agency, Ziana. 'It does not matter what they think or say. We are going ahead with our plans.'

But the main opposition party said Mugabe was overreaching his authority. 'The president is not entitled to use the presidential power act for such purposes,' said lawyer David Coltart, an official of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change.

The war veterans, meanwhile, took to the streets of Harare yesterday in a show of force. Their leader, Chenjerai Hunzvi, whose supporters have invaded hundreds of white-owned farms and spearheaded violence against opposition members, led an estimated 200 demonstrators and vowed to deal with the opposition 'sell-outs'.

Hunzvi's deputy, Patrick Nyaruwata, warned foreign journalists to stop referring to the invaders of the white-owned farms as squatters.

'We are the indigenous owners of this country,' he said. 'You cannot say a person who invaded our country in 1890 is now the legitimate owner of our land, and we are the squatters.'

webTitle: 'Death squads' are poised for fresh Kashmir offensive

fields.headline: 'Death squads' are poised for fresh Kashmir offensive
fields.standfirst: Muslim fighters reject moves towards negotiation as they vow to put the last nail in India's coffin in holy war for a 'paradise on earth'
fields.trailText: Muslim fighters reject moves towards negotiation as they vow to put the last nail in India's coffin in holy war for a 'paradise on earth'
fields.body:
High on a hillside on the outskirts of Muzaffarabad stands a shaded, two-storey, redbrick house covered in vine leaves. By the broken doorbell is a handwritten sign marked 'HUM' and behind the white steel gate a young, bearded man in camouflage uniform stands guard, gripping a Kalashnikov.

This is home to Harkat ul-Mujahideen, listed as a terrorist organisation by the US State Department and the most hardline of the Islamic movements fighting the Indian army in Kashmir.

For 11 years Harkat and a dozen other militant groups have been training thousands of young men to cross the 462-mile Line of Control dividing the Himalayan state of Kashmir and to give their lives in a bitter guerrilla war against Indian security forces.

Pakistan's new military regime says it is willing to talk to India about their rival claims to the Muslim-majority state. India refuses to come to the table until the militants lay down their weapons. But the leaders of the three main Pakistan-based Islamic groups operating in Kashmir have told The Observer they are preparing for a new round of heavy fighting this year. 'We will fight until the last drop of blood is running in our veins to seek the blessing of Allah,' said one of Harkat 's most senior Kashmir commanders, known as Altaf.

A Harkat splinter group was behind the kidnapping of six tourists in Indian Kashmir in July 1995, including Britons Keith Wells and Paul Mangan whose bodies have never been found. Harkat was also accused of organising the Indian Airlines hijacking in Afghanistan at Christmas, in which one passenger was stabbed to death. The group denies it was involved.

'We are not terrorists,' said Altaf, crouched on a rug and wearing a camouflage waistcoat over his traditional shalwar kameez clothes. 'This generation will put the last nail in India's coffin. Our companions are fighting in Bosnia and in Chechnya, and we are hopeful Allah will not disappoint us.'

As part of a new offensive the militant groups have begun using 'death squads' or fedayin , Altaf said. Well-armed fighters working alone or in small groups take on heavily fortified Indian positions, with little hope of escaping alive. One militant killed himself and five Indian soldiers when he drove into an Indian army base in Srinagar this month in a car packed with explosives.

Lashker-e-Taiba, another militant group, has led 26 fedayin missions in Kashmir since last summer. Only 14 fighters have returned alive. 'Soon we will start a new round of fighting, it will be very dangerous for India, and it will be the final round,' said Abdullah Muntazer, a spokesman for Lashker. 'India is losing occupied Kashmir and inshallah (God willing) within two to three years we will liberate Kashmir.'

The group runs training camps on the Pakistan side of Kashmir, an area Islamabad calls Azad, or free, Kashmir. For three weeks, recruits are given religious training before taking a three-month course in guerrilla warfare.

New Delhi says its intelligence shows squads of fighters massing on the Pakistan side of Kashmir, preparing for a spring offensive when the mountain snows begin to melt.

More than 10,000 people gathering in Muzaffarabad for a conference on Kashmir heard a strident call to arms from militant commanders and even mainstream religious Pakistani figures like Qazi Hussain Ahmed, head of the powerful Jamaat-i Islami group.

Although President Bill Clinton and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook have pushed for negotiations to end the dispute, there is little sign of a thaw in relations. India and Pakistan have already fought three bloody wars since Partition in 1947, and a year ago the two newly nuclear-armed countries nearly sparked a fourth war in Kashmir's Kargil mountains.

Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, is under pressure from religious organisations and right-wing officers in his own army not to curb the actions of groups like Harkat and Lashker. 'If a man is killed by the Indians in Kashmir, people look on his family with shame unless they go to fight with the mujahideen,' said one senior officer in the elite Northern Light Infantry.

The militants are in no mood for negotiation. 'There is no alternative to the armed struggle,' said Syed Salahuddin, 50-year-old leader of Hezbul Mujahideen. 'Kashmir is paradise on earth, but it has become a hell. Kashmiris have never accepted the Line of Control. It is our Berlin Wall.'

His group's tactics have moved from hit-and-run attacks to 'area domination', where fighters try to take strategic points temporarily in Indian Kashmir as they did during the Kargil conflict last year. Now, he says, the next stage is 'area occupation' in which fighters will take and hold areas in Indian-ruled Kashmir.

Salahuddin, like other militant leaders, wants more support from the Pakistan army. 'Pakistan should intervene militarily,' he insisted. 'Moral support is just not enough.'

Islamabad denies it is funding or training the militants, but gives open political support to the cause. Yet retired army officers do help to train the militants, and India maintains that the military intelligence service, the ISI, is also heavily involved.

'People very deeply feel that Pakistan has been swindled by the Indians and has been cheated as far as Kashmir is concerned. I do not think it is something that is very easy to forget,' said Major-General Rashid Qureshi, who is Pakistan's top military spokesman. 'Nations never sacrifice their national objectives.'

webTitle: Martin trial witnesses 'in campaign of harassment'

fields.headline: Martin trial witnesses 'in campaign of harassment'
fields.trailText: The harassment and intimidation of witnesses and jurors in the Tony Martin trial was part of an orchestrated campaign which began just days after teenage burglar Fred Barras was shot dead at Martin's farm last August, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
The harassment and intimidation of witnesses and jurors in the Tony Martin trial was part of an orchestrated campaign which began just days after teenage burglar Fred Barras was shot dead at Martin's farm last August, The Observer can reveal.

Sources within the gypsy community say that friends and supporters of Barras used contacts to find out information on the whereabouts of potential witnesses as well as of Martin himself.

Following his arrest, the 55-year-old farmer was granted bail on condition that he resided at a police 'safe house'. The travellers were so successful in their attempts to track him down that Martin's bail was revoked after just a week and he was returned to prison 'for his own protection' until a new safe house outside Norfolk could be arranged.

It was the activities of this same group of supporters that led to Martin's first court appearance being transferred at the eleventh hour from King's Lynn to Norwich magistrates court. Police had been tipped off that large numbers of travellers would be attending the hearing.

Threats to burn down Martin's home, Bleak House, have resurfaced since the end of the trial. However, these threats were first made in the days after Martin's arrest. They were taken so seriously that police established a 24-hour guard on the property and installed CCTV cameras and security lighting at a cost of £20,000 per month.

Under gypsy custom, all attacks must be avenged. Although gypsy society has its own system for settling disputes, with punishments ranging from fines to banishment, little is known about the kind of judgments made where the perpetrators of the crimes are non-gypsies.

According to one source, a gypsy court, known as a kris, is believed to have already passed a death sentence on Martin. 'The case was never expected to come to court,' said one source. 'There were those who believed it would have been sorted out long before.' Once it was clear that the trial would go ahead, the supporters of Barras are alleged to have set about intimidating potential defence witnesses. Last week, a statement by a former neighbour of Martin told how he was threatened. 'A car drew up and its occupants shouted: "We'll deal with Tony Martin first and we are coming for you next".

'Living in this area you are at the mercy of the travellers and local villains. I saw three strangers coming across my field late at night. I fired a number of warning shots over their heads and they ran away.'

Another man who shot at burglars caught stealing a safe from his property just three miles from Martin's house said he would appear only if his evidence was heard in camera after he too received threats.

Martin, currently being held in the hospital wing of Bullingdon Prison in Oxfordshire, has been subjected to death threats from a group of travellers within the prison.

fields.headline: Revealed: Loyalists' lethal pipe bomb
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Dissident loyalists have developed a new type of lethal pipe bomb.
fields.body:
Dissident loyalists have developed a new type of lethal pipe bomb.

A bomb destined for a republican commemoration at Castlewellan in South Down on Easter Sunday was the first of the devices, never seen before in Northern Ireland, discovered by the security forces. The pipe bomb, found outside the loyalist village of Clough earlier this month, had been manufactured at a factory in Kilkeel, according to RUC sources.

A senior RUC officer said the device was far more sophisticated than the pipe bombs used in the two-year bombing campaign by the Red Hand Defenders and Orange Volunteers. Their terror campaign came to an abrupt end in November when the RUC arrested scores of dissident loyalists.

'The earlier pipe bombs were designed in such a way that they were an irritant, they broke windows and damaged doors. This bomb was far more lethal,' the RUC officer said.

It is understood the bomb was to be placed near the republican plot in the cemetery at Castlewellan. The plan was foiled when the RUC, acting on intelligence, searched several roads in the week leading up to Easter Sunday. Following the find near Clough, the RUC also discovered a number of other similar pipe bomb devices in the Kilkeel area.

The discovery of the new type of pipe bomb comes as dissident loyalists attempt to re-group in the South Down area. Even though the LVF is officially on ceasefire, many of its cells are pressing for a return to their campaign of sectarian assassination.

LVF units opposed to the ceasefire have targeted nationalist and republican rallies. On St Patrick's Day two pipe bombs were found close to the march route of an Ancient Order of Hibernians parade through Kilkeel.

The latest upsurge in dissident loyalist activity comes amid deepening tensions between the two largest loyalist terrorist groups - the Ulster Defence Association and the Ulster Volunteer Force. The UDA's west Belfast brigade has been giving political support and cover to the Loyalist Volunteer Force in their long-standing feud with the UVF.

LVF leaders have also asked the UDA's west and north Belfast brigades to back them at this year's Drumcree stand-off which dissident loyalists have threatened to turn into a confrontation with the security forces if Portadown Orangemen are again barred from marching down the nationalist Garvaghy Road.

fields.headline: INLA blamed for flats murder
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Irish National Liberation Army was blamed last night for the murder of a 30-year-old man in south Dublin.
fields.body:
The Irish National Liberation Army was blamed last night for the murder of a 30-year-old man in south Dublin.

Patrick Neville was found shot in the head in the stairwell of flats on the St Michael's estate, Inchicore, at around 7.30am.

Gardai believe the murder might have been in retaliation for the death of INLA member Patrick Campbell, who was killed during a fight with criminals last October. Campbell was found with multiple stab wounds on the city's Ballymount estate.

The INLA had vowed to take revenge over Campbell's murder.

Another theory is that the death was linked to a personal vendetta.

Detectives, who are appealing for information about the incident, say the murder bore all the hallmarks of a contract killing.

webTitle: 50,000 jobs at risk as Alchemy gold turns to lead

fields.headline: 50,000 jobs at risk as Alchemy gold turns to lead
fields.trailText: Friday's extraordinary news that Alchemy had terminated negotiations to take on Rover has plunged the West Midlands economy into fresh crisis.
fields.body:
Friday's extraordinary news that Alchemy had terminated negotiations to take on Rover has plunged the West Midlands economy into fresh crisis. Thanks to a high-level poker game where both main players folded, 50,000 jobs could be lost by June.

In high-risk negotiations, both Alchemy and BMW thought they held the aces.

'Alchemy thought they were the only game in town and tried to extract more aid from BMW,' said car industry expert Professor Kumar Bhattcharyya of Warwick University. 'BMW, convinced that the DTI was backing Phoenix, thought that it could use that as a lever to palm off redundancy costs on to Alchemy. Both thought they were negotiating from positions of strength.'

Alchemy's decision to pull its deal when on the point of victory followed a BMW statement which seemed to end the Phoenix bid last Thursday lunchtime. An hour later, the German car maker foisted on to Alchemy 11 new bid conditions. These included financial guarantees to Rover dealers, plus Alchemy taking on pension and redundancy.

'The conditions would have meant Alchemy stumping up hundreds of millions of pounds,' said an Alchemy spokesman. 'At 2.30pm on Thursday, Jon Moulton thought he had a deal. By six, it was dead.' The resulting break-down in talks, say observers, left BMW in tatters. Losing £2 million a day, thanks to its British subsidiary, there is a real likelihood that the Bavarian car giant may shut the Longbridge plant in Birmingham if it cannot find an alternative firm capable of taking it on within its self-imposed 30-day deadline. If this happens, up to 50,000 jobs in the West Midlands could go. Worse still, BMW's reputation in this country would take a severe pounding which could affect sales of its up-market models.

'BMW has already seen its market share drift downwards in Britain since it first announced it was giving Rover away to Alchemy,' said Tony Woodley, of the Transport and General Workers Union. 'If it closed Longbridge, BMW's reputation in this country would never recover.' It seems unlikely that Moulton, Alchemy's abrasive managing partner, will return to the negotiating table with BMW.

If Alchemy is finished, only one man can save Rover. John Towers, a bluff, affable ex-Rover executive, appears to offer the only means by which Rover could survive as a car manufacturer.

The 52-year-old Durham engineering graduate is now embarking on the most important month of his life. His task, which early last week seemed inconceivable, is to raise over £500m needed to keep Rover alive as a mass volume car maker for a year.

While his Phoenix consortium - an alliance of wealthy West Midlands businessmen, venture capitalists, Rover dealerships and unions - have stubbornly refused to detail who will put up the cash for Rover, the consortium has one powerful ally.

Within minutes of the Alchemy news breaking, Towers was in talks with DTI Minister Stephen Byers about raising funds for his consortium, say well-placed sources.

Since BMW announced it was ridding itself of Rover on 16 March, the ultra-Blairite Trade Minister has been accused of failing to heed BMW warnings that the strength of sterling was damaging Rover car sales.

Now in fear of losing his job, Byers's one hope to stop job losses jobs is to facilitate a Towers rescue bid.

'Byers has been incredibly active through all this. He's acting as a facilitator and is doing everything he can to back Phoenix. He has no option,' said a union official. 'Towers is the only game in town and this one-month end-game scenario is concentrating minds like never before.'

However, on Thursday night before the Alchemy announcement, it seemed Byers had backed a loser. A tumultuous week for Byers and Towers began last week when a number of reports wrote off the Phoenix bid as doomed to fail.

The suggestion continued to circulate until last Wednesday when Towers, with Nick Stephenson (the brother of Alex Stephenson, who is heading the government taskforce aiming to minimise job losses), met Werner Samann, the BMW director in charge of Rover, at its Warwickshire headquarters.

They got off to a bad start. Towers exploded at what he thought was 'nit-picking' by Samann and BMW finance director Christian Jon von Freyend, over shareholding stakes in the Phoenix plan.

After this, Towers was told by the Germans that the deadline for him beefing up his business plans with backers would be extended.

Next morning, when an eight-strong Longbridge delegation flew to BMW's Munich headquarters, it seemed Phoenix was winning. Alchemy seemed rattled. A spokesman hinted that it could walk away from a Rover deal if no agreement was reached within the week.

In warm Bavarian sunshine, the Birmingham car workers emerged from a two-hour meeting with top BMW executives, confident that Phoenix would be given more time to get its finances in order. For a few minutes, the Longbridge workers' mood matched the fine weather. Then BMW officials said Phoenix lacked financial muscle and talks would only go ahead with Alchemy.

Everyone thought that Phoenix was burnt out. But the consortium did not consider its bid dead. 'It's not over till the fat lady sings,' said John Hemming, the LibDem councillor and founding member of the consortium, last Thursday evening. 'They haven't ruled out our bid.'

No one listened until Friday morning. Odds are against Phoenix pulling off a deal. But it has seen off its main rival and entered the final round.

A good job John Towers is broad-shouldered, because on his shoulders rest 50,000 jobs - and possibly that of a senior Government Minister too.

webTitle: Three tests will provide three lessons

fields.headline: Three tests will provide three lessons
fields.standfirst:
Thursday's votes will leave both the main parties with a bloody nose, writes Peter Kellner

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Thursday's votes will leave both the main parties with a bloody nose, writes  Peter Kellner
fields.body:
Politicians claim to prefer 'real' votes to 'mere' opinion polls. This week will put that preference to the test. If, as is widely expected, Tony Blair decides to hold the coming general election next May, then Thursday will yield the last big nationwide harvest of 'real' votes in the current Parliament. Three quite separate sets of contests will take place - and they may tell three different stories.

First, London. Few doubt that Ken Livingstone will be the capital's first directly-elected Mayor - indeed, the first person in British political history to win executive office with a personal mandate. Only 33,426 people actually voted for Tony Blair personally in 1997 - and the ballot paper asked them merely who they wanted to represent Sedgefield at Westminster. On Thursday more than one million people will vote directly for Livingstone to run London.

Even if the victor is beyond doubt, plenty remains at stake. The battle for second place is not over. Last week's ICM/ Evening Standard poll showed Steve Norris edging away from Frank Dobson. If Norris does come second, he will claim it as a moral victory over Labour. To make this claim convincing, he needs to score well above his current 17 per cent poll rating. Dobson also needs a late spurt if he is to avoid the humiliation of third or even fourth place. At present, neither main party looks as if it will find real evidence of public popularity in the race for Mayor.

The parallel elections to London's Assembly look at first sight to be more fertile territory for the main parties. However, these contests provide a different kind of hazard. They are being fought under a proportional voting system. Electors will have two votes, one for their 'constituency' (normally a combination of two boroughs), and one for a London-wide list. Any party that wins 5 per cent of the list vote will capture at least one seat.

The Greens' current 7 per cent poll rating would give them two seats. If they repeat their ability in previous elections to win late converts, they could end up with three or four. Not only would this make it easier for Livingstone to claim his likely appointment of the Greens' Darren Johnson as his deputy, it would dent the ability of the main parties to find succour in the Assembly elections. In 1997 Labour won 49 per cent of the vote across London, while the Tories won 31 per cent. Labour is certain to slip well below that figure, while the Tories may end up with even less support than on that terrible May night three years ago.

The Liberal Democrats could have more cause to cheer. Their candidate for Mayor, Susan Kramer, could push Dobson into fourth place; and the latest ICM poll suggests they could win 20 per cent of the vote, and five seats, in the Assembly elections (up from 15 per cent in 1997).

However, Lib-Dem strategists will be looking outside London for their best result on Thursday. Virtually unnoticed by the media, a parliamentary by-election is taking place in Romsey, where the late Conservative MP, Michael Colvin, died in a fire at his home. In 1997 Colvin won a majority of 8,585. There are only 50 safer Tory seats in Britain.

Sandra Gildey could well capture the seat for the Liberal Democrats. In a Test Valley council by-election in the constituency two weeks ago they increased their share of the vote by 23 points, taking support equally from the Tories and Labour. The Lib Dems are using this result to persuade Labour voters to switch tactically to defeat Tim Palmer, the Tory candidate.

If the Tories do lose Romsey, it will not be the first time the main opposition party at Westminster has lost a by-election. Labour lost four during its 18 years in opposition after 1979. It would, however, be the first time the Tories have lost a seat in opposition since David Steel captured Roxburgh, Selkirk and Peebles for the Liberals in 1965. And a year later Labour went on to retain power nationally with an increased majority. Even if the Tories hold Romsey narrowly, the constituency looks as if it will fail to deliver the resounding boost William Hague badly needs.

So there is a real prospect on Thursday that voters will deliver bloody noses to both Blair and Hague in London and Romsey. Can either of them look to council elections in the rest of England for encouragement? More than 3,300 seats are at stake - a quarter of them in big conurbations, a quarter in the new unitary authorities (mainly medium-sized towns and cities) and a half in shire districts.

These seats were last fought in 1996, an exceptionally good year for Labour. Some Labour losses and Conservative gains are inevitable. The Tories should recapture Solihull, and end a five-year period when they have controlled not a single metropolitan council in England. Labour are in danger of losing Bradford and Trafford, once flagship Tory cities, Oldham, where the Lib Dems hope to further dent Labour's northern heartlands, and Doncaster, where the party has been beset by problems with corruption.

Further south, Labour is at risk in Oxford, Milton Keynes and Portsmouth. Meanwhile the Tories hope to take control of other southern councils by capturing seats from the Lib Dems

The parties will be studying the projections from the council results to nationwide vote share. Last year Labour held a narrow 37-34 per cent lead over the Tories, with the Lib Dems on 24 per cent. Since then the Tories have gained some ground both in local by-elections and in nationwide opinion polls (even though the polls still show Labour miles ahead). According to Britain's most assiduous council election-watchers, Colin Rallings and Michael Thrasher of Plymouth University, recent local by-elections point to a nationwide Tory lead of five points, and up to 400 Tory gains on Thursday.

At first sight, that would help Hague fend off any blues from Romsey, but not help the Prime Minister deflect attention from Dobson's likely humiliation in London. However, such an outcome would not make the Tories favourites to win the next general election. For one thing they need a lead of no less than 10 points for an outright majority on a uniform national swing. For another, an increasing number of voters now split their vote between Lib Dem in local elections and Labour in general elections. And, finally, turnouts in local (and last year's European) elections have been pitifully low at 30 per cent or less, with Labour voters especially inclined to stay at home. In a general election, where more than twice as many people will vote, that will change. For the Tories to be frontrunners in the general election, they need a lead of at least 15 points this week. That is almost certainly way beyond their grasp.

Capital gaffes

Ken Livingstone

 Comparing the media coverage of his undeclared income to that of a 'convicted Nazi war criminal living in Britain'.

 Suggesting that the international financial system kills more people every year than Hitler during World War Two.

 Demolishing his image as a cuddly moderate by appearing to offer his support to the anarchists who rampaged through the City last summer.

Frank Dobson

 Raising the hackles of ginger-haired people everywhere, when he said his mother had always told him to 'steer clear of redheads' after broadcaster Chris Evans's donation of £100,000 to the Livingstone campaign.

 Facing the possibility of criminal prosecution for failing to buy himself a £75 licence from the Data Protection Registrar before he wrote a campaigning letter to 68,000 London Labour Party members, prior to his election as the party's mayoral candidate.

 Unsuccessfully trying to force Livingstone into declaring his hand by invoking Dirty Harry's 'make my day' catchphrase.

Steve Norris

 Initially losing the Tory mayoral nomination when a selection panel threw his name out after hearing complaints about his extra-marital affairs.

 Having his open-top bus pulled over by the police for a 'routine' document check, less than an hour before its launch.

 Alienating Asian voters when he declined an offer of a specially recorded broadcast on Asian TV station ZEE TV.

Susan Kramer

 Running out of steam about five minutes into her speech at a Westminster hustings meeting, apologising to her audience for 'losing track'.

 Unnecessarily corny campaign song lyrics: 'Got a pair of Doc Martens on my feet; I got places to go, I got people to meet; I'm moving to the rhythm of the London beat.'

webTitle: Have plants and watering can; will protest

fields.headline: Have plants and watering can; will protest
fields.standfirst: This weekend's May Day festivities are an affirmation of positive action, not an excuse for anarchyMay 2K: special report
fields.trailText: Nothing has given me as much cause for optimism recently as this weekend's May Day 2000 festivities. For the first time, environmental issues are at the heart of widespread popular activity.
fields.body:
Nothing has given me as much cause for optimism recently as this weekend's May Day 2000 festivities. For the first time, environmental issues are at the heart of widespread popular activity. This is a timely rebuff to Westminster politicians who still think only a tiny minority cares about such things and who cynically abandon environmental commitments at the faintest whiff of disapproval from big business.

The activities and protests this weekend will probably be interpreted by conventional politicians and the press in negative terms, especially if trouble flares up. They will use images of anarchists hellbent on destroying property and hurting people. Since November, when plans were first announced, the Metropolitan Police have taken exactly this line, warning people to stay away from what is bound to become a riot. The police reportedly regard this weekend as a 'major challenge', presumably hoping for revenge for what they consider to have been the 'defeat' of the City of London Police last summer.

Some protesters are attracted by the prospect of a showdown with the 'state', but the explicit intentions of this weekend's organisers are very different. It's no accident that these events are taking place on May Day, when the City is empty. And while the organisers often use rhetoric like 'overthrowing capitalism', it's clear they are also drawing in a wide range of ordinary people concerned about quality-of-life issues.

This weekend's events speak volumes about the genuine environmentalism at its heart. On Friday, there was a 'critical- mass' cycle ride around London, which attracted 400 people and was described as good-humoured. Yesterday and today, a large conference, May Day 2000: a Festival of Anti-capitalist Action, has laid on workshops on GM foods, animal rights and the environmental impact of the Serbian war. Tomorrow's Guerrilla Gardening is the central focus of the 'festivities'. After meeting at 11am in Parliament Square, people armed with plants, soil and water will attempt to create a community garden, to show the streets can be reclaimed to promote social and environmental harmony.

This is a far cry from the old ragbag of leftish interests. Indeed, when the usual far-Left groups turned up outside the conference with their leaflets, eager to latch on to any new political movement, the organisers promptly provided special recycling bins for 'unwanted socialist propaganda'. This is a new, distinctive and creative linking of interests. Even as recently as two years ago, issues like motorway protests or animal exports would have produced mutually exclusive protests. Now they are part of something wider, more sophisticated, more holistic. The conference's subjects - multinationals, biotechnology and pollution - show the connection now being made between concern for the environment, for other species and for quality of life and wider concerns about the relentless exigencies of global capitalism.

This may smack of youthful idealism, but for those of us who have long been involved in environmental campaigns, much of this is already familiar and hardly frightening. Reclaim the Streets's Guerrilla Gardening is a tactic already used successfully in anti-motorway and anti-car protests. There's a critical-mass cycle ride organised one Friday every month by supporters of the Environmental Transport Association, which most decent citizens belong to as an alternative to the pro-road lobbies of the AA and the RAC. It is active Christians, not anarchists, who have spearheaded the most effective anti-IMF protests, Jubilee 2000's cancel-the-debt campaigns.

However the press, politicians and police try to cut it, these groups are far from extreme. Their dissatisfactions are the same as those of many ordinary peo ple: the way cars have been allowed to undermine communities and destroy the environment; the need for sustainable forms of transport like cycling; the need to live harmoniously with other species; the need not to exploit Third World countries. Until now, these concerns have been separate from one another, so Westminster politicians were easily swayed by the potent and organised lobbies of big business and the international financial institutions.

Now though, these causes are not just being linked theoretically. The Internet is also providing literal links, making it possible to inform and organise activities globally. There are similar events across the UK and the world this weekend and they are on a continuum with the big Seattle and Washington protests. This is changing everything. Using conventional and new media for actions that are creative and symbolic at the same time, groups like Reclaim the Streets are transcending spontaneous action and articulating a vision of a new future. Orthodox political parties, with their declining membership and inability to communicate with the young, have every reason to feel challenged.

This may smack of youthful idealism, but for those of us who have long been involved in environmental campaigns, much of this is already familiar and hardly frightening. Reclaim the Streets's Guerrilla Gardening is a tactic already used successfully in anti-motorway and anti-car protests. There's a critical-mass cycle ride organised one Friday every month by supporters of the Environmental Transport Association, which most decent citizens belong to as an alternative to the pro-road lobbies of the AA and the RAC. Using conventional and new media for actions that are creative and symbolic at the same time, groups like Reclaim the Streets are transcending spontaneous action and articulating a vision of a new future. Orthodox political parties, with their declining membership and inability to communicate with the young, have every reason to feel challenged.

fields.headline: Labour steeled for poll defeats
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is bracing himself for a 'black Thursday' political disaster this week as Labour faces hundreds of losses in the local council elections and defeat in the race for the Mayor of London.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is bracing himself for a 'black Thursday' political disaster this week as Labour faces hundreds of losses in the local council elections and defeat in the race for the Mayor of London.

Labour Party officials are concerned that an embarrassingly low turnout will reveal deep-seated problems of apathy and disillusion among its core supporters.

Party analysis of recent council by-elections revealed turnouts as low as 6 per cent on Merseyside and in South Yorkshire, both supposed Labour heartlands. Inner-city areas have average turnouts of 15 per cent, while elections in the more Tory-friendly shire seats average 35 per cent.

Officials have highlighted this 'support differential' as one of Labour's major problems. Labour believes it could lose up to 500 seats to the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats. The last time the same seats were contested was in 1996 when Labour was running at record highs in the polls and turnout was healthier.

Meanwhile, Labour sources admit that Ken Livingstone now looks unstoppable in his bid to be London Mayor. In a last throw of the dice, Frank Dobson, the official Labour candidate, has used a new e-mailing scheme to try to drum up support.

Blair has yet to decide how he will respond to a Livingstone victory.

Although he is likely to meet Livingstone on Friday if he wins, the Prime Minister has been advised to steer clear of photo-opportunities outside Number 10.

He has also yet to decide on what might be offered to Dobson, who sacrificed a Cabinet post to run for Mayor. 'You cannot imagine Tony allowing him to languish in the wilderness,' one source said.

Meanwhile Livingstone, who has been discussing with key aides possibilities for his mayoral cabinet, distanced himself from anti-capitalism protesters who are planning a series of demonstrations across the country tomorrow.

His condemnation on the Today programme of 'a small core who will try and cause violence' was in contrast to a magazine interview earlier this year, when he appeared to support the protesters against the World Trade Organisation in Seattle.

fields.headline: Blair's birthday blues
fields.standfirst:
On the anniversary of its election win, the Government is under the cosh as never before. Kamal Ahmed, Political Editor, asks how will it cope in a crisis

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: On the anniversary of its election win, the Government is under the cosh as never before.  Kamal Ahmed,  Political Editor, asks how will it cope in a crisis
fields.body:
In 1996 a politician, much younger, less battered, less bruised than he is today, wrote a book called New Britain, My Vision of a Young Country . 'It is time to sweep away the quango state, to take power back from big government and share it with the people,' the writer said. 'London will have its own elected mayor.'

Tony Blair's book set the tone for the Government he was about to lead. Bright, young, modern, confident, effective. These were the buzz words. Life in New Britain was going to be different. Of course it was.

Blair is four years older now. Four years more bruised. Four years more battered. On Thursday he will almost certainly see his nemesis, Ken Livingstone, win one of the most powerful political posts in Britain - that of Mayor of London. Blair can never have thought, in the sunny uplands of 1996, that it would come to this.

On the same day, Blair will see hundreds of Labour councillors across the country lose their seats. In many wards the turnout will be miserable because the party cannot get its vote out. In recent council by-elections on Merseyside and in South Yorkshire, the turnout has been as low as 6 per cent.

On Tuesday, Blair will again grapple with the stalled mess that is Northern Ireland, meeting Bertie Ahern, the Irish Prime Minister. By next Friday, BMW could have pulled every last lock, stock and barrel from the Rover plant in the West Midlands. Labour councillors in the region are likely to be punished more harshly than most.

This week will also see one of the biggest backbench rebellions of this Government. Up to 50 Labour MPs are set to walk through the No lobby, to show what they think of John Prescott's plans for the partial privatisation of air traffic control centres.

And, for relaxation, next weekend Blair can sit down and watch two programmes on Channel 4 that will not cheer him up at all. The Mo Mowlam Story, which will once again rake over all the problems of her sacking as Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, and You the Jury, on Labour's perceived failure to put through its programme for building a modern, fair Britain.

The case for the prosecution will be led by Labour MP Diane Abbott. Peter Kilfoyle MP, the rebel former Minister who says he speaks for Labour's heartlands, will be a key witness.

Much has been made of Blair's apology, in The Observer three weeks ago, over his treatment of the leader of the Welsh Assembly, Rhodri Morgan. He has also expressed regrets over his failure to appoint Paddy Ashdown to the Cabinet and has talked of his restlessness at the pace of change.

Britain's parliament and government is not yet the modern example to the world Blair wanted, the party's own private focus group work reveals that women in particular are increasingly dissatisfied with progress. And in three weeks his wife, Cherie, is due to have their fourth child, throwing all these problems into the sharp relief of fatherhood.

The prime minister is at his country retreat, Chequers, this weekend. Tomorrow sees the third birthday of the Labour Government. There will be no celebrations. Blair finds himself in an odd world. Support for his Government is as high as anyone could reasonably expect three years into a term of office.

The most recent Mori poll may have revealed that his personal ratings across a whole range of indicators (capable leader, understands Britain's problems, is not out of touch with ordinary people) are markedly down, but only because of the stratospheric highs Blair achieved in 1997.

Blair's administration has reduced unemployment, cut youth unemployment, launched the Working Families Tax Credit, introduced the minimum wage, brought in substantial increases in child benefit, limited the working week, put billions of pounds into health and education and pushed through the most radical constitutional changes this country has seen for a century. Oh yes, and Gordon Brown presides over a stronger economy than anyone would have thought possible.

It could also be said that, whatever Thursday's results, they will reveal that the tradition of voting locally for the Government's opponents is alive and well.

'If you had said to any of our supporters that we would be in this position three years into a government, they would have been very pleased - no, not pleased, they wouldn't have believed you,' said a senior Labour backbencher. 'But expectations were so high, so high. It is difficult for some people not to feel disappointed.'

So, there is the criticism about the heartlands. So, there is the criticism about freedom of information and pensions and class sizes and air traffic control ('even though Labour learnt long ago that privatisation has nothing to do with safety,' the backbencher said). So, there is concern about control freakery and centralisation and Tony's cronies packing out the House of Lords.

Among all the issues cramming Blair's in-tray, Livingstone is the major irritant. In discussions between the Labour Party and Downing Street, party officials have said Blair should refuse photo-opportunities with Livingstone if he triumphs on Thursday.

'We don't want pictures of him grinning with Tony outside Number 10,' one official said. 'What kind of message will that send if Livingstone's made a mess of it in six months?'

Labour Party sources said Blair would speak about London's verdict on Friday and take a carefully conciliatory line. 'It's up to Livingstone,' the official said. 'If he wants to play it sensible, then that's fine by us, but if he wants to make a mess of it then we are not going to help.' Labour sources said Blair was ready to take 'a short-term hit' on Livingstone, but was convinced that, if Citizen Ken is the man he thinks he is, the electorate will vote him out in four years' time.

But there is a bigger issue here. It has long been a central tenet of New Labour that elections cannot be won from the Left. Blair fought to drag the party to the centre, believing it the only way forward. Livingstone is turning that theory on its head and his victory, if it comes, will strengthen the hand of those within government more comfortable with Old Labour: Gordon Brown, Robin Cook, Clare Short and Peter Hain. Expect more of the language of radicalism in frontbench speeches: help for the poor, the disadvantaged, the dispossessed.

The approach to Livingstone - humbler, more willing to listen and accept - is part of a wider move to reposition the Government and the party. In an attempt to defuse some of the sense of expectation, and show Labour does not believe its success should be taken for granted, officials meeting at party headquarters at Millbank in London have decided on a less grandiose approach.

This is no longer the Government throwing down spectacular statements from atop Mount Olympus. No, this is the Government next door, the Government you can share a pint with, hey, y'know, just doing its best.

The local election slogan is a lot done, a lot to do. To this will be added a lot to lose, as the party tries to convince the voters that the Conservatives are still out there, somewhere. But even the Tories, as a leaked memo revealed two weeks ago, don't believe they will win the next election. In her foreword to a magazine celebrating the Labour Party's centenary, general secretary Margaret McDonagh talks of a third term. At meetings of the Parliamentary Party, discussion centres on strategy stretching forward five, 10, 15 years. 'We shouldn't focus on the potholes in front of us,' one backbencher said. 'Otherwise we'll miss the smooth road further ahead.' Everyone thinks Labour is here for the foreseeable future. Except Blair.

'One of our major problems is that no one believes there is an Opposition,' a Downing Street official said. Many Labour campaigners are secretly pleased that William Hague seems at last to have hit a few right-wing home runs with his speeches on asylum and Tony Martin. 'They are campaigning well now,' one Millbank strategist said. 'It is effective for their core voters and shows how much distance there is between the two parties.'

As part of the 'step by step Britain is getting better' policy, Blair has wandered into the world of apology. There was Rhodri Morgan. Then, a week before, in an interview with his friend and confidant, Robert Harris, in America's Talk magazine, Blair said maybe he had been 'too scarred' by the Labour Party of the 1980s to realise that, when in power, he didn't need to control everything all of the time.

He also said he regretted that his major project, an accommodation with former Liberal Democrat leader Paddy Ashdown, a man he respects, had never happened. Maybe he should have been stronger, he said, and put Ashdown in the Cabinet in the days Blair could walk on water.

How far away that grand coalition, that big idea, appears now. Yesterday the present Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, produced a 30-page document to mark the Government's third anniversary, claiming it had failed on a plethora of policy commitments.

On education, the Liberal Democrats said, most children were in bigger class sizes than they were three years ago; education spending as a proportion of national income had fallen; taxes had risen; the strong pound was wrecking manufacturing industry; crime was still rising ...

'Many of the Government's problems have stemmed from their determination to out-Tory the Tories by adopting Conservative spending plans or Tory-style policies,' Kennedy wrote. 'Where in Labour's manifesto did they pledge to cut income tax during a time of crisis in our essential public services? Many people who voted Labour will be disappointed now.' Kennedy has privately said he is less keen than his predecessor on any accommodation with the Government.

Blair wanted to be the man remembered for launching a new style of politics, an approach where all right-thinking people could agree on the way forward and implementation would be a matter of efficient and committed management. Now he surveys a scene where business leaders, angered by the strong pound and what they see as increasing regulation, say the honeymoon is over; transport union leader Bill Morris attacks the Government for being racist; and the voters worry about the failing NHS.

Senior Labour sources said last week Blair had told Ministers not to get bogged down in the detail of micro-managing their departments. They had to get back the focus, get away from the sense of drift.

One man, conspicuous by his absence on the political tub-thumping circuit, a Labour official said, was a certain Stephen Byers.

But that, at the moment, is the least of the Prime Minister's problems.

fields.headline: Our shotgun politicians
fields.standfirst: Tony Martin murder case: special report
fields.trailText: The most striking thing about the reaction to Martin's life sentence for murder is the symmetry between the Tories' cynical exploitation of the issue and the political excuses made for paramilitary terror here.
fields.body:
'There's no faith in the police in our community.' 'A policing vacuum exists.' 'The community demands real justice.' 'Vigilantism is a dirty word, but if the police won't do their job...'

The above comments sound like they should have come from the Falls or Shankill Road, or possibly the editorial page of Ireland's Andersonstown News. They are the cheap mantras trotted out in defence of paramilitary 'justice' in Northern Ireland, arguments used to justify the IRA and loyalist beatings, shootings and mutilations.

But the comments paraphrase political outbursts from the mouths of British Conservatives, including William Hague, in response to the jailing of the Norfolk farmer and shotgun totting good old boy, Tony Martin. The last of them is actually a direct quote from Thursday's leader in the Daily Telegraph. Indeed, the most striking thing about the reaction to Martin's life sentence for murder is the symmetry between the Tories' cynical exploitation of the issue and the political excuses made for paramilitary terror here.

At the beginning of 1999 the IRA and loyalists were engaged in serial beatings and maimings culminating in the UVF's horrific crippling of Andrew Peden. It was none other than the Tories' Northern Ireland Spokesman, Andrew Mackay, who led the charge in the House of Commons against what he claimed was the Labour Government's 'Nelsonian attitude' to the savagery, ignoring what Mackay argued were blatant breaches of the ceasefires.

The Tories, alongside David Trimble's Ulster Unionists, accused the Blair administration of allowing deprived loyalist and republican areas to fall under the rule of lynch law. Mackay and the Conservatives also backed local human rights campaigners, fighting to highlight the paramilitary expulsion of hundreds of alleged young criminals from Northern Ireland, many with records as long as that of the young man Martin shot dead.

But now it seems the Tories are adopting the same rationale spouted by the likes of Sinn Fein... that in some way the criminal justice system should be predicated on what the community wants rather than what is actually just and fair, ignoring the fact that the justice system takes law out of the hands of a populist lottery and acts as an alternative to communal witch-hunts and vendettas.

There is further hypocrisy: for decades successive Tory Secretaries of State resisted calls by civil liberties groups to change the law on how to prosecute soldiers and policemen involved in killing unarmed civilians. Even today a British soldier charged with shooting, say, a teenage joyrider can only be found guilty of murder or declared innocent. He or she cannot be charged with manslaughter, which would rightly put more soldiers behind bars. And yet the Tories now want the law changed, from murder to manslaughter, for shotgun farmers who blow away burglars.

The Left, particularly in Britain, though should not get too smug, however. After all, why is it that leftists in the Labour Party and the media howl over the hero worship of an individual vigilante like Martin but have no problem sharing platforms with republicans who excuse, support, in some cases organise the same kind of vigilantism on a grand scale in Ireland? The parallels between the knee-jerk emotions whipped up by the Tories in the Martin affair and the macho populism behind headlines in the Andersonstown News, such as 'IRA back on the beat', should be a warning to leftist sympathisers of republicanism as to who they are really getting into bed with. Not so much latter-day Che Guevara, rather secular Christian Brothers wielding the strap on the unruly ruffians in their community.

The Tories and the Belfast baseball gangs certainly make strange bedfellows, but the sub-fascistic logic of vigilantism, whether in Norfolk or North Belfast, shows that they have more in common than you think.

fields.headline: The gospel according to Wee Willie
fields.standfirst: He might sound increasingly like an American revivalist preacher, but can William Hague lead his disciples out of the wilderness?Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: He might sound increasingly like an American revivalist preacher, but can William Hague lead his disciples out of the wilderness?
fields.body:
Enough of 'listening to Britain'. The leader of the Opposition has decided to speak for England. The ideal Tory voter, seen from Smith Square, hoves into view. Mr Hague's main man is a fox-hunting, homophobic supporter of the hereditary principle and Pinochet. Here he stands, he can do no other.

Out there on the central European plains, hordes of Kosovars and a flood of Albanians are preparing to invade his boarded-up castle. Tapping his brogues impatiently, fear runs like a coarse thread through his tweed suit. In one hand, he clutches Blackstone's Commentaries on the Laws of England with their encouraging eighteenth-century counsel on murder as self-defence. In the other, there's an illegal shotgun. These are the newly defined heartlands and Mr Hague is taking no hostages.

Tories are now easily parodied as subjects for care in the wider, national community. But the reactionary platitudes of the Hague winter and spring speeches are self-conscious. Mr Hague's illiberal rants are designed to encourage liberal ones. He is happy to be parodied and gives every sign of enjoying himself. On asylum-seekers, Section 28, Lords reform, tax reduction, an embarrassment of riches for satirical treatment now supplement the original, meagre Tory diet of Europhobia.

To dignify these reactions as serious 'policies' is to miss the point. More interestingly, we are dealing here with the internal neuroses of the Conservative Party and the tactics of a party leader who is determined to survive beyond the next election. William Hague's is the loneliness of the long-distance leader.

He has travelled some distance from that talk of 1997 about a more 'tolerant' and 'inclusive' party. The hollowness was soon apparent. Lady Thatcher promising Franciscan peace and Mr Major invoking a nation at ease with itself show Tory leadership form on these aspirational canters around the course. The Hague party of 1997-9 first defined itself around a central doctrine of anti-European dogmatism as a single-issue party.

From the European elections of 1999, Hague Tories drew the conclusion that there was a core vote of some 20 to 25 per cent which always wanted to vote Tory and had to be given reasons for doing so. Variously defined now according to taste as 'unpleasant' or revolutionary in a common-sensical way, they are the chosen ballast in the years ahead.

Internal constitutional reform in 1997-8 helped Hague. The new leader made himself the most secure party leader in Tory history by making it more difficult for a challenger to emerge. The killer stroke was to make the final ballot one which was open to all party members. The Major years had shown that loyalism and sycophancy were more powerful than treachery and knavery when push came to shove. Like some pocket Augustus, the Tory leader had concentrated power while preserving a façade of constitutional propriety.

It's an important function of a party of the Centre-Right that it should contain some very nasty people. They need to be given the occasional bit of red meat in case they break the constitutional ranks and create trouble on their own. This is dirty, appeasing work but someone has to do it, otherwise we are all losers. The result has been some interesting twentieth-century Tory tensions between liberal leaders and illiberal followers.

Churchill, Macmillan and Heath, Butler, Macleod and Heseltine - all in different ways show that suspicion of the Tory party is not confined to those who vote against it. In this respect, these lights of Toryism were all witnesses to the difficulties of congenital anti-socialists after the death of the Liberal Party in the 1920s. Needing a political party, they had to make do with what was on offer. The result was the awkward Tory alliance between prejudice and Whiggery.

Margaret Thatcher was the first modern Tory leader actually to like her own party. To her original fusion of greed and nationalism, an additional element has been added by Mr Hague: fear. He is not fearful of losing the next general election because he knows he has not a prayer in that direction. But, knowing that most leaders are allowed two bites at that particular cherry, he will be happy with even a modest Tory advance in 2001-2.

We are in a period when economic issues have ceased to be the great dividing line in modern politics. The collapse of the traditional two-party tribalism of capital and labour was an initial Tory difficulty in the late 1990s. Europe as a threat seemed attractive because it was the only great issue left which could divide allegiances, win friends and make enemies. But Europe was not enough, especially as the prospect of a referendum receded. Hence the contrivance of social scare, Hague's very own Back-to-Basics.

The transformation of the Tory party at a senior level now seems complete. It is one in which the Tory Left has been largely complicit. It was a crucial insight of Mrs Thatcher's that Tory wets really were wet. The idea that they were public schoolboys who didn't know how to treat a woman is one of the sillier mythologies. The Tory party is an organisation of natural office-holders and Tory wets proved themselves truly Tory in the determination to cling on to their jobs.

Sometimes, when Tory wets grow up, they become 'big beasts'. But these clichéd figures are beasts who neither bark nor bite. Kenneth Clarke went silent in the run up to the European elections lest he be accused of disloyalty. Anticipating an electoral rout which might be to his advantage, he survives only to rue the silence. Mr Clarke is the senior Trappist of the Tory Left.

Michael Heseltine, announcing his retirement, chooses to endorse his leader's asylum policy with some vicious twists of his own and proposes that the right to asylum be determined in the country of origin. If the Tory Left has vanished, it is because it lacks conviction as well as convictions. Its pro-Europeanism lacked imagination, being an affair of the counting house rather than of strategic vision or political opportu nity. Europe - 'open for business' - was about as far as it went. Once the economic arguments started to go Eurosceptic or Euroflaccid, Tory Europeans could only respond with banality about half of our trade going to 'Europe'

The Tory tone is increasingly that of the American Right. William Hague has an opaque theology but looked at home addressing Christian evangelicals recently at a Butlin's holiday camp. The revivalist, beleaguered tone recalled Pat Buchanan's rallies. Can it be long before Mr Hague discovers that there are votes in protectionism and attacks Labour as the party of uncaring capitalism?

In another light, the Tories can look a very European party. The Europe, that is, of Haïder rather than of Adenauer. Disraeli and Peel revitalised the corpse of a dead party and separated it from the Throne and Altar associations of reactionary conservatism. It looks as if Mr Hague's historic achievement will be to return the Tories to their condition before the 1832 Reform Act as they reclined in the last ditch which proved to be their grave. Perhaps his next policy initiative will be the repeal of the Catholic Emancipation Act? While we're about it, isn't there something compelling about the Divine Right of Kings?

 A former adviser to John Redwood, Hywell William's book, Guilty Men: Conservative Decline and Fall 1992-1997, is published by Aurum Press, £19.95.
