webTitle: Put the plural back into politics

fields.headline: Put the plural back into politics
fields.standfirst: If this week's elections show anything, it is that single local issues matter to people as much as, maybe more than, macroeconomicsSpecial report: Elections 2000
fields.trailText: If this week's elections show anything, it is that single local issues matter to people as much as, maybe more than, macroeconomics.
fields.body:
What is the plural of 'politics'? Politicses? Certainly, this spring, we have more than one. We have the old politics of the Treasury spending round, the Commons questions, the green papers and green leather benches. But we also have London politics, which feels entirely different; and Scottish and Welsh politics, different again. And this is only the beginning. Our traditional sense of a singular national political conversation is being shaken to bits. We all live in Britain. But politically, many of us live in the scattered provinces of post-Britain, too.

Ask, for instance, where Ken Livingstone's magic resides? To the old political establishment - which includes white, middle-aged professional commentators like me - it is trivial, baffling, even silly. He was never taken seriously at Westminster, his economic views could better be described as populist-anarchist than socialist and his 'campaign' has been mostly silence, punctuated by gaffes. And - here's the point - none of it has mattered . He has been more popular than free champagne.

Nor has it been because Ken himself is so obviously hip. Here, after all, is a man who dresses like a British Home Stores accounts controller; whose musical tastes veer to Ennio Morricone, the Mamas and the Papas, Love and Blur; who quotes Churchill on why politicians should be respected; and who sounds about as enthusiastic about drugs as Jack Straw. It doesn't matter. The cool, the arty, the young, can't get enough of him. Livingstone's nasal whine has become the capital's aphrodisiac.

There are some simple explanations for this. First, there is enough desperation about the state of the capital's transport for people to hope that the most aggressive pro-bus and pro-Tube man might actually get something done. Second, there is a long tradition of using local elections to warn national government not to swank. If Britain has no balancing of powers in some great scroll of a constitution, with seals and ribbons dripping off it, then let us try to even things up a bit informally, through the ballot box. Blair's constitutional reform has given voters extra opportunities for doing exactly that: he bared his own back. Then his demonising of Livingstone told Londoners clearly who was the best opposition instrument available. Hit me with Ken, he said, and they will.

But there is a bigger story too. Livingstone is not merely the passive instrument of mid-term critics of Tony Blair. He is also successful because he has personified a strand of populism that's miles away from New Labour. His emphasis on anti-racism, sexual and gender equality, environmentalism and open government plays very well in London, the most liberal, diverse and youthful electorate in the country. His sardonic wit and outbreaks of passion typify how Londoners like to imagine themselves - lippy, rebellious, well-informed. People don't, in my experience, quote his policies when they say why they'll vote for him. They say they just sort-of like him. And it's no good saying that such vague, inarticulate support is meaningless. It's enough to spur huge numbers of people to vote.

It is almost as if Ken's a lifestyle choice. The more, this week, I pondered the mystery of his dizzying, energetic egoism the more he reminded me not of any other politician, but of Walt Whitman. He sings and celebrates himself, he loafs and invites his soul. He sounds his barbaric yawp over the roofs. Does he contradict himself? Very well, he contradicts himself. He is large, he contains multitudes. 'I guess it must be the flag of my disposition, out of the hopeful green stuff woven.'

The occasional irresponsible asides, in short, are thought-through messages to voters who are bored of the pompous predictability of politics. The sense of slight danger, of unexpectedness, is what they are buying into. Westminster loathes and isolates this maverick charm, as Livingstone found during his time in exile there. It's a strange thought, that a Londoner can feel exiled on the banks of the tidal Thames, but so it is: Westminster politics marches to a different beat, far more culturally conservative, serious and cautious, looking instinctively to the Daily Mail and the haze of Middle England where so many marginal constituencies are located. New Labour's style and instincts, its ferocious respectability, its middle-brow, family-values aesthetic, have been very successful in the Westminster-politics context. In the London context, they seem to have proved disastrous - elderly, control-freakish, patronising.

This does not mean that national politics is about to change. Livingstone will always be an implausible prime ministerial candidate. He would not work outside his chosen metropolitan, progressive territory any more than Tony Blair's more conventional, ideal-family image is winning new converts today inside it.

Nor does Livingstone's success in London herald a new dawn for social liberalism in Britain. Far from it: other examples of the new populism are hurtling in just the other direction - think of the Clause 28 supporters in Scotland, for instance, challenging the establishment with a privately-funded referendum to keep homosexuals in their place; or the fierce current of support for William Hague on the self-defence issue in the English countryside, whatever the distaste of liberal Westminster. Progressive and conservative populism can coexist in the same places and parties, even in the same people. (Think of Steve Norris, liberal on race and sex, but also a keen hanger.)

At times this new mood in Britain feels more like American politics, with its raw libertarian urges, its competing ethnic, moral and religious interest groups, its prickly localism. What we have, as I suggested, is less a single national British argument, the dialectical debate of a state, but 'politicses', a hubbub of simultaneous conversations.

Are there longer-term lessons to be drawn by Blair as he strains to make himself heard? He seems to have learned some already, admitting mistakes over Rhodri Morgan and Scotland. This humbler, more relaxed Blair will probably have to deal with Ken's triumph in tones of mild good humour - though that may be more than flesh and blood can stand. He knows that it tells us almost nothing about the next general election. Indeed, in the new fluid politics, for many people, voting Green, Tory, Lib-Dem or independent at local level may be a precondition for backing Labour nationally in a year's time. Nor does it look as if Mayor Livingstone will necessarily shift non-metropolitans against Labour. He is, after all, now outside the party.

The harder thing for Blair to ponder is the rise of local populist agendas. For if this strange spring shows anything, it's that the familiar Westminster agenda - the cost of living, the size of the state, trade unionism, the future of the nation, defence, income taxes - which dominated in the final quarter of the twentieth century, is no longer the only game in town. For many voters, from Ayr in Scotland to London's Soho, Clause 28 supporters and Ken supporters, other things now matter more - the issues left behind after ideology has withered.

New Labour has not proved adroit at the new populism - on sexuality, drugs, fox hunting it has found none of the self-confidence it can boast about on macro-economics. It never realised it mattered so much. It never spent the time and effort on arguing through its positions. And probably this is an area where national government will have to accept less coherence and impose less discipline. If it is to be large, it will have to contain multitudes. In a more varied and edgy country, a single style of Minister becomes a handicap - which is why Blair's failure to find a way for Mo Mowlam to function happily at the heart of New Labour has been more serious than perhaps it looks.

The crucial thing, though, is to educate the country about the new hierarchy of power, so that national government gets on with, and is judged by, the macro-issues that are its proper business, and is not used as the whipping-boy and final court of appeal for every private prejudice and local grievance. We have the forms and the elections of a more devolved, less centralised state. Soon we will have the new leaders of one too. These are reforms that should have happened 100 years ago. What we don't have, yet, is the habit of all this. We don't have a plural for politics.

fields.headline: A sacrificial lamb with bite
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Perhaps the mayoral election is genuinely a national story because it involves the soul of Labour. Yet other struggles, perhaps more painful and intense, have been treated with almost complete indifference by the national media.
fields.body:
The local political boss has usually attracted little attention outside his own civic boundaries except, as we now see, in the case of the London mayor.

Ken Livingstone is a household name although he, and the assembly he will head, will have little power. Perhaps the mayoral election is genuinely a national story because it involves the soul of Labour. Yet other struggles, perhaps more painful and intense, have been treated with almost complete indifference by the national media.

New Labour calculated it could chop down Pat Lally as Lord Provost of Glasgow out of the glare of national media interest. He was an obscure victim of New Labour's control freakery but his ordeal was extreme. He was supposed to be a sacrificial lamb for modernisers anxious to bury Labour's reputation for feather-bedding at best and corruption at worst in the municipal politics of Central Scotland.

What Lally's tormentors did not bargain for was his exceptional resilience. He had an extraordinary capacity to take punishment and come up smiling, hence his nickname of Lazarus. His memoirs*, written with Neil Baxter, are lively, couthy, occasionally impassioned and, inevitably, an apologia pro vita sua.

Yet they burn with an anger that is sincere and largely convincing. New Labour gave him a Kafka-esque trial. His persecutors, headed, as he recounts, by Jack McConnell, then the secretary of the party in Scotland and now Finance Minister in the Executive, planted unattributed leaks in compliant newspapers in order to discredit him. His persecution enjoyed the tacit endorsement of Donald Dewar who, along with his long-time civic rival Jean McFadden, emerges as a villain of the tale.

In the end, he was able to turn for protection to the courts which held that he had been treated unfairly and that the evidence against him was unsubstantiated. He found many of his allies in unexpected quarters, among the gallant ragtag band of Glasgow municipal Tories and in the city's business community.

Another bone he chews on is the question of who should take the credit for the strategy to revive Glasgow. He elegantly knifes Sir Michael Kelly, one of his predecessors as Lord Provost, whom he accuses of having stolen the authorship of the 'Glasgow's Miles Better' campaign from advertising man John Struthers. This stricture would have been more convincing if Lally could have found it in him to acknowledge Kelly's own undoubted contribution to Glasgow's resurgence. If the memoirs have a fault, it is their reluctance to forgive or to admit the importance of others .

Yet despite their essentially partisan thrust, they reflect a genuine civic patriotism. Lally's account of his formative years in the Gorbals and the drapery trade are touching, wry and, yes, pawky.

The verdict on Lally may be that he was not entirely without sin. He was a ruthless civic boss who used patronage as a form of control but not corruptly. His sins were no worse than those of the Westminster whips. His struggles were not unavailing. In the last few weeks, I have been lucky enough to attend the series of Bach concerts given at the Royal International Concert Hall by Murray Perahia and the Academy of St Martin in the Fields. The music was magnificent; so too the hall. No doubt many hands were in its making.

New Labour calculated it could chop down Pat Lally as Lord Provost of Glasgow out of the glare of national media interest. webTitle: Time to be patient for all our sakes

fields.headline: Time to be patient for all our sakes
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: It has been another difficult week for Donald Dewar and the Scottish Executive but much of the instability that commentators perceive is more imagined than real. The Scottish Parliament has come through a difficult first year in which it has been harried by a hyperventilating Scottish press which has fastened ravenously on to every minor hint of turbulence.
fields.body:
It has been another difficult week for Donald Dewar and the Scottish Executive but much of the instability that commentators perceive is more imagined than real. The Scottish Parliament has come through a difficult first year in which it has been harried by a hyperventilating Scottish press which has fastened ravenously on to every minor hint of turbulence.

The real work of a Parliament is not particularly glamorous; it is largely worthy and dull. It is not just at Holyrood that the press ignores substantive issues in favour of the more ephemeral. And there is a new army of hungry political journalists who must feed their editors a diet of conflict and dissonance.

Even so, the response to the news that Dewar must undergo a heart operation has been grotesque even by recent standards. Some have tried prematurely to open a war of succession. And there has been some muttering that Jim Wallace, because he is a Liberal Democrat, has no right to lead the coalition in Dewar's absence. Yet only a prolonged illness would justify such a view.

Wallace had an unhappy passage in the Parliament last week. Yet his work has by no means been worthless.

As Justice Minister he is introducing a substantial and necessary change in the method of judicial appointments.

It would be naive to expect this to whip up much excitement in the tabloids. But the Parliament should take comfort from a year of steady improvement. It is growing up fast. And the correct response to the First Minister's health is to wish him a speedy recovery and, for the moment, to leave it at that.

webTitle: Mugabe's thugs kill five more opponents

fields.headline: Mugabe's thugs kill five more opponents
fields.standfirst: Business leaders and the press are targeted as violent intimidation spreads across Zimbabwe's society
fields.trailText: Political violence intensified in Zimbabwe yesterday with the news that five opposition supporters were beaten to death by President Robert Mugabe's supporters in the resort town of Kariba.
fields.body:
Political violence intensified in Zimbabwe yesterday with the news that five opposition supporters were beaten to death by President Robert Mugabe's supporters in the resort town of Kariba.

The deaths are the latest in a series of lethal acts of political intimidation in which 14 opposition members have been killed by Mugabe's backers in the past month.

White farmers, black peasants and upwardly mobile young black professionals have all been targeted by Mugabe's ruling party, Zanu-PF, to frighten them from supporting the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

In most of the killings Zimbabwe's police have not taken any action, either to stop violence as it is taking place or to investigate the murders and other crimes that have been committed.

The details of the Kariba killings are chilling. Comrade Rex Jesus, a notorious leader of the war veterans who support Mugabe, arrived in Kariba, which is on the shores of Lake Kariba, because of reports that the MDC had a great deal of visible support. He reportedly had orders to stamp it out. Jesus had already carried out a campaign of intimidation in the farming town of Karoi.

With a band of more than 30 men, Jesus abducted MDC members Luckson Kanyurira, Nicholas Chatitima and three others from their workplaces on Tuesday and beat them for three hours at Banana Charara farm, according to accounts from local residents. He then paraded the bloodied five before residents of Kariba's Nyamunga township. Kanyurira collapsed and died on the spot. Chatitima died in hospital and two others are in critical condition with broken arms and legs and head injuries.

In two other incidents in Kariba, Jesus rounded up 30 farm workers and 20 Nyamunga township residents and beat and tortured them. Three are now presumed dead, according to local doctors.

Horrified Kariba residents demanded that police take action and Jesus and 15 others were arrested and charged on Friday with two murders and public violence. The disappearances of the three others are being investigated.

In addition to the intimidation of black supporters of the opposition, Mugabe's supporters have apparently subdued the country's white farmers and their labourers. Across the country, Zanu-PF officials are holding rallies with white farmers and their workers. The war veterans and ruling party officials tell the white farmers in no uncertain terms that if they want to continue farming they must drop all support for the MDC or any other opposition party.

'You white farmers must make a decision,' said Comrade Koche, the local leader of the war veterans at a rally in Goromonzi, 20 miles east of Harare on Friday. 'You can either decide to be farmers and grow agricultural crops or you can decide to be politicians, allied with the MDC and face the consequences. It is your choice.'

It appears the farmers are choosing to be apolitical farmers. Terrified by the brazen killings of two white farmers earlier this month and the beatings of five others, the farming community appears to have agreed not to support the opposition.

Now it appears Zanu-PF is turning on Zimbabwe's business leaders who have also supported the MDC. Top businessman Nigel Chanakira, who is an economic adviser to the MDC, was arrested this week on charges of fraud that are widely believed to have been trumped up. Five other leading businessmen have been arrested and released on bail in connection with the fraud charges at First Mutual Life.

'It is nothing less than intimidation of businesses that were openly supporting the opposition,' said a Harare financial expert, who did not want to be named. 'The government is going after business leaders, both black and white, who support the opposition.'

The Mugabe government is also stepping up its pressure on the press. A bomb went off last week at the offices of Zimbabwe's only privately-owned daily newspaper, the Daily News. The paper has been outspokenly critical of Mugabe's economic and land policies. Daily News editor Geoffrey Nyarota received a death threat days before the bomb blast. The suspicion that the bombing was carried out by Mugabe's supporters was strengthened when the Daily News received a bomb threat on Wednesday last week and the phone call was traced back to the headquarters of Mugabe's Zanu-PF headquarters.

Rather than following that lead, the police have arrested an international photographer on suspicion of carrying out the bombing. Obert Siyabuliza Zilwa, a South African photographer working for Associated Press, was held in jail for three nights. Zimbabwean police admitted yesterday morning that they had no case against Silwa and he was released. But he was still prevented from leaving Zimbabwe.

The Mugabe government's multi-pronged attack on the opposition appears to have succeeded in subduing dissent in urban townships, on white-owned farms, in the business community and in the press. But several opposition supporters say the Mugabe government has only won the first round.

'With hindsight we stood up against the government too soon,' said one white farmer. 'We came out and campaigned openly too early and that made us a target. People are scared now, but already some are thinking of other ways to carry on.'

Morgan Tsvangira, president of the MDC, said: 'We are not giving up. We are not throwing in the towel. There is violence and our people are being killed. But we will continue. With all this intimidation and state-sponsored violence the elections cannot possibly be free and fair. But we will stand in the elections in any case because we are committed to changing the government through democratic means.'

fields.headline: A vote for Ken - just
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: If the opinion polls are right, Ken Livingstone will become London mayor by an astonishing margin. You may live outside the capital, but the consequences of his success for the practice of politics and terms of political engagement extend nationally.
fields.body:
What is happening in London is no less than a political earthquake. An independent politician with no political organisation is set to overturn all the rules of the political universe. If the opinion polls are right, Ken Livingstone will become London mayor by an astonishing margin. You may live outside the capital, but the consequences of his success for the practice of politics and terms of political engagement extend nationally.

This is all the more extraordinary given his track record. Those who worked with him in local government have come forward to testify to his weaknesses - his penchant for surrounding himself with favourites, his lack of attention to detail, his untrustworthiness and his shallow, populist instincts. His period as leader of the Greater London Council was characterised by the worst forms of gesture politics and lack of financial discipline and helped legitimise the abolition of the metropolitan authorities by the Thatcher government. He, more than any other Labour politician, helped to establish the 'Loony Left' label that damned the party to 18 years of opposition. Yet here he is, promising to resurrect himself as London mayor.

The readiest explanation for Livingstone's success is that Londoners want to snub New Labour's self-evident desire to control and centralise power around a political programme established essentially by two politicians - the Chancellor and the Prime Minister. Many Conservatives will vote for Mr Livingstone to make mischief for Blair, while many Labour voters are appalled by the crude attempt to manipulate the outcome of the Labour primary contest for mayor. On the other hand, the Labour Party is likely to do well in the voting for the Greater London Assembly and may even win overall control; the ties of party loyalty have not been completely reversed. The Livingstone phenomenon is more than just a protest vote.

Livingstone, for all his manifest imperfections, personifies the notion of political possibility. It is not just that his candidature has enlivened what otherwise would have been a lacklustre campaign between three party hacks. A vote for Livingstone will stir things up, asserting the people's voice over the party machines. It is, curiously, a vote for the capacity of politicians and politics to change things - to widen political debate beyond the terms set by the centralised hierarchies of the two main parties. The emergence of Conservative Stephen Norris as the clear second favourite also reflects this mood. Norris may suffer from well-publicised character flaws and imperfections but, like Livingstone, he is his own man. He has distanced himself from the illiberal populism of William Hague and has re-established the notion that a more liberal, pro-European conservatism still retains a political constituency.

The cynical response is that Norris knows his electorate - that to make progress in multicultural, individualist, liberal London, he has to say the things he does. Which proves the point. The savvy politician is the politician in touch with the emerging political mood and the strength of support for Livingstone and, to a lesser extent, Norris shows that they have read the runes well. Even Frank Dobson has shown flashes of this understanding, speaking out against the complicated and unnecessary structure that New Labour proposes for the London Underground, which will reproduce the mistakes of the privatisation of British Rail.

But Dobson has been trapped in a political Hobson's choice. He can't declare too much independence from the Labour line without losing the benefits, such as they are, of the party's central support, but too much slavish allegiance to the Blair/Brown diktat disables him from building the momentum and coalition that he needs. Dobson's campaign has been ponderous and uncreative, but, as he now must know, to have had any chance whatever, he needed to declare his independence from Number 10 and Number 11 from day one of his candidature. He did not, or could not, and is now paying the price. He risks coming in third or even last, a massive personal and political humiliation.

In this respect, what London's electorate is showing is that the calls for constitutional change in general and devolution in particular that developed over the Nineties were not the irrelevant babble of the chattering classes, as they were characterised by right-wing critics and New Labour political strategists alike. They reflected a yearning for a more responsive and accountable politics that neither Britain's political structures nor political culture were and are able to express. New Labour had to champion a degree of constitutional reform and devolution, in part as its debt to John Smith, who was committed to both, and in part because it had to keep sufficient liberal intellectuals onside, who believed in reform, to sustain its broad coalition. But the leadership was never convinced of the case. Rather, it recognised that its job was to redefine the Labour Party as the new One-Nation party of the Centre, so that it could never again be marginalised as it was during the Eighties, and to make only those constitutional reforms that were congruent with retaining the essence of centralised British parliamentary democracy.

In London, this expressed itself as the establishment of a London assembly and mayor, intended as sops to reforming opinion but never designed as a serious political platform for devolved, city-wide government. The London mayor has almost no independent sources of finance apart from congestion charges. But this was as New Labour intended - devolution without any content while strategic control remains firmly at the centre. For example, the London mayor is laughably responsible for promoting the public health of Londoners while control of the NHS remains with central government. The candidates have done well to fashion what they have within the limitations, but their manifestos expose the trivial nature of the power they will assume.

If the London mayor had been a serious political office, it might have attracted political heavy-hitters from within and without the political class. For example, a Mandelson or Mowlam might have volunteered for the task rather than running for cover, while a substantial independent might have entered the lists. The London Labour Party, faced with the responsibility of nominating a serious candidate for a serious office and left alone to do the task without the rules being bent from above, would have been much less tempted to support a maverick like Livingstone. For this would have been a wholly different political climate, in which New Labour could never have earned the reputation for control freakery because its commitment to devolution and political reform would have been genuine. There would be no manipulation to protest against.

But this is not where we are. Londoners are faced with an imperfect field of candidates for an office which is largely of symbolic governing importance. What to do? In our view, the very minimalism of the office means that many of the practical disadvantages of a Livingstone mayoralty are outweighed by the advantages. He is the candidate who most nearly expresses the values of the liberal, social-democratic Left. We disagree with some of his more outlandish positions on the international financial system or the City, but we sympathise with why he says what he does. He is overtly pro-European and pro-euro.

Moreover, he has a vision for London that is inclusive, humane and liberal. He is likely to champion bold architecture and cheap public transport and will speak vigorously for all Londoners. He will be held to account for any silly gesture politics by the London Assembly that New Labour has ensured will be dominated by its drones. As for central government, it will need to find an accommodation with a mayor with such a large mandate. There are risks and we wish the choice were different, but he is the least worst option.

Given that Livingstone looks set to win overwhelmingly, the second preference vote is of some importance. The decision should be governed by where the vote might have the maximum beneficial political impact - and for this reason we plump for Norris. Although we decry his views on capital punishment, he, none the less, comes from the tolerant, pro-European, socially-conscious wing of the Tory party and if he performs well, it will be a shot across the bows of the rednecks and xenophobes around Hague.

If Livingstone and Norris do well, it will be a sharp reminder to the political establishment that there is another constituency beyond that defined by the leader writers of the Telegraph, Mail and Sun. Above all, London is sending a message to New Labour that it is hungry for politicians who stand for something. That it wants a politics of debate rather than milk-and-water attempts to be all things to all men. Voters want political creeds that they can choose between, rewarding those who succeed and punishing those who fail. Without Livingstone, none of this hunger would have been revealed. For that alone, he deserves our support.

 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER Telephone: 020 7278 2332, Fax: 020 7713 4250/4286 e-mail:editor@observer.co.uk

Although we decry his views on capital punishment, he, none the less, comes from the tolerant, pro-European, socially-conscious wing of the Tory party and if he performs well, it will be a shot across the bows of the rednecks and xenophobes around Hague. If Livingstone and Norris do well, it will be a sharp reminder to the political establishment that there is another constituency beyond that defined by the leader writers of the Telegraph, Mail and Sun. Above all, London is sending a message to New Labour that it is hungry for politicians who stand for something. That it wants a politics of debate rather than milk-and-water attempts to be all things to all men. Voters want political creeds that they can choose between, rewarding those who succeed and punishing those who fail. Without Livingstone, none of this hunger would have been revealed. For that alone, he deserves our support.  119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER Telephone: 020 7278 2332, Fax: 020 7713 4250/4286 e-mail:editor@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Eco-warriors ready to dig up city streets and plant flowers

fields.headline: Eco-warriors ready to dig up city streets and plant flowers
fields.standfirst:
London is braced for its biggest security operation as anti-capitalism activists aim to bring the centre to a standstill tomorrow. The talk is of urban gardening - but violence is promised too

May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: London is braced for its biggest security operation as anti-capitalism activists aim to bring the centre to a standstill tomorrow. The talk is of urban gardening - but violence is promised too
fields.body:
'Four or five of us start digging up the street. The police turn up in masses. We let some get taken away. Meanwhile, there's a group of us somewhere else getting down to business. The police will never control it all. It will be chaos.'

It is Friday night in the Kings' Inn near Whitechapel and Neil, 22, from Liverpool is talking tactics for Monday's May Day City protest. Decked out in urban warrior regalia - jeans, T-shirt and a leather jacket - he describes how he will take to the streets tomorrow carrying a pick-axe and trowel and 'do a little gardening'.

He laughs. But this is not Charlie Dimmock and Alan Titchmarsh fun in the sun. It is direct action in the concrete jungle. 'Guerrilla gardening is easy and very effective,' says Andrew, 29, from Birmingham. 'We dig up the streets and plant flowers and the police try to stop us. It's the best way to debilitate a city centre. The pavement has to be restored before pedestrians can walk: the streets have to be tarred again.'

Seeds and saplings may seem an unlikely follow-up to the worst riots since the poll tax disturbances of 1990, but after the 18 June protest in London last year and the disturbances in Seattle and Washington, demonstrators say it is the latest tactic 'to bolster Planet Earth and declare war on Planet Inc'.

Guerrilla gardening draws direct inspiration from New York, hit last May by waves of ground protests following Mayor Rudy Giuliani's decision to sell off 114 garden lots to property developers. Protesters dressed as vegetables, fruits and flowers marched on City Hall, taunting the mayor with kazoos and acts of civil disobedience. The gardens were eventually restored to neighbourhood care.

The New York actions and recent mass protests like those waged in Seattle and Washington have helped to galvanise British protesters. But not all are such keen gardeners. John is university-educated and has worked for United Nations organisations, such as the World Food Programme. 'But I got fed up. It was all as corrupt as the politics I despise.

'I don't want to use a trowel on Monday. I think we should do more. I want to see people donning balaclavas and smashing street video cameras. If they want to go on to destroy cars and telephone boxes, and invade office buildings, then that's their business.'

It is tempting to dismiss the protesters as green-fingered Marxists and disaffected anarchist dopeheads - the kind of people who walk around the streets with dogs on string leads wearing dodgy knitwear and talking fast and nervously about changing the world before 'our culture becomes a culture of extinction'. But there is more to Monday than that.

Although many of the organisers are from the unemployed, professionals are getting involved and joining organisations like Reclaim The Streets in ever bigger numbers - among them doctors, anthropologists, university lecturers and graduates.

'When we first started out we managed to get 500 people on a protest in 1995, then we had 2,000 and we expect 10,000 or more this weekend. If you had told me three years ago that bankers would have been struggling to get into the IMF meeting in Washington, that the disruption of the World Trade Organisation meeting would be international news, I would have laughed in your face,' says John Jordan, a 35-year-old Fine Art lecturer at Sheffield Hallam University, rushing to meet the latest train of activists to arrive at Waterloo Station.

A variety of fringe protest groups are building on a growing unease about environmental degradation, the growth of big corporations and what is seen as a widening global gap between the haves and have-nots. 'There is definitely something going on. People know that the world is threatened by an ecological crisis. Unlike in the 1960s, they despair of conventional political parties to do anything about it. So it is up to us. That's what direct action is all about,' Jordan says.

Sean Pillot de Chenecey, a trend forecaster and youth marketing consultant, who observed the Seattle riots and advises firms targeted by rioters, including CocaCola, Nike and Levi's, agrees that the Reclaim The Streets movement is new, powerful and could turn out to be more influential than most are ready to concede.

'There is no doubt that there is a growing activism among ordinary people who question out-of- control consumerism and the overt branding of society.

'Youth movements in the past have always had a focus to their protest, whether it was radical politics in the 60s or punk in the 70s. Today that youthful rebellion has turned to questioning consumerism, and what they see as the way global brands are taking over the world.'

The protesters' claims that the world's eco-system could collapse by 2030 may be exaggerated, but it is true that the world's leading consumer brands generate annual turnover greater than the poorest 20 countries' total wealth. Walk down any high street in almost any city and the logos are the same - McDonalds, Coke, Starbucks, Levi's. As politicians appear increasingly powerless to influence big business, what better way to express opposition than to show the corporate world what you think with direct action?

'Capitalism is supposed to give people choice. But what choice do we have? We have to go out and participate in an economic system that destroys the Earth to earn money to buy a home we probably can't afford. People confuse freedom and democracy with happiness and justice. They are not the same,' says Jordan.

Few protesters offer a clear account of the new world order they seek. They talk vaguely of 'society meeting all its own needs', of 'trading newspapers for root vegetables'. As Joan, 18, puts it: 'Living in the 90s is about built-up frustrations. Young people don't know what direction they should be pointing in. There is buzz, a mass coming together. but we are not sure where we are going.'

Although London is likely to be the scene of the largest anti-capitalist gatherings this weekend, the campaign has roots around the globe. People's Global Action, an international network that 'supports direct action as a means of communities reclaiming control of their lives', was formed in 1998.

It held its first meeting in Geneva that year, bringing together groups as diverse as French farmers, Maoris, Canadian postal workers, anti-nuclear campaigners, Korean trade unionists and the Indigenous Women's Net work of North America.

Whether protesters are carrying seeds and saplings or pick-axes, police are taking tomorrow seriously. All leave has been cancelled and Scotland Yard says preparations for the May Day protests will be the biggest law-enforcement operation in the capital for 30 years. Protesters know there will be violence but say they don't want it. 'There is always a small group who want a ruck. It does not help us, but it goes with the territory. And when we talk of violence, which is worse? A few smashed cars or an economic system that is killing our planet?' asks Jordan.

webTitle: What message should I be on?

fields.headline: What message should I be on?
fields.trailText: I bumped into my old friend Sir Douglas Corridor in Whitehall's Red Lion pub the other day. Or, rather, the great man bumped into a group that consisted of Sam Spin, one of the Prime Minister's closest advisers, Gavin Trend, the Chancellor's media supremo, and myself. Sir Douglas said he had long wanted to meet my two younger friends and I decided the best thing to do was to take a back seat while he quizzed them.
fields.body:
I bumped into my old friend Sir Douglas Corridor in Whitehall's Red Lion pub the other day. Or, rather, the great man bumped into a group that consisted of Sam Spin, one of the Prime Minister's closest advisers, Gavin Trend, the Chancellor's media supremo, and myself. Sir Douglas said he had long wanted to meet my two younger friends and I decided the best thing to do was to take a back seat while he quizzed them.

CORRIDOR: Tell me about yourself, Mr Spin. I have heard a lot about you. Frankly, you don't look as fierce as your reputation would suggest.

SPIN: Can I quote you, Sir Douglas?

CORRIDOR: Quote me? Oh no, dear boy. I come from another era. We civil servants remained in the background in those days. Why, I only made two public speeches during my time at the Treasury.

TREND: I've always wanted to meet you, Sir Douglas. You're living history.

CORRIDOR: That's one way of putting it. Tell me, how is the Treasury?

TREND: The Treasury? Fantastic. I love it.

CORRIDOR: I don't mean its impact on you, Mr Trend. I mean what have you done for my former department?

TREND: Well, love us or hate us, everybody says Gordon's the greatest Chancellor since records began.

CORRIDOR: Oh yes, I served a number of those in my time.

TREND: Excuse me, Sir Douglas. It's my pager. I've just got to go outside a second.

CORRIDOR: Pager, Mr Spin? What's a pager?

SPIN: It's a little gadget he carries on his belt. It tells him when the Chancellor wants him.

CORRIDOR: Wonders will never cease. I thought it might be something to do with his heart - but then, you're all so young. Tell me, though, surely there are office hours when the Chancellor can talk to his staff?

SPIN: Oh yes, Sir Douglas. But under New Labour every hour of the day is an office hour. We all have to be available at all times, wherever we are.

CORRIDOR: Goodness, it sounds a little uncivilised. Is that really necessary?

SPIN: Well, it was my idea actually, Sir Douglas. The idea is that we're always on our guard, we're never caught out, everybody's in touch with everybody.

CORRIDOR: Is that what you mean by this expression I keep hearing - what is it now? Dear me, I shall forget my own name next _

SPIN: Being 'on message', Sir Douglas?

CORRIDOR: Yes, being 'on message'.

SPIN: Yes, partly. But the real point of being 'on message' is that everybody knows what the Government line is, so that we're all singing from the same hymn sheet, you might say.

CORRIDOR: Goodness me, how dull you make it sound.

SPIN: Since it's you Sir Dou glas, and I've heard so much about you, I'll be perfectly frank. It's all unbelievably dull. We work so hard we never have any time to ourselves. I can't understand why people think it's glamorous.

( TREND returns to his seat looking shaken and says nothing. )

SPIN: Are you all right Gavin?

TREND ( head in hands ): No, it's terrible. Gordon was really shaken by those anti-capitalism riots in Washington and now we hear they're planning them for May Day in London.

SPIN: What's bugging him? We had a few protests over Putin's visit. It's routine these days. We don't want the Chancellor cracking up just when he and Tony are finally getting on all right.

TREND: No, he's not cracking up. But, look at it from our point of view: after all those years fighting capitalism the Labour Party finally accepts it and now there are anti-capitalist riots everywhere.

CORRIDOR: Yes, it's wonderful isn't it! At last people are waking up to the evils of capitalism. And it's only 11 years since the Fall of the Wall.

SPIN and TREND ( in unison ): You're against capitalism, Sir Douglas?

CORRIDOR: Always have been. But, in the felicitous words of one of my old enemies, what is the alternative? No, capitalism is all we've got these days, I'm afraid.

TREND: Yes, it's capitalism for all.

SPIN: It's the People's Capitalism.

CORRIDOR: Oh really? Equal opportunity for everyone to become a capitalist? Socialism has travelled a long way ...

SPIN: It's what the focus groups want.

CORRIDOR: Focus groups? Oh, do enlighten me.

TREND (to SPIN): He's having you on, Sam.

SPIN: Yes, focus groups.

CORRIDOR: It's all right. I've heard of them. In the old days in Whitehall we were always worried about how things would go down north of Watford. I understand that New Labour conducted its focus groups about the single currency in Watford ...

SPIN ( to TREND ): I'm afraid he's right, Gavin. We did.

TREND: Anyway, Sir Douglas, Gordon says everyone will be empowered by the New Economy.

CORRIDOR: New Economy? To my mind there's only one economy, with old bits, new bits and lots of in-between bits.

(SPIN and TREND look longingly at their mobile phones but there is no escape. Tony and Gordon are talking to each other. Nobody calls.)

CORRIDOR: What, in any case, do you people mean by 'empower'? I find it an alien concept.

TREND: Well, er ...

SPIN: It's kind of e-commerce, the Internet, mobile phones, being wired up, everybody can participate ...

CORRIDOR: Like New Labour Ministers and officials, you mean? Always - wait a minute - you'll have the whole country 'on message'. Is that it?

SPIN ( to TREND ): Hey Gavin, that's not a bad idea.

TREND: Yes, we'll have everybody in the land on message. Just think of it! No more mistakes. No more misunderstandings. Everyone will know what we're trying to do.

CORRIDOR: I see my old friend Sir George from the Bank over there. Time to go. But, if you'll forgive me one last question - what exactly is the message everybody is supposed to be 'on'?

fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: E-finance: special report
fields.body:
Dim start for a bright spark

Roll up, folks, and win a huge cash prize for your bonza Internet idea. Channel 4 has teamed up with a consortium of business investors and Internet incubators and will award £1 million to the bright spark who comes up with the best business plan for an online firm. The www.emillionaireshow.com will be broadcast in July. Aspiring dot.com millionaires must register their entries at the site, where they will then be 'scrutinised by top business analysts provided by Andersen Consulting'. Unfortunate choice this. Andersen's reputation for being a bastion of IT expertise is open to debate, as its recent troubles with both the Stock Exchange and NIR2 computer systems show all too embarrassingly.

Final entry?

As if Lastminute did not have enough to worry about, with its interim results coming out this Thursday. Some upstart called, rather unsurprisingly, www.laststop.co.uk has just launched claiming to be 'the UK's largest retailer of late availability bargain holidays'. How long before we see one Neil Curnow, the company's MD, splashed across the fashion pages and everywhere else in a way eerily reminiscent of the approach adopted by his opposite number at Lastminute? No, don't bother writing in.

Shed a tear

Still, if things look bad in the business-to-consumer end of the Internet market, at least those business-to-business companies look capable of producing some super soaraway valuations to pump some air into the ever decreasing dot.com bubble. Erm, apparently not.

Even some of the shining lights in this arena, those firms which strive to create transparent market places, the apotheosis of the Internet ideal, are doomed. Research firm AMR says 90 per cent of all independent business-to-business exchanges will go bust. And lo, there came the sound of sobbing day traders.

webTitle: Brave new world signalled by 300mph levitating trains in airport link-up between airports

fields.headline: Brave new world signalled by 300mph levitating trains in airport link-up between airports
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Passengers could soon be hurtled at more than 300 mph on levitating trains that run through vacuum tunnels hundreds of feet underground.
fields.body:
Passengers could soon be hurtled at more than 300 mph on levitating trains that run through vacuum tunnels hundreds of feet underground.

Services would link major airports, such as Heathrow and Gatwick, cutting transfer times to a few minutes, say engineers.

In the longer term, a network of high-speed, metro trains could be constructed across Europe, they add.

The system has been dubbed the Underground Concorde and is the brainchild of a European consortium backed by Daimler-Chrysler, Alstrom and several major civil engineering companies.

The Swiss Government has asked the group to design a £3 billion, 55-mile underground line that could whisk passengers between Zurich and Basle airports in less than 10 minutes. It is also hoped that Geneva and Lyons airports could be similarly connected.

'Our train technology could transform the airports of tomorrow,' said Dr Michele Mossi, a director of the consortium, Swissmetro.

'By providing near instantaneous transfers between terminals in different cities, we will be creating new, super-airports from flight centres dozen of miles apart.'

The new system is based on magnetic levitation. Instead of running on wheels, carriages and engines would float, suspended by powerful magnetic fields, while linear induction motors would propel trains through their tunnel.

'This suspension technology has been proven in trials in Germany and Japan,' added Mossi. 'However, we have added a new twist. We will run levitation trains through tunnels from which we have pumped nearly all the air. This will greatly reduce atmospheric resistance and allow us to operate even faster, and more efficient trains.'

Under the consortium plans, air pressure in metro tunnels would be reduced to a fraction of their normal levels - to the equivalent of the atmosphere 55,000ft above sea level, the cruising altitude of Concorde. 'Essentially, we are going to build supersonic planes that will fly underground,' he said.

Apart from boosting train speeds, depressurised tunnels will allow designers to construct extremely compact trains. Each carriage would be less than 10ft in diameter, while tunnels would be only 16ft across.

Such restricted dimensions should help to make significant reductions in construction costs.

However, to prevent passengers collapsing from lack of air as they enter or leave trains, airlocks will have to be constructed at each station.

It is expected that trains carrying 200 passengers would run every four minutes once the system is fully operational.

'We originally planned to build a £2bn pilot link between Lausanne and Geneva, but have been told by the Swiss government that revenue from such a line would not be sufficient to justify the investment,' Mossi added.

It is expected most concerns about the system will focus on its cost. With its £3bn price tag, and as yet untested vacuum technology, the Zurich-Basle Underground Concorde requires a significant capital outlay.

This point is acknowledged by the consortium, though its engineers point out that its costs are comparable with those of the latest generation European TGV train lines on the surface. They say the latter cost about £25 million a mile to build, while their new levitation train line would eventually cost about £38m a mile to construct - underground where they cause no noise or pollution.

Other problems to be overcome will include those concerned with heat build-up in the tunnels, which may have to be cooled to prevent outbreaks of fire.

The consortium has already begun work on a scaled-down line half-a-kilometre long near Lausanne, and will begin trials there in a few months. If approved by the Swiss parliament in June, work on the full-scale pilot line between Zurich and Basle would begin in 2002, but it will take take several years to complete.

fields.headline: If the jester's cap fits ...
fields.standfirst:
The Motley Fool began as a hoax. Now it's a serious player in investment advice, reports Jamie Doward

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The Motley Fool began as a hoax. Now it's a serious player in investment advice, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
For a while it was a very successful company. It was the new, new thing and everyone wanted a slice of the action, despite the fact that details of what it did and where it operated were more than a little hazy.

The company was called Zeigletics, and it was responsible for the development of innovative technology linking sewage disposal systems in Chad. But the company, and the stock exchange its shares were listed on, did not exist. The entire thing was an invention, the brainchild of the two brothers who founded the Motley Fool, the irreverent financial advice firm which started as a newsletter and is evolving into a cross-media empire with global pretensions.

'We started the hoax on 1 April 1994 and we suggested people should be buying these shares because they were going up. More and more people began paying attention. We were getting e-mail from brokers saying "my client wants me to look into this and I can't find the Halifax-Canadian exchange",' recalls Tom Gardner, co-founder of the Motley Fool.

The move was designed to warn investors about the risks of investing too heavily in penny shares. Back in the mid-Nineties, as the Motley Fool started to transfer its advice to the Internet, moving away from being a pure tip sheet, Tom and brother David became frustrated by investors' appetite for small stocks which often feature in 'pump and dump' scams. That is the sort of scheme where companies' shares are hyped online causing a quick surge in their value only for this to dissipate as those who talked up the firm sell their stake and make a killing.

'A lot of people just wanted to trade penny shares online. We kept trying to talk about the Gap or General Electric and they were saying "look at the shares I've bought. They've gone up six times in value, but the Gap's only gone up 20 per cent". We couldn't get a conversation going,' Gardner says.

The prank created its own dynamic as followers of the Fool started to participate in the illusion. 'In typical Foolish spirit people began joining in saying "I've already made $6,000",' he added. The point was to show that people were trading very thinly traded stocks.

The stunt created a blaze of publicity, despite the fact that the Fool newsletter had only 360 subscribers and had a staff of two. 'We never had a business plan. We began doing this without any expectation that we would be striking it rich,' Gardner says of the early attempts to found the newsletter.

'We sent out 2,000 copies of the newsletter to anyone we had an address for - including those we had drawn from my cousin's wedding invitations. At the end of the first month we had 36 subscribers who were paying $48 a year. We were told later that this was a 1.8 per cent response rate, which is pretty good for direct mailing. However it was mailed to a lot of people who we knew and who were blood relatives of ours.'

The Wall Street Journal picked up the Zeigletics story and soon America Online was knocking on the Gardner brothers' door looking to run the Fool's service on its network. The timing of the alliance between the Fool and what was to become America's biggest Internet service provider was another lucky break for the Gardner brothers. More were to follow.

Back in the mid-Nineties, AOL had no content and only 300,000 subscribers. 'They had nothing to put on their main screen and our Fool button was up there and so everyone had to click it. We had an overflow of people and there was just me and and Dave working 12 hours a day.'

The pair decided to dump the newsletter and concentrate on developing the Fool's online presence. In a sense the Motley Fool (the name comes from an idiot savant character in Shakespeare's As You Like It who highlights the absurdities of others) was an Internet company before the Internet, building interactive communities by encouraging investors to write in and swap information.

'We wanted our readers to be our contributors because we didn't feel we were good enough or smart enough to do all of the writing. That's really been the spirit of the Internet site because so much of the knowledge is contributed by the users,' Gardner explained.

That spirit was not without problems at first. 'Our live chat rooms contained the regulars who had been with us from the start - money managers, analysts from Wall Street - but then, when we got the mainscreen promotion with AOL, we would find the chat rooms would be full of 13-year-olds who just wanted to talk about Pearl Jam. It was total chaos.

'One person was saying "what do you think about wireless communications, is that a good industry to invest in?" and the next post was "I love the Spice Girls". It was a truly Motley collection.'

The exposure brought further lucrative spin-offs. The New Yorker wrote an article featuring the Motley Fool which prompted a raft of book deals. An investment column was syndicated to more than 120 newspapers. Soon the brothers had their own radio show broadcast across more than 150 stations. Some of the guests reflected the Fool's more eccentric side.

'We get legitimate guests on the show now. We've had the chief executive officers of Yahoo! and Starbucks on. In the past we've had people like Kenny Baker, he's a dwarf. He was the guy who was inside R2D2 in Star Wars. He had no idea who we were.'

The success meant the brothers were able to hire some staff and move into plush headquarters in Virginia. Today the Fool employs more than 300 people and has operations in the US, the UK and Germany. Japan will follow soon.

One day the business will float, a move which will bring new challenges for the company whose US site attracts two million clicks a month. 'There is a natural fascination with what we do when the market does well and that can ebb when the market doesn't do well.'

Such serious expansion plans are potentially at odds with the Fool's playful image as the pricker of pompous City egos, the more touchy-feely side of capitalism.

Tom Gardner, however, argues that the original ethos of the Fool continues. 'Anytime an organisation grows as quickly as we're growing, determining how to develop your culture takes a lot of work. But the spirit has been maintained. We love the mix of intellectual curiosity and base popular culture.'

Gardner suggests that such a mix is the only way of encouraging more people to get serious about their finances. 'The humour is the sugar around the medicine. We wouldn't get people interested in treatment if we gave them just the hard numbers.' Or, as Shakespeare's character would have it: 'Give me leave to speak my mind, and I will through and through cleanse the foul body of the infected world, If they will patiently receive my medi cine.' For now the Fool is king. His real test, however, comes when he is answerable to shareholders. Investors, as the Fool knows, don't always have a sense of humour.

webTitle: Great idea, shame about the rules

fields.headline: Great idea, shame about the rules
fields.trailText: Isn't it sensible that fund managers, whose business depends on making us rich, should be paid according to how well they perform that task?
fields.body:
Payment by results: everyone from teachers to football players is having to live with this kind of market discipline. So it is sensible, isn't it, that fund managers, whose business depends on making us rich, should be paid according to how well they perform that task?

The answer is only a qualified yes. Performance fees are a Good Thing which every fund manager should have. But, to be worthwhile, they have to reward good performance, penalise bad, and have safeguards which prevent them becoming too large a burden on the fund. That is harder than it sounds.

Take the examples of two technology trusts, Henderson Technology and Finsbury Technology. Both have been excellent investments, turning £100 into more than £500 in less than five years. Both have performance-related fees which are producing generous rewards for their managers. Brokers Merrill Lynch estimates that Henderson could have accrued more than £40 million in performance fees for the year which ends today, while Finsbury earned more than £10 million in the year to last November. But, the fees owe at least as much to the boom in technology shares as they do to the managers' skills. And neither fund has any limit on how far the fees could rise.

To be fair, that is not the managers' fault. When the two trusts were launched in the mid-1990s, there was no global technology index. Both, therefore, chose general international benchmarks such as the FT or the MSCI world index. Not surprisingly, they have beaten those benchmarks. But Merrill Lynch attempted to construct a global technology index - a difficult exercise - and both have done little better than keep pace with that.

The fees would have been less eye-popping if there had been a cap - the recently launched 3i European Technology, for example, puts a ceiling on its fees of 1.5 per cent of net asset value. But, when the trusts were launched, investors thought that the technology boom was over - both funds had to work hard to raise their money. No one was predicting the run of the last six months so a cap seemed academic. The trust's major shareholders are not complaining about the fees: after all, they have done at least as well as the managers.

But the directors of the Henderson trust are considering whether the current performance criteria are appropriate and Finsbury is likely to be thinking along similar lines. But, as Andrew Close of Finsbury's managers points out, if it changes to a technology index as its benchmark, it could be accused of altering the rules to suit itself - particularly if technology shares continue to underperform.

The issue is less with the fees paid to these trusts than with the structure of performance incentives in general. These must be measured against an appropriate benchmark - and if none exists, then there must be a question mark over whether a performance fee is appropriate. They must be capped. And they must penalise managers who do badly. Without all three conditions, performance fees could do more harm than good.

webTitle: Phil Hogan  does time in Constable country

fields.headline: Phil Hogan  does time in Constable country
fields.trailText: Would you believe it? According to something that fell out of the financial pages of my wife's Grout! magazine, we have once again shot ourselves in the foot by missing the April deadline for transferring a prudent quota of our surplus funds into a warming, organic tax-free Individual Savings Account.
fields.body:
Would you believe it? According to something that fell out of the financial pages of my wife's Grout! magazine, we have once again shot ourselves in the foot by missing the April deadline for transferring a prudent quota of our surplus funds into a warming, organic tax-free Individual Savings Account, which I suppose means that we now have no option but to divert this month's disposable income (which in the current fiscal year has to be calculated in minus figures for technical reasons) into an unhurried drive through rural Essex and a pub lunch at the first homely inn displaying the MasterCard sign.

An hour later we have discovered just the picturesque village hostelry, with a handsome frontage and Georgian parking facilities at the rear accessible through a passage built for a small goat-drawn vehicle without wing mirrors. But, at last, we're all in and seated and admiring the interesting collection of 18th-century jelly moulds before getting down to poking the food around our plates, me pondering the wisdom of ordering a feta cheese salad this far west of the Acropolis, the eldest complaining that his onion soup is full of tomatoes and my wife agonising over whether to send the sausages back in exchange for something less flagrantly burnt to a readily carbon-dated form of fossil fuel.

'Everything all right?' trills the landlady.

'Lovely, thank you!' we chorus.

We stay as long as is decent before abandoning our UHT coffee and ice cream with its special Gillette aerosol cuckoo-spit topping and make an exit past a sign aimed at drawing the attention of passing gastronomes to an exciting forthcoming pasta and wine evening. 'Book early to avoid disappointment,' says the sign, though obviously, if you're pressed for time, you could avoid disappointment by staying at home and putting a crumpet under the grill.

By a strange freak of weather, it's a lovely day and we walk over the bridge to see the ducklings in the pond and the baby cows in the meadow, my beautiful wife and I strolling contentedly, hand in hand, children gambolling ahead, as if blissfully unaware that this is the scene just before the one where one of us contracts a terminal wasting illness or embarks on an ill-advised affair with a psychopath who attempts to butcher and sexually abuse the entire family in the final denouement staged at an improbably remote location in the pouring rain, only to be killed in the nick of time with his own harpoon gun, which during the ensuing struggle has slithered across the wet floorboards into the hands of the 11-year-old daughter (or son, in our case).

This is Constable country, though you wouldn't know it by looking at the deserted high street and the local café, which has blatantly flouted English heritage law by failing to call itself Haywain Tea Rooms. Tourist Information is shut, so we pop into the craft centre to see how simple, natural materials can be transformed into novelty toilet-roll holders. There's someone up the stairs busy at his easel. 'Is he painting by numbers, Dad?' asks the six-year-old. The artist laughs genially, though it seems like a reasonable question to me.

From here we go into the big old church, where you can buy bookmarks and postcards and a whole rack of posters bearing the message 'A smile costs nothing'. I resist an impulse to set it on fire and try to catch up with the children, who have taken themselves off to an elegant High Class Grocer's to see if they sell Pokémon cards. The staff look at them as though they are speaking Japanese, which of course they are.

Eventually, we are saved from not knowing what to do next by a local drunk, who insists on directing us to some old cottage, which is famous for being a blob in one of Constable's paintings. We manage to talk the eldest into parting with his fiver to get us into the car park, and walk down to the lovely little museum, which is a treasure store of signs saying Please Mind Your Head and has an actual photograph of Constable's palette, in addition to a pair of paintbrushes very similar to those quite possibly used by the artist himself.

But then, further down the road, is another museum, which has nothing to do with Constable but is just a collection of rubbish passed down through the ages and arranged in order of inconsequence - early lightbulbs, pre-war razors, bicycles with wooden wheels, pitchforks, sheep's skulls, stuffed owls, gas masks, leg irons that they used to use for letting your slave know who was boss, something for catching eels, a Zulu shield. Fantastic. The children ask lots of intelligent questions. OK, so it costs 30p to get in, but isn't an investment in knowledge an investment for life? And, hey, you can't take it with you.

Museum pieces to phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

But then, further down the road, is another museum, which has nothing to do with Constable but is just a collection of rubbish passed down through the ages and arranged in order of inconsequence - early lightbulbs, pre-war razors, bicycles with wooden wheels, pitchforks, sheep's skulls, stuffed owls, gas masks, leg irons that they used to use for letting your slave know who was boss, something for catching eels, a Zulu shield. Fantastic. The children ask lots of intelligent questions. OK, so it costs 30p to get in, but isn't an investment in knowledge an investment for life? And, hey, you can't take it with you. Museum pieces to phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Stick with Blue Circle's great white hopes...

fields.headline: Stick with Blue Circle's great white hopes...
fields.trailText: If timing were the key to success, the French cement company Lafarge would win its battle for Blue Circle hands down. Technology stocks may not be quite the one-way bet they were a couple of months ago, but investors would still rather buy into the new economy than invest in boring old building materials producers.
fields.body:
If timing were the key to success, the French cement company Lafarge would win its battle for Blue Circle hands down. Technology stocks may not be quite the one-way bet they were a couple of months ago, but investors would still rather buy into the new economy than invest in boring old building materials producers.

Lafarge is not only offering these shareholders a cash exit, it made its move when Blue Circle's shares were at their lowest ebb, hit by concern that the great white hope of Malaysia was turning into the great white elephant.

But timing is not everything. Price matters, too. Lafarge is simply not offering enough. Even analysts who are sympathetic to Blue Circle say that, at a price of £3.6 billion, the deal would have no impact on its own earnings in 2001, the first full year of ownership, and would increase them substantially the following year. Others say the enhancement next year could be as high as 8 per cent.

Whichever number you choose, it means that too many of the benefits are flowing through to Lafarge's shareholders and not enough to Blue Circle's.

Nor is the multiple of Blue Circle's earnings generous. The 439p a share offer - excluding Blue Circle's 10.95p final dividend, which Lafarge will keep if it wins - represents less than 16 times analysts' estimates before Blue Circle came out with its promise of a £116 million 'operational improvement programme' and the £800 million buyback. Factor these in, and it represents around 11 times forecasts for 2001.

Lafarge questions whether Blue Circle can achieve the savings promised - and shareholders could legitimately wonder how much it will have to pass on to customers. But even if it achieves only half what it promises, the offer looks too cheap.

There are risks in rejecting the bid, not least of which is a precipitate plunge in Blue Circle's shares as soon as it is defeated. But Lafarge is likely to keep its 20 per cent stake and exercise its option on the 9.6 per cent held by Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, its advisers, which should keep the bid speculation alive.

Following the £800 million buyback, which represents about 23 per cent of Blue Circle's share capital, Lafarge's stake will rise to almost 40 per cent, assuming it does not participate in the buyback. That will not be comfortable. Chief executive Rick Hay-Thornthwaite says it will 'not change our priorities nor the way we do business'. It could, however, encourage the board to take excessive risks to boost profits.

The advantages of rejecting the bid outweigh the risks. Shareholders who want out can cash in through the buybacks. Those who stay in will enjoy the earnings enhancement, recovery in Malaysia, and the benefits of the efficiency programmes. And if Blue Circle fails to deliver, the business will still be there for Lafarge or some other bidder to acquire.

Try patience

Just as sensible householders would not count on using their lottery winnings to pay their plumbing bills, so sensible banks would not count on opportunistic acquisitions to grow their business. Those who followed Bank of Scotland's unsuccessful bid for NatWest will recognise that as yet another of the pithy quotes which are the trademark of Peter Burt, group chief executive of the former. But that still leaves the question of where the bank's growth will come from.

That seems a churlish view, given the impressive performance in the year to 29 February. Everything was up: lending, by a heady 19 per cent, profits, earnings, dividends, market share. The only thing down was the cost-income ratio, and that is undoubtedly a good thing.

What interests the City, however, was how the growth is achieved. And there were enough signs of strain to make investors worry about whether it can be sustained.

Most worrying was the contraction in margins, down from 2.05 per cent to 1.8 per cent with the biggest fall coming in the second half of the year. Then there was the 34 per cent increase in business lending, more than double the rate of growth in lending to personal customers. That may represent an increase in market share, but the pessimists worry about the higher risks of lending to customers. Then there is the dreaded I-word.

Burt and his team have quite rightly set their face against investing millions on an internet start-up. The bank already has 350,000 e-commerce customers, but the majority of them are on its old HOBs system - home office banking. They are gradually migrating to the internet but, in the meantime, it has to run two separate systems.

Combined, these factors meant the results disappointed a City eager for a bit of excitement. They should remember that chasing excitement led to NatWest's downfall. If the Bank of Scotland is facing margin pressure, its rivals will be feeling the same. The Scottish bank is far better placed than most to cope. Its shares are likely to remain depressed until the NatWest saga fades into history. Patient investors should tuck them away.

Comfy cash

Graham Kirkham, executive chairman and founder of DFS Furniture, has clearly benefited from the discovery that he was only human after all. Just three years after its performance started to falter, DFS has come storming back with a surge in sales, an 84 per cent profits rise and, once again, more cash than it knows what to do with.

The recovery was partly a result of listening to the customers. They wanted lower prices and wider ranges. They got them. Stores now stock more sofas at both the top and the bottom end and those in between have fallen in price by around 10 per cent in the six months to 29 January. Despite that, sales by value rose 18.5 per cent, and Kirkham estimates volumes were up by a third.

But the real driver of the recovery has been DFS's acquisition of Lincoln House, the furniture manufacturer bought from the receivers. That brought in-house manufacture back to the 20 per cent level when the group floated. New store openings had pushed it as low as 7 per cent. That gives it extra bargaining power with its suppliers, more flexibility on ranges - and, of course, allows it to keep both the retail and the wholesale margin.

The result was a widening of margins from 8 per cent to 12.7 per cent. That is still below the record of 16 per cent-plus. Unrepeatable, perhaps, but there should be room for more improvement this year and next.

webTitle: How to turn us all off pension planning

fields.headline: How to turn us all off pension planning
fields.trailText: The Government seems determined to turn us all off pension planning for good. Not content with creating at least two new types of pension, it now plans to tinker with the ages at which we can draw on them.
fields.body:
The Government seems hell-bent on turning us all off pension planning for good. Not content with creating at least two new types of pension - which, according to one estimate, brings the total number of schemes available to a bamboozled public to 22 - it now plans to tinker with the ages at which we can draw on them.

One of the attractions of building up a private pension, and forgoing spending today in order to do that, is the thought that it might help you to escape the workaday grind in middle age. But the Government believes that employers are using this as a way to turf fiftysomethings on to the unemployment scrap heap. One aim of the changes would be to stamp on age discrimination. But this is the touchy, feely spin. The Government is also counting the cost of state benefits for under-pensioned and under-employed early retirees. But there must be some doubt over what will actually be achieved through this latest piece of meddling. Few people are putting enough into personal pensions to draw more than paltry pensions at 50 and even 55, and the new age proposed for drawing benefits would produce little more for many.

Pensions are already an inflexible, rule-bound form of saving and to limit access to them further will deter people. Those who are organised, and wealthy enough, will turn to other methods of saving. Others will do nothing.

Elsewhere, there is an air of gloom hanging over the country's last remaining mutual insurers. Standard Life, Scottish Provident and Friends Provident are all now in the throes of reviewing this form of ownership. Standard Life, for one, will not go without a fight. Although there is no real commercial pressure for it to become a public company - it stands out for its good returns to policyholders - the pressure from windfall hunters will be intense. If it does not succumb this time, it will certainly remain vulnerable unless the management receives decisive support. The outlook for its smaller mutual brethren looks bleaker as they do not have its investment form, or size. There are predators aplenty in this overcrowded market. And insurers, dogged by years of mis-selling scandals and shortfalls on endowment mortgages, do not enjoy support from policyholders.

webTitle: Hear me now! I is largin' it with Madonna's posse

fields.headline: Hear me now! I is largin' it with Madonna's posse
fields.standfirst: Ali G: special report
fields.trailText: It's da big time, innit. Ali G, the spoof gangsta rapper, is 'keepin' it real' with Madonna in her latest video.
fields.body:
It's da big time, innit. Ali G, the spoof gangsta rapper, is 'keepin' it real' with Madonna in her latest video.

The leader of da Staines Massive travelled to Hollywood - and that's not the nightclub in Bracknell - to film the video for Music , the title track from Madonna's new album.

In his trademark yellow FUBU track-suit, wrap-around shades, chunky gold jewellery, and Tommy Hilfiger hat, Ali G - Cambridge graduate Sacha Baron-Cohen - stars alongside the pregnant pop queen. The single - described as a mix of pop, funk, techno and dance - will be released in August.

Madonna asked Baron-Cohen to perform with her after a friend sent her a copy of his Christmas Special - Ali G, innit . 'She watched the tape and thought he was brilliant - the Peter Sellers of our generation. We came up with the video idea, and she thought he would be great in it,' Madonna's manager Caresse Norman told The Observer .

Ali G flew to the US two weeks ago and shot the video in two days. 'It was all very professional. It was "Hi, how are you?" And then straight to work,' Norman said.

Madonna has told friends his performance is 'genius'. 'Madonna loves him. He is such a doll. She still can't stop laughing,' Norman said.

Ali G, who rarely speaks publicly about his work, does not sing or rap in the new video but has a central role. 'There is a strong storyline, but we are not saying what it is. We are keeping it under wraps because we don't want to spoil the surprise.'

Ali G is virtually unknown in America despite his decision to shoot much of his new solo Channel 4 show there, but Madonna is confident a global audience will enjoy his humour. 'You don't have to be British to get Ali G. Americans do understand irony. Ali G is comparable to Jim Carrey or Ben Stiller,' Norman said.

It is not the first time Madonna, who is having her second child with British film director Guy Ritchie, has cast TV or film-stars in her videos. She lap-danced with Austin Powers star Mike Myers in 'Beautiful Stranger'. In her latest film she cavorts with gay British star Rupert Everett as she sings the Don McLean 70s hit 'American Pie'.

Ali G has appeared with music stars in his new series using his 'mad mixing skills' to 'improve' songs by Supergrass, Chrissie Hynde and Travis.
