webTitle: Can New York's Giuliani win the sympathy vote?

fields.headline: Can New York's Giuliani win the sympathy vote?
fields.standfirst: Even his Senate election rivals are finding it hard to knock the stricken Mayor, reports  Melinda  Wittstock
fields.trailText: Even his Senate election rivals are finding it hard to knock the stricken Mayor, reports  Melinda  Wittstock
fields.body:
The disclosure that New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani has prostate cancer has plunged the most highly charged political battle in recent American history into a state of suspended animation, as the mayor ponders his political future.

Republicans are in a panic about the prospect of facing Democratic contender Hillary Clinton in November without their star candidate on the ballot for the US Senate. Democrats are in a spin about how to attack a man they see as nasty, cold-hearted and vindictive, without taking any political flak for aiming below the belt.

Buoyed by a swell of newfound sympathy, Giuliani returned to the campaign trail on Friday, heading upstate to a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinner in Saratoga, his aides insisting it was 'full speed ahead' for his Senate bid.

A day earlier, standing alone at a podium in City Hall's Blue Room with news of his battle with the disease that killed his father, Giuliani's equivocal comments on the status of his senatorial ambitions had led many to believe that he'd soon be out of the running.

'I hope that I'd be able to run,' said the mayor, 'but the choice that I'm going to make about treatment is going to be contingent upon the treatment that gives me the best opportunity to have a full cure. After I determine that, then I will figure out, does it make sense this year, or doesn't it. I don't think it's fair to answer questions about the Senate race right now.'

With the First Lady ahead in the polls for the first time in months, following Giuliani's insensitive handling of yet another unarmed black man's death by a NYPD bullet, and the mayor also under political fire - even within his own party - for not campaigning enough, it was only a matter of minutes before political pundits were buzzing with possible replacement candidates.

'We're on the verge of panic,' said Republican strategist Jay Severin, one of many insiders to acknowledge that the party's over if Giuliani makes an exit. 'No question, Giuliani is going to be under a lot of pressure to run.'

Doctors say whatever therapy Giuliani chooses it will interrupt his campaigning temporarily but should not prevent his run for the Senate. Dr Michael Droller, chair of urology at Mount Sinai Hospital Centre, says that Giuliani 'could resume his mayoral duties and campaigning about three weeks after surgery or during radiation treatments'. David McLeod, chief urologist at Walter Reed Army Medical Centre, who operated on Senator Bob Dole for prostate cancer, says that, if Giuliani is treated 'this early in the campaign schedule, by midsummer he should be able to hit his stride'.

On Friday, after Rick Lazio, his main rival, phoned Giuliani to say he wouldn't challenge him, the mayor started to sound like he plans to be up and running, telling CBS News his campaign schedule would be 'a little lighter - I'll eliminate half the events, or something like that'.

Pundits agree that, if Giuliani gets a clean bill of health and deals with the issue openly as he did at his Thursday news conference, there should be little lasting political fallout. 'There will be scrutiny - and sympathy - and then the campaign will continue,' says Republican consultant Joseph Mercurio.

On the plus side for Giuliani, he gets a chance to appear a more sympathetic figure, complicating the First Lady's efforts to portray the combative Giuliani as temperamentally unsuited to the Senate. Republican consultant Nelson Warfield believes 'he could emerge as an inspirational figure: the man who beat cancer'.

The wave of sympathy which has swept over even the city's most liberal media has been mirrored by the reactions of his most bitter opponents: Hillary Clinton wished him well at a news conference, and the black community leader, the Rev Al Sharpton, did the same from his pulpit, even though he leads daily protest marches against the mayor.

Even Ed Koch, former mayor and author of Giuliani: Nasty Man, who predicted a month ago that Giuliani would abandon his Senate run, told the New York Times that he hoped the mayor would continue because it would 'be better for the mayor to be out there slugging away'.

fields.headline: Childcare study boosts back-to-work mothers
fields.trailText: Working parents of small children need feel guilty no longer following a major new study on childcare.
fields.body:
Working parents of small children need feel guilty no longer following a major new study on childcare.

The survey of 1,300 children in the United States, one of the largest undertaken, reveals that even babies under 12 months are unharmed by a mother's early return to work, provided the childcare is of sufficiently high quality and parents are happy with the choice. The findings suggest mothers should worry less about whether to work and more about the quality of the arrangements they make.

In a review of latest research, including the US study, Tony Munton of the Institute of Education found overwhelming evidence that good childcare does not dilute the bond between mother and baby. While children need to develop close relationships in early life, they can happily form 'a number of close attachments', he says.

But the evidence is that 'continuity and stability' of childcare arrangements are important. A succession of informal arrangements was likely to stress both parents and children. At present, children typically have experienced six or seven different care arrangements before age of five.

Munton also found that children whose parents were under stress at work or unhappy with the arrangements made for their children, were more likely to suffer than those who were happy with their decision to return to work.

The review was undertaken for the Childcare Commission, chaired by Harriet Harman, MP, who yesterday told The Observer she hoped crude rows over whether woman should or should not work would now stop. 'That debate is now bankrupt,' she said. 'Mothers can heave a sigh of relief in that the political agenda will not be about judging them but about supporting them and helping them break through the guilt barrier. Very few women have a choice about whether they work and most have been both a stay-at-home and a working mother. We must move on to help them get good childcare and be good parents.'

Munton says the new findings are consistent with the widely reported British study undertaken last year by Heather Joshi, which showed that children over the age of one could benefit if mothers went out to work. Munton reports that new research goes further. The ongoing longitudinal study of 1,300 young children, conducted by the US National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, found that 'childcare in the first year of life doesn't have a direct effect on attachment security'.
fields.bodyText: Working parents of small children need feel guilty no longer following a major new study on childcare. The survey of 1,300 children in the United States, one of the largest undertaken, reveals that even babies under 12 months are unharmed by a mother's early return to work, provided the childcare is of sufficiently high quality and parents are happy with the choice. The findings suggest mothers should worry less about whether to work and more about the quality of the arrangements they make. In a review of latest research, including the US study, Tony Munton of the Institute of Education found overwhelming evidence that good childcare does not dilute the bond between mother and baby. While children need to develop close relationships in early life, they can happily form 'a number of close attachments', he says. But the evidence is that 'continuity and stability' of childcare arrangements are important. A succession of informal arrangements was likely to stress both parents and children. At present, children typically have experienced six or seven different care arrangements before age of five. Munton also found that children whose parents were under stress at work or unhappy with the arrangements made for their children, were more likely to suffer than those who were happy with their decision to return to work. The review was undertaken for the Childcare Commission, chaired by Harriet Harman, MP, who yesterday told The Observer she hoped crude rows over whether woman should or should not work would now stop. 'That debate is now bankrupt,' she said. 'Mothers can heave a sigh of relief in that the political agenda will not be about judging them but about supporting them and helping them break through the guilt barrier. Very few women have a choice about whether they work and most have been both a stay-at-home and a working mother. We must move on to help them get good childcare and be good parents.' Munton says the new findings are consistent with the widely reported British study undertaken last year by Heather Joshi, which showed that children over the age of one could benefit if mothers went out to work. Munton reports that new research goes further. The ongoing longitudinal study of 1,300 young children, conducted by the US National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, found that 'childcare in the first year of life doesn't have a direct effect on attachment security'.

fields.headline: Unravelling Straw's refugee crisis
fields.trailText: The NHS is recruiting frantically overseas and Jack Straw writes in your pages of 'benefits to our society of inward migration'. Surely the only sensible policy is to make the test for residence here the ability to find and hold a job.
fields.body:
Burhan Wazir has shown that it is impossible to stop the arrival of refugees (News, last week) and that, because they expect to earn their own living, changing the benefit system will be no deterrent whatever.

The UN says we need four times as many immigrants of working age to fund future pensions, the NHS is recruiting frantically overseas and Jack Straw writes in your pages of 'benefits to our society of inward migration'. Surely the only sensible policy is to make the test for residence here the ability to find and hold a job.

Indeed, Jack Straw's article seems to blow his own policy out of the water.
D. Cole
St-Leonards-on-Sea
E. Sussex

 Jack Straw (Comment, last week) warns against viewing as a race issue Government policy on refugees. It is as asylum seekers (not as black people) that he impoverishes and humiliates them; as asylum seekers (not as black people) that he sensibly and proportionately imprisons them; as asylum seekers (not as black people) that he uses them as election fodder. No one imagines Straw's treatment of refugees is motivated by a personal hatred of ethnic minorities (votes alone provide sufficient incentive).

Sadly, not everyone in Britain shares his tolerance, and not everyone will react tolerantly to Jack Straw and Tony Blair's anti-asylum seeker (but not anti-black) pronouncements. Does Jack think that in future the racist gangs, before beating up or stabbing their victims, will ask to see a birth certificate?
Tim Wright
Huddersfield

 Clearly the burdens of office haven't affected Jack Straw's sense of humour. Could this be the same Jack Straw whose Home Office Department assured us that, if white Zimbabwean farmers decided to come to Britain, the voucher and dispersal system he has just introduced for 'other' refugees would not apply to them? He might tell us why these colonial remnants should not be classified as economic migrants and whether they'll be banged up in nice new detention centres pending deportation.

Jack Straw knows as well as any, including Bernie Grant to whom he was paying tribute, that 'asylum seeker' and 'refugee' are code-words for race. By its nature, the voucher scheme will separate and mark out refugees and asylum seekers from the rest of the population... the monetary equivalent of a yellow star.

Instead of standing up to the prejudices of the tabloid press and defending the right of those who are victims of persecution to come to these shores, Jack Straw decided to run with the wind. Unfortunately, William Hague and the Tory Right have decades of experience at outflanking even the opportunists of New Labour on the subject of immigration.

What was most disgraceful about the article was that Jack Straw sought to disguise his record with the mantle of Bernie Grant.
Tony Greenstein
Brighton & Hove Unemployed Workers Centre
Brighton

 While some of us may agree with Martin Bright's description of E. Nesbit's classic story The Railway Children as 'dripping with unadulterated soppiness' (Screen, last week), I feel that his unnecessarily vehement criticism fails to point up one interesting and pertinent fact, namely that the first instinct of this middle-class family, although finding themselves in financial difficulties, was to offer help and succour to a badly-dressed, East European asylum seeker who spoke little or no English.

How different from today's well-heeled residents of the south of England who seem to echo the words of a character from another great children's classic: 'No room, no room.'
Philip Wix
Brecon
Powys

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Literary prize withdrawn for writer's 'work of fiction'
fields.body:
Literary prize withdrawn for writer's 'work of fiction'

The Jewish Quarterly-Wingate Literary Prize for non-fiction, awarded in 1997 to Swiss writer Binjamin Wilkomirski, has been withdrawn because his Fragments, purporting to be a childhood memoir of concentration camps, has 'been found to be a work of fiction'.

Fireraisers target schools

Arsonists were blamed for three fires at schools in the Glasgow area. Police have launched a major investigation. In Clydebank a building in a school for children with learning difficulties was destroyed. Police want to interview four youths seen running away from the school.

Flooding forces shutdown of National Lottery machines

Hundreds of National Lottery outlets were shut down because of flooding. Machines at 600 stores were switched off. The winning numbers were 15 16 19 27 29 42, bonus 24. Thunderball numbers were 2 8 13 14 27, Thunderball 10.

Nuns accused of cruelty

A nursing home run by nuns in Old Lenton, Nottingham, is under investigation by police after allegations of cruelty.

Crane driver killed on M40

A man was killed yesterday when the mobile crane he was driving overturned on the M40 motorway.

Anti-abortion campaign

Anti-abortion campaigners formed human chains in 85 cities and towns.

The Society for the Protection of Unborn Children, which organised the silent vigil, said 20,000 people were expected to take part.

Hundreds lined a two-and-a-half-mile route through London. A chain was formed outside the Houses of Parliament.

Sex change

A parrot called Jasper, thought by its Scarborough owners to be male, has been renamed Jasmine after laying an egg.

New weight

A 28-stone woman from Widnes, Cheshire, given £100 by the New Deal scheme to join a slimming club, has lost 13 stone and is working in a charity shop and studying.

fields.headline: Serb's rape case
fields.trailText: In Helena Smith's report (News, 16 April) on alleged victims of rape in Kosovo, she only uncovers three cases. So from whence that lurid estimate of 20,000 in the two years before Nato occupied Kosovo?
fields.body:
In Helena Smith's report (News, 16 April) on alleged victims of rape in Kosovo, she only uncovers three cases. So from whence that lurid estimate of 20,000 in the two years before Nato occupied Kosovo? Smith attributes the estimate to the World Health Organisation.

However, a call to Gamilla Backman, cited by Smith, reveals that this estimate was not the WHO's own, but one provided by local, ethnic Albanian, NGOs under the overall control of one Sevdije Ahmeti. Ahmeti, according to Backman the main source of the Kosovo mass rape tales, is a member of the 'transitional government'.

In 1998, Human Rights Watch documented just six cases of rape. During the 79-day Nato bombing campaign starting March 1999, HRW heard of another 96 claims. Perhaps other incidents went unreported. Clearly, however, the historical record contradicts the claims made at the expense of the Serbs, Europe's most targeted ethnic group.
Marko Gasic
Serbian Information Centre
London W11

fields.headline: Mobiles to carry health alert
fields.standfirst: Government experts say more research needed into threats from phone radiation, reports  Kamal Ahmed
fields.trailText: Mobile telephones, used by more than 24 million people in Britain, will have to carry health warnings after the most comprehensive safety review found public concern over their use was justified.
fields.body:
Mobile telephones, used by more than 24 million people in Britain, will have to carry health warnings after the most comprehensive safety review found public concern over their use was justified.

The Government committee on mobile phone safety, which will publish its findings next week, will demand mobile phone companies give customers more information on the dangers of radiation from handsets.

Committee members told The Observer they were angered by earlier reports that it would say mobile phones were safe.

The warnings will tell people to be cautious about where, and for how long, they use phones. 'The public must be in a position of choice,' said a source close to the committee. 'At the moment they feel in the dark. We want that to change.'

The committee of 12 experts was set up last year by then Health Minister Tessa Jowell after reports that radiation from mobiles could trigger memory loss, Alzheimer's disease and cancer. It was chaired by Sir William Stewart of Tayside University, former chief scientist to the Cabinet Office.

Its report will be handed to the Department of Health this week and published a week later. It is expected the Government will act on all its recommendations.

The report will call for national guidelines to control the construction of mobile phone masts, and stress that concern about their siting near schools and residential areas must be tackled. It will say rules on safety drawn up by the National Radiological Protection Board (NRPB) should also be tightened.

The report is unlikely to defuse public concern. This month, a Which? investigation reported that the new generation of hand-free sets, which use an earpiece so the handset does not have to be held against the side of the head, did not lower the levels of radiation for users. In some cases it increased it.

Which? refused to comment on the proposed warning labels but a spokeswoman said: 'We stand by our research into hand-free sets and shields. If people are buying these devices for health reasons, they are barking up the wrong tree.'

The Stewart committee received the report, demonstrating that heating to the brain increased with the use of some headsets, near the end of its deliberations but had 'taken strong recognition of that work', said a source.

The committee has been impressed by the government-funded research of Dr Alan Preece at Bristol Royal Infirmary. He concluded that old-style analogue cellphones raised brain temperature and temporarily improved memory, noting any change in brain activity demanded further study.

Although the committee will find no conclusive proof of health dangers from mobile phones, it will insist on more research.

The Government gives the NRPB, which paid for the Stewart committee's work, £13m each year to fund radiation research. Of that, only £1m is spent on investigating the impact of radiation from masts and a further £330,000 on the effects of mobile phones.

The NRPB is privately hoping it will benefit from a £22 billion windfall the Government will receive from the sale of third-generation mobile phone licences. The board was excluded from the final writing of the report to make it clear it had not 'captured' the Stewart committee.

webTitle: No shame in our aid programme

fields.headline: No shame in our aid programme
fields.trailText: Clare Short writes: I was extremely disappointed with your article, 'Britain slashes aid to famine-hit Ethiopia', and your associated leader, 'For our sake, don't cut third world aid' (News and Comment, 9 April). Both pieces seriously misrepresented Britain's development policy towards Africa.
fields.body:
I was extremely disappointed with your article, 'Britain slashes aid to famine-hit Ethiopia', and your associated leader, 'For our sake, don't cut third world aid' (News and Comment, 9 April). Both pieces seriously misrepresented Britain's development policy towards Africa, creating a quite inaccurate picture of our spending priorities in the region. And throughout there was the clear suggestion - quite without foundation - that British policy was driven not by a commitment to reduce poverty or suffering, but rather by my personal enthusiasm and/or prejudice towards particular countries.

You say that, 'Britain has halved its aid to Ethiopia despite a drought which has triggered the worst food shortages in the Horn of Africa since the terrible famine that killed a million Ethiopians in the mid-1980s'. There is no attempt here to distinguish between emergency aid and long-term development assistance. On emergency aid, we have provided £5 million of food aid since January - more food aid in the first quarter of 2000 than any other donor except the US.

On long-term development assistance, Britain, like other donors, has not taken on any new commitments since the start of the war between Ethiopia and Eritrea in May 1998, because we cannot have confidence that the resources allocated would not end up subsidising the war.

You also say that, 'Short is cutting Mozambique's aid budget by £24 million'. This is highly misleading. It would be fairer to say that the rate of increase in spending in Mozambique was less than planned last year. You also say, 'in the most controversial move, Short is increasing levels of aid to Zimbabwe and Sierra Leone'. In Zimbabwe, our expenditure has not been increased. As regards Sierra Leone, I see nothing controversial about supporting the peace process. Sierra Leone is one of the poorest countries in the world and its people have suffered terribly from the civil war. I am proud that Britain has played a leading role in supporting the Lome peace agreement.
Clare Short
House of Commons
London SW1

fields.headline: Global gangsters
fields.trailText: Gregory Palast's 'Inside Corporate America' column (Business, last week) was an excellent piece of investigative reporting on an issue of vital concern to everyone   who wishes to understand how, and in whose exclusive interests, our globalised capitalist economy works.
fields.body:
Although I generally hold journalists in low regard, Gregory Palast's 'Inside Corporate America' column (Business, last week) was an excellent piece of investigative reporting on an issue of vital concern to everyone who wishes to understand how, and in whose exclusive interests, our globalised capitalist economy works.

One of the reasons why the corporate gangsters who are robbing the people of Bolivia and other countries around the world get away with it is because so few people understand how the global market works.
Steve Radford
Hull

fields.headline: Pay for learning
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead and Ofsted have scapegoated teachers for two decades of relative neglect of education. This is despicable for, by blaming the teachers for the short-comings of education, they hide the irrefutable truth that our education system is chronically under-funded.
fields.body:
Martin Bright should be congratulated on his defence of 'traumatised teachers' (News, last week). Chris Woodhead and Ofsted have scapegoated teachers for two decades of relative neglect of education. This is despicable for, by blaming the teachers for the short-comings of education, they hide the irrefutable truth that our education system is chronically under-funded.

We are in the relegation zone of international Education league tables, as compared with the rest of the Western world. We spend less of our national wealth on education than all but three developed countries.

As with the NHS, only a move towards spending the average of what other nations afford education, can the situation be improved. However, this will not make us Man United but take us only to mid-table respectability.
Professor Colin Pritchard
University of Southampton

fields.headline: Oral history
fields.trailText: I qualified as a dentist in 1968. I became increasingly despondent about the quality of dentistry I saw and, in 1972, following a similar public outcry, I wrote to the press. I was immediately criticised by fellow dentists for daring to speak out.
fields.body:
Anthony Browne (News, last week) reminded me of similar stories in newspapers around 1972. I qualified as a dentist in 1968. I became increasingly despondent about the quality of dentistry I saw and, in 1972, following a similar public outcry, I wrote to the press. I was immediately criticised by fellow dentists for daring to speak out. Complaints were made to the General Dental Council and my case was heard by its preliminary proceedings committee.

I subsequently received a letter warning me about my behaviour. Shortly after this, I started to study medicine in order to get out of dentistry and now practise as a forensic psychiatrist. It is sad to see that the dental profession appears to have advanced so little over 28 years.
Peter Haydn Smith
Lewes, E Sussex

 The Observer 's assertion that 90 per cent of dental work falls below international standards is extraordinary when oral health has improved dramatically and consistently since the inception of the NHS. The real scandal in UK dentistry in the last decade is that NHS treatment has become more difficult to find - precisely because dentists are concerned about quality. We have been instrumental in encouraging a culture in which whistle-blowing on poorly performing colleagues is easier.
John Renshaw
Chair, British Dental Association Executive Board
London W1

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: The Brussels prosecutor's office has charged 10 current and former officials of the Kredietbank Luxembourg in a bank fraud probe centring on claims of money-laundering involving as much as a billion euros. The charges are denied.
fields.body:
Bank officials charged over money-laundering

The Brussels prosecutor's office has charged 10 current and former officials of the Kredietbank Luxembourg in a bank fraud probe centring on claims of money-laundering involving as much as a billion euros. The charges are denied.

Anti-Franco playwright dies

Playwright Antonio Buero Vallejo, the father of modern Spanish theatre, has died aged 83. His works History of a Stairway and In the Burning Darkness are veiled attacks on the Franco dictatorship. A death sentence imposed during the civil war was commuted.

Genocide prosecution

The UN and Cambodia have reached tentative agreement on plans to try Khmer Rouge leaders on genocide charges, according to US Senator John Kerry.

Workers in car firms protest

About 15,000 workers marched through Seoul demanding a shorter working week and opposing the sale of car firms abroad. Renault has bought Samsung while Ford and General Motors are bidding for the ailing Daewoo.

Opium war booty plea

A senior Hong Kong official urged auction houses Christie's and Sotheby's to remove from a sale of Chinese art and ceramics four treasures looted by the British and French from an imperial palace in Beijing 140 years ago during the opium wars. The houses did not say whether they would comply.

Syntax equals cash: PM

Singapore's Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong launched a 'Speak Good English Movement', warning that failure to shed 'corrupted English' could cost investment. Argot examples: 'Can or not?' (Is it possible?), and 'Don't pray-pray' (Don't play around).

Argot examples: 'Can or not?' (Is it possible?), and 'Don't pray-pray' (Don't play around).

fields.headline: Trujillo killers stripped of halo
fields.trailText: A new novel by Mario Vargas Llosa has caused controversy after the families of men who assassinated Dominican dictator Rafael Trujillo accused him of writing a book that portrayed national heroes with feet of clay.
fields.body:
A new novel by Mario Vargas Llosa has caused controversy after the families of men who assassinated Dominican dictator Rafael Trujillo accused him of writing a book that portrayed national heroes with feet of clay.

The accusations were made as the Peruvian novelist and former presidential candidate visited the Dominican Republic to promote and defend his new novel, La Fiesta del Chivo (The Goat's Party ), set during the time of Trujillo's brutal dictatorship.

Vargas Llosa spent months researching the novel about Trujillo and found that, even 39 years after his death, the Dominican Republic was still haunted by his tyranny. The author says his book, a work of historical fiction, represents the 'human truth' of Trujillo's tyranny.

But despite Vargas Llosa's reputation, his version of history is one that many Dominicans feel deeply uncomfortable with. The book has left many feeling exposed and a little embarrassed.

Trujillo governed the Dominican Republic from 1930 until 1961, when he was assassinated by a handful of conspirators. In that era, many Dominicans acquiesced with the dictatorship in order to survive.

Among those welcoming the novel is the Dominican literary critic, Carlos Francisco Elias. 'The iron curtain that we have covered ourselves with for decades has been broken,' he said.

Trujillo's legacy was a series of authoritarian administrations, fraudulent elections and a culture that reveres strongmen, including Joaquín Balaguer, a close aide of Trujillo who led the country on and off and, at 93, is running again for the presidency in May elections.

Vargas Llosa told a crowd of more than 800 that everything in the novel either 'happened or could have happened'.

Not everyone is so sure, however. Among the discontented are the family of Antonio de la Maza, one of the assassins. De la Maza's relatives took out a newspaper advertisement saying the novel would confuse younger generations who didn't live through 'the system that asphyxiated us'.

Former US Ambassador Bernardo Vega said: 'The families are not happy with the book because he treats them as humans who get drunk and cheat on their wives and have human weaknesses, rather than as the heroes we read about in history books.'

Vargas Llosa said the complaints of the families pained him. 'If I have admiration for any of the characters that figure in the novel, it is for the seven men who waited for Trujillo on the highway to San Cristóbal and killed him there.'

Vargas Llosa devotes part of the book to Balaguer, describing how Trujillo's puppet President succeeded in staying in power after the puppetmaster was dispatched. Balaguer has not commented on the book.

fields.headline: Shock tactics that finally backfired
fields.standfirst: Oliviero Toscani's stark images made Benetton a global market leader. But when his photos harmed sales in the US, he was dumped, reports Rory Carroll
fields.trailText: The controversial Italian photographer who loosed snogging priests, dying Aids victims, copulating horses and death row inmates on to an unsuspecting world in the name of selling jumpers has delivered his latest and possibly final shock.
fields.body:
The controversial Italian photographer who loosed snogging priests, dying Aids victims, copulating horses and death row inmates on to an unsuspecting world in the name of selling jumpers has delivered his latest and possibly final shock.

Oliviero Toscani yesterday split from Benetton, the fashion house that lavished on him the money, freedom and platform which saw his photographs smash taboos and revolutionise advertising.

An 18-year partnership, deemed unbreakable, has discovered that there is, after all, such a thing as going too far.

Unprecedented levels of outrage over the latest poster campaign, featuring convicted murderers on death row, is believed to have helped split a team Toscani had compared to Papal patronage of Michelangelo.

A statement from Benetton thanked Toscani for his 'fundamental contribution to "new" advertising', announced his swift departure, but gave no reasons.

Italian commentators declared it the end of an era. For while Toscani will continue to work as creative director of Tina Brown's New York magazine Talk, he almost certainly will never again reach a worldwide audience on the scale of his Benetton billboards.

Toscani once said that only Benetton had the courage to employ him. Yesterday he was in the United States and unavailable for comment. His wife Kristi, however, claimed the decision was unrelated to the backlash from the latest campaign.

'After so many years the decision was mutual,' she said. But the 59-year-old had recently spoken of future work for Benetton. Speculation suggests the firm had had enough of odium and boycotts and wanted a safer way to market its clothes.

His last campaign was the most controversial, despite others that featured genitalia, the blood spattered tee-shirt and jeans of a dead soldier and a dying Aids victim. 'Looking Death in the Face', a billboard campaign in which 26 inmates from different states in prison uniforms stare into the camera over the words 'Sentenced to Death', took two years and cost $10m. The familiar green-and-white United Colours of Benetton logo features alongside. But the company was thrown on to the defensive after howls of protest in the United States, its biggest market. Since its launch in January relatives of people murdered by the inmates have lobbied retailers and consumers to boycott its products.

They persuaded Chicago retail giant Sears, Roebuck & Co to dump Benetton in February, shocking a firm that made its name from shock.

The Sears deal had been viewed as a godsend to the company's declining US fortunes. Now the state of Missouri has filed a multi-million dollar lawsuit, claiming that Toscani and the journalist Ken Shulman pretended to be from Newsweek while taking pictures and interviewing inmates. Other states who are claiming to have been similarly hoodwinked may follow.

A recent resolution passed by the California Assembly echoed the state of Pennsylvania in asking for a national boycott. Benetton defended itself by saying the prisoner portraits were aimed 'at giving back a human face to the prisoners of death row' and not treating them as 'virtual characters eliminated or spared with a simple click'.

But as fury spread their tone changed. 'Maybe we didn't fully calculate the emotional reaction it was going to cause,' conceded spokesman Frederico Santor.

While financial results for last year announced on Friday showed a modest rise in American sales, to $260.6m, shareholders were worried about the impact on future sales. Since January Toscani has been at the eye of the storm. And loved it.

Regaling interviewers in his broken English, he took the moral high ground of opposing capital punishment and stoked the controversy with quotes he may come to regret. 'I don't have to justify myself. Controversy is very useful. It's up to the other side to justify the shit they do. It is almost a Third Reich vision in these prisons,' he declared.

Toscani said he wanted to foster debate on capital punishment even at the cost of losing business. 'Of course, that may happen. But as a result of the campaign, we may gain new customers. If advertising made everyone happy, it would be an act of hypocrisy.'

A grandfather of seven, his bravado was not always thus. He was born the son of an Italian photojournalist who photographed the dead Mussolini hanging upside down from a meat hook. Now a hulking, designer-stubbled executive, Toscani studied photography in London in the Sixties on exchange from the Kunstgewerbeschule in Zurich.

In the Seventies and early Eighties he was a fashion photographer for Vogue, Elle, Mademoiselle, Harper's Bazaar. His first ad featured his girlfriend's posterior encased in Jesus Jeans. It was banned for its slogan, 'He who loves me will follow me'.

In 1983 his work seduced Luciano Benetton, figurehead of the $2 billion Benetton empire, based in Treviso.

The first images were portraits of inter-racial relationships at a time when non-white faces were were almost invisible in advertising, but the more controversial work would follow quickly. 'You are talking with the luckiest and most privileged man ever created by God,' he once told an interviewer.

For work he was given a brightly-coloured office housed in a cream-coloured, stand-alone pavilion. The mogul told him: 'The Benetton image is your toy. Do not let anyone interfere with it, even me.' No one did. Soon he progressed to more daring images. In 1993, Aids groups in France sued over Benetton ads that showed the words 'HIV positive' on buttocks, calling them commercial exploitation of suffering. In the Nineties, the Roman Catholic Church protested a campaign that featured models dressed as a priest and a nun kissing, and human rights groups attacked ads that supposedly showed the clothing of a Bosnian war victim. Other images used included a bloodied new-born child, and horses copulating. The outrage became a permanent background buzz, but never reached the fever pitch of the death row protests.

webTitle: Ten key things about ... May Day

fields.headline: Ten key things about ... May Day
fields.trailText: According to Samual Taylor Coleridge, the ancient name for May Day was Wittlentide, 'the time of choosing the Wits, or wise men, to the Wittengermutte'. Three years to the day since Tony Blair and his team were overwhelmingly chosen for the Westminster moot we may judge just how far we've come since the dark ages of the ancients
fields.body:
According to Samual Taylor Coleridge, the ancient name for May Day was Wittlentide, 'the time of choosing the Wits, or wise men, to the Wittengermutte'. Three years to the day since Tony Blair and his team were overwhelmingly chosen for the Westminster moot we may judge just how far we've come since the dark ages of the ancients. More lightly throughout the northern hemisphere May Day is associated with festivals of fertility and renewal.

1. A May Queen was first documented in 900BC.

2. The Romans decorated their houses with branches bound with flowers and fruit.

3. Today in Provence tress are still decked with ribbons and flowers.

4. In olde Englande, young people used to go into to the woods the night before May Day, to 'bring in the may'.

5. Oliver Cromwell tried to abolish May Day in the 1640s, saying it was 'unChristian'.

6. Disraeli tried to revive ancient May Day celebrations as part of a vision of the English rural idyll.

7. Adopted by Socialists as a day to honour workers in 1889.

8. Made a Bank Holiday in 1975 by Michael Foot, then Employment Secretary to honour the International Labour Movement.

9. Song c1670: 'Come lasses and lads, get leave of your dads,/And away to the Maypole hie,/for every he has got him a she,/And the fiddler's standing by'

10. Send a May Day card: http://www.cardville.com/maydayz.htm

webTitle: Busted: The world's biggest Ecstasy haul

fields.headline: Busted: The world's biggest Ecstasy haul
fields.standfirst: A young British jetsetter who has just become son-in-law to a duke could face 20 years in jail if found guilty of trafficking 330,000 pills, allegedly seized from his car boot
fields.trailText: A young British jetsetter who has just become son-in-law to a duke could face 20 years in jail if found guilty of trafficking 330,000 pills, allegedly seized from his car boot
fields.byline: Jason Burke and Duncan Campbell, Los Angeles. Philip Willan, Rome
fields.body:
This is a story that links two continents, four police forces, a disgraced British duke, an Australian soap star, a cocaine dealer called Gerald, a London socialite and the world's biggest Ecstasy bust. The saga starts in Hollywood and ends, via London and Amsterdam, in the small Italian beach resort of Lignano where, on a cold Easter Monday evening last week, local police found two Nike hold-alls containing 333,000 distinctive pastel-coloured pills in the boot of a sporty little Lancia.If the consignment had got through to its destination - the streets of Los Angeles - it would have brought in nearly £7 million.

The bust was the end of a two-month investigation for the police and the beginning of a nightmare for a well-heeled young Englishman, Alex Bruell, 26, one of two men now in police custody in the Adriatic resort of Trieste, where they were charged yesterday with drug trafficking. The pair now face jail sentences of 20 years.

Bruell was born in Bournemouth but raised in Beverly Hills by his father, then an eminent Hollywood psychologist. His mother, Biba Hiller, a Knightsbridge-based property dealer and socialite, last week became the fourth wife of Angus Charles Drogo Montagu, 12th Duke of Manchester. The Duke was recently released from a prison in Florida where he had been serving a three-year sentence for fraud.

This weekend Hiller, speaking from a luxury hotel while on honeymoon in Jersey, told The Observer her son, educated at top private schools in Beverly Hills and Britain, was 'naive but not a criminal'.

'He has everything going for him and has never been in any trouble before,' she said.

The new duchess said Bruell had recently been licensed by police in London to work in the security industry. Her husband said : 'I believe he is the fall guy for others. He has been exploited.'

The other suspect is 30-year-old Australian Simon Main, believed to be the stepson of an Australian quiz show host and filmstar. Main is based in Beverly Hills where he claims to be a journalist. The Italian police say he has asked Robert Shapiro, the Los Angeles-based lawyer who helped get O. J. Simpson acquitted of murdering his wife, to represent him. Shapiro's office refused to comment last week. Main is understood to deny all the allegations against him.

Bruell appears to have less illustrious legal representation, making do so far with a court-appointed local lawyer.

Police say the Briton broke down in tears within hours of his arrest. He then outlined, they say, details of one of the most ambitious drug-smuggling operations ever.

Bruell is thought to have met Main on a recent trip to California. The Australian gave police an address in the suburb of Studio City, but it appears that he only stayed there briefly before being moved on because of his 'boisterous' lifestyle.

Somehow Bruell appears to have been sucked into the world of drug dealing. The Italian police claim he told them he became involved in a cocaine deal that went badly wrong when 14kg of the drug were stolen by an Italian criminal - 'Gerald' - who is based in Britain and has connections with major English villains.

To recoup the loss and repay his backers, police say, Bruell hatched another scheme. He travelled to Amsterdam, where Dutch contacts arranged for him to pick up 453,000 Ecstasy tablets. The cost price for Ecstasy is around 70p a pill. British customs officials are now liaising with their Dutch counterparts to track down the manufacturers.

Customs sources say that since Ecstasy fetches up to £20 a pill in the US - nearly twice the average of £11 in Britain - increasing amounts are being trafficked across the Atlantic from laboratories in Europe, particularly Holland. If all Bruell's 453,000 pills had been sold, they would have realised £9.5m.

The former security consultant next surfaced in the Adriatic resort of Lignano, the home of his fianceé. By the time they were on to him, police say, he had already sent more than 120,000 of the pills to America. Some went in a Federal Express parcel, others were shipped in a consignment of furniture. The police - tipped off, they say, by an underworld informant - put Bruell under surveillance and began monitoring his mobile telephone calls. 'We created an invisible cage around him,' said Frederico Frezza, the Italian investigating magistrate who ran the operation.

Bruell appears to have been something of an amateur. His 6ft 4in frame was obvious in the bars and clubs of the small Italian resort. A squad of 25 Italian police tracked him everywhere, even on the beach. They rented a flat near the modest three-bedroomed apartment he was living in, and hired and borrowed dozens of cars to follow him inconspicuously.

Many of the calls Bruell made, police say, were to Main, who had arrived in Rome from California. For weeks the two argued over where the handover of the drugs would take place, the police say, though their conversations were discreet and gave nothing away.

'All the phone conversations were conducted as if they knew they were being intercepted,' said Colonel Carlo Germi of the surveillance squad. 'They gave no details of their appearance or information about their location.'

Main wanted to meet in the attractive Tuscan towns of Lucca or Pisa. Bruell refused to move so far from his base with 80kg of Ecstasy in his car. Finally the two met outside the pizzeria in Lignano. It was an astonishing lapse of security. The two men were tall, fair, tanned, muscular, very good-looking and very conspicuous. They attracted a lot of attention. 'They were fantastic,' one female admirer later told police.

For an hour the pair argued, say the police, then Bruell agreed to collect the drugs from his home and hand them over.

At 9pm the police say they watched him park his sporty Lancia in the pizzeria carpark. Main, perhaps spooked by the Easter holiday crowds on the streets, wanted to move on again. Fearing that they would lose them, the police made a snap decision to move in. They swooped, arrested the pair and found, in two bags in the boot of the car, the biggest pile of Ecstasy any of them had ever seen. But there remain a number of loose ends. Main was equipped with a two-way radio with an earpiece and GSM positioning device. Police say he was getting instructions from a man called Dave throughout the operation. He is believed to be an American, and the US Drugs Enforcement Agency is investigating. So far all attempts to track down 'Dave' have failed.

Additional reporting: Tracey McVeigh

If all Bruell's 453,000 pills had been sold, they would have realised £9.5m. The former security consultant next surfaced in the Adriatic resort of Lignano, the home of his fianceé. By the time they were on to him, police say, he had already sent more than 120,000 of the pills to America. Some went in a Federal Express parcel, others were shipped in a consignment of furniture. The police - tipped off, they say, by an underworld informant - put Bruell under surveillance and began monitoring his mobile telephone calls. 'We created an invisible cage around him,' said Frederico Frezza, the Italian investigating magistrate who ran the operation. Bruell appears to have been something of an amateur. His 6ft 4in frame was obvious in the bars and clubs of the small Italian resort. A squad of 25 Italian police tracked him everywhere, even on the beach. They rented a flat near the modest three-bedroomed apartment he was living in, and hired and borrowed dozens of cars to follow him inconspicuously. Many of the calls Bruell made, police say, were to Main, who had arrived in Rome from California. For weeks the two argued over where the handover of the drugs would take place, the police say, though their conversations were discreet and gave nothing away. 'All the phone conversations were conducted as if they knew they were being intercepted,' said Colonel Carlo Germi of the surveillance squad. 'They gave no details of their appearance or information about their location.' Main wanted to meet in the attractive Tuscan towns of Lucca or Pisa. Bruell refused to move so far from his base with 80kg of Ecstasy in his car. Finally the two met outside the pizzeria in Lignano. It was an astonishing lapse of security. The two men were tall, fair, tanned, muscular, very good-looking and very conspicuous. They attracted a lot of attention. 'They were fantastic,' one female admirer later told police. For an hour the pair argued, say the police, then Bruell agreed to collect the drugs from his home and hand them over. At 9pm the police say they watched him park his sporty Lancia in the pizzeria carpark. Main, perhaps spooked by the Easter holiday crowds on the streets, wanted to move on again. Fearing that they would lose them, the police made a snap decision to move in. They swooped, arrested the pair and found, in two bags in the boot of the car, the biggest pile of Ecstasy any of them had ever seen. But there remain a number of loose ends. Main was equipped with a two-way radio with an earpiece and GSM positioning device. Police say he was getting instructions from a man called Dave throughout the operation. He is believed to be an American, and the US Drugs Enforcement Agency is investigating. So far all attempts to track down 'Dave' have failed. Additional reporting: Tracey McVeigh

webTitle: Exposed: MoD nuclear dump at Southend

fields.headline: Exposed: MoD nuclear dump at Southend
fields.standfirst: Consortium 'paper deal' with Ministry avoided the need for public consultations.
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence covered up the secret disposal of radioactive material near a popular seaside resort, The Observer has learned.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence covered up the secret disposal of radioactive material near a popular seaside resort, The Observer has learned.

Confidential documents show the MoD has acted to prevent the public knowing the fate of high-explosive components of British nuclear warheads once they have been removed from old weapons. Until today the destination of these explosives, contaminated with radioactive material, has never been made public.

The documents detail how since the Eighties, explosives from the old free-fall W177 atomic bombs and Polaris nuclear missiles have been taken to a site in Shoeburyness near Southend-on-sea on the Essex coast run by the Defence Evaluation and Research Agency. The explosives, used to trigger the nuclear explosion in a warhead, are then detonated.

The MoD has never told the local community that radioactive material is involved. It recently sold land next to the Shoeburyness site for housing and farming.

The documents reveal that the MoD worked with the private owners of Aldermaston - the Berkshire base that builds Britain's atomic weapons - to conceal facts from the public, fearing a backlash by those living close to the Essex site. By law, any company that wants to dispose of radioactive material must get authorisation from the Environmental Agency, involving a public consultation.

To avoid the risk that it would not get this approval, the private consortium running Aldermaston undertook a 'paper transaction' giving the MoD temporary ownership of the contaminated explosives. This was done because the MoD is exempt from laws covering radioactive substances and can dispose of the material without consulting the public.

In the words of the document: 'MoD has been involved primarily to make obtaining an Environment Agency licence easier.' The secret report explains: 'What the MoD had done is take ownership of material on paper, so the Environment Agency request can be processed and avoid the "public comment" phase. On a government-to-government permit, public interaction is not required.This allows the permit to be processed in much less time and reduces the risk that it might not be approved. However, AWE plc [the private group running Aldermaston] still does the work and funds most of the activity under the existing contract.' In April the contract to run Aldermaston was transferred from AWE plc to a consortium involving British Nuclear Fuels and US giant Lockheed Martin.

The documents are written by senior directors of the new consortium and headed 'restricted'. Dated a week before the changeover, they run through items that might have an effect on the firm's profits. Discussing what the impact would be if the MoD withdrew from the ploy, the report concludes it 'would put the means of destruction in the public domain and approval would not be won easily or quickly'.

Sir Teddy Taylor, MP for Southend, was horrified when The Observer showed him the documents. He has demanded an explanation from Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon and wants an urgent meeting with the minister and the local community.

Taylor said: 'I find this very frightening. Why have we never been told this is happening? I want assurances that the process is 100 per cent safe and that there are no potential health issues involved.'

Southend Councillor Verena Wilson said: 'I am horrified that in this day and age local people have not been told what is happening on their doorstep. If it is all safe and there is nothing to worry about, why have they hidden it from us for all these years?'

Officially, the MoD refused to confirm that it detonates radioactive-contaminated explosives at the Shoebury ness site, saying activities there are 'top secret'. But an MoD spokesman anxious to play down fears stressed that the level of radioactive material was 'minute' and the detonations were 'totally safe' and carried out with Environment Agency approval.

But Di Macdonald of the Nuclear Infomation Service believes the cumulative effects of releasing radioactive material into the environment over 20 years could pose health risks. She said: 'If there is no problem with this method of disposal, why have they tried to hush it up? They knew if the public ever found out what they were up to there would be an uproar.'

Ian Jackson, the Environment Agency inspector in charge of the atomic weapons establishment at Aldermaston, stated the levels of radiation involved were small but refused to say there was no risk to public health at all.'The explosives are contaminated with the radioactive gas tritium. While this is at a low level, there are no completely safe minimum levels of exposure to any radioactive material. It would be much better if the whole process was put into the public domain.'

fields.headline: Science finds weight of world
fields.trailText: It's a small world, or at least, a smaller world than we once thought. New calculations which have got physicists 'falling off their chairs' reveal the Earth's mass to be 8 - followed by 21 zeroes - kilograms lighter.
fields.body:
It's a small world, or at least, a smaller world than we once thought. New calculations which have got physicists 'falling off their chairs' reveal the Earth's mass to be 8 - followed by 21 zeroes - kilograms lighter.

After four years and thousands of dollars of work, two University of Washington scientists claim we can now say that the planet weighs 5,972,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 kgs - or 5.972 sextillion metric tonnes for short. That's one trillion metric tonnes of earth and rock and molten metals each for every man, woman and child on the planet.

The breakthrough is to be announced tomorrow at the American Physical Society. The two physicists, Dr Stephen Merkowitz and Professor Jens Gundlach, believe they have come up with the most precise measurement yet for the force responsible for the fate of the cosmos. Known as 'Big G', it is the gravitational constant which affects every planet.

While the speed of light and sound have all been understood for years, gravity has eluded science. Knowing it enables the weight of the planet to be calculated. For astronomers and physicists the breakthrough is earth-shattering.

UK physicist Dr Clive Speake of Birmingham University said the discovery was of the 'type that makes you fall off your chair'.

'The Big G is the holy grail of physics, the last frontier. It's a fundamental constant of nature that we know least accurately. 'We will have to wait and see if they are right because, in a nutshell, this is the first time anyone has claimed such a high accuracy of measurement, although this game is littered with people who have tried.'

Gundlach said: 'Gravity is the most important large-scale interaction in the universe, there's no doubt about it. It is largely responsible for the fate of the universe.' But the calculation is not likely to affect the day to day life of the average person, he admits.

'Knowing the value of G won't make better cell phones. However, it's something that mankind should know because it's so fundamental.'

webTitle: In the office or at home, parent stress hurts kids

fields.headline: In the office or at home, parent stress hurts kids
fields.standfirst: You need not worry or feel guilty if you opt for childcare - children just need you to be happy, says Maureen Freely
fields.trailText: Do children suffer when their mothers work, or do they thrive? Hardly a month goes by without a study establishing beyond doubt that children who are put into nurseries by their working mothers (a) grow up to be emotional and educational cripples, or (b) are the luckiest, most talented and resilient creatures who ever lived.
fields.body:
Do children suffer when their mothers work, or do they thrive? Hardly a month goes by without a study establishing beyond doubt that children who are put into nurseries by their working mothers (a) grow up to be emotional and educational cripples, or (b) are the luckiest, most talented and resilient creatures who ever lived.

It's an either/or debate that has had a pernicious effect. Whatever parents decide - to stay at home full-time, to work part-time, full-time, or overtime, to put their children into nurseries occasionally or all day long or use no childcare at all - one group of 'experts' will say it is the wrong choice.

But maybe both sides of the debate have got it wrong. According to Ellen Galinsky of the New York-based Families and Work Institute, maternal employment is not the all-determining factor we thought it was. What counts is not if a mother works but how she works. And how a father works counts as much.

If mothers and fathers are stressed at work they will 'bring their work home with them'. But (as common sense suggests, and research can now confirm) if they are in happier jobs in which they enjoy a degree of autonomy, they have more energy for their children when they get home. And their children are the better for it.

The evidence from a large study by the US National Institute of Child Health and Human Development is that children do best when their mothers can choose whether to work or stay at home. Having been able to make a positive choice about the arrangements that best suit them and their families, they are, miraculously, more effective as parents.

The study has also found that, while good childcare can have a small positive effect on children's cognitive development, the quality of family life continues to be the most important influence on a child's development.

Family life does not just depend on love, but also on money. The biggest single risk factor when assessing a child's chances in life turns out to be poverty. Common sense suggests all this, but why has it taken so long to find its way into serious research?

Tony Munton of the Institute of Education says John Bowlby is to blame. Dr Bowlby is the originator of attachment theory which grew out of work he did after World War II with children in institutional care. Having found their emotional and intellectual development was impaired, he concluded that 'a child's development is contingent on exclusive maternal care, that maternal separation from the child disrupts the attachment process, and that, therefore, mothers with young children should not work'.

Policy-makers trying to find jobs for men returning from the war took to the theory with enthusiasm. Women had taken over many jobs and, if they did not now step out of them, the country would have a problem. According to Dr Munton, attachment theory 'gave a theoretical justification to the argument that mothers should not work'. It influenced policy makers the world over. In 1951 the World Health Organistion went so far as to say that the use of day nurseries would cause 'permanent damage to the emotional health of a future generation'.

Attachment theory has continued to influence policy on mothers' working, though it has had a shakier career in the academic world. Bowlby's research was about children in residential care. Studies of children in daycare have not uncovered the same problems. Munton notes that Bowlby's ideas on the need for the mother to be exclusive carer were not confirmed by a review of 186 non-industrial societies, where only five had mothers as exclusive carers.

According to Michael Rutter of the Institute of Psychiatry in London, children 'can cope well with several adults caring for them, provided it is the same adults over time and provided that the individuals with whom they have secure relationships are available at times when they are tired, distressed or facing challenging circumstances'.

These secure relationships do not need to take place inside a home. There is no reason why a child could not also enjoy the same benefits when in the care of trained professionals. Even so, it would be silly, even dangerous, to deduce from this that 'children of working mothers thrive' or that childcare is 'good for children'. It's only good if it is, well, good .

But knowing that does not answer the important question. What sort of life do we want for our children, at home and outside, during their early years? How much time do we want them to spend outside the home? How much time do we want to spend with them? When should they start formal education? Now that research has shown how important informal play is, should we put kids into school at four?

These are the sorts of practical, forward-looking questions that we need to be asking if we are going to 'get childcare right'. They are urgent questions, says Anne Longfield of the Kids' Clubs Network. More than half of mothers whose youngest child is under five are now economically active, and 79 per cent of mothers whose youngest child is between five and 10, now work. Most have no choice: it is that or poverty.

Quality is important to all working parents when making childcare arrangements, but in practice they are seldom in a position to insist on it. Demand far exceeds supply. Only 10 per cent of under-eights have access to a registered childcare place. Fewer than 3 per cent of 4-14 year olds have access to out-of-school childcare or holiday playschemes.

And yet 80 per cent of working families use childcare. Two-thirds of children under five spend time in the care of adults who are not their parents. Most of these adults are not trained professionals but relatives, neighbours, and unregistered, untrained childminders. Most families have no choice but to resort to 'informal' care arrangements. With private nurseries charging roughly the same as private schools, most families would not be able to afford formal childcare even if it were available. So they make do with the resources they have to hand.

While 'informal care' can be a good thing (as in the case of a doting grandmother) it can also mean leaving children with people who have little understanding of children and may even be a danger to them. But much of the registered care on offer is also poor. No working parent can breathe easily until all childcare workers are held to consistent and enforceable standards.

The clunkily named National Childcare Strategy is a vast initiative that aims to create childcare places for up to a million children, 20,000 new out-of-school clubs, and 60,000 new playworker and childcare jobs.

It hopes to offer one million children 'safe and enjoying learning opportunities', support one million parents to work or train, and help a quarter of a million parents move off benefits.

Its mantra is quality, quality, quality. Get childcare right, and we'll see less delinquency in adolescence and happier, higher achieving adults and all of society will benefit. The key concept is continuity. At present, says Dr Munton, a child will have been through as many as seven or eight different child care arrangements by the age of five, and 'that's not good'. Childcare services should be designed so that children don't lose touch with the carers they love and trust on a routine basis. This is one of the reasons why in the 25 Centres of Excellence that the Government has set up to date, the aim is to provide childcare from birth to age 14.

But even the highest quality childcare services are worthless unless they fit in with the way we work. They have to suit shift workers and short-term contract workers, and parents who work long or anti-social hours - not just the lucky few who are still in stable 9-to-5 jobs.

So to get childcare right, you have to push for serious changes in the work world, too. According to Munton, the National Childcare Strategy is the most radical piece of legislation we've seen in this country since the formation of the Welfare State. 'But the majority of people don't know about it.'

What we need, according to Munton and Galinsky and their fellow campaigners, is to throw out the old debate and begin a new one.

The first challenge is to make sure children get the best possible environments wherever they are. The second challenge is to make sure that working parents have access to high quality services they can afford. The third is to make sure that childcare is not compulsory.

It is important, says Lucy Daniels, Associate Director of the Work/Life Research Centre, that parents do not allow themselves to be turned into wage slaves. There is always the danger that a vast supply of high quality childcare might give parents less leverage when arguing for flexible, family-friendly work patterns.

But parents and children of all ages need family time, and parents with very young children should be able to stay at home with their children for extended periods without having to suffer the severe economic setbacks they do today. The National Childcare Strategy needs to go hand in hand with some sort of National Workplace Strategy.

The idea that childcare is not just a private responsibility but also a social one has become a minority view. The majority think mothers who involve others in the care of their children are mothers who are not doing their job, and that Government should not spend money to let them off the hook.

According to Daniels, the main challenge is to make the case that 'good childcare, like good health and education, is good for society'. This sounds like yet another piece of common sense. Caring for children means caring for the next generation: it is in everyone's interest we do the job well.

The National Childcare Strategy needs to go hand in hand with some sort of National Workplace Strategy. The idea that childcare is not just a private responsibility but also a social one has become a minority view. The majority think mothers who involve others in the care of their children are mothers who are not doing their job, and that Government should not spend money to let them off the hook. According to Daniels, the main challenge is to make the case that 'good childcare, like good health and education, is good for society'. This sounds like yet another piece of common sense. Caring for children means caring for the next generation: it is in everyone's interest we do the job well.

webTitle: A very English battle for equality on the fairways

fields.headline: A very English battle for equality on the fairways
fields.standfirst: How two women have found themselves pilloried for taking a stand against the small-minded prejudices at the golf club they adore : 'I have actually been told, on the course on a Sunday, that I shouldn't be here, I should be at home getting the roast ready for my man'
fields.trailText: How two women have found themselves pilloried for taking a stand against the small-minded prejudices at the golf club they adore : 'I have actually been told, on the course on a Sunday, that I shouldn't be here, I should be at home getting the roast ready for my man'
fields.body:
'Sir,' thundered the letter to the Telegraph. 'If women such as Bridget Malin want equality with men on the golf course they must play off the same tees, participate in humorous banter before and during a game, and be prepared to forgo a shower to be first in the bar to buy the drinks.

'Above all they must know the answer to every major world problem. I once played with a woman during the era of Chairman Mao, and on the fifth hole asked her what she thought of Red China. "Well," she said, "It looks lovely on a white tablecloth." '

It was quite brilliant, self-stereotyping worthy of Basil Fawlty's resident poltroon, Major Gowen, and Bridget and Barbara can't stop laughing. They're also happy to recognise that tongue was at least partially inside cheek, a welcome respite: for before us lies correspondence and transcripts that show how monstrously vicious, how quite absurdly poisonous and petty and humourless the little world of English golf can be. The little world which still, despite everything, they love.

It was only last month that Bridget, a 53-year-old legal executive, decided, rather reluctantly, to go public on what she called 'the most backward golf club in England', Gay Hill in Wythall, near Birmingham. She and Barbara had been members for years and, because they loved the course, they had put up with the outdated gender discrimination (private clubs, remember, were exempted from the 1976 Act).

They had put up with the men-only bars. They had laughed at the way in which the Gay Hill men once, during a period of refurbishment to the 'public' room, i.e. the only one in which women were allowed to drink, allowed them only half-way into 'their' bar, painting a white line on the floor to stop the jezebels coming closer. They'd accepted, reluctantly, the fact that they, being women, could only tee off at 12 at weekends (the only times they could play, working as they do full-time in children's law), no matter that the tees lay empty before them.

They had just giggled at the dress codes - no shorts in the clubhouse, no jeans at any time, and women ('Ladies,' stressed Bridget with a wide smile. 'In golf, we're always ladies. Whatever they are.' For we are, of course, deep in Al Murray's Pub Landlord world, where it's always a small libation for the good lady wife) strictly banned, at one stage, from wearing 'trousers with stirrups'. (What? Why? Why ?)

When the club decided, how ever, to up everyone's fees to pay for a £300,000 facelift for the men's bar and changing rooms, Bridget spoke out. She was practically ignored by the committee, she said, and told to stop 'hijacking' the meeting for her own feminist ends. 'It was at that point I realised, finally, that things were never going to change. I had hoped, many of us had hoped, it would change organically, and become less unfair, as many, many clubs have in recent years; but at that moment I just knew nothing would ever happen, unless someone made it happen.'

She spoke to the local press, suggesting she might oppose the forthcoming drinks licence on the grounds of sexual discrimination. She landed, solidly, in the rough. Her mixed-doubles partner told her he could no longer play with her. Abusive and threatening phone calls began. The club is now riven with bitchy gossip, nearby clubs are apparently being encouraged to blackball her should she ever apply, and a serious, horrible froideur descends, of the kind that the very smallest of English minds can manage so well, when she and Barbara turn up with their clubs. The pair now find themselves near the forefront of MP Robert Walters' campaign to alter legislation on private clubs. They are revered by women nationally; and reviled on their own course.

It seems, at first, a simple story of stereotypes. The gin-swilling, pastel-tied, upper-middle misogynists of the club. The lone stroppy woman. And on the telephone Bridget had the clipped tones that suggested one of those terribly golfy women with sturdy calves, a tankard behind the bar and just the faintest hint of a luxuriant handlebar moustache.

The first surprise is her humour. She's a very sharp, very funny, very passionate woman. The second surprise is Barbara, her partner in every sense. Seven years younger, the gentler of the two, she is a solicitor in the same practice. They work together, golf together, and they have lived together almost 20 years now. A surprise, I say, because, as I learn more of the bitching that Bridget's been subject to I realise how brave it was for her to stand up and be counted; to do so knowing that she was likely to have the relationship with Barbara scrutinised makes it even more courageous. Nor, in terms of stereotypes, does the club really fit the bill. 'It's not, actually, that posh,' says Bridget, pronouncing it 'poash'. She is very wary of sounding snobbish, but I get the distinct impression that they feel it's because of the very fact that the club features more self-made working-class men than others that it is so rigid, so exclusive.

'It's more beer then G&T,' says Bridget. 'And the attitude to women ... well, in some of the more allegedly snobbish clubs, there's at least pride in the women, they trot them out in their finery. Here, it's more "Put on a nice Crimplene dress and try not to embarrass me too much". I have actually been told, on the course on a Sunday, that I shouldn't be here, I should be at home getting the roast ready for my man.'

'The thing is,' continues Bridget, 'I don't hate the members, of course not. We have some really good friends there. I think the feeling is split; a third are behind us. A third sort of agree, but don't think we should be making a fuss. A third hate us. But I just had to do something, had to.

'And, if I'm absolutely honest about why I did this, I suppose it's because you get to a certain age when suddenly you realise that, basically, you don't give a shit any more. What am I doing here, in a situation which represents nothing of what I believe in?'

Both had grown up attached, to varying degrees, to the women's movement, Barbara then going into law and Bridget working as a nurse. But it's not just a remembered sense of fairness that's come back to motivate them, they say; it's also a simple love of golf. 'It's such a democratic game,' stresses Barbara. 'Anyone can play. Blind people can play. People with no legs can play. You can play from the age of 5 to 95, literally.'

'Which is why it's so bloody ironic,' adds Bridget, 'that there's still this discrimination. It's nonsense. But we'll see it through, all of it. I don't want another club; I like this one. And I wouldn't like to create all this furore and then walk out on it.'

They fill me in at the end on the continuing pettinesses of the club. The tiny gossip, tiny worlds and tiny snobberies of a kind of Englishness bucking in its death throes. And yet, in the middle of it all, a smart, loyal, valiant couple who have remembered the power of another type of Englishness, the power to be different and to stand up for something to the bitter end; to decide to make a difference, to decide to remember the thoughts of youth, and decide to grow old disgracefully together.
