fields.headline: Murder blights postcard village
fields.standfirst: A model student and employee, loved by her many friends, Sara Cameron was about to start a dream job. Then a killer struck, just yards from her home.  Sarah Ryle reports
fields.trailText: Her friends should have have been celebrating a new chapter in the life of one of their best-loved colleagues. Anglo-Finnish student Sara Cameron, 23, a part-time bar worker, was due to start a new job at the Olympic Village in Sydney this weekend. Instead, 50 of her young workmates found themselves conducting a wake.
fields.body:
Her friends should have have been celebrating a new chapter in the life of one of their best-loved colleagues. Anglo-Finnish student Sara Cameron, 23, a part-time bar worker, was due to start a new job at the Olympic Village in Sydney this weekend. Instead, 50 of her young workmates found themselves conducting a wake.

They regarded themselves as her extended family, brought closer by their anti-social hours. Shutting the doors to the public, they gathered at Deep, a bar beneath the Edwardian Rex Hotel in Whitley Bay, a once elegant resort near Newcastle upon Tyne, with a reputation for lively theme pubs and clubs.

The group wondered why and how an intelligent, friendly and, above all, very normal student could end up dead in a muddy field, naked but for her socks.

'To the staff it's more like losing a sister than losing a friend,' said Mark Whitaker, assistant manager of the chain of three bars that Sara worked in on Friday and Saturday nights. 'This is the sort of thing that happens to other people, that you read about but never imagine happening to anybody you know.'

Sara was technically a foreign student, born and raised in Finland by her mother, but she gained fluent English and dual nationality from her British father, who visited her often from his home in Devon.

'Her English was better than mine,' said Mark, admitting that Sara often corrected the grammar in his Geordie dialect. She was so good at her bar job, which she had held since the group of three bars opened 18 months ago, that she had just been promoted.

Sara, due to work her last shift on Easter Monday, had completed her sports management studies at the University of Northumbria, Newcastle, and this weekend should have been arriving in Australia. She was full of her plans and, having worked as a steward at the Atlanta Olympics, knew she would have a wonderful summer.

Her colleagues found out about her death, in a field less than 50 yards from her front door, at the start of a weekend that was supposed to be the liveliest of the year. Police say there is no evidence of a 'violent sexual attack' but have not ruled out a sexual motive.

'It has been really tough on the staff, who are all completely devastated,' said Mark. 'It is not often that you can put 50 people in a room and expect them to get on as well as work together, but we all do. We are so angry and we will not stop putting Sara's picture up on the video screens in all the bars here until the killer is found.

'At first we didn't want to talk about it. We saw the tabloid headline that described her as a naked blonde and we were disgusted. People might see a pretty blonde in the picture and think "Oh yes, she was one of those types", if you know what I mean, but Sara wasn't like that. She was really intelligent. She spoke four languages. She was very studious and fretted about her studies. We called her The Liberator, because she was so into human rights. She was class.'

Her father, Roy, is so grief-stricken that he cannot face talking to anybody apart from the Northumbria police team investigating the case. Her mother, Sirpa, who travelled from Helsinki, is distraught and disorientated in a country whose language she barely knows. They issued the briefest of statements this weekend: 'There are no words that we can use to explain our grief at the loss of our only child. The flowers and love that we have received from all who knew her are overwhelming.'

Sara's house-mate, Vanessa, has left the home they shared in the quiet village of Earsdon. She has escaped the reality of waking up to a view which includes her friend's last walk and a large, floral tribute at the entrance to the tiny village. It is one of several that have sprung up in the area wherever Sara was known and loved.

There are more flowers, including Vanessa's with the simple message, 'Thanks for two years of fun', by the hedgerow where Sara's body was discovered at 9.30am on Good Friday morning by neighbours. She was first noticed by an elderly woman whose bedroom overlooked the scene.

The village nestles between sea and cornfields. Until now, Earsdon's main claim to fame was the stained glass in the parish church that originally came from the former royal palace of Hampton Court in Surrey. The church is visible from miles around. Even at midnight, when Sara made her way home from the nearby metro at Shiremoor, there would be little to alarm her.

Sara, slight but fit, trained and found time to work shifts at the Rye Hill College gym in Newcastle. Her work at the bar at the foot of South Parade had involved calming potentially difficult situations among the revellers who flood Whitley Bay. She would have dodged groups of leery, beery lads many times.

Police have reconstructed her last movements from the metro station in the former pit village. Sara walked past a row of houses and the Grey Horse pub, where landlady June Dixon knew her by sight. She didn't see Sara that night because the pub had been busier than usual and she was clearing up.

At the pub, Sara turned right. From this point she could see her house less than 150 yards away. She crossed the A186 dual carriageway to the path that runs alongside the well-lit stretch of road. Something went wrong as she took the short path up to her house. Neighbours say they heard screams but, used to hearing kids from nearby Wellfield, they did nothing.

A young man seen following Sara along the path has not been traced. There is no photofit and it is not clear whether he got off the metro with Sara at Shiremoor.

A team of 35 police officers continues to make door-to-door inquiries, returning to clarify or expand on leads. Residents are convinced it must be somebody local because Sara's clothes, or most of them, were found in a school field.

Besides, they ask, who would risk following somebody from Newcastle on the off-chance that they would be alone and vulnerable somewhere along the metro network? He was wearing trainers and jeans, they reason, so he would have been refused entry to the bar where Sara had spent the night saying farewell to her student friends.

Anger grows as residents suspect somebody is hiding the young man and, possibly, Sara's missing handbag.

Local pubs are subdued. Prayers are said in the church, and the local cab firm, somewhat sheepishly, reports booming business because people are too scared now to walk anywhere.

webTitle: Anger over asylum seekers in Ireland

fields.headline: Anger over asylum seekers in Ireland
fields.trailText: The hand-written placard was one of a number, some more overtly hostile, carried by demonstrators outside the Vee Valley Hotel in a small village in County Tipperary. It said: '40 is too many for Glogheen.'
fields.body:
The hand-written placard was one of a number, some more overtly hostile, carried by demonstrators outside the Vee Valley Hotel in a small village in County Tipperary. It said: '40 is too many for Glogheen.'

Residents of Glogheen (population 400) were protesting against the government's decision to house 40 asylum seekers in their village. Earlier last week, when the news first leaked out, there was an arson attack on the hotel where the refugees are to live. Several rooms were damaged. Not exactly Ireland of the Welcomes.

This is the latest of a series of angry protests which are causing serious alarm, as the Irish government struggles to cope with growing numbers of asylum seekers and economic migrants. This is a new phenomenon. In the past Ireland has been more accustomed to export its people looking for a chance of a better life.

Now the success of the 'Celtic tiger' economy is attracting thousands of people, mainly from Africa and Eastern Europe, to seek a new start in Ireland. Official sources in Dublin say that this year 1,000 people a week are arriving and that there is a backlog of nearly 15,000 applications for asylum.

The government's directorate of asylum services has been pathetically ill-equipped to handle this. In recent months the number of officials dealing with refugees has been increased from 22 to 300, but the general impression remains that policy is being created on the hoof and that the government is failing to explain its decisions.

The most immediate problem is housing the newcomers. John O'Donoghue, the Minister for Justice, said yesterday: 'We can't have these people sleeping on the streets.'

The government, alarmed at the growing concentration of refugees in Dublin and other large cities, has introduced a policy of dispersal. This means finding accommodation, often at very short notice, in villages where there are hotels, hostels and even sites for mobile homes.

In theory this makes reasonable sense. Many of these places are in tourist areas and empty in the winter. Their owners are happy to house refugees at the state's expense. But there has been a woeful lack of consultation with local people about the numbers involved or the services needed. There has also been little attempt to mobilise the sort of local leadership - in the churches or on councils - that might help to calm the situation.

Last week the media was full of accounts of angry protest meetings in small towns and villages across rural Ireland, though there have been objections to plans for hostels by residents in much richer suburbs of Dublin. Partly these express a fear of the unknown and many of the comments are openly racist. But there have also been more reasonable questions about the education of refugee children in local schools, the extra burden on small hospitals and so on.

For the refugees themselves the situation is even more frightening. All too often groups of people, comprising several different nationalities and unable to speak English, have found themselves housed in remote rural areas with little or no social contact with the local community.

The government's decision to replace social welfare benefits with 'direct provision' has not helped. In effect this means giving refugees full board and lodging with £15 a week as pocket money. This has led to problems acquiring familiar foods and other necessities, such as disposable nappies. Even more demoralising has been the way it has isolated refugees with other members of their own community, since even a telephone call, let alone a rail trip, to Dublin can only be got for cash.

These policies have been condemned by human rights organisations. The government defends them on the ground that Ireland must be seen to be at least as tough as Britain, to deter would-be asylum seekers from coming here. Politicians are fearful of taking on the issue which is seen as a vote loser.

There are also more hopeful signals emerging. On Wednesday four Catholic bishops issued a statement appealing for more a compassionate attitude to refugees and better treatment of those who are already here.

Two weeks ago a public meeting was held in Dublin and was packed to overflowing. Members of the audience expressed grave alarm at the thrust of the government's policy.

More important, perhaps, there have been accounts of initiatives being taken at local level to provide much needed support. English classes for adults, playgroups for children, legal help, all these were being provided on a voluntary basis in some places.

There is hardly a family in Ireland which has not had direct experience of emigration, with sons and daughters travelling to the United States and other countries, often illegally, in search of work. Irish governments have lobbied shamelessly for more generous visa allocations for these youngsters.

There is a growing feeling that perhaps the time has come to pay back some of the debt we owe to others.

It said: '40 is too many for Glogheen.' Residents of Glogheen (population 400) were protesting against the government's decision to house 40 asylum seekers in their village. Earlier last week, when the news first leaked out, there was an arson attack on the hotel where the refugees are to live. Several rooms were damaged. Not exactly Ireland of the Welcomes. This is the latest of a series of angry protests which are causing serious alarm, as the Irish government struggles to cope with growing numbers of asylum seekers and economic migrants. This is a new phenomenon. In the past Ireland has been more accustomed to export its people looking for a chance of a better life. Now the success of the 'Celtic tiger' economy is attracting thousands of people, mainly from Africa and Eastern Europe, to seek a new start in Ireland. Official sources in Dublin say that this year 1,000 people a week are arriving and that there is a backlog of nearly 15,000 applications for asylum. The government's directorate of asylum services has been pathetically ill-equipped to handle this. In recent months the number of officials dealing with refugees has been increased from 22 to 300, but the general impression remains that policy is being created on the hoof and that the government is failing to explain its decisions. The most immediate problem is housing the newcomers. John O'Donoghue, the Minister for Justice, said yesterday: 'We can't have these people sleeping on the streets.' The government, alarmed at the growing concentration of refugees in Dublin and other large cities, has introduced a policy of dispersal. This means finding accommodation, often at very short notice, in villages where there are hotels, hostels and even sites for mobile homes. In theory this makes reasonable sense. Many of these places are in tourist areas and empty in the winter. Their owners are happy to house refugees at the state's expense. But there has been a woeful lack of consultation with local people about the numbers involved or the services needed. There has also been little attempt to mobilise the sort of local leadership - in the churches or on councils - that might help to calm the situation. Last week the media was full of accounts of angry protest meetings in small towns and villages across rural Ireland, though there have been objections to plans for hostels by residents in much richer suburbs of Dublin. Partly these express a fear of the unknown and many of the comments are openly racist. But there have also been more reasonable questions about the education of refugee children in local schools, the extra burden on small hospitals and so on. For the refugees themselves the situation is even more frightening. All too often groups of people, comprising several different nationalities and unable to speak English, have found themselves housed in remote rural areas with little or no social contact with the local community. The government's decision to replace social welfare benefits with 'direct provision' has not helped. In effect this means giving refugees full board and lodging with £15 a week as pocket money. This has led to problems acquiring familiar foods and other necessities, such as disposable nappies. Even more demoralising has been the way it has isolated refugees with other members of their own community, since even a telephone call, let alone a rail trip, to Dublin can only be got for cash. These policies have been condemned by human rights organisations. The government defends them on the ground that Ireland must be seen to be at least as tough as Britain, to deter would-be asylum seekers from coming here. Politicians are fearful of taking on the issue which is seen as a vote loser. There are also more hopeful signals emerging. English classes for adults, playgroups for children, legal help, all these were being provided on a voluntary basis in some places. Irish governments have lobbied shamelessly for more generous visa allocations for these youngsters. webTitle: Orange chief threatens to walk out over sale terms

fields.headline: Orange chief threatens to walk out over sale terms
fields.trailText: Hans Snook, Orange's chief executive officer, will quit the firm if the rival operator who ends up buying the mobile phone operator doesn't share his vision for the business.
fields.body:
Hans Snook, Orange's chief executive officer, will quit the firm if the rival operator who ends up buying the mobile phone operator doesn't share his vision for the business.

Snook and his senior management team are understood to be prepared to walk if the next owner stifles the company's autonomy, attempts to impose a new management style or refuses to commit to turning Orange into a global brand. The move would be potentially devastating for any buyer because Snook is seen as integral to Orange's success. Snook is understood already to have outlined his non-negotiable view to the scores of firms who have expressed interest in Orange, including France Telecom, KPN of the Netherlands, MCI WorldCom and SBC Ameritech of the US. It is thought that MCI WorldCom is the preferred partner.

Orange is currently owned by Vodafone AirTouch which acquired the UK's third largest mobile operator as part of its recent ground-breaking deal with German conglomerate Mannesmann. Competiton regulations, however, mean Vodafone must sell Orange. Vodafone favours refloating it, to prompt a furious bidding war.

Vodafone, meanwhile, has prompted outrage from rivals when it emerged that it is to avoid paying around £360 million in interest on the third generation mobile phone licence it acquired last week.

Vodafone will pay for its licence only when it has sold Orange, also successful in acquiring a mobile licence last week. The demerger of Orange will not be completed until November at least. Vodafone will not have to pay for the two licences until the demerger. Unlike other operators, charged interest at an annual 8.65 per cent if they fail to pay for licences in full, Vodafone escapes interest charges for 180 days at around £2m a day, analysts said.

Rivals fear this will strengthen Vodafone's position in the European telecommunications market and say the Government failed to provide a 'level playing field'.

webTitle: Taxpayer gains by funding pre-school care as earnings soar and crime falls

fields.headline: Taxpayer gains by funding pre-school care as earnings soar and crime falls
fields.trailText: The Perry Preschool Study, undertaken in Michigan over a number of decades, underpins the UK's National Childcare Strategy. The much-cited Michigan study started in the Sixties and looked at the longer-term effects of good pre-school care
fields.body:
The Perry Preschool Study, undertaken in Michigan over a number of decades, underpins the UK's National Childcare Strategy. The much-cited Michigan study started in the Sixties and looked at the longer-term effects of good pre-school care. Children aged three and four were randomly assigned to an experimental pre-school group or a control group. Children were tested on entry to the project, then throughout school and again at ages 15, 19 and 27.

The preschool group had a lower rate of arrests, with only 7 per cent of the programme group arrested five or more times compared with 35 per cent of the no-programme group.

Fewer women on the programme had out-of-wedlock births compared to the other females (57 per cent against 83 per cent). The test group also enjoyed a higher rate of employment: at age 27, four times more programme participants earned $2,000 or more per month than in the control group (29 per cent against 7 per cent). Almost three times as many owned their own homes (36 per cent v 13 per cent), and more than twice as many owned two cars (30 per cent against 13 per cent).

There was also evidence of better educational achievement: 71 per cent of programme group members graduated from regular or adult high school or received General Education Development certificates, compared with 54 per cent of the non-programme group.

The return to the taxpayer of funding the pre-school group was just over seven dollars for every dollar spent.

fields.headline: 'Illegal poison' used on salmon
fields.standfirst: Chemical treatment at fish farms is hazard to health and marine life, claims ex-employee
fields.trailText: Some of Britain's most prestigious salmon farmers have been accused of using illegal toxic chemicals, which experts claim destroy the marine environment and endanger human health.
fields.body:
Some of Britain's most prestigious salmon farmers have been accused of using illegal toxic chemicals, which experts claim destroy the marine environment and endanger human health.

Jackie MacKenzie, 47, a former worker at one of Scotland's longest-established salmon farms on the northwest coast, has blown the whistle on what he calls 'disgusting and dangerous' practices.

The claims will send shock waves through the £260 million Scottish salmon farm industry, which has created thousands of jobs in rural communities but which environmentalists believe has been an ecological disaster.

Despite promotional literature on supermarket shelves showing leaping salmon and idyllic Scottish lochs, critics say the reality of Scottish salmon is thousands of fish stuffed into small pens, fed artifical colouring to make their flesh pink and dosed with chemicals to stop rampant disease.

Although there has been anecdotal evidence of illegal chemicals being used in salmon farming, until now no one involved in the industry has spoken out - because of fears of a backlash from the local community.

But in a signed statement given to The Observer , MacKenzie, who worked at Ardessie Salmon for four years, alleges he was instructed by the company to buy and use Deosect to kill sea lice, parasites that infest intensely farmed salmon.

Deosect is a highly poisonous neurotoxin developed to kill parasites on horses and chicken. It is illegal for use on fish because it can destroy aquatic habitats and is particularly damaging to crustacea such as lobsters and crabs. However, it is much cheaper than the chemical licensed for use in salmon farms.

Deosect contains high concentrations of the controversial pesticide Cypermethrin - which is used in sheep dip and some scientists claim causes sterility and cancer.

MacKenzie says he bought the Deosect from a farm supplier in Inverness and used a false name and paid cash so he could not be traced. He also claims to have bought Deosect for another salmon farmer and says 'the practice is widespread'.

Instructions that come with the pesticide warn it is dangerous to fish and advise the user not to 'contaminate ponds, waterways or ditches'.

A vet at Fort Dodge Animal Health in Southampton, a supplier of Deosect, said: 'As far as marine life goes it is about as toxic as you can get.'

MacKenzie, who has suffered from hepatitis C since a young age, believes using this chemical and another pesticide called Ivermectin exacerbated his health problems.

He said: 'We were spraying this stuff all over the fish without any protective clothing and inhaling it all.' A lot of Ardessie salmon is smoked and sold worldwide.

Following the claims, the Scottish Environment Protection Agency has begun an investigation into the company, which a spokesman said it was 'treating very seriously'. It has already prosecuted a salmon farmer in the Shetland Islands for using Deosect.

Kevin Dunion, director of the Friends of the Earth Scotland, said: 'Salmon farmers appear now to be operating outside the law, with a contempt for both the marine environment and their employees' health and safety. The Scottish Executive must instigate a thoroughgoing review of the industry.'

Today's accusations will severely embarrass Scottish Quality Salmon, the body that regulates the industry and of which Ardessie Salmon is a member. Firms that belong to the organisation can use a tartan kitemark on their salmon as a stamp of its supposed quality.

James Lindsay, chairman of the group, said: 'We will investigate these allegations and take action if they are proved to be true. But the use of illegal chemicals is very rare and this is just one farm out of hundreds.'

Lindsay stressed there was no danger to the public from eating farmed salmon, because tests were done on the fish to ensure there were no chemicals left in them by the time they reached supermarket shelves.

Norman Baker MP, the Liberal Democrats' consumer affairs spokesman, said: 'If these allegations are true, this is all very worrying.

'The industry body claims it is well regulated. But if so, how can one of its members get away with using illegal chemicals until a former employee decides to blow the whistle?

'The Government must undertake random testing of Scottish salmon to ensure this dangerous chemical is not found elsewhere.'

Environmental groups claim a disease that has destroyed large tracts of the Scottish shellfish industry is linked to chemicals used on farmed salmon.

The disease, amnesic shellfish poisoning, can be fatal to humans if they eat infected shellfish. It has plagued Scottish coastal waters for the last decade.

John Parry, owner of Ardessie Salmon, is a trustee of Wester Ross Fisheries Trust, a body set up to protect the marine environment. He refused to deny that the farm had used Deosect.

He said: 'I will not comment on that. There is an ongoing investigation by the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and I await with interest what they will find. We are a small farm and I am utterly amazed that a former employee would want to spread scare stories about the farm.'

fields.headline: £400m competitor spoils Hyder deal
fields.trailText: Japanese bank Nomura faces a rival consortium's £400 million-plus bid this week for Hyder, the floundering Welsh electricity and water utility.
fields.body:
Japanese bank Nomura faces a rival consortium's £400 million-plus bid this week for Hyder, the floundering Welsh electricity and water utility.

The new bidding group, involving United Utilities, Southern Company of the US and Barclays Private Equity, intends to break Hyder up.

The bid will be led by Western Power Distribution (WPD). Advised by City bankers Schroders, WPD plans to take over Hyder's South Wales electricity operations.

Under the plans, put to Hyder on Friday, water and sewage activities will be the subject of a buy-out backed by Barclays' venture capital arm and a management contract with Merseyside-based United Utilities.

'The announcement will be made this week. And the price will, of course, be higher than Nomura's,' one City source said this weekend.

Nomura's Principal Finance Group, headed by City whizzkid Guy Hands, swooped on Hyder with a £402m recommended bid through St David Capital, a specially formed company, a fortnight ago.

The Welsh utility has struggled under increasing debt following rapid expansion and regulatory price reviews. The firm made £208m on turnover of £1.3 billion last year, but faces falling profits in the next few years. But the board is split over the Nomura deal, with two directors, including water chief Graham Brooker, dissenting.

webTitle: Crackdown on graft in armed forces

fields.headline: Crackdown on graft in armed forces
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of RAF servicemen have been interviewed over an alleged multimillion-pound scam
fields.trailText: Hundreds of servicemen at a crucial Royal Air Force transport centre are being investigated for an alleged multi-million pound fraud as part of a crackdown on graft in the armed forces. More than 200 men at RAF Stafford have been interviewed by officers from the Special Investigations Branch (SIB), the forces' internal investigation service.
fields.body:
Hundreds of servicemen at a crucial Royal Air Force transport centre are being investigated for an alleged multi-million pound fraud as part of a crackdown on graft in the armed forces. More than 200 men at RAF Stafford have been interviewed by officers from the Special Investigations Branch (SIB), the forces' internal investigation service.

The alleged fraud centres on expenses claims entered by air force drivers, including senior non-commissioned officers, for journeys around Britain. The alleged scam is believed to have been going on for several years. Sources close to the investigation believe losses could run into millions of pounds.

The probe is one of a series that have been launched by the SIB in a bid to stamp out a culture of graft that is widespread in certain units. There are thought to be at least 15 separate inquiries looking at allegations of petty fraud.

Other investigations are thought to be focusing on allegedly fraudulent expenses claims made by air-traffic controllers co-ordinating bombing exercises in the North of Scotland and fake travel expenses entered by a number of helicopter pilots while serving in Kosovo.

The inquiries follow in the wake of a scandal involving false claims made by Tornado pilots while flying missions from Italy as part of the United Nations peace-keep ing operation during the Bosnian civil war. They were accused of unauthorised stays in luxury hotels in Venice and Florence. At least 50 officers were questioned during the inquiry. Two were eventually found guilty.

Serving soldiers speak of a 'culture of graft' in certain units. 'There are practices that have been going on for years. They are almost seen as a tradition of the regiment in some cases,' one senior non-commissioned officer told The Observer .

Others accuse the army of slack management practices. In many units cutbacks have meant regimental funds are overseen by officers with only minimal training in acccoun tancy. Expenses and other accounts are usually signed-off by direct line managers with little investigation.

The result, say observers, is that the Armed Forces are an easy target for fraudsters. Last February, Marvin Hamill, a civilian employee in the Army's pay and personnel centre in Glasgow was jailed for four years after admitting he had embezzled nearly £500,000 from the Army pension fund. What shocked many was the relative simplicity of the crime. Hamill had merely typed his details into a computer and diverted huge sums of money into his own bank account in less than a year.

The Ministry of Defence was criticised earlier this year in a National Audit Office report for poor financial management.Another NAO report, into the risk of fraud in the MoD's property management division, is expected to be critical of Ministry bureaucrats when it is published next month.

According to one solicitor with extensive experience of defending servicemen charged with fraud such incidents are increasing. 'The more people who get away with it, the more people who try it,' he said. 'There is no reliable system for checking claims that have been made. Instead, very expensive investigations are launched to pick up the pieces after the money has gone.'

The solicitor said fraud was often revealed when a servicemen was unsuccessfully investigated over an unrelated matter such as sexual misconduct or an assault. 'If the service police can't get a prosecution then their next port of call is the serviceman's file of travel and subsistence claims.'

The Army has been embarrassed by a series of scandals in recent months. Not only has it been forced to recall its main infantry rifle, the SA80, because of persistent technical problems, but it is also facing severe difficulties with its new radio system.

Cost overuns on dozens of long-term procurement projects totalled more than £2 billion last year.

fields.headline: Hounded beggars 'driven to crime'
fields.standfirst: Report claims increased public hostility has served only to aggravate existing problems
fields.trailText: A zero tolerance approach to begging would dramatically increase crime figures by forcing destitute people to turn to theft and property crime to survive, according to research to be published this week.
fields.body:
A zero tolerance approach to begging would dramatically increase crime figures by forcing destitute people to turn to theft and property crime to survive, according to research to be published this week.

The report comes as homeless campaigners say public hostility towards beggars has increased since the outcry over Romanian beggars earlier this year. New figures show people on the streets are increasingly becoming victims of physical and verbal abuse from the public. Now charities are calling on people to show more compassion and less aggression before the situation reaches boiling point.

The report into street beggars, commissioned by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, an independent charity, is expected to demonstrate that most are genuinely destitute and beg as an alternative to stealing or prostitution. The results come from interviews with the homeless.

Other organisations working in the field have welcomed the research. The policy director of the homeless charity Crisis, Kate Tomlinson, said the levels of victimisation were now unparalleled. 'There is a danger that, if things are provoked to a crisis by the increasing hostility of the public, we will see a situation that spirals out of control,' she said.

Crisis's own research shows that 78 per cent of homeless people were victims of crime the last time they slept rough. Around half had been assaulted and only a fifth of all crimes had been reported to the police. 'There is a hidden undercurrent of violence towards people sleeping rough and it is from the public,' Tomlinson said.

'Quite a lot of the abuse is when the pubs and clubs turn out at night. Someone in a sleeping bag in a doorway becomes the focus for a bit of free-floating aggression. People in this situation need to be able to trust the police rather than a situation when they are continually being arrested.'

Eugene Melanaphy, 46, backs the claims of increased violence with his own tragic story. Two years ago he was a Royal Mail worker. Single, he had a circle of friends and family and a flat in Ilford. Then Fate dealt him several blows in quick succession - redundancy, illness and eventually eviction because his housing benefit was stopped while he was in hospital with TB. The report comes as homeless campaigners say public hostility towards beggars has increased since the outcry over Romanian beggars earlier this year. New figures show people on the streets are increasingly becoming victims of physical and verbal abuse from the public. Now charities are calling on people to show more compassion and less aggression before the situation reaches boiling point. The report into street beggars, commissioned by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, an independent charity, is expected to demonstrate that most are genuinely destitute and beg as an alternative to stealing or prostitution. The results come from interviews with the homeless. Other organisations working in the field have welcomed the research. The policy director of the homeless charity Crisis, Kate Tomlinson, said the levels of victimisation were now unparalleled. 'There is a danger that, if things are provoked to a crisis by the increasing hostility of the public, we will see a situation that spirals out of control,' she said. Crisis's own research shows that 78 per cent of homeless people were victims of crime the last time they slept rough. Around half had been assaulted and only a fifth of all crimes had been reported to the police. 'There is a hidden undercurrent of violence towards people sleeping rough and it is from the public,' Tomlinson said. 'Quite a lot of the abuse is when the pubs and clubs turn out at night. webTitle: Big brains ensure survival of brightest

fields.headline: Big brains ensure survival of brightest
fields.standfirst: Evolution merely the reproduction of the most cultured
fields.trailText: Mankind is driven to paint pictures, compose sonatas and write poetry, even when such skills are redundant when it comes to the business of survival, because our ancestors chose to have babies with the most sophisticated person they could find.
fields.body:
Where women's magazines and lonely heart adverts lead, science has finally followed. A GSOH (good sense of humour) has always been the most highly rated personal attribute. Now an evolutionary psychologist has explained why. It is for exactly the same reason that peacocks have such exuberant tails.

The controversial theory - which suggests that Einstein is the ultimate sex pin-up - is 'sexual selection for cognitive abilities'. In pub terms, it's that people like smart mates.

Darwin first considered the theory, which then lay forgotten for more than a hundred years. Now it is making a comeback in a book to be published this week and explains why mankind is driven to paint pictures, compose sonatas and write poetry, even when such skills are redundant when it comes to the business of survival.

We all have more powerful and complex minds than we actually need - and vocabularies of 60,000 words when 1,000 would do - because for much of our prehistory our ancestors chose to have babies with the most sophisticated person they could find.

The Mating Mind, by Geoffrey Miller of the Centre for Economic Learning and Social Evolution at University College London, argues that our complex minds have not evolved to aid survival, but to appeal to members of the opposite sex. In other words, it's not been survival of the fittest but reproduction of the most cultured.

The theory has already drawn criticism from other scientists. 'The trouble with it is, it's untestable. I'm always very dubious about these types of hypotheses. I can't take any of them seriously,' said the celebrity geneticist Steve Jones. The theory also flies in the face of evolutionary orthodoxy - proposed by Stephen Jay Gould and others - which suggests that culture evolves on its own, separate from the evolution of the human mind.

Evolutionary biologists agree that high status individuals - namely the rich and powerful - are more likely to attract a good mate. However, Miller argues: 'A creative musician or poet can get status out of what they do, even without earning much money. I don't mean that people are attracted to the egg-heady nerdiness of Bill Gates, but intelligence that is witty, interesting, creative, and means you like being with someone.'

'You're always trying to be more sophisticated than your sexual competitors - it's an arms race,' said Miller. The result - many generations later - is that we aren't a naturally puritan or philistine species, but have a diverse and complex culture.

Poetry is good for seduction because it shows off the verbal dexterity of the wooer, and how bright he or she is. The same applies to the seductiveness of a sense of humour - it's in fact nothing to do with people liking a good laugh. 'To have humour you need to set up a mental expectation, and then violate it, which shows you have a great deal of social intelligence,' said Miller.

The theory of sexual selection of the mind - which applies to both sexes - also attempts to explain why representational paintings have traditionally been far more popular than modern abstract ones - because it more obviously shows off the artist's technical skill. 'If you can't read the artist's skill from the painting, people get frustrated,' claimed Miller.

The Mating Mind, by Geoffrey Miller, price £20, is published by William Heinemann on Wednesday.

webTitle: 'I've fought to clear my name for 50 years. Now I can see an end to it'

fields.headline: 'I've fought to clear my name for 50 years. Now I can see an end to it'
fields.standfirst: In 1952 a judge's daughter was killed and a young airman confessed. Now, reports Stuart Millar, his nightmare is nearly over
fields.trailText: In 1952 a judge's daughter was killed and a young airman confessed. Now, reports Stuart Millar, his nightmare is nearly over
fields.body:
For 47 years, Iain Hay Gordon has been haunted by the same dream. He is locked in a tiny cell filled with people. One by one, the others are released by a man going through a list of names until the only one left is Gordon. 'What about me?' he always asks. 'You're not on the list' is always the reply. At that point, he wakes up sweating and shivering from fright.

But this weekend there is fresh hope that the real ordeal which has fuelled these nightmares for almost five decades could soon be over. In 1953 the Scot confessed to one of Northern Ireland's most notorious murders after three days of near-constant interrogation by five police officers in a 12ft x 6ft room.

Now the Criminal Cases Review Commission is understood to be preparing to refer his case back to the Court of Appeal in Belfast as early as the end of May, paving the way for the overturning of what many believe to be Britain's longest-standing miscarriage of justice.

In his first full interview since details of the development emerged, the nervous, emaciated 68-year-old revealed to The Observer his growing confidence that the struggle to clear his name is nearing a successful end. 'I can see the finishing line at last. For a long time I was not prepared to say anything one way or the other because it could have been wrong, but now I feel very positive.'

Gordon's nightmare began on a cold, wet evening in November 1952 with the murder of Patricia Curran, 19-year-old daughter of Justice Lancelot Curran, one of Northern Ireland's most influential judges and pillar of the Province's all-powerful Unionist establishment.

The student's body was discovered in the driveway of The Glen, the family estate in Whiteabbey, five miles north of Belfast. She had been stabbed 37 times. The pressure on the RUC for a conviction was enormous. Five years earlier, Curran had been made Northern Ireland's youngest Attorney-General, and his influence stretched from Whiteabbey to the highest levels of the Stormont government.

As a result, glaring irregularities in the family's behaviour that evening were ignored. Although his daughter was clearly dead - her right arm had been frozen upwards by the onset of rigor mortis - Curran, aided by his son and the family solicitor, put the body in a car and drove it to a doctor's surgery, unhindered by the first officers to arrive at the scene. Such contamination of evidence would be unthinkable today.

There were other discrepancies which should have set alarm bells ringing. Despite the multiple stab wounds, very little blood was found at the scene, suggesting she had not been killed where she was found. A pile of her belongings were lying 10 yards from the body, but they were dry despite the rain and appeared to have been placed there rather than dropped during a scuffle. The judge also refused to allow his family to be interviewed until four days after the murder, and it was a week before he allowed police to search the family home.

These factors have led many to believe that there was a conspiracy to cover up what really happened to Patricia Curran. And the victim of the alleged cover-up, say campaigners, was Iain Hay Gordon, a socially awkward 20-year-old stationed in Northern Ireland for his National Service in the RAF. 'I was very naive, I had never been away from home,' Gordon, who now lives in Glasgow, told The Observer. 'My idea of policemen came from Agatha Christie, and unfortunately I found out that reality was very different.'

Gordon came under suspicion two months after the murder. He had met Patricia's brother, Desmond, through church and had visited The Glen on four occasions. In January 1953, he was taken in for questioning by a team of detectives led by Chief Superintendent John Capstick, who was on secondment from Scotland Yard. Three days later, he signed a confession which his lawyers say was false and coerced.

It is the trauma of those three days that haunts him most deeply 47 years on. Just mentioning it is enough to bring the look of terror back to his eyes. 'To me it's like the interrogation happened yesterday. It will never leave me. I still have the nightmares, and they are still as horrific as when they first started.

'The shouted at me constantly. They said if I didn't confess they would let my mother know about my friendship with a local homosexual and the shock would kill her. I had no lawyer or RAF officer with me, and for three days I had virtually nothing to eat. By the end I would have signed anything. The window was open halfway and all I could think was that if I didn't get out of that room I was going to jump through the window.'

Gordon's big problem was that he had no alibi for the night of the murder, so, encouraged by his colleagues, he concocted one. 'It was the height of stupidity, but I knew that I hadn't killed Patricia Curran. I didn't think it would matter.' It did. When the trial opened in March, the confession was ruled valid by the judge, Lord Justice McDermott, a close family friend of the Currans.

Gordon was spared the gallows, but only after his defence produced evidence which led him to be found guilty but insane. He was sentenced to be detained at Her Majesty's pleasure in the Holywell mental hospital in Antrim. His medical records show that he received no treatment for insanity and seven years later he was quietly released. But the time in Holywell, especially the first two years in a closed ward, took its toll. Even now, check-ups at Gartnavel hospital in the west end of Glasgow terrify him. 'I start to think that they might lock me in there.'

Adapting to life back in Glasgow was just as traumatic. He managed to get a job in the stores of a publisher, but only on condition that he used the name John and that he never mentioned the case. After 33 years, the pressure of staying silent became too much and he took early retirement in 1993.

'It was seeing all the other miscarriage-of-justice cases being overturned that was the worst thing. I felt I was being left behind.'

Since then, the campaign has gathered pace. In 1998, his legal team presented a dossier of evidence to the Criminal Cases Review Commission. It threw it out on the technicality that it was not empowered to investigate cases of guilty but insane, a verdict which no longer exists. But the campaign rallied, and last July MPs were persuaded to change the law to allow the commission to investigate.

Gordon admits that he will never be able to make up for the time he has lost. But now at last, he is daring to think about the future. 'For some people it might have been enough to be released and have a job, but not me. I was convicted of something I didn't do and I have been fighting to clear my name for nearly 50 years. It will be strange at first, but I'm looking forward to it happening.'

fields.headline: MPs back Observer campaign
fields.standfirst: The Government is urged to act as dentists demand help to improve standards of treatment
fields.trailText: Members of Parliament of all parties have urged the Government to undertake a radical overhaul of British dentistry, following The Observer's revelations of the appalling state of dental treatment inflicted on most patients.
fields.body:
Members of Parliament of all parties have urged the Government to undertake a radical overhaul of British dentistry, following The Observer's revelations of the appalling state of dental treatment inflicted on most patients.

The House of Commons Health Select Committee is set to launch an investigation and the British Dental Association has publicly hit out at the Government for complacency and inaction, while secretly warning dentists not to fuel The Observer campaign.

The Observer caused a storm of controversy among dentists with its revelations that more than £200 million of unnecessary work is done on patients each year; and that as much as 90 per cent of work fails to meet agreed standards. A large number of reputable dentists have secretly urged support.

One dentist in Manchester told The Observer : 'I strongly urge you to keep going - there is much more to come out and only this kind of pressure will ever force the Government to re-think the whole process.' A Salisbury dentist said: 'The Government and the (British Dental Association) between them make for very comfortable bedfellows - there are many in the profession who agree entirely with the spirit of your article, but worry that the public may not like the answer!'

The revelations have also caused controversy internationally, with one Australian dentist saying: 'We [the dental profession] are all following this story closely. Numerous studies have shown NHS dentistry is inferior.' Another Australian dentist said: 'I now know why English dentistry is the laughing stock of the civilized world.'

However, many dentists have poured abuse on The Observer, prompting Anthony Kravitz, chairman of the General Dental Services Committee of the British Dental Association to send a round-robin e-mail: 'As I thought might happen, all the personal animosity directed to Anthony Browne, Health Editor of The Observer, has alerted him to a further story. He has also received some wonderful additional material. By all means write to the Editor with reasoned opposition to what Mr Browne writes, but please do not e-mail him with personal abuse - it will alienate him more against the profession.'

Publicly, Kravitz insisted the BDA supported reform, and lambasted the Government for complacency: 'We are very concerned about government inaction. It is three years since they have come to power, and we haven't officially heard one shred about any proposals.'

Calls for urgent reform were led by David Hinchliffe, chairman of the Health Select Committee, who said he wanted the committee to investigate: 'Dentistry has been allowed to drift for the last few years. We need to have a radical look at what is going on.' He said the fee system encourages unnecessary and poor quality work.

Shadow Health Secretary Liam Fox said: 'I am alarmed at the evidence of what is going on. We need a complete review of dental provision, looking at access to services, quality and remuneration. The General Dental Council [the regulator] needs considerable tightening.'

The Department of Health announced a review of dentistry two years ago, but has postponed any decisions. Lord Hunt, the Minister responsible for dentistry, was not available for comment.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: ...cope with nice people
fields.trailText: ...cope with nice people.
fields.body:
1. Remember that Adolf Hitler and Uncle Joe Stalin were regarded as pleasant men by those they decided to smarm to. We say 'Mervyn is nice' - but the truth is probably that 'Mervyn gives the impression of being nice to me when it suits him'. Recognise that most successful greasy pole climbers usually have considerable experience in turning on the charm.

2. Work out your own definition of niceness - especially if the word figures in your vocabulary. 'Trying to make other people happier - and not necessarily wanting the credit' is one definition. But in less objective moments, we are inclined to see as nice those who profess the same aims as us, appear to like us and might even help us. Office operators will play on these assumptions of ours to attract our support - but many will be ruthless and would ditch you without a backward glance.

3. Expect a decent approach from people who are genuinely kind - but don't assume they will roll over. Decent people can be very tough in pursuit of a principle. The solicitor to the Guildford Four, Alastair Logan, made huge personal sacrifices to fight his clients' cause.

4.Be wary of anyone who seems inordinately charming. Be on guard against someone that everyone hugely likes: if niceness implies working from a set of principles, then a nice person will have firm views that jar with colleagues.

5. Appreciate the weaknesses that are often associated with being widely liked. 'It can cause shallowness,' says Liz, an experienced office politician. 'It's like being beautiful. If you've got natural charm, you don't have to work hard and it can mask laziness..' Similarly, someone whose strength is being liked can become very manipulative of others - rather than trying to achieve their aims directly.

6. Look at the top people in your company - and see what role charm and niceness play. In a business based on the old boys' network there can be the appearance of bonhomie - but these are fake friendships. Your upwardly mobile colleagues will ape this approach.

In a business based on the old boys' network there can be the appearance of bonhomie - but these are fake friendships. Your upwardly mobile colleagues will ape this approach.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: JN Nichols, the family firm behind Vimto, has certainly been through the juicer in the last year. The drinks firm wasn't content with just shifting three sites into one new purpose-built £12.5 million factory. It also went on the expansion trail with the £6m acquisition of hot drink systems supplier Balmoral Trading, of Cabana soft drinks and a deal securing the rights to produce Sunkist brands from Cadbury Schweppes.
fields.body:
JN Nichols, the family firm behind Vimto, has certainly been through the juicer in the last year. The drinks firm wasn't content with just shifting three sites into one new purpose-built £12.5 million factory. It also went on the expansion trail with the £6m acquisition of hot drink systems supplier Balmoral Trading, of Cabana soft drinks and a deal securing the rights to produce Sunkist brands from Cadbury Schweppes.

As a result of all the changes, the bottom line forecasts look uninspiring, with profits next year only likely to regain 1998's level of just under £10m.

Still, Nichols now goes forward on a much sounder platform as a broader based company and the short-term pain should deliver long-term gains.

The shares are unlikely to do spectacular things immediately but, at 114p, look a sound recovery. The prospective price earnings multiple stands at just seven times and the yield is an attractive 8 per cent.

Costume drama

Despite their bombed-out share prices, broker Salomon Smith Barney remains sceptical of recovery prospects at two of the best-known high street names: Arcadia and Debenhams.

Arcadia, formerly known as Burtons, of course, has just taken the knife to some of its brands, including the closure of Richards and Principles for Men. With debt still high, however, and pressure from new entrants continuing, Salomon's retail team fears the risks still outweigh the potential rewards of the restructuring programme.

Debenhams, meanwhile, undoubtedly has a respected management team, which is stabilising the ship by increasing market share of late. This, however, looks insufficient to stop profits declining in the second half after a drop of 7 per cent in the first six months, Salomon believes.

With the clothing market seeing price deflation running at 2 to 3 per cent a year, and wage and rent costs rising, Debenhams still faces continuing pressure on margins. Avoid for the moment.

Animal magic

Lawrence is an interesting business, admittedly with an uninspiring name, which has been around on the Alternative Investment Market for five years. Of late, however, the tightly traded shares have been under pressure and, at 330p, are now changing hands on a forward multiple of just eight times earnings.

Lawrence distributes medicines for animal health, including anti-parasite drugs, antibiotics and treatments for ailments like dysentery. It also makes feed growth additives, which are an alternative to much over-used antibiotics. Through Interpet, Lawrence also supplies pet and aquarium products and the group still has a profitable chemical treatment division.

House broker Charles Stanley believes the shares to be substantially undervalued and has set a 12-month price target of 590p. Lawrence only has one marketmaker so liquidity is a real risk, but the firm looks worth a speculative punt.

Building value

Kingspan, the Irish building materials company, also looks to be a promising recovery stock. The firm dominates the UK and Irish markets for its core products, including composite panels for building interiors, insulation and raised access flooring.

New construction regulations to be adopted in the UK are likely to boost Kingspan's sales in a big way, says the firm's broker Investec Henderson Crosthwaite.

Analyst Geoff Allum says the shares are lowly rated for technical reasons due to Irish funds rebalancing their portfolios, a situation unlikely to last long.

At 195p, the shares are rated at just 10 times forecast earnings this year. Buy.

webTitle: Hot Rod flies in to bat for BA's first eleven

fields.headline: Hot Rod flies in to bat for BA's first eleven
fields.standfirst: The new chief executive of the world's favourite airline brings with him winning form, writes  Joanna Walters
fields.trailText: The new chief executive of the world's favourite airline brings with him winning form.
fields.body:
Never underestimate a left-handed spin bowler. Enigmatic, subtle, clever, frighteningly effective when on form.

And when they swap the ball for the willow? Deadly.

It is only a game, but do Rod Eddington's cricketing proclivities tell us anything about him?

A little.

'He is not the stereotypical loud, brash Aussie. No back-slapping, hail fellow well met, Mr Cosy Roly Poly, in the bar at 6pm,' said a former colleague.

And yet the new chief executive of British Airways is famous for his people skills - as BA has been tirelessly pointing out since it appointed him last week to pilot the troubled airline.

Eddington flies in to London to take up his new post tomorrow from Sydney, where he was chairman of the regional airline Ansett Australia.

The air is heavy with expectation. One BA board member told The Observer breathlessly: 'When you meet him the obvious qualities are that he is a people person. He is clearly very confident in matters of morale and leadership. He understands how to motivate people and relate to them.'

This is not just a gushing tribute to Eddington but an ill-disguised and gratuitous slur on the man he replaces. Bob Ayling had many talents but being a 'people person' was not one of them. In attempting to drive through tough but necessary cost-cutting at BA he alienated the rank and file, mishandled the cabin crew strike, botched media relations, allowed customer service levels to deteriorate and the share price to plummet.

Ayling's ignominious departure last month left the company with a recovery plan but financial losses, a battered image and damaged staff morale.

The fixit job now falls to Hot Rod (as those vulgar Sydney headlines call him).

The BA board has endorsed Ayling's strategy to persevere with cost-cutting while trimming capacity and concentrating on lucrative business passengers.

Now it wants an inspirational leader to push it through and carry the troops with him.

The ex-colleague put in a note of caution: 'I hope they are not over-hyping this Mr Nice Guy thing and expecting Rod to ride up on his chariot and perform miracles overnight.'

There is still a big job to be done at BA. Its alliance with American Airlines is no more than a loose marketing part nership and Eddington will have to decide how to take it forward, within the Oneworld group of airlines that also includes his old employer Cathay Pacific.

He will be new to the volatile North Atlantic market. He will have to sort out BA's loss-making European and domestic operations and he will have to learn to deal with the City and the authorities in London, Washington and Brussels.

'He'll walk it,' said one long-time associate. 'He is brilliant at dealing with people on all levels.'

Eddington, who turned 50 in January, is known as a good listener with a phenomenal memory. One source remarked that he has the ability to take tough decisions while remaining above the fray as others carry them out.

He has been an airline executive for the last 21 years, but qualified as a nuclear physicist.

He was born and educated in Perth and came to Oxford University as a postgraduate Rhodes scholar in the early Seventies. By all accounts he had a ball playing cricket for the university second team, making friends and walking through his doctorate before staying on to lecture for several years.

One friend said that Eddington became very attached to Britain and loves Europe, particularly France. He is very keen on good wine.

He joined Cathay Pacific in 1979. One of the principal shareholders of the Hong Kong-based airline is the Swire Group.

Shortly after beginning his career, Eddington was posted to South Korea for some international experience. He came back to run Cathay's operation at Hong Kong airport in 1982 and, having done well, was posted to the airline's largest overseas market, Japan, as sales manager.

Former colleagues now say that, even in the early days, it was clear that Rod was destined for the top. He was human resources chief, commercial director and became managing director of the airline in 1992 at the age of 42.

'People have an image of Swire and Cathay as this fuddy-duddy, colonialist institution, but it is actually very dynamic and Rod was a heavyweight,' said one.

Like Ayling, Eddington had a cabin crew strike on his hands not long after taking over the top job. By all accounts neither he nor the airline as a whole handled it particularly well and tough lessons were learnt.

He survived the tumult, however, and guided Cathay through the glorious mid-Nineties financial boom, constantly boosting customer service levels while introducing a leaner management and aircraft fleet structure.

The Asian economic crisis prompted a much deeper efficiency drive and radical job cuts, but by then Eddington had left for Australia.

There was some surprise when he vaulted across the South China Sea to take the executive chairmanship of Ansett in 1997.

There appear to have been two main reasons for the switch. First, he had married a South Korean woman and they had had two babies while living in Hong Kong - which gave the children narrowly-defined rights of residence in the ex-colony but did not make them Korean, Australian or British citizens. By moving to Australia they would gain citizenship.

Second, Eddington's talents had been noticed by one of the most powerful people in business - Rupert Murdoch - who courted him and offered him the job at Ansett.

The airline was a part-owned subsidiary of News Limited, the Australian arm of Murdoch's global media empire News Corporation.

In fact, Eddington's last task before leaving for BA was to complete the sale of Murdoch's 50 per cent stake in Ansett to Air New Zealand. That deal is expected to be finalised this weekend and, with Ansett destined to be wholly-owned by Air NZ, it was the perfect moment for Eddington to move on.

In three years he had turned around an airline that was of good quality but suffering from financial losses and a confused strategy. He was not afraid to cut costs and loss-making routes. Murdoch flew from the US to Australia to try to persuade Eddington to stay with News Corp rather than go to BA.

But the BA job is just too tempting. Eddington will remain a non-executive director of News Corporation and is bound to support Oz whenever the Ashes are up for grabs. He'll no doubt also have a company satellite dish on which to pick up coverage of his second favourite sport - Aussie rules football.

But he has packed his bat and ball for England and BA chairman Lord Marshall is probably so grateful he would even iron his whites for him.

webTitle: How Brown should spend mobile billions

fields.headline: How Brown should spend mobile billions
fields.standfirst: Whether it's tax or debt cuts, the Chancellor has to avoid inflationary perils, says Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: Whether it's tax or debt cuts, the Chancellor has to avoid inflationary perils, says Faisal Islam
fields.body:
It would have made a great TV show. The mobile phone auction was a cross between The Price is Right and a high-stakes game of poker, with the Chancellor as a smiling Leslie Crowther-figure inviting the mobile phone firms to 'Come On Down'.

How he must be smiling. The Treasury's coffers are sweeter to the tune of £22.5 billion. The Budget estimated receipts from the auction of around £2.5bn, so the Treasury has received out of thin air a windfall of around £20bn.

Imaginative plans to spend this sum on health, education, tax cuts for business or buying euros to weaken the pound have been mooted. But like any sensible poker player, the Government has signalled an intention to bank its winnings. 'The prudent thing to do with such a large income is to use it to reduce debt, and that is what our plans are,' said Andrew Smith, Chief Secretary to the Treasury.

The prudence lies not only in the fiscal responsibility of debt reduction but because spending the windfall would be considered inflationary.

Comparisons have been drawn with previous government gains from privatisations and North Sea oil. 'It's not like a privatisation - it's more like a tax on production upfront,' says Carl Emmerson of the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

Although the conditions of the auction state that half the money is to be paid upfront, the high rate of interest required on payments will suggest that the Government is likely to receive the entire £22.5bn immediately.

The money will be spread over the 20-year period of the licence for accounting purposes, and is better considered as a £1.1bn a year windfall for the next 20 years. 'He could spend that money, and it wouldn't affect the golden rule,' says Emmerson.

All £22.5bn could be spent now, as long as the project is a long-term capital investment with return over 20 years. The main worry is the effect of a fiscal loosening on inflationary pressures. But the expansionary effects of a fiscal windfall are one side of the equation. Can the extraction of £22.5bn from the economy not be considered a fiscal tightening of sorts? According to HSBC, by valuing the licences as the current value of the telecoms companies' future profits, the charges can be seen as a gradual tightening by feeding through to consumers in the form of higher prices. But in a competitive market, with an eagle-eyed Oftel watching, this should not happen, and the effect of the charges will instead be felt by shareholders - a lesser tightening.

So the windfall could be used, while keeping to fiscal rules and without being overly inflationary.

In fact, it might be argued that it is more prudent to spend these proceeds from selling off a national asset on paying for a long-term investment providing returns in 20 years' time, perhaps a transport infrastructure project. Italy is suggesting plans to invest its mobile windfall in hi-tech research and education, its human capital infrastructure. Norway spent much of its North Sea windfall in the 1980s on investing in its manufacturing base.

But the Government is already running a record surplus of £15bn. 'If there are investments that are that good, then the Government should already be using the surplus to pay for them,' says Douglas McWilliams of the Centre for Economics and Business Research (CEBR).

Using the windfall for tax cuts is another option - for these purposes the windfall is an annual one of £1.10bn - equivalent to half a penny off income tax per year. A good platform from which to win an election perhaps, but the surest way of stoking inflationary pressure and bouncing the MPC into further interest rate rises. Cutting business taxes, by lowering corporation taxes or National Insurance contributions may not be as inflationary.

The CEBR is suggesting that the best way to avoid inflationary pressures is to invest the money in a range of foreign assets. In Singapore and Kuwait, government agencies earn strong returns from investing surpluses in foreign bonds and shares, says McWilliams. But investing abroad at the expense of British industry would be a political minefield.

The windfall could be used to temper the strength of the pound, by buying euros or euro-denominated gilts. But currency market intervention is a tricky business and the overall effect of such intervention can rebound spectacularly, although it's more often used when a central bank is trying to prop up its currency.

So what about reducing the debt - the option chosen by Germany and Holland, as well as the UK? The main problem is it threatens to exacerbate an emerging shortage of government securities. Most institutional funds are legally obliged to hold a fixed proportion, and are chasing a dwindling stock of gilts with lower yields.

This means, says Andrew Scott of the London Business School, that the Government can issue new debt at lower interest rates. It will also, of course, reduce interest payments, saving around £1.7bn a year, if interest rates stay at 5 per cent.

This annual windfall is slightly higher than the value of the licences spread over their 20-year lifetime. Furthermore, over each year of the licence, its annual value is available for current spending while still conforming comfortably with fiscal rules.

So, despite reducing the national debt, the windfall could still be worth nearly £3bn in the first year and the debt interest savings, meanwhile, could seep into public spending via the contingency fund.

Dealing with the proceeds of the auction might yet prove to be a case of Family Fortunes.

fields.headline: Maggie Hyde's Company futures
fields.trailText: Planetary prescription for Boots
fields.body:
Planetary prescription for Boots

A bleak future for Boots has been predicted by brokers CSFB. It faces increasing supermarket competition and its share price has halved in 18 months. For an astrological prognosis, we can return to its public incorporation (11 November 1888). Boots was born under the medical sign of Scorpio, with health and hygiene Virgo rising, and the scorpion's power to turn the tables should not be underestimated.

The Jupiter-Saturn conjunction falls on the company's Taurus Midheaven at the end of May, marking its current crisis. The coming year remains tough with non-core business, including its photographic services, having to be curtailed. Redundancies are possible next Easter. To find its long-term strategy, Boots needs to reclaim the progressive vision of its founding family. John Boot, an agricultural labourer, learnt herbalism from his mother and his first shop in 1849 provided consultations and remedies for the poor. His son Jesse created the company and established the winning formula of qualified pharmacists employed in a general store.

Boots is in a unique position to bridge the gap between mainstream medicine and 'new age' healing. Over the next two years, self-help Uranus provides opportunities to combine innovation with its trusted reputation and its scientific Saturn. Evolving its projected health clubs into mainstream and complementary treatment clinics would fit perfectly with John Boot's vision. E-commerce Uranus also suggests on-line health-lines. If Boots can swallow the New Age pill, after autumn 2001 it will gallop along the road to recovery.

Watch out for: Lastminute.com

All eyes will be on Lastminute.com, which reports its first set of interim results on Thursday. The online store, which takes a commission on everything it sells, including restaurant places and holidays, has seen its share price slide horribly since it floated in March, leading to accusations that it is overhyped and fundamentally over-valued.

Having lost half its value in little more than two months, co-founders Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox know these results are crucial. The company has said it doesn't aim to make a profit for some time so analysts will look for evidence that Lastminute is continuing to grow its customer base. When its prospectus was published, the company had 1.1 million subscribers; 5 per cent had bought something from Lastminute. Up until the end of last year it had been growing its subscriber base at a rate of 33 per cent a month. These figures will need to have shown growth, otherwise a further collapse in share price looks inevitable. Trading Floor

Buy...

No! Sell! No Buy! ....No Sell! A difficult week for Morrison & Co, Cheshire Estate agents. They are crying in their G&Ts at the collapse of Ruud Van Kneedestroyed's £19 million transfer to Manchester United. As it would have surely brought a price surge in the Cheshire 'soccer merchandising and transfer-broker belt', with its Dutch-style very flat geography, rubbery tasteless cheese and ghastly ersatz country-cottage suburban sprawl. He could, for example, have bought approximately 4,000 terraced houses in Stockport and then knocked them together using a huge number of RSJs. Alternatively he could have gone for the more standard contemporary footballer's gaff of purpose-built detached doubled-fronted modern 'Dun Bunging' Las Vegas-brothel-cum-mock-Tudor mansion tricked out in the local architectural style using local building materials (chalk, compacted silage) boasting multiple garage space to park a dozen or so Mazaratis, connecting quarters for live-in servants, contract lawyers and Hello! journalists.

But though the possibility of Ruud has vanished with his ligaments, the news on Friday night of Manchester City's promotion to the Prem has brightened the outlook for estate agents peddling gaudy mansions to spotty youths. The pay rises afforded to the light blues - plus a couple of high tariff transfers - will more than make up for the lost soldier of Wounded Knee. Open the electronic gates and let them in....

... Sell

Armitage Shanks - the country's biggest supplier of 'sanitaryware' (ie toilets and urinals). A perfectly good, even excellent, company in many ways. But this week a leading firm of expert lavatory outfitters, as well as several trendy PR companies, predicted that the urinal could be on its way out as a result of a move towards unisex public and office toilets. The excitement began when it was revealed that a new office block near the Bank of England in the City had been provided with toilets catering for both sexes, apparently following the example of the American television series Ally McBeal. Female workers in the office block affected are already moaning that they no longer feel comfortable 'having a good gossip' in the single-sex sanctuary of the toilet cubicle. Men, meanwhile, are reportedly 'shocked' by the experience of seeing women marching into the toilet in front of them. But a spokesman for Nexus, the company which created the new toilet told the papers: 'We hope the toilets will become part of the next generation of offices and we expect other companies to follow our lead.' If so, this could spell curtains for Armitage which has been providing bowls and urinals for single sex toilets since 1817.
fields.bodyText: Planetary prescription for Boots A bleak future for Boots has been predicted by brokers CSFB. It faces increasing supermarket competition and its share price has halved in 18 months. For an astrological prognosis, we can return to its public incorporation (11 November 1888). Boots was born under the medical sign of Scorpio, with health and hygiene Virgo rising, and the scorpion's power to turn the tables should not be underestimated. The Jupiter-Saturn conjunction falls on the company's Taurus Midheaven at the end of May, marking its current crisis. The coming year remains tough with non-core business, including its photographic services, having to be curtailed. Redundancies are possible next Easter. To find its long-term strategy, Boots needs to reclaim the progressive vision of its founding family. John Boot, an agricultural labourer, learnt herbalism from his mother and his first shop in 1849 provided consultations and remedies for the poor. His son Jesse created the company and established the winning formula of qualified pharmacists employed in a general store. Boots is in a unique position to bridge the gap between mainstream medicine and 'new age' healing. Over the next two years, self-help Uranus provides opportunities to combine innovation with its trusted reputation and its scientific Saturn. Evolving its projected health clubs into mainstream and complementary treatment clinics would fit perfectly with John Boot's vision. E-commerce Uranus also suggests on-line health-lines. If Boots can swallow the New Age pill, after autumn 2001 it will gallop along the road to recovery.
