webTitle: Let's leave Aunt Emily in peace

fields.headline: Let's leave Aunt Emily in peace
fields.trailText: If my name was Emily and I had nephews or nieces, I would be tempted to sue. Aunt Emily, you may remember, is the reason usually quoted for the Government's cautious attitude to switching off analogue TV signals, thereby hastening the digital revolution by forcing us all into digital television. If it wasn't for Aunt Emily - quite happy watching Songs of Praise on her 25-year-old Grundig set - Britain could be blazing a digital trail in multi-channel interactive television, leading a world revolution in new technology and releasing valuable spectrum space which could reap yet more billions for the Treasury.
fields.body:
If my name was Emily and I had nephews or nieces, I would be tempted to sue. Aunt Emily, you may remember, is the reason usually quoted for the Government's cautious attitude to switching off analogue TV signals, thereby hastening the digital revolution by forcing us all into digital television. If it wasn't for Aunt Emily - quite happy watching Songs of Praise on her 25-year-old Grundig set - Britain could be blazing a digital trail in multi-channel interactive television, leading a world revolution in new technology and releasing valuable spectrum space which could reap yet more billions for the Treasury.

This appeared to be the consensus at a conference on digital television in London 10 days ago. The young Turks were out in force. Here was a revolution that would put the wheel and the light bulb to shame, delivering to consumers in electronic form 'what they want, when they want it'. There were enough jibes at the 'old-fashioned' notion of 'one-to-many broadcasting' to make communal, passive TV watching sound positively quaint.

It took a slightly older Turk, Channel 5 chief executive David Elstein, to bring some reasoned argument to the proceedings. True, Channel 5 is making a perfectly good living as a free-to-air analogue channel and is probably in no hurry to go digital, but that should not detract from Elstein's forensic analysis of why the whole switch-off question is more complex than a few recalcitrant Aunt Emilys. As he reminded his audience, it took 21 years for the transition from 405 to 625 lines to be complete - and that was with the plainly visible advantage of bringing colour. It was also at a time when renting was more com mon and therefore upgrading was easier.

Now nearly all TV sets are owned. While there might be a seven- or eight-year replacement cycle for main sets, these are additions to the household which tend to displace other (still working) sets into other rooms. It is rare, even among digital satellite homes, for every set to be wired for digital reception.

Then there are the millions of analogue VCRs which would be instantly rendered obsolete. Even if more than 12 million homes could receive digital television by 2006 (itself an optimistic forecast), there would still be nearly 80 million analogue devices in homes. When 405-line was switched off in 1985, only 15,000 homes were left without the new standard. What, wondered Elstein, would disabling tens of millions of pieces of perfectly functional consumer equipment do to government popularity?

And there's the rub. Whatever proportion of households are prepared to invest voluntarily in digital televi sion and its still-compulsory subscription channels - unlikely to go beyond 65 per cent, even within 10 years - most households will still be analogue in some respect.

No doubt the army of Aunt Emilys could be bought off with a meals-on-wheels type distribution of digital converter boxes, funded from the squillions derived from selling off the analogue frequencies. What, however, do you do about the real problem - Aunt Emily's Middle England children whose three other TV sets and two VCRs suddenly conk out with the press of a government switch?

At the heart of the problem is an uncomfortable fact of television life for the digital Turks: the mass audience television experience is still as much an integral part of middle England's life as the computer and the 'I want it and I want it now' consumerist culture. As long as shows as diverse as Antiques Roadshow, Blind Date, Ground Force and Monarch of the Glen can command live audiences of more than 8 million, no government will be mucking around with the way they are delivered.

This Government has taken out a sensible risk-free insurance policy which makes switch-off contingent on 95 per cent of homes going digital of their own accord. Meanwhile it can promote itself as IT-friendly to rich and poor by providing schools with computers and setting up free electronic information points such as the one pioneered in Islington (where, I can testify, the queues are rather shorter than for the telephone boxes nearby). It therefore cannot be accused of Luddism and is saved from making a horrible political decision. Poor old Aunt Emily is just the fall girl for a clever strategy of squaring a difficult electoral circle.

 Steven Barnett is senior lecturer in communications at the University of Westminster.

webTitle: Knutsford is poised to make its first swoop

fields.headline: Knutsford is poised to make its first swoop
fields.trailText: Knutsford, the bid vehicle which has been seeking a target since it was formed in November last year, is understood to be close to completing its first acquisition.
fields.body:
Knutsford, the bid vehicle which has been seeking a target since it was formed in November last year, is understood to be close to completing its first acquisition.

According to a source close to the company, it is running its eyes over the accounts of an Internet services company. 'It's taking a bit of time because Knutsford is having to do due diligence on the company's subsidiaries in several different countries,' the source said.

The deal is expected to be announced within the next few weeks. The company's share price leapt last year when former Asda boss Archie Norman, property tycoons Nick Leslau and Nigel Wray and Richer Sounds chief executive Julian Richer, bought into the company to use it as a takeover vehicle. As a result, its value soared from £5 mil lion to £600m. Possible bid targets mentioned at the time included the ailing Storehouse group.

However, failure to find a suitable target has seen the share price plunge this year and the company is now worth just over £200m.

Having lost out to US venture capital firm KKR in its bid to take over lighting firm Wassall in February, Knutsford shifted its focus to the Internet sector.

Since Archie Norman's promotion to the shadow cabinet, Nigel Wray has assumed the company's chairmanship. City analysts speculate that the target may be an Internet fulfilment business.

Knutsford is one of a string of businesses set up by Manchester United director Michael Edelson who specialises in reversing firms into shell companies.

webTitle: A slow fling in the Highlands

fields.headline: A slow fling in the Highlands
fields.trailText: Victoria | Mother Courage | Burning Issues
fields.body:
Victoria Pit, Barbican, London EC2

Mother Courage New Ambassadors, London WC2

Burning Issues Hampstead, London NW3

That rare thing, a large-scale new play, has taken off from the pen of the Scottish playwright David Greig and landed on the stage of the Pit. In an era of short scenes and small casts, of elliptical statements and oblique political commitment, Greig has written something of revolutionary strangeness: a romantic saga with a political slant. With the help of Ian Brown's able direction, he has given it sweep and verve and heart.

Victoria is a trilogy set in the Highlands which begins at the time of the Spanish Civil War with a group of young men fired up with ideals and anger, and ends 60 years later with a young woman dipping around in her own psyche. It holds you with its interlocking stories: of seduced maidservants and wilful rich girls; of the young laird in the Thirties who's an enthusiast for naturism and Hitler; of the hippie in the Seventies who looks round the great hall and sees a vision of a room strewn with bean bags. It binds these stories to a theme - a falling away of political commitment, a pillaging of the earth's resources.

The play has the faults of its ambition. It's sometimes lush to the point of soupiness; it's sometimes - with a cast required to triple up in overlapping parts - confusing. And too long: it's irritating that someone at the RSC didn't notice that with three-quarters of an hour lopped off, this could be really popular. Never mind. It's still vivacious, and not least because it's never dully naturalistic. Angela Davies's bold, austere design sets undulating wooden walkways in front of glossy steel panels which are in turn flecked with shadows, flooded blue like an icy loch, and made rosy by a sunset.

Davies has also used her considerable talents to good effect in designing an evocative, corrugated-iron-and-fluttering-fabric set for Shared Experience's production of Mother Courage at the New Ambassadors. It's a design in tune with Lee Hall's idiomatic new translation and with Nancy Meckler's direction, which brings a touch of the merry-go-round to Bertolt Brecht's cycle of deprivation.

In this version, Brecht's story of seventeenth-century warfare and homelessness bowls along on wheezing waves of accordion music. In the opening moments the cast sway together in a comically doleful chorus. Kathryn Hunter plays the title role got up like a gypsy in brightly-coloured glad rags: shrewd and sprightly, merry and desperate.

To see a tattered band of refugees weaving their way across the stage is to see an animated version of today's headlines. You might think there's never been a better time to stage the play, until you remember that there once was an equally appropriate time: the play was first performed in 1941. The images - that cart, that sad, diminished family - are still strong, but what do the words contribute beyond hectoring? Not much. It's no accident that the part of dumb Kattrin (Hayley Carmichael) is the evening's most potent piece of characterisation.

One of the great young lights of the British theatre, Carmichael can't put a foot on to the stage without being arresting. It's not that you're conscious of her acting away all the time: it's her quality of self-absorption that's so unusual. To watch her is like watching a six-year-old playing: she collapses with grief as if there could be no recovery; she dresses up and struts around as if sorrow could never touch her. She never behaves as if she has an audience.

She can't, however, save Mother Courage from its customary condescension, from the idea that what it's putting across is 'essence of peasant'. Or from the theatrical chic which has hung around the play from its beginnings. Picasso designed a special headscarf for Helene Weigel, the original Mother Courage.

Every now and then, a plea goes up for theatre to debate contemporary problems. Ron Hutchinson's new play at Hampstead shows why it's not always a good idea. Burning Issues sets out to investigate the dilemma posed - to his publishers - by a writer whose confessional works are at odds with his sensitive fictions. The piece is draped in well-worn literary garments - Eliot is cited, and Larkin is implied. But nothing is made immediate or plausible. The writer's work is never evoked with any savour, simply plonkingly described as being full of moral crises.

webTitle: It used to be all Greek to me

fields.headline: It used to be all Greek to me
fields.standfirst: Martinu's classic deserves its belated revival
fields.trailText: The Greek Passion | Gloriana
fields.body:
The Greek Passion Royal Opera House, London WC2
Gloriana BBC2

Forty years ago, the Royal Opera House turned down the opportunity of giving the world premiere of Martinu's The Greek Passion. Hampered by inertia and xenophobia, a committee of experts (yes, one of those) deemed it unlyrical, short on characterisation and, frankly, a bit foreign for a Covent Garden audience, even though the libretto is in English.

What would they make of the arcane religious hierarchies of Greek village life written by a Czech composer? As excuses go, they hardly come more flimsy. Opera goers have long coped with Jews in Egypt and Italians in Algiers. Why should we have trouble with Armenians in Greece?

Nikos Kazantzakis's novel Christ Recrucified, on which The Greek Passion is based, tells a straightforward story: villagers take on the roles of Christ and his disciples for a performance of the Passion play, only to find themselves becoming those figures in real life. The drama is played out against a background of starvation tied to the theme of refugees seeking shelter after their village has been burnt by Turks.

Now Covent Garden has made amends with a striking new staging by David Pountney, also making his long overdue ROH debut. Moreover, this is the first airing of a reconstruction of the composer's first version of the opera.

The work has a complex performance and compositional history. In brief, after the rejection of his first efforts, Martinu wrote a substantially new piece, premiered in Zurich in 1961 and generally used since. Nearly three quarters of the material is different. To British audiences, who have had little chance to get to know the opera, except in a 1981 Welsh National Opera production, the extent of the differences may not be apparent. But version-spotting is a buff's game. For most people, it's like comparing tails when you haven't yet met the dog. The experience of hearing the work in the theatre is what counts.

The set, a handsome construction of platforms, was pure Piranesi from front on. But thanks to Covent Garden's new revolve, Stafanos Lazaridis had achieved the still more remarkable feat of showing it from all sides (something Piranesi never had to do). The rapid, cinematic feel of the scenes, enacted simultaneously and on different levels, was immediately apparent. Village life is played out as if on a Greek hilltop, the chorus swarming like black ants up and down the different walkways and decks. The chief priest and elders sit smoking, drinking raki and coffee throughout, untouched by the unfolding agony around them.

At the start, massive bells and censers swing from on high, with the high priest, Grigoris (Esa Ruuttunen), up aloft in swathes of gold and crimson finery. Echoes of Boris Godunov quickly recede when you realise that Martinu's individual scoring is transparent rather than dense, linear and rapid rather than dark and weighty. He employs folk instruments, such as the accordion, and makes distinctive use of the harp.

Charles Mackerras, always persuasive in the Czech repertoire he knows and loves, conducted a fluent performance, with fine playing by the ROH orchestra. Manolios, the Christ figure, was sung with searing ardour by the Finnish tenor, Jorma Silvastri. The many cameo roles were well cast, with company principals such as Robin Leggate and Roderick Earle as key villagers and Gwynne Howell as the refugees' priest, Fotis.

Martinu has always been given a rough critical ride, condemned as old-fashioned and too aesthetically pliable. Here, the choruses, especially, have true grandeur, conveyed impressively by the ROH chorus. Even if the rest of the score at times sounds thin, with none of the knotty complexities of his contemporaries, it makes strong theatre and tells a story. That's enough.

Since Martinu had been dead two years by the time The Greek Passion was first performed, he never knew what people thought of it. Britten, on the contrary, was all too alive to witness the abuse heaped on his Gloriana, first performed in 1953, and described by Lord Harewood as 'one of the great disasters of operatic history'.

Nearly half a century later, our views have changed. The work may have its problems, but Phyllida Lloyd's celebrated staging for Opera North was one of the great productions of the Nineties. One reason for its triumph is the casting of Josephine Barstow as a caustic Elizabeth I, now recreated in a filmed version for television shown on BBC2. It took some time to grow accustomed to the all-seeing camera following the Virgin Queen off stage and into her dressing-room. Yet the effect was intriguing and compelling.

Britten's libretto (by William Plomer) takes Lytton Strachey's Elizabeth and Essex as a starting point, with Essex characterised as the dashing, troublesome love-toy of the ageing queen. Thomas Randle, in flowing black wig, conveyed his ardent opportunism to perfection. The chief regret in an otherwise worthwhile enterprise was the favouring of voices over orchestra in the recording. This is a frustrating habit of music broadcasts on radio too. To squeeze the sound in this way robs us of half the composer's intentions.

Paul Daniel and the Opera North orchestra, without doubt doing their best, seemed to be in a different room. This sort of thing ruins people's first experiences of live opera (when singers are in their correct sound proportions), as well as of concertos where they are used aurally to a violin or cello as big as the Ritz. Does no one else object to this auditory manipulation?

fields.headline: Thin Elvis
fields.standfirst: Copyright problems have made rock'n'roll spectacular The King a pale shadow of its subject
fields.trailText: The King
fields.body:
The King Sadler's Wells, London EC1

You have been warned: 'This production is not endorsed by Elvis Presley Enterprises Inc.' Presley's estate is prone to throwing its weight and its money around, so rather than risk an injunction, Peter Schaufuss has reworked his Elvis ballet, The King, for his company's London debut, changing the scenario and selection of songs.

The 'dansical spectacular' had toured Scandinavia last year without copyright problems. When The King 's British visit was publicised, however, the music publishers and Elvis Presley Enterprises kicked up a fuss. The show's Edinburgh dates were cancelled to give time to reorganise the choreography for Sadler's Wells (until 6 May). The story now revolves around an Elvis impersonator who abandons his band to seek fame, fortune, booze and drugs in big-time Blackpool. The location, mentioned in the printed scenario though not, of course, in the songs, can obviously be relocated when the ballet tours.

Our opening-night hero, Juan Rodriguez (who trained at the London Studio Centre), is an amazingly convincing Elvis lookalike. He starts and ends the show coiled around his alter-ego, Zara Deakin, whose jet-black quiff of hair exactly matches his. She will be his fate, reclaiming him in the final section to Wagner's Liebestod. This isn't just rock'n'roll - it's life'n'death, celebrity and sacrifice.

Two other women alternate in duets with him: one in white (Caroline Petter), his saintly mother, and the other in black (Lisa Probert), his girlfriend. Mother is associated with the maudlin songs; Priscilla - sorry, Debbie - with the lovelorn ones. She does him wrong, flinging herself into sexy clinches with other men while he is off Elvis-impersonating. The corps de ballet get the funky numbers.

Presumably because of copyright difficulties, 'Wooden Heart', from Presley's army period in Germany, has been replaced by Marlene Dietrich's 'Muss ich denn'. In a camp routine, leggy females in military fatigues march on pointe, while Elvis - sorry, Johnny - does his drill. Les girls reappear later in bathing dress and toe-shoes, strutting along the Pleasure Beach to 'Tutti Frutti'. They run screaming through the aisles before being halted by big minders as Rodriguez shakes, rattles and rolls, strumming his extended leg like a priapic guitar.

In spite of the audience incursions, the performers' energy does not fully connect with the spectators. In its revised form, the show is too stop-start. The format is that of a revue with pretensions, but rubber-jointed Rodriguez is a splendid dancer, with the stamina and presence to sustain a very demanding central role.

Almost the only time he leaves the stage is to change into his white Elvis-in-Vegas outfit - the costume choice of Elvis impersonators in the audience. The new scenario is nonsense but the show is well-packaged, in stylish designs by Steven Scott - and, pared down, it's mercifully brief.

fields.headline: The new prince of Wales
fields.standfirst: Matthew Rhys is not only being seduced every night by Kathleen Turner in The Graduate, he also stars in Metropolis, a new ITV thriller about - graduates. And,  Kate Kellaway  discovers, he is in love with an older  woman in real life
fields.trailText: Matthew Rhys is not only being seduced every night by Kathleen Turner in The Graduate, he also stars in Metropolis, a new ITV thriller about - graduates. And, Kate Kellaway discovers, he is in love with an older woman in real life
fields.body:
Matthew Rhys has been practising the art of seduction. In Metropolis, the compulsively watchable ITV thriller (beginning tomorrow) about six graduates from Leeds trying to make a go of it in London, he plays the male equivalent of a dumb blonde: he's an unemployed brunette with unruly hair and devastating blue eyes. Matthew (the actor and the character share a name) is young, lazy and seldom seen out of bed. His main occupation is smoking dope. He is vile to his girlfriends but there is a kind of sexual provocation to his insults and he is rewarded for his lack of charm.

Rhys also plays Ben in Terry Johnson's stage version of the Sixties film The Graduate (at the Gielgud theatre). Ben is smarter than Metropolis Matthew but, like him, has little more than sex appeal to recommend him. Ben's hair is nicely barbered, he has a crisp American accent and a blameless white shirt. He is an amusing contrast to Kathleen Turner's Mrs Robinson. She is smoothly predatory, like a Disney lioness tossing her blond mane. He is jumpy as a grasshopper - he majors in nerves.

Matthew and Ben have this in common: they don't have to do a thing, at least at first, to get their women. Women are drawn to them like stupid moths to a flame. Ben and Matthew share something else. By a bizarre coincidence, they both choose to take the same romantic initiative: each hijacks a wedding with the intention of securing the bride for himself. I suggest to Rhys when we meet, that he should be careful to avoid further scenes of this kind lest it lead to a most peculiar and specific form of type-casting.

We meet at tea-time, at Soho House. Matthew Rhys looks cool - but isn't. He is in no way smooth or over-confident - which makes him immediately likeable. I've always had a weakness for people who trip up easily. (As he left, he got seriously tangled up in the furniture). It is easy to see why he does nerves so well.

I hardly noticed him walk in because of the more extrovert presence of his girlfriend, Ciara Parkes, who runs a PR company. She is an untidily glamorous blonde, a good 10 years older than him (he is 25). Matthew and Ciara have been on the receiving end, inevitably, of jokes about life imitating The Graduate - but seem to be surviving happily. Ciara plays the older woman well. She orders tea in a motherly style and makes no secret of her relationship with Matthew, calling him 'love' in a breezily possessive way.

The first and most striking thing about Matthew is his Welshness. His voice comes as a lilting surprise after hearing his Mancunian and American accents. He is 'intensely proud' of being Welsh (it is his first language). He hangs out with Welsh friends (he shares a flat in Kilburn flat with Welsh actor Ioan Gruffud). He says that 'though it may be a cliché', it is 'frighteningly true' that his nights at the pub end in song. Does he sing well? 'If I am honest, I can string a good tune together. I might even throw a few harmonies in.'

Matthew grew up in a Methodist, working-class family in Cardiff. Both his parents were teachers. He looks back at his childhood affectionately 'through the old rose-tinted spectacles'. His father's family were farmers, his mother's people lived near the sea. Until he was 10 or 12, he wanted to be a farmer. He feels very much 'the same person' now even though his life has changed so much. He minds about his parents' approval and is at his most nervous on stage when one of his family is in the audience. His greatest happiness, he swears, is travelling home by train to Wales.

He went to RADA where he had to unlearn before he could learn a thing. The mannerism police were out in force. 'I was told in week two to stop rubbing my nose when speaking. I had no idea I was doing it.' He is mannerism-free now - except that he often pillows his cheek with his hand. But his language is full of catchphrases. He often uses the word 'frightening' - when he is not frightened at all. And he answers many questions with the words 'To be honest' - there is every reason to believe he is just that. He does not seem vain though he dresses beautifully - he was wearing a white shirt with turquoise cufflinks.

He laughs at himself a lot. When I pointed out that he looked miserable in his photo in the programme, he surprised me by roaring with laughter. 'I'll have to change it. I look nerdy when I smile. I have always wanted to be like Marlon Brando and the brooders.' He makes it sound like an old-fashioned pop group - and I can just see him singing in it.

He loved playing Matthew in Metropolis partly because he is such a conundrum. He kept asking himself 'Who is he?' He tries to find an anchor - something to identify with in each role he plays. He identified with Matthew's working-class background, he says (a safe choice). Rhys has recently been informed that he can no longer pass for 18 - which came as a shock. So how much does age matter? Does the 10 years between himself and Ciara mean anything? 'No I honestly don't believe it does. It never has been an issue for the pair of us because we get on so well together,' he says.

Age was an issue - in a beneficial way - between Rhys and Kathleen Turner. At the audition, he felt 'blind panic', daunted at the thought of the naked scenes between himself and the Hollywood star. 'For the first 40 minutes I was a dribbling mess. She was brilliant: she had been there, done that.' A different take on the experienced woman? 'That's it. The whole kernel of the play was in that audition.' And Turner had a say in the casting. So he must have done OK.

Matthew Rhys has been in seven movies - he can be seen next month in the seventh as Demetrius in Julie Taymor's Titus Andronicus. His eighth will be a Welsh version of Braveheart in which he will play a jealous brother by the name of Llywelan. He will be on horseback a lot - he is a good rider. And presumably the film will be made in Wales (alias heaven). Rhys says the most difficult thing about acting is 'keeping your integrity in a world so heavily governed by other people's opinions'.

What he means, I think, is: it is hard to keep your head. Does he ever imagine middle-age? Being 45 - like Kathleen Turner? 'Yes - and it's frightening. I wonder: Will I still be acting?'

webTitle: The Classical Brits. Oh please, no!

fields.headline: The Classical Brits. Oh please, no!
fields.standfirst: Naked divas, movie tie-ins, spurious awards. Welcome to the final days of the classical music industry
fields.trailText: Naked divas, movie tie-ins, spurious awards. Welcome to the final days of the classical music industry
fields.body:
It is an old and shameless ploy: an economic group whose activities are not esteemed by society - ferret breeders perhaps, or used car salesmen - boosts its morale by inventing an awards ceremony. Silversmiths are commissioned, a hall is hired, press releases go out. No one else would think of celebrating such people. There's a solemn pretence that merit is being rewarded, but really it's just an orgy of unearned self-congratulation.

On Saturday at the Royal Albert Hall, the British Phonographic Industry will present the first Classical Brit Awards. The gelled, egregious Kennedy will fiddle, Charlotte Church will weakly warble, Lesley Garrett will effervesce as usual like a shaken bottle of Babycham. In addition, a performance is promised by 'highly acclaimed new soprano Filippa Giordano'. Highly acclaimed by whom, I wonder? By her press agents, I presume: I have never heard of her. And, just to ensure that classical music forfeits forever its lofty allure and spiritual grace, among the presenters will be a man who might himself be given an award as vulgarian of the year: Michael Winner.

The nominees are at best middlebrow, exposing the industry's abject dependence on movie tie-ins. James Horner's More Music From Braveheart, competes for Best Orchestral Album against John Williams's latest brash, blatant marches from Star Wars, while Stephen Warbeck's pastiched score for Shakespeare in Love has earned him a nomination as Male Artist of the Year. Williams also appears in this category, for a deadly compendium of his Greatest Hits.

Charlotte Church stands to win both as Young British Classical Performer and as Female Artist of the Year. Kennedy likewise divides himself between two lists, as Male Artist of the Year and as a candidate for Best Orchestral Album. These doublings suggest the sparseness of the available talent (if, in the case of hacks like Horner or over-exposed moppets like Church, you can call it that).

The ceremony supposedly publicises the vital health of the classical music business, even though it's common knowledge that the sector is moribund. Last week in New York, BMG, the German conglomerate which recently gobbled up RCA, announced that it will make no more classical recordings in Europe. Artists with exclusive contracts found themselves abruptly down-sized: the percussionist Evelyn Glennie has been terminated, and accountants are looking sternly at the cost-effectiveness of the conductor Lorin Maazel and singers such as Waltraud Meier and Vesselina Kasarova. Sony made the same tactical retreat from the classical field a few months ago.

How many other companies will soon come to the same decision that the musicians they retain are an expensive indulgence? EMI artificially resuscitates itself by endlessly 'remastering' Fifties records by Maria Callas who is fortunately dead and so need not be paid royalties. Other companies aren't so lucky. The Deutsche Grammophon website currently announces a recording project which is hardly calculated to make the cash registers trill: a Beethoven cycle conducted by Claudio Abbado - just what the world needs!

The marketers forestalled the end for quite a while by merchandising personality, selling sex rather than sound. Hence the increasingly diaphanous get-ups of Lesley Garrett. Female artists were enticed into sprawling on the floor in tight jeans like the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter or lolling in bed, as the soprano Renée Fleming does on the cover of a new Strauss recital. The diminutive tenor Roberto Alagna was made to bestraddle a motorbike for a Decca recording of La Bohème, with his leather-jacketed consort Angela Gheorgiu clinging to him.

Is there any evidence that these crass stratagems sell records? If the business is so buoyant, why are shops closing all over the country, while those which remain open grudgingly allocate ever smaller quantities of floor space to classical music?

There may well be a funerary air to the Classical Brits. Among the nominees are two faded deities: Kiri Te Kanawa, now content to whisper Maori ditties, and Pavarotti, an arthritic mockery of his erstwhile self who may, if the Italian tax authorities get their way, make his valedictory recordings in jail.

As we live through the last days of the classical music industry, it's worth recalling how recently it all began. The technology for recording sound has existed for less than a century; the virtuosi of the past flourished without it. Music, like all the performing arts, is ephemeral. A note once sung or sounded expires in the air, and cannot be recalled.

This is what makes a great performance precious. We can replay it in our memories, but the reality is as irretrievable as the young face which no longer looks back at us from the mirror. Deprived of the false immortality and slick perfection purveyed by the microphone, musicians may rediscover the truth of their fragile, tragic yet somehow otherworldly vocation - and in the process they might become worthy of receiving awards from us, rather than needing to cheer one another up.

Last week in New York, BMG, the German conglomerate which recently gobbled up RCA, announced that it will make no more classical recordings in Europe. Artists with exclusive contracts found themselves abruptly down-sized: the percussionist Evelyn Glennie has been terminated, and accountants are looking sternly at the cost-effectiveness of the conductor Lorin Maazel and singers such as Waltraud Meier and Vesselina Kasarova. Sony made the same tactical retreat from the classical field a few months ago. How many other companies will soon come to the same decision that the musicians they retain are an expensive indulgence? EMI artificially resuscitates itself by endlessly 'remastering' Fifties records by Maria Callas who is fortunately dead and so need not be paid royalties. Other companies aren't so lucky. The Deutsche Grammophon website currently announces a recording project which is hardly calculated to make the cash registers trill: a Beethoven cycle conducted by Claudio Abbado - just what the world needs! The marketers forestalled the end for quite a while by merchandising personality, selling sex rather than sound. Hence the increasingly diaphanous get-ups of Lesley Garrett. Female artists were enticed into sprawling on the floor in tight jeans like the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter or lolling in bed, as the soprano Renée Fleming does on the cover of a new Strauss recital. The diminutive tenor Roberto Alagna was made to bestraddle a motorbike for a Decca recording of La Bohème, with his leather-jacketed consort Angela Gheorgiu clinging to him. Is there any evidence that these crass stratagems sell records? If the business is so buoyant, why are shops closing all over the country, while those which remain open grudgingly allocate ever smaller quantities of floor space to classical music? There may well be a funerary air to the Classical Brits. Among the nominees are two faded deities: Kiri Te Kanawa, now content to whisper Maori ditties, and Pavarotti, an arthritic mockery of his erstwhile self who may, if the Italian tax authorities get their way, make his valedictory recordings in jail. As we live through the last days of the classical music industry, it's worth recalling how recently it all began. The technology for recording sound has existed for less than a century; the virtuosi of the past flourished without it. Music, like all the performing arts, is ephemeral. A note once sung or sounded expires in the air, and cannot be recalled. This is what makes a great performance precious. We can replay it in our memories, but the reality is as irretrievable as the young face which no longer looks back at us from the mirror. Deprived of the false immortality and slick perfection purveyed by the microphone, musicians may rediscover the truth of their fragile, tragic yet somehow otherworldly vocation - and in the process they might become worthy of receiving awards from us, rather than needing to cheer one another up.

fields.headline: Champion of the word
fields.standfirst: There's a new lyricism to Ed Ruscha's text paintings of rural America
fields.trailText: Ed Ruscha | Juan Cruz
fields.body:
Ed Ruscha Anthony d'Offay, London W1 from Friday

Juan Cruz Camden Arts Centre, London NW3 until 25 May

Ed Ruscha, the American artist, likes to start with a cliché. There's a painting in his new show of snowcapped mountains towering against a Californian sky. These sugar-dusted pinnacles look like the peaks of the Paramount logo; likewise, the picture seems to be a small souvenir of the Great Outdoors enlarged to Cinemascope size. But down among the foothills, like the cross marking the sender's hotel on a postcard, the word 'ME' is stencilled in scarlet capitals. Dwarfed by nature, the ego shrieks to be heard among the picturesque mountains: a silent word in a mordant visual joke.

Ever since he painted Noise in 1963 - a neat paradox of mute noun and loud colour - Ruscha has been playing these word games on canvas. He used to go for the sight gag: 'Heavy Industry' pencilled in feeble graphite, 'The End' printed in Gothic letters scrolling endlessly down a screen. He liked the onomatopoeiac - 'I Think There Is Something Dangerous Going On Here' spelled out in gunpowder - and the word as image; the Hollywood sign blocked out like the final credits to an epic is still his most famous Sixties painting.

But Ruscha began with images that naturally contained words, cityscapes of his native Los Angeles, a bristling thicket of billboards and signs. His latest work transposes the language of the city to the Californian countryside, applying it so literally that the words come directly between viewer and vista. One snowy sierra is barely visible behind the outsize message 'Parking for Tower Rcds', a commercial hangover that obscures the sparkling panorama. Meaningless in this context, the words are nonetheless as obdurate as they were: a banal direction that sticks to the urban mind like a burr.

Which came first - the image or the words? Ruscha's technique is so smooth, so deadpan and flawless, that it's hard to tell whether the letters have been superimposed or were there from the outset. In Blast Curtain, the words seem to have sliced right through the mountain with nuclear efficiency. In Crash Cushion they hover like a threat of megaton disaster. Ruscha has perfected this illusionism in so many ways that he is even able to make the words seem organic to the mountain. In -so, the single syllable emanates from the snow like powdery air, a pause in the mysterious story that this painting narrates.

Sharp Pop with a witty undertone has so long been Ruscha's tune that it is hard to remember that he can also be a romantic lyricist. He loves to give words another dimension, to rescue them from tight spots, to give them a visual hearing. Possibly the least ironic works he has ever produced are the monochrome paintings in the Highways series - four new variations are included in this show.

Oregon, Denver, Kansas, Tennessee: the states whip by, ghostly letters receding between grids of white lines. Names stack up, stretching in sharp perspective towards a hopeful future. Portland, Memphis, Albuquerque, Little Rock: flashing by so quickly you would scarcely sense the dust beneath your wheels. These semi-abstract paintings can be read as imaginary maps, routes to freedom for the escapist heart. But they go beyond the diagram into concrete poems for the canvas: every word holding out the promise of somewhere else in an optical trail of shimmering paint.

Juan Cruz, the young Spanish-English artist who won the prestigious Paul Hamlyn Award last year, has so far made an entire career out of words. For 10 days, he gave a reading of Don Quixote with simultaneous translation, a laborious performance in a darkened room. He has also transcribed the stage directions from Chekhov on various gallery walls in faint pencil, a modest gesture to stimulate the mind's eye which turned out to be as distractingly self-conscious as any stage whisper.

Self-effacement is the supposed virtue of Cruz's work: you look or you listen, but you think of somewhere else. If this is the case, then he is taking a peculiar route with his latest piece, Driving Home, in which he describes, with outstanding pedantry, the tedious details of a car trip. His voice is relayed through a pair of speakers, itemising every bend in the road, every telegraph pole. There are asides - for example, about the way the windscreen frames the vista - but they are enunciated in the same lifeless, mechanical tone. Cruz ignores the first rule of radio - never sound as though you are reading a script. As a result, your mind has no time to wander before you exit fast from the room.

fields.headline: Thighs and lows
fields.standfirst: Tina Turner's final world tour proves that, at the age of 60, she's still anything but retiring
fields.trailText: Tina Turner
fields.body:
Tina Turner National Car Rental Centre, Florida

For 60 years Annie Mae Bullock's life has switched between American dream and American nightmare: the poor, daydreaming girl plucked from nowhere and reinvented as Tina Turner, then the abused wife and washed-up thirtysomething. The legend resurrected as an all-conquering AOR singer, then the increasingly grotesque cartoon character in her fishnets and fright-wig. Now she is planning the dream retirement: after this tour, she will quit the music business to live with her 42-year-old toy-boy in a mountainside mansion near Nice, filling the days with Herculean shopping trips.

So when Turner, in America's ultimate Retirement State, announces to this middle-aged, orange-skinned crowd that the show they are about to witness is 'the journey of my career', we know we are in for one long, lurid ride. In this sense, Tina Turner does not disappoint. Her last-ever stadium tour, currently eating up America and due to hit Britain in July, is high on entertainment value if low on taste.

Nearly three hours long, it comes complete with 20ft flames, an enormous metallic stage, a second stage that flies out over the audience, a nine-piece backing band, three eye-popping dancers, two backing singers (one of them Gloria Reuben, who used to play Jeanie Boulet in ER), video screens flashing up archive footage, and, at the centre of it all, a 5ft 4in muscular miracle in heels as high as barstools. It's like a pop Disney World, fun and nauseating in equal parts.

The venue is perfect. The charmingly named National Car Rental Centre, home of ice-hockey team the Florida Marlins, looks like the Royal Albert Hall bloated to three times its normal size. A large section of the car park is devoted entirely to stretch limos. In the lobby, TT T-shirts sell for $35-$55.

By the time Turner appears, at 10pm, the crowd is already up for it, having wiggled its seats warm through a glitzy disco set by Lionel Richie. One woman in the front row holds up a banner for the entire show which reads, somewhat sweepingly: 'Scandinavia Love Tina'. Just in case anyone still imagines they are in for an introspective acoustic concert, she begins with a pumped-up version of Sly Stone's 'I Wanna Take You Higher'. This is followed by a workmanlike new song, 'Absolutely Nothing's Changed', and a sweet reprise of 'Fool In Love', the first song she ever recorded.

But frankly it is hard to concentrate on the music when you watch Tina Turner move. Dressed in spray-on black leather knee-length pants and black leather jacket, her hairpiece so wild and woolly that it looks as if the Dulux dog is asleep on her head, she half-swaggers, half-waddles across the stage, as though she's still recovering from some fearful rectal operation. Encased in leather, her legendary thighs remain an uncomfortable-looking four inches apart throughout all her dance routines. There's always been something masochistic about Turner's wardrobe, but this is ridiculous: you feel like ringing the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Pensioners and asking them to intervene.

The material is a true reflection of her career: raw Sixties originals ('Nutbush City Limits', 'Proud Mary'), smooth soul covers ('I Heard It Through the Grapevine', 'Try A Little Tenderness'), slick Eighties ballads ('Better Be Good To Me', 'Private Dancer'), and ugly, bombastic advertising jingles ('Simply the Best', 'Addicted to Love'). It is Turner's commercial fortune and artistic misfortune that her revival came in 1983. In the 17 years since, her music has never lost the arid, overblown feel of that era.

Through it all, though, her voice has never really changed. Rasping and indomitable on most songs, it is infinitely more listenable on those rare occasions when she allows some vulnerability to seep into its machine-like delivery, as on a slow gospel rendition of The Beatles' 'Help'. Most of the time, though, the ruthless power and pace of this show precludes any real intimacy or soulfulness.

Still, as a big-balled, super-charged entertainment extravaganza, Tina Turner's farewell tour cannot be faulted. At 60, she shows no signs of losing that incredible energy. Indeed, she seems almost to have too much. At one point, she interrupts her wet-nappy strut to have what looks like a silent toddler tantrum - legs and arms shaking weirdly for several seconds. Let's hope she's truly knackered by the end of this tour. Otherwise the high-street boutiques of the French Riviera are going to be hit like they've never been hit before.

 Tina Turner plays Hampden Park, Glasgow (7 July); Millennium Stadium, Cardiff (9 July); Don Valley Stadium, Sheffield (13 July); and Wembley Stadium, London (15,16 July)

webTitle: I've taken a shine to it...

fields.headline: I've taken a shine to it...
fields.standfirst: The gleaming Lowry Centre is a gem among the redeveloped urban dross of Salford Quays
fields.trailText: The gleaming Lowry Centre is a gem among the redeveloped urban dross of Salford Quays
fields.body:
Three months after its inaugural performance, the Royal Opera House, huge though it is, has all but vanished from the radar screens of everyone but confirmed opera buffs. The Tate Modern hasn't even opened yet and already we are sick of hearing about it. Spoilt for choice, we want to move on to the next big thing.

The new National Portrait Gallery, the new Somerset House, the new Wallace Collection, the new Science Museum and the new British Museum are still to come. Projects that would have been treated at any other time as once-in-a-decade landmarks are being shuffled off the stage with almost indecent haste as we wait for the next architectural blockbuster.

None of the current crop of Lottery-funded projects has suffered more from this kind of fatigue than the Lowry Centre. It is an enormously brave attempt by Michael Wilford to build as if architecture mattered, in the midst of an environment dedicated to the proposition that it's not worth a damn.

But well before it was actually completed, busy critics were writing it off as a cut-price Bilbao on the basis that, like Frank Gehry's Guggenheim, it is made of shiny metal and tries to breathe cultural regeneration into a blighted industrial relic. Despite its undoubtedly striking form, Wilford's building is architecturally at the opposite extreme from the Guggenheim.

Frank Gehry likes to build wilful, expressionist sculpture with a strongly personal vocabulary. Wilford's building, on the other hand, is about the fundamental, but unaccountably neglected issue of making architectural space. It is neither architectural sculpture, nor an anonymous box inside a flashy skin. It is a building of rich complexity which has to be experienced in its completed state to realise its full impact. And it still isn't quite complete even now, despite its official opening last Friday.

The Lowry is the new heart of Salford Quays on which Manchester's nineteenth-century prosperity was built, but which now has the jaw-dropping banality of the kind of generic urban landscape that we had all better get used to.

Wandering through the the maze of cul de sacs, pedestrian courtyards, call centres and back offices that carpet the area in a snowdrift of junk building, you could be in one of Canary Wharf's less favoured corners, just about anywhere on the M25, on the banks of the Clyde or in Slough.

It is as if, having been made brutally aware of the transience of the Victorians, our generation has abandoned any attempt to build to last, revelling in Styrofoam rather than stone. The call centres could all vanish tomorrow, so why bother to put them in anything with more lasting quality than a set for Brookside?

Salford Quays could have been a real place. It still has the water of the canal basins, and the big, grey northern skies billowing over them. But instead, it is a sea of numbing mediocrity in which a few giant objects, of which Manchester United's Old Trafford stadium is the most conspicuous, float aimlessly. Now there is the Lowry to join it.

How can architecture hold its own in such an environment? Clearly, it is no place for shrinking violets. And Wilford, once the partner of James Stirling, perhaps the most distinguished British architect of the twentieth century, is certainly not that. Like Stirling, he has a passion for the gamier architectural flavours.

Wilford has a weakness for vivid colour, strong shapes and bold forms. And he has used them in abundance to give the Lowry the bravura presence that makes it feel as if it belongs to a different universe from the restaurant franchises, and package-deal car-parks that shaped its context.

The Lowry has a complex range of motivations. It was first mooted as an opera house, a brief that was later modified to turn it into a lyric theatre. It is a reflection of Salford's determination to be seen as more than just an administrative anomaly next door to Manchester. It is an attempt to bring investment into the area. But in the end, it is about creating a place that people want to be in. And if it succeeds in that, it will have achieved all its other objectives.

Oddly, what it is least about is Lowry the painter. There is a gallery dedicated to a changing selection of his paintings and an archive of his works, stacked up in a tower of white cubes contained in the stainless-steel cylinder that marks the entrance like an lighthouse. But the two Lowry rooms form a relatively minor element in what is fundamentally a theatre complex.

There are two stages, one with 1,700 seats and a second, smaller auditorium. Although the foyers are flamboyant, the two auditoria, each with a distinct personality, manage to combine an appropriate sense of theatrical occasion with intimacy.

Despite the prestige we accord to theatres, this is not promising material out of which to make great architecture. Look at what happened to the Barbican arts centre in London with much the same mix of spaces. For an architect trying to create a landmark, the art gallery is a more forgiving brief than a theatre, which has to carry the weight of too much technical paraphernalia. There are too many blank walls, too many loading docks and too many escape stairs.

But Wilford's design deals with all this brilliantly. He has taken the theatres and turned them into a composition which relates to the impossible setting by wrapping them in a continuous promenade of foyers, bars restaurants and gallery spaces. You could come to the Lowry just to take a walk in them: it's certainly a more eventful journey than going for a stroll anywhere else in Salford Quays.

Through a skilful series of changes of level that makes the main floor of the centre undulate like a gently rolling landscape, you get a series of spectacular views out over water, and find yourself moving from one space to the next, from a tight corridor to a clearing in the forest, constantly reminded of the building itself and water and sky outside.

The Lowry's architect has done the job he was asked do and more. The question now is whether people will come in sufficient numbers to bring the centre to life. The projections are for an ambitious 800,000 a year, a lot for a receiving house with a modest gallery attached. And even an architectural promenade as dynamic as the Lowry's can't guarantee those numbers.

 For details phone: 0161 876 2000

Through a skilful series of changes of level that makes the main floor of the centre undulate like a gently rolling landscape, you get a series of spectacular views out over water, and find yourself moving from one space to the next, from a tight corridor to a clearing in the forest, constantly reminded of the building itself and water and sky outside. The Lowry's architect has done the job he was asked do and more. The question now is whether people will come in sufficient numbers to bring the centre to life. The projections are for an ambitious 800,000 a year, a lot for a receiving house with a modest gallery attached. fields.headline: In the name of the father
fields.standfirst: In 1995, the distinguished playwright Ken Saro-Wiwa was hanged after his campaign against Western oil firms in Nigeria. Last week  Ken Wiwa went home to bury his father. Here he describes his extraordinary journey
fields.trailText: In 1995, the distinguished playwright Ken Saro-Wiwa was hanged after his campaign against Western oil firms in Nigeria. Last week  Ken Wiwa went home to bury his father. Here he describes his extraordinary journey
fields.body:
At midnight on the eve of my father's funeral there was a cool breeze blowing in his home village. Easter Sunday had been a hot, muggy day. The rains that had threatened all weekend still hadn't arrived and the village was sweltering under a clammy night. The wind rustling through the palm trees offered some respite to the crowd gathered in my father's compound for a night vigil and the traditional wake-keeping.

Inside my father's concrete bungalow, there was an eerie, muted atmosphere. Outside, troops of Ogoni women marched around the house singing a haunting eulogy. Every now and again a masquerade or a dance troupe would emerge out of the darkness in a frenzy of colour and movement whipping up the atmosphere to the beat of thundering drummers. And still the rain held.

As the breeze blew through the bungalow I found a quiet spot by a window and sat staring at a life-sized picture of my father perched on a table across the room. It was taken about two years before his execution on 10 November 1995. His face is slightly lopsided from the effort of keeping his pipe in the corner of his mouth. My father was never the most photogenic subject. Somehow the camera never quite caught the man I knew. He always looks too conscious of the image he is trying to project. The picture I was staring at was different though. He must have been caught off guard. As I stared at the picture, he looked to me as though he somehow knew that his life was going to end violently. I found myself wondering what was going through his mind in the last seconds before he was hanged.

I've been over that question so many times and I've learnt to stop myself from wandering too far down that road. I kept staring at the picture, though, searching for something. It seemed so real, so lifelike that I deluded myself it was about to send me a sign, give me some reassurance that I was doing him proud. I was still looking for his approval when a fork of lightning snaked across the sky. The storm was approaching and for the next hour intermittent and spectacular bursts of lightning lit up the night.

The eve of my father's funeral was a spectacular African night. The remnants of a full moon gave the night an opaque silvery, grey texture that silhouetted the palm trees and village against the sky. As the breeze picked up, the palm trees swayed and sighed in the wind. Small drops of rain began to fall.

For a while it seemed we might only get a small spattering until a sustained burst scattered the crowd, drenching the singers and dancers and battering down on the corrugated aluminium roof of my father's bungalow. When I looked out onto the front porch, it seemed as if the whole of my village had massed in a huddle on the veranda.

Bane is the home of my clan. It is one of the 120 or so Ogoni villages scattered around 404 square miles of a gently sloping floodplain on the north-eastern fringes of the Niger delta. You get there by taking the main road north out of Port Harcourt, a congested, smoke-filled city on the southern coast of Nigeria. After an hour's drive you turn off the main road and head down a road that snakes through the rainforest and into my village.

When I returned to bury my father, it was eight years since I had last visited the village. The journey back there began in September last year when I called members of my family to a meeting in Chicago for preliminary discussions about a date for my father's funeral. According to Ogoni traditions, I, as my father's saro (eldest son), am the chief mourner and it is my duty and responsibility to bury him. Since his death he had been buried alongside the eight other men executed with him in an unmarked grave in Port Harcourt cemetery, but the return to civilian rule in Nigeria last year meant we now had the opportunity to recover his bones for a proper burial.

My father's execution had deepened my ambivalence and heightened old anxieties about the land of my birth. I'd spent much of my teenage years and early twenties in England and I had become somewhat alienated from my culture. Although I still spoke my native language and had many fond memories of my childhood in Nigeria, I had already decided, subconsciously, at 23, that I was going to make England my home.

Deep down, I suspect, in fact I now know, that my decision had been motivated by an intense yearning to get away from my father. Long before Ken Saro-Wiwa became a symbol of human rights and environmental activism, he had acquired a reputation as an outspoken political commentator and a trenchant, fearless critic of military rule in Nigeria. He was also well-known there as a successful self-made businessman. But his shadow ended at Nigeria's border. Outside the country I was free of it, free to be whatever I wanted to be, free to be Ken Saro-Wiwa. The fact that we shared the same name didn't trouble me in England because there, at least, it had very little currency.

That all began to change in my late teens and early twenties once my father's shadow began to encroach on my hideaway in England. By the time he formed the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (Mosop) in 1990 and the organisation began to attract attention around the world, I sensed that there was room for only one Ken Saro-Wiwa in this world. So I changed my name, dropping the Saro and hiding behind the less colourful Ken Wiwa. My father was dismayed when I told him but since he was in detention by then, there was nothing he could do about it and I gleefully signed myself short whenever I wrote to him.

Ours was a fractious and difficult relationship. My father had been wary that I would lose touch with our roots when he sent me, my brother Gian and two sisters to private schools in England. I was sent abroad to get the 'best education that money can buy'. That education was meant to equip me to return to Nigeria to take a leadership role or at least play my part in the Ogoni community. During my teens, my father took every opportunity to impress on me that I was being groomed for a purpose. Naturally, I rebelled and spent my teenage years avoiding anything that smelled of responsibility, trying to evade the issue of having to return home to repay my dues to my father and my people.

My father's killer, the former dictator General Sani Abacha, had been my alibi for staying away for five of the past eight years. When my father was arrested in May 1994, I decided to give up my life as a journalist in London to lead the worldwide campaign to save Ken Saro-Wiwa's life. I offered myself as a focus to his story. I slipped into the role of my father's spokesman rather too easily for my liking. I often imagine him sitting in his cell relieved that that boy of his was finally making his expensive education pay off.

Wherever I travelled to spread the word of his predicament I regurgitated all the politics that had been drilled into me down the years. I played the role so well that many people came to see Ken Saro-Wiwa and Ken Wiwa as one and the same. Abacha was not impressed and I was placed on his wanted list should I return to Nigeria. So I became a political exile. I was delighted. Where I had struggled against a creeping shame and guilt over my decision to stay away from Nigeria, I now had a valid reason to stay away.

Abacha's death in 1998 meant there was nowhere left to hide. It was time to return to face everything I had been running away from. It was time to face up to what it meant to be Ken Saro-Wiwa's son.

When I emerged from Port Harcourt airport I was greeted by a crowd of about a thousand Ogonis cheering and waving ecstatically. Before I had time to take stock, I was surrounded by delirious Ogonis wearing T-shirts emblazoned with my father's name. A giant flag adorned with his picture was unfurled behind me while an activist stepped out of the crowd to recite, verbatim, my father's final statement to the tribunal that sentenced him to death. I blinked as the flashbulbs of a thousand and one cameras popped off in the early evening light.

Welcome to Nigeria, I thought wearily as my car pulled out of the airport followed by a convoy of Ogonis who had come to witness the reincarnation of Ken Saro-Wiwa. My personal needs had been hijacked, subsumed under the higher political agenda of our people. In short, the story of my life.

When I arrived at my father's home in the city, the house was full of friends and relatives who had come to welcome me home. I stopped briefly to greet everyone then made a beeline for my father's study. A small rectangular room, about 10 foot by six, it is packed full of documents, files, letters, books and photographs. It was where my father always retreated after a long day at the office. He would sit in there, listening to the news on World Service on his shortwave radio before writing into the early hours. He always left the door open. I would be in my room down the corridor, my door also open so that I could listen to the news blaring from the radio. The invitation to come in was clear but I never took it up. I found it hard to relax around my father and I kept my distance.

No one had been in the study since 21 May 1994 - the night my father was arrested. Entering it was like opening a mausoleum. It was eerie discovering how many books we had in common. It dawned on me that I have unconsciously or otherwise replicated my father's working arrangements in my own home. I also have a study crammed full of books from where I spend most of my time trying to unravel the puzzle of his life and death. Many of my favourite authors were in my father's library: V.S. Naipaul; Chinua Achebe; Wole Soyinka; Ngugi Wa' Thiongo; Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Nadine Gordimer and Ben Okri. I also found out-of-print books I had been trying to get hold of myself.

The next morning I set out for the village. I got down from the car and walked the last quarter-mile to my father's house. People streamed out of their homes just to get a glimpse of me. It was a humbling experience. I was wary, though. I am always conscious that much, if not all of the adulation and sympathy I get is reflected glory. And that it comes with expectations.

The joy on the faces of the Ogonis told a powerful story of a people still in mourning for my father. Everywhere I went people kept telling me how much I looked like him. It began to dawn on me that our people were desperate for a return to the kind of selfless and inspired leadership he had provided. He and I were obviously seen as an interchangeable commodity and their expectation of my homecoming was that though Ken Saro-Wiwa was dead another Ken Saro-Wiwa was ready to step in and fill the breach.

The highlight of going back to the village was seeing my grandparents. My grandfather, Chief Jim Wiwa, is 96 years old and still going strong, although I was relieved to hear that he seems to be slowing down a little. His last child, Gibson, my great-uncle, is now seven, and he appears to be Papa's last. Papa has become something of a celebrity around here. He has been interviewed by journalists from around the world and can always be relied upon to provide a soundbite blasting the government's treatment of his son.

Papa's face lit up like a little boy when he saw me. He had been waiting for the moment ever since my father was executed. But it was my grandmother who brought home to me what my return really meant. Frail as she was at 74 she hugged me tightly and whispered in my ear that now she had seen me she wasn't going to cry any more. It was then that I realised that my return was as much for the people I had left behind as it was about my own feelings.

Once I satisfied everyone's need to see me, I returned to Port Harcourt to prepare for a meeting with the State Governor, Dr Peter Odili. I wrote to President Obasanjo of Nigeria last year requesting the return of my father's bones to our family and he responded warmly. But Dr Odili now told me that he had been unable to obtain the consent necessary for the exhumation from the families of the other men buried with him. We were going to have to go ahead with a symbolic burial.

The authorities were clearly nervous about the prospect of Ken Saro-Wiwa's funeral being used as a focus for the continuing discontent in the Niger Delta. My father's championing of minority rights had greatly annoyed the élites who have ruled Nigeria since its independence in 1960. Almost all of Nigeria's annual income of £22 billion of oil is derived from petroleum or oil-related activities in the delta of the Niger but the people of the delta benefit from just 13 per cent of the revenue. My father persistently argued that the oil bearing communities deserved at least 50 per cent, especially as the money was needed to alleviate the problems caused by oil exploration.

By sensitising Ogoni and other ethnic groups in the delta to their exploitation, Ken Saro-Wiwa came to be viewed as a threat to the status quo. The powers that be decided he had to be eliminated by any means. The circumstances leading up to his arrest, trial and execution are tangled and will, in time, surely unravel. In the meantime the élites feared a Ken Saro-Wiwa funeral would open old wounds. But I told the Governor I was determined to keep it simple and free of all political agenda.

After my meeting with him I returned to the village on Wednesday 19 April to begin preparations for a funeral scheduled for the following Monday. The Easter Monday date had been set since last November and my grandfather had made a public announcement to that effect in January. But a faction of Mosop had declared that my father should be buried with the eight other Ogoni martyrs at a later date chosen by a burial committee. While I sympathised with the sentiment I was incensed at not being consulted. In the end common sense prevailed and the family funeral was allowed to go ahead.

However, by Good Friday, due to the lack of adequate communication between the village and the city, preparations still hadn't begun. We hadn't even started to dig my father's grave and the service had not been planned or organised. We didn't have a coffin, no food had been prepared, no drinks bought and my father's bungalow in the village hadn't been cleaned or painted. It would take a miracle to finish the preparations in three days. We were up against the clock and besides, it was Easter weekend. I had three sleepless nights worrying that we might not be able to give my father a befitting send off. I had nightmares that the burial would shame his memory.

God, I guess, works in mysterious ways because by Sunday night, I was relaxed enough to sit down and contemplate what the morrow would bring.

My grandfather and two of my uncles woke me from a short nap at dawn. I had almost observed the vigil but the lack of sleep caught up with me. At 10.30 that morning, my sister Zina led the procession out of the house holding a cross of wreaths she had helped to pluck from the forest. Behind the pall bearers, Zina's twin Noo carried the picture of my father. I followed behind, leading the family as the procession headed for the Anglican Church immediately behind my father's house.

The crowds, already 10-deep kept a respectful distance as the procession moved to the church for an interdenominational service. It went smoothly enough considering that the order of service had only been agreed and printed on Saturday night and despite frequent interruptions from a restive crowd that had massed outside. The church was packed with clan members who had commuted from all corners of the world. In all there were about 300 of us give or take a 100 or so uninvited guests who gatecrashed the occasion in the honoured Nigerian tradition.

After a seemingly interminable two hours, the procession moved from the church and followed a narrow dirt track to the one-acre plot that had been donated to the family by the village. Walking the 400 yards to my father's resting place was one of the most powerful experiences of my life. I struggled to contain my emotions, hiding my tears behind dark glasses and a stern expression. The route was lined with people straining to get a glimpse of the coffin and the procession.

Such is the love and respect for my father that nothing was going to stop people from getting a glimpse of their hero's burial. The crowd massed on the fringes of a gentle sloping plot of land that had only been cleared three days before. In the middle of the field was a concrete tomb, 20 feet deep and beautifully tiled.

As the coffin containing his pipe and two treasured books was lowered people surged to the edge of the grave. For one terrible moment it looked as if we would be swept into it by the crowd. There must have been about 5,000 people clamouring to get a better view. Scuffles and arguments broke out. It was impossible with all the shouting to hear the presiding archdeacon give the final orations. On my cue, ashes to ashes, dust to dust... I shovelled three small clumps of earth onto the coffin before retreating, fighting my way through the crowd to the bungalow for a moment of contemplation before receiving guests and condolences.

And so my father was finally laid to rest. When his bones are finally exhumed they will be reinterred with his coffin. It seems almost futile as I now write, three days later, to try to make sense of what I have been through in the past week. So much has happened and I feel I have lived several lives. I suspect it will take time before it all falls into place. I feel somewhat empty, that I was denied the opportunity to express my grief. But I am resigned to the feeling. After all, my father was a father to everyone and perhaps it is only right to allow everyone to have shared in the occasion.

In a week's time I will be back in Toronto where my wife Olivia is expecting our second child at any moment. Birth and death, the full cycle of life. All in the space of a month.

But I will return here. You can never leave Africa. It infects you, inhabits your very being, waits patiently like a dutiful wife for your return. As I prepare to leave I have a distinct feeling that one life has finally come to an end and another is just beginning.

 Ken Wiwa's memoir of his relationship with his father and his country, The Shadow of a Saint, will be published by Doubleday this autumn.
