fields.headline: When Saturday comes...
fields.standfirst: After a hard, 40-hour slog at the office, all you want to do is put your feet up, says  Phil Hogan. But the one thing they don't tell you about being a parent is... you don't get weekends off
fields.trailText: After a hard, 40-hour slog at the office, all you want to do is put your feet up, says Phil Hogan. But the one thing they don't tell you about being a parent is... you don't get weekends off
fields.body:
What happens to the weekend when you have kids? Where does it go? And, to borrow an old metaphysical chestnut, does a weekend still exist if you don't see it flash by with your own eyes?

It's one of the quirks of biological necessity that nature smooths the course of human reproduction by opening our minds to the pleasures of parenthood while keeping us ignorant of the full scale of its horrors. We think changing nappies is the bad part, when they're the easy bit. We joke with pregnant fathers about the prospect of sleepless nights, though at the time of joking we still think of a sleepless night as something that can be slept off during the day, the result of some self-inflicted pleasure - a marathon drugs binge perhaps or a conspicuously protracted sex tournament with someone you're still trying to impress.

Even when we've made up our minds to have kids and done the antenatal classes, skimmed through the manuals and thought up trendy names, we're still pretty clueless. Until it's too late. None of us expects having children to improve the quality of life exactly, but where does it say you have to give up weekends?

Having a civilised weekend is what separates us from the dolphins. It is Saturday, therefore you get up at noon, go to the pub, buy a pint of milk, go back to bed, eat some Pot Noodles, watch Match of the Day, go back to bed again. The details may differ from person to person (some people, I understand, enjoy potholing and visiting museums and, if you are a couple, sexual intercourse and shopping for kitchen utensils might well come into it), but the point is you can do what you like. It's supposed to be the opposite of work.

But that was then. All the surveys are telling us how frantic we are about devoting more quality time to our children - far more than our parents ever gave us, the bastards - and the weekend is when we do it. Our children can't get rid of us. We scoop them up and take them off to leisure pools or Roman ruins or museums specialising in agricultural machinery. We read to them, pretend to take an interest in their incomprehensible computer games, intrude on their private woes with our anxiety for their mental health. One day they'll hate us for it. And it's all down to guilt for not being around enough the rest of the week.

Working women are by far the worst culprits. According to one survey, mothers in full-time employment do 56 hours of chores and childcare every week. I'm sorry, but that is sick. Even fathers do 31 hours (it says here). Of course, women are bound to do the lion's share of the housework - it's in the blood, as I think Darwin explained. But this is something else. And it all adds up to less time to relax, put your feet up and watch Football Focus.

Even after four children, I still can't quite get used to the lost weekend. Once I'm out of bed at the shockingly late hour of 8.30, I hang around in my dressing-gown eating toast, awaiting instructions from my wife, whose job it is to run the duty roster and stop me sitting down to read yesterday's paper. One of us has to take the six-year-old for his swimming lesson, leaving the other (me) to take an active interest in the rest of them, who are watching Pokémon and who I'm pretty sure wouldn't notice if I set myself on fire, let alone slipped back to bed for a while.

But I can't. Statistically, one of the children will need to be taken for either a haircut or a pair of shoes. There will be endless meals and auxiliary snacks to prepare, cook and clear away. We might lose one child to a party at Quasar (if you have to ask, don't), but one of us will have to ferry him to the next town and pick him up again. A small DIY job will have risen to the top of our priorities, involving the use of a drill, which will breed subsidiary DIY jobs of polyfilling unwanted craters around the site of the first.

Our staggered sessions of baths, TV suppers and bedtime stories will stretch from six till 9.45 and that's it. Half the weekend gone. Do you see any room in there for going trout-fishing, writing haikus or climbing Mount Snowdon? After Hoovering up the debris and mopping their footprints off the walls, we will sit down and open a bottle of red wine to celebrate still being awake. Admittedly, the proceedings will still be enlivened by Match of the Day, but the five-minute spell in which all the goals are scored will be marked by our three-year-old shouting the house down for a drink or a wee or, sometimes, just for the hell of it.

I do feel sorry for new parents. Polly (not her real name), who my wife knows from the days when she had a social life that didn't involve taking the Tesco loyalty card out with her, has one of those cash-rich, time-poor jobs that entails flying to Tokyo and back just in time to watch the nanny putting 18-month-old Archie to bed, which then means devoting weekends to doing guilt-time with the little chap. It's driving her nutty.

'I'm trying to make up what I can't give him properly in the week, but I'm so exhausted. We never have a lie-in,' she tells me. 'I miss going to lunch and the cinema and just relaxing. You think children are just going to fit into your life and they don't. You have to fit into theirs. You think you can just take them into restaurants with you, but you end up at Pizza Hut or somewhere else with highchairs. I can never go shopping for clothes or go into a department store. I know it sounds selfish but I just want five minutes to unwind and relax. To be honest, I'd really quite like to get my nails done.'

Her husband who is a part-time lecturer and in his late fifties (quite a bit older than her), is very good - though at medieval history rather than childcare. 'He makes a big fuss of Archie,' she says, 'but he doesn't much like being left alone with him. He doesn't know what to do.'

Well I'm glad it's not just me.

I'm in the pub with Sam after a hard day at the office. 'How do you relax at weekends?' I ask. Sam has three boys and is still under 30, so obviously I'm looking for tales of woe. 'Play tennis in the mornings,' he says. 'Take the kids to the supermarket in the afternoon, chill out...' Chilling out involves watching something called Soccer Saturday on Sky! I can't believe it. 'We look after the kids in shifts,' he explains. His wife Odile, who is French and laid back, bakes cakes, but sometimes just slobs around watching ancient Sunday afternoon movies while he takes the kids swimming. They buy a huge Indian (food, not person) for Saturday night. They are very happy.

'And you don't have to do anything else - housework, DIY?'

What - at the weekend ? He never does DIY or housework. He tells me about a man who lives on a boat nearby and does the occasional odd job for them. A woman comes in to clean every couple of weeks. He starts telling me about long lie-ins, leisurely breakfasts. I have to stop him before he starts telling me about his fantastic sex life.

Still, as a strategy for relaxation, shiftwork has much to recommend it and is obviously less traumatic than divorce as a means of sharing the children out at weekends. I do have a few escape routes myself, the most successful one being retiring to my so-called study to do something urgent that I had forgotten about. Less risky strategies include asking friends round, which involves cooking and cleaning, but you do get to talk to other adults and drink during daylight. Better still is to go to someone else's house and let them do the work.

But the healthy alternative is... well, getting used to it. Natalie, one of the mums at our children's school has five kids under 12 and holds down a job as a doctor too. Is she completely mad? No, she loves her work, she says, because she gets to use her brain and is allowed to go to the toilet on her own. But she looks forward to weekends, too, even though Colin, her husband (a consultant), works Saturdays.

'The weekend is a lot easier because the pressure's off. I don't have to get them to school; there are no after-school activities, no music practice.' Just lots more time for cuddling, she says. Of course, there's the usual frenetic round of football training, library, swimming lessons, flat tyres to repair and washing machines to load up. But she doesn't do any dusting or gardening or ironing. A woman comes in to help with the kids and housework during the week and that's it.

'Don't you ever do anything without the children?' I ask.

'Never,' she says. 'But the point is I don't expect any time to myself. As soon as you accept that this is your life - having loads of children, getting up in the middle of the night - you enjoy it. I don't fight it, I just go with it.'

Maybe I could just 'go' with it too. I'll definitely give it some thought. Well, the next time I can hear myself think.
fields.bodyText: What happens to the weekend when you have kids? Where does it go? And, to borrow an old metaphysical chestnut, does a weekend still exist if you don't see it flash by with your own eyes? It's one of the quirks of biological necessity that nature smooths the course of human reproduction by opening our minds to the pleasures of parenthood while keeping us ignorant of the full scale of its horrors. We think changing nappies is the bad part, when they're the easy bit. We joke with pregnant fathers about the prospect of sleepless nights, though at the time of joking we still think of a sleepless night as something that can be slept off during the day, the result of some self-inflicted pleasure - a marathon drugs binge perhaps or a conspicuously protracted sex tournament with someone you're still trying to impress. Even when we've made up our minds to have kids and done the antenatal classes, skimmed through the manuals and thought up trendy names, we're still pretty clueless. Until it's too late. None of us expects having children to improve the quality of life exactly, but where does it say you have to give up weekends? Having a civilised weekend is what separates us from the dolphins. It is Saturday, therefore you get up at noon, go to the pub, buy a pint of milk, go back to bed, eat some Pot Noodles, watch Match of the Day, go back to bed again. The details may differ from person to person (some people, I understand, enjoy potholing and visiting museums and, if you are a couple, sexual intercourse and shopping for kitchen utensils might well come into it), but the point is you can do what you like. It's supposed to be the opposite of work. But that was then. All the surveys are telling us how frantic we are about devoting more quality time to our children - far more than our parents ever gave us, the bastards - and the weekend is when we do it. Our children can't get rid of us. We scoop them up and take them off to leisure pools or Roman ruins or museums specialising in agricultural machinery. We read to them, pretend to take an interest in their incomprehensible computer games, intrude on their private woes with our anxiety for their mental health. One day they'll hate us for it. And it's all down to guilt for not being around enough the rest of the week. Working women are by far the worst culprits. According to one survey, mothers in full-time employment do 56 hours of chores and childcare every week. I'm sorry, but that is sick. Even fathers do 31 hours (it says here). Of course, women are bound to do the lion's share of the housework - it's in the blood, as I think Darwin explained. But this is something else. And it all adds up to less time to relax, put your feet up and watch Football Focus. Even after four children, I still can't quite get used to the lost weekend. Once I'm out of bed at the shockingly late hour of 8.30, I hang around in my dressing-gown eating toast, awaiting instructions from my wife, whose job it is to run the duty roster and stop me sitting down to read yesterday's paper. One of us has to take the six-year-old for his swimming lesson, leaving the other (me) to take an active interest in the rest of them, who are watching Pokémon and who I'm pretty sure wouldn't notice if I set myself on fire, let alone slipped back to bed for a while. But I can't. Statistically, one of the children will need to be taken for either a haircut or a pair of shoes. There will be endless meals and auxiliary snacks to prepare, cook and clear away. We might lose one child to a party at Quasar (if you have to ask, don't), but one of us will have to ferry him to the next town and pick him up again. A small DIY job will have risen to the top of our priorities, involving the use of a drill, which will breed subsidiary DIY jobs of polyfilling unwanted craters around the site of the first. Our staggered sessions of baths, TV suppers and bedtime stories will stretch from six till 9.45 and that's it. Half the weekend gone. Do you see any room in there for going trout-fishing, writing haikus or climbing Mount Snowdon? After Hoovering up the debris and mopping their footprints off the walls, we will sit down and open a bottle of red wine to celebrate still being awake. Admittedly, the proceedings will still be enlivened by Match of the Day, but the five-minute spell in which all the goals are scored will be marked by our three-year-old shouting the house down for a drink or a wee or, sometimes, just for the hell of it. I do feel sorry for new parents. Polly (not her real name), who my wife knows from the days when she had a social life that didn't involve taking the Tesco loyalty card out with her, has one of those cash-rich, time-poor jobs that entails flying to Tokyo and back just in time to watch the nanny putting 18-month-old Archie to bed, which then means devoting weekends to doing guilt-time with the little chap. It's driving her nutty. 'I'm trying to make up what I can't give him properly in the week, but I'm so exhausted. We never have a lie-in,' she tells me. 'I miss going to lunch and the cinema and just relaxing. You think children are just going to fit into your life and they don't. You have to fit into theirs. You think you can just take them into restaurants with you, but you end up at Pizza Hut or somewhere else with highchairs. I can never go shopping for clothes or go into a department store. I know it sounds selfish but I just want five minutes to unwind and relax. To be honest, I'd really quite like to get my nails done.' Her husband who is a part-time lecturer and in his late fifties (quite a bit older than her), is very good - though at medieval history rather than childcare. 'He makes a big fuss of Archie,' she says, 'but he doesn't much like being left alone with him. He doesn't know what to do.' Well I'm glad it's not just me. I'm in the pub with Sam after a hard day at the office. 'How do you relax at weekends?' I ask. Sam has three boys and is still under 30, so obviously I'm looking for tales of woe. 'Play tennis in the mornings,' he says. 'Take the kids to the supermarket in the afternoon, chill out...' Chilling out involves watching something called Soccer Saturday on Sky! I can't believe it. 'We look after the kids in shifts,' he explains. His wife Odile, who is French and laid back, bakes cakes, but sometimes just slobs around watching ancient Sunday afternoon movies while he takes the kids swimming. They buy a huge Indian (food, not person) for Saturday night. They are very happy. 'And you don't have to do anything else - housework, DIY?' What - at the weekend ? He never does DIY or housework. He tells me about a man who lives on a boat nearby and does the occasional odd job for them. A woman comes in to clean every couple of weeks. He starts telling me about long lie-ins, leisurely breakfasts. I have to stop him before he starts telling me about his fantastic sex life. Still, as a strategy for relaxation, shiftwork has much to recommend it and is obviously less traumatic than divorce as a means of sharing the children out at weekends. I do have a few escape routes myself, the most successful one being retiring to my so-called study to do something urgent that I had forgotten about. Less risky strategies include asking friends round, which involves cooking and cleaning, but you do get to talk to other adults and drink during daylight. Better still is to go to someone else's house and let them do the work. But the healthy alternative is... well, getting used to it. Natalie, one of the mums at our children's school has five kids under 12 and holds down a job as a doctor too. Is she completely mad? I don't have to get them to school; there are no after-school activities, no music practice.' Just lots more time for cuddling, she says. Of course, there's the usual frenetic round of football training, library, swimming lessons, flat tyres to repair and washing machines to load up. fields.headline: A man of two halves
fields.standfirst: Who better than David Ginola to replace Princess Diana as the Red Cross's ambassador on landmine control? On the eve of his trip to Cambodia, the Gallic glory boy talks to Denis Campbell about fame, football and fatherhood
fields.trailText: Denis Campbell talks to David Ginola, who believes he has wasted the best years of his career by playing in the Premiership.
fields.body:
The dark sunglasses, nondescript grey clothes and floppy hat pulled down over his eyes are a poor disguise. Almost everyone in the north London Italian restaurant where we meet for lunch recognises David Ginola. Heads turn as soon as he opens the door; there's an outbreak of stares, nudges and whispers. He shrugs off the attention gracefully. He's used to it.

Since moving here five years ago, Ginola has worked almost as hard at building a profile for himself outside football as he has on the pitch. There was the catwalk outing for Cerruti and those ads for L'Oréal shampoo ('Because I'm worth it') and Renault Laguna cars ('It's all worked out beautifully for Ginola'); the World Cup commentating stint for the BBC; the chat- show appearances and magazine covers; the 11-page spread in Hello!. He has also addressed the Oxford Union, passionate and ironic in equal measure, on the mortal danger facing English soccer from the huge number of imported footballers.

Today, though, the Tottenham Hotspur midfielder is in less flamboyant mode. As Princess Diana's successor as the public face of the Red Cross's worldwide campaign to ban anti-personnel landmines, Ginola is preparing for a very public and potentially risky trip to Cambodia.

In two weeks, the day after facing Sunderland on the last day of the Premiership season, instead of indulging in the usual footballer's summer holiday - sun, all-day drinking, nightclubs and run-ins with tabloid snoops in Gran Canaria - he will fly to one of the most heavily-mined countries in Asia. As Cambodia's fragile peace allows citizens to return home after decades of war to areas previously inaccessible because of the fighting, more minefields are being stumbled upon. Old mines create new victims every day.

The killing fields await Ginola, as does an exacting tour of duty, taking in sites such as a component factory in Phnom Penh which makes artificial limbs for amputees and a limb-fitting centre in Battambang, where these prostheses help victims regain mobility and self-respect. He'll also play in a football match with some landmine survivors and witness a de-mining operation in one of the many rural areas infested with mines. A retinue of journalists and cameramen will record his every move.

It's an unusual way to spend a summer break, even for a footballer who conforms to none of the usual stereotypes. Why is he doing it? 'Landmines is a big cause, and the Red Cross a big charity,' he answers. 'The Princess of Wales did so many remarkable things on landmines that when she died it would have been a shame for the Red Cross to leave the campaign like that and forget about it. It would not have been right to just remember the Princess of Wales but forget that she was working on the landmines issue.'

Ginola has already visited Angola and was deeply affected by what he saw. He played a game with some young amputees. 'It was remarkable. They were playing great football, and they train every day using both the prostheses and the other leg to kick the ball. One of our team scored two goals, one with the normal leg and one with the prosthesis. Sometimes, they forget they have lost a leg. They put on a brand new pair of trainers provided by the Red Cross and they are quite happy. We try and make them think, "OK, this isn't the best thing, but although I've blown on a mine, life isn't finished yet".'

One girl failed to be inspired by this can-do approach, however. 'She was seven or eight. I could see in her eyes that she was thinking, "You, white guy, what are you doing here and can you explain why this has happened to me?" The girl had trodden on a landmine when she and her mother were walking down a path they used every day to collect water from a pond. Her mother wasn't injured, but she saw what happened.' Lost for words, he simply held her hand.

Ginola argues that in our celebrity-obsessed culture, names and faces have a duty to use their fame to help others. 'If you are organising an event and you need to attract interest, or cheques, you need names. Without famous people, you have nothing.' It's a responsibility he claims both to love and hate. 'Sometimes, I'd like to go somewhere and be completely anonymous, like eating somewhere and not having people looking at you. Like today, you realise people recognise you. You can't do anything silly. Everything I do, I have to be careful of my image as a father, football player, husband and person with the badge of the Red Cross. It's like to be a priest. I have almost to be a saint everywhere I go.'

On the pitch, Ginola is a wonderfully gifted, crowd-pleasing extrovert. Two days before we met, he had shown off the full range of his repertoire in Tottenham's 4-2 home defeat by Aston Villa. His first touch, a cheeky backheel, drew appreciative cheers. He regularly beat two or three opponents, forced the opposition to substitute his marker at half-time and was at the heart of Tottenham's best moves. Any time he got the ball, the level of noise - and of anticipation - rose.

But the instinctive entertainer is also a team player, always looking to create opportunities for usually much less talented colleagues. He was voted player of the year last year by football writers and fellow professionals alike. However, he is now 33 and has at most five years left. So how fulfilled is he as a footballer? A pause. 'Frustrated,' comes the reply. It is a refreshingly candid answer.

It quickly becomes clear that Ginola is consumed with regret and a sense of missed opportunities which cuts deep. 'I've played for 15 years as a professional. When I think about my quality, my skills, what I'm capable of doing on the pitch, I deserve to be playing in a really top team. I will not say Newcastle United [his former club] and Tottenham are not big clubs,' he says, correcting himself quickly, not wanting to appear ungrateful, 'but by big clubs I mean Milan, Barcelona and Manchester United.' That, he says, is his natural level.

While on Tyneside, Ginola had two chances to transfer to Barcelona. The first time, Newcastle would not release him; the second, Barcelona manager Johan Cruyff, his boyhood hero, could not get rid of two established stars whose departure would have enabled the Frenchman to come. 'This kind of thing really frustrates me, because I think I would be even bigger today if I had played there for the last four or five years. I would have played in the Champions League every year.'

Instead, he has suffered disappointment as a Kevin Keegan-managed Newcastle team blew a 12-point lead to hand Manchester United the title and has spent the last two seasons as the star turn in a very ordinary Tottenham team. The success he experienced for three years with Paris Saint Germain has not dulled his view that, as his friends put it, he has been 'wasting my talent' in England since 1995.

Even worse was the experience of being voted France's player of the year in 1994 and then almost immediately being discarded by French national team boss Gerard Houllier, now manager at Liverpool. Houllier blamed Ginola for ensuring that France didn't qualify for the 1994 World Cup. A misplaced pass from the winger's boot in the final qualifying game ended up with a Bulgarian opponent and, seconds later, led to a goal which put France out. Houllier branded him 'a criminal' and he was dumped from the national side. The memory still hurts.

'It's a team effort. When you win, it's a team effort; when you lose, it's a team effort. People said I had killed their dream. But this isn't fair. Everybody was hiding behind me.'

When France hosted the same tournament four years later, Les Bleus also won it by beating the mighty Brazil in the final. Ginola was in Paris as part of the BBC's commentary team. How did he feel about his compatriots' victory? 'Very bad. It was fantastic for the French people, but on the other hand, from a personal point of view, it was terrible.' Because you should have been out on the pitch with them? He nods. An occasion of national rejoicing became a moment of intense private grief, another case of what should have been.

Ginola is already contemplating life after football. Several film scripts have arrived and he's thinking about maybe trying to break into acting, as Eric Cantona, his fellow countryman, has been trying to do. 'When you did a job like football all your life, and it was carrying so much emotion [note the past tense], to find something else that's giving you the same kind of emotions is very difficult. I will not be able to work easily in an office because I have spent most of my life outside, on the pitch.'

Whatever happens, he thinks he will stay in England, though he will move from his house in Totteridge, on the suburban fringe of north London, to the countryside. He's had enough of being bothered by fans who know where he lives and has a longing for rural life.

Does coaching or management appeal? He doesn't rule it out but reckons the relentless pressure of being a football boss would be too much. In his next life, he wants to be able to spend more, not less, time with his wife Coraline, his son Andrea and daughter Carla. 'That is most important. I don't want to see my boy any longer crying at the airport leaving for France saying, "I want to stay with you, Daddy" while I'm staying here to play matches.'

Talk of his son brings him back to football and to what might have been. 'I look at my boy on a Saturday morning when he's going training, I think about when I was his age, dreaming about being a professional and dreaming about winning trophies. I still dream in the night about winning trophies. Well, life goes by very, very quickly.'

 For more information, contact the British Red Cross, 9 Grosvenor Crescent, London SW1X 7EJ (tel: 020-7201 5060)

fields.headline: Indiscreet charm of Louise Bourgeois
fields.standfirst: The 89-year-old sculptor's New York home is as uncompromising as the artist herself.
fields.trailText: On 12 May, the new Tate Modern will open with a temporary exhibition devoted to the French-born, New York-based sculptor Louise Bourgeois. On show will also be a special commission the 89-year-old has created for the museum's 155m-long Turbine Hall. Entitled  I Do, I Undo and I Redo , the installation consists of three steel towers, which incorporate spiral staircases, large circular mirrors, platforms and bell jars containing sculpted figures of a mother and child.
fields.body:
On 12 May, the new Tate Modern will open with a temporary exhibition devoted to the French-born, New York-based sculptor Louise Bourgeois. On show will also be a special commission the 89-year-old has created for the museum's 155m-long Turbine Hall. Entitled I Do, I Undo and I Redo , the installation consists of three steel towers, which incorporate spiral staircases, large circular mirrors, platforms and bell jars containing sculpted figures of a mother and child.

At the artist's four-storey house in New York's Chelsea a few weeks ago, an intense, talented, Slav-sounding performance artist called Denise gave her interpretation of a text written by Bourgeois, also called I Do, I Undo, I Redo . Far more surreal than the Tate installation, it involved Denise waving a piece of material furiously in the air, writhing around on the floor screaming 'Fernand Léger, Léger, Léger', and smashing one of Bourgeois's sculptures to smithereens on the coffee table. When it was over, Bourgeois grinned from behind her desk. 'I hope you're going to break lots more of my sculptures in the future!'

Bourgeois herself has been known to destroy her works of art in front of television cameras in the past. Her other antics are legendary. She regularly throws fits and walks away from interviewers. When photographer Nan Goldin took her portrait, Bourgeois took her scissors to the negatives and cut up all but the one she wanted Goldin to use. Another camera meister , Duane Michals, photographed her three times in the Sixties. He still remembers her as one of the most difficult subjects he has ever had to deal with. Indeed, while those who know her well insist that she is adorable, for others she is quite simply unbearable. 'I break everything I touch because I am violent,' she once said. 'I destroy the relationships I have with my friends, lovers, children.'

She moved to the house in Chelsea in 1962 with her family. Her late husband, the American art historian Robert Goldwater, hired an architect to redo the interiors. Today, it looks like the place hasn't been touched since. The paint is peeling off the walls, the parquet floors are in need of a good sanding, and the furniture is decidedly old and tatty. In the living room is a worn, round coffee table and a rather hip-looking red highchair. In one corner is Bourgeois's desk - a former dining table, which she cut in half after her husband died. Today, she still eats on it after cleaning it thoroughly with bleach. Next to it, a set square hangs on the wall and a metronome sits on a bench. One wall is covered with photocopies of awards, exhibition invitations and a couple of abstract watercolours. The other is completely taken up by bookshelves, laden with everything from a bread bin and videotapes, to files and a book about the Paine Webber art collection.

When I arrive, Bourgeois is hiding away in her tiny kitchen. With two ancient (and apparently dangerous) gas rings and a row of old tin cups hanging on hooks from the cupboards, it looks very much like something from a bygone era. It takes a good while for her to come out and greet her guests. They are a motley crew. As well as Denise, there is a rather sinister-looking Italian dressed in a three-piece navy-blue velvet suit.

There's also a guy called Jason from an artists' community called Yaddo in Saratoga Springs (touch the box of work he has brought along to show Bourgeois and he himself springs on you sharply). There's also a sculptress friend of Bourgeois's called Cheyne and a woman called Phyllis, who keeps managing to stand in front of the camera (the weekly Sunday gatherings are always filmed).

The one person, however, who seems to concern Bourgeois is a German artist called Konrad Klapheck, who is coming to do her portrait. When he calls to say that he's lost, Bourgeois says very audibly to her assistant that, 'He's the only person I really want to see this afternoon'. Very nice for the rest of us. However, instead of offering everyone a piece, she proceeds to scoff the whole of it herself.

After his first, very swift preparatory drawing, she throws a fit, starts prodding at it with a knife, insists that he modifies it considerably and refuses to let him do another. Quite understandably, he ends up walking out, complaining that he can't work in such conditions. But Bourgeois has somehow managed to coax him into coming back the following week. But not before he has asked her, 'How would you feel if someone started telling you what to do with your work?'

The answer is that Bourgeois would be furious. Indeed, throughout her career, she has always kept an independent path and avoided being influenced by any of the century's major artistic trends. Her earliest sculptures were spindly, totem-like, wooden forms she built on the roof of her apartment in the 40s. In the 60s, she started working with poured forms, such as plaster and latex. Wide recognition, however, did not come until the 70s, and since then she has provoked us with her sexually ambiguous figures, 'cells' (evocative installations incorporating doors, windows and objects like decapitated limbs, mirrors and toys) and more recently, her gigantic spiders.

Each of her spiders, she says, represents her mother ('my best friend. She was a weaver like the spider'), and her family and childhood are constant themes in her work. 'My childhood never lost its magic, never lost its mystery, and never lost its drama,' she says. She was born in Paris on Christmas Day, 1911. In Bourgeois's eyes, her mother was a saint. Her father most certainly was not. He ran a tapestry repair company, had a collection of garden sculptures (his wife would not let him have any in the house) and introduced his mistress, Sadie, into the household as the family governess. In 1974, Bourgeois produced a piece entitled The Destruction of the Father . 'Since I was demolished by my father, why shouldn't I demolish him?' she asks.

The basement of her house serves as a studio. Medieval-like iron gates stand at the top of the wooden stairs leading down to it. The objects found there are certainly eclectic. There is a large, Gothic-style fireplace, a drill machine and an archaic printing press. On the wall is written enigmatically: 'The whining pit - Camus'. A black mannequin lies on a cardboard box, old drawings are propped up on the water pipes (one, entitled A Cottage Seamstress , recalls her mother's profession) and Bourgeois's own works are scattered about. There are two columns made from ribbon bobbins in one corner, sculptures of family groups on a bench and unorganised piles of drawings.

An insomniac, Bourgeois now spends most of her nights drawing. On her bedside table is a loopy composition. A telephone number is scrawled on the bedroom wall, industrial lamps are attached to bookshelves and a drawing of Adam and Eve sits on the marble fireplace. There are books everywhere in the house (she used to run a bookstore in the 50s). In the room in which she now sleeps are numerous French classics - Victor Hugo's Notre-Dame de Paris , Jules Verne's Voyages Extraordinaires and La Fontaine's Fables .

On the same floor is the bedroom she used to share with her husband. A photo of Goldwater, with their son Jean-Louis, stands on the fireplace, a framed Bourgeois painting of a totem-like figure hangs between the windows, and a pile of old fabrics rest on a chair. The bedspread is a red and white crocheted affair. The walls are unpainted and completely cracked. In actual fact, the room remains exactly as it was when Goldwater was alive and has not been touched since. Stuck in her past, it seems there are some things Bourgeois simply does not want to undo and redo.

On show will also be a special commission the 89-year-old has created for the museum's 155m-long Turbine Hall. Entitled I Do, I Undo and I Redo , the installation consists of three steel towers, which incorporate spiral staircases, large circular mirrors, platforms and bell jars containing sculpted figures of a mother and child. At the artist's four-storey house in New York's Chelsea a few weeks ago, an intense, talented, Slav-sounding performance artist called Denise gave her interpretation of a text written by Bourgeois, also called I Do, I Undo, I Redo . Far more surreal than the Tate installation, it involved Denise waving a piece of material furiously in the air, writhing around on the floor screaming 'Fernand Léger, Léger, Léger', and smashing one of Bourgeois's sculptures to smithereens on the coffee table. When it was over, Bourgeois grinned from behind her desk. 'I hope you're going to break lots more of my sculptures in the future!' Bourgeois herself has been known to destroy her works of art in front of television cameras in the past. Her other antics are legendary. She regularly throws fits and walks away from interviewers. When photographer Nan Goldin took her portrait, Bourgeois took her scissors to the negatives and cut up all but the one she wanted Goldin to use. fields.headline: Take me to the River
fields.standfirst: It worked wonders for Jamie Oliver and set Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall on his way, but can our man Tim Adams cut it in the kitchen of The River Cafe?
fields.trailText: It worked wonders for Jamie Oliver and set Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall on his way, but can our man Tim Adams cut it in the kitchen of The River Cafe?
fields.body:
Ruth Rogers is standing at her usual station at one end of the stainless-steel bar that runs the length of The River Cafe. Under a small pool of halogen light she is casting her ice-blue eyes over each plate before a waitress dispatches it to a table. She breaks up asparagus, looks for a missing herb - occasionally she sends a plate back, but more often she simply wipes its rim, pausing every so often to push her straight blonde hair back off her face. In the corner, there is a party of her friends, which includes Salman Rushdie (and his bodyguards at a separate table), and she is paying particular attention to the progress of their order ('Where's that pigeon?' she calls to her chef from time to time).

Towards nine o'clock, when the restaurant is candlelit and full, one of her waitresses, a trainee architect, approaches to mention that 'table 16 say they are friends of yours'. Rogers scans the room, looks blank. 'I've never seen them before in my life,' she tells me, from the corner of her mouth. And then, catching the eye of the woman in question, offers a wave and a beam of a smile. The River Cafe used to employ a system whereby 'friends of Ruthie' would be denoted in the reservation book: F.O.R. Eventually this was amended to incorporate F.O.F.O.Rs (friends of friends of Ruthie), but when that seemed to account for just about everybody, the system was abandoned. 'Very occasionally,' she says conspiratorially, 'I've gone up to people and confronted them and said, "Do I know you?"' Usually, she admits, it turns out that she does.

Ever since Ruth Rogers joined forces with her partner Rose Gray 13 years ago to open The River Cafe as a canteen for her husband Richard Rogers's architecture practice next door, it has been much more than a restaurant. Their plan, they say, was to create 'a kind of utopia on the banks of the Thames'. Just as Lord Rogers, New Labour's favourite architect, has a vision to recreate urban communities based on Italianate ideas of shared public spaces, so his wife and her partner, New Labour's favourite cooks, wanted to make something that was more a way of life than a place to eat.

'Food was just one part of the concept,' says Rose Gray, who could pass for Ruth's slightly older, more intellectual sister. 'Both Ruth and I had large families, a lot of mouths to feed, and we had both spent a lot of time in Italy. We were struck by the way Italians approached family life: they cook very good, simple food which everyone, including the young children, eats. And they have a communal way of making a meal - having someone shell peas, having someone else peel artichokes makes the whole thing more fun. We used to do it with our children and now we do it with our staff. We wanted the restaurant to be like a big family.'

The family gets bigger all the time. Not only does it embrace the writers and film stars (Hugh and Liz, Ralph and Francesca, Uma and Madonna) who dine here, it also extends to the newly formed polenta-eating classes. The River Cafe's first cookbook, River Cafe Cookbook , with its totemic typography, has sold half a million copies; Rogers and Gray have made a couple of TV series - 'two thin ladies' as one critic dubbed them - and now they are on to their third volume of recipes: River Cafe Green , which is organised around seasonal, and mainly organic vegetables (many of which your greengrocer won't be able to pronounce let alone produce, 'but keep at him,' says Rose).

The food remains wonderful, if expensive. If Lord Rogers's Urban Task Force marched on its stomach, you guess, inner cities might be transformed overnight. And the restaurant's political influence may not only be symbolic. The River Cafe has long been a kind of unofficial canteen for New Labour. The Blairs and Peter Mandelson and Gordon Brown have been regular mozzarella munchers over the years. On the night of Labour's election victory, Ruth sent a food parcel round to the new prime minister; when Vanity Fair ran a 'London Swings Again' issue, the launch party was held at the restaurant (where else?). This chanterelle socialism has, of course, provoked some disquiet in obvious quarters. At the Tory party conference the year after their election defeat, Peter Lilley took the platform and whined about the fact that the nation was 'now all about Britpop and The River Cafe'.

If the nation was all like The River Cafe then, you can't help thinking, we wouldn't have a great deal to worry about. It is a well-lighted space full of the aromas of ground coffee and fresh mint. Unlike most Michelin-starred restaurants, this one is run on 'democratic' principles, and there are, by their own account, no dictatorial pan-throwing tantrums from its proprietors. The restaurant drew its inspiration from New World rather than French models (there is always a sprinkling of Antipodeans on sabbatical in the kitchen). 'We never saw the point of shouting at people,' Ruth says. 'I think we both started this thing at a certain point in our lives. If people start a restaurant or any business in their twenties, there's much more ego; but I think we had already been there in a way. We're more, I don't know, grown up.' The waiters help with the food preparation, the staff eat the same food as the customers, and (prices apart, of course) the place seems open and egalitarian in spirit. Still, on the basis that most utopias fade on closer inspection, I asked Rose and Ruth if I might work for a day in their kitchen.

When I arrive, togged up in my chef's whites, Rose is working up a lunch menu. 'Do we write "live" langoustines,' she asks? 'I can't remember.'

'Well, they're not live once they've been on the grill,' someone says helpfully.

Like any good New Labour chef, Gray takes care with presentation. 'Certain words,' she says, 'are guaranteed to shift things. "Wood-roasted" is always good. If we say "Romana" we're sure to sell a few more.'

She and Ruth take it in turns to run the kitchen and today Rose is on lunch and Ruth on dinner. They have recently returned from completing their book and talk with a sense of relief to be back cooking after three months locked in a room with each other 'from half eight in the morning until whisky time at about seven in the evening'.

Their partnership, they both say, is like a marriage. 'It's a very intense relationship. I suppose there is a kind of unspoken language between us,' Rose explains. That language is partly one of evangelical connoisseurship. Talk to either of them for any length of time and you are assailed with stories of this wonderful artichoke or that incredible risotto. Mention a turbot dish and Rose will tell you about the relationship they have with a number of south-coast fishing boats and how they go to different boats on different days depending on what they hear is good. (All their fish are line caught; fish get bruised in nets.) Ask what's in a pork recipe and she'll talk about a farmer in Suffolk who puts his Middlewhite sow with different pigs in a constant effort to improve the flavour of The River Cafe pork loin.

Rose has, she explains, just returned from a few days at a wine-tasting event in Verona, at one stage trying 86 wines in a day - 'You know, blue teeth and purple mouth.' She shows me a notebook in which she notes her reactions to everything placed in front of her in a careful Elizabeth David-like hand that only gets slightly more gregarious as the day progresses. She and Ruth are jackdaws of Italian cuisine. They visit Italy every six weeks or so, persuading olive oil suppliers to show them what they do with peas, foraging in nettle beds for long-lost salad ingredients.

As if to prove the point, Rose then sets me off preparing some puntarelle, a relation of the dandelion, with which she is going to make a salad 'in the traditional Roman style'. She is messianic about good natural ingredients. She talks of the restaurant's new vegetable garden. 'We're the only place that's got one,' she says. In her spare time, she designs gardens in her head; it all goes back, she says, to her growing up in Surrey during the war, 'with this fabulous vegetable garden. There was all sorts of rationing, but I saw how you could make good things from simple seasonal ingredients.'

In the kitchen, meanwhile, the talk is of top-secret plans for Jamie Oliver's forthcoming stag night - Oliver was a former puntarelle peeler, as was Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall of TV dinners fame (if you want to be a star these days, shell peas) - and, at my prompting, of the differences between Rose and Ruth's ways of running the kitchen. 'Rose is more cerebral,' someone says, 'she can visualise tastes in her head. She'll come back with a sack of beans or a bag of a particular flour and have a very clear idea of what she wants you to do with it. She also does things last minute. Ruth tends to strip things to their essentials more, aims to keep things simpler, but wants to plan.' Or, says someone else: 'Rose is a bit more suspicious; Ruth's better at PR'. Or: 'Rose is far more confident than Ruth; Ruth is sometimes less sure of her decisions.'

The kitchen is agreed on two things. First that 'It's mental when they are working together; they did a night a while back where one was on the grill and one was up front: madness.' And, second, all suitably on message, that they could not have landed in a more enlightened kitchen. There is talk of food parcels being delivered to them when they are ill; annual trips to Italy to taste olive oil. 'Where else would you get that?'

Of her own style of running the kitchen, Rose says that she's 'capable of barking at people if its not running properly. Sometimes you have a chef who goes silent on you and you have to try to keep them all communicating, pull them out of themselves.'

There is not a great deal of need for barking this lunchtime, however. Business is slow - only 45 covers (they can do 130 in the summer, when the garden is open) - a fact which Rose blames on the blip in the American stock market. 'Everyone has stayed by their screens,' she says. But, despite the global economic downturn, my expertly prepared puntarelle sells like hot sambucca.

When Ruth arrives in the afternoon, double kissing me, a cardigan around her shoulders, the atmosphere changes a little. She sits down with her young assistant chef, Arthur, and constructs an evening menu partly based on what has gone well at lunchtime. There is much talk of dark plates, and of light plates. Borlotti beans travel up and down the menu, alternatively inserted and erased by Rogers, sucking her pencil.

Arthur's role is mainly to enthuse, but occasionally he disagrees with a dish, offering suggestions of his own. ('The great thing here is that everyone has a say,' he tells me. 'If you said that kind of thing to Gordon Ramsay he'd just tell you to fuck off.')

Ruth Rogers gives off a kind of palpable and charming nervous energy. She sets me off chopping asparagus, and tells me how she's just been on the phone to my editor, to talk about a skiing trip she's taking the next day with Richard and his five sons (Ab, Ben and Zad from his first marriage; Roo and Bo with Ruth.) She shows me how to make a perfect pear tart, all the while chivvying her staff. She reveals to me the precise moment for dispatching the caramel part of her signature caramel ice cream. ('If someone hasn't shouted "something's burning", then its not done'.) She laughs off my suggestions that she is running the country from her flame grill, but then admits that the previous night she had dinner with Alan Yentob, creative director of BBC1 and Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian . She introduces me to her kitchen staff and puts her hand over their mouths when they jokingly threaten to reveal indiscretions ('And me a patron of Index on Censorship').

Her friends tend to fall over themselves with superlatives to describe Ruth. Certainly, she seems to have led the most charmed of lives. She grew up in 'Woodstock of all places' in the 60s, the child of wealthy anti-Vietnam radicals. She met and fell for Richard in 1969, when she was in England and 19. At the time, Rogers, 15 years her senior, was married (to the architect Su Brumwell) and was earning £2,000 a year teaching at the Architectural Association. Not long after Ruth moved in, however, he had his amazing break: winning the competition to design the Pompidou Centre in Paris. Ruth resigned from her job in the design department at Penguin Books and went to join him in Paris. They lived in the Place des Vosges, had their first child in 1975, and never looked back.

'Ruthie wore very bright colours when we first met,' her husband recalls. 'Students used to ask me what came first: my wife's clothes or the colours of my buildings. The truth is that she did have a big influence on that.' If she brought colour to Rogers's life she also set about bringing it to the friends she met with her husband. She hosted parties including famous Thanksgiving dinners for fellow ex-pats like Doris Saatchi and Ed Victor. She organised political campaigns, notably 'the friends of Salman Rushdie' with her great ally the socialite publisher Caroline Michel, enlisting the support of the Yentobs and the Bertoluccis, Jacob Rothschild and Melvyn Bragg, among others.

And she started the restaurant. Her inspiration came form her husband's mother, Dada, who died last year. Rose had known Richard long before he met Ruth and was already a disciple of his mother's cooking. Ruth was bought up to think that Italian cooking was meatballs and she was overwhelmed by what Richard's family ate.

'Dada came from a very very wealthy family in Trieste,' she says. 'She grew up in that period when James Joyce was there, and Italo Svevo, and she married Richard's father who was a Florentine. With the onset of war, they came to London. And there she was, this Italian girl lifted out of Florence and plonked down in a bedsit behind Paddington station. She spent her whole time trying to find things here that she could cook.'

In the early days of The River Cafe, Dada would come in and taste what Ruth and Rose were making. She always used to say: 'Too many herbs; too much butter keep it simple, simple.' And just before she died, she called Ruth to her bedside. 'Pretty much her last words to me were: go easy on the herbs, not so many herbs,' smiles Ruth.

You can see a bit of Dada in Ruth as she cooks, trying to keep things simple. However often she does it, she says, she still gets a little adrenaline as eight o'clock comes around. 'It's like I imagine the theatre to be,' she says. But by the time the sun is setting over the Harrod's Depository opposite, she seems in her element. 'People think it must be so stressful because they get stressed out by cooking dinner for 10 people. But the most exhausting thing for us is seeing accountants or looking after the staff properly. Cooking is the fun part, the relaxing part.'

Her lowest point, she says, was discovering that she had cooked a risotto for General Pinochet some years ago. She had, she remembers, thought the Spanish speaking party was 'just another royal family with their bodyguards'. When she found out 'my blood went cold and I was in tears... I'd poured my heart into this dictator's risotto.'

Other than dictators, the only guests she dreads are Italian chefs. A while ago, the writer Adam Gopnik opined in The New Yorker that 'the best Italian food to be had in Europe was on the banks of the Thames'. All the Italian restaurateurs in London came and sat at the bar here and told us that what we were cooking was not Italian: 'You know, where is the Bolognese?'

The closest she comes to a crisis this evening though, is a shortage of chard. Some nights, she says, 'it's just like a big dinner party - but then that's the idea really.'

Working with Rogers and Gray you could convince yourself that you get a tiny glimpse of a more perfect world. It's only a restaurant, of course, but it's one in which all families are happy and all vegetables are fresh and all conversation is interesting. They get many people asking them why they don't open another restaurant, and they say there are two reasons: 'The first is that it would be impossible to find anywhere as beautiful as this; and the other is that you suddenly dilute your identity. It's nice having a piece of work that is wholly your own.'

Like all successful recipes, this one depends on its main ingredients. In a rare moment, when they sit down together, I ask them to choose a single adjective to describe each other. 'Beautiful,' says Rose of Ruth. 'That was going to be mine,' says Ruth. She thinks for a while. 'Excellent,' she says.

Like married couples, they say they have grown alike: 'Well, we both wear the same clothes,' says Rose, 'so to that extent, yes.'

'Sometimes, says Ruth, 'I hear myself talking and I think, "Oh God, I sound like Rose."'

'You mean you sound excellent,' says Rose. 'Yes, of course,' says her friend, 'I sound excellent.' And they both giggle like schoolgirls.

The River Cafe's first cookbook, River Cafe Cookbook , with its totemic typography, has sold half a million copies; Rogers and Gray have made a couple of TV series - 'two thin ladies' as one critic dubbed them - and now they are on to their third volume of recipes: River Cafe Green , which is organised around seasonal, and mainly organic vegetables (many of which your greengrocer won't be able to pronounce let alone produce, 'but keep at him,' says Rose). The food remains wonderful, if expensive. If Lord Rogers's Urban Task Force marched on its stomach, you guess, inner cities might be transformed overnight. And the restaurant's political influence may not only be symbolic. The River Cafe has long been a kind of unofficial canteen for New Labour. The Blairs and Peter Mandelson and Gordon Brown have been regular mozzarella munchers over the years. On the night of Labour's election victory, Ruth sent a food parcel round to the new prime minister; when Vanity Fair ran a 'London Swings Again' issue, the launch party was held at the restaurant (where else?). This chanterelle socialism has, of course, provoked some disquiet in obvious quarters. At the Tory party conference the year after their election defeat, Peter Lilley took the platform and whined about the fact that the nation was 'now all about Britpop and The River Cafe'. If the nation was all like The River Cafe then, you can't help thinking, we wouldn't have a great deal to worry about. It is a well-lighted space full of the aromas of ground coffee and fresh mint. Unlike most Michelin-starred restaurants, this one is run on 'democratic' principles, and there are, by their own account, no dictatorial pan-throwing tantrums from its proprietors. The restaurant drew its inspiration from New World rather than French models (there is always a sprinkling of Antipodeans on sabbatical in the kitchen). 'We never saw the point of shouting at people,' Ruth says. 'I think we both started this thing at a certain point in our lives. If people start a restaurant or any business in their twenties, there's much more ego; but I think we had already been there in a way. We're more, I don't know, grown up.' The waiters help with the food preparation, the staff eat the same food as the customers, and (prices apart, of course) the place seems open and egalitarian in spirit. Still, on the basis that most utopias fade on closer inspection, I asked Rose and Ruth if I might work for a day in their kitchen. When I arrive, togged up in my chef's whites, Rose is working up a lunch menu. 'Do we write "live" langoustines,' she asks? 'I can't remember.' 'Well, they're not live once they've been on the grill,' someone says helpfully. Like any good New Labour chef, Gray takes care with presentation. 'Certain words,' she says, 'are guaranteed to shift things. "Wood-roasted" is always good. If we say "Romana" we're sure to sell a few more.' She and Ruth take it in turns to run the kitchen and today Rose is on lunch and Ruth on dinner. They have recently returned from completing their book and talk with a sense of relief to be back cooking after three months locked in a room with each other 'from half eight in the morning until whisky time at about seven in the evening'. Their partnership, they both say, is like a marriage. 'It's a very intense relationship. I suppose there is a kind of unspoken language between us,' Rose explains. That language is partly one of evangelical connoisseurship. Talk to either of them for any length of time and you are assailed with stories of this wonderful artichoke or that incredible risotto. Mention a turbot dish and Rose will tell you about the relationship they have with a number of south-coast fishing boats and how they go to different boats on different days depending on what they hear is good. (All their fish are line caught; fish get bruised in nets.) Ask what's in a pork recipe and she'll talk about a farmer in Suffolk who puts his Middlewhite sow with different pigs in a constant effort to improve the flavour of The River Cafe pork loin. Rose has, she explains, just returned from a few days at a wine-tasting event in Verona, at one stage trying 86 wines in a day - 'You know, blue teeth and purple mouth.' She shows me a notebook in which she notes her reactions to everything placed in front of her in a careful Elizabeth David-like hand that only gets slightly more gregarious as the day progresses. She and Ruth are jackdaws of Italian cuisine. They visit Italy every six weeks or so, persuading olive oil suppliers to show them what they do with peas, foraging in nettle beds for long-lost salad ingredients. As if to prove the point, Rose then sets me off preparing some puntarelle, a relation of the dandelion, with which she is going to make a salad 'in the traditional Roman style'. She is messianic about good natural ingredients. She talks of the restaurant's new vegetable garden. 'We're the only place that's got one,' she says. In her spare time, she designs gardens in her head; it all goes back, she says, to her growing up in Surrey during the war, 'with this fabulous vegetable garden. There was all sorts of rationing, but I saw how you could make good things from simple seasonal ingredients.' In the kitchen, meanwhile, the talk is of top-secret plans for Jamie Oliver's forthcoming stag night - Oliver was a former puntarelle peeler, as was Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall of TV dinners fame (if you want to be a star these days, shell peas) - and, at my prompting, of the differences between Rose and Ruth's ways of running the kitchen. 'Rose is more cerebral,' someone says, 'she can visualise tastes in her head. She'll come back with a sack of beans or a bag of a particular flour and have a very clear idea of what she wants you to do with it. She also does things last minute. Ruth tends to strip things to their essentials more, aims to keep things simpler, but wants to plan.' Or, says someone else: 'Rose is a bit more suspicious; Ruth's better at PR'. Or: 'Rose is far more confident than Ruth; Ruth is sometimes less sure of her decisions.' The kitchen is agreed on two things. First that 'It's mental when they are working together; they did a night a while back where one was on the grill and one was up front: madness.' And, second, all suitably on message, that they could not have landed in a more enlightened kitchen. There is talk of food parcels being delivered to them when they are ill; annual trips to Italy to taste olive oil. 'Where else would you get that?' Of her own style of running the kitchen, Rose says that she's 'capable of barking at people if its not running properly. Sometimes you have a chef who goes silent on you and you have to try to keep them all communicating, pull them out of themselves.' There is not a great deal of need for barking this lunchtime, however. Business is slow - only 45 covers (they can do 130 in the summer, when the garden is open) - a fact which Rose blames on the blip in the American stock market. 'Everyone has stayed by their screens,' she says. But, despite the global economic downturn, my expertly prepared puntarelle sells like hot sambucca. When Ruth arrives in the afternoon, double kissing me, a cardigan around her shoulders, the atmosphere changes a little. She sits down with her young assistant chef, Arthur, and constructs an evening menu partly based on what has gone well at lunchtime. There is much talk of dark plates, and of light plates. Borlotti beans travel up and down the menu, alternatively inserted and erased by Rogers, sucking her pencil. Arthur's role is mainly to enthuse, but occasionally he disagrees with a dish, offering suggestions of his own. ('The great thing here is that everyone has a say,' he tells me. 'If you said that kind of thing to Gordon Ramsay he'd just tell you to fuck off.') Ruth Rogers gives off a kind of palpable and charming nervous energy. She sets me off chopping asparagus, and tells me how she's just been on the phone to my editor, to talk about a skiing trip she's taking the next day with Richard and his five sons (Ab, Ben and Zad from his first marriage; Roo and Bo with Ruth.) She shows me how to make a perfect pear tart, all the while chivvying her staff. She reveals to me the precise moment for dispatching the caramel part of her signature caramel ice cream. ('If someone hasn't shouted "something's burning", then its not done'.) She laughs off my suggestions that she is running the country from her flame grill, but then admits that the previous night she had dinner with Alan Yentob, creative director of BBC1 and Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian . She introduces me to her kitchen staff and puts her hand over their mouths when they jokingly threaten to reveal indiscretions ('And me a patron of Index on Censorship'). Her friends tend to fall over themselves with superlatives to describe Ruth. Certainly, she seems to have led the most charmed of lives. She grew up in 'Woodstock of all places' in the 60s, the child of wealthy anti-Vietnam radicals. She met and fell for Richard in 1969, when she was in England and 19. At the time, Rogers, 15 years her senior, was married (to the architect Su Brumwell) and was earning £2,000 a year teaching at the Architectural Association. Not long after Ruth moved in, however, he had his amazing break: winning the competition to design the Pompidou Centre in Paris. Ruth resigned from her job in the design department at Penguin Books and went to join him in Paris. They lived in the Place des Vosges, had their first child in 1975, and never looked back. 'Ruthie wore very bright colours when we first met,' her husband recalls. 'Students used to ask me what came first: my wife's clothes or the colours of my buildings. The truth is that she did have a big influence on that.' If she brought colour to Rogers's life she also set about bringing it to the friends she met with her husband. She hosted parties including famous Thanksgiving dinners for fellow ex-pats like Doris Saatchi and Ed Victor. She organised political campaigns, notably 'the friends of Salman Rushdie' with her great ally the socialite publisher Caroline Michel, enlisting the support of the Yentobs and the Bertoluccis, Jacob Rothschild and Melvyn Bragg, among others. And she started the restaurant. Her inspiration came form her husband's mother, Dada, who died last year. Rose had known Richard long before he met Ruth and was already a disciple of his mother's cooking. Ruth was bought up to think that Italian cooking was meatballs and she was overwhelmed by what Richard's family ate. 'Dada came from a very very wealthy family in Trieste,' she says. 'She grew up in that period when James Joyce was there, and Italo Svevo, and she married Richard's father who was a Florentine. With the onset of war, they came to London. And there she was, this Italian girl lifted out of Florence and plonked down in a bedsit behind Paddington station. She spent her whole time trying to find things here that she could cook.' In the early days of The River Cafe, Dada would come in and taste what Ruth and Rose were making. She always used to say: 'Too many herbs; too much butter keep it simple, simple.' And just before she died, she called Ruth to her bedside. 'Pretty much her last words to me were: go easy on the herbs, not so many herbs,' smiles Ruth. You can see a bit of Dada in Ruth as she cooks, trying to keep things simple. However often she does it, she says, she still gets a little adrenaline as eight o'clock comes around. 'It's like I imagine the theatre to be,' she says. But by the time the sun is setting over the Harrod's Depository opposite, she seems in her element. 'People think it must be so stressful because they get stressed out by cooking dinner for 10 people. But the most exhausting thing for us is seeing accountants or looking after the staff properly. Cooking is the fun part, the relaxing part.' Her lowest point, she says, was discovering that she had cooked a risotto for General Pinochet some years ago. She had, she remembers, thought the Spanish speaking party was 'just another royal family with their bodyguards'. When she found out 'my blood went cold and I was in tears... I'd poured my heart into this dictator's risotto.' Other than dictators, the only guests she dreads are Italian chefs. A while ago, the writer Adam Gopnik opined in The New Yorker that 'the best Italian food to be had in Europe was on the banks of the Thames'. All the Italian restaurateurs in London came and sat at the bar here and told us that what we were cooking was not Italian: 'You know, where is the Bolognese?' The closest she comes to a crisis this evening though, is a shortage of chard. Some nights, she says, 'it's just like a big dinner party - but then that's the idea really.' Working with Rogers and Gray you could convince yourself that you get a tiny glimpse of a more perfect world. It's only a restaurant, of course, but it's one in which all families are happy and all vegetables are fresh and all conversation is interesting. They get many people asking them why they don't open another restaurant, and they say there are two reasons: 'The first is that it would be impossible to find anywhere as beautiful as this; and the other is that you suddenly dilute your identity. It's nice having a piece of work that is wholly your own.' Like all successful recipes, this one depends on its main ingredients. In a rare moment, when they sit down together, I ask them to choose a single adjective to describe each other. 'Beautiful,' says Rose of Ruth. 'That was going to be mine,' says Ruth. She thinks for a while. 'Excellent,' she says. Like married couples, they say they have grown alike: 'Well, we both wear the same clothes,' says Rose, 'so to that extent, yes.' 'Sometimes, says Ruth, 'I hear myself talking and I think, "Oh God, I sound like Rose."' 'You mean you sound excellent,' says Rose. 'Yes, of course,' says her friend, 'I sound excellent.' And they both giggle like schoolgirls. Observer readers can order a copy of River Cafe Green for the special price of £25 (rrp £30), including UK p&p, by calling freephone 0800 3168 171

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Agnès b was so moved by a Douglas Gordon installation, she resolved to meet him. Now, the designer and the artist meet wherever they can. And Agnès has even said she'll fix his favourite leather trousers
fields.trailText: Agnès b was so moved by a Douglas Gordon installation, she resolved to meet him. Now, the designer and the artist meet wherever they can. And Agnès has even said she'll fix his favourite leather trousers
fields.body:
Agnès b: The fashion industry does not interest me. I never go to any fashion shows or even visit any shops, only the occasional flea market. I like to keep away from the whole business as much as I can. It is not important to me. I love to design clothes, but I try to do it differently and I work very quickly. I feel you have to like people when you design. I try to imagine who the person wearing it would be, I put myself in their place. I especially like designing for men. Like David Bowie. I saw him at a concert in Paris and I thought he was very badly dressed. I'd loved him for years, of course, like everyone has who loves music. So I wrote him a note saying, 'You are very badly dressed', and I sent him a pair of leather jeans. He liked them so much he ordered another four pairs and asked me to dress him for his 50th birthday party at Madison Square Garden.

My real loves, though, are art, film and music. With artists I admire, I like to meet their work first. This is how I met Douglas. In Paris in 1996, I saw a piece of his work called 30 Second Text . You go into a dark cupboard and the light stays on for only 30 seconds, in which time you have to read the text on the screen. Apparently, 30 seconds is the time it takes for the head to die after it has been cut from the body. I mean, I was born in Versailles, so it held a special interest for me. It was the way people were killed in France until the 20th century. That got me very interested - I wanted to know him through this piece. I began to explore other pieces of his work, and then we kept bumping into each other in different cities, Berlin, New York, Paris, and we would carry on the conversation we left off from the last time. He has contributed to my art magazine, Le Point d'Ironie . It is a free magazine and each time we print 100,000 copies, and each time a different artist produces it. He is always so kind to me. When I was in New York and his show hadn't yet opened, he called me up to invite me to see it early.

I was one of the producers on Gordon's piece of work, Feature Film , which came out last year. It is a very beautiful film and concentrates on the Bernard Herrmann music from the Alfred Hitchcock film, Vertigo . The whole film is built around the conducting of the score by James Conlon, who is an amazingly charismatic man and who actually looks a lot like Douglas - he could be his uncle. I am organising screenings in Paris because I want very much for people to see it. My love of film has led me to make six little stories of my own, which I recently filmed in New York, of different people wearing my clothes. I filmed and edited it myself. I am very proud of this because this skill is so new to me. I hope to show them in London soon.

Douglas and I generally see each other when he is in Paris or I visit Britain. When I was on the judging panel for the Edinburgh Film Festival last summer, we had a little time to spend with each other, and recently we have both been judging the Beck's Future Award for Film and Video. I wanted especially to be involved in this award because it encourages younger artists who aren't particularly well known. That's why I make a point of collecting young artists' pieces, it is very encouraging for them. We don't tend to meet up with each others' families, although I have met Douglas's girlfriend and I liked her very much. I think of Douglas and myself as electrons libres , free neutrons.

Douglas Gordon: I was, of course, aware of Agnès's clothes before I knew her. I used to go into her shops and look around longingly, knowing that I could never afford them. Luckily, I've got one or two items now. She's also agreed to help mend an old leather jacket of mine that I am very fond of, but which has huge holes in it.

When we first met, about five years ago, I remember Agnès ordered a glass of Champagne and I ordered a vodka martini, and so immediately we started talking about James Bond and then we continued to talk about cinema for the next two hours. She has a huge knowledge of film and art. The friendship grew over a number of meetings. I go to Paris quite often. Feature Film was filmed there. It took five years, from the initial idea to the first projection, to complete. It was funny, because during filming, members of the orchestra kept coming up and asking if they'd seen my last film, and I'd never made a film before, so I kept saying, 'Oh, you wouldn't have heard of it'. James Conlon was a great find as the conductor. I don't know much about the classical music world, and so I just went on the internet and found the best-looking guy. I didn't know whether he'd be a good conductor or not. Luckily, not only was he a great conductor but he had a real cinematic quality.

I've just returned from a very hectic three weeks in Paris, where my latest exhibition, Sheep and Goats, has just opened at the Musée d'Art Modern. I have not exhibited at Agnès's gallery yet, but she keeps urging me to. I like to think that we work together in ways that are not necessarily within the confines of four walls, not in terms of a gallery space. As soon as you put four walls around a situation, then it doesn't remain as open. She is very supportive and her explanations of my work are often far better than my own. It was great to have her as one of the producers on Feature Film . I like working in Paris, and it was the Musée d'Art Modern that approached me about my latest exhibition. They asked me to do the show maybe three years ago, and I put it off three times, but now I think it's right. I find that in countries like France or Germany, there are better facilities to make bigger shows. There was nowhere, really, in London that I could have exhibited Sheep and Goats. It might be better when the Tate Modern opens, hopefully it will change the landscape there. I am putting on a smaller show at the Liverpool Tate Gallery, though, in June.

I'm based in Glasgow, but I did live in London during the second recession, between 1988 and 1990. Though I don't feel the need to live there any more, I still pop down more or less every weekend. I don't really perceive a 'London Art Scene'. People like Tracey Emin and Sarah Lucas are just people who I have a drink with. It's the same in Glasgow. I don't think anybody who works internationally perceives a scene. It's more likely you would meet up with these people in Berlin or New York or Paris.

Because Agnès and I share a great love of the cinema, especially Alfred Hitchcock, we tend to send each other films that we think the other should see. I am looking forward to seeing her six short films she made in New York. I won't give her any advice, though - I don't tend to advise anybody about anything.

fields.headline: The Tate we're in
fields.standfirst: Tamsin Blanchard gets a sneak preview of the new Tate Modern
fields.trailText: The press officer in charge of corralling nosy journalists and temperamental taxi drivers on their sneak previews around London's latest and greatest temple to art, has disappeared behind a partition wall and is flicking light switches on and off.
fields.body:
The press officer in charge of corralling nosy journalists and temperamental taxi drivers on their sneak previews around London's latest and greatest temple to art, has disappeared behind a partition wall and is flicking light switches on and off.

We are standing in one of the Tate Modern's one-room installations, marvelling at Cornelia Parker's exploding garden shed. Cold Dark Matter: An Exploded View has never been displayed before in London. Since being loaned out to the Laing Art Gallery in Newcastle, it's been hidden away, piece by piece, in the Tate's vaults in Southwark. If there was ever a reason why London needed more space for its art, this is it.

Unfortunately, the light - a single bare bulb - suspended inside the shed isn't working today. Cold Dark Matter is meant to be displayed in a dark room, so that the bits of trowels, gloves, boots and other garden shed paraphernalia that was exploded along with the shed in 1991, hang on fine wire, the shadows dancing eerily against the walls.

All around the Tate Modern, in the perfectly proportioned spaces, with their unvarnished oak floors barely walked on, there is art in progress. Watching a piece of modern art being installed is a happening in itself. They could sell tickets for this. One room is being pieced together like a jigsaw puzzle. In another, there's a restorer, seemingly pounding away at a canvas, cleaning it up after years in storage. A few rooms along, a couple of curators are working out how to unpack a large cardboard box filled with light bulbs, and labelled Christian Boltanski. Degrees in art history and electrical engineering, it would seem, are essential for this job.

It is two weeks before the galleries will be filled with people jostling for a closer look at the rehung Rothkos, or queuing for their cups of tea in the top floor café with its panoramic views across to St Paul's. By then, Cold Dark Matter 's lighting effects will be working perfectly.

But the big thrill of Tate Modern is the building itself. That is not a criticism. No collection of art could compete with the sheer scale of the place. When you first set foot inside the colossal Turbine Hall, you get butterflies in your stomach. Our guide informs us, shouting to be heard over the drilling and welding, that the hall is to be left raw and industrial-looking, cold and drafty as it always was.

There will be just one piece of sculpture exhibited here - the first, specially commissioned, by Louise Bourgeois. On my visit, it was still being erected and looked like a pile of rusty metal cylinders with a team of ant-sized people scurrying around it. I imagine it will take me several visits to stop gasping at the building and concentrate on the 88 galleries within it. Personally, I can't wait.

Tate Modern, Bankside, London SE1 (020 7887 8000) opens on Friday 12 May. Opening hours, 10am-6pm Sunday to Thursday, 10am-10pm Friday and Saturday
