Our guide informs us, shouting to be heard over the drilling and welding, that the hall is to be left raw and industrial-looking, cold and drafty as it always was. There will be just one piece of sculpture exhibited here - the first, specially commissioned, by Louise Bourgeois. On my visit, it was still being erected and looked like a pile of rusty metal cylinders with a team of ant-sized people scurrying around it. I imagine it will take me several visits to stop gasping at the building and concentrate on the 88 galleries within it. Personally, I can't wait. Tate Modern, Bankside, London SE1 (020 7887 8000) opens on Friday 12 May. Opening hours, 10am-6pm Sunday to Thursday, 10am-10pm Friday and Saturday

fields.headline: Lessons in life
fields.standfirst: Colleges are keen to recruit more mature students - how else can they hope to win University Challenge?
fields.trailText: Colleges are keen to recruit more mature students - how else can they hope to win University Challenge?
fields.body:
The government has just announced a £17 million package of bursaries to lure mature students back to university. Why? Because they offer value for money.

Just look at one of them in action. The big, bearded one on the far right of the University Challenge line-up. Forty if he is a day, and wearing a Real Ale T-shirt, although these days what his right hand's for is pressing buzzers at superhuman speed. Colin Smith, ex-steelworker, reading political science at North Midlands University .

'And it's over to you, North Midlands. In which year did both Stalin and Queen Mary die?'; 'What was Walt Disney's first feature-length film?'; 'What word for a secret society is formed by an acronym of the initials of Charles II's ministers?'

'1953'; ' Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs '; 'Cabal.'

The pale, intense adolescents of one of Oxbridge's oldest colleges look aghast. They knew they were weak on computers, sport and large swathes of post-1870s history, but Smith has been around. He's had two extra decades to think, to listen, read, ferret about outside the boundaries of his subject. Storing information, that's what Smith's been up to since he left school in the 70s. No contest.

The mature students' 'gap' between leaving school and matriculating into university can be anything from three to 50 years - time spent working, having children, travelling, surviving. Some have been made redundant by business, by lovers, by life. There are those whose teenage rebellions got too far out of hand to deliver them tidily at a college door and those whose mid-life crises have led them to contemplate potsherds or fractals. Those drawn by personal or televised drama to white coats, wigs or surplices, those who wanted more money or respect. Those, above all, who hoped for a second chance. But however ornamental the initial fantasy, by the time they arrive at their chosen institution an October or two later, the potential student will have had their new vocation fiercely tested. Forget 'life experience' qualifications - the more erratic the former life, the more purging the entry requirements.

Like all late converts, mature students tend towards total immersion. They work hard, spin from seminars to library and devour reading lists, later affecting to having scanned only the odd paragraph. When younger peers falter over an unexpected question, the thought-bubble over the mature head still pleads, 'Me, me, ask me, Miss.' They hang on lecturers' every word, argue about New Historicism, get their essays in on time. These are undiscerning enthusiasts who act, sing, protest and play sport. They practise drinking games, assimilate student wardrobes and vocabulary and fall in love with their supervisors. And, by the by, they get good degrees.

Which is not to say that it is all fun. It is very, very hard. Financially, returning to education is a huge strain - more so for those with dependants - and it is getting harder as the criteria for grants get more stringent. Nearly all mature undergraduates take out loans, and any post-degree vocational qualification adds to a burden of debt that may be impossible to shift. Partnerships also come under pressure; with a charismatic third party in the relationship, the rate of attrition is high. Many older students become intoxicated, not with the odd bonding roll-up in the college bar, but the excitement of learning combined with a seductive sense of power and freedom. The life is exhausting, compelling and exclusive.

It would also be wrong to believe that mature students' intellectual eclecticism is welcomed across academia. Certain institutions are more accepting of the eccentric entrant than others - more willing to gamble, to find their ways challenged, to adapt. Oxbridge, which can take its pick of the cleverest, most finely honed sixth-formers, can be formidable, even discouraging, to a 30-year-old doing Access courses at evening class. Adaptation is not part of the culture. But even Oxford and Cambridge now have colleges for mature entrants. In reality, their one-to-one supervisions are ideal for the late-starter and the collegiate system, generally attacked as elitist, is a perfect environment for the unconventional neophyte: protective, guiding and, crucially, rich.

In 1991, having not so much drifted as lurched through life, I was accepted by Lucy Cavendish College at Cambridge. Suddenly I was in control. Suddenly I was mainstream; there were women who were much more 'difficult' than me around. My fellow students, aged between 21 and 63, included an exotic dancer, an ex-spy, a barmaid, a journalist, a Bosnian exile and a policewoman who shared a disbelief both at being taken seriously and their sudden right of access to gowns, gothic halls and libraries of Byzantine complexity.

It was, and remains, the most astonishing, even redemptive, experience of my life; it is one that more and more others will share if their efforts are rewarded by financial support. And no, I didn't go on University Challenge , but one of my best friends did.

fields.headline: Director sees the big picture
fields.standfirst: Charles Saumarez Smith faces change at home and work
fields.trailText: Charles Saumarez Smith, Director of the National Portrait Gallery, talks to Neasa McErlean.
fields.body:
Few people know who he is, although a million people each year visit the gallery he runs. Charles Saumarez Smith has been director of the ever more successful National Portrait Gallery for six years, and sees one of his great projects brought to fruition on Thursday. This is when the £16 million extension to the NPG is unveiled by the Queen - in the presence of many of the great, the good and the not so good who have sat for portraits that now grace the gallery walls. It is also the day on which the NPG - in a bow to modern life - launches its late-night openings (now extended to 9pm on Thursday and Friday).

Saumarez Smith's rather low profile could be seen as a testament to his success. He has modernised the gallery without attracting the howls of protest that have greeted Nicholas Serota at the Tate and many other artistic directors. Proof of the gallery's burgeoning appeal is that visitor numbers have nearly doubled from just over 500,000 a decade ago. Saumarez Smith has been behind decisions such as the running of an exhibition of 'netheads', - the youthful entrepreneurs, including photogenic Martha Lane Fox, who have made fortunes from the Internet.

Not so well known is that while Saumarez Smith, 45, has been seeing through the building project in St. Martin's Place, he has also been involved in protracted negotiations about his own house. After a marathon conveyancing process of more than a year, he, his wife and two children are due to move to new, larger premises in June. 'The most satisfying part of each process has been the sense of design and the anticipation of how best the space can be used,' says the former head of research at the Victoria and Albert.

The NPG extension is in what used to be a back yard between it and its huge neighbour, the National Gallery. The project was only made possible because of the 'goodwill' of Neil MacGregor, the NG director who supported the plan and agreed to lose some of his sunlight. Saumarez Smith - who learnt accountancy and other business skills in courses run by the Getty Trust - says: 'Many business problems are really about the larger issues of planning and management.'

Saumarez Smith, a history of art and architectural specialist, has been forced into becoming very aware of economic pressures. With little or no increase in government grants over the last few years, the NPG has had to go in for a variety of commercial ventures - opening a bookshop and cafe in the basement, renting out the gallery in the evenings and - from Thursday - operating a restaurant from the top floor. The director is convinced that free admission is a crucial part of the NPG's success.

Future initiatives could include encouraging people to mention the gallery in wills and bequests. Saumarez Smith sets his own example here - being one of that minority of fortysomethings who have written their wills. 'I'm methodical in my finances,' he says. 'That's because I have a reasonably consistent salary and consistent outgoings.'

He sees another parallel here. Just as the NPG will have to manage 50 per cent more space on the same amount of government grant, so he will now have to manage a much larger mortgage on the same income.

Next week: Gillian Lindsay, Olympic rower

fields.headline: Flaming hard work
fields.trailText: KD of Hull raises the question of when it is reasonable to ask for compensation, beyond reimbursing losses, after a financial institution has caused you concern.
fields.body: KD of Hull raises the question of when it is reasonable to ask for compensation, beyond reimbursing losses, after a financial institution has caused you concern. He was prompted by a reader (Your Problems , 26 March) who lost his house deeds in the fire that destroyed thousands of Bradford & Bingley documents: 'The question of compensation has arisen a number of times and I think it is a natural and genuine reaction. After all, while title to the property may be restored, many will not be absolutely sure there will not be problems in the future, perhaps after their death. I raised the compensation issue after my deeds were lost in the fire and received the same response. I was not seeking a large sum, more a token to acknowledge the worry and anxiety my wife and I were put through. In the end, I sent the society a bill for the time and effort in searching out documents and attending our solicitors to make a statutory declaration. The bill was paid.'

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: Customers can compare a range of financial products and providers, apply for products online and, where possible, get approval in principle from financial providers via a new independent broker, moneygator.com. The company is offering mortgages, credit cards and personal loans, and has already agreed terms on several hundred products with more than 12 providers. The website provides a one-off application form which captures all the information needed for providers to make a decision on whether to lend to a particular applicant.

The company is offering mortgages, credit cards and personal loans, and has already agreed terms on several hundred products with more than 12 providers. The website provides a one-off application form which captures all the information needed for providers to make a decision on whether to lend to a particular applicant.

People buying, selling or even remortgaging their homes often have their stress levels cranked up because they are unable to check the progress of their deal. Moneysupermarket.com is aiming to ease the tension by offering a low cost online conveyancing service where you can track progress at any time.

The stockmarket turmoil of the last few weeks has shown the value of being able to check up-to-the-second share prices. A free service from Teletext enables investors to check real-time share prices for 3,000 of the most popular shares listed on the London Stock Exchange at Teletext.co.uk.

Screentrade, the internet insurance supermarket, is guaranteeing that anyone visiting its site will receive the cheapest motor, home and travel insurance - or it will refund the difference on more than 50 products. The site at Screentrade.co.uk allows users to compare prices and features, select the policy that really suits them best, and then buy the chosen policy online.

webTitle: Truffle research claim failed to move the insurers

fields.headline: Truffle research claim failed to move the insurers
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
In January, I was to visit the Dordogne for a research project concerning insect pests of truffles. The gîte we were to use was damaged by storms and the meeting was cancelled. I had taken out a standard travel policy offered by Rail Europe. The insurer will not refund my travel costs even though the accommodation was uninhabitable.
JC, Hereford

The insurance was underwritten by Home & Overseas, which delivered a standard response that it will not refund your fare because you should have looked for alternative accommodation. Clearly no one read your claim carefully or listened to my explanation. The other large underwriter in the holiday business, Bishopsgate, said it would have paid up because cancellation was outside your control. I repeated to Home & Overseas that an alternative was irrelevant because the object of your trip had been cancelled. But they have not managed to respond. Take your complaint to the Insurance Ombudsman on 0845 600 6666.

I have term insurance with Cornhill Direct and received a mailshot offering personal accident insurance for 'no additional policy fee'. On reading the letter, I found that, while no new fee was involved, there was an addition of 72p a month to the existing fee. I threw the letter away. Weeks later, I had another letter referring to 'your instruction to include the above benefit in your policy'. I asked for a copy of my form, which I know does not exist, but have had no acknowledgment. This strikes me as inertia selling.
PH, Cardiff

Cornhill claims that you sent the form back, uncompleted and unsigned, but a member of staff mistakenly treated this as an application. And, says the insurer, there is a microfiche to prove it.

This is a mystery because the company agrees you are unlikely to confuse throwing the form away with addressing an envelope, licking a stamp and walking to the postbox. Cornhill accepts its mistake and has removed the additional insurance, refunding the 72p premium.

In September 1998, I was forced to close my business due to ill health and asked Scottish Widows if I could take an early pension; they said not until August 1999 when I was 65. A year ago, my financial situation worsened so I contacted them again and this time they said I could have it. But because I took my pension last May, I am entitled to only £500 from the merger with Lloyds TSB. If I had waited till August, I would have received around £18,000.
PR, Brigstock

Scottish Widows says it can find no evidence that anyone said you could not take your pension in 1998 and confirms you could have done. You can pursue your complaint with the PIA Ombudsman: South Quay Plaza, 183 Marsh Wall, London E14 9SR. (020-7712 8937).

As for the merger, Scottish Widows confirms negotiations were taking place last April but says this was known only to a few senior people. You have been unlucky with your timing.

Go for the highest rate now. Whether you have £3,000 or £9,000 when your Tessa matures, you can transfer it to whichever Isa pays the best rate at that time. You could also transfer the money already in your Tessa to one paying more. On £3,000, 6.4 per cent is good but Nationwide pays 6.85 per cent with no fees if you switch (0500 302010); HSBC pays 6.75 per cent (0800 130130). If your existing Tessa provider charges a penalty to leave, that might outweigh the higher interest.

Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Poor returns dog some of the big names

fields.headline: Poor returns dog some of the big names
fields.standfirst: Christine Stopp advises caution on buying into some unit trusts sold over the bank counter
fields.trailText: A recent press release from Barclays sang the praises of the group's General Fund - a unit trust launched more than 40 years ago and now accounting for more than £1bn of investors' cash. Barclays General was launched within weeks of the Mini, much loved by motorists ever since, and which had an initial purchase price of £497. If, say Barclays, you had put the value of a Mini into the General Fund, you would by the beginning of February this year have had £64,734 - more than enough to buy a new Jaguar XK8. What Barclays does not tell you is that while performance over very long periods is not bad - and unfortunately there are no published 40-year performance figures to make comparisons - over periods of up to 10 years to the end of March, the General Fund consistently underperformed the average in its sector. Over one year it was in 226th position out of 271 funds, and over the first quarter of this year made a loss of almost 12 per cent. For this performance record customers pay charges which are relatively high compared to the rest of the industry, at 5.25 per cent initial and 1.25 per cent annual.
fields.body:
A recent press release from Barclays sang the praises of the group's General Fund - a unit trust launched more than 40 years ago and now accounting for more than £1bn of investors' cash. Barclays General was launched within weeks of the Mini, much loved by motorists ever since, and which had an initial purchase price of £497. If, say Barclays, you had put the value of a Mini into the General Fund, you would by the beginning of February this year have had £64,734 - more than enough to buy a new Jaguar XK8. What Barclays does not tell you is that while performance over very long periods is not bad - and unfortunately there are no published 40-year performance figures to make comparisons - over periods of up to 10 years to the end of March, the General Fund consistently underperformed the average in its sector. Over one year it was in 226th position out of 271 funds, and over the first quarter of this year made a loss of almost 12 per cent. For this performance record customers pay charges which are relatively high compared to the rest of the industry, at 5.25 per cent initial and 1.25 per cent annual.

As our table shows, Barclays is not alone in offering funds which have captured a massive amount of investors' money, but which, over most investment terms, have given poor performance. Some of the best names in the financial services industry are included, all of them from large banks or insurance companies.

Jason Hollands of adviser Best Investment publishes a 'Spot the Dog' investment bulletin to help investors weed out poor performers from their portfolios. He confirmed that the funds highlighted in our table are largely 'big lumbering trusts which are not very well managed and which have consistently underperformed'. He singles out one or two for particular criticism, being distinctly unenthusiastic about Halifax Growth, Scottish Amicable Equity and Prudential UK Growth. He has kinder words however for Equitable's Pelican, which 'used to be atrocious, but in recent years has performed in line with the index'.

When some unit trusts can do so much better, how is it that such major fund managers are doing such a poor job for investors? The answer seems to lie in how these funds are sold. 'They are bought by investors who are not looking for a top performer. Instead of reading the press or going to a financial adviser, they just go to their bank,' says Hollands. Most of the funds shown are sold either over bank counters or by tied agents. Few are sold through independent advisers, who have a duty to their clients to pick out the best performers. Since advisers largely ignore them and they do not feature highly in the performance rankings, these funds are not much mentioned in the press. They are effectively invisible.

'These are direct sales so they have no incentive to produce shop-window performance. Companies can go on selling them to people who do not look at the performance statistics,' says Mark Dampier, research director at the Bristol advisers Hargreaves Lansdown.

What do the management groups say about their funds? Lucy Cook, press officer at Barclays, said she did not feel the 'Mini to a Jaguar' theme was a false platform on which to sell the fund. 'I think the performance is quite good when you look at £497 to £64,000,' she said.

At Equitable Life, Alistair Dunbar, senior public relations manager, said the Pelican fund had not done well recently because it was biased towards FTSE 100 stocks, whereas market performance had largely come from the technology sector. 'It wouldn't be right for a fund like Pelican to invest in much of that. It would be against what investors have been led to expect.' He also said the Pelican fund had averaged a little under 18 per cent growth a year for the past five years.

Standard Life's UK Equity General fund can only be bought through the company's insurance products such as the Capital Investment Bond. Investment director Jacqueline Kerr feels that it is inappropriate to compare it to funds in the unit trust UK All Companies sector. This, she says 'is not the best place for it to be judged. If it is looked at against insurance funds, it's a different story'. Spokesman Geoff Newton adds: 'The fund is so large it is hard to take a meaningful position in hi-tech stocks. Its profile is quite different from unit trusts which are looking for short-term gains. It is a safe and secure long-term fund.'

For comparative purposes we looked for very large funds which had done consistently well and found that some do exist: the table includes CIS UK Growth, larger at £1.8bn than any other fund shown, and Norwich UK Equity - much smaller, but still not a tiddler at almost £750m.

Both have consistently produced above-average performance over most of the periods shown, and give the lie to arguments that big funds cannot be expected to perform, 'safety' is not consistent with strong performance, and all large equity growth funds should be closet index-trackers.

The lesson for investors is that household names do not guarantee performance; funds should be monitored regularly to ensure that growth is up to scratch; and not too much attention should be paid to dramatic figures quoted in isolation.

Both advisers offer discount dealing.

fields.headline: Working lives just got longer
fields.standfirst: They're making it harder to walk out of your job at an early age, says Jill Insley
fields.trailText: If you are dreaming of an early escape from the rat race, think again. You could be forced to postpone your retirement for up to five years if Government plans to curb early retirement go ahead.
fields.body:
If you are dreaming of an early escape from the rat race, think again. You could be forced to postpone your retirement for up to five years if Government plans to curb early retirement go ahead.

The proposals, published last week by the Government's Performance and Innovation Unit, will raise the minimum age at which you can draw an income from a private pension scheme. The state retirement age - which triggers payment of the basic state pension - will remain at 65. But the age at which you can draw from an occupational or personal pension would rise from 50 to 55, in a phased programme between 2010 and 2020.

Civil servants will see their retirement age rise from 60 to 65, with part-time duties in the later years, and the rest of the public sector will be expected to follow suit.

The Government hopes the rule changes will help to retain experienced, older people in the workforce and will make it more difficult for employers to force such employees into early retirement before they are financially prepared.

Early retirement is believed by many employers to be a cheap alternative to redundancy. The employer can avoid making a redundancy payment and any additional payments made to the employee's occupational pension will come from the pension fund rather than the employer's pocket. Although the employer will probably still have to pick up the bill for this later on, the perception is that such a move costs less money.

However, 60 per cent of those between 50 and the state pensionable age who are not working have no occupational pension, and many others have inadequately funded pensions. They cannot receive the state pension before the age of 60 for women (rising to 65 between the years 2010 and 2020) and 65 for men, and many claim state benefits to survive. According to the Performance and Innovation Unit, 2.8 million people between 50 and the state pension age are not working. Of these, 2 million claim state benefits designed to replace income from work, and only 300,000 are actively seeking work.

In practice, very few people can afford to retire before 55. But the Government is also keen to encourage people over the age of 50 to 'downshift' - working shorter hours and supplementing their earnings by drawing partial pensions.

Although occupational pension rules do not allow people over 50 to work reduced hours and receive a part-pension while working for the same firm, the Inland Revenue has agreed in principle to change this.

However, unions and trade associations attacked the plans this week, claiming that the Government would be limiting employees' choice, in some cases forcing them to continue working after they had burnt out. And experts in the pensions industry said that they feared the new rules could put people off saving through pension schemes.

Liz Maw, a spokeswoman for Norwich Union, says: 'Rather than stopping people from saving at all, we think it's likely to focus attention on other forms of investment, particularly the tax-efficient individual savings schemes.

'The fact that they have longer to go until retirement may also encourage people to delay starting their pension, or to pay in smaller premiums, so they end up with an inadequate pension income.'

But Stewart Ritchie, director of pensions development at Scottish Equitable, welcomes a further proposal in last week's announcement to raise the age by which pensioners must buy an annuity to 80. 'Ideally, they wouldn't have to buy an annuity at all, but age 80 is better than 75.'

Who will the increase in minimum pension age affect?

Anyone now aged 40 or less who would normally be eligible to retire in the year 2010 onwards.

The proposals suggest that the minimum pension age should be phased in over a 10-year period, increasing by one year in every two. By the year 2012, you will have to be 51 to retire, by the year 2014 you'll have to be 52 and so on.

Will the change apply to existing schemes?

This is not yet clear. The proposals state that the increase should apply to all schemes (including defined contribution schemes and new personal pensions), which could then be taken between the ages of 55 and 80.

However, the Government says that further consultation is necessary before decisions on this type of fine detail are made. Stewart Ritchie says that previous disadvantageous changes to pension rules have never been applied retrospectively, and it would be 'extraordinary' for the new minimum pension age to be applied to pension benefits accrued under different rules.

Can I still 'retire' early?

You can stop work whenever you want - provided you have enough money to live on. Nick Bamford of pension specialists Informed Choice says people will simply need to invest sufficient money in alternative savings schemes to provide an income before they reach the new minimum retirement age and then to make up the shortfall before they can draw the state pension at age 65.

Robert Reid, of London independent financial advisers Syndaxi, says most people need a mix of financial products to achieve their goals: 'Sit down and think about monetary objectives and timescales, then consider what the best vehicles are to achieve that.' These could include pension schemes, Isas, unit and investment trusts and deposit accounts.

Should I still pay into a pension scheme?

Yes. Pension schemes offer considerable tax advantages - tax relief on premiums, roll up of gains free from income and capital gains tax, and up to 25 per cent of the eventual pension fund can be taken as tax free cash.

Do not be panicked into surrendering these tax advantages, but incorporate them into a financial plan that allows you to retire when you want. Be realistic about when you can afford to retire: you are likely to find it a financially impossible before 55 anyway.

The PIU points out that someone retiring early will receive less each year in pension income than someone who retires later. The sum needed to buy a £10,000 a year pension for someone aged 60 £173,000 - but this would buy only £6,000 a year for someone aged 50.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Car prices change gear
fields.body:
Car prices change gear

The alluring smell of a brand new car is becoming more affordable, according to the Alliance & Leicester Car Price Index, compiled by What Car? magazine. Although the average price of new cars has fallen by just 3.6 per cent year-on-year, certain categories have fallen by much more. City cars (which includes VW Lupo, Ford Ka, Daewoo Matiz) have plummeted by 9.2 per cent, multi-purpose vehicles (people carriers) by 11.1 per cent and luxury cars (Jaguars, Mercedes S class, and BMW 7 Series) by 13.2 per cent.

Nearly-new cars that are one year old are even better value, falling in cost by an average of 15.8 per cent year on year. People carriers lead the slump in prices, falling by 25 per cent, followed by executive cars which have fallen by 21.3 per cent and family cars, by 15.5 per cent.

Geoff Seymour of the Alliance & Leicester says the dip in prices may be due to the Competition Commission report on car sales, published earlier this month. On the basis of the report, Trade Secretary Stephen Byers has proposed that car suppliers must offer retail customers the same discounts offered to commercial customers. This is expected to reduce the average cost of a car by £1,100.

Word power

Insurance companies are under attack by 'carpetbaggers' who want them to demutualise, but two building societies have fought off conversion bids by employing semantics.

Skipton building society's board recommended that members vote in favour of a resolution requiring the board to consider taking steps to change the independent mutual status of the society. The board says it considers the status of the society periodically anyway, so asked members to sup port the resolution and more than 90 per cent of those who voted did so. Skipton says it will review its position again over the next few months.

Chelsea building society said: 'The first and primary resolution invited the board to consider conversion or takeover. This is something the board does annually as part of its strategic planning. Consequently, the board recommended that members vote in favour and the resolution was duly passed.'

Free shares

The Share Centre, the dealing service for small investors, has mailed to 120,000 customers details of free share entitlements in the company's forthcoming share issue - a prelude to flotation. Those who accept their shares will have them allotted on 23 June, a week before trading starts on the Share Centre's new auction-based dealing system. While the Share Centre intends eventually to seek a Stock Market listing, trading will take place between existing investors until then.

It is still possible to obtain free shares in the company by subscribing £5,000 or £7,000 to the Share Centre's self-select Maxi Isa. To obtain shares in time for the market opening in June, subscriptions must be received by 26 May, but the offer will remain open until 29 December. Those who subscribe £5,000 will be entitled to 100 shares, and for £7,000 the entitlement will be 135 shares. Tel: 08000 28 28 12. Website: www.share.com .

Homes warning

Mortgage borrowers should not be lulled into a false sense of security by the recent fall in repossession rates, the Council for Mortgage Lenders has warned.

Figures published by the Lord Chancellor's department show that repossessions have fallen by 14 per cent in the last three months compared to the first quarter of last year. The number of court actions taken by lenders against borrowers dropped from 22,525 in the first quarter last year to 19,302 this year. The number of court orders against borrowers has fallen even further.

However Michael Coogan, director general of the CML, warns: 'Despite the good news, everyone paying a mortgage should consider how they would cope if there were an unforeseen change in their circumstances.'

'Although economic prospects remain good, household budgets are only just beginning to feel the impact of recent rises in interest rates and the withdrawal of mortgage interest tax relief. It's important that borrowers continue to protect themselves by taking out mortgage payment protection insurance against the risks of accident, sickness and unemployment.'

Sexual indemnity

Heard the one about the woman, whose bags went missing - contraceptive pills and all? She ended up claiming from her travel insurer for disruption to her sex life. Or the man travelling to southern Spain whose stolen suitcase apparently included 11 pairs of trousers and tops, but strangely no underpants.

These are just two of the bizarre claims collected by telephone travel insurer JourneyWise Direct. Another claim for personal effects damaged in a flooded apartment even cited a poltergeist as the culprit.

Michael Ramsey, product manager at JourneyWise, says: 'Unfortunately, travel policies do not cover a disrupted sex life.'

webTitle: Trends, damned trends and house prices

fields.headline: Trends, damned trends and house prices
fields.standfirst: Graham Norwood on the indices that should not be taken as gospel
fields.trailText: House price indices are being obsessively followed by Britain's middle classes. New figures out this week will be seen as indicators of economic activity and used by thousands of households to help them decide whether to buy or sell. So how are house price indices calculated - and are we right to trust them?
fields.body:
House price indices are being obsessively followed by Britain's middle classes. New figures out this week will be seen as indicators of economic activity and used by thousands of households to help them decide whether to buy or sell. So how are house price indices calculated - and are we right to trust them?

There are three authoritative national house price indices, run by the Halifax, Nationwide, and the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions.

Surprisingly the Government's figures are rarely quoted and lack the authority in the industry accorded the Halifax and Nationwide surveys. This is because it bases its monthly and quarterly results on completion prices. With house sales taking up to four months to complete, this means the DETR figures reflect an out-of-date position.

The Halifax and Nationwide figures are based on mortgage offers made by the two firms and reflect a much more contemporary trend. Both companies exclude certain properties from their calculations:

 houses costing £1m-plus, most of which are bought without a mortgage

 ex-council houses bought for the first time (re-sales are counted)

 large, untypical houses (the Halifax, for example, excludes properties with 20 rooms or more)

 re-mortgages

 any property with a commercial element

'These are only a few per cent of all our mortgages each month, but it is important that we exclude anything which stops the property being regarded as a free-market transaction,' says Stephen Rothwell, a statistician for the Halifax.

The Halifax says that during recent busy months up to 20,000 mortgage offers have been made - not far off the 25,000 peaks of the past. Before the recent boom, the index was based on about 12,000 offers a month.

The companies break down each property into its constituent parts (for example, the number of toilets) to allow a process called 'standardisation'. This takes into account the fact that properties built at different times will have different facilities - newer properties, for example, have more toilets.

These constituent parts are then weighted to allow average price rises to be calculated in a geographical area, irrespective of whether the houses sold were mainly new, old or a mix.

The Halifax and Nationwide lists vary slightly, but the main constituent parts are:

 purchase price

 location - the part of the country, and the perceived status of the area

 floor size

 property design (eg, detached house, terraced, or bungalow)

 tenure

 number of bathrooms

 type of central heating, if any

 number of bedrooms

 age of property

Figures are also seasonally adjusted according to the time of year when the mortgage offer is made, because prices are slightly higher in the spring and summer irrespective of the overall trend.

The Nationwide says June is generally the strongest month for house prices and January the weakest.

'Indices are very much general indicators of what goes on in the market,' says Nationwide group economist Alex Bannister. 'People must look at them for a trend, not to see what's happening to their own property. That would be a bit like looking at the Retail Price Index to work out the price of bread,' he says.

Both firms issue national figures each month, covering a range of property sales - for example, all residential properties, or only those bought by first-time buyers, or only those bought by existing owner-occupiers.

Regional figures - covering property types, too, such as terraced or semi-detached - are issued each quarter. Even then, some local areas do not feature every quarter if the number of offers made by the company in that area was too few to satisfy rigorous statistical criteria.

The dependence on one company making sufficient mortgage offers in any period is seen by some housing industry experts as a weakness in the existing indices. This is particularly true in Northern Ireland, where there is a higher proportion of local independent estate agents than in the rest of the UK.

The University of Ulster's Centre for Research on Property and Planning issues a quarterly price index for Northern Ireland based on valuations of properties being sold through about 100 estate agents' offices. The different approach produces dramatically different figures over most quarterly periods, with the University of Ulster figures usually being higher - a result local estate agents, unsurprisingly, prefer. 'I feel it's the most accurate reflection of house price increases in Northern Ireland since it incorporates details of all properties sold by a substantial number of estate agents,' says Gault Ervine, a partner in Ulster Property Sales, which has 13 offices across the province.

None of these figures is wrong, but the variations show the need to treat such indices with caution.

'People must realise these are simply trends,' says the Halifax's Stephen Rothwell. 'A lot of people appeal against their council tax bands and try to use the index figures over the past several years. But we tell them that the figures are only regional, and there are huge differences within each region and sometimes even within a street.'

Keen devotees of the house price indices can see them posted on Internet sites, with regional breakdowns to complement the press stories that normally accompany their release.

Contact:

www.nationwide.co.uk

www.halifaxplc.com

Both companies exclude certain properties from their calculations:  houses costing £1m-plus, most of which are bought without a mortgage  ex-council houses bought for the first time (re-sales are counted)  large, untypical houses (the Halifax, for example, excludes properties with 20 rooms or more)  re-mortgages  any property with a commercial element 'These are only a few per cent of all our mortgages each month, but it is important that we exclude anything which stops the property being regarded as a free-market transaction,' says Stephen Rothwell, a statistician for the Halifax. The Halifax says that during recent busy months up to 20,000 mortgage offers have been made - not far off the 25,000 peaks of the past. Before the recent boom, the index was based on about 12,000 offers a month. The companies break down each property into its constituent parts (for example, the number of toilets) to allow a process called 'standardisation'. This takes into account the fact that properties built at different times will have different facilities - newer properties, for example, have more toilets. These constituent parts are then weighted to allow average price rises to be calculated in a geographical area, irrespective of whether the houses sold were mainly new, old or a mix. The Halifax and Nationwide lists vary slightly, but the main constituent parts are:  purchase price  location - the part of the country, and the perceived status of the area  floor size  property design (eg, detached house, terraced, or bungalow)  tenure  number of bathrooms  type of central heating, if any  number of bedrooms  age of property Figures are also seasonally adjusted according to the time of year when the mortgage offer is made, because prices are slightly higher in the spring and summer irrespective of the overall trend. The Nationwide says June is generally the strongest month for house prices and January the weakest. 'Indices are very much general indicators of what goes on in the market,' says Nationwide group economist Alex Bannister. 'People must look at them for a trend, not to see what's happening to their own property. That would be a bit like looking at the Retail Price Index to work out the price of bread,' he says. Both firms issue national figures each month, covering a range of property sales - for example, all residential properties, or only those bought by first-time buyers, or only those bought by existing owner-occupiers. Regional figures - covering property types, too, such as terraced or semi-detached - are issued each quarter. Even then, some local areas do not feature every quarter if the number of offers made by the company in that area was too few to satisfy rigorous statistical criteria. The dependence on one company making sufficient mortgage offers in any period is seen by some housing industry experts as a weakness in the existing indices. This is particularly true in Northern Ireland, where there is a higher proportion of local independent estate agents than in the rest of the UK. The University of Ulster's Centre for Research on Property and Planning issues a quarterly price index for Northern Ireland based on valuations of properties being sold through about 100 estate agents' offices. The different approach produces dramatically different figures over most quarterly periods, with the University of Ulster figures usually being higher - a result local estate agents, unsurprisingly, prefer. 'I feel it's the most accurate reflection of house price increases in Northern Ireland since it incorporates details of all properties sold by a substantial number of estate agents,' says Gault Ervine, a partner in Ulster Property Sales, which has 13 offices across the province. None of these figures is wrong, but the variations show the need to treat such indices with caution. 'People must realise these are simply trends,' says the Halifax's Stephen Rothwell. 'A lot of people appeal against their council tax bands and try to use the index figures over the past several years. But we tell them that the figures are only regional, and there are huge differences within each region and sometimes even within a street.' Keen devotees of the house price indices can see them posted on Internet sites, with regional breakdowns to complement the press stories that normally accompany their release. Contact: www.nationwide.co.uk www.halifaxplc.com Northern Ireland Quarterly House Price Index, £12.50, University of Ulster

webTitle: Using greenbacks creatively for a dot.com future

fields.headline: Using greenbacks creatively for a dot.com future
fields.standfirst: Bridget and Damon speak to  Margaret Dibben about setting up their business from home
fields.trailText: Vital Statistics
fields.body:
Vital Statistics

BRIDGET FISHLEIGH
Age : 32
Lives in : Brighton
Occupation : Public relations
Earns : Living expenses
Mortgage : £33,000 covered by rent
Debts : £1,000 on credit card
Investments : $30,000 and privatisation shares
Pensions : none
Aims : to build a business and start saving

Bridget Fishleigh and her boyfriend, Damon Crane, met while they were working in New York. She says: 'We clicked from the start but it felt a bit stupid going all the way to America to find each other.'

Damon is 30 and had been in the US for four years as general manager of the American arm of a UK creative agency. Bridget was there for two-and-a-half years, working for a PR agency that specialised in publicity for hi-tech companies. She says ruefully: 'I helped make a lot of people rich.'

Now the couple have returned to the UK to set up their own communications agency, Nomad Communications, which will provide PR and creative services for Internet start-ups and dot. coms in this country. They have settled in Brighton, renting a flat that doubles as their office, and already have two clients. Within a year, they want to buy somewhere, but this depends on finding the right sort of accommodation.

They still like the idea of working from home. Bridget says: 'We are planning to take on a few extra people within the year so need to find a house with suitable space for an office. Plus we would like to plan for a family.'

Bridget already owns property in the UK. She and her sister bought a flat in London in 1992 for £72,000 and it is now worth about £150,000. She has an endowment mortgage on this property, which is rented out.

Bridget has not decided what to do about the flat. 'It seems a bit mad to sell it and take myself off the property-owning ladder,' she says.

While she and Damon were working in the US they managed to save and have $30,000 in American bank accounts. Bridget wants to know what to do with this money.

'We don't mind if we leave the money in the US or bring it back to the UK. We want to get the best bang for our buck as we are not using it at the moment.'

Their only other investments are Bridget's BT and BAA shares, worth about £4,000, which her parents bought for her when the companies floated.

At the moment the couple are taking out of the business only as much as they need for daily living expenses, but are talking to their accountant about how best to structure the business. Now they want to know how to best to invest their money.

Adviser 1: Danielle Leich

Bridget and Damon must declare their United States savings on UK tax returns but they may also need to complete a US tax return, although a double-tax treaty means they will not be taxed twice.

There seems no advantage in keeping the cash in the United States and, if they have no strong thoughts on dollar/pound exchange rates, they could transfer it in several tranches to benefit from different rates. But they should weigh this against bank charges for each transaction.

Assuming they need this money to buy a new property, they should keep it in bank or building accounts for easy access and to keep their capital safe.

If they do not intend using all their cash on a house purchase and are prepared to invest for at least five years, they could consider a stocks and shares Isa - although they need to be sure they are comfortable with the risk involved.

As they work in the volatile area of Internet companies, they may be risk averse, in which case they could choose a cash Isa or Index-Linked National Savings Certificates.

Bridget's mortgage with her sister could restrict her ability to get a good deal from a new lender. She could switch her mortgage to a buy-to-let scheme; the interest payments are higher but she can get a better deal on her next homeloan.

If Bridget lived in the property before moving to the US, she could sell the flat now and avoid capital gains tax by claiming it as her principal residence.

Danielle Leich works for PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

Advisor 2: Neil Bailey

Bridget and Damon should consider the impact of death, disability or serious illness on their business and their personal lives. Competitive providers of insurance include Swiss Life and Scottish Provident.

They should also consider income protection which provides a replacement income in the event of long-term sickness or disability. As they don't have an income track record in the UK, they will need to be careful that they do not over-insure. Friends Provident and UNUM have competitive schemes, the former with guaranteed premium rates.

Bridget should also clarify the ownership of the property she shares with her sister in case of disaster. Many lenders will require at least two years' accounts and about 15 per cent deposit before lending to the self-employed.There are lenders who will provide reasonable terms to self-employed people with less than one year's accounts.

Most of the cash should stay liquid, as a short-term contingency fund. Equity-based investments are not suitable if the cash is needed within five years. They should consider bringing the cash back into the UK, or at least converting it to a sterling account which will not be subject to exchange-rate fluctuations. Accessibility is likely to be more important than a marginally greater interest rate. Consider First-e internet account, or C&G Tracker account if they prefer a traditional type of account.

Neil Bailey is a certified financial adviser with Winslow-based Sensible Financial Planning.

Advice is for guidance only.

Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail:cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Ever fancied having complete control over the minds of others, or forcing people to obey you without saying a word?
fields.body:
Ever fancied having complete control over the minds of others, or forcing people to obey you without saying a word?

According to the London firm Dynamic Publications, the miraculous power of 'Omnipotence' will allow you to do just that. 'You will win respect and admiration. No one will dare oppose you. You will be virtually invincible,' says the firm's mailshot.

It claims that Omnipotence, a mysterious method discovered in a Tibetan temple more than three centuries ago, will enable you to regain the love of people you thought lost, to win the friendship and esteem of influential people, or to get a salary rise - all for £23.99.

'Whatever you want from others - even people you don't know - use Omnipotence. There are no visible actions to perform. Simply express your wishes and people will carry them out. But no one will ever have the slightest idea that it is you dictating their actions.'

The Advertising Standards Authority tried to investigate the firm's ability to substantiate its claims, but Dynamic Publications failed to respond. Perhaps it was trying to use Omnipotence on the ASA. In which case we can confirm that the method does not work. The ASA has told the firm to withdraw the mailing, and has asked the Committee of Advertising Practice to advise its media members not to sell their mailing list to the firm.

Seen an advertisement or mailshot that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch? The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: What goes up ... must come down

fields.headline: What goes up ... must come down
fields.standfirst: Home loans may have to rise again but the fall may now be in sight, reports Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Homeowners without fixed-rate loans should brace themselves for another rise in homeloan costs, but not all economists think it will come this week.
fields.body:
Homeowners without fixed-rate loans should brace themselves for another rise in homeloan costs, but not all economists think it will come this week.

The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee meets on Wednesday to decide whether to raise the bank base rate from 6 per cent. The MPC's decision will be announced on Thursday.

The base rate has already increased from 5 per cent last September and economists believe it will go higher yet but are uncertain whether the next step will come immediately.

Michael Saunders at investment bank Salomon Smith Barney says the strength of the pound, and the latest figures on gross domestic product, released on Friday, have convinced him otherwise. 'I was going for a hike but, with the pound and GDP where they are, I am going for no change.'

Dharshini David at HSBC agrees, although she predicts that rates will peak at 6.5 per cent.

David Brickman at PaineWebber says: 'I'm going for a 0.25 per cent rise but it's pretty close.'

He believes the economy is now slowing down but thinks the monetary authorities may choose to raise rates again 'to get it over and done with'.

Steven Pearson, an economist with the largest mortgage lender, Halifax Bank, is also plumping for a 0.25 percentage point rise.

One of the many factors that the Bank of England will be considering is the outlook on house prices and statistics due out from Halifax and Nationwide this week. Pearson says the market is slowing, but not at the rate the Bank had included in its forecasts of future inflation.

Mortgage adviser Patrick Bunton says activity in the mortgage market has slowed, but he is nevertheless predicting that mortgage rates will rise this week. 'I think we will see a 0.25 per cent rise in base rate and the same on mortgages.'

A rise of 0.25 percentage points would raise the standard variable rate at Halifax, and most other major lenders from 7.74 per cent to a whisker below 8 per cent. For Halifax borrowers this would raise repayments on a £50,000 25-year repayment loan by £8.29 a month to £389.99 a month. On a £100,000 loan, payments would rise by £16.60 to £779.99.

Bunton believes that regardless of what happens this week, people on variable rate loans should be trying to cut costs. Competition in the market remains fierce - 'there is a scrap going on for market share' - and there are attractive deals available at lower than the variable rate.

He does not recommend five-year fixed rates because borrowers could end up paying too much because rates will come down again within that period.

But two-year fixed rates are attractive, and two-year discounts even more so. Staffordshire building society is offering a 2.01 per cent discount, which has a starting rate of 5.49 per cent and there are no early redemption penalties. National Counties has a three-year discount of 1.4 per cent to give a starting rate of 5.79 per cent and there are no redemption penalties after the three years.

Bunton calculates that someone with an £80,000 mortgage paying 7.74 per cent would save £130 a month by switching to the National Counties deal. This works out at almost £4,700 over the three years.

'Anyone paying the variable rate is shredding money.'

Ray Boulger at broker John Charcol says it is difficult to predict the outcome of this week's rate decision by the MPC. 'It's a particularly difficult one to call. My gut feeling is that the rate will go up a quarter of a point but it's not something I want to put money on.'

Even if homeloan costs do go up this week, the good news for home owners is that the end is now in sight for rises.

fields.headline: Talkin' about my generations
fields.standfirst: There are three heroes in István Szabó's epic family saga - and they're all Ralph Fiennes
fields.trailText: Sunshine
fields.body:
Sunshine (179 mins, 15) Directed by István Szabó; starring Ralph Fiennes, Rosemary Harris, Rachel Weisz, Jennifer Ehle, William Hurt

The exodus of German cinematic talent which accompanied the rise of Hitler in the early Thirties was preceded by the less publicised dispersal of Hungarian moviemakers during Béla Kun's short-lived Communist government in 1919 (when the film industry was briefly nationalised) and the right-wing Horthy regime which followed it.

Michael Curtiz departed to become one of Hollywood's most prolific directors; Alexander Korda and his brothers came here to transform the British cinema; the designer Alexander Trauner gave the French cinema a new look; Peter Lorre and Bela Lugosi became iconic exiles.

The Communist government installed in Hungary by the Soviet Union after the Second World War was initially more oppressive, and infinitely longer-lived, than the earlier authoritarian regimes. Yet there was no comparable drainage of talent. Between the early Sixties and the late Eighties, cinéastes working within a state-subsidised industry were allowed to make technically accomplished and imaginative works that, within certain prescribed limits, criticised the system (usually in allegorical form) and raised complex moral issues.

Such gifted directors as Miklós Jancsó and his wife Márta Móros became world famous on the festival and art-house circuit and they were joined by younger moviemakers, among them István Szabó. In the Eighties, Szabó directed Mephisto, Colonel Redl and Hanussen , three remarkable films about the interaction between private lives and public events during middle-Europe's period of cataclysmic political change from the turn of the century to the coming of the Third Reich.

Szabó's trilogy, made in German, is among the major achievements of world cinema, with the great Austrian actor Klaus Maria Brandauer starring in all three. Since then, in a de-nationalised Hungarian cinema abandoned to market forces, which have led to American action pictures dominating the domestic market, his development has been as uncertain as his country's.

Szabó's upbeat excursion into English-speaking Euro-cinema, Meeting Venus (1991), was a near disaster. But the low-budget Sweet Emma, Dear Böbe of the following year, the tale of two young Budapest teachers coping with problems attendant on the new freedom, is one of the best, most humane studies of the way ordinary East Europeans have experienced the collapse of communism.

With Sunshine, his first picture for eight years, Szabó returns to the big canvas and the large themes of our responsibility to ourselves, our families, the community and the state. As in the trilogy, he has a charismatic foreign actor playing three different characters. But here they're from successive generations of the same family, and the period covered is nearly 150 years from the mid-nineteenth century to the fall of communism.

Because of the romantic aura, the marvellous images of Szabó's regular cinematographer, Lajos Koltai, the seductive score by Maurice Jarre and a succession of attractive performances, the picture holds one's attention for three hours. But it's thinner, more contrived and far less compelling than his oblique, complex trilogy.

This is essentially a family saga, nearer in spirit to Herman Wouk than Thomas Mann, telling the story of a Jewish dynasty whose fortunes is founded on a best-selling health tonic called Sonnenschein ('Sunshine'), the secret recipe for which Emmanuel Sonnenschein (David de Keyser) brings to Budapest following the accidental death of his father, a tavern keeper in a small Hungarian village.

His elder son, Ignatz (Ralph Fiennes), becomes a lawyer and in order to become a judge and to be assimilated into the state of the emperor he admires, he changes his name to the more acceptable 'Sors' (Hungarian for destiny). His allegiance to a corrupt empire estranges him from his liberal wife and his left-wing doctor brother, (James Frain). Ignatz's son Adam, (Ralph Fiennes again), goes one further than his father in the Thirties by becoming a Catholic and thus eligible to join the fascistic military fencing club that will allow him to compete at the 1936 Olympics. However, neither converting nor becoming a national sports hero exempts him from the Holocaust.

After the Second World War, Adam's son Ivan, (Fiennes once more), briefly throws in his lot with the vengeful communists until they turn out to be as anti-Semitic as earlier regimes and start purging Zionist conspirators in the party hierarchy.

A hell of a lot of history is crammed into this picture - two world wars, several revolutions and counter revolutions, the collapse of two empires - and Szabó's central thrust is clear, though only up to a point. A liberal tolerance for human diversity is what he believes in. If he's saying that it's wicked to be a chameleon Vicar of Bray figure, fitting in with successive regimes to survive, where does he stand on reasonable compromise? Or is he by implication just endorsing Polonius's advice to Laertes (ie 'This above all; to thine own self be true, and it must follow, as the night the day, thou canst not then be false to any man')?

I'm sure he doesn't intend to imply that because anti-Semitism is ineradicable, Jews must always be self conscious outsiders who deceive themselves if they think they are truly Hungarians or Germans.

There are also problems in the film's patterning. Each time Fiennes arrives on the scene (and the third occasion produced an uneasy laugh from a sympathetic audience), a highly sensual woman virtually throws herself at him and in each generation he's dragged into a transgressive relationship - first with his cousin (Jennifer Ehle), then his brother's sister (Rachel Weisz) and finally, in the Communist era, a secret policeman's wife (Deborah Kara Unger). Is this because he's weak or just plain irresistible?

Then there's the name Sonnenschein. It is, of course, heavily ironic to evoke sunshine throughout a story of dark clouds and storms, yet at the end, when the name is reclaimed in a bright, post-communist Budapest, we're invited to see this as an affirmation. But earlier, in a scene where the past in the form of furniture and personal impedimenta is literally consigned to the dustbin of history, the book containing the secret recipe for the Sonnenschein tonic is thrown away, like the Rosebud sledge at the end of Citizen Kane.

Perhaps the most disturbing aspect of a movie about identity and a nation's historical experience is that Sunshine (which has been financed by Canada, Britain and several Continental countries) is made entirely in English and it doesn't give a major role to a single Hungarian actor.

The Communist government installed in Hungary by the Soviet Union after the Second World War was initially more oppressive, and infinitely longer-lived, than the earlier authoritarian regimes. Between the early Sixties and the late Eighties, cinéastes working within a state-subsidised industry were allowed to make technically accomplished and imaginative works that, within certain prescribed limits, criticised the system (usually in allegorical form) and raised complex moral issues. Such gifted directors as Miklós Jancsó and his wife Márta Móros became world famous on the festival and art-house circuit and they were joined by younger moviemakers, among them István Szabó. In the Eighties, Szabó directed Mephisto, Colonel Redl and Hanussen , three remarkable films about the interaction between private lives and public events during middle-Europe's period of cataclysmic political change from the turn of the century to the coming of the Third Reich. Szabó's trilogy, made in German, is among the major achievements of world cinema, with the great Austrian actor Klaus Maria Brandauer starring in all three. Since then, in a de-nationalised Hungarian cinema abandoned to market forces, which have led to American action pictures dominating the domestic market, his development has been as uncertain as his country's. Szabó's upbeat excursion into English-speaking Euro-cinema, Meeting Venus (1991), was a near disaster. But the low-budget Sweet Emma, Dear Böbe of the following year, the tale of two young Budapest teachers coping with problems attendant on the new freedom, is one of the best, most humane studies of the way ordinary East Europeans have experienced the collapse of communism. With Sunshine, his first picture for eight years, Szabó returns to the big canvas and the large themes of our responsibility to ourselves, our families, the community and the state. As in the trilogy, he has a charismatic foreign actor playing three different characters. But here they're from successive generations of the same family, and the period covered is nearly 150 years from the mid-nineteenth century to the fall of communism. Because of the romantic aura, the marvellous images of Szabó's regular cinematographer, Lajos Koltai, the seductive score by Maurice Jarre and a succession of attractive performances, the picture holds one's attention for three hours. But it's thinner, more contrived and far less compelling than his oblique, complex trilogy. This is essentially a family saga, nearer in spirit to Herman Wouk than Thomas Mann, telling the story of a Jewish dynasty whose fortunes is founded on a best-selling health tonic called Sonnenschein ('Sunshine'), the secret recipe for which Emmanuel Sonnenschein (David de Keyser) brings to Budapest following the accidental death of his father, a tavern keeper in a small Hungarian village. His elder son, Ignatz (Ralph Fiennes), becomes a lawyer and in order to become a judge and to be assimilated into the state of the emperor he admires, he changes his name to the more acceptable 'Sors' (Hungarian for destiny). His allegiance to a corrupt empire estranges him from his liberal wife and his left-wing doctor brother, (James Frain). Ignatz's son Adam, (Ralph Fiennes again), goes one further than his father in the Thirties by becoming a Catholic and thus eligible to join the fascistic military fencing club that will allow him to compete at the 1936 Olympics. However, neither converting nor becoming a national sports hero exempts him from the Holocaust. After the Second World War, Adam's son Ivan, (Fiennes once more), briefly throws in his lot with the vengeful communists until they turn out to be as anti-Semitic as earlier regimes and start purging Zionist conspirators in the party hierarchy. A hell of a lot of history is crammed into this picture - two world wars, several revolutions and counter revolutions, the collapse of two empires - and Szabó's central thrust is clear, though only up to a point. A liberal tolerance for human diversity is what he believes in. If he's saying that it's wicked to be a chameleon Vicar of Bray figure, fitting in with successive regimes to survive, where does he stand on reasonable compromise? Or is he by implication just endorsing Polonius's advice to Laertes (ie 'This above all; to thine own self be true, and it must follow, as the night the day, thou canst not then be false to any man')? I'm sure he doesn't intend to imply that because anti-Semitism is ineradicable, Jews must always be self conscious outsiders who deceive themselves if they think they are truly Hungarians or Germans. There are also problems in the film's patterning. Each time Fiennes arrives on the scene (and the third occasion produced an uneasy laugh from a sympathetic audience), a highly sensual woman virtually throws herself at him and in each generation he's dragged into a transgressive relationship - first with his cousin (Jennifer Ehle), then his brother's sister (Rachel Weisz) and finally, in the Communist era, a secret policeman's wife (Deborah Kara Unger). Is this because he's weak or just plain irresistible? Then there's the name Sonnenschein. It is, of course, heavily ironic to evoke sunshine throughout a story of dark clouds and storms, yet at the end, when the name is reclaimed in a bright, post-communist Budapest, we're invited to see this as an affirmation. But earlier, in a scene where the past in the form of furniture and personal impedimenta is literally consigned to the dustbin of history, the book containing the secret recipe for the Sonnenschein tonic is thrown away, like the Rosebud sledge at the end of Citizen Kane. Perhaps the most disturbing aspect of a movie about identity and a nation's historical experience is that Sunshine (which has been financed by Canada, Britain and several Continental countries) is made entirely in English and it doesn't give a major role to a single Hungarian actor.

webTitle: In space, everyone can hear you scream - with laughter

fields.headline: In space, everyone can hear you scream - with laughter
fields.standfirst: Galaxy Quest parodies Star Trek while Wes Craven tickles the rules of horror movies again. Those directors know that you know, you know
fields.trailText: Scream 3 | Galaxy Quest | Ghost Dog | The Million Dollar Hotel | In All Innocence
fields.body:
Scream 3 (116 mins, 18) Directed by Wes Craven; starring Neve Campbell, Courteney Cox, David Arquette, Parker Posey

Galaxy Quest (102 mins, PG) Directed by Dean Parisot; starring Tim Allen, Sigourney Weaver, Alan Rickman, Tony Shalhoub

Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai (116 mins, 18) Directed by Jim Jarmusch; starring Forest Whitaker, Henry Silva, Cliff Gorman

The Million Dollar Hotel (122 mins, 15) Directed by Wim Wenders; starring Mel Gibson, Jeremy Davies, Milla Jovovich, Jimmy Smits

In All Innocence (100 mins, 15) Directed by Pierre Jolivet; starring Gérard Lanvin, Virginie Ledoyen, Carole Bouquet

The great American critic Robert Warshow wrote that westerns have turned their audiences into connoisseurs who understand the genre's conventions and attend not for novelty but to observe the variations made on them. This week's three films by US directors are all made for this kind of connoisseur.

Wes Craven's Scream 3 completes his trilogy of postmodern, self-referential horror flicks with a rhetorical flourish. The first was about a serial killer loose in a town full of teenage horror buffs. Scream 2 moved on to a university campus stalked by a killer similarly dressed as the Grim Reaper and where everyone understood the rules of sequels. This concluding film takes place in a Hollywood studio headed by Roger Corman where Stab 3, a movie about the events in the original Scream is being made.

People are being killed in the order of the script, only the script is being constantly rewritten. The 'real' people meet the actors impersonating them. The threatened heroine (Neve Campbell) finds herself pursued on a mock-up of her old home rebuilt on a sound-stage. The real Carrie Fisher plays a Carrie Fisher lookalike, who didn't get the role of Princess Leia because she wouldn't sleep with George Lucas and is now a clerk in the studio's archive department.

Then the characters discover they are in the last part of a trilogy, not a sequel, and (as in Godfather III ) the rules change. Though not quite as good as the others, it's funny, clever, scary, with lots of good lines - such as the 'celebrity guard' pulling rank by claiming to have protected Julia Roberts, Salman Rushdie and Posh Spice.

The hilariously funny Galaxy Quest is about a group of superannuated actors, stars of a long defunct Star Trek-style TV series, who spend their time attending conventions organised by their obsessive fan club. Tim Allen is their leader, Alan Rickman is the English thesp who sacrificed his stage career by playing a Spock-like alien, Sigourney Weaver the female interest.

They find a new lease of life when recruited to assist a distant planet that has modelled its ethical system and technology on Galaxy Quest and we have the spectacle of actors playing characters who are mistaken for real people by extraterrestrials. This is a lighthearted variation on Jean Genet's The Balcony (1963) where three clients acting out their fantasies of being a judge, a bishop and a general in a Latin American brothel are forced to act their roles for real during a revolution. The movie is played straight, the observation precise, and the invention sustained to the final credits.

The third knowing movie is Jim Jarmusch's suave underworld thriller Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai starring Forest Whitaker in top form as a hitman who lives by a Zen code (eg, 'Every day without fail he should consider himself dead'), and communicates with clients only through carrier pigeons. He gets on the wrong side of a Mafia family headed by poker-faced Henry Silva (evoking his one real star role as the Mob assassin in cult 1963 thriller Johnny Cool) and must kill or be killed.

The body count is formidable, but it's the quirky bits that stick in the mind - a paperback of Rashomon that changes hands in circular fashion through the film; the gentle, ambling Whitaker's chess-playing friendship with the black, French-speaking owner of an ice-cream van; the hitman distracted by a woodpecker tapping the tree chosen for a stakeout. Ghost Dog has a dry wit and is given a hard, clean surface by cameraman Robby Müller.

Müller made his name for Wim Wenders, whose new movie is rather beautifully lit by Phedon Papamichael, one of the most mellifluous names to appear on a movie since Christopher Isherwood's. But after his return to form with Buena Vista Social Club Wenders has pressed the snooze button with The Million Dollar Hotel.

This aimless affair is some sort of whimsical thriller and though the story is attributed to Nicholas Klein and Bono, it seems more like an extended homage to Shock Corridor, a minor classic by Wenders's mentor Sam Fuller in which a journalist feigns madness to solve a murder committed in an asylum that is clearly an image of America.

Here a mentally disturbed semi-crippled FBI agent (Mel Gibson) investigates the death of a millionaire's son (an uncredited Tim Roth) at a seedy Los Angeles residential hotel inhabited by retards and misfits. Did he jump? Was he pushed? Do we care? The film moves at the pace of the London Eye and is a feast of over-acting. The ripest contribution is from Peter Stormare, sporting a Swedish-Scouse accent, as a musician who claims to have been the fifth Beatle and to have written Sergeant Pepper.

In Claude Autant-Lara's En Cas de Maleur (1958) Brigitte Bardot gave one of her best performances as a teenage thief who seduces middle-aged lawyer Jean Gabin and ruins his life. This Georges Simenon novel has been filmed again by Pierre Jolivet as In All Innocence starring Gérard Lanvin as the attorney, Carole Bouquet as his wife and Virginie Ledoyen as the sex kitten. It's slick, watchable and none too interesting.
