fields.headline: Store banks earn customers' trust
fields.standfirst: Convenience and a strong brand name fuel steady growth, says  Sarah Cunningham
fields.trailText: Despite recent criticism being aimed at their industry as a whole, the supermarket banks have continued to thrive.
fields.body:
Both supermarkets and banks have had a torrid time of it in the past couple of years. The industries have stood accused of being part of 'rip-off Britain', of taking customers for granted and abusing their power in the marketplace. Strangely enough, the supermarket banks, who you might think would suffer doubly under this onslaught of disapproval, have managed to get on quietly with growing their businesses during this turbulent period.

Following the fanfare that greeted the launch of Sainsbury's Bank and Tesco Financial Services in 1997, along with the other partnerships established between the likes of Safeway and Abbey National, they have been steadily increasing their customers and the number of products they offer.

Their growth has not been enough to pose a serious threat to the old established banking order, and in the past year or so it has been overshadowed by the burgeoning of Internet banks. But the partnerships formed between supermarkets and banks have survived, and they have begun to make profits.

With Internet banks, such as the Prudential's Egg and Co-operative Bank's Smile, sharply increasing competition, Tesco, Sainsbury's and Marks & Spencer are all moving as quickly as they are able into this arena. M&S is already offering preferential rates for those applying online for loans, while Tesco says it may offer some Internet-only products and rates, although it is wary of upsetting the bulk of its customers, who rely on the stores and the telephone to deal with their finances. Sainsbury's Bank is in the process of revamping its website and plans to cater for transactions online from this summer. Customers will be able to view their own account, apply for mortgages and carry out other banking chores via the Internet.

The initial move by food retailers into banking was only superficially surprising. Supermarkets had long been in financial services through their loyalty card schemes, and Tesco and Sainsbury had the successful example of Marks & Spencer Financial Services to follow. Throughout the travails of that once-revered retailer, its financial services arm has consistently performed well.

The attraction of supermarket banks is that they seem a little bit different from the traditional banks but offer the reassurance of a strong brand name, and they are convenient. Most of us have to go to the supermarket regularly anyway, so might as well make it a doubly useful trip. 'Our products may not always have the best rates, but we are convenient,' Fay Hogg of Tesco Personal Finance says. But as with the new Internet banking operations, the supermarket banks have low overheads and so can generally be competitive, with low customer charges. 'We are seen as one of the good guys because we don't have big networks to support, we don't go in for a lot of advertising, and people trust the brand,' she says.

M&S, which operates independently without input from any of the traditional banks, still offers the widest range of financial products, from pensions to personal loans. Tesco, which formed a partnership with Royal Bank of Scotland, has concentrated on insurance and loans, but announced last week that it was entering the mortgage market for the first time with the launch next month of an online 'mortgage supermarket' in partnership with John Charcol, the mortgage adviser. The service will offer a market-wide mortgage search, selection and on-line application service. While it is stopping short of selling own-brand mortgages, like Sainsbury's Bank, it will include some Tesco 'Special' mortgages - deals with some major mortgage lenders only available through the Tesco Internet site.

At Sainsbury's, whose bank is run as a joint venture with Bank of Scotland, the emphasis has been on savings and mortgages for the past couple of years.

Even the supermarkets that do not do banking under their own name are keen to form partnerships with banks.

Waitrose, the supermarket arm of the John Lewis Partnership, is the latest to join the move into financial services. It is trialling in-store branches of HSBC, which is running a similar scheme with Yorkshire-based supermarket group William Morrison. A pilot branch has been opened at the Waitrose in Twyford, Berkshire. It has a full range of banking facilities, including a private meeting room and cash withdrawal machines. Safeway is introducing branches of Abbey National into its stores, and sells a limited range of products which are managed by Abbey National but come under the Safeway brand.

Views on whether supermarket customers want to have a bank branch to hand are mixed. Sainsbury's Bank has this year begun testing personal banking branches at 10 of its supermarkets across the UK. According to Graham McCarte, director of product development, these are different to anything tried before. They are mini-branches, just 150 ft square, with two people staffing them at any one time. 'Customers like them,' he said.

With the traditional banks, notably Barclays, under fire for closing rural branches, this could be a smart move. But Tesco Personal Finance decided to scrap a personal banking trial at 12 supermarkets last year because they were not generating enough new business.

Whether we want a branch on site or not, most of us are likely to turn to our supermarkets for one important financial service - withdrawing cash.

The popularity of withdrawing up to £50 a time when we pay for our shopping has increased by up to a quarter since the banks plans to levy inflated charges at cash machines became public.

Supermarkets, which are home to thousands of ATMs, have seen a surge in cashback withdrawals - which are expected to top £6 billion this year. Understandably, with the service becoming increasingly popular, the supermarkets are keen to increase the amount that can be taken out at a time to £100, and they expect to persuade the banks to agree to the increase soon. Pubs and bars have also started offering cashback to customers keen to avoid bank charges.

So whether we find bank branches in our supermarkets or not, we will probably be able to withdraw more money when we do our shopping. What else can we expect?

The arrival at Sainsbury's of Sir Peter Davis as chief executive, hot from the Prudential and the success of the Egg Internet bank, should bode well for Sainsbury's banking arm. With the supermarket suffering from profound trading problems, the bank, which has moved into profit, is probably a low priority on his list - but it is hard to see him resisting for long the temptation to develop new ideas for financial services.

At Safeway another new broom, Carlos Criado-Perez, is also busy tackling some core problems with the food retailing side, so the banking joint venture with Abbey National is, again, a rather low priority for the company.

Asda, now part of Wal-Mart, the largest retailer in the world, has never made any move into banking, even scrapping its loyalty card trial scheme last year. Although it leases space to some small branches of Lloyds TSB within its larger stores, it has always prided itself on concentrating on its retailing businesses. 'We prefer to leave banking to the bankers,' a spokesman said.

However, Wal-Mart has recently bought a banking business in the US, and although the UK business is still largely autonomous, it could take the view that banking should be part of the activity of its British outpost in the longer term.

Tesco, the undisputed market leader in food retailing, is the most aggressive of the supermarkets in moving into the new and competitive world of Internet banking. It plans to offer online quotes for home, motor and travel insurance by June, is moving into mortgages and already processes loan applications over the Internet.

All of the supermarket banks are clearly aware that they risk allowing Internet-only operations to steal their thunder and their customers, but they are caught in something of a bind. 'We want to compete with the Internet banks, but not exclude anyone,' Tesco Personal Finance's Fay Hogg says.

But with many of the traditional banks upsetting their customers by closing branches and charging apparently unjustifiable amounts for withdrawing cash from each others' machines, the supermarket banks want to make sure that, whatever difficulties their supermarket and banking owners may face, they remain in consumers' good books.

webTitle: Tasty Visa rates to check out at Tesco

fields.headline: Tasty Visa rates to check out at Tesco
fields.trailText: Tesco Personal Finance, a joint venture between the supermarket and Royal Bank of Scotland, now has more than 1.5 million customers and has moved into month-by-month profit. Its stated aim is to offer value for money, convenience, simplicity and quality customer service.
fields.body:
Tesco Personal Finance, a joint venture between the supermarket and Royal Bank of Scotland, now has more than 1.5 million customers and has moved into month-by-month profit. Its stated aim is to offer value for money, convenience, simplicity and quality customer service. From next month there will be an Internet mortgage supermarket, available in conjunction with broker John Charcol through the Net.

At present, through the chain of 650 stores in the UK, Tesco provides information leaflets and a free phone inquiry service. There are also more than 290 Tesco Personal Finance ATMs in stores throughout the country. The company is considering launching a banking service in the Republic of Ireland, where it also has stores. Customers can pay money into Tesco savings accounts through any of the normal routes, and at Tesco checkouts. fields.headline: Standard Life in City clash
fields.standfirst: Barclays warned off backing Monaco carpetbagger  Friends Provident in auction threat
fields.trailText: Standard Life has warned Barclays that it stands to lose hundreds of millions of pounds of business if the bank backs carpetbaggers who are trying to force the insurer to demutualise.
fields.body:
Standard Life has warned Barclays that it stands to lose hundreds of millions of pounds of business if the bank backs carpetbaggers who are trying to force the insurer to demutualise.

The threat has also been made to City investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. Both banks carry out huge amounts of lucrative share, bond and treasury dealing for Standard Life's £80 billion investment funds.

Europe's biggest mutual insurer, which is worth up to £20bn, is under attack from Monaco-based investor Fred Woollard, who is promising windfalls of £6,000 for policyholders. He is supported by three Barclays-managed investment trusts, which hold £17 million of Standard Life policies. DKB - the biggest, with £45m of policies - is planning to meet the insurer this week.

Standard Life's aggressive response comes as fellow Scottish insurer Friends Provident also faces a challenge. Friends Provident insiders indicated that it would put itself up for auction rather than float, if the challenge succeeds. Likely bidders include Halifax, Abbey National or Prudential and European rivals Allianz and Aegon.

'Are we to get the opportunity to carry forward our mutuality or should we be more proactive and consider the alternatives?' Friends Provident director Brian Sweetland said. Friends Provident is still waiting for a valid resolution, which it would put to its annual meeting on 31 May. Standard Life members, meanwhile, will now vote on its future on 27 June.

The Standard Life dispute has echoes of a carpetbaggers' bid for the Co-op three years ago. Then, the Co-op used its banking and pension fund clout to warn off City backers.

This weekend, a worried Barclays furiously denied any corporate support for Woollard. It has asked the trusts, the BGI Endowment Funds, to change their names to emphasise the fact that they are advised by - but not actually part of - Barclays Global Investors (BGI), its fund management arm.

The Observer has established, however, that Dan Nathanson, their manager at Barclays, advised the trusts of Woollard's respectability before they agreed to give him their support a week ago.

'The people at Barclays met him. They gave him a clean bill of health. The advice is included in the board papers,' the trusts' chairman Paul Seymour said.

Woollard, 37, has admitted he stands to make around £150,000 from windfalls if Standard Life demutualises. City experts, however, suspect he and his offshore associates stand to gain far more to make his expensive campaign worthwhile.

Woollard is closely associated with Australian corporate raider Danny Hill, another Monaco resident, who made a fortune out of the 1998 demutualisation of AMP, the Australian group which owns Pearl Assurance.

This weekend Woollard said he had nothing to fear from aggressive tactics. 'We've been very careful to do this properly, by the book,' he said. 'If they try to find evidence that I've bribed employees or done anything stupid, they won't. I'm clean.'

He also said: 'I have absolutely no intention of doing anything with any other mutual life company.'

fields.headline: M&S branches out with 'clean' pensions
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is not strictly a supermarket bank, as M&S is not strictly a supermarket. But the stores offer both food and banking, so it should be included. It was first into the field, and is now the only one to run an independent financial services operation with no link to a traditional bank.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is not strictly a supermarket bank, as M&S is not strictly a supermarket. But the stores offer both food and banking, so it should be included. It was first into the field, and is now the only one to run an independent financial services operation with no link to a traditional bank.

M&S has been brilliant at exploiting its trusted brand name. The success of M&S's financial services operation has been based on its Chargecard, held by more than six million customers. For regular customers, the card was virtually de rigueur, as the stores have only just begun accepting credit cards. Its APR of 18.9 per cent makes it one of the more acceptable store cards (others charge up to 31.9 per cent).

The company has used its cardholder database to make inroads into other areas. For example, cardholders can get preferential personal loan rates. M&S will lend from £500 to £20,000, repayable over one to seven years. The standard rates are pretty high, however, ranging from 17.7 per cent to 9.8 per cent. Special rates, as low as 8.9 per cent, apply to Internet applications.

Other financial products include life assurance, with critical illness cover and an 'over 50s guaranteed protection plan' with contributions as little as £10 a month. M&S also offers a pension which passes the 'clean' tests set by financial advisers Chartwell - meaning that it's reasonably low-cost and flexible.

M&S offers mini and maxi Isas. The mini Isa is in stocks and shares, the maxi Isa is in cash and stocks and shares. The current rate of interest payable on the cash element is 6.09 per cent. From this autumn, M&S will provide home and contents insurance.

M&S Financial Services: 0800 38999 11/ 38999 55 or www.marks-and-spencer.co.uk

webTitle: New BA chief could free Go

fields.headline: New BA chief could free Go
fields.trailText: New British Airways chief executive Rod Eddington is considering spinning off low-cost airline Go so that it can raise its own funds for expansion.
fields.body:
New British Airways chief executive Rod Eddington is considering spinning off low-cost airline Go so that it can raise its own funds for expansion.

Eddington takes up the reins at BA tomorrow and faces the immediate task, in the wake of Bob Ayling's sacking, of stemming £250 million losses and restoring battered staff morale.

Up to 8,000 jobs were earmarked for the axe last year and a host of loss-making European routes face closure. BA's 60,000 staff are waiting to see if Eddington will carry these plans forward and what other strategic moves will follow his arrival hotfoot from turning around Australian regional airline Ansett.

Air talks between the UK and US resume in June, with the future of BA's alliance with American Airlines and access to Heathrow for carriers such as British Midland in the balance.

Airline sources said Eddington would be fully taken up with dealing with these fundamental issues upon his arrival.

But the future of Stansted-based Go is likely to attract his attention fairly rapidly. Barbara Cassani, chief executive of the low-cost subsidiary, hinted this weekend that a breakaway would be supported by Go.

Such a move could take the form of a flotation or the sale of a stake to a venture capital group or, less likely, another airline.

She said several external approaches had already been made to invest in Go.

'I take it as a compliment. We have created value. That is something that Rod will be keeping in mind as he looks at the strategic fit of Go into everything else that is going on at the airline. Our future is in our hands. It is our job to deliver the results - to break even.'

Cassani said Go was 'on track' for a pre-tax break-even by 31 March 2001. It is expected to announce losses for 1999-2000 of more than £10m.

Cassani is likely to propose buying more aircraft and establishing a second base on the Continent.

fields.headline: Lastminute faces namesake rival
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Just when things began to look up for Lastminute.com a rival has come along bearing a similar name and an even more familiar business plan.
fields.body:
Just when things began to look up for Lastminute.com a rival has come along bearing a similar name and an even more familiar business plan.

US Internet firm LastMinuteTravel.com is gearing up for a UK launch which will put it into direct competition with its near namesake.

The Atlanta-based company, formed in 1997, has links with more than 600 travel and leisure firms including the Bass, Hilton and Sheraton hotel chains as well as 25 airlines.

Both firms look to sell excess inventory - everything from holidays to theatre tickets - over the Internet. Both argue this means cheaper prices for consumers. Both say they have global expansion ambitions. The companies' websites have similarities as well.

However, the US company also offers a personalised service - something the UK firm is looking to introduce. Registered users are sent an e-mail when requested deals become available. LastMinuteTravel.com's UK subsidiary is expected to be up and running by the end of July.

The threat of competition is likely to alarm Lastminute's investors who have seen the company's value cut in half since it floated last month. The business is now worth around £225 million. However, last week the company's share price started to rise following positive comments from analysts. Both Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, who oversaw the company's float, and Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette have issued buy ratings for the stock in the last couple of weeks.

News of LastMinuteTravel.com's entrance into the UK market comes as another online seller, the First Resort (which is 30 per cent owned by tour operator Thomson Travel Group) looks to put 13 million package holidays - around 90 per cent of the UK annual total - on the Internet.

The First Resort pledges to sell holidays at below the prices listed in travel agents' brochures.

The UK firm argues that because it has first mover advantage it has six months head start on its rivals. Since its launch in October 1998 the company has built up a customer base of more than 1 million users, around 5 per cent of whom have bought something from the firm.

The flotation of Last minute.com, which reports its first set of interim results later this week, made paper millionaires of its founders, Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox.

fields.headline: Off-beat mortgages from Sainsbury's
fields.trailText: Sainsbury's Bank might not offer the lowest rates, but their mortgages are more flexible than average, allowing customers to adapt their payments to suit their needs.
fields.body:
Sainsbury's Bank is owned 55 per cent by J Sainsbury and 45 per cent by Bank of Scotland. Its stated aim is to offer exceptional customer service, value for money and 'flexibility other banks have failed to deliver'. It has more than 1 million customer accounts with deposits of over £1.7 billion.

Ahead of Tesco, by a whisker, into the field of banking, Sainsbury's Bank has a broad range of products, with an emphasis on mortgages and savings.

The bank specialises in slightly off-beat mortgage products. They do not offer the lowest rates, but they are more flexible than average. They include an options mortgage which offers variable rates and allows customers to adapt their payments to suit their needs. This can mean paying over 10 months rather than 12, taking a 6-month break from repayments, or paying off more each month to reduce the cost of the loan, all with no penalty. Also, after three months, customers are able to take a further advance of 5 per cent of the value of the property, using an options mortgage personal cheque book. Savings can also be paid into the mortgage account, thus avoiding tax.

Sainsbury's also does a fixed-rate mortgage (7.39 per cent for three or five years), with no lock-ins beyond the fixed rate period. It also does a hybrid fixed/variable rate, which allows customers to fix up to 50 per cent of borrowings for up to three years, and still benefit from the flexibility of the options mortgage. The variable rate is currently 6.95 per cent. There is also a discount variation, which combines the options mortgage with a 1 per cent discount for the first six months.

Sainsbury's also has a 'buy to let' mortgage, which allows customers to buy up to five properties for rental with a 30 per cent deposit for each. The maximum total borrowing is £350,000 with an arrangement fee of £250 per loan. The current rate of 7.50 per cent is one of the best.

Savings products include an instant access savings account. It pays 4.85 per cent on £1-£2,499; 5.10 per cent on £2,500-£9,999, 5.25 per cent on £10,000-£24,999 and 5.60 per cent on balances over £25,000.The rates are competitive with many building societies and banks, and similar to those paid by Tesco. But an Egg savings account will currently pay 6.30 per cent for any amount.

Sainsbury's PetCare insurance costs £8.99 per month for dogs and £6.99 for cats. Other new products include a personal contract purchase car scheme.

Personal loans have not particularly enticing interest rates of 16.5 per cent APR for £1,000 to £2,999, 13.9 per cent for £3,000 to £4,999, 10.9 per cent for £5,000 to £9,999 and 9.9 per cent for £10,000 to £15,000.

Sainsbury's Classic Visa and Visa Gold credit cards offer double Reward points for every £1 spent in Sainsbury's stores and one point for each £1 spent at other retailers. The Classic Visa card has an APR of 20.9 per cent for purchases while the Visa Gold is 17.7 per cent. Smile, the Co-operative Bank's internet banking arm, is charging 12.9 per cent, while Egg's rate is 10.9 per cent.

Sainsbury's Bank: 0500 405060 or www.sainsbury'sbank.co.uk

fields.headline: Saving with Safeway
fields.trailText: Safeway has been low-key by comparison with J Sainsbury and Tesco. It has not launched a separate, branded and licenced bank, but instead has formed a partnership with Abbey National that allows it to sell some financial products with the Safeway name.
fields.body:
Safeway has been low-key by comparison with J Sainsbury and Tesco. It has not launched a separate, branded and licenced bank, but instead has formed a partnership with Abbey National that allows it to sell some financial products with the Safeway name.

The two launched the Safeway Direct Savings Account in January 1998. The minimum opening balance is £50 and the account is operated over the telephone. Interest rates are tiered (£1+ at 0.45per cent, £50+ at 1.90per cent, £500+ at 5.00per cent, £1,000+ at 5.50per cent, £2,500+ at 5.60per cent and £10,000+ at 5.90per cent), and there are no limits on the number of withdrawals/transactions. The rates are considerably less attractive than those offered by the other supermarkets. Offering rather more enticing rates is the Safeway mini cash Isa, launched in March last year, which has a minimum opening balance of £10, also operated by telephone. It carries the CAT standard. The interest rates are £10+ at 6.00per cent, £1,000+ at 6.15per cent and £3,000 at 6.65per cent.

Safeway: 0800 995 995

It has not launched a separate, branded and licenced bank, but instead has formed a partnership with Abbey National that allows it to sell some financial products with the Safeway name. Interest rates are tiered (£1+ at 0.45per cent, £50+ at 1.90per cent, £500+ at 5.00per cent, £1,000+ at 5.50per cent, £2,500+ at 5.60per cent and £10,000+ at 5.90per cent), and there are no limits on the number of withdrawals/transactions. The rates are considerably less attractive than those offered by the other supermarkets. Offering rather more enticing rates is the Safeway mini cash Isa, launched in March last year, which has a minimum opening balance of £10, also operated by telephone. It carries the CAT standard. The interest rates are £10+ at 6.00per cent, £1,000+ at 6.15per cent and £3,000 at 6.65per cent. Safeway: 0800 995 995

fields.headline: Windfall fever returns
fields.standfirst: Existing investors could benefit, says Maria Scott,  but it is too late to take the plunge now in pursuit of a payout
fields.trailText: Windfall fever is raging again. The news last week that Standard Life will ask policyholders to decide whether to convert to a public company, has ignited interest in potential bonuses from this and other remaining mutual insurers.
fields.body:
Windfall fever is raging again. The news last week that Standard Life will ask policyholders to decide whether to convert to a public company, has ignited interest in potential bonuses from this and other remaining mutual insurers. Further interest was generated by news that Friends Provident may face a proposal for demutualisation.

For the most part, however, people who do not already have a stake in one of the mutuals that could convert have left it too late. The cost of investing is unlikely to be bettered by any potential payouts, according to Patrick Connolly of Chartwell Investment Management. 'Lots of people are asking how they can get into Standard Life. The answer is that they can't.'

Since February, when the insurer's mutuality was first challenged, anyone taking a new with-profits policy - the type most likely to qualify for bonuses - has been asked to sign a declaration forgoing windfall bonuses for the next three years.

Among other insurers thought likely to convert, Scottish Provident is already asking new investors to waive their rights to bonuses following its recent announcement that it is conducting a review of its status.

A pressure group is calling for 100 members of Friends Provident to support a demutualisation resolution through a website at www.fpvote.co.uk and the insurer says that it will consider any proposal.

The minimum monthly investment at Friends Provident is now £35 a month, or £3,000 for a lump sum. Endowments should normally be held for 10 years to qualify for tax relief; these costs are unlikely to be outshone by any windfall, says Connolly.

Another insurer thought likely eventually to convert is Scottish Life, which now requires a minimum monthly investment of £50.

Helen Langton, marketing manager of Neville James, a firm that deals in secondhand endowments, points out that the largest windfalls are likely to go to policyholders who have held their investments for some time.

There is uncertainty over how many owners of secondhand policies will receive bonuses. Standard Life says that windfalls - if, indeed there is a conversion - will go only to those who were registered as members on 10 February. Advisers in the secondhand market believe that many owners of such policies will not have realised the significance of registering membership.

Standard Life has 2.3 million with-profit policyholders, who are most likely to receive windfalls in a demutualisation.

Fred Woollard, who is heading the conversion campaign, estimates payouts could average £6,000, assuming Standard Life has a stock market valuation of £15bn. Some larger investors may receive substantially more and Woollard himself stands to make £150,000.

If Standard Life members vote for conversion and the board decides on a stock market flotation, with-profits policyholders are likely to be paid windfalls in free shares.

Investors in other types of investments - including mortgages and savings customers with Standard Life Bank - would not benefit, nor would they have a vote on the proposal.

Woollard, a former fund manager, made his first assault on Standard Life in February, but the board was advised by its lawyers that the proposal was not legally valid. He renewed his assault last week, presenting a proposal backed by 109 signatures. The board has been advised that this new proposal is valid and must be put to a vote. It has called a special meeting for 27 June.

The management will be mounting a high-profile campaign aimed at persuading members to vote in favour of remaining mutual. Standard Life has a formidable reputation as a top-paying provider of with-profit policies. It regularly features in top-ten league tables for the performance of its endowment policies.

Langton says: 'The returns on 25-year policies maturing in 1999 were 13 to 14 per cent, which is fantastic.'

The management will argue that the lack of any obligation to pay dividends to shareholders will continue to enhance its ability to reward policyholders. Policyholders will have to make judgments about whether future returns will be as good as they have been in the past if they are competing with shareholders for a share of the earnings.

The experience of building societies which have converted has been mixed.

Most now have mortgage rates that are higher than those of the remaining societies and although some have continued to offer attractive savings rates, this is not the case across the board. Langton is confident Standard Life would remain a strong performer and Connolly at Chartwell agrees.

Woollard and his supporters have their own website, www.slmag.co.uk, while the insurers' own website is www.standardlife.com.

webTitle: The brand is dead, long live choice

fields.headline: The brand is dead, long live choice
fields.standfirst:
To keep customers you have to offer a total goodness package, says Robert Heller
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Managers and management gurus have all agreed on one sovereign point: that in a world of intense and growing competition, Brand is King.
fields.body:
Managers and management gurus have all agreed on one sovereign point: that in a world of intense and growing competition, Brand is King. During the Nineties, the world's great brands duly grew enormously in value - for example, Coca-Cola's super-brand swelled to an apparent worth of $150 billion - the difference between its assets and its $169 billion market capitalisation.

But the mighty are fallen indeed. Before the Easter gyrations on Wall Street, Coke had lost $62 billion of fizz, or 37 per cent in value. Another great brand, Gillette, fared even worse. Its capitalisation collapsed by half to $32 billion. The two downgraded companies have one other thing in common - both are core holdings of the world's master investor, the Sage of Omaha, multi-billionaire Warren Buffett.

Both firms fit perfectly into Buffet's investment formula. He likes to invest Berkshire Hathaway's billions in worldwide brands which enjoy dominant shares of markets whose continued growth can be expected.

Both companies have crashed into severe management problems after the loss of chief executives. To that extent, the setbacks may be temporary. But these are by no means the only troubled global brands. Is the Buffett formula fading - or even failing? The Brand-is-King theory always had an element of paradox, since consumer tastes in the Nineties, far from being committed to one brand, have steadily fragmented. Consumer power, too, was plainly on the increase.

The New Millennium has tightened the screws. Consumers are continuing to gain power while the unluckier household names are struggling with eroding brands. Some of the erosion reflects the very competition that the 'power brand' is supposed to surmount. But other, more insidious forces are at work. They include the momentous events in cyberspace. None of the e-retailers is especially large in sales, but combined they are moving enough goods to skim some cream off bricks-and-mortar profits. It only takes a 10 per cent shift in trade to push many stores into loss.

Whatever the reason, the High Street brands - such as Marks & Spencer, Somerfield and Arcadia - have been in deep trouble. But such travails need not mean that the brand is dying. It may merely be misunderstood, and consequently mismanaged.

Focusing on the product brand is too narrow a concept. The true brand is the sum total of the perceptions of all the constituencies which contribute to revenues and profits.

Among other insults to its constituents, Coke's now axed CEO Doug Ivester, alienated his powerful bottlers with extortionate price rises for syrup. That one of the affronted bottlers actually has the son of Coke's biggest investor, the even more powerful Buffett, on its board, adds stupidity to injury.

As for M&S, among many and varied failings, it alienated its middle-class shoppers with falling quality. Its subsequent reforms have driven home the point about the total brand. St. Michael, while dearly beloved by the Marksists themselves, was never really a brand. That honour went to Marks & Spencer, or Marks & Sparks, which has now been brought to the fore. The future hinges on whether management can restore the stores to their old reputation as places where high quality and excellent service provide high Value for Money - VFM, rather than absolute price being the critical factor.

Research shows conclusively that customers desert even the strongest brand if prices rise above the perceived value. Loss of customer support is bound to be devastating. But you can't afford to lose support anywhere in a climate of rapidly proliferating alternatives.

Employees, for example, are the visible face of the brand. The suppliers are its prime agents of quality - squeeze their prices or unceremoniously dump them and, as M&S has found, there is trouble in store. Nor can you ignore the opinion-formers, who can rapidly undermine any image.

But even if brands are collectively losing power, their continuing high value in the marketplace is a reality. Killing a brand is much harder than killing a company. Who remembers the British Motor Corporation, or British Leyland, or Austin-Morris? Yet just one brand rescued from these hulks, MG, emerged from decades of neglect as the core of Alchemy's controversial plans for the Rover Group.

The Internet entrepreneurs know all about the permanence of brand value. Their massive marketing spends are intended to reinforce 'word of mouse' and 'share of mind' - brand strength. The theory is that, if you capture the mouse clicks and the customer recognition early on, no competitor will break your grip on the market. In this view, what Microsoft did to Netscape's hold is an exception, impossible without equal monopoly power. The theory sounds convincing - but it cannot be fully tested in a still immature Internet marketplace .

The Net giants may also face brand problems, which could prove more important in the long run than the bursting of their stock market bubbles. America OnLine, Amazon and e-Bay are very vulnerable to competition, as AOL found when confronting free internet service providers. Competitors do not need to attack on a broad front. They can pick off succulent sectors, gaining customers who have already been made internet-friendly by the big brands.

Brands are never safe unless there is compelling reason for customers to buy from you and nobody else - look what happened to IBM. It lost 70 per cent of its market share once corporate buyers realised that they could buy perfectly good alternatives without risk. The essence of today's marketplace is that perfectly good alternatives exist for everything - even Coke. The total brand is only as good as the total company that owns it. Total goodness is the true King.

webTitle: Can I win justice over unfair discipline?

fields.headline: Can I win justice over unfair discipline?
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: I was recently disciplined in a farcical and unfair process, told by my manager that the issue would be hushed up then transferred to another branch of the bank I work at. My responsibilities are lower but my pay is the same. This is just one example of the bullying by senior managers here. What can I do without damaging my job prospects?
fields.body:
I was recently disciplined in a farcical and unfair process, told by my manager that the issue would be hushed up then transferred to another branch of the bank I work at. My responsibilities are lower but my pay is the same. This is just one example of the bullying by senior managers here. What can I do without damaging my job prospects?

You have few legal remedies if you want to preserve your job prospects. You can have an informal chat with your personnel department. They may decide to keep an eye on your branch. But you have to be careful. Most large banks have measures set up to deal with grievances. You could be swept down one of these routes.

You could consider registering a grievance if you are confident that nothing bad will come out about you (that the disciplinary procedure against you was completely ill-founded ).

There is no legal way of lodging a claim against bullying. The closest you get is a claim of discrimination on race, sex or disability grounds. Or - if your health is suffering - you can make an allegation under the Health & Safety legislation.

Alternatively, you could leave the bank and claim constructive dismissal - but these cases are notoriously hard to win.

 Legal advice this week from Lewis Silkin

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

webTitle: A political ally in the strong pound

fields.headline: A political ally in the strong pound
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pop quiz: you are a member of the Monetary Policy Committee meeting this week to set interest rates. Rover is closing, the pound is stronger than Ken Livingstone's mayoral lead, earnings are on the up and Gordon Brown is growling about the evils of wage inflation. What do you do?
fields.body:
Pop quiz: you are a member of the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting this week to set interest rates. Rover is closing, the pound is stronger than Ken Livingstone's mayoral lead, earnings are on the up and Gordon Brown is growling about the evils of wage inflation. What do you do?

As the MPC has no remit to consider exchange rate targets, it has to ignore the existence of the high pound and focus on the immediate problems. Brown's broadside to employers yesterday, warning them that if they consistently award inflation-busting pay rises to workers they will have to put up with higher interest rates, is a statement of the obvious. Let's face it, in Wilson, Callaghan, Healey, there are plenty of precedents of dire Government warnings on the same issue having absolutely no impact at all.

But earnings figures point to the peril of raised inflation, and therefore to expect a quarter per cent rise this month followed by a further quarter per cent rise next month would now appear to be the evens bet for what will happen. Industry will be profoundly unhappy, but then it would also be profoundly unhappy at a rise in inflation. The expectation is for interest rates to peak around 6.5 per cent.

But what, then, about the strong pound problem?

Well, it depends what you mean by 'problem'. Underneath the Government's insistence that it cannot - at any price - intervene in the foreign exchange markets to prop up the pound is a horrible truth which it does not want telling. The suspicion is that, in fact, the Government does not care about the strong pound, in fact it is rather pleased about it. Why? Because the death rate inflicted by sterling's buoyancy is largely among the two highly diverse lobbies of manufacturing and agriculture. In the case of the former they will probably but reluctantly remain Labour voters - after all, it's not as though William Hague and Sebastian Coe are advocating Government support for loss-making industries - and in the latter case Labour has calculated that it won't get their votes whatever. Welcome to the political economy.

The Care Blair Bunch which doles out tea and sympathy to the workers at Longbridge doesn't intend to dispense anything else. A recent delegation to 10 Downing Street by the motor manufacturers yielded nothing from Blair at all, hence the 'going public' by Nissan, Toyota and Peugeot on their imminent economies prompted by the sorry sterling situation. And as for agriculture, Blair does not expect their votes in the first place and the greater public support his lack of concern for the legion of bankruptcies and redundancies among those who toil in the soil.

What the Government really cares about is the other 80 per cent of the population. The population which can buy a round of lagers at a Malaga golf course, hire a 4x4 to zoom round the Kenny Noye Tourist Trail and still have change from a fiver. It's the 80 per cent of the population which can go on a booze cruise to Calais and come back with enough claret to drown half the population of Islington, and the 80 per cent who, while oddly sentimental about Rover, are absolutely chuffed as nuts to discover that the price of a new BMW or Volkswagen or Sony hi-fi has dropped by 20 per cent. These are the people Blair, Brown, the cabinet and the front and back benches really care about, because it is they who will vote New Labour in for a second term.

For the Government, the prospect of the cure for a strong currency is distinctly worse than the disease itself. The insistence that entering the market to splash out mobile phone money on buying euros to douse down sterling is tantamount to taking taxpayers' money into a casino is patent nonsense, as is the weak assertion that intervention never works. If the Government actually wanted to do anything about the strong pound it would. But it doesn't. And this is why when interest rates rise again this week there will be an embarrassed sideways glance at the pound, but no action.

fields.headline: Great oaks from little acorns...
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Standard life was founded in 1825 as the Life Insurance Company of Scotland, a commercial enterprise with a political raison d'etre. Edinburgh's financial community was dominated then by Tories, led by the Dundas family. The Whigs set about breaking this stranglehold by setting up financial institutions such as Standard Life to serve the new businesses of reform-minded entrepreneurs in the late Industrial Revolution.
fields.body:
Standard life was founded in 1825 as the Life Insurance Company of Scotland, a commercial enterprise with a political raison d'etre. Edinburgh's financial community was dominated then by Tories, led by the Dundas family. The Whigs set about breaking this stranglehold by setting up financial institutions such as Standard Life to serve the new businesses of reform-minded entrepreneurs in the late Industrial Revolution.

From tiny beginnings, insuring and making loans to engineering and textile companies, Standard Life (its name from 1832) is Europe's largest mutual insurance company, with annual income of £15bn, profits after tax of £1.7bn and assets of £80bn belonging to its 5 million life and pensions policyholders.

The firm became a mutual only in 1925, under its fourth manager, Steuart Edye Macnaghten, to provide better returns to policyholders. Macnaghten succeeded Leonard Dickson, hero of Standard Life's history, killed by a runaway horse in 1919. In 15 years Dickson rescued Standard Life after reckless expansion and ill-judged loans to foreign railways and struggling Scottish aristocrats.

By the First World War, the firm had offices all over the world, although by the outbreak of the Second World War, sharp retrenchment had pruned the overseas presence back pretty much to Canada and Ireland. During the interwar period, Standard Life was busy transforming itself into the organisation it is today.

In 1920, the firm attracted its first insured occupational pension scheme - at Vickers, the arms and warship building company. In 1933, after the worst of the Great Depression, Standard Life pioneered institutional investment in shares as the stock market recovered. Edinburgh's financial community was dominated then by Tories, led by the Dundas family. The Whigs set about breaking this stranglehold by setting up financial institutions such as Standard Life to serve the new businesses of reform-minded entrepreneurs in the late Industrial Revolution. From tiny beginnings, insuring and making loans to engineering and textile companies, Standard Life (its name from 1832) is Europe's largest mutual insurance company, with annual income of £15bn, profits after tax of £1.7bn and assets of £80bn belonging to its 5 million life and pensions policyholders. fields.headline: Beating the carpetbaggers
fields.standfirst: The future of mutuality depends upon Standard Life, but it's not an open and shut case, argues  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: Forget the emotional things like being nice to babies and kind to the environment. There are real financial benefits to Standard Life's policyholders from being a mutual insurance company.
fields.body:
Forget the emotional things like being nice to babies and kind to the environment. There are real financial benefits to Standard Life's policyholders from being a mutual insurance company.

That assertion, by Standard's finance director Iain Lumsden, sets the tone for a two-month campaign to persuade its 2.3 million voting members that they should reject the proposal to turn itself into a public company and vote to keep it as Europe's largest mutual.

It is a tough battle. Standard will have to persuade policyholders that their future benefits are worth more than the windfall payout they would receive on conversion. While it disputes the £6,000 average payout estimated by Fred Woollard, the Monaco-based fund manager who has requisitioned the meeting, it does concede that a fifth of members will get more than £6,000. Set that against the promise of a higher payout on a policy whose value is uncertain anyway and Woollard looks like an easy victor. Standard, however, has come out fighting.

Its announcement of the special meeting, to be held on 27 June, shows that it is not averse to a play on policyholders' emotions. 'The benefits of mutuality should be preserved for both current and future members,' it says. For those who are more interested in their own finances than that of their grandchildren, it also provides a barrage of statistics to prove that mutual is best.

Others disagree - and not just Woollard and his supporters. Many of Britain's largest mutuals - including Standard's rivals Norwich Union, Scottish Widows and Scottish Amicable as well as former building societies like the Halifax, Abbey National and the Woolwich have all opted for a stock market flotation or been taken over recently.

So do Standard's arguments for mutuality stand up? The core is performance. Taking the average payout on a with-profits policy over the last 15 years as 100, the average proprietary life office - as shareholder-owned companies are known - pays out 97.3, the average mutual 102.6 and Standard Life, as one of the best of the mutuals, 106.9. And they are more efficient. For the average proprietary company, the cost of getting new business is over 97 per cent of premiums in the first year, 15.4 per cent in subsequent years. For mutuals, that falls to 75.8 per cent and 14.7 per cent respectively.

Mutuals are also better at keeping their customers. More than 80 per cent of endowment policies sold by mutuals are still in force after four years - and 86.6 per cent of Standard Life's - compared with 75.4 per cent of mutuals. But averages do not show the whole picture. In a survey of past performance of with-profits policies by Money Management, the industry magazine, the three companies with the largest number of top 10 performances over the last 30 years were mutuals - Standard Life, Friends Provident and Equitable Life, and the next two only recently converted.

But two of the three at the bottom of Money Management's table - Scottish Equitable and Reliance Mutual - are mutuals. And, while only three out of the 10 best performing with-profits policies over 10 years, maturing in February 2000, were proprietary companies, for 20 and 25-year policies, five were mutual and five proprietary.

What that demonstrates is that there are good and bad among both mutuals and proprietary companies. Standard Life undoubtedly falls among the good, partly because of its size and its financial strength. Iain Lumsden estimates that it outperforms by enough to add 10 per cent to the final value of a Standard Life policy compared to rivals.

For the average policyholder, that is worth about £4,000 - not bad when compared with the £2,500 Standard claims its members will get if it converts.

But there are two problems with that. The first is that it is difficult to persuade policyholders they are really getting that extra benefit - after all, they will not know the value of their policy until it actually matures, so how can they be sure it is worth more to them if Standard stays a mutual? More seriously, would conversion to a public company mean that extra benefit would disappear?

There are certainly signs that demutualisation affects performance. The Money Management survey suggests that the performances of Scottish Amicable and Norwich Union, which have demutualised over the past two years, are slipping. But that was partly the reason for their demutualisation.

Earlier demutualisations have fared better. Scottish Mutual, which was acquired by Abbey National eight years ago, equalled Standard Life's top 10 appearances in the performance tables over the last decade. Building societies offer another lesson to the dwindling band of mutual life companies: the importance of making your members feel like owners. Until the demutualisations started, it was difficult to identify any real benefits of building society membership. Rates were little different to those available elsewhere and there was no real accountability.

Mutual life offices suffer from the same problem. The controversy over demutualisation meant that a couple of hundred people turned up for last week's Standard Life annual meeting but that is a pitiful attendance given that it has 2.3 million members. But how many of these policyholders know they own the company, let alone have an idea of how to recognise these rights?

Standard Life admits it has not done much to encourage its owners to participate in their company. That could well change during the course of this campaign. It is likely to look at all the options, from giving a more detailed explanation of exactly how much of the growth in owners' policies comes from a share of the profits which would have to be given away to shareholders to considering a customer reward scheme, like fellow mutual Wesleyan.

Will that be enough to persuade policyholders to reject the carrot of free shares? Ned Cazalet, an independent insurance analyst, doubts it: 'A typical policyholder will be better off having shares.' Standard Life may warn that that will change when the policyholders have to share their profits with shareholders.

But, as Cazalet points out, the policyholders will be the shareholders so they will get that extra share anyway - or the sale proceeds from their shares to compensate. Standard Life's campaign to stay mutual essentially rests on persuading us to ignore these short-term financial benefits for the long-term good of ourselves and our children. It is a hard argument to win. The future of mutuality depends on Standard Life managing it.

fields.headline: Don't be dot.compromised
fields.standfirst:
Recruits are flocking to e-commerce firms with dreams of retiring at 30, but do they risk RSI or even burn-out? Jim Pollard reports.
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: So far the dot.commentary on the dot.com enterprises has followed the money. But what about the people behind the see-saw share prices? The idea that they will all be retiring on their 30th birthdays looks good on paper - just like those inflated stock valuations - but what is the reality?
fields.body:
So far the dot.commentary on the dot.com enterprises has followed the money. But what about the people behind the see-saw share prices? The idea that they will all be retiring on their 30th birthdays looks good on paper - just like those inflated stock valuations - but what is the reality?

The Department for Education and Employment estimates that there are about 1 million people employed in IT in the UK, but has no idea what proportion are involved in dot.coms. The companies themselves are also a bit coy on numbers, although Yahoo.co.uk says its staffing has doubled in the last 12 months. What is clear is that numbers are snowballing and there is a skills shortage. A survey of IT managers by the online IT recruitment network Silicon.com found 47 per cent reporting vacancies.

Some employers, like the one who recently advertised for someone with 'three years experience of Windows 2000', may be expecting too much but - as the industry grows - companies will have to look beyond the traditional geek.

'The problem is recruiters are looking for an exact match,' says Robina Chatham of the Cranfield School of Managment. 'They shouldn't look for people with particular tools but just with the right aptitude.' That could be you.

Amazon.co.uk, for example, intends to take on another 500 staff this year. Music merchandiser Helen Marquis joined the company from a branch of HMV. 'At university five years ago I was afraid of computers,' she admits. 'Now I'm working with them. I saw it as a natural progression from bricks and mortar as E commerce has a better future than the record shop. I wanted to be stretched and here my abilities are better appreciated. They trust me.'

The feeling of liberation from traditional working styles and attitudes is at all levels. 'The job is a gift,' says Martine King, MD of Yahoo.co.uk who previously held senior positions in both radio and TV. 'People here are vibrant, passionate and they care.' Indeed, with bright gold name stars above each desk and on every door, Yahoo's current home is as much primary school classroom as the traditional office. Like many, King took a pay cut to join a dot.com.

Nessa Curran is an operations analyst with Moonfruit.com, a new site-creation operation built around Macromedia's Flash technology which makes web-page design easier and more versatile. She joined at start-up. 'Nobody judged me by the fact that I'd spent three years bumming around in Spain and now I'm riding a tiger,' she says. Moonfruit has grown from three staff to 45 in six months. 'How could I be bored?' asks Curran.

Indeed, with their flat hierarchies and open cultures, dot.coms are a little dot.commie. 'We have an open-door policy as there are no doors, 'says King, who works in the open-plan office. 'If you like the expensive trappings of the executive lifestyle, a dot.com isn't for you,' she says. Nick Young of Moonfruit says: 'If I want to talk to the CEO I just do it and things happen straight away. There is no chain of command. The CEO is the next desk anyway' This time last year Young was fretting over his university finals.

An open working ethos is not exclusive to dot.coms, but Moonfruit takes it a little further. Former journalist Pat White, 58, brings a breadth and depth of experience to her 'unusual role'. 'I'm a sounding board,' she says. 'There are a lot of emotional problems caused by the fast pace of change and the rapid growth.' The marketing team's Richard Cook calls her 'the lighthouse'.

He says: 'The hectic pace affects your life. Everything's 100 miles an hour here and you take that home. One minute you feel like a God, the next out of control. It takes courage to ask for help or admit mistakes. The honest, open approach isn't for everyone. You need to understand yourself well to handle it and Pat helps with that.' Moonfruit's CEO Wendy Tan, formerly at Egg, sees White's role as vital. 'The promise I've made all staff is that they should enjoy our journey wherever it goes,' she says. 'It's a culture of responsibility. If people want to pick up kids or go to the gym during the day, they can. It's about balance. Pat helps me achieve that.'

But it is not just emotional problems that can be caused by the fast pace of change. Workplace consultant Kathy Tilney, of Tilney Shane, says: 'There is a tendency for offices to be overcrowded. As companies grow they shove in more people and more screens. We see back pain problems and repetitive strain injuries.

'When businesses are run by people with little experience, as many dot.coms are, that can be very refreshing but the downside is that they may not be aware of all the legislation. Most of it exists for good reason - to protect staff health. You need to take a holistic approach. It's no good offering a relaxed environment if the desk is dangerous.'

The holistic approach is important as many of these twenty-first century companies still work nineteenth century hours. Many staff report 12-hour days. This worries Nigel Stanley of the TUC. 'The dream might be retiring with a fortune at 30, but for the vast majority that isn't going to happen. They're more likely to be burnt out by 30. The dot.com image is a glamourous front for some pretty poorly paid, poorly unionised work in warehouses, call centres, delivery and so on.'

While nobody still argues that the Internet is a passing fancy, the future of individual companies is less certain. It took nearly a century for the motor industry to consolidate from thousands of firms to a handful. It will surely happen more quickly in the new tech economy. 'My parents freaked at first,' says Cook. 'They have traditional jobs and worried that there was no security. Friends thought I was mad for stepping into the unknown but I felt like a pioneer.'

'Before the capital was in place, we were worried about whether we'd get paid,' says his colleague Nessa Curran. 'We didn't even have offices at first. I was interviewed in a coffee shop and there were other dot.com meetings going on at every table.'

The enthusiasm of people like Cook and Curran is undeniable and infectious. If commitment alone were enough Moonfruit - which has just secured its first revenue deal - would be massive.

Of course, it is more dot.complex than that, but that coffee shop, if you are interested, is Coffee Republic, in London's Soho Square.

webTitle: Taylor shines and the moon is blue

fields.headline: Taylor shines and the moon is blue
fields.trailText: Presumably the 17,000 hardy souls who have already parted with £3m to renew their Manchester City season tickets, regardless of which division their ragtag heroes will be occupying, have scrutinised the small print for the possible health implications.
fields.body:
Presumably the 17,000 hardy souls who have already parted with £3m to renew their Manchester City season tickets, regardless of which division their ragtag heroes will be occupying, have scrutinised the small print for the possible health implications.

The club's endearing propensity for heroic failure has been dubbed Cityitis by Joe Royle and even though the genial manager has concocted something of an antidote in the past 18 months a nauseating tension suffocated Moss Side last night before the ultimate and overwhelming sense of euphoria.

A priceless goal from Robert Taylor ensured that Manchester reverberated to lung-bursting strains of Blue Moon. Unless Ipswich win at Charlton this afternoon the 30th anniversary of City's European Cup Winners' Cup triumph will be spent toasting a new league and a new era.

Otherwise, as regular City-watchers will know, those of a nervous disposition would be advised to switch off now. For should Royle's charges be required to glean some sort of return at Blackburn next weekend the suspicion lingers that a team famed for aiming a 12-bore at their own toecaps could surpass themselves once again.

On this evidence, however, Manchester's football urchins merit their place in the game's highest echelon - even if Old Trafford is hardly quaking at the prospect. The rich aroma of promotion had enticed another 32,000-plus crowd into a ground simmering with feverish expectancy and within seconds of the final whistle it seemed as though most of them were dancing a Status Quo knees-up on the pitch.

Royle could not disguise his feelings as he supped a celebratory can of cider. "And then there were two," he beamed. "It's taken Barnsley out of the equation and now we have to hope Lady Luck decides we have suffered enough.

"The fans have been waiting a long time for a night like this. They have been suffering more than the team. All those people who followed us to the outposts of the Second Division deserve Premiership football and we've got one foot in the door."

Birmingham City, of course, harbour their own Premiership aspirations and Trevor Francis's side were intent on gate-crashing the party in their pursuit of a play-off berth.

For long spells industry outstripped ingenuity but that mattered little to the delirious hordes when Taylor sent the decibel levels spinning five minutes before half-time. Kevin Horlock clipped a free-kick into the penalty area and when Richard Jobson diverted the ball into Taylor's path the striker - an "alehouse player", according to the man from Radio Five - lashed a low shot beyond Thomas Myrhe. Some pub team.

Taylor could have prevented much gnawing of fingernails when he broke clear only to shoot straight at Myrhe. But by then Birmingham were playing a bit-part role, their disappointment compounded by Jon McCarthy's injury, which they fear may be his second broken leg of the season.

Taylor's fifth goal in laser blue had earned him instant cult-hero status and, after four queasy minutes of stoppage- time, everyone associated with City was in Utopia.

Premiership

Champions League Chelsea cannot qualify for the Champions League if they lose at home to Liverpool and Arsenal win at Everton.

First Division

Promotion Should Ipwich not win at Charlton today, Manchester City will go up.

Play-offs Wolves will be out of contention if they draw with Fulham and Huddersfield win, or if they lose and Huddersfield get a point. Bolton must avoid defeat at Crewe to stand any chance of reaching the play-offs.

Relegation Walsall will go down if they fail to beat Portsmouth and West Brom win at QPR. Crewe will stay up if they win, as will Crystal Palace if they beat Blackburn.

Second Division

Relegation Blackpool will go down if (a) they lose at Oldham and Oxford do not lose at home to Scunthorpe, (b) they draw and Oxford win, or (c) they lose and Cardiff win. Scunthorpe will be relegated if (a) they lose or (b) they draw and Cardiff win.

Third Division

Promotion Swansea will be promoted if (a) they draw with Exeter or (b) two of Northampton, Darlington and Peterborough do not win.

Relegation Shrewsbury go down if they lose to Brighton and Chester and Carlisle beat Cheltenham and Darlington respectively.

Conference

Promotion Kidderminster will be promoted if (a) they draw at Woking, or (b) Rushden fail to beat Scarborough.

Unless Ipswich win at Charlton this afternoon the 30th anniversary of City's European Cup Winners' Cup triumph will be spent toasting a new league and a new era. Otherwise, as regular City-watchers will know, those of a nervous disposition would be advised to switch off now. For should Royle's charges be required to glean some sort of return at Blackburn next weekend the suspicion lingers that a team famed for aiming a 12-bore at their own toecaps could surpass themselves once again. On this evidence, however, Manchester's football urchins merit their place in the game's highest echelon - even if Old Trafford is hardly quaking at the prospect. The rich aroma of promotion had enticed another 32,000-plus crowd into a ground simmering with feverish expectancy and within seconds of the final whistle it seemed as though most of them were dancing a Status Quo knees-up on the pitch. Royle could not disguise his feelings as he supped a celebratory can of cider. "And then there were two," he beamed. "It's taken Barnsley out of the equation and now we have to hope Lady Luck decides we have suffered enough. "The fans have been waiting a long time for a night like this. They have been suffering more than the team. All those people who followed us to the outposts of the Second Division deserve Premiership football and we've got one foot in the door." Birmingham City, of course, harbour their own Premiership aspirations and Trevor Francis's side were intent on gate-crashing the party in their pursuit of a play-off berth. For long spells industry outstripped ingenuity but that mattered little to the delirious hordes when Taylor sent the decibel levels spinning five minutes before half-time. Kevin Horlock clipped a free-kick into the penalty area and when Richard Jobson diverted the ball into Taylor's path the striker - an "alehouse player", according to the man from Radio Five - lashed a low shot beyond Thomas Myrhe. Some pub team. Taylor could have prevented much gnawing of fingernails when he broke clear only to shoot straight at Myrhe. But by then Birmingham were playing a bit-part role, their disappointment compounded by Jon McCarthy's injury, which they fear may be his second broken leg of the season. Taylor's fifth goal in laser blue had earned him instant cult-hero status and, after four queasy minutes of stoppage- time, everyone associated with City was in Utopia. Premiership Champions League Chelsea cannot qualify for the Champions League if they lose at home to Liverpool and Arsenal win at Everton. First Division Promotion Should Ipwich not win at Charlton today, Manchester City will go up. Play-offs Wolves will be out of contention if they draw with Fulham and Huddersfield win, or if they lose and Huddersfield get a point. Bolton must avoid defeat at Crewe to stand any chance of reaching the play-offs. Relegation Walsall will go down if they fail to beat Portsmouth and West Brom win at QPR. Crewe will stay up if they win, as will Crystal Palace if they beat Blackburn. Second Division Relegation Blackpool will go down if (a) they lose at Oldham and Oxford do not lose at home to Scunthorpe, (b) they draw and Oxford win, or (c) they lose and Cardiff win. Scunthorpe will be relegated if (a) they lose or (b) they draw and Cardiff win. Third Division Promotion Swansea will be promoted if (a) they draw with Exeter or (b) two of Northampton, Darlington and Peterborough do not win. Relegation Shrewsbury go down if they lose to Brighton and Chester and Carlisle beat Cheltenham and Darlington respectively. Conference Promotion Kidderminster will be promoted if (a) they draw at Woking, or (b) Rushden fail to beat Scarborough.

webTitle: Watkin is the pick but Hick gives the rest some stick

fields.headline: Watkin is the pick but Hick gives the rest some stick
fields.standfirst: Worcestershire 206-7 v Glamorgan
fields.trailText: Worcestershire 206-7 v Glamorgan
fields.body:
The sodden faithful who finally saw some play yesterday had hoped to watch Worcestershire's Glenn McGrath bowling to Glamorgan's Matthew Elliott, a county cricket first.

Somehow watching Darren Thomas running in to Paul Pollard did not carry the same box-office appeal. But at least there was the persevering excellence of Steve Watkin and Graeme Hick to applaud.

Not that there were many left to cheer and clap. And those who had survived the weather were then subjected to a stream-of-consciousness style of announcing from a babble-happy Tannoy official.

There had been no play on Wednesday and Thursday and only 53 overs were possible yesterday. In that time Worcestershire, who had been put in, did well to scoot along to 206 for seven. This was partly due to some inept bowling from the Glamorgan seamers, but Hick, who batted with his old savage disdain, should take some of the credit for the rattling run-rate.

Thirty boundaries were struck, which is far too many. Watkin, 35 and just married, should not be blamed for any of this. His 19 overs cost only 33 runs; the 34 others went for 168, almost five an over.

Watkin not only restrained Hick but also beat him with three beauties. His two wickets were idiosyncratic and identical.

David Leatherdale and Stuart Lampitt both edged catches to the wicketkeeper Adrian Shaw, who punched them into the hands of Elliott at second slip. They were the last wickets of the truncated day.

Pollard had fallen leg-before to Thomas to the second delivery of the second over. Worcestershire lost their second wicket in the 12th over, when Elliott Wilson was beaten for pace and bowled by Simon Jones. In Jones's next over Vikram Solanki played back when he should have been forward and had his off stump knocked back.

Jones, though he bowled too short yesterday and also strayed too often down the leg side, is some prospect. He has real pace and, as the son of the former Glamorgan and England left-armer Jeff Jones, he should get plenty of advice.

Jones senior is not his only middle-aged adviser. In the winter the bowler turned to Lyn Davies, the 1964 Olympic long-jump gold medallist, for run-up advice and his overstepping problem appears to have disappeared.

The best batting yesterday came in the fourth-wicket stand of 68 in 14 overs between Hick (76) and Reuben Spiring (26).

Hick cut his first delivery, from Thomas, for four and pulled his second for another boundary. His 109th century seemed a mere formality when, after striking 13 fours in his 80-ball innings, he edged a catch that Shaw caught all by himself.

fields.headline: No quibble with Bicknell's credentials
fields.standfirst: Surrey 185 Somerset 15-2
fields.trailText: Surrey 185 Somerset 15-2
fields.body:
Martin Bicknell is nothing if not compassionate. "Brother plays, but with no luck," he comments in his Who's Who entry, a sympathetic reference to his elder brother Darren, who left the Oval for Trent Bridge during the winter in search of a regular first-team berth.

He neglected to mention that the fates have also given Bick nell minor a wide berth, but then whingeing is not his style.

Not that he lacks just cause. For penetration and economy, no current English medium-fast bowler can match his haul of 768 first-class victims at under 25 runs apiece, yet recognition has been minimal; two tests in 1993 and seven one-day internationals have been the extent of his international career.

webTitle: Lancashire's turn at bat is protracted by the contracted

fields.headline: Lancashire's turn at bat is protracted by the contracted
fields.standfirst: Lancashire 186 Kent 29-1
fields.trailText: Lancashire 186 Kent 29-1
fields.body:
Whether an England contract makes anyone financially better off, there might just be a desirable side-effect in the form of an extra layer of confidence for the chosen dozen if the performances of Lancashire's Andy Flintoff and Chris Schofield here are anything to go by.

Resuming on 95 for three on the third day after 1 hour had been added to the lost time in this First Division match, Lancashire added 20 runs before Flintoff lost his overnight partner Mark Chilton, caught behind by Kent's new wicketkeeper Paul Nixon off the redoubtable Mark Ealham.

Flintoff reached his 50 with a classic off-drive before Graham Lloyd and Warren Hegg were out in quick succession, Hegg caught brilliantly by the diving Matthew Fleming at cover.

After lunch Schofield and Flintoff offered a brief glimpse of some future seventh-wicket stand for England, Schofield impressing with natural timing and placement while Flintoff oozed power and class. His frustration at edging Mar tin Saggers to Rahul Dravid at slip when a century was beckoning was understandable.

Schofield took control after Flintoff's departure and contributed the lion's share to a useful stand with Glen Chapple that was ended by an athletic leg-side catch by Nixon, who then stumped Schofield off Min Patel.

The same pair combined to dismiss Peter Martin and wrap the innings up, at which point Kent might have thought of setting a target some time today. But then the rain returned, not long after the loss of Ed Smith to Chapple's first delivery.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Derbyshire's pace bowlers made full use of the advantage given them by Rob Bailey's painstaking century against Leicestershire.
fields.body:
Derbyshire's pace bowlers made full use of the advantage given them by Rob Bailey's painstaking century against Leicestershire.

When bad light ended play 12 overs early Leicestershire had slumped to 100 for five, still 110 runs away from avoid ing the follow-on, with Dominic Cork and Trevor Smith taking two wickets each.

Bailey's 118, his 45th first-class century, took seven hours and 13 minutes, though he was ably supported by Karl Krikken, who scored 51, and Paul Aldred.

 Gloucestershire had the best of another rain-affected day's play at Bristol, largely thanks to Mike Smith. The left-arm seamer took three wickets for 13 from 10 overs, dismissing both Sussex openers and their captain, Chris Adams. In-form Michael Bevan, though, scored 46 before nicking the ball to Jack Russell.

After a full morning session, only five overs were bowled in the afternoon, leaving any positive result unlikely with Sussex 110 for five going into the final day.

 There was no play yesterday in Zimbabwe's match against Hampshire in Southampton, leaving the tourists desperately short of match practice three weeks before the first test at Lord's.

"The longer we have with rain, the less chance we have for our batsmen to get used to these conditions. We need as much practice as we can get," said their manager, Dan Stannard.

webTitle: Call the lawyers, it's going to be a fight to the last

fields.headline: Call the lawyers, it's going to be a fight to the last
fields.trailText: Given that the ECB sounds suspiciously like one of those tinpot boxing organisations that produces ersatz title-holders of little talent and less credibility at the drop of a gumshield, it is appropriate that the gloves are being laced for a punch-up in St Johns Wood to rival anything that might happen this weekend between the world champion and the singing pugilist.
fields.body:
Given that the ECB sounds suspiciously like one of those tinpot boxing organisations that produces ersatz title-holders of little talent and less credibility at the drop of a gumshield, it is appropriate that the gloves are being laced for a punch-up in St Johns Wood to rival anything that might happen this weekend between the world champion and the singing pugilist.

This one involves Lewis - only it's Chris rather than Lennox and his opponent is Simon Pack, a fiftysomething cricket administrator. The pair are in dispute over who said what to whom and when regarding suggestions, reported by Lewis last year, that a number of England cricketers had sold themselves to the bookies and taken cash to fix matches.

Lewis says one thing on the matter, whereas Pack (who has neither confirmed nor denied anything in public, relying instead on his employers, the England and Wales Cricket Board ) apparently says the opposite.

It has degenerated into a war of words, and promises - if veiled threats from the Lewis camp are to be taken seriously - to escalate into another battle that will give m'learned friends their cut of the purse.

Lewis has maintained all along, with more steadfastness than he has sometimes shown at the crease, that he was given the names of the England players by an Asian businessman who was trying to recruit him as a middleman for match-rigging last August and reported this to the board. Pack is the ECB's international teams director and it was to him and him alone that Lewis spoke.

Lewis says he offered the names to Pack, was rebuffed on the basis that it was hearsay and of no interest and that the board's subsequent inaction was scandalous. Lewis's account, said the board on Thursday, was "unbelievable". That is, a whacking great porkie pie.

The trouble is that there were no witnesses to the meeting on August 3 last year and so the only two people who know the truth about what happened are Lewis and Pack themselves. And on the presumption that one of them is telling the truth the other must perforce be a liar. But which one? It is an intriguing question, for the two are poles apart.

Lewis is in possession of a huge cricket talent that has remained largely unfulfilled. He is regarded as something of a screwball by his peers, mostly on the spurious grounds - bearing in mind what some Premiership footballers get up to - that he wears Calvin Klein underwear and snappy suits, drives a Mercedes convertible and once posed nude for a magazine. He has also frustrated selectors and team- mates with a compendium of ailments and injuries ranging from the circulatory problems caused by Raynaud's syndrome, through "heavy legs" and migraines, to the sunstroke he sustained in Antigua as a result of shaving his head and then playing without a hat.

T his, while giving him a reputation as a maverick, and occasionally a pillock, does not mean he tells untruths. Pack's credentials for cricket seem to be on a par with those of Bruce Willis for morris dancing. Until he retired he had been a Nato commander in Gibraltar and a member of Valderrama Golf Club, which is where he would have met Lord MacLaurin, the chairman of the ECB.

He is regarded as a genuinely nice fellow whose organisational skills are first-rate, but who falls down only on his relationship and dealings with the sport and its habitually mistrustful participants. He does though, said one administrator recently, generate more paper than Bowaters. Everything he does is minuted in a meticulous manner that is consistent with his military background, as indeed would be a respect for the chain of command. It is, said the same administrator, inconceivable that his conversation with Lewis last year was not documented precisely and anything of significance reported to a higher board authority. So the key to the argument would appear to rest with Pack's notes.

The board says it will not release them for general scrutiny. But unless and until they do, no one will be any the wiser and the pair will carry on slugging it out. Seconds out, round three . . .
