webTitle: Board refuses to make notes public

fields.headline: Board refuses to make notes public
fields.trailText: The England and Wales Cricket Board has refused to make public the notes that were taken at a meeting with Chris Lewis last summer when the former England all-rounder alleges he named three England players who he had been told were involved in match-fixing.
fields.body:
The England and Wales Cricket Board has refused to make public the notes that were taken at a meeting with Chris Lewis last summer when the former England all-rounder alleges he named three England players who he had been told were involved in match-fixing.

The ECB's chairman Lord MacLaurin had denied Lewis's allegations of a cover-up and roundly criticised him in a letter to the 18 first-class counties. The Leicestershire player then challenged MacLaurin to reveal the contents of notes taken by the international teams director Simon Pack at the meeting.

Lewis alleges that the ECB took no action even though he named three "famous" players who he claimed had been revealed to him by the sports promoter Ashim Kheterpal.

"I think those notes are private property of the ECB. I am very happy to go along with Simon Pack's notes, he's a very distinguished army officer," MacLaurin said. "He dealt with the thing absolutely properly. I think it is our business, we are dealing with it and there is an ongoing police inquiry.

"All the reports that I have from Simon Pack and the notes that were taken quite clearly state that Chris Lewis refused to give the names to Simon Pack.

"It is a logical thing to do if somebody says, 'Look, there are three England players.' You don't say, 'We are not interested', you say, 'Well who are they please?' because we take this situation in our game and in the world game very seriously indeed."

Lewis responded to MacLaurin's stand by attempting to defuse the row while sticking to his version of events. "I told the truth and whether people choose to believe that is up to them," he said. "I'm extremely comfortable with what I have done, but it seems as though people want to play politics. I've said my piece and told the authorities exactly what happened at the time.

"Really there is nothing more to add now other than get into name-calling and I do not see the worth in that. I'm not disappointed about what has been said; it is life. What people do now is up to them. I'm not concerned about what the ECB are doing. I have told my story as it happened, I am happy with my conduct and there is nothing else to add."

fields.headline: Azharuddin quizzed after murder
fields.trailText: Mohammad Azharuddin, the former India captain, is being questioned by Bombay police investigating the murder of a diamond trader on Monday.
fields.body:
Mohammad Azharuddin, the former India captain, is being questioned by Bombay police investigating the murder of a diamond trader on Monday.

Ashraf Patel was shot dead by three assailants outside his house. Azharuddin, who met him a couple of days earlier, is being questioned about his links with the trader, police said.

Police investigating match-fixing allegations involving South Africa's Hansie Cronje believe Patel was the target of a powerful bookie network. "We're working on the match-fixing link," police said when asked about the possible cause of Patel's murder.

Azharuddin has denied any connection with match-fixing.

fields.headline: 'I have nothing to hide'
fields.standfirst: On Thursday he learned that Indian police had issued a warrant for his arrest in their match-fixing inquiry. Today he makes his debut in a Lancashire league.  Vivek Chaudhary  caught up with Ajay Sharma
fields.trailText: On Thursday he learned that Indian police had issued a warrant for his arrest in their match-fixing inquiry.Today he makes his debut in a Lancashire league. Vivek Chaudhary caught up with Ajay Sharma.
fields.body:
It was late on Thursday night when Ajay Sharma found out that he had been caught in the malign web of intrigue and rumour that extends to every corner of international cricket. His wife rang him from India to say that he had been accused by the Indian police of being involved in match-fixing and that a warrant had been issued for his arrest.

They said that they thought he was in England, that he had fled there shortly after the Hansie Cronje tapes had been made public. They said that the police suspected he had made a small fortune by acting as the link between corrupt cricketers and bookmakers. They did not know when they would find him.

If they are still interested, they should make sure they drop by the pavilion at the Arbories Memorial Ground in Padiham this afternoon. Weather permitting, they should see the former Indian test player trotting out at No3 to make his debut in a grudge match against Ribblesdale Wanderers in the Ribblesdale cricket league.

At the best of times it is an epic encounter; Padiham are the current champions, Wanderers last year's runners-up. But in turning out for the home team today, Sharma has inadvertently plunged the genteel, somewhat eccentric world of minor Lancashire league cricket into the centre of the multimillion-pound scandal currently engulfing the international game.

"I won't really know what to say," said the home team's captain Andrew McNicholas. "The whole thing has been a bit of a shock. It's quite amazing really. It's not really what you expect in our league. There's not much to be gained from match-fixing in the Ribblesdale League. I'm still quite amazed by some of the allegations."

When he is not playing cricket, McNicholas is employed by Lancashire police as a constable. At least if the warrant comes through he will be handily placed to execute the arrest.

The Indian police claim they have proof of Sharma's dealings and of telephone calls made to players and bookmakers during South Africa's recent tour of India, when match-rigging allegations first surfaced. According to one estimate, Padiham's star player made about 500 calls to bookmakers and players during the series and called one leading Indian cricketer prior to every match in March.

As the Indian press berated him and the Indian police searched for him, accusing him of being at the centre of an illegal multimillion-pound empire, Sharma was sitting comfortably, watching television in an unremarkable terrace house adjoining a corner shop on the outskirts of Burnley.

The house and shop belong to his friend and team-mate Pankaj Tripathi, who runs the business when not playing for Padiham and was responsible for bringing Sharma to Lancashire after befriending him in 1991. The team are currently going for a record third consecutive title and Tripathi is hoping Sharma's expertise can bring them that elusive piece of silverware.

Nothing to hide

"I only had an average of 35 last season," says the shopkeeper-cum-Padiham opening batsman and former captain in a crisp Lancashire accent, ignoring match-fixing questions. "But I did break my toe.

"It's my last season playing cricket and what a way to end it. Who'd have thought that Padiham would become involved in a match-fixing scandal? The phone has not stopped ringing since Ajay's name first appeared in the Indian press. I'm sick of it. We've got a very important season ahead, you know. The whole thing's just rubbish. It's one big joke."

Joking aside, Sharma insists that his humble surroundings and the fact that he is plying his trade in what is effectively village cricket speaks volumes for his innocence. "I have nothing to hide. I am in England to play cricket and did not leave India because of the police. This is complete nonsense.

"I don't know any bookmakers but I do know lots of Indian cricketers and this is why I have been named in this scandal. Mohammad Azharuddin has been my friend since 1997. There's no crime in talking to your friend. I always call him before matches to wish him good luck. Whenever he's in Delhi I go and meet him. I know his family very well.

"Everybody is at it in India; everybody is naming anybody they can think of as a match-fixer. I am quite happy to let the Indian police see my bank account. I do not have any foreign cars and own only one flat. If I really had millions in the bank, do you think I would be here in Burnley? I am here to play for Padiham and we've got a very important match. That's the main thing that I am thinking about. I am here to help this club."

It is Sharma's reputation on the field which persuaded the Padiham cricket committee to offer him a contract until September 9. A former captain of Delhi, he owns the third highest first-class batting average of all time at 68.5 and, according to Tripathi, "turns the ball better than Shane Warne".

If the cricket-obsessed folk of Padiham seem oblivious to the alleged international match-fixer in their ranks then the presence of Shahid Nawaz, Ribblesdale Wanderers' overseas player, might have something to do with it. The Pakistani batsman holds the league record after scoring 1,608 runs last season and Sharma is set to test his skill against the opposition's main weapon. The local press has billed it as a clash of the Asian titans and local cricket enthusiasts are rubbing their hands in anticipation of a crunching duel.

Seeing the funny side

Moments after Sharma had got off the phone to his wife his next job was to call the other important woman in his life, the Padiham honorary secretary Ann Hall.

"I've met Ajay," Hall said yesterday. "He seems like a nice gentleman and we are all looking forward to watching him play. A lot of the players don't know what's going on so we are going to tell them before today's match. I'm sure they'll all have a good joke about it."

She has had a stoic approach to the whole affair throughout. There are, after all, more important things at stake than the reputation of international cricket, in Padiham at least. "We are going for a third consecutive title," she said, anticipating today's first taste of cricket action. "Match-fixing is not what you really expect at our level of cricket. It might go in other countries but it doesn't happen in Lancashire; not in Padiham, anyhow."

I am here to play for Padiham and we've got a very important match. That's the main thing that I am thinking about. I am here to help this club." It is Sharma's reputation on the field which persuaded the Padiham cricket committee to offer him a contract until September 9. A former captain of Delhi, he owns the third highest first-class batting average of all time at 68.5 and, according to Tripathi, "turns the ball better than Shane Warne". If the cricket-obsessed folk of Padiham seem oblivious to the alleged international match-fixer in their ranks then the presence of Shahid Nawaz, Ribblesdale Wanderers' overseas player, might have something to do with it. The Pakistani batsman holds the league record after scoring 1,608 runs last season and Sharma is set to test his skill against the opposition's main weapon. The local press has billed it as a clash of the Asian titans and local cricket enthusiasts are rubbing their hands in anticipation of a crunching duel. Seeing the funny side Moments after Sharma had got off the phone to his wife his next job was to call the other important woman in his life, the Padiham honorary secretary Ann Hall. "I've met Ajay," Hall said yesterday. "He seems like a nice gentleman and we are all looking forward to watching him play. A lot of the players don't know what's going on so we are going to tell them before today's match. I'm sure they'll all have a good joke about it." She has had a stoic approach to the whole affair throughout. There are, after all, more important things at stake than the reputation of international cricket, in Padiham at least. "We are going for a third consecutive title," she said, anticipating today's first taste of cricket action. "Match-fixing is not what you really expect at our level of cricket. It might go in other countries but it doesn't happen in Lancashire; not in Padiham, anyhow."

webTitle: Now the onus is on Andy Cole to make a name for himself, preferably one with more than four letters

fields.headline: Now the onus is on Andy Cole to make a name for himself, preferably one with more than four letters
fields.trailText: Darren Tackle on why Andy Cole four-letter surname can't cut the fiscal mustard in today's football.
fields.body:
Tuesday

Obviously, as a leading spokesman for the game, Darren Tackle is more than aware of his responsibilities vis-a-vis his pronouncements in the media and that. For instance, he is more than acquainted of the fact that Sir Alex Ferguson is but one of many what hangs upon his every word.

So when asked, on his influential spot on BBC Hereford & Worcester's after-midnight football phone-in, his opinion of which Man U striker was likely to have to make way for the lad Ruud van Nistelrooy, yours truly weighed his words careful like. The last thing he would want is to be held responsible for the premature curtailing of a fellow professional's career.

"Football's all about opinions," I says. "And in my opinion, they is all shite. If you believe what you reads in the News of the World, Yorkie's quite literally shagged out. We all know Teddy's heading for the knacker's yard and Ole Gunnar's going absolutely nowhere till he gains control of his barnet. Baby curls is very much yesterday's look.

"But the one who's really got to watch out is Cole. See, it all stems down to this: at a quid a time, only four letters on a replica shirt really isn't hitting at its weight in the old merchandise department. Van Nistelrooy, that's very much the direction the game is heading. And if you don't believe me, how come Marc Vivien Foe got turned down by Man U couple of years ago? Simple, innit? Your three-letter surname really hasn't got a future in the modern game."

The well informed word is the money men at Old Trafford is looking for a forward line next season of Van Nistelrooy, Pierre van Hooijdonk and Giovanni van Bronkhorst, with Chris Bart-Williams slotting into midfield and Chesterfield's Steve Blatherwick taking over from the economically unproductive Jaap Stam at the back.

Straight up: take it from Dazza, that's what'll happen. See, Wattsy's got an inside track to the corridors of power via the bloke what valets his motor, whose cousin used to service some bird who once sold a kiss 'n' tell story on Martin Edwards to the People.

Which, all things considered, means I must get on the blower pronto to Rodders to make sure he has a clause inserted in yours truly's next contract that I is to be known - shirt letter-wise - exclusively by the full moniker of Darren Brontosaurus Tackle from now on. It's a short enough career as it is, without failing to protect your fiscal longevity in this harsh financial climate.

Wednesday

Turns out your Ruud is, as I correctly anticipated, history, about as resilient in the leg department as that trophy cabinet our Lee built in MDF for the new snooker room at Tackle Towers, what collapsed under the weight of one runner's-up medal from the Auto Windscreens Shield.

With Ruud very much indeed yesterday's man, instead the Tackle attention is drawn by another Dutch dude, your Edgar Davids, who has been playing his football in shades. Turns out he's claiming he's got some sort of eye infection, which, as we all know, is sheep's arse.

A footballer needs to play in shades only for the following reasons:

1. He is a poseur.

2. He regularly suffers the afters from the kind of night out on River Street what resulted in Vic and Bob attempting to play in a cup game recently wearing captain's armbands as blindfolds.

3. He is both of the above.

Anyhow, it appears that great minds think on the same wavelength, since Rodders is on the mobe early doors.

"You seen that Edgar Davids?" he says.

"You bet. Plonker or what?"

"Au contraire, Dazzlet. Think merchandise opportunity. Think spond-spinning situation. What part of the player's anatomy can you think of that has yet to be exploited sponsorship-wise?"

"Well, I heard Dion Dublin's poised to do a tattooing deal with McDonald's which provides full listings of local outlets when he's got a..."

"No, boy, we are talking eyes here. Get a range of Tackle Eye Wear on the shelves for the holiday season, boy, and soon Rodney will hisself be vacationing in warmer climes."

"Nah, Rodds," I says. "Not my scene."

"Bollocks to that, boy, you fill perfectly each and every one of the known requirements needed for wearing the things."

Friday

To be frank, the first experiment with the shades could have resulted in somewhat more tangible success. Grovelling around looking for them in the mud in the goalmouth throughout five-a-sides, after Wattsy had repeatedly flicked them off my face, was not exactly what you call a marketing triumph.

Still, where there's sponds, Darren Tackle has never not been known to go the extra mile. So I rings Rodders to tell him I'm happy to wear them for the rest of the season.

"Yesterday's news, boy," he says. "Rodney Gee has got bigger fish to fry. He's just off to JJB to finalise a deal on the biggest sporting product of the millennium: Ruud van Nistelrooy personalised knee guards."

fields.headline: White ' s week
fields.standfirst: Jim White on the truth behind 'that' deal: Ruud's ill-health is a clear case of medical paranoia
fields.trailText: On the truth behind 'that' deal: Ruud's ill-health is a clear case of medical paranoia
fields.body:
Sadly, for students of the conspiracy theory, the Ruud van Nistelrooy saga appears to have a very simple explanation. Despite what the BBC news suggested on Thursday night, the collapse of the biggest transfer deal in British football history is nothing to do with the deteriorating relationship between Martin Edwards and Sir Alex Ferguson. Neither is it, as has been speculated, merely another Ferguson psychological ruse, an attempt to gee up his existing strike force. In fact, like so much of modern football, it is entirely down to money.

When a public limited company with a stock market listing of over £1bn makes an investment as big as £18.5m, it is obliged by its shareholders to employ all due diligence. In other words, at that price it can't afford any risk. So some sort of insurance policy is required: after all, if the player breaks down and doesn't play, £42,000 a week in unproductive wages is a burden few profit margins can lightly meet. Insurers, however, are rarely keen on paying out, so need to satisfy themselves that all is in order before underwriting any policy.

Thus we have seen an arms-race escalation in the medical examinations that big-money signings are obliged to undertake. When Spurs sought to buy John Hartson for £7m from Wimbledon recently, the club insurers insisted not merely on some quick once-over but on specific tests centring on his heart, blood, knees, ankles and back, a session of scanning and sample-giving which lasted more than three hours. Even though it did not include close perusal of his scalp, Hartson didn't make it.

Van Nistelrooy, with a recent history of medial ligament damage, had to run an even more rigorous medical assault course. And when doubts surfaced from it, United's insurers refused to issue a policy unless the club agreed to a clause ruling out seeking compensation for any injury resulting from his weakened knee. Which would have been as sensible as a motorist living in Liverpool agreeing to a clause in his car insurance ruling out seeking compensation if it was stolen. In short, when he broke down in training back home in Eindhoven yesterday, back in Manchester trebles would have been ordered all round.

How things have changed. In 1973, Lou Macari became United's then-record signing for £200,000. "To be honest, looking back I don't recall ever having a medical," he says. "I was signed on the Thursday, went down to Manchester overnight, trained on the Friday and was in the team Saturday. I may have had a quick chat with the club doctor but Tommy Docherty told everyone he'd seen me play and I was fine. But then I signed a contract for £180 a week, which was never something Man United couldn't cope with."

T his is the point. The spectre hanging over the Van Nistelrooy transfer is not so much his knee as that of Ronaldo. It is costing Internazionale £140,000 a week for their Brazilian to sit in physiotherapy for a year; enough to make the most resolute accountant blanch. Yet he was match fit when Inter bought him from Barcelona. No amount of medical tests could prevent his subsequent injury.

In truth, it is hard to remember any club successfully offloading a player of suspect fitness rather than suspect ability to another club. On the other hand, Van Nistelrooy will be encouraged to hear, there have been plenty of occa sions in which players failed medicals and then enjoyed long and triumphant careers. Asa Hartford, for one, was turned down by Leeds only to play on wholeheartedly for another decade elsewhere. Not to forget the infamous and, for obvious reasons, nameless forward whose dream move to a top club in the 70s fell through because his medical revealed he was temporarily suffering from a social disease.

Then there's Paul Ince. "I was at West Ham when we sold him to Man United," recalls Macari. "We agreed a fee of £2m, he failed a medical when I thought there was nothing wrong with him, and Alex said he'd only pay us £1m down with the rest in instalments. Ten years later he's still playing. Mind you, I didn't dismiss at the time the possibility it was all part of the negotiations on price."

Which leads to a tantalising thought about Van Nistelrooy. No, that is a conspiracy theory too far.

Mascot mayhem sees red devil losing its hindmost

Ruud van Nistelrooy is not the only performer connected with Old Trafford to be short of a full complement of working parts.

According to a report on the admirable Football 365 website, during the shooting of a commercial for Axa, to be screened during the FA Cup final, the United mascot Fred The Red was assaulted by a posse of other mascots. The cuddly representatives of Preston, Bolton and Manchester City seemingly became more than a little annoyed by the United devil's boastful demeanour, and Fred was not only ducked in the Wembley dressing-room bath but had his tail docked.

Those who have witnessed Fred's wearisome antics would agree he appeared to have got off lightly. But that was not the end of it. The tail was not given back, and a ransom note was dispatched giving the conditions for its safe return. Eventually United coughed up, as demanded, a pair of tickets to a game at Old Trafford.

Leaving aside the implication that the other mascots would stop at nothing in their anxiety to watch some decent football, what I want to know is why a United mascot was involved in a commercial pushing Axa's involvement in the FA Cup.

Surely he should have been granted immunity from this season's promotional round and instead ought to have been out in Brazil annoying sun-worshippers on the Copacabana. No doubt Arsène Wenger will be writing to Axa to complain.

fields.headline: Strachan considers shock return
fields.trailText: Gordon Strachan may have to retrieve his boots from the attic and name himself as a substitute at Newcastle today because of Coventry's escalating injury crisis.
fields.body:
Gordon Strachan may have to retrieve his boots from the attic and name himself as a substitute at Newcastle today because of Coventry's escalating injury crisis.

Coventry have at least 18 players injured and Strachan, 43, is unwilling to field any of the club's talented youngsters because they are preparing to play Arsenal in the FA Youth Cup final on Thursday.

With Steve Ogrizovic also among the substitutes, City could have two 40-somethings in reserve. But the pair would be considered spring chickens had Strachan been able to include his coach Gary Pendrey, a former Birmingham defender, on the bench. The 51-year-old was ruled out because his player registration has lapsed.

Gillingham's chairman Paul Scally has been charged by the Football Association with misconduct for allegedly betting on the outcome of his side's play-off final against Manchester City last season.

Scally is said to have bet on Gillingham to win 2-1, which is considered by the FA to be more serious than a purely win, lose or draw bet. City equalised for 2-2 deep in injury-time and went on to win promotion to the First Division on penalties.

The FA explained that its rules "forbid any player or club official from betting on football, other than on authorised football pools".

webTitle: Star-crossed Ipswich find themselves in desperate need of more of the Wright stuff

fields.headline: Star-crossed Ipswich find themselves in desperate need of more of the Wright stuff
fields.standfirst: Push for the Premiership: Town must make it this year if they are to hold on to their goalkeeper
fields.trailText: Richard Wright, the Ipswich goalkeeper talks to Trevor Haylett about the Portman Road club's promotion chances.
fields.body:
This year Richard Wright is leaving nothing to chance. He will marry his long-term girlfriend Kelly just as soon as the season ends, after which he will surely head off to the European Championship with the England squad. Should the ghost of seasons past come back to haunt Ipswich again he at least will have that compensation.

The Portman Road supporters, for whom an invitation to the play-offs is like a recurring nightmare, are unlikely to be so lucky. At the Valley today they will wear a shade of green as well as blue and white, because if there is one team Ipswich are envious of right now it is Charlton, who have already booked their place in the Premiership and can play out the remainder of the season free of tension.

But for Ipswich there is everything to play for. They have a talented team shaped by astute management. They have commitment and spirit and a fervent support. Yet in each of the past three years they have failed to go the extra mile and this season is hinting at another repeat.

Again they are handily placed going into the penultimate weekend but so are Manchester City and Barnsley. If George Burley's team are to miss out on the second automatic promotion place a week tomorrow then the prospect of more play-off failure will put Suffolk in a collective tizz.

As the only player to take part in all three play-off semi-finals, Wright has suffered more than his fair share of footballing heartbreak. He is at a loss to explain what happens to the side at the last-gasp stage of the campaign, although fortune does not appear to be on their side.

Last year the goalkeeper with a club record of 26 clean sheets conceded three goals at home to Bolton, and Ipswich were out on the away-goals rule. It was the same two years before when Sheffield United scored twice at Portman Road. In 1998, Jamie Clapham put through his own goal to send Charlton on the way to Wembley.

"We're hoping it's a case of fourth time lucky," says Wright, amused by how desperate that must sound.

To be fair to Wright and the rest of the squad the play-offs are not occupying their thoughts just yet and on paper at least theirs is the easier final fixture. They are at home to Walsall while Manchester City must travel to Blackburn.

"At the start of the season we wanted promotion badly and everyone has worked hard to achieve that," Wright says. "We are aiming to be promoted after the next two games and if we can't we'll do it in the play-offs. We've learned from our previous experiences and we have a stronger squad now."

Promotion, whether at Wembley or before, would be a fitting end to a campaign in which Wright has established a new club record for consecutive appearances (today will be his 178th) and passed the double century for league games. And then there was the double stop he made to thwart Tony Dinning's penalty for Stockport three days before the start of the year that was voted "save of the century" by supporters.

His father, who passed away in 1995, four months after Richard's debut, would have been proud of his son's achievements and progress to challenge David Seaman and Nigel Martyn for the England jersey. It was Colin Wright's redundancy that first turned Richard towards football. Before then his passion had been grass-track racing and the Ipswich Witches speedway team. With money tight football was the cheaper option. His older brother Stuart gave him the next shove forward, forcing Richard to take his place between the posts while he opted for the glamour of the outfield.

"I didn't realise at the time that Stuart was doing me a favour. I really enjoyed flinging myself around. I joined a Sunday league team in which Kieron Dyer and Matthew Upson were team-mates, and I was spotted by an Ipswich scout when I was about 12. After that I was lucky to get the right breaks at the right time."

In the Ipswich first team at 17, Wright has never looked back. But for how long will he remain the local hero? If there is no promotion in May, he will surely be sold - economics and the player's own ambitions dictate that. His contract expires at the end of next season and he has so far refused to consider another.

Strangely, his kit is sponsored by a recruitment agency and with Chelsea, among others, poised with an open cheque-book, he is surely one player who needs no help in finding new employers.

Promotion, whether at Wembley or before, would be a fitting end to a campaign in which Wright has established a new club record for consecutive appearances (today will be his 178th) and passed the double century for league games. And then there was the double stop he made to thwart Tony Dinning's penalty for Stockport three days before the start of the year that was voted "save of the century" by supporters. His father, who passed away in 1995, four months after Richard's debut, would have been proud of his son's achievements and progress to challenge David Seaman and Nigel Martyn for the England jersey. It was Colin Wright's redundancy that first turned Richard towards football. Before then his passion had been grass-track racing and the Ipswich Witches speedway team. With money tight football was the cheaper option. His older brother Stuart gave him the next shove forward, forcing Richard to take his place between the posts while he opted for the glamour of the outfield. "I didn't realise at the time that Stuart was doing me a favour. I really enjoyed flinging myself around. I joined a Sunday league team in which Kieron Dyer and Matthew Upson were team-mates, and I was spotted by an Ipswich scout when I was about 12. After that I was lucky to get the right breaks at the right time." In the Ipswich first team at 17, Wright has never looked back. But for how long will he remain the local hero? If there is no promotion in May, he will surely be sold - economics and the player's own ambitions dictate that. His contract expires at the end of next season and he has so far refused to consider another. Strangely, his kit is sponsored by a recruitment agency and with Chelsea, among others, poised with an open cheque-book, he is surely one player who needs no help in finding new employers.

webTitle: Not crazy enough after all these years

fields.headline: Not crazy enough after all these years
fields.standfirst: Seven defeats in seven games leave the Dons needing a win at Bradford tomorrow to stay among the elite
fields.trailText: Wimbledon's decision to travel rather than train yesterday conveniently spared their manager Egil Olsen and his players another uncomfortable few hours under the white-hot media spotlight.
fields.body:
Wimbledon's decision to travel rather than train yesterday conveniently spared their manager Egil Olsen and his players another uncomfortable few hours under the white-hot media spotlight. Unlike clubs such as Arsenal and Manchester United, who now work behind high walls and electronic security doors, Wimbledon still train on a public park where any passing man and his dog, not to mention a television crew, can spy on their every movement.

With their Roehampton facilities, as usual, looking like Silverstone on a bad day, Olsen would also have needed more than his trademark cut-down wellies to keep his feet dry. Not that he would have worried about that when it is his head he is desperately fighting to keep above the water as he stands, Canute-like, against the rising tide of criticism.

The former Wimbledon managers Dave Bassett, Bobby Gould and Joe Kinnear have all had their four penn'orth this week, as they say south London way.

"Egil Olsen has taken the players who were the heartbeat of Wimbledon and either chopped them, changed them or axed them," said Kinnear this week. "I'm talking about the likes of Chris Perry, Efan Ekoku, Michael Hughes, Robbie Earle, Andy Roberts and Neil Ardley.

"Too many experienced players like that have been either left out of the side or sold. Looking at the players he has replaced these guys with, I believe they are inferior. Not only that, they have come in at a cost of £8m."

Jumping the sinking ship

Criticism of one's predecessors is never politically pure, but voices of dissent from among the players gain the immediate attention of a manager. The club captain Kenny Cunningham was the latest to breach the dressing-room code of omerta by revealing that after last week's defeat at Tottenham, Olsen walked in and said, "How did the others get on?", meaning Wimbledon's rivals in the relegation fight. Cunningham said: "That's not right. We have to be worried about ourselves and as long as we do that we will be OK. I still think we are the best team down there."

The striker Carl Cort, who is apparently among a whole crew ready to jump the sinking ship, has criticised Olsen's 4-5-1 formation in which he and Marcus Gayle have been asked to play as the wide men. He complains: "Marcus and I are supposed to go up to make it a three-man attack when we go forward. But I'm not a natural wide player and we've ended up having to do too much defensive work."

Obviously they and their colleagues have not done it that efficiently, since Wimbledon have lost seven successive games and will drop into the bottom three for the first time this season if they lose to Bradford tomorrow.

Should they be relegated, the club do not anticipate a funeral on the Kray scale. It is doubtful if they would get so much as a with-sympathy card from their Premiership rivals since only Manchester United could give them an argument for the title of most-hated team for each of their 14 seasons in the top flight.

They should take that as an enormous compliment to their extraordinary resilience. Bradford, like Charlton and Barnsley before them, have earned the condescending applause and head- patting of their biggers and betters because they offer no threat to the Premiership oligarchy. But Wimbledon have regularly beaten the best in the land, despite lack of money and star names and having had to leave their cramped, intimidating ground for Selhurst Park, where they attract crowds less dense than those in the aisles of the Sainsbury's supermarket adjoining the stadium.

Though Bradford obviously do not want Wimbledon to survive this season, the Dons' demise would be a punch in the solar plexus to all the other small clubs who believe they can similarly defy the odds in a league now dominated by the plcs.

When Wimbledon paid £7.5m for John Hartson in January last year, more than the likes of Coventry, Southampton or even West Ham would dream of spending, it seemed to be the statement of a club secure in their Premiership status. The owner Sam Hammam, who has since sold all his shares, seemed to be announcing that his was no longer a club that could only survive by buying cheap and selling dear.

Hartson himself certainly thought so, having left West Ham, perhaps the coun try's best-loved club, to join Wimbledon. He says: "We had a strong squad when I came here and I honestly believed we'd be pushing for a top-six place. But the new manager has brought in a lot of new players for a lot of money and most of them haven't been able to settle in.

"That's been hard for the rest of us, too. People say the new players lack quality and that there's been a lot of bickering but I don't want to get into a slanging match in the build-up to the biggest game in the club's history." Thanks heavens he does not, since his words are damning enough about the mood in the Wimbledon dressing room.

Lack of tactical thrust

Much has been made of the demise of the old Crazy Gang spirit. But that long ago became a parody of itself, with the photographers on hand to capture Hammam being dumped into a puddle on his final day at training and Hartson's burning tracksuit being thrown out of a window on his first day. Such antics had become as wearisome as Bruce Forsyth shouting "good game, good game".

Wimbledon's problems stem from bad buying, bad management and the lack of tactical trust between Olsen and his players, which are all as old as football itself. Plus a more modern ingredient, the takeover by a team of Norwegians who have been accused of not understanding the club.

They have at least attempted to remedy that this week by promoting the academy director Terry Burton to assistant manager after consulting senior players.

Burton was also assistant manager to Kinnear, whose footballing style threatened to take Wimbledon to the threshold of respectability during 1992-99.

He was forced to bow out after suffering a heart attack last March and, whereas he has made a full recovery, some Dons fans believe that the attack was fatal to the club.

The PR manager Reg Davis laughs at all the theories, insisting: "We are still the same old mad lot off the training pitch. You will never change that." And to prove that there is still a bit of insanity inside the dressing room, Hartson admits to phoning Bradford's Dean Saunders this week and asking: "How the hell did you win at Sunderland?"

S aunders told him that only Wimbledon's run of seven defeats had given them hope, though Bradford believe that tomorrow's game is even more crucial to them. Hartson says: "Dean reckons it is now or never for them because he fancies us against Aston Villa and Southampton in our final two games.

"It would be a total nightmare if we went down. There would be a lot of players wanting to leave because the likes of Carl Cort, Ben Thatcher and Jason Euell wouldn't want to be in the First Division." Nor, of course, would Hartson, who agreed to join Tottenham a few months ago before failing a medical. And the goalkeeper Neil Sullivan is on a Bosman this summer.

Olsen would appear to be doomed whatever happens in the final three matches. But his players will be fighting to extend the greatest fairy tale in modern football, even if their Premiership rivals still regard them as an enduring horror story.

webTitle: New injury puts Van Nistelrooy out for year

fields.headline: New injury puts Van Nistelrooy out for year
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy's anguish at missing out on a move to Manchester United was followed by even more trauma yesterday when the Dutch striker suffered a fresh injury which is likely to put him out of the game for a year.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy's anguish at missing out on a move to Manchester United was followed by even more trauma yesterday when the Dutch striker suffered a fresh injury which is likely to put him out of the game for a year.

Any prospects of United resurrecting their £18.5m deal for him imploded when his suspect right knee gave way at PSV Eindhoven's De Herdgang training ground.

European football's most sought-after striker underwent exploratory keyhole surgery at St Anna hospital in nearby Geldrop and the immediate diagnosis was that he would be out for up to a year with a ruptured cruciate ligament.

Television pictures showed Van Nistelrooy writhing in agony after collapsing during heading practice with his personal fitness trainer Luc van Agt. At one stage he appeared close to tears, pulling his shirt over his head and covering his face with his hands.

The PSV doctor Kees Rein van der Hoogenband carried out the operation.

"It's a very unhappy and unlucky situation," said the PSV spokesman Pedro Salazar Hewitt. "It could have happened to any player but that is the way these things go.

"In the next few weeks a decision will be made about when an operation will take place. After that, Ruud will have to wait a minimum of eight months before he is fit again. He is out for the rest of the year and it could be a full year before he is back but he is a strong player and hopefully he will come back as good as ever."

As he lay in a hospital bed last night, Van Nistelrooy will also have been digesting the numbing news that his only involvement in Euro 2000 will be as a spectator.

"He was doing some exercises for almost an hour," added Salazar Hewitt. "He did the same exercise 25 times, and on the 26th it went wrong."

Van Nistelrooy said: "When I fell on my knee it was very painful for about two minutes.

"The pain lessened and I was able to walk off the pitch myself and in the dressing room we decided to go to hospital."

Although Sir Alex Ferguson insisted he was still "monitoring the situation", there is no chance whatsoever of the deal being resurrected now.

"It's a terrible blow for the lad," said the United manager. "What started as a bright week for him has turned into a nightmare."

With a bitter irony, the latest and cruellest twist to the Van Nistelrooy saga comes less than 24 hours after his proposed British transfer record move to Old Trafford collapsed because he would not have an exploratory operation on the same knee.

He damaged a medial ligament in the same knee in a friendly against Silkeborg of Denmark seven weeks ago and United reluctantly pulled out of the deal when he failed a routine medical on Tuesday.

They wanted to reassess the injury but Dutch football's leading scorer refused because of the possible implications for his rehabilitation programme before this summer's European Championship in the Netherlands and Belgium in which he had been expected to lead the Dutch attack.

Although PSV hastily released a statement claiming the two injuries were not related, United will feel their decision has been vindicated.

"It's a very unhappy and a very unlucky situation because it happened just 48 hours after he was with Manchester," said Salazar Hewitt. "But it could have happened if he was a totally fit player and that's how these things go."

"He's a young man and a strong guy and we'll wait and see what happens when he comes back in a year's time."

fields.headline: Leeds prepare £11m bid for Solskjaer
fields.trailText: Leeds United are to make an £11m offer for the Manchester United striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.
fields.body:
Leeds United are to make an £11m offer for the Manchester United striker Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. The Leeds manager David O'Leary is confident that the champions will let Solskjaer go despite the breakdown of the Ruud van Nistelrooy transfer.

Leeds had an official £10m bid turned down for the Norwegian striker 24 hours before transfer deadline day and will return with an improved offer at the end of the season.

They have the funds to increase Solskjaer's wages of £24,000 a week and will be able to succeed where the Reds fail by guaranteeing him regular first-team football.

O'Leary has drawn up a shortlist of players - headed by Solskjaer and the West Ham defender Rio Ferdinand - whom he wants to help his team mount a sustained challenge to Manchester United next season.

Leeds will make their move with another faxed offer in the next fortnight and will hope for a more positive reaction than that given by West Ham. "David O'Leary did inquire about Rio but we are not interested in selling any of our top young players," West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp said yesterday.

Leeds have been fined £4,000 by Uefa for failing to control their players against Galatasaray in Istanbul this month, where they had four players booked. At the same disciplinary hearing yesterday Uefa cleared the Leeds forward Harry Kewell of stamping on Galatasaray's Romanian international Gica Popescu during the return leg at Elland Road, removing any threat of suspension.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: 'Nist' deal shows you should listen to a mate of a mate
fields.trailText: • The transfer rumour mill has cranked into gear alarmingly early this "summer". Apparently Chris Sutton has been sighted shopping at Asda in Watford - make of that what you will. But the story of "Nist" (as we were just getting used to calling him) is a welcome reminder that occasionally you should listen to that allegedly intimately connected mate.
fields.body:
 The transfer rumour mill has cranked into gear alarmingly early this "summer". Apparently Chris Sutton has been sighted shopping at Asda in Watford - make of that what you will. But the story of "Nist" (as we were just getting used to calling him) is a welcome reminder that occasionally you should listen to that allegedly intimately connected mate.

The news of Van Nistelrooy's transfer was first broken several weeks ago on the top late-night phone-in show, You're On Sky Sports, by a bloke who works in a garage where he has a workmate who is a mate of someone who plays football with someone who got the full story off his dad. We're not mentioning any names, but suffice to say that the garage is in Wrexham.

 More developments in the struggle over Wembley's wretched Twin Towers this week, with the news that they may end up either at a rugby league museum in Widnes or as the gateway to Runcorn Bridge. Bob Blackman, the opposition leader on Brent council, is keen for the National Lottery to stump up another £20m to keep the towers at Wembley. "Moving the towers to Merseyside is farcical," he told the Wembley Observer. "Runcorn Bridge is a horrible industrial area." Totally unlike the picture-postcard setting of Wembley, then.

 Time to salute the footballers of Andorra, who on Wednesday recorded their first ever victory by beating Belarus 2-0, whipped up by a frenzied crowd of 500. The first goal, a penalty, was converted by Julian Lucendo, described as "the portly former Barcelona striker, who now earns his living as a cigarette salesman". Now it's all eyes on San Marino, the only European country still winless.

 Not much gets past Watford's Darren Ward, recently returned from a loan spell at QPR. "I have found out very quickly that the biggest difference between Division One and the Premiership is the standard of the players."

 Portsmouth have a proud tradition of setting disciplinary records, dating back to Alan Ball's celebrated 80s ne'er-do-wells (six sendings-off, one player jailed, two arrested and three charged with disrepute in one season). This season they have achieved another milestone by having no fewer than three of their goalkeepers arrested - Andy Petterson (drunk driving), Aaron Flahavan (disorderly behaviour) and Russell Hoult (charged over kerb crawling).

 The second most interesting knee injury of the week was sustained by the referee Dave Evitts of the Warley local league, when two horses invaded the pitch during a match between Lion Farm Harriers and Abbey FC. Evitts, who took a painful kick from one of the nags as he tried to herd it off the field, said: "I suppose it must have looked comical with me hobbling around with a corner flag in my hand chasing after a horse." No Dave, not at all.

 Priceless information on Chelsea players' names is contained in the club's newspaper. The most surprising discovery is to find that England's favourite comedy Frenchman, Frank Leboeuf, bears the impeccably English middle names Alan and James. "Don't ask me," says Frank, "ask my parents."

webTitle: Cold wind blows through the corner shop

fields.headline: Cold wind blows through the corner shop
fields.trailText: The original Crazy Gang grew old disgracefully and retired to leave the Victoria Palace still echoing with laughter. At Wimbledon, however, the jokes have worn a little thin. There the gang show is no longer crazy and if the team are to stay in the Premiership their players need to reacquire a modicum of fighting madness.
fields.body:
The original Crazy Gang grew old disgracefully and retired to leave the Victoria Palace still echoing with laughter. At Wimbledon, however, the jokes have worn a little thin. There the gang show is no longer crazy and if the team are to stay in the Premiership their players need to reacquire a modicum of fighting madness.

If Wimbledon lose at Bradford City tomorrow they will probably be relegated and already the repercussions have begun. A clamour of former Wimbledon managers, along with players past and present, have apportioned blame for the crisis according to their lights.

Dave Bassett, under whose management Wimbledon won promotion to the old First Division in 1986, says the bulk of the responsibility must lie with the team.

Joe Kinnear, who managed the club successfully for seven years until his heart attack 13 months ago, blames his successor, the Norwegian Egil Olsen.

Carl Cort, Wimbledon's leading scorer this season, has criticised Olsen's team formations and tactics. Kenny Cunningham, the club captain, feels that Olsen has reacted too casually to the run of seven successive defeats which has plunged the side into a relegation crisis.

John Fashanu, red-booted battering ram of the Wimbledon attack in better days, believes that Robbie Earle, who has been on the playing staff for nearly 10 years, should be the next manager if Olsen leaves at the end of the season, as has been widely predicted.

In the meantime Terry Burton, once Kinnear's assistant but more recently in charge of the youth academy, has been given his old job back - at the behest of the players, according to some reports.

Given the seriousness of Wimbledon's situation Olsen's decision to spend two days back on native soil this week collecting an award for services to Norwegian football seemed a mite perverse. Then again, the welly-wearer was noted for his eccentricity long before he arrived at Selhurst Park. He was a successful coach, that was all that mattered.

Wimbledon, however, have always needed something more than a capable boss. Kinnear was right for them not merely because he knew how to organise a winning team, or at least one that did not lose too often, from slender resources but because he understood the psyche of this odd little club and was prepared to embellish it with his own offbeat powers of motivation.

At times he overplayed the image of sod-busters holding out against the Premiership's cattle barons and his perpetual complaints about getting a poor deal from referees, the Football Association, the wicked witch of the west and so on became predictable and tedious.

Nevertheless it is hard to escape the fact that Wimbledon's precipitate and possibly fateful decline set in the moment Kinnear collapsed with a heart attack shortly before the kick-off at Hillsborough on March 3 last year.

Wimbledon beat Sheffield Wednesday 2-1 that day and lifted themselves to sixth place. They did it, everybody said, for Joe, but the gesture was a brief one. Nine of the last 11 fixtures have been lost and the other two drawn.

Olsen has been unable to arrest the slump, not helped by the departure of Wimbledon's best defender Chris Perry to Tottenham for £2.4m before the season began.

The situation has not been improved, either, by financial matters which persuaded the club's Norwegian owners, Kjel Inge Rokke and Bjorn Rune Gjeltsen, to send in a troubleshooter, Svein Bakke, to inspect the books shortly before Christmas.

At the time Sam Hammam, who sold a controlling interest in the club to Rokke and Gjeltsen in the summer of 1997, made a gloomy but now increasingly accurate prediction of the effect of the three-day investigation on the players.

"It will demoralise the team and we could hit a downward spiral," Hammam said. "If we ever go to the First Division we will lose between £7m and £11m a year. In two years the club will have no players, no money and would probably be in the Second or Third Division, heading nowhere."

The results of Bakke's labours can only be guessed at but it does seem clear that should Wimbledon be relegated the players the owners already want to offload would be joined by several more who, like Cort, want to stay in the Premiership.

The likelihood of Wimbledon ever regaining Premiership status would be remote. They might, as Hammam has warned, drop through the divisions like stones down a well.

But why the fuss about Wimbledon? After all, clubs have abseiled before now. Carlisle, Northampton, Brighton, Leyton Orient, Swansea: they had all found room at the top once upon a time.

The point about Wimbledon is that, and especially since the formation of the Premier League, they have represented the last of the corner shops in a game which increasingly benefits supermarketeers and their shareholders.

Maybe Wimbledon's course was run once they became the property of distant Norwegian trawler billionaires who were never going to allow the ship to be skippered in the manner of Captain Pugwash.

Then again, vikings always wanted to die with their swords in their hands. At least Wimbledon could show some fight tomorrow before their longships are put to the torch.

fields.headline: Site for sore eyes
fields.standfirst: With everyone scrambling to go online,  Steve Shipside finds out why one of the big players is opening a superstore in Watford
fields.trailText: With everyone scrambling to go online, Steve Shipside finds out why one of the big players is opening a superstore in Watford
fields.body:
What with Thomas Cook planning to sell holidays on line, and Thomson Travel pledging a £100m investment in internet projects, it might seem increasingly as if the web is the only way to wander. So you might question the wisdom of launching a new travel service not from cyberspace, but from the decidedly un-virtual location of Watford.

Nonetheless, that's what Virgin, itself no stranger to the wonders of webbery, is doing early this autumn with the unveiling of a 20,000 sq ft superstore, the flagship of the latest Branson brainchild, Virgin Destinations.

"Destinations will challenge the way the travel industry works," says Tim Felix, information technology director of Virgin Destinations. "It will be a real high-street presence and, while there are already large travel agencies and holiday hypermarkets, this will be much more customer-focused than the straightforward supermarket-style experience."

It's a little odd to find an IT director promoting a bricks-and mortar-business, but Felix is firm on the need for high-street presence. "E-commerce is clearly a fast-growing business area, but the purchase of a holiday is a very complicated business, and customers need reassurance, someone to talk to.

"Small outlets may begin to diminish, but there is definitely a niche there in terms of larger outlets."

Any why Watford? "We've analysed the demographics, and within a 20-minute radius there is an affluent population that spends heavily on holidays."

Virgin sees its unique selling points as service (hopefully, more Virgin Airways than Virgin Trains), and independence. "Virgin Destinations aims to make the customer feel more involved, which means training staff more heavily and matching customer needs to staff experience," says Felix. "If you have a family and you're looking for a holiday in the States, we would try and put you together with a staff member with their own experience of US family holidays.

"We won't just be selling a Virgin product, we will be totally independent, something that most travel agencies aren't since they are owned by the big four tour operators. Our product lines will be wider and, as well as selling holidays, Virgin will be offering goods, services, and retail shopping from the store."

This is not to say that technology won't play a part in the high-street push. The in-store technology has already been sourced and will revolve around computer touchscreens from a company called XN. "Touchscreen kiosks act like virtual travel agents," says Barrie MacCarthy, XN's director of marketing. "You'll be able to come in and browse where you're going before you go."

Virgin Destinations refuses to be drawn on how it may or may not tie in with an online strategy. "One logical way of doing things would be to have an online presence in parallel, with both business supplementing each other," says MacCarthy.

The in-shop terminals could benefit from looking out at the world through the web, while the web could be used to steer people towards the wonders of Watford - and indeed elsewhere around the M25 if Virgin's new flagship floats.

fields.headline: 3 minute guide
fields.standfirst: Powder Byrne
fields.trailText: Holiday encounters of the snowy kind?
fields.body:
Holiday encounters of the snowy kind?

Originally. An upmarket chalet operator in 1985 decided that hotels in both ski and summer resorts with dedicated child-care programmes were a winning combination.

Haven't Club Med and Mark Warner been there?

No. They run their own resorts. Powder Byrne import their own staff and merge into existing hotels for the season.

Good ones?

Four- and five-star properties clinging to beauty spots around the Med.

Where, exactly?

France, Greece, Italy, Majorca, Portugal and Sardinia.

Child-friendly properties?

Not especially. Powder Byrne provides that aspect. Porto Elounda in north-east Crete, for example, is a parental nightmare of steps, balconies, and superb views over several hundred feet.

But I'd love it?

A grown-up holiday in a luxurious hotel with the children is quite unique.

A dumping ground for parents?

An opportunity for them to chill or rather roast out for five or so hours a day.

What's to do?

There are eight different types of bars at Villa Vita Parc in the Algrave. The ruins of Minoan Knossos is an hour's drive from Porto Elounda. And an indoor complex at La Fregate in Province is ideal for off-season short-breakers.

Are the clubs for all the hotel guests?

No. Only Powder Byrne clients use the clubs. Hence the intimacy between club staff and children.

Will they be busy?

Non-stop. The programme of week's activities, whether sporty, musical or nautical, will be in your room on arrival.

How much would I have to pay for a daily date with a good book?

From £1,142 per adult (£1,032 per child) for one week half-board high season with scheduled flight, and they will tailor-make to suite.

Can I still book this year?

Certainly, contact PB on 020-8246 5320 www.powderbyrne.com, although next winter's ski hotels in the Alps are selling fast.

fields.headline: Giant steps
fields.standfirst: The scenery in the Yorkshire Dales is as dramatic as it gets in England. Bestselling author  Joanne Harris  takes a break from her word processor  to broaden her horizons
fields.trailText: The scenery in the Yorkshire Dales is as dramatic as it gets in England. Bestselling author Joanne Harris takes a break from her word processor to broaden her horizons
fields.body:
Joanne Harris's hugely successful novel Chocolat deals with the conflict between austerity and indulgence, and it's possible to detect the same pattern in her favourite walk - a long yomp through a harsh and dramatic landscape, ending up in a nice teashop.

Harris took parties of teenagers on this circuit in the Yorkshire Dales when she was a teacher at Leeds Grammar School, but her preference now is to go there by herself to savour the tranquillity of the countryside and allow the cobwebs to clear from her mind.

She starts from the village of Malham and heads for Gordale Scar, taking a detour off the stone-walled lane to the idyllic waterfall of Janet's Foss, where people leave objects in a little cave to be turned into fossils by the dripping limestone-rich water.

Gordale Scar is a great cleft in the rocks that excited the Romantics and inspired a rather exaggerated painting by the landscape artist James Ward in 1812. Harris says it looks worse than it is: she passes the waterfall, shins up a chimney, skirts a boulder and climbs the rough slope to the top.

"Once you're at the top, you can see for miles," she says. "Malham Cove looks very dramatic with its limestone cliffs, and there are some very precipitous-looking crags with sheep teetering on the brink of them - and occasionally falling off, which confirms my view that sheep are rather stupid animals.

"It's usually a bit misty, but you can see a long way, and the village below you is so typically English it's almost absurd, with all these little cottages in Yorkshire stone and gardens that win prizes - and some rather jolly tea rooms."

But it's not tea-time yet, and she sets off across the moorland, with its shake holes and remains of neolithic settlements, to Malham Tarn - "a big lake with frogs in, on a fairly flat piece of land". There she joins the path that heads back towards the Cove, crossing a fine example of limestone pavement.

"The first time I saw it I thought it was dinosaur bones. It's difficult to walk across it because it's very hard on the ankles and very slippery in the rain. The top of it looks like the surface of the brain, all crenellated patterns and deep fissures - kids really love it, and it's full of plant life, which you can look at but not take away."

Again there's a wonderful view from the top of the Cove, and the path skirts the cliffs, descends a stairway cut into the rocks, crosses a stile and follows a little valley to the village. This completes a circuit of about nine miles which takes her from mid-morning to about 4pm.

"I can drive up there in a short while, and I know I'm not going to come to any harm. I like just to see that it's still there and stare at the scenery - it's very tranquil, even if there are groups of people around, and it's such a big place, with such wide skies; the format is so enormous.

Limestone cowboys

Publicity campaigns and the odd prosecution have virtually stopped people sneaking mechanical diggers into the Dales at night and stealing lumps of beautifully-weathered limestone pavement for garden rockeries. The big problem now is what to do about the rabbits.

Rare plants like limestone fern, baneberry and angular Solomon's-Seal grow at the bottom of the fissures, called grikes, and in the blocks of pavement, called clints. Sheep grazing on the clints take the tops off the plants, but rabbits get right into the grikes and can destroy them completely.

"We haven't made a decision about how we can control them," says Dr Tim Thom, ecologist at the Yorkshire Dales National Park Authority. "But we would want to do it in a humane way. There are more traditional methods like using ferrets, and they can be shot with air rifles and sold to butchers, which is more sustainable."

Only about 3% of Britain's 2,500 hectares of limestone pavement - half of it in the Yorkshire Dales National Park - is considered to be completely undamaged. It's now illegal to break it up in this country, but stone from limestone pavements in Ireland is sold over here. The Limestone Pavement Action group wants to make that illegal, too, arguing that halting demand would stop the trade.

The attraction of the stone is its beautiful pale colour and subtle shapes, created by water erosion of sedimentary beds left behind when shallow oceans retreated from Britain millions of years ago. Quarried limestone is not so popular, but it's now possible to buy artificial limestone pavement made with concrete, using moulds and dyes to mimic the shapes and colours.

Chocolat, by Joanne Harris, is published by Bantam at £6.99.

fields.headline: Watch the birdies
fields.standfirst: Erlend Clouston  sees the gannets of Bass Rock, North Berwick make their big screen debut
fields.trailText: The £3m Seabird Centre, which opens on May 21 in North Berwick is the most sophisticated exploitation yet of the fetish for nature worship that has made "green" tourism one of the growth areas in the British holiday market. Its attractions include remote cameras, that will beam "broadcast-quality" images from the world's largest gannetry back to huge screens stationed in the centre's basement.
fields.body:
King James VI of Scotland and several of his courtiers once spent an uncomfortable night in North Berwick, peering from behind gravestones as 94 witches and six warlocks celebrated a black mass in the harbourfront church of St Andrew. Times change, but the tactics don't.

Four hundred years on, the Royal Burgh is once again relying on a form of wizardry to lure visitors to its craggy corner of the Firth of Forth.

The £3m Seabird Centre, which opens on May 21 is the most sophisticated exploitation yet of the fetish for nature worship that has made "green" tourism one of the growth areas in the British holiday market. Its attractions include remote cameras, that will beam "broadcast-quality" images from the world's largest gannetry back to huge screens stationed in the centre's basement. Like the Royal snoopers of 1590, we can observe the rituals without intruding on them.

The centre is the brainchild of Bill Gardner, a North Berwick electronics expert who carved a small niche for himself in BBC history by devising the system that illustrates the Corporation's weather forecasts. It seemed to him the resort could do more to exploit its 90,000 neighbours on the Bass Rock than offer bumpy six-mile boat trips and puffin ashtrays.

Money and technology were the main impediments, but now funding from the Lottery has taken care of one and the microchip revolution the other. Two cameras have been planted on the Bass Rock's square mile of basalt and one on the smaller, nearby Fidra. Viewers will be able to rotate and zoom in or out as gannet behaviour dictates. The centre's technical team has leaned heavily on the expertise of an Alaskan organisation, Seemorewildlife.com, which periodically pumps live pictures of bears and eagles on to the internet.

"For the first time ever people will be able to enjoy a close-up, comfortable view of this amazing bird," says centre director Tom Brock. Amazing? Gannets? The thought may not have struck you before, but don't take his or my word for it. Dr Bryan Nelson spent the best part of three years living on the 350ft-high basalt plug and retains a deep respect for Britain's largest seabird.

The zoologist found that millennia of breeding on overcrowded ledges has forced gannets to evolve a sign language. "Tapping the centre of the nest with the beak while stretching the wings and calling loudly means 'I am the owner of this site,' " explains Dr Nelson. Other phrases in the gannet lexicon include neck-stretching ("I am about to fly off for a short while") and beak-fencing ("Welcome home, dear ").

Tele-viewers bored with all this domesticity can always savour the gannets' 70mph power dives into the Firth of Forth. The centre has more than ornithologists' hopes riding on it. Strategically poised 20 miles east of Edinburgh between two sandy bays and several fine golf courses, North Berwick has survived the flight to overseas sun better than most: day trippers still love the pillared High Street and the ladders that dangle like frayed stockings between back gardens and beaches.

Nostalgia is a limited market, though, and the centre's sponsors, which include East Lothian Council, are gambling that their initiative will nudge North Berwick back into something like the tourist mainstream. Brock predicts that the prospect of studying gannets (and kittiwakes, guillemots, puffins and the rest ) will draw a further 60,000 to North Berwick over the next 12 months. His confidence is shared by the Inver ness-based Tourism and Wildlife Forum.

"Never forget that many Americans and Europeans live hundreds of miles from a coast," advises its Scottish manager, Duncan Bryden. He estimates that by 2003, marine wildlife tourism will be worth an annual £90m to the Scottish economy. The Centre's building itself, designed by Edinburgh architects Simpson & Brown, is clad in sinuous stone and larch and resembles a bird's wing or a tadpole, depending on your point of view. Before viewing the video screens, visitors can enjoy exhibitions and specially-shot seabird films in a 55-seater auditorium. Afterwards, they can wander out into the immediately adjacent precincts of the infamous and now ruined St Andrew's church.

Here they can reflect that James VI was the first man to take an interest in the wildlife of the Bass Rock. Sailing back from Denmark with his new queen, Anne, he was startled to see a sieve manned by hares float from the shadow of the island. A hypersensitive soul, he was still enough of a zoologist to work out later that they had probably been witches in disguise.
