fields.headline: Lei lines
fields.standfirst: Martin Kettle  leaves the Elvis associations of loud shirts and hula dancers behind, and hits the coastal road to paradise
fields.trailText: Martin Kettle leaves the Elvis associations of loud shirts and hula dancers behind, and hits the coastal road to paradise
fields.body:
Few places in the world are better suited to uninterrupted relaxation than Hawaii. Maui wins endless awards as the world's best island and for having Hawaii's most swimmable beaches. Yet, as on all the Hawaiian islands, what is really striking is to discover that the resort areas occupy only a limited, though intensively developed, part of the coastline. Sure, the Elvis Presley version of Hawaii exists. But so do versions you never thought about.

Wherever you are in Hawaii, even on the streets of the capital Honolulu, there is always the sense of being cut off from the rest of the world. After all, these spectacular volcanic islands are more than 2,000 miles away from the nearest mainland, the west coast of the US, and it still takes a long time to get here, even by the jets that revolutionised Hawaii's accessibility as a holiday destination.

There are more than 100 islands in the chain, and all but a handful of tourists will only ever visit the six main ones - Oahu, Hawaii, Maui, Lanai, Molokai and Kauai. Though Hawaii - otherwise known as the Big Island to avoid confusion - is the largest and highest of the group, Oahu is easily the most visited, and Honolulu is most people's first - and many people's only - port of call. Three-quarters of the 1.2 million inhabitants of Hawaii live on Oahu, and half of those live in Honolulu and its legendary resort of Waikiki.

The driving routes

It doesn't take long to get away from the crowds. Drive out along the coast road from Waikiki, past the volcanic crater of Diamond Head and a string of suburban settlements, and you will soon come to largely unspoiled coastal scenery. Hanauma Bay, Oahu's over-exploited but dramatic snorkelling centre, is followed by gorgeous beaches at Waimanalo, Lanikai and Kailua, where the waves roll in under the backdrop of stunning hills and cliffs. It feels remote - yet the Gucci life of Waikiki and the wartime memorials of Pearl Harbor are each barely half an hour away.

And if it is possible to get away from it all on Oahu, then it is even easier on Maui. We took our hire car on one of the most popular expeditions for visitors to Maui, the 120-mile round-trip drive along the north and east coasts of the island to beyond the remote eastern town - though it's really only a big village - of Hana. And in spite of its deserved popularity, the feeling of remoteness that we found there was just extraordinary.

A drive of 120 miles may not sound a lot, but there can't be many places in the world where a distance of that kind takes so long. East of Paia, a nice town with a Pacific hippie feel to it, the narrow coast road begins to twist and climb through tropical rain forest scenery that gets more breathtaking the further east you go. A lot of the time it's impossible to go much more than 15 miles an hour. And who would want to, as the road leads deep into lush gorges, tinkling with the sound of waterfalls, densely overhung with banana trees and bamboos, eucalyptus, orchids and tulip trees.

It is hardly surprising that the rich and reclusive have made their homes along the road to Hana: George Harrison has long had a house near Nahiku; Woody Harrelson recently bought an estate near Hana; and the aviator Charles Lindbergh came here in the 1970s to live out his last years.

The resorts

Most of the 2m people who make the trip to Maui each year will stay in one of the island's two main beach resort areas - the Kaanapali-Kapalua area on the west side of West Maui, or the Kihei-Wailea area on the west flanks of the main part of the island. These areas are dominated by large, often beautifully-planned and frequently lavish resort hotel complexes, which lie in a string of premium oceanside sites and which provide every possible incentive for visitors to stay glued to their loungers for sunny day after sunny day.

The Outrigger Wailea, where we stayed, is one of the succession of groomed and landscaped resorts stretching along the southern coast of Maui. When we arrived, we were greeted with the lei garlands that have become synonymous with Hawaii, and then by a heart-stoppingly beautiful Pacific sunset.

Hawaii is the only state in the US where the indigenous culture has partly held its own against the march of westernisation. But the price of that resistance, for the tourist, is the hard-to-avoid ersatz version of Pacific paradise, with swaying hula dancers, kitschy songs about the charms of the islands, and fixed smiles all round which conceal as much about the realities of traditional Hawaiian life as they reveal.

The food

Even sceptics should try to get to a lu'au. After all, how often do you get to sit on a lawn by the Pacific on a warm tropical evening, eating local food, listening to hula music, and watching a fire dance? Exactly. And what a menu: sautéed island fish with lemon macadamia nut butter, pork, fish and beef with taro steamed in ti leaf, Hawaiian sweet potatoes with coconut milk and honey, chicken long rice, Imu baked Kalua pig, grilled teriyaki steak, Hawaiian fried rice, and stir-fry vegetables, followed by fresh Maui pineapple and papaya slices and a complimentary bar. All for $62 for adults and $28 for under-13s.

The activities

And then there are the fish: live ones; big ones; and little ones. And the turtles. To say nothing of the whales. Ulua Beach near Wailea is a public beach - as almost all the beaches on Maui are - and provides excellent and safe snorkelling, especially in the morning before the afternoon trade winds make things a little choppy. La Perouse Bay, to the south, is another snorkelling option, and there is a good chance of seeing dolphins, too.

But the best way to get top quality snorkelling on Maui is to take a cruise boat. They sail each day from the rapidly developing little harbour at Ma'alaea - which also now sports a fine new Pacific aquarium called the Maui Ocean Centre - and take you for a 40-minute each-way trip down to the tiny uninhabited volcanic island (uninhabited by humans, that is) of Molokini.

Here, under the lee of Molokini's cliffs, we swam for an hour amid an amazingly varied array of tropical fish, seemingly of all colours. Later on, when the boat moved on to Turtle Arches, we swam some more, this time among large and gentle sea turtles, which glided up and down from the ocean floor to the surface, an experience unlike any other.

Another equally magical cruise option at this time of year is to go on a whale watch. Up to 2,000 Pacific hump-back whales are reckoned to swim south annually from Alaska to Hawaii in the winter, to live and breed in the warm waters around Maui before returning north once more. From November to April, you have a good chance of seeing whales on one of these trips - and they are often visible in the distance even from the shore. Up close, though, the sight of these huge creatures is extraordinarily satisfying. We saw them break the surface and then dive, their huge black tails gleaming. We saw them leap from the ocean, fins outlined, twisting and crashing back into the water on their backs.

The Hawaiian islands are so much more dramatic and interesting than I had imagined. All that and sitting under a palm tree drinking a $6 mai tai, too. You soon realise why so many people never want to leave.

Making a mai tai

A mai tai is a rum cocktail invented by Victor J "Trader Vic" Bergeron in his Oakland restaurant in 1944 and introduced to the Hawaiian islands in the 1950s. When he originally tested it on some Tahitian friends, one was moved to say, "Mai Tai - Roa Ae", which means "Out of This World - The Best".

The original recipe * 2oz 17-year-old J Wray Nephew Jamaican rum * 1/2 oz French Garnier Orgeat * 1/2 oz Holland DeKuyper orange curacao * 1/4 oz rock candy syrup * juice from one fresh lime Hand shake and garnish with half of the lime shell inside the drink and float a sprig of fresh mint at the edge of the glass.

Today's recipe There are many variations, but the ingredients for this one are readily available: * 1oz white rum * 1oz dark rum * 1oz curacao * 1/2 oz amaretto * 1/2 oz grenadine * 1/2 oz lime juice * 1tsp sugar

Volcano biking

It never occurred to me that I would go to Hawaii and end up describing the numbing cold. I mean, of all the clichés in all the world that you might ever read about Hawaii, I don't remember anyone going on very much about their frozen fingers.

But that was before I went to the top of Mount Haleakala on the island of Maui at 5am in late March to wait for the dawn. It was pitch dark when we got up to the volcano crater. At 10,000ft above sea level, even here in the tropics, it was very cold indeed. The rain was pouring, and the wind was blowing. We had already been on the road for two hours. It was, in short, about as miserable an experience as you could devise anywhere. Spring break on a paradise island? It felt more like the Pennines. Which is why you are just going to have to take my word for the fact that it was worth it.

It wasn't as though we even got to see the sun. As we struggled into our rainwear on Haleakala summit, there was at least the lingering hope that the weather might relent by dawn, still more than an hour distant. But later, as a remarkably large crowd of us early-risers huddled for shelter inside the visitor centre, a park ranger announced that it was 6.20am and that the sun had now duly risen. Outside, everything remained blanketed in impenetrable thick, wet, grey cloud. We took her news on trust.

In winter - even Hawaii has seasons - there is at least a 50-50 chance of getting caught in the clouds and the rain at dawn on Mount Haleakala. But even if, like us, you draw a losing ticket and miss what must be the inspiring sight of the sun emerging over the rim of the volcano, there is still an epic reason for making the trip whatever the weather.

That reason is the exhilarating downhill bike ride off the mountain. From the crater rim down to the Pacific Ocean at Paia on the north shore of Maui is 39 miles, and with the exception of only a few hundred yards of pedalling, it's downhill all the way.

As a result, the summit car park on Haleakala fills up each dawn with minibuses from the rival downhill bike companies, who collect visitors from their hotels, then drive them to the summit before supplying them with custom-built bikes (as well as helmets, gloves and rainwear) for the descent.

At the top, on the day we went, the conditions were dire, and several of our party took refuge in the minibus for sections of the journey to warm up and dry out before getting back on their bikes lower down. Those who stuck it for the full 39 miles, such as my elder son, swept down a succession of hairpin bends amid volcanic terrain so bleak that the Apollo astronauts trained up there for their moonwalks, before emerging on to the lusher - and sunnier - lower slopes for the more leisurely second half of the trip.

Once we got below the clouds, the views over Maui were stunning. Below us stretched the lush greens of the local vegetation, with smoke rising from the tall chimneys of the island's two remaining sugar cane factories in the flat lowland valley that divides the two halves of Maui. Across from us rose the smaller but more shapely volcanic peaks of West Maui, tipped with thin clouds. To both east and west stretched the blue Pacific, with white waves breaking on distant golden beaches.

At moments like this, you realise that Maui, like all the main Hawaiian islands, is a land of extremes. And, in a place that is only 48 miles long and 26 miles wide at its broadest points, you obviously don't have to travel very far to find them.

Mount Haleakala bike ride: Maui Downhill (001 808 871 2155, www.mauidownhill.net. Costs $68 each for the Summit Sunrise trip, including hotel pick-up and return, minibus to summit, bike and clothing, guide, snacks, breakfast.
fields.bodyText: Few places in the world are better suited to uninterrupted relaxation than Hawaii. Maui wins endless awards as the world's best island and for having Hawaii's most swimmable beaches. Yet, as on all the Hawaiian islands, what is really striking is to discover that the resort areas occupy only a limited, though intensively developed, part of the coastline. Sure, the Elvis Presley version of Hawaii exists. But so do versions you never thought about. Wherever you are in Hawaii, even on the streets of the capital Honolulu, there is always the sense of being cut off from the rest of the world. After all, these spectacular volcanic islands are more than 2,000 miles away from the nearest mainland, the west coast of the US, and it still takes a long time to get here, even by the jets that revolutionised Hawaii's accessibility as a holiday destination. There are more than 100 islands in the chain, and all but a handful of tourists will only ever visit the six main ones - Oahu, Hawaii, Maui, Lanai, Molokai and Kauai. Though Hawaii - otherwise known as the Big Island to avoid confusion - is the largest and highest of the group, Oahu is easily the most visited, and Honolulu is most people's first - and many people's only - port of call. Three-quarters of the 1.2 million inhabitants of Hawaii live on Oahu, and half of those live in Honolulu and its legendary resort of Waikiki. The driving routes It doesn't take long to get away from the crowds. Drive out along the coast road from Waikiki, past the volcanic crater of Diamond Head and a string of suburban settlements, and you will soon come to largely unspoiled coastal scenery. Hanauma Bay, Oahu's over-exploited but dramatic snorkelling centre, is followed by gorgeous beaches at Waimanalo, Lanikai and Kailua, where the waves roll in under the backdrop of stunning hills and cliffs. It feels remote - yet the Gucci life of Waikiki and the wartime memorials of Pearl Harbor are each barely half an hour away. And if it is possible to get away from it all on Oahu, then it is even easier on Maui. We took our hire car on one of the most popular expeditions for visitors to Maui, the 120-mile round-trip drive along the north and east coasts of the island to beyond the remote eastern town - though it's really only a big village - of Hana. And in spite of its deserved popularity, the feeling of remoteness that we found there was just extraordinary. A drive of 120 miles may not sound a lot, but there can't be many places in the world where a distance of that kind takes so long. East of Paia, a nice town with a Pacific hippie feel to it, the narrow coast road begins to twist and climb through tropical rain forest scenery that gets more breathtaking the further east you go. A lot of the time it's impossible to go much more than 15 miles an hour. And who would want to, as the road leads deep into lush gorges, tinkling with the sound of waterfalls, densely overhung with banana trees and bamboos, eucalyptus, orchids and tulip trees. It is hardly surprising that the rich and reclusive have made their homes along the road to Hana: George Harrison has long had a house near Nahiku; Woody Harrelson recently bought an estate near Hana; and the aviator Charles Lindbergh came here in the 1970s to live out his last years. The resorts Most of the 2m people who make the trip to Maui each year will stay in one of the island's two main beach resort areas - the Kaanapali-Kapalua area on the west side of West Maui, or the Kihei-Wailea area on the west flanks of the main part of the island. These areas are dominated by large, often beautifully-planned and frequently lavish resort hotel complexes, which lie in a string of premium oceanside sites and which provide every possible incentive for visitors to stay glued to their loungers for sunny day after sunny day. The Outrigger Wailea, where we stayed, is one of the succession of groomed and landscaped resorts stretching along the southern coast of Maui. When we arrived, we were greeted with the lei garlands that have become synonymous with Hawaii, and then by a heart-stoppingly beautiful Pacific sunset. Hawaii is the only state in the US where the indigenous culture has partly held its own against the march of westernisation. But the price of that resistance, for the tourist, is the hard-to-avoid ersatz version of Pacific paradise, with swaying hula dancers, kitschy songs about the charms of the islands, and fixed smiles all round which conceal as much about the realities of traditional Hawaiian life as they reveal. The food Even sceptics should try to get to a lu'au. After all, how often do you get to sit on a lawn by the Pacific on a warm tropical evening, eating local food, listening to hula music, and watching a fire dance? Exactly. And what a menu: sautéed island fish with lemon macadamia nut butter, pork, fish and beef with taro steamed in ti leaf, Hawaiian sweet potatoes with coconut milk and honey, chicken long rice, Imu baked Kalua pig, grilled teriyaki steak, Hawaiian fried rice, and stir-fry vegetables, followed by fresh Maui pineapple and papaya slices and a complimentary bar. All for $62 for adults and $28 for under-13s. The activities And then there are the fish: live ones; big ones; and little ones. And the turtles. To say nothing of the whales. Ulua Beach near Wailea is a public beach - as almost all the beaches on Maui are - and provides excellent and safe snorkelling, especially in the morning before the afternoon trade winds make things a little choppy. La Perouse Bay, to the south, is another snorkelling option, and there is a good chance of seeing dolphins, too. But the best way to get top quality snorkelling on Maui is to take a cruise boat. They sail each day from the rapidly developing little harbour at Ma'alaea - which also now sports a fine new Pacific aquarium called the Maui Ocean Centre - and take you for a 40-minute each-way trip down to the tiny uninhabited volcanic island (uninhabited by humans, that is) of Molokini. Here, under the lee of Molokini's cliffs, we swam for an hour amid an amazingly varied array of tropical fish, seemingly of all colours. Later on, when the boat moved on to Turtle Arches, we swam some more, this time among large and gentle sea turtles, which glided up and down from the ocean floor to the surface, an experience unlike any other. Another equally magical cruise option at this time of year is to go on a whale watch. Up to 2,000 Pacific hump-back whales are reckoned to swim south annually from Alaska to Hawaii in the winter, to live and breed in the warm waters around Maui before returning north once more. From November to April, you have a good chance of seeing whales on one of these trips - and they are often visible in the distance even from the shore. Up close, though, the sight of these huge creatures is extraordinarily satisfying. We saw them break the surface and then dive, their huge black tails gleaming. We saw them leap from the ocean, fins outlined, twisting and crashing back into the water on their backs. The Hawaiian islands are so much more dramatic and interesting than I had imagined. All that and sitting under a palm tree drinking a $6 mai tai, too. You soon realise why so many people never want to leave. Making a mai tai A mai tai is a rum cocktail invented by Victor J "Trader Vic" Bergeron in his Oakland restaurant in 1944 and introduced to the Hawaiian islands in the 1950s. When he originally tested it on some Tahitian friends, one was moved to say, "Mai Tai - Roa Ae", which means "Out of This World - The Best". The original recipe * 2oz 17-year-old J Wray Nephew Jamaican rum * 1/2 oz French Garnier Orgeat * 1/2 oz Holland DeKuyper orange curacao * 1/4 oz rock candy syrup * juice from one fresh lime Hand shake and garnish with half of the lime shell inside the drink and float a sprig of fresh mint at the edge of the glass. Today's recipe There are many variations, but the ingredients for this one are readily available: * 1oz white rum * 1oz dark rum * 1oz curacao * 1/2 oz amaretto * 1/2 oz grenadine * 1/2 oz lime juice * 1tsp sugar Volcano biking It never occurred to me that I would go to Hawaii and end up describing the numbing cold. I mean, of all the clichés in all the world that you might ever read about Hawaii, I don't remember anyone going on very much about their frozen fingers. But that was before I went to the top of Mount Haleakala on the island of Maui at 5am in late March to wait for the dawn. It was pitch dark when we got up to the volcano crater. At 10,000ft above sea level, even here in the tropics, it was very cold indeed. The rain was pouring, and the wind was blowing. We had already been on the road for two hours. It was, in short, about as miserable an experience as you could devise anywhere. Spring break on a paradise island? It felt more like the Pennines. Which is why you are just going to have to take my word for the fact that it was worth it. It wasn't as though we even got to see the sun. As we struggled into our rainwear on Haleakala summit, there was at least the lingering hope that the weather might relent by dawn, still more than an hour distant. But later, as a remarkably large crowd of us early-risers huddled for shelter inside the visitor centre, a park ranger announced that it was 6.20am and that the sun had now duly risen. Outside, everything remained blanketed in impenetrable thick, wet, grey cloud. We took her news on trust. In winter - even Hawaii has seasons - there is at least a 50-50 chance of getting caught in the clouds and the rain at dawn on Mount Haleakala. But even if, like us, you draw a losing ticket and miss what must be the inspiring sight of the sun emerging over the rim of the volcano, there is still an epic reason for making the trip whatever the weather. fields.headline: Late bookings
fields.trailText: Bali beach | Grenada all in | Thai break
fields.body:
Bali beach
Seven nights in Bali in May costs £529 with Qantas Holidays (020-8222 9104). The price includes accommodation at the four-star Grand Bali Beach Hotel, return scheduled flights, taxes and transfers.

Grenada all in
Seven nights all-inclusive in Grenada cost £599pp departing May 17 and 19 from Gatwick. Price includes return flights, acommodation at the four-star Rex Grenadian and transfers. Tropical Journeys (020-7849 4113).

Thai break
Save £100pp on an eight-night holiday in the resort of Krabi in Thailand. The cost of £575pp includes return flights from Heathrow throughout May and June and B&B in the Andaman Resort based on two sharing. Premier Holidays (0870 7898926).

Fjord escort Save almost £500 on a seven-night cruise of the Norwegian fjords sailing out of Dover on May 7. Reduced from £868 to £395, the cruise on Black Watch goes to Balestrand, Bergen, Kinsarvik and Kristiansand before returning to Dover. The Cruise Line (01273 835252).

Go West
A 14-day fly/drive in the US West throughout May and June costs £499 per person with Bon Voyage (0800 3160194). You can fly in to a choice of five destinations - LA, San Diego, San Francisco, Phoenix and Las Vegas -and head home from another, with no extra drop-off charges for the car. The price includes BA flights from Heathrow (Gatwick for San Diego) Monday-Thursday. The company can offer accommodation from £39 a night.

Normandy nights
Three-night breaks in Deauville, Normandy, until the end of May cost £191pp (including one free night worth £53) with Eurotunnel Motoring Holidays (0870 3332001). Price covers crossing for car and passengers and B&B the four-star Normandy Hotel.

The Gambia style
Two weeks in The Gambia costs £549pp leaving on May 12. The price includes flights, transfers, taxes and B&B accommodation at the Ngala Lodge, a former colonial mansion overlooking the sea. The Gambia Experience (023 8073 0888).

Island in the sun
A week in a villa in Corfu costs £399pp leaving May 15. The villas, a 15-minute walk from Sinies in the north-east of the island, sleep two to five people and have a swimming pool. The price includes return flights from Gatwick and Manchester, a week's | car rental and accommodation. Direct Line Holidays (020-8239 3399).

fields.headline: Soros quits dot.com betting
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: George Soros, the international financier who "broke the pound", yesterday admitted he had been beaten by billions of dollars of losses through misguided investments in technology companies.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York,  John Cassy  and  Jill Treanor
fields.body:
George Soros, the international financier who "broke the pound", yesterday admitted he had been beaten by billions of dollars of losses through misguided investments in technology companies.

The 69-year-old Hungarian-born multimillionaire said "we are bringing an epoch to an end" as he announced a radical restructuring of his huge hedge fund operation and the departure of his two closest lieutenants.

In a letter to his clients, he said his high-profile Quantum Fund, which since the end of December has fallen in value from $10.4bn (£6.7bn) to $8bn, would be converted "into a lower risk or lower reward operation".

He annnounced the unexpected retirement of Stanley Druckenmiller, the chief investment officer who guided the fund to its $10bn bet against the Bank of England in 1992 and who was regarded as his successor, and Nick Roditi, the Zimbabwean London-based manager.

The two executives had run the two best-known Soros funds, Quantum and Quota, which analysts said yesterday would suffer client defections as a result of their departure.

Mr Druckenmiller, who previously had the power to move markets around the world, admitted he had been caught out by falls in the Nasdaq technology index in the US. "I screwed up. I should have got out in February," he said.

The size of the bets placed by the funds had given Mr Soros legendary status and allowed his pronouncements to make or break markets.

Like other hedge funds, the managers often borrowed to place their large bets - which exaggerated their profits but also exacerbated their losses.

Last night Mr Soros acknowledged that the markets had changed, becoming "extremely unstable", and that traditional valuation methods no longer applied.

"In taking this step my objective is to establish an organisation that can efficiently administer my funds and those of other shareholders, even beyond my lifetime," he said - adding he wanted a "more reliable stream of income for my charitable activities".

He continued: "We've come to realise that a large hedge fund like Quantum is no longer the best way to manage money. Quantum Fund is far too big, and its activities too closely watched by the market to be able to operate successfully in the market."

The former Soros fund manager described the announcement as the biggest news to hit the hedge fund industry in more than a decade.

"Here is a man [Soros] who probably has one of the best records of investing in capital markets and has taken some of the biggest bets effectively withdrawing from the hedge fund arena," he said. The Soros funds have been hit hard by bets on internet and telecommunications stocks that have failed to pay off. In one month they are understood to have lost as much as $5bn. Their highly leveraged positions on the Nasdaq Composite index misfired when the benchmark for technology stocks fell by a third last month.

Nicola Meaden, director of Tass, a hedge fund research group, said: "Without these two established fund managers investors will be very nervous."

Mr Soros said shareholders would be given the choice of remaining in Quota Fund, moving to the portion managed by that adviser or taking cash if they withdraw their funds.

Ironically the Soros funds had performed relatively well over the past year as the group belatedly bought into the hi-tech shares market.

The Quantum Fund, which will be renamed the Quantum Endowment Fund, was up by about 2% in the first quarter of this year while the Quota fund was up about 12%, according to Tass. Mr Soros said the name change would allow the history of the Quantum Fund, which has provided shareholders with an annual return of more than 30% during its 31-year history, to be preserved as "a monument more lasting than bronze".

The shake-up comes a month after tech stock vagaries helped prompt Julian Robertson to close Tiger Management, formerly the world's second largest hedge fund group.

webTitle: Reigning Queens: Queen Elizabeth II, Andy Warhol (1985)

fields.headline: Reigning Queens: Queen Elizabeth II, Andy Warhol (1985)
fields.trailText: Title: Reigning Queens: Queen Elizabeth II. Part of a series that also includes the queens of Denmark, the Netherlands and Swaziland.
fields.body:
Title: Reigning Queens: Queen Elizabeth II. Part of a series that also includes the queens of Denmark, the Netherlands and Swaziland.

Date: 1985.

Artist: Andy Warhol, famous for painting cans of soup and coke bottles.

Subject: Britain's hereditary head of state.

Distinguishing features: The Queen is one of the few people in the world whose portrait is regularly painted, but this depiction is unique because she neither sat for it nor commissioned it. Warhol, you might conclude, found Elizabeth II more interesting than any of her court painters, whose efforts are hackwork compared to this camp treat. Why? Warhol was fascinated by repetition, the mass-production of images, and since Alexander the Great monarchs and emperors have mass-produced and circulated their images, put their heads on coins for their subjects to see.

The shape of Warhol's portrait recalls a postage stamp, though the picture of the Queen, taken from her 1977 Jubilee portrait, is head-on instead of in profile. There are different versions of the screenprint in different carnival colours, flaunting the repetitious nature of the image. At the same time there is an emotion in the way Warhol has drawn the Queen's features, tracing from a photograph in a way that suggests an attempt to imaginatively understand this face, this person.

This is a painting of someone caught in the eye of the multitude; Elizabeth exists here only for us. The greatest of all royal portraits, Velazquez's Las Meninas, doesn't show the Spanish king and queen except as figures in a mirror; it shows the world as they see it and implies the world only exists in the eye of the sovereign. Warhol's portrait implies the reverse, that monarchy only exists in the eyes of its subjects. It is a democratic portrait, a joke at monarchy's expense, and the full extent of the naughtiness lies in the title, Reigning Queens. Many of Warhol's portraits in this period were of New York transvestites, and the candy colours of his Queen Elizabeth II are similar to the high-saturation colours of his transvestite portraits. Warhol's work also echoes Jamie Reid's 1977 punk image of the Queen with a safety pin through her nose. If Reid turned her into a punk, Warhol's 80s portrait turns her into a Manhattan clubber.

Did she like it? The Queen's opinion of this portrait is not recorded. However, her subjects seem to like it. The National Portrait Gallery promotes it on T-shirts, mouse mats and playing cards. Royal re-branders can learn a lot from Warhol - except that they won't enjoy the political lesson. The Queen looks more human here because she is treated not as monarchs are meant to be, but as a celebrity like any other, part of the long list of famous people Warhol depicted, from Marilyn Monroe to Mick Jagger. May she rule for, ooh, another 15 minutes.

Where is it? The National Portrait Gallery, London WC2 (020-7306 0055).

fields.headline: Should speeding motorists face jail?
fields.trailText: Steven Toole of transport safety pressure group PACTS argues that this week's Home Office plans to introduce a new crime of excessive speeding would reduce the road death toll. Andrew Howard of the Automobile Association maintains that such a halfway house crime will draw police attention away from the really dangerous driving. Read the debate and have your say here.
fields.body:
Steven Toole of transport safety pressure group PACTS argues that this week's Home Office plans to introduce a new crime of excessive speeding would reduce the road death toll. Andrew Howard of the Automobile Association maintains that such a halfway house crime will draw police attention away from the really dangerous driving. Read the debate and have your say here.

Dear Andrew,

I hope we can agree on one issue: speeding is a contributory factor in too many road crashes. Government research suggests that speeding is a factor in as many as one in three crashes. It comes in two forms: "excess" speed, which means breaking the legal limit, and "inappropriate" speed, going too fast for the road conditions.

We need to be ready to punish, and to punish heavily. Research and campaign officer, Parliamentary Advisory Council on Transport Safety

Dear Steven,

I would never disagree with what you say about the role of speed in accidents. But I have trouble with exemplary penalties, and we must be talking about exemplary penalties: prison is the most serious penalty society can impose.

As the offence of dangerous driving can already send a driver to prison, this discussion has to be about speeding where a conviction for dangerous driving cannot be secured. This could cover the driver who misses a 30mph limit sign and hurtles on, oblivious, at 60, because the current signing regulations for 30mph limits are so inadequate. Or the man who does 100-plus on an empty motorway. Some punishment is appropriate for both, but neither is a wanton risk-taker who endangers life and deserves exemplary penalties.

To stop speed accidents, we need to win the hearts and minds argument. We need action that can be seen to stop accidents and improve the quality of life for those who live near the roads; action that will be seen by all as reasonable, where offenders will be seen to be foolish, not unlucky. Sending a few more drivers to prison won't do that.

Yours,
Andrew Howard,
Head of Road Safety Motoring Policy Unit, The Automobile Association

Dear Andrew,

Your argument would be convincing if we were convicting dangerous drivers effectively. We are not. The 1988 North review of road traffic law anticipated an increase in successful convictions, both for dangerous driving and for death by dangerous driving. But the reality has been very different: there has been a consistent decline over the last 10 years in the number (and proportion) of findings of guilt.

I would argue that there is a clear need for a new charge of excessive speeding, which would include a jailing option for serial speeders and wanton risk-takers. It would include those driving at 60mph in a 30 zone. As most 30mph zones are in built-up areas, these drivers clearly do endanger life. The need to slow down is obvious to most considerate drivers.

Excessive speeding impairs a driver's ability comparably with alcohol and drugs. If we are to win the battle of hearts and minds, we should have a range of sentencing options comparable to those for drinking and driving, for which a six-month jail sentence is available. By letting persistent excessive speeders get away with their actions, we are not signalling that we wish to improve the life for the community.

Yours,
Steven

Dear Steven,

I must agree with you about the problems with the offences of dangerous driving and causing death by dangerous driving. But just because we can't make these offences work, why introduce others? Let's make the existing law more effective.

There is a real risk that "bad driving" offences will become a thing of the past. They mustn't. We cannot have a system where the only offences that are pursued are those that can be automatically detected, quantitatively proved and administratively processed - six miles per hour over the limit means a fine, 30 over the limit means prison. We need a system where serious charges will also follow from aggressive driving and driving in contradiction of the Highway Code. This would be better than concentrating on those who exceed a statistical milepost, because otherwise we will have a system that will ignore those who do not.

We want irresponsible drivers to understand that very bad driving will be punished very severely. Introducing a halfway house offence with a severe penalty will allow the real problem of the law against dangerous driving to be put to the side. Let's make sure the government tackles the problem.

Yours,
Andrew

Dear Andrew,

You're right to highlight very bad driving, which includes speeders, and to argue that serious charges must follow from these offences. But this can't be pursued effectively without sufficient resources. I would have more confidence that it could be if enough police officers were on road traffic duties, but as we know, this number has halved over the last decade. Traffic policing is not a priority for many forces: this needs to be reversed.

I re-emphasise that a jail sentence should be used as an option only for the serial offender when other options have failed. I believe that educational opportunities are important, especially for the "unlucky" driver who has only offended once and is most likely to be deterred by a fine, points on the licence, and a warning.

The recent government national road safety strategy has set a target of reducing by 40% those killed and seriously injured on the roads in the next 10 years. It has also announced a review of penalties for motoring offences, something on which many MPs have strong views. I support this review and hope that jail will be considered as a potential option for dealing with the serial offender.

Yours,
Steven

Dear Steven,

If we are looking at prison for the persistent repeat offender, in a world where bad driving, not just speed limit breaking, is detected and punished, then I'm happier. But is this the whole answer?

In your first letter you talked about "hearts and minds": the need to get public acceptance of safety and speed. If this is a goal, should we concentrate so much on offences and penalties? Or should we pay at least equal attention to getting people to buy in? In recent times, all the public has heard about are new types of speed cameras, new ways of funding cameras and raised speeding fines, with police boasts of increased speed convictions. Hardly hearts and minds, more like all stick and no carrot.

We need to tackle the genuine problems faced by drivers. AA Foundation research shows that they don't understand why apparently similar roads have different limits They don't understand speed limit signing rules. We all pass speed cameras, or speed camera signs, yet can't be sure of the limit. And we see cameras without signs and signs without cameras. These things must be sorted out.

Let's review all speed limits, and either make them reasonable to drivers or take steps to explain why they are not. Then the hearts and minds argument can be won. Drivers caught speeding will be considered foolish, not unlucky. The roads will be safer, better places.

Yours,
Andrew

Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety
The AA

webTitle: Vatican takes a walk on the wild side

fields.headline: Vatican takes a walk on the wild side
fields.standfirst: Half a century after its birth, rock is finally knockin' on heaven's door
fields.trailText: The Vatican has announced that rock music is not diabolical on the eve of a May Day concert headlined by Pope John Paul II and the embodiment of sex, drugs and walking on the wild side, Lou Reed. Signalling detente after decades of mutual loathing, the Vatican will on Monday allow a papal Mass in Rome to mutate into a rock concert.
fields.body:
The Vatican has announced that rock music is not diabolical on the eve of a May Day concert headlined by Pope John Paul II and the embodiment of sex, drugs and walking on the wild side, Lou Reed. Signalling detente after decades of mutual loathing, the Vatican will on Monday allow a papal Mass in Rome to mutate into a rock concert.

More than 600,000 people are expected to watch the Pope celebrate a highlight of his jubilee, or holy year, before giving way to rockers not known for Christian family values. The line-up of Reed, Alanis Morissette and the Eurythmics was agreed by the 79-year-old pontiff, but he will leave before they come on stage. The show was going ahead on the understanding that it would convey a religious message, said a Vatican spokesman.

Commentators in Italy hailed the collaboration, dedicated to workers and cancelling third world debt, as a marriage. Fernando Charrier, the bishop in charge of the Vatican's May Day celebrations, was more prosaic. "Do not be astonished. Rock is an expression of today's world, particularly dear to the young. All [forms of] human expressions, when they have dignity, command respect. I do not believe that there has ever existed a [form of] rock that is diabolical.

"At most I think that there can be some diabolical personalities, because real human beings can do good, but also bad. The concert is not a way to consecrate rock, but a chance to to give space to a form of expression widely shared."

Lou Reed, the 58-year-old founder of Velvet Underground, once said that he used heroin, cocaine, LSD, amphetamines and cannabis just to attain equilibrium. "Certain drugs don't even get you high, they just get you normal."

Walk on the Wild Side, his 1970s hit, is about a risk-taking transvestite. A Vatican official said Reed was a reformed character leading a decent life. The selection of Alanis Morissette, who contributed to the Church-baiting film Dogma, has also been greeted with surprise. The Vatican is presuming that she and Reed will avoid songs likely to cause offence.

It will be the Pope's first brush with rock's hard edge, but he is far from a pop innocent. A dance single mixed with some of his soundbites reached the top 10 in several European countries last year.

Bob Dylan sang for him at a concert in Bologna three years ago and BB King has presented him with a guitar. The leader of the world's 1bn Catholics was pronounced funky and presented with sunglasses by Bono of U2. The Vatican staged a pop concert with Italian performers in St Peter's square on millennium eve.

The newspaper Il Messaggero yesterday reported that the Vatican had begun to get cold feet about Reed and wanted to distance itself from the concert. No rockers had been invited to its festival of youth in August, it pointed out.

Italian television and city authorities are helping with the Monday's logistics. A giant cross will loom over a stage with screens and speakers, surrounded by the campus of Rome university.

The concert is one of the highlights of the jubilee, a 12-month series of commemorations and prayer which the Vatican holds every 25 years.

This year is the biggest yet and many of the audience are expected to be pilgrims. Surrounded by 600 priests, the ailing pontiff will start the Mass at 10.30am local time. He will pay tribute to workers and plead for debt relief. Andrea Bocelli, a tenor appointed voice of the jubilee, will sing four religious arias accompanied by an orchestra and conducted by Whun Chung.

The Israeli singer Noa will sing Life is Beautiful, the theme from the Holocaust-film of the same title, after which the Pope is expected to return to the Vatican, at 2pm. The Italian bands and singers Agricantus, Bluvertigo, Carmen Consoli, Max Gazze and Irene Grandi will take the stage. As night falls it will be the turn of Morissette, Annie Lennox and Dave Stewart of the Eurythmics and Lou Reed. Video clips are expected to screen greetings from Paul McCartney, Paul Simon and the family of Jimi Hendrix.

The finale will be another surprise: a rendition of Andrew Lloyd Webber's Jesus Christ Superstar. Since its 1971 premiere the musical has been picketed by Christian fundamentalists furious at its alleged trivialisation of the Messiah.

webTitle: Are you having to twist arms to get a good reference?

fields.headline: Are you having to twist arms to get a good reference?
fields.standfirst: Don't throw in the towel until you've explored every possibility
fields.trailText: Don't throw in the towel until you've explored every possibility
fields.body:
A friend of a friend was sacked last year in very unfortunate circumstances. Euphemistically speaking he had been caught indulging in some 'under-the-table' activity while surfing the less salubrious areas of the internet.

To make matters worse he had apparently received a warning for the same behaviour six months previously. Unfortunately there is no up-to-date information as to his current employment.

Schadenfreude aside, this (true) anecdote throws into sharp relief the problem of progressing to a new job when you've messed things up in your current position. And if you think you can blag your way through, the small matter of the employer's reference could well be your undoing.

References play a central and important role in the recruitment process and most offers are still subject to a satisfactory one, says Kate Dann, chairman of the Association of Search and Selection Consultants. Unsavoury habits are the least of most prospective employers' worries: they are on the look out for candidates who have exaggerated their qualifications or, worse still, might have been involved in fraudulent activities in the past.

The ASSC has carried out research which states that as many as one in four job seekers will be dishonest to some extent on their CV. And 40% of top companies have been victims of fraud at least once in the last year and a half.

In light of these figures it's easy to see why, far from being a formality, references can have a pivotal role in your employment prospects. So whose name should appear at the bottom of your CV and to what extent can you influence what they are going to say?

Carl Gilleard, chief executive at the Association of Graduate Recruiters, advises new graduates to include an academic reference and also one from a previous employer - but to ask them first.

"I get a bit cheesed off when I'm writing references for people who haven't the manners to ring me up first and that might influence what I write," says Gilleard. "And I would always have a conversation with them first. It gives them a hook to hang the reference to.

"I saw one reference and it was demeaning. I wondered if that person knew the reference was saying these things about him. He could have remained unemployed for years."

For non-academic references Gilleard reckons graduates should even go back to summer job employers. "A lot of graduates play down their work experience whereas I think it's very valuable. Go to an employer and ask if they would be happy to do it. Then say 'the sort of things I would like you

to write are: how reliable I was' etc. If someone is not keen, don't push it, otherwise you will generate a reference that is not relevant."

Higher up the career ladder, this approach is just as valid. Angela Baron, an adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development, points out that employers can be nervous about what they write since they could end up in court.

"If someone has done a good job and they sue for damages to their career resulting from a reference, the employer can be liable for quite a lot of money. But also if they don't disclose something which subsequently damages the new employer's business the new employer can sue as well."

Why not exploit this apprehension, then, and discuss the content with your employer direct? That way if they are planning to include an unflattering opinion that's not based on any fact you can dispute it at that stage and the employer will probably back down.

Similarly, if the employer normally supplies references but refuses to in your case (there's no legal obligation to do so) you might be able to sue because they're damaging your career prospects, says Baron. Again this problem could be solved at an earlier stage.

But in the unlikely scenario that a job offer is blown out of the water by an unfair reference you could do worse than following Mr Spring's example. A few years ago his job offer was withdrawn after Guardian Insurance's reference told the new employer not to take him on. He won his case.

But if you are expecting a negative reference and there's nothing you can do about it because it's based on fact, the best policy, says Kate Dann, is honesty.

"There's nothing worse than finding something out and being unprepared for it. The best policy is to tell them at the interview. That way whoever is looking at the reference will know what to expect."

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Midwifery
fields.standfirst: Margaret McCradie, a community midwife in Lanarkshire, Scotland talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Margaret McCradie, a community midwife in Lanarkshire, Scotland talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
It doesn't matter how many births you attend, it's always an amazing experience - and I say that as someone who's attended a fair few. As a community midwife I am attached to the local maternity hospital but spend most of my time visiting mothers in their own homes. Having a baby can be a frightening experience, particularly if it's the first, so a lot of the job is explaining to the mother what is going to happen and reassuring them that it's perfectly normal.

The first contact I have with the expectant mother is usually after 12 weeks and it comes as a referral from the local GP. The immediate priority is to persuade her she needs to look after herself by eating well, drinking very moderately and giving up smoking. Over the course of the pregnancy we will probably see them between eight and ten times and at each visit I measure things like blood pressure, their weight and making sure everything is fine with the baby. I'll arrange the regular ultrasound scans and, if need be, carry it out.

Before the big day I run a series of pre-natal classes where we talk about the actual birth, how the father can help and I'll show them round the labour ward. I'll also help the mother to produce a 'birth plan' which will define the type of birth she wants and what pain relief she prefers. We also try to drum in why breast feeding is so important.

Although I am usually looking after between 50 and 100 mothers at any one time I only attend a birth every couple of weeks. Even though most of my mothers will have already had one child, almost all still elect to go into hospital and I am on call two to three nights week to accompany them.

As soon as the contractions start I'll get a call and then it's just a case of monitoring the situation until its time to go in to hospital - hopefully the whole thing is very calm.

At this hospital the mothers who have had uncomplicated births tend to go home very quickly and I'll make several visits during the following days to make sure all is well - particularly the breast feeding.

Because we spend a lot of time with the mothers during what is a very eventful period of their lives we can become very close - especially if it's a home birth. It'll come as no surprise that there are a few girls in Lanarkshire with Margaret as a middle name.

As a community midwife I am attached to the local maternity hospital but spend most of my time visiting mothers in their own homes. Having a baby can be a frightening experience, particularly if it's the first, so a lot of the job is explaining to the mother what is going to happen and reassuring them that it's perfectly normal. The first contact I have with the expectant mother is usually after 12 weeks and it comes as a referral from the local GP. The immediate priority is to persuade her she needs to look after herself by eating well, drinking very moderately and giving up smoking. Over the course of the pregnancy we will probably see them between eight and ten times and at each visit I measure things like blood pressure, their weight and making sure everything is fine with the baby. I'll arrange the regular ultrasound scans and, if need be, carry it out. Before the big day I run a series of pre-natal classes where we talk about the actual birth, how the father can help and I'll show them round the labour ward. Although I am usually looking after between 50 and 100 mothers at any one time I only attend a birth every couple of weeks. Even though most of my mothers will have already had one child, almost all still elect to go into hospital and I am on call two to three nights week to accompany them. webTitle: How to socialise outside of office hours

fields.headline: How to socialise outside of office hours
fields.standfirst: A drink or two after work is good for 'bonding' but don't drop your guard
fields.trailText: A drink or two after work is good for 'bonding' but don't drop your guard
fields.body:
After-work drinking is a particularly English sport. Instead of heading home to partners or mates, huge numbers of office workers storm the nearest pub to drink and discuss the day - often until closing time.

"I see my friends at the weekend," says IT recruitment adviser Nick Wells, "but in the week I hang out with people from work. Everyone from our firm goes to the same pub - it's like a members club and it's a really great way to meet people from other departments. Occasionally there's a few embarrassed faces the next day but people rarely overstep the mark."

Socialising with work colleagues is an important part of office life - and surprisingly it's often the hardest part to get right. "After-work socialising is a very blurry area," says business consultant Tom Peterson.

"At work there are structures and routines - and when we are socialising with friends then we are relaxed and things are easy. Socialising with workmates is somewhere between the two - and it can be hard, particularly when you start in a new company with unfamiliar people, to get the balance right."

No-one knows this better than Lucy Jones, who works as a solicitor in a large legal firm. "We were at a wine bar for someone's leaving do, and I found myself sitting next to Angus, my head of department. We were chatting and getting on very well and I failed to notice the amount of wine I was drinking." All was fine, until Lucy decided to tackle some inter-office matters.

"Angus seemed so approachable that I started to tell him how we all knew that he didn't like the guy who was head of our section - and how embarrassing it was that he constantly put him down and patronised him in front of us. At the time he seemed really interested and asked me for more details - which at the time I was delighted to give."

Despite hoping that all would be forgotten the next morning, Jones was summoned to the department head's office and informed that action would have to be taken. "Nothing dreadful happened, but there was a long meeting between Angus and our head of section. I felt awful, in all ways. But I learned my lesson. Now, whenever we go out I drink one glass of wine and then one glass of water - and I never sit next to anyone important."

The key thing to remember is that what happens at work gatherings can never be totally distanced from the office - and so in some ways you can never truly relax. "Spending time with colleagues in the pub or at dinner allows you to get to know them better, and is great for strengthening relationships.

But you have to be aware of the boundaries, says Tom Peterson. "Don't tell them anything you wouldn't normally say in the confines of the office - don't badmouth colleagues simply because you've had a few drinks, or try to sort out work issues. Talk about other things: what you do out of work, films you've seen - neutral topics that allow you to relax."

One of the most dangerous aspects of work socialising is that suddenly people are removed from the safe world of the office into a more sexually-charged space. "I'm a terrible flirt," admits Caroline Moreton, who is an account manager in a PR firm, "and after a few vodka and Red Bulls I do get a bit provocative. The trouble comes when people don't realise that I'm only like that in the pub - and they expect me to be the same in the office. I'm trying to tone down a bit, but I do find it hard."

According to Ros Heaton, of business consultancy Insight, flirting can be fun but the safest policy is to keep things superficial. "Although some women use low-grade flirting within the workplace, things become more complicated in a social environment.

Respect is extremely important in office life and to gain it you must seem professional, not an object of attraction. Flirting is revealing a part of your personality that doesn't really belong in the workplace, which is why it feels exciting. But you have to remember that its the professional side of you that really counts at work."

It can be hard to remember that you are at work when you're on your sixth glass of chardonnay - but getting blind drunk, snogging a partner or throwing up in the toilets will do your career no good at all. "People's perceptions are coloured as much by our behaviour out of the workplace as in it," says Ros Heaton. "If you never go to the pub people think one thing, if you go every night they think another. Drink in moderation, be discreet and resist the temptation to slag off your boss." Oh yes, and leave as soon as the room starts spinning.

If you don't remember anything else...

Socialising with colleagues is not the same as going out with your friends. It may be unfair, but notice is taken on how you behave out of the office - so keep an eye on the booze intake and turn up the charm.

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Learn to haggle
fields.trailText: Learn to haggle
fields.body:
Is there anything worse than being asked at interview what salary you think you're worth? Bodyswerve it, says author Gale Kennedy with one of the following ripostes:

a) "For the right position I'm very willing to be flexible."

b) "I'm not sure I know enough about the job yet. Perhaps after we have discussed more of the details of the job and my qualifications we will both be better able to determine that."

c) "If you are concerned about whether you can afford me, I'm sure that if we decide that this job is a good fit, we will be able to come to a favourable conclusion about salary, too."

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to mapping out your career

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to mapping out your career
fields.trailText: Flexibility can be the key to achieving your ideal career
fields.body:
A. I wish

Ever observed someone else's career and thought I should be so lucky? Delve deeper and in most cases luck plays only a small part in the way their lives have worked out. Those with enviable employment have put considerable effort and planning into getting there.

Chance encounters and unexpected opportunities can have a significant effect on career progression, but first you've got to have talent that's worth spotting. Then make sure you're in the right places to be seen. Good fortune can be elusive, if it doesn't come looking for you.

B. Open to offers

Don't wait for an employer to develop your career; manage it yourself. If you drift and go with the flow there is a chance you could wash up some where pleasant enough. Take control and you decide on the destination. A clear sense of direction is important, but not to the point where it excludes serendipity. By being too focused and single-minded you may miss the lucky break.

C. Route master

An understanding of where you're starting from and where you'd like to end up is essential. Compare how much time you spend researching holiday alternatives and how much on career planning. If there's a great discrepancy it could explain why you find one of these activities more satisfying than the other. Like planning the perfect getaway, mapping out your career progression is not a once-and-for-all task. As you outgrow destinations and activities, explore alternatives.

webTitle: Help: I'm working for a company android!

fields.headline: Help: I'm working for a company android!
fields.trailText:
My boss has a really rigid approach to life. Everything has to be done by the rules. She disapproves of me thinking for myself and expects me to know every detail in the company manual and stick to it.
Nuala K, recruitment consultant, Dublin
fields.body:
My boss has a really rigid approach to life. Everything has to be done by the rules. She disapproves of me thinking for myself and expects me to know every detail in the company manual and stick to it.
Nuala K, recruitment consultant, Dublin

Guidelines and codes of conduct are essential: in most cases there are sound reasons for their existence which offer protection to all concerned. When regulations are used sensibly and reviewed for relevance they should prevent rather than cause problems.

What's frustrating is unquestioning acceptance of every decree no matter how outdated and ridiculous. In these circumstances ignoring daft directives is a moral obligation. If you worked in Air Traffic Control, enforcing compliance with all rules would be an acceptable management style; in many other settings it's an indication your boss is one procedure short of a quality manual.

Blind adherence to all regulations is a sure sign of insecurity and lack of intelligence. You're justified in feeling smug and superior, but let that show and you'll undermine her shaky confidence further. That will only make life more difficult for you - those who perceive free thinking as a threat are inevitably control freaks.

Experiment with the easy option of not thinking for yourself. Working to rule is less taxing than being inspired and acting on it. It can, in the right setting bring promotional rewards denied to those who persist in remaining off message. Don't rock the boat and your passage will be smooth, fast and deadly dull. If doing as you're told is not for you, break some rules then jump ship for a bit of adventure.

Email Irene Krechowiecka

webTitle: Oh no... not another exam to revise for

fields.headline: Oh no... not another exam to revise for
fields.standfirst: Is there any value to professional qualifications?
fields.trailText: Is there any value to professional qualifications?
fields.body:
Amanda McKinney, a marketing analyst at Standard Life took two weeks off last June. However, unlike many of her colleagues, McKinney was not using her holiday to relax and unwind from the daily grind.

Instead, she was hard at work studying for the Chartered Institute of Marketing diploma. Two years after graduating from Strathclyde University with a 2.1 in International Business, McKinney had decided she needed to back up her academic success with a professional qualification.

"Marketing is quite competitive," she says, "and I felt it would improve my career opportunities if I could improve my core knowledge."

She isn't alone in believing that professional qualifications can help

when it comes to careers advancement. A recent study of graduate members of the Institute of Personnel and Development - all of whom had completed the

equivalent of a post-graduate diploma - revealed that 99% felt it had proved an appropriate route for career advancement.

But the importance of professional qualifications varies enormously between different industries. In some professions, such as accountancy, a professional qualification is considered a prerequisite for any accountancy

graduate planning to forge a career in the profession.

"Most of our trainees are employed by the big accountancy firms and are planning to go ahead into public practice," says Professor Brian Chiplin, director of

education and training at the Chartered Institute of Accountants. "In this industry credentials are important. It signifies that you've reached a standard and that you are marketable around the world."

The Chartered Institute of Accountants has recently revised the ACA - the chartered accountancy qualification - to make it more business-focused. "If the intellectual qualification is stamped by a university, the professional qualification offers a seal of approval of practical experience," says Chiplin.

While a high-flying accountancy graduate will almost certainly sign up for a professional qualification, in other areas such as marketing or

engineering, young professionals remain free to decide whether or not to add a professional qualification to their bow.

"Engineers have a choice," says Juliet Upton, deputy director of public affairs at the Engineering Council. "They can do their degree and go no further - there is no statutory registration of engineers."

Yet Upton believes that the fact that it is possible to get a job without one has lead many recent entrants into the industry to overlook the benefits associated with a professional qualification. "It demonstrates a professional competence and provides an international standard for knowledge and experience, making it easier to go and work overseas," she says. "It also has a number of personal benefits, such as providing recognition and status, particularly among your industry peers. In addition, once you have a qualification, you're linked into a professional institution which brings with it networking opportunities and career

opportunities such as access to further training courses, industry

publications and mentors. In that respect it is good value."

This view is backed up by David Royston-Lee, chief executive of the

Communication, Advertising and Marketing Education Foundation. The CAM Foundation offers a number of qualifications. At the basic level is the advanced certificate, which can be taken in six subjects within the marketing communications arena including advertising, direct marketing and

sales promotion. Take all six and you get an advanced diploma and you can then go on to study for a higher diploma or higher certificate.

"The emphasis is on giving people who take CAM courses employability within the marketplace and the ability to communicate with clients on all levels of marketing communication," says Royston-Lee.

Sue Zerk, senior manager in marketing communications for British Airways, gained a CAM diploma in advertising four years ago while with a former employer, the Australian Tourist Commission. Recently promoted from head of global advertising at BA, she remains firmly convinced that the knowledge and tools picked up from her CAM studies continue to help her today.

"When you are working, you become very focused on your immediate responsibilities and you rarely get the opportunity to take a more strategic view from a higher level," she says. "If you go beyond this and learn the accepted business models, it gives you new ways of doing things."

For this reason, most graduates follow a similar route to Zerk and McKinney and wait until they have some solid workplace experience before signing up for a professional qualification.

"Some people signed up straight after finals," says McKinney, "but I felt it was better to get work experience because the course is so practical. Study was much more theoretical at university."

Another advantage of waiting until you are in a full-time job before doing a professional qualification is that many employers will offer to finance your studies. Standard Life paid for the cost of McKinney's CIM diploma

and also offered money towards books.

The reason forward-thinking employers are often prepared to do this is because they realise that a professional qualification can add to the worth of their employees.

"BA has excellent development opportunities internally but if people are interested in gaining more knowledge I think it is very important to encourage that," says Zerk. "We encourage people to pursue qualifications as a development opportunity."

A professional qualification demonstrates an individual is committed to a profession - always an advantage in the eyes of an employer. Peter Purdom, director of online careers advisor, workingfutures.com, believes it can sometimes be invaluable.

"If employers advertise and are faced with a myriad of application forms, they arbitrarily shortlist," he says. "They look at degree, professional qualification or sector experience - it's an easy eliminator."

However before you rush out to sign up, be warned. Studying for a

professional qualification is likely to involve sacrificing your spare time.

Budding accountants can spend several years burning the midnight oil to get the necessary professional qualification. In other professions the demands are less rigorous. The CAM Foundation advises prospective students that they

are likely to need to set aside around 50 hours for "guided study" per module. Meanwhile, the Chartered Institute of Marketing suggests that prospective students set aside 90 hours of study time per subject and at each level a student is required to study four subjects.

"It was more work than I thought it would be," says McKinney. "That's why I had to take two weeks off before the exam."

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Perspectives on working at Unilever UK, from both ends of the career ladder
fields.body:
Top rung

Richard Greenhalgh
Aged 55
Chairman Unilever UK

People showing potential - that's how Richard Greenhalgh sums up what his company looks for in a graduate. "We ask ourselves: 'How will they match up in five or ten years time?' We look particularly for leadership and learning skills."

After a career in the group, he now heads the UK division with a workforce of 16,000 producing a turnover of £2.4bn in 1999. The company manufactures foods and home and personal care brands such as Bird's Eye, Flora and Persil. "Nine out of ten sinks have a Unilever product under them," he boasts.

CV to date: Social anthropology degree (Cambridge) followed by posts with Bird's Eye, United Africa International, the foods businesses in Rotterdam and on to Unilever Group.

High point? "Two things, really: in 1996 being part of the biggest shake-up in Unilever for 30 years, and currently being involved in a community project supporting seven schools in Tower Hamlets, east London."

In his present role, Richard has day-to-day responsibility for nine businesses and two research labs in the UK.

The buzz? "The success of the businesses meeting their targets and the launch of brands."

Bottom rung

Georgina Perrott
Aged 23
Sales expenditure accountant Unilever UK

Georgina Perrott chose Unilever because of the range it offered. "The choice of functions sold it to me," she explains. "Finance appealed to me because it provided the chance to see an awful lot of the business."

After graduating from Southampton University (Management Sciences), Georgina was one of ten graduates joining Unilever's finance function in 1998 (around 70 grads are hired in total).

Graduates are part of a five-year programme for "high potential people" - although actual training lasts for 18 months to two years - and includes courses and mentoring. Georgina hopes to qualify as an accountant next November.

Projects to date: She has done management accounting in the corporate centre in London, been part of the annual review team and the Africa business group and worked in the treasury looking at loans for the operating companies.

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: Good times ahead | Book of the week | Event of the week
fields.body:
 Good times ahead: This summer's graduates can look forward to a thriving job market, according to Barclays Bank. Its annual graduate survey claims that 66% of last year's graduates had found permanent employment within six months of leaving university, and that record numbers had been recruited into their desired job, or a graduate position.

 Book of the week: If only you'd got a better degree. Or had rich parents. Or had a nicer boss. Stop making excuses, says author Jay Abraham whose new book is a guide to Getting Everything You Can Out Of All You've Got (Piatkus). Priced £20.00, you can order this hardback by ringing our Cultureshop on 0800 316 6102.

 Event of the week: If your destiny lies in "the meejah" get yourself along to next Friday's Guardian-sponsored Yorkshire Media Careers Information Day at the University of Leeds, where you'll meet all sorts of radio and TV personalities, including Countdown 's Richard Whiteley. For more info call 0113 233 5289 or visit the web site

 Eye eye: The internet might be a great way to find your dream job, but it's still no match for old-fashioned, face-to-face interviews where you can use eye contact and body language to land the post, says a new report. The survey of 300 employers by Yankelovich Partners found that the vast majority dislike the impersonal feel of interviewing online.

 Do lunch: Don't miss the most important hour of your working day, says dietician Gloria Horwitz, who claims we all need the mental and physical break for which lunch hours were designed. "Your body is like a car. Give it no fuel or cheap fuel, and it won't run efficiently. The metabolism is the motor. The rule is, you have to feed the body to make it work."

 Yac-ety yak: Worried about missing calls from potential employers while backpacking after your finals this summer? Telecoms company Yac says more than 15,000 students have signed up to have all their calls redirected to a personal number. For more info see www.yac.com.
