webTitle: Win four months in the sun - and do your bit for the planet

fields.headline: Win four months in the sun - and do your bit for the planet
fields.standfirst: A once-in-a-lifetime chance to study at the Biosphere
fields.trailText: Only a matter of weeks to your finals and still wondering what the point of your degree is? Did you spend Easter cramming for exams which might equip you with first class honours, but won't help you "make a difference"?
fields.body:
Only a matter of weeks to your finals and still wondering what the point of your degree is? Did you spend Easter cramming for exams which might equip you with first class honours, but won't help you "make a difference"?

Let us take you to a place where you'll see a rainforest to your left, a salt water ocean to your right, a coastal fog desert up ahead and a wilderness behind.

Welcome to Biosphere 2, one of the largest living laboratories in the world where researchers are able to conduct large-scale environmental experiments on earth systems. And if you are excited about discovering how you can use your skills and knowledge to benefit the world, we'd like to take you there.

We're offering two lucky readers of Rise the chance to win a 16-week, all-expenses-paid semester at Columbia University's Biosphere 2 Center campus near Tuscon in Arizona, courtesy of Volvo Car Corporation - a prize worth more than £10,000 each.

Biosphere 2 has been converted from an experiment to test the feasibility of humans living in a closed eco-system (see below) to a large-scale ecological laboratory and western branch campus of Columbia University, one of so-called Ivy League schools in the United States. ('Biosphere' means sphere of life.

The term originated with Austrian geologist Eduard Suess in 1875 as a way to describe the envelope around the Earth where life exists. Biosphere 1 is the Earth.)

The 250-acre campus is set in the beautiful Sonaron desert, 30 miles north of Tucson, Arizona and around 200,000 visitors tour the site each year. The campus is a fascinating geological area sitting amidst three separate biomes, created by varying topography, temperatures and rainfall. It is an archaeologically-rich area with extensive Native American history.

No other university has a research and education facility like the Biosphere 2. The building itself is an air-tight greenhouse covering three acres and seven million cubic feet of volume and has a unique capacity for sensing and controlling the environment within.

Sensors monitor the vital statistics such as temperature, light, humidity, carbon dioxide and other qualities of the air and soil.

Researchers can control many of these variables by varying rainfall, temperature and even carbon dioxide levels to mimic different environmental conditions.

For example, Biosphere 2 is the only laboratory in the world where a mature grove of cottonwood trees can be grown under controlled conditions permitting researchers to examine the effects of different levels of carbon dioxide on the growth of the trees.

Atmospheric carbon dioxide has been increasing since the last Ice Age. Today, carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere is the highest it has been in a million years, caused in part by burning coal, oil and natural gas.

If we continue to depend on these fuels for our energy supply, there are great concerns about how plants and their systems will respond to this increase in carbon dioxide.

The Volvo Environmental Scholarships - open to any student graduating at a UK university this summer - are the result of a partnership between Volvo and Columbia University aimed at better preparing students for future roles as decision makers in society.

It doesn't matter what your degree discipline is: Columbia University believes its multi-disciplinary curriculum is the best way of acquiring environmental knowledge because real world issues involve a wide range of fields including economics, culture, sociology, technology, and law.

Its inter-disciplinary courses are designed to help students understand global problems and to develop vital leadership skills. Students are challenged to think critically and to solve the problems we face as a planet.

On your arrival, you'll be enrolled to the Earth Semester which this year runs from September 4 to December 21. During the Earth Semester, you'll learn the fundamental science of earth and ecological systems, examining how science is used, not used or misued in human management of ecosystems.

You'll be given a chance to apply lessons learned from the Biosphere 2 and regional case studies to the question of how people can better approach environmental problems on a global scale. You'll also complete a semester-long independent project.

The course will include a three-week module on successful environmental management practices developed jointly by Columbia and Volvo. Columbia forged a partnership with Volvo Car Corporation in February 1999 to promote cooperation between research institutions and industry toward common environmental goals.

Students live in fully-equipped apartments with kitchen, dining room, living area and full bath. Bedrooms are double or triple occupancy. Free laundry facilities are available 24 hours a day.

A shuttle service provides weekly access to shopping and entertainment for students without cars.

Volvo already runs successful environmental scholarships for American students at Biosphere 2, but the company is keen to make it an international scholarship - our two lucky readers will be the first outside the US to be admitted.

"We regard the scholarships as a catalyst to speed up environmental awareness and skills among the the young talented minds who will be the future's decision makers," explains Volvo's environmental manager John Pitts.

"Being a Volvo Environmental Scholar means becoming an ambassador for proactive environmental action."

The Biosphere 2 web site at www.bio2.edu provides more information on how being an inaugural UK scholar could help your prospects - and those of the planet.

How to get there

The Volvo Environmental Scholarship is open to any student - from any degree discipline at any university - who is graduating this summer.

To enter, simply tell us in 250 words or less how you believe the Earth Semester at Columbia University's Biosphere 2 campus would enhance your career and help you to make a difference to the environment.

Your entry must be accompanied by a CV, which should include at least one academic reference.

Then send your entry and CV to:
The Volvo Environmental Scholarships,
c/o Rise,
The Guardian,
119 Farringdon Road,
London EC1R 3ER.

Closing date is May 16 and the decision of the judges - who will include representatives from Volvo, Columbia University and The Guardian - will be final.

Full terms and conditions are available on request.

Good luck!

fields.headline: Agent for change
fields.trailText: Ashley Lumsden, Campaign manager and electoral agent for Liberal Democrat mayoral candidate Susan Kramer
fields.body:
Name: Ashley Lumsden

Status: Campaign manager and electoral agent for Liberal Democrat mayoral candidate Susan Kramer. Also a local councillor - all at the age of 26.

Past: Read maths at London University. Temped with House of Fraser for three months, then became a merchandiser. Promoted to business analyst and finally marketing finance analyst. Dabbled in politics and became Lambeth councillor two years ago.

Present: Responsible for keeping campaign team motivated and for setting strategy, including design and content of campaign leaflets.

Future: "Marketing and strategy - whether for a consultancy or an individual company."

Strengths: "Good judgement. I can also manage and motivate a large team involved in complex projects."

Weaknesses: "Delegating -I want to do everything."

Wisdom: "Learn from other people. Storing away the advice and experience you have is a way to gain several years of experience in a very short period of time."

References: www.susankramer.org

fields.headline: Love at first bite
fields.standfirst: Mushrooms on toast
fields.trailText: Mushrooms on toast
fields.body:
You can get fancy, and use chanterelles, morels or cepes, but your average button mushroom does the trick admirably, if treated right. You can add oomph by chopping a bit of onion and a rasher of bacon, and frying them up before you add the mushrooms. Serves 2.

2 slices of white bread, fried crisp in a little butter

340g button mushrooms

70g butter

Juice of 1/4 lemon

4 tbsp double cream

Salt & pepper

Chopped parsley (optional)

Melt the butter in a frying pan. Brush any dirt off the mushrooms, and fry until golden and slightly soft. Add the lemon juice, then the cream. Bring the cream to bubbling point and hubble-bubble away for a minute or so. Add chopped parsley if you feel like it. Season and serve.

fields.headline: Visitors to dome reach 2m
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Millennium Dome organisers yesterday welcomed their two millionth visitor - leaving them eight months to attract 8m more.
fields.body:
Millennium Dome organisers yesterday welcomed their two millionth visitor - leaving them eight months to attract 8m more.

Christine Sandlan, of Allhallows, near Rochester, Kent, with her children Richard, 16, and Vicki, 13, won a series of prizes at the attraction in Greenwich, south east London.

But the New Millennium Company faces an uphill struggle to reach its break-even target of 10m visitors this year.

Despite longer opening hours, half-price admission offers and special attractions, the Dome welcomed only 120,072 visitors in the seven days from April 17, which included the Easter holiday.

fields.headline: Miami at odds
fields.standfirst: Police chief resigns after mayor attacks Elian raidThe Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: The power-struggle within Miami's city authorities - fuelled by an ethnically based row over the handling of the Elian Gonzalez affair - erupted in turmoil yesterday when the police chief angrily resigned, describing the mayor as "divisive and destructive".
fields.body:
The power-struggle within Miami's city authorities - fuelled by an ethnically based row over the handling of the Elian Gonzalez affair - erupted in turmoil yesterday when the police chief angrily resigned, describing the mayor as "divisive and destructive".

William O'Brien said he refused to serve under Mayor Joe Carollo, a Cuban-American who had fiercely supported Elian's Miami relatives in their fight to keep the young refugee in Miami, defying a US justice department ruling.

After Miami police took part in an operation to remove Elian from his temporary Little Havana home on Saturday, Mr Carollo publicly called for the police chief's dismissal for failing to inform him of the raid. He also accused the police of over-zealous crowd control during the ensuing protests by Cuban-Americans in Miami's Little Havana.

After the city manager, Donald Warshaw, refused to fire Mr O'Brien, the mayor fired Mr Warshaw on Thursday night.

Standing alongside Mr Warshaw yesterday, a defiant Mr O'Brien said he was retiring early because "the healing has got to start for this community".

"I refuse to be the chief of police in a city that has someone as divisive and destructive as Joe Carollo as mayor," he said.

Mr Warshaw, who was Miami's police chief before Mr O'Brien, said: "I'm sad for all that's happening in our city. Please be calm. The eyes of the world are watching us."

webTitle: Rover faces oblivion as deal fails

fields.headline: Rover faces oblivion as deal fails
fields.standfirst:
24,000 West Midlands jobs at risk after Alchemy pulls out of talks to buy Longbridge blaming BMW

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: BMW left 24,000 West Midlands workers in a race against time last night after takeover talks for Britain's biggest car plant collapsed just hours before the deal was due to be completed.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Mark Milner  and John Hooper in Berlin
fields.body:
BMW left 24,000 West Midlands workers in a race against time last night after takeover talks for Britain's biggest car plant collapsed just hours before the deal was due to be completed.

The German motor manufacturer threatened to shut Longbridge in Birmingham, wreaking economic havoc in the heart of England, if a new buyer is not found by the end of next month.

Though BMW said yesterday that it was open to offers, the only bid left on the table is an offer from the Phoenix consortium, led by the former Rover chief executive John Towers, which it rejected earlier this week.

The Phoenix plan has workforce backing because it would maintain volume car production at the plant.

But BMW's cool response, and private reservations among some union leaders who claim Phoenix needs up to £700m state backing, suggests the consortium might struggle to convince the Munich board to hand over Longbridge.

BMW spokesman Hubert Bergmann was last night pessimistic about the Phoenix bid. "I think we have never been in negotiations with Phoenix," he said. "We believe that the bid is not in an appropriate way, that it gives us a clear view of how to continue the business."

A deal with Alchemy had been thought to be a near-certainty. But yesterday morning BMW said that talks had been called off.

"BMW Group will now pursue alternative routes to bring to an end its involvement in Rover Car Operations. Those routes include the sale of Rover Car Operations or its closure. A decision which of those alternatives will be implemented will be taken during the course of next month," its statement said.

Though Rover Car Operations refers directly to the Longbridge plant, one source close to BMW suggested yesterday there could be wider implications if BMW were unable to find a buyer for the plant. "The entire production of Rover and MG is involved," the source said.

BMW said it had been unable to reach agreement with Alchemy on "certain conditions of contract". Among the sticking points was who would pay potentially huge compensation claims from Rover's 320 franchised dealers in the UK and another 500 worldwide.

BMW introduced a series of complex legal deals that Alchemy described as a "nightmare" and claimed could take up to three years to unpick.

Jon Moulton, head of Alchemy, said: "I think the end position was that they simply had better economics available, from another route - I'm not sure which one - than they did out of doing our deal."

The debacle poses a huge political and industrial test for the government, which fears it would be severely punished at the polls if Longbridge closed.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, held emergency telephone talks with the chairman of Rover, Werner Samann, after again being caught on the hop. Professor Samann told Mr Byers that BMW's exclusivity agreement with Alchemy had ended and promised to make details available to Phoenix.

Mr Byers also spoke to Mr Towers to encourage the bid. Tony Blair, who recently held a car summit in Downing Street amid fears the industry is collapsing, has asked to be kept fully informed.

The Department of Trade and Industry tried to put a positive light on yesterday's development by stating: "BMW's announcement provides a new opportunity for proposals to come forward which offer a viable future for Longbridge and which might provide more jobs than under the Alchemy proposal. Our efforts over the next few weeks will be directed towards achieving a successful outcome which will serve the interests of the workers at Longbridge and the wider community in the West Midlands."

John Hemming, a supporter of the Phoenix consortium, said there was now a "window of opportunity" for his bid. "Yesterday, it was being said through the misinterpretation of documentation that Phoenix was dead in the water. It is now quite clear that Alchemy is dead in the water," he said.

A disappointed Mr Moulton offered no words of comfort to the Longbridge workers celebrating his failure as he predicted the factory would now shut. "Another sale or a closure within a month? I'm afraid I'm not optimistic on another sale so I think closure is a very likely option," he said.

BMW's proposed £1.85bn sale of the Solihull Land Rover plant to Ford is unaffected and is expected to be completed within months.

Longbridge, Solihull and Cowley together support an estimated 50,000 jobs in the West Midlands, 8% of the region's manufacturing.

The 24,000 at risk over Longbridge, including 9,000 in the plant itself, are paid an average £25,000 a year and a government taskforce has warned that few employees would find similar jobs.

Bill Morris, head of the T&GWU transport union, urged BMW not to take the "nuclear option" and shut Longbridge. "They have a legal responsibility and a moral responsibility to take the best route to secure the maximum number of jobs," he said.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU engineering union, said: "The possibility of closure is too frightening to contemplate and I am sure that BMW would not want the relentless bad publicity it would bring."

Among the sticking points was who would pay potentially huge compensation claims from Rover's 320 franchised dealers in the UK and another 500 worldwide. BMW introduced a series of complex legal deals that Alchemy described as a "nightmare" and claimed could take up to three years to unpick. Jon Moulton, head of Alchemy, said: "I think the end position was that they simply had better economics available, from another route - I'm not sure which one - than they did out of doing our deal." The debacle poses a huge political and industrial test for the government, which fears it would be severely punished at the polls if Longbridge closed. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, held emergency telephone talks with the chairman of Rover, Werner Samann, after again being caught on the hop. Professor Samann told Mr Byers that BMW's exclusivity agreement with Alchemy had ended and promised to make details available to Phoenix. Mr Byers also spoke to Mr Towers to encourage the bid. Tony Blair, who recently held a car summit in Downing Street amid fears the industry is collapsing, has asked to be kept fully informed. The Department of Trade and Industry tried to put a positive light on yesterday's development by stating: "BMW's announcement provides a new opportunity for proposals to come forward which offer a viable future for Longbridge and which might provide more jobs than under the Alchemy proposal. Our efforts over the next few weeks will be directed towards achieving a successful outcome which will serve the interests of the workers at Longbridge and the wider community in the West Midlands." John Hemming, a supporter of the Phoenix consortium, said there was now a "window of opportunity" for his bid. "Yesterday, it was being said through the misinterpretation of documentation that Phoenix was dead in the water. It is now quite clear that Alchemy is dead in the water," he said. A disappointed Mr Moulton offered no words of comfort to the Longbridge workers celebrating his failure as he predicted the factory would now shut. "Another sale or a closure within a month? I'm afraid I'm not optimistic on another sale so I think closure is a very likely option," he said. BMW's proposed £1.85bn sale of the Solihull Land Rover plant to Ford is unaffected and is expected to be completed within months. Longbridge, Solihull and Cowley together support an estimated 50,000 jobs in the West Midlands, 8% of the region's manufacturing. The 24,000 at risk over Longbridge, including 9,000 in the plant itself, are paid an average £25,000 a year and a government taskforce has warned that few employees would find similar jobs. Bill Morris, head of the T&GWU transport union, urged BMW not to take the "nuclear option" and shut Longbridge. "They have a legal responsibility and a moral responsibility to take the best route to secure the maximum number of jobs," he said. Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU engineering union, said: "The possibility of closure is too frightening to contemplate and I am sure that BMW would not want the relentless bad publicity it would bring." fields.headline: Teachers in holiday strike threat
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A teachers' leader yesterday threatened the government with national strike action in protest against plans to cut the traditional six-week summer holiday in a shake-up of the school year.
fields.body:
A teachers' leader yesterday threatened the government with national strike action in protest against plans to cut the traditional six-week summer holiday in a shake-up of the school year.

Many education authorities are considering reorganising the academic year into five terms, instead of the current three, which would mean cutting the six-week summer break to four weeks and lengthening other holidays.

A national commission representing authorities in England is expected to recommend in a report in June that authorities switch to the new system.

Delegates attending the National Union of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers' annual conference in Llandudno, however, yesterday voted unanimously to oppose the plans which they said were "change for change's sake". Teachers needed the long holiday to recuperate before the start of the autumn term, they argued.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the union, said later: "If they tried to impose it nationally we would have to respond on a national basis. We would consider anything up to and including strike action."

One tactic under discussion by the union is to stick with the traditional timetable and refuse to recognise changes to the school year. "If that means turning up to school when there are no kids there and not turning up when there are, so be it," Mr De Gruchy said. In Newham, east London, teachers staged a one-day strike earlier this year in protest at the proposals.

Supporters of the five-term year say the long summer holiday can lead to children forgetting much of what they learned during the previous year, and frequently use research based on similar practice in America to underline the educational advantages.

The NASUWT claims the research is flawed. Mr De Gruchy said: "We are very strongly opposed to the five-year term. It's all about parents wanting teachers to look after their kids during the summer holiday so they can go to work. That's the real agenda. If they introduced this, headteachers would go back in September more tired and exhausted than they already are."

Paul Mundt, a member of the union's national executive, told delegates on the final day of the conference: "All of this is change for change's sake. There is no logical research as to why we should do this. We all know we need an extended break at the end of the year to de-stress, wind down and look forward to getting away and out of school so we can survive."

Many city technology colleges already use the five-term year, although delegates complained that there was no evidence that it has boosted academic results. Other state schools, including Woodlands primary school in Grimsby, are operating the new-style year in pilot schemes. Oxfordshire will become the next authority to consider the changes when it launches a consultation process next month, delegates heard.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, has said he will leave it up to authorities to decide for themselves. But the national commission set up by the Local Government Association in January to look at the changes believes there is a strong case for reform. Its chairman, Christopher Price, a former Labour chairman of the Commons education select committee, has already warned that retaining the status quo is not an option.

Richard Hinton, a delegate from Cannock in Staffordshire, said teachers in his area had voted the plans down by a two-to-one majority. He said the five-term year was "like a disease" spreading through the country. "We have had the wonderful prospect of parents pushing their ideas forward to amend our working conditions. I find it deplorable."

Margaret Morrissey, of the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations, said she supported the long summer break, which gave parents the chance to spend more time with their children, but was disappointed by the threat of industrial action. She said: "Parents will be very unhappy about it because it is their children who will suffer."

webTitle: Why Marie Stopes' verse made Rudyard Kipling curse

fields.headline: Why Marie Stopes' verse made Rudyard Kipling curse
fields.standfirst: Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Rudyard Kipling's If - the most popular poem of the last century - which came to embody the cult of the stiff upper lip, could have been very different indeed if the feminist Marie Stopes had had her way.
fields.body:
Rudyard Kipling's If - the most popular poem of the last century - which came to embody the cult of the stiff upper lip, could have been very different indeed if the feminist Marie Stopes had had her way.

Stopes, the famously overbearing author of the first modern sex manual, Married Love, wrote to the equally grouchy poet in 1925 asking him to change the last line from "And - which is more - you'll be a Man, my son!" to the less elegant "And you will lead the race o'er ground you've won."

Stopes wanted the line altered to encompass women so she could use it to inspire the nurses in her new family planning clinics. Just in case Kipling might have been a little hard of understanding, she underlined her every reference to women. "She was an underlining sort of person," said Elizabeth Inglis, the manuscripts librarian at Sussex University, where the letter goes on show next month.

Kipling gave her proposal short shrift. He took a dim view of Stopes' lifestyle - she believed it was every husband's duty to satisfy his wife and bullied her own husband into accepting her many lovers - and was not keen on her clinics.

Meryl Macdonald, a cousin of Kipling who has written a new biography of him, The Long Trail, said he would probably have been astonished by the sheer gall of the woman.

"It's telling that he replied to her in a single sentence," she said. "I am sure he said a few words privately. Contrary to what a lot of people think, he was very open to criticism of his writing, remarkably so in fact. It was his drawing which he got a bit crotchety about."

Kipling's reply is the model of restraint, proving he heeded his own poem's advice to "keep your head when all about you/ Are losing theirs _" He wrote: "If a precedent of this kind were established we might end by sanctioning the change of every line."

Stopes' response to his refusal is not known, though she was not normally a woman to take no for an answer.

A fanatical believer in eugenics, Stopes campaigned to stop poor and disabled people having children, and accused her only son of committing a crime against his "country, his family and his children" by marrying a shortsighted woman. When he refused to dump Mary Wallis, his childhood sweetheart, she boycotted the wedding.

It was not the only indignity Harry Stopes-Roe suffered at his mother's hands. She was also convinced trousers damaged the genitals and made him wear skirts as a child.

But he later insisted that his unorthodox upbringing did him no harm: "What happened in my childhood was a long time ago and I am prepared to laugh at it now."

fields.headline: Gardening
fields.trailText: In a desperate attempt to banish the rainclouds by an act of sympathetic magic, we bring you the hottest titles from the world of the green-fingered...
fields.body:
In a desperate attempt to banish the rainclouds by an act of sympathetic magic, we bring you the hottest titles from the world of the green-fingered. It must be noted, however, that the number one book is devoted to ambling around looking at other people's horticultural successes rather than getting mulch under your own fingernails. The Yellow Book, as it is fondly known among initiates, will tell you how to find more clematis than you can shake a stick at, where to go for the best Alpine garden around and when you'll discover the most gardens open. According to gardening doyen David Hessayon, it "is more than a really useful book - it is an institution".

Meanwhile, Anna Pavord's account of the dot.com phenomenon of its time continues to sell. According to reviews, The Tulip "does what Longitude did for clocks and what Fermat's Last Theorem did for maths". How many undug borders can be left in the world of publishing?

fields.headline: In want of a husband
fields.standfirst: From  This Life to white wedding? Spinster  Alex Clark, 31, is unmoved by Amy Jenkins' Honeymoon
fields.trailText: From This Life to white wedding? Spinster Alex Clark, 31, is unmoved by Amy Jenkins' Honeymoon
fields.body:
Honeymoon
Amy Jenkins
Hodder, £10, 362pp
Buy it at BOL

In the interests of the purity of literary criticism, we shall pass quickly over the £600,000 advance that Amy Jenkins secured for this and another yet-to-be-written novel, after her publishers had convinced her that they - in the words of the strapline for the book - were "the love of her life" by escorting her to their offices in a stretch limousine, showering her with confetti and getting their chequebook out. Neither will we mention This Life, the film deal or the acres of feature coverage that Jenkins's CV and cheerful good looks seem to elicit. Rather, we shall concentrate on the text.

Honeymoon is the latest addition to that stable of books dedicated to soothing the night terrors of fretful metropolitan spinsters as they contemplate their 30s without a man in tow. Do these freaks of nature really exist in the numbers that send books soaring to the top of the bestseller lists? Reports of a man shortage notwithstanding, it seems unlikely, so one must presume that other women, in various states of partnerhood, also get their kicks from reading about their sisters' sorry love lives.

Honeymoon at least has a twist - aside from the cringingly awful gag that the central character is actually called Honeymoon, or Honey for short, as that's where she was conceived. (Her sister is called Venice. Try not to think about this for too long, or it will depress you.) Mercifully, her wacky parents are no longer around to get up to more hilarious antics, having been aboard a plane that went down somewhere over Mexico when Honey was 12.

Honey has in fact found a man, the extraordinarily nice landscape gardener Ed, who is so enamoured of every last shred of her narcissistic, neurotic little personality that he wants to spend the rest of his life with her. She, as the novel opens, is riding around London in a stretch limo (see above), whooping it up on her hen night.

But despite, or perhaps because of, the tender ministrations of the gullible Ed, Honey is far from happy. For one thing, she seems to find her fiancé rather indifferent company. To this we must say that anyone who can remain indifferent to a lover who strews their flat with rose petals and is constantly ripping their clothes off in order to ravish them needs to lower their expectations of life drastically. However, behind this facade of ambivalence lies a far darker truth.

Honey, you see, once met a man who didn't call. (Once? Once?) He was sitting in a restaurant eating risotto. So was she. Their eyes met, and "looking away wasn't an option he had me wired straight into his soul" (sic). Thus wired, the pair abandoned their dining companions and fled in a cab back to her place, where - and this is how she could tell it was the Real Thing - they didn't Do It. In the morning he trotted back to LA to produce commercials, and she waited for the phone to ring. Seven years later, it still hasn't, so she's throwing caution to the winds and marrying someone else.

That's the set-up. The follow-through involves all the staples of spinster fiction. There's a large cast of supporting characters, including a ballsy best friend, a cigar-puffing Hollywood movie type, a rehab-refugee Hollywood wannabe, the obligatory homosexual, a feng shui consultant and a wise Irish woman. No one's happy unless they're getting on or off a plane (they've put luckless ma and pa out of their minds, obviously), holding frantic "What shall we do now?" conversations on mobile phones or attending starry film premieres that are disrupted by gunmen and helicopters. Suffice it to say that Mr Risotto makes a reappearance, Honey gets terribly confused, and it's a miracle that a vicar doesn't appear through the french windows.

Farcical though the plot might be, this is farce with pretensions. Jenkins clearly fancies herself as a bit of a comedian, particularly when it comes to sending up the zeitgeist: lap-dancers, DVD players, M&S, condoms, yoga, Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus, depilatory cream and reduced-fat hummus are all pressed into the service of her clunking wit as the one-liners extend for line after dreary line.

But if the comedy could make you weep, then the tragedy certainly puts a smile on your face. Not only has Honey been orphaned, not only has she had to cope with losing The One, but cruel fate has also deprived her of Red Ted - not, as one briefly hopes, a description of her disillusionment with left-wing politics, but a reference to a childhood trauma involving a teddy bear and the pitiless maw of a dustcart. No wonder she's screwed up. "I'm not too sure what existential means," notes Honey, before hazarding a guess that it might be "something to do with the meaning of life". Er, don't worry about it, sweetheart, it's probably not that important.

Perhaps the best that we might say is that Jenkins has redefined the notion of a page-turner. Such is her authorial exuberance that a nervous reader will experience palpitations worrying about how she can possibly tie up all the loose ends and yet come up with a finale that convinces on psychological, social, literary, comedic and tragic levels. Others might wonder at the spectacle of an extremely rich and successful young woman who is clearly not stupid writing a book purely to tell us that, however streetwise and ironic we think ourselves, however much we scorn white weddings, red roses and purple prose, we're all gagging for them really. Me, I'm just gagging.

fields.headline: Strawberries and In Glasgow
fields.trailText:
There were never strawberries

like the ones we had

that sultry afternoon

sitting on the step

of the open french window...
fields.body:
Strawberries

There were never strawberries

like the ones we had

that sultry afternoon

sitting on the step

of the open french window

facing each other

your knees held in mine

the blue plates in our laps

the strawberries glistening

in the hot sunlight

we dipped them in sugar

looking at each other

not hurrying the feast

for one to come

the empty plates

laid on the stone together

with the two forks crossed

and I bent towards you

sweet in that air

in my arms

abandoned like a child

from your eager mouth

the taste of strawberries

in my memory

lean back again

let me love you

let the sun beat

on our forgetfulness

one hour of all

the heat intense

and summer lightning

on the Kilpatrick hills

let the storm wash the plates

In Glasgow

In my smoochy corner

take me on a cloud

I'll wrap you round

and lay you down

in smoky tinfoil

rings and records

sheets of whisky

and the moon all right

old pal all right

the moon all night

Mercy for the rainy

tyres and the violet

thunder that bring you

shambling and shy

from chains of Easterhouse

plains of lights

make your delight

in my nest my spell

my arms and my shell

my barn my bell

I've combed your hair

and washed your feet

and made you turn

like a dark eel

in my white bed

till morning lights

a silent cigarette

throw on your shirt

I lie staring yet

forget forget

 Morgan's 'New Selected Poems' is published this week (Carcanet, £7.95). He won this year's Queen's Medal for Poetry
fields.bodyText: Strawberries There were never strawberries like the ones we had that sultry afternoon sitting on the step of the open french window facing each other your knees held in mine the blue plates in our laps the strawberries glistening in the hot sunlight we dipped them in sugar looking at each other not hurrying the feast for one to come the empty plates laid on the stone together with the two forks crossed and I bent towards you sweet in that air in my arms abandoned like a child from your eager mouth the taste of strawberries in my memory lean back again let me love you let the sun beat on our forgetfulness one hour of all the heat intense and summer lightning on the Kilpatrick hills let the storm wash the plates In Glasgow In my smoochy corner take me on a cloud I'll wrap you round and lay you down in smoky tinfoil rings and records sheets of whisky and the moon all right old pal all right the moon all night Mercy for the rainy tyres and the violet thunder that bring you shambling and shy from chains of Easterhouse plains of lights make your delight in my nest my spell my arms and my shell my barn my bell I've combed your hair and washed your feet and made you turn like a dark eel in my white bed till morning lights a silent cigarette throw on your shirt I lie staring yet forget forget  Morgan's 'New Selected Poems' is published this week (Carcanet, £7.95). fields.headline: A  bad girl's code
fields.standfirst: In 1996, a book called The Rules caused a sensation in the US. It was a list of commands for desperate Bridget Joneses on how to capture Mr Right, encouraging a passivity completely out of step with the times; it was as if feminism never happened. Here, the writer Elizabeth Wurtzel counters with some rules of her own - for  real women, who want to live a little rather than wait around for a man

fields.body:
I am not the happiest person. In fact, in the battle between joy and misery, I'd say that the latter often seems to prevail. But I do have one thing on my side: I have enormous faith. And hope. I am not speaking of the kind you find in church or in the afterlife, I am speaking of a simple faith that says that one way or another, no matter how many times I stumble and stub my big toe, somehow life is going to work itself out. Being human, we all kind of want the same things, to love and be loved, and all that. And in the rules I've laid out here, I believe I have found the secret of life.

Don't Clear the Table at a Dinner Party Unless the Men Get Up to Help, Too

You know how it is. Friends are trying to be domestic and act grown up by having a bunch of people over for a meal. Invariably, the risotto will be too sticky, the salmon overcooked, the dill sauce too salty - but the effort will, of course, be the whole point. You will feel, momentarily, as mature as your parents were at your age. And to be appreciative and well mannered, between courses and at the end of the meal, you and others will get up to clear the table and help wash the dishes.

Now, as it happens, I have it from those who know about etiquette, that when you are a guest at somebody else's table, you need not offer to help, in fact you should let your hosts attend to all the post-repast cleaning. But because these good manners were formulated with butlers and maids figured in, it is probably acceptable and desirable to help with the clean-up effort.

But not if the men don't. Clean-up tasks should not be gendered.

Do you want to know how you can change the whole world, one dinner table at a time? By holding a sit-in! By refusing to be helpful unless the men are! Stay in your chair, savour a few more sips of your wine, finish the last spoons of your melting orange-kumquat sorbet, and refuse to participate in a process that maintains the status quo of women serving men. In fact, even if the men do get up to clear the table and help load the dishwasher, you should just sit there and let them take care of it. It is your due. For thousands of years women have served men, and the alarm clock of history has at long last rung.

The revolution begins in the kitchen!

Eat Dessert

I have a dream that some day I will have a daughter who will believe she can eat what she wants, when she wants, without worrying about her thighs or her abs or her butt or the saggy, bat-like arms that some women get at middle age. Maybe she won't even know the word cellulite. Is this too much to expect? I think not. But in the meantime women can stubbornly refuse to succumb to the notion that food is the enemy. The fact is that if you eat what you want, when you want it, and exercise three times a week like the experts say you should, you'll be fine. The whole offensive culture of dieting seems invented as yet another way to make women smaller and weaker - to make us become less, literally. The starving self symbolises a diminishing person, and we ought to strive to be more.

Even though models must be remarkably thin to mannequin clothes correctly, most of us need not be concerned about how we'll appear on a catwalk or in fashion photographs. We need only worry about how we look in real life, which is not static, and allows our vitality and expressiveness to be part of our gorgeousness. The first step toward becoming this kind of living, breathing beauty is to eat your banana cream pie and cheesecake with great relish, to have your dessert like you believe you deserve it.

Men, by the way, find this trait very attractive, in contrast to vomitatious eating disorders, which no one finds appealing.

Try to Know What the Kids are Up To

Let's face it: you will grow old no matter how much Retin-A you slather on at night, no matter how many alpha- and beta-hydroxy acids there are in your moisturiser, or how many vitamin pills and raw vegetables you eat each day. And you will start to wonder how it is that teenyboppers and their assorted idols seem so much stupider/ louder/more obnoxious than you ever were. You will think that when you were young, you had ideology and hope, but today's kids just have idiocy and despair. Worst of all, they seem to like it like that. You will tell yourself that, somehow, if you really think about it, Duran Duran was meaningful and 'N' Sync is not. You will remember a time when MTV was - yes - subversive.

Once you are done being disgusted with their "music", you will then be baffled by the aesthetic choices of the younger generation. You will find green hair and eyebrow rings and those bovine nose hooks increasingly repulsive, and wonder why it is that these teenagers want to make themselves look so ugly. Why they can't just wear the belly-baring stretch skirts and layers of black gauze and armfuls of black rubber bracelets like Madonna taught us to do. You will be dumbfounded by the allure of Special K - the horse tranquilliser that gives users a special sense of being trapped in a dark dungeon.

In other words, you will be out of it, just like your mother is out of it. You will occasionally pull out Never Mind The Bollocks just to prove to yourself that it was not always thus, that once you were a kid who wanted to destroy passers-by. But essentially, you will not have a clue. Styles come and bands go, and hemlines go up and down; only the generation gap persists.

But that does not mean you can't at least know a little bit about Limp Bizkit. I myself must confess that I did not know until recently that Sean "Puffy" Combs and Puff Daddy were one and the same; but now I know. You don't have to know who pulled an AK47 on whom. You don't have to see I Know What You Did Last Summer or any Wes Craven movies at all. But you do need to understand why 12-year-old girls are cuckoo about Leonardo DiCaprio.

Because as bleak as this stuff looks now, our kids are going to get into death-metal music and snuff movies that will be way worse than anything that is produced today. Outrage only knows how to get more outrageous.

But people also tend to outgrow outrage, which is why few rock bands have extensive careers while Merle Haggard and Frank Sinatra go on forever. Does anyone know who Ugly Kid Joe is? And when was the last time you listened to Jane's Addiction?

One fine day, you will be sitting in your drawing room, doing needlepoint, watching Wimbledon with the sound off while some peaceful James Taylor, circa 1974, wafts in the background. At the same time, in a room just down the hall, your pubescent son with dirty hair will be banging his head against the wall, to the tune of something very screechy. And at that moment, before you phone up the men in white coats to take him away, it might be worth noting that this is just what the kids do and this too shall pass.

Always Keep Your Mind on How You Feel, Not on How He Feels

If you are like me, you wander self-consciously through life, wondering what other people are thinking about you, frightened that they are judging you. Since, most likely, all these other people are walking around with the same thoughts, you need not worry what they think about you, because they probably don't. The sooner you realise this, the easier it will be for you to glide through life, unscathed and unconcerned.

This preoccupation with what other people think is particularly nefarious when it involves a man. In the beginning of a relationship, you are always walking around with a daisy, plucking at its petals, wondering if he loves you or loves you not. In the meantime, you may very easily lose sight of how you feel about him.

Truth is, studying tea leaves, throwing the I-ching, reading the Tarot or talking to a psychic might give you some insight into what is going on - but only into what is going on with you. Barring paranormal powers, you cannot possibly ascertain what he thinks and feels. If he calls and wants to spend time with you, these are pretty good indications that he is at least falling in like with you, but beyond that, things can go any which way. More will be revealed.

Meanwhile, every time you find yourself wondering how he feels about you, if he likes you, if he loves you, if he wants you desperately, try instead to start asking yourself how you feel about him. Because that's what really counts. A lot of times, your wondering about his emotions may in fact reflect your own ambivalence: maybe you don't adore him so much. Often we are so eager to be in love and happy that we forget to keep track of what we really think of any one particular guy. Men seem less likely to fall into this trap.

For an assortment of biological and sociological reasons - most of which are just plain not fair - men are rarely so eager to get into a relationship that they are willing to overlook some lady's appalling table manners, her affected British accent, and the potently ugly shade of orange eyeshadow that she wears in broad daylight. Women, on the other hand, often seem prepared to believe that Hitler was just an animal-loving vegetarian and ignore the rest. This is a problem. This is how we find our way into relationships that don't work out, but that leave us obsessively self-loathing, wondering, why didn't he like me? Somehow, we forget that he has all the charisma of John Major, that he has all the sex appeal of Boris Yeltsin, that he dances like a white man and that he listens to The Carpenters with no ironic distance. You will, in other words, be obsessed with a man who, by all rights, you should not even like.

It is time to stop the insanity. Don't just fall for any old guy who is giving you a hard time on that particular week. In all the time you invest in some loser, you could probably have met 20 people who would make you ready to kick up your heels and jitterbug.

Embrace Fanaticism

Learn to love things other than boys. Women must learn how to be crazily committed to ideas, theology, interests - anything. We must be positively bonkers about something other than men. Consider this analogy. During the second world war, Winston Churchill spoke of the importance of the government's continued subsidy of the arts, explaining that there was no point sending men out to fight if there was no civilisation worth saving - and worthy of returning home to. Likewise, the point of the sexual revolution was to give women fuller lives; it was not so that we could grimly labour to earn only three-quarters of what men do, and then come home to nothing but housework and screaming children.

If women had the kinds of consuming passions that men have - be it watching football or playing golf or drinking with the boys - we would do more to assert our rights than we do by, for instance, filing a complaint with the personnel department when the boss makes some leering comment.

"Be drunken, always. That is the point; nothing else matters," wrote Charles Baudelaire, a man who understood too well what it meant to give oneself over to life. "Drunken with what? With wine, with poetry or with virtue, as you please. But be drunken." And women must learn what is meant by these lines, what it means to be besotted with something other than some useless bloke.

Unless, of course, that useless bloke is Bob Dylan or Bruce Springsteen, or some other genius with lines, lyrics and chord progressions. Why is it that not only are most musicians male, but even most serious fans are men? At secondary school, girls like the bands that their boyfriends like, and usually not even that much. Perhaps one of the reasons I do so much prefer High Fidelity to Bridget Jones's Diary is that Nick Hornby's Rob, pathetic though he may be - completely commitment-phobic and puerile as a newborn - is still a devoted music fan; he's crazy for something other than his own neuroses. I have always felt my life was saved by rock 'n' roll, and I am baffled about why other women don't tend to have deposited their own desperation into such an obvious receptacle. I understand the lack of a female Jimi Hendrix - it's the loser teenage boy mentality that exacts the necessary masturbatory devotion to guitar practice alone in your room - but why are there not more female Jimi Hendrix fans (not to be confused with groupies, another pre-feminist proposition)?

In Fever Pitch, Nick Hornby discusses men's ability to completely immerse themselves in football viewing, admitting that, as a result, "they become repressed, they fail in their relationships with women, their conversation is trivial and boorish, they find themselves unable to express their emotional needs, they cannot relate to their children, and they die alone and miserable. But, you know, what the hell?" Somehow, unlike Bridget Jones, Hornby is not afraid of having his carcass half-eaten by an Alsatian.

Women who have better things to do than be obsessive stay out of trouble. So just find a way to become fanatical about something, just for fun. Take an interest in horseracing, or read Proust's Remembrance Of Things Past in its entirety, or invest in the stock market, or learn to ski at a late age. It is easy to develop interests - they are called that because they are interesting.

The Only Way to Get One Person Off Your Mind is to Get Another One on Your Body

Of course, this action could easily backfire, so it is only recommended when you really know what you are doing. This is a situation where ex-boyfriends in good standing can be helpful. But they have to be men you have truly lost interest in. Years ago. You have to pick a man who can still make your heart flutter and your body shiver just a little bit - but not too much. Not enough that you will find yourself - heaven forfend! - wanting to get back together with him the next day. Because if you sleep with one man to get un-obsessed with another man, the last thing you want is two men who give you paroxysms of agony.

Your emotional life, in the aftermath of a break-up, will be sufficiently messy that you should only do comforting and nourishing things with yourself. This is a good time for facials and massages, but absolutely no haircuts: women in the throes of heartbreak have been known to enter a salon with long, lovely locks - and to exit it looking like Johnny Rotten, circa 1978.

If there is some guy out there who can be of any aid to you in your delicate condition, by all means use him as a resource, exhaust his energy until he has completely sapped yours. Fuck your brains out in the bed you used to share with your boyfriend, and think ha ha ha ha ha the whole time.

But know thyself - and, for that matter, kid thyself not. If you feel even sort of like you are about to be inhaled into a situation that might go from bad to weird, do refrain.

Do Nothing

This is a really hard one. It is hard because it is about cultivating a deep passivity in your emotional life - a tender calm that would probably be very detrimental to other aspects of your existence. So don't start thinking that doing nothing is about whiling away the hours sitting on your settee and eating bonbons. Doing nothing is not the same as being a lazy, useless bum. Doing nothing is about making a conscious decision to not accelerate the drama. It means not booking a flight to Morocco - because good sources have reported that there is no such thing as pain in Marrakesh - when you know you have neither the money nor the time to make this excursion. It means not calling various people in your life to threaten suicide when you know perfectly well that's not what's going to happen.

Doing nothing means calmly asking for help when you need it. Doing nothing is opting for the sweetness of stillness. It is about just sitting with your loneliness, making some effort to accept how bad you feel. It is about taking long, contemplative walks through the park, meeting girlfriends for tea and reading silly self-help books. It means checking out the horoscopes in Elle and Vogue and Marie Claire, and comparing them for common and inconsistent predictions. It is about not pursuing histrionics and hysteria, it is about knowing that only time and peace of mind will make things better.

And doing nothing is not just something you must try in the case of a broken heart. It is the operative rule with office altercations, screaming fights with your mother and unpleasant tiffs with friends and lovers. If you try to force a resolution to some situation that needs only to be left alone to diffuse, you are only going to worry a wound. In a perfect example of stuffy, sensible and unmistakably British wisdom, Dame Rose Macaulay once noted that, "It is a common delusion that you can make things better by talking about them."

So don't pick up the phone so that you can add one last word. Don't go running through the streets late at night, and ring your boyfriend's doorbell with a floral peace offering because you cannot bear the thought that he might never speak to you again. All this activity is simply unnecessary, tiresome and cloyingly manipulative.

I feel it is only right for me to confess here that learning to do nothing has pretty much saved my life. I feel a bit hypocritical telling anyone not to get drunk and drugged and disorderly, or not to go too far, because, God knows, at times that has been the story of my life. But it was exhausting and taxing and eventually enough became enough.

In the time I have wasted making matters worse, I could have easily raised six children. Without a father. Without even a nanny. So just believe me: don't do something about whatever crazy feelings are boxing in your head until you have first tried to just do nothing. You will be amazed to discover that feelings are not facts, and feelings can be trusted to go away. They always do.

Enjoy Your Single Years

Do not view the years between school and marriage - and I hope we are talking years and not months, or heaven forbid, days - as one long preamble to real life. Worse still, do not view the years between kindergarten and marriage, between your first Oasis concert and marriage, between losing your virginity and marriage - as life in abeyance. Do not think that the whole point of being single is getting married; men don't think this way, and neither should you. Your single years are not to be traded for the Taj Mahal or the Hope diamond or anything - and do not let your grandmother tell you otherwise.

Because, if you marry too young, you will always wonder. Wonder about the boyfriends you will never have and about the singular solo personality that you will never develop, and about the trashy, flashy outfits that you will never get to wear because you are a nice married lady. Even if you are happy with your husband and think he is the greatest thing since bread pudding, you will wonder what you are missing.

By the time we are little old ladies, all of us will be living to the ripe old age of 200, settled in colonies on the moon, and living on a steady diet of Ovaltine and Tang. Given this situation, it seems like a good idea to choose wisely when seeking out the man with whom you want to spend a gravity-free old age. These days, until death do you part is a very long time, and despite the prevalence of divorce, I do believe that all of us still wish to wed only once. It is not a bad idea to grow into yourself just a wee bit before you try to blend in with someone else.

Now, I know that, after 16, boyfriends and 60 one-night stands, you start to wonder when - or if - it will ever end. But you must endure. Somewhere, in the pile of debris that you will accumulate for the rest of your life, is a point to every misbegotten rendezvous, every bad sexual encounter where some guy mistook your clitoris for an elevator button and you faked an orgasm just to make it end; someday, I promise, you will be able to plot these points on a spreadsheet, and the sensible curve that is your life will become clear, inevitable - you will see all these events for just what they were, and you will know that it could not have happened any other way.

Sometimes, after one too many dry-mouthed Sunday mornings with a bad headache, you may start to wish that you had been betrothed at birth to the boy next door. It may start to seem like every man you meet is your last chance. It may seem like every guy you come across is the only person left you haven't already met, that you have not already spent a bad, boring night with. But this isn't true. You are never too old, jaded, wasted and used by the world to once again feel young, dreamy and amazed by life and love once again. You should not give up five minutes before the miracle is about to happen.

And besides: you must take your chances. You must even take your chances that you will never find someone to marry. This won't happen, by the way, but you are better off living with that possibility than hiding from life. Because it's fun to be single and to live in a place that belongs to you and only you, that is decorated the way you like, with Oriental rugs that you carried back from Turkey yourself. It's fun to do almost everything by yourself.

Certainly, I think it extremely ill-advised either to have children alone or climb Mount Everest on your own - which is why at least the latter is prohibited by Nepalese law. But - like everyone else on this planet who is born alone and will finally die alone - you must cultivate the ability to enjoy your own company. Until you overcome any silly inability to be alone, you should recognise that you are also completely unsuitable for the married life of togetherness. You are not, for thatmatter, suitable for much of anything.

In short: Don't even think of getting married until you are quite certain that you've outgrown your little-girl days of being a whiny, needy pain in the ass.

Very rarely has anyone's life actually been ruined by the stupid things they have done when they were young and dopey (Princess Diana may be the glaring exception). And really, that is the secret to this whole business of life: you must cultivate the dignity to walk away before they make you run.

People who behave in a silly way do not end up with limited lives of no substance - on the contrary: the miserable fate of having nothing ever happen to you is reserved for those who never do anything. So do dumb things and do them with impunity. Spend you nights crying on the bathroom floor, and your icky, incandescent early mornings searching for the last traces of cocaine on the white tile. Sleep with married members of Parliament. Male and female. Look back laughingly on youthful folly. Just so long as you outgrow it.

But Do Settle Down

Because having a family is a happy thing. After you have swung from the best Waterford crystal chandeliers that someone else's money can buy; after you have been through the combined humiliations of being duped and dumped for your much-less-attractive best friend; after you have travelled through the Balkans with nothing but a schoolgirl knowledge of French to get you between youth hostels; after you have, just once, enjoyed a New Year's Eve when you didn't have a boyfriend and you were not so drunk or high or wired that you were vomiting out the window of some stranger's noisome party, but instead were able to spend a relatively quiet night with a few truly dear friends; after you have done those things, and somewhere between satiation and saturation you have achieved the occasional state of grace, then you are ready to call it quits. Enough is enough. Now it is time to collect your bag of party favours, and move on. You've been single long enough. It's time to settle down. So find some good man and just do it.

Just like that.

And don't worry: when you are good and ready, the right man will just show up. He just will. Unplanned but entirely expected, like a dandelion growing on the front lawn, there he will be. If I can pass on just one thing, I hope it will be that when you take care of yourself and tend to your garden like Voltaire instructed us, life will do its part to take care of you.

And the truth is, when you are ready to settle in and settle down, the hard part will be avoiding your life-partner, the challenge will be the millions of tricks that you will treat yourself to in an effort to thwart this inevitability, to stop true happiness as it greets you. The temptation to run from that which you have always hoped for - particularly if happiness has always been a stranger to you - may well be your predominant impulse in the face of true love. But you are just going to have to get a grip. Don't postpone, deny or derail joy. Because at a certain point you actually will become sufficiently fucked up to get in the way of life's inevitable, happy flow, you really can start doing the kinds of things that will mess you up for good. If you have played out your days as a single girl, and a good person comes along offering you his heart and all you do is skewer it to bits, you are going to start becoming an actually troubled person, as opposed to just an evolving woman who is figuring things out.

While the occasional Isaac Newton among us is going to be satisfied by a life under the apple tree without any of the Andrews Sisters or anyone else for company, for most of us the abstract beauties of the world mean little with no one to share them with. The corniness of purple-pink sunsets and the starkness of starry nights and the pristine purity of white, white snow and the hallucinatory pleasure of red, red wine are lonelier than a Roy Orbison song when you are all alone. You've got to give it time but sooner or later, you will be needing to find your special one.

There are exceptions to this rule, but I have never met any of them. Most of us need the conventions of coupledom, family and stability to be happy, need to give of ourselves body and soul and heart and spirit to our own true love to know the selfish joy of selflessness.

So do not despair of the miserable example of your own childhood and choose not to have a family of your own. Do not be denied by fear. No matter how much shit was visited upon you when you were young - so much bad that it occasionally seems like the best you will ever manage to do is hate so much that it hurts - I still believe we all ought to take the chance, the huge and potentially devastating chance, that we will be rewarded by loving that much. As was pointed out by Albert Einstein himself: "People like us, who believe in physics, know that the distinction between past, present, and future is only a stubbornly persistent illusion." If you correct your past with good choices made in the present, then when all these different time zones smash together, they will turn into a happy future.

Clearly, the family structures that we were born into were less than ideal, or they would not have resulted in a 50% failure rate. It is now up to us to make and model our own family moulds. It does not have to be like our parents were. It does not have to be the way it ever was. A family is whatever works.

I think of the opening scene of Wim Wenders' 1987 film Wings Of Desire, when the angel lands on earth and peers into all the different windows in Berlin buildings, and at all the solitary lives that go on in each apartment, all these people living as close together as neighbours in urban centres do, with women crying and men yelling, and everybody so all alone. Here are all these people, in such close physical proximity, each one of them desperate and in need of an angel to save his heart or her soul from this desolation, and yet none of them can know or help each other. None of them can reach through the walls to touch anyone else's loneliness, and so the angel watches all of them through the glass panes of their lives, and he is horrified by the alienation he sees. And just like in the movie, all over the world there are people torn apart before they have even had a chance to be together, and there are people who are just dying of loneliness. Fortunately, you are not going to be one of them.

© Elizabeth Wurtzel, 2000

This is an edited extract from The Bitch Rules, by Elizabeth Wurtzel, published by Quartet on May 8, at £6
