Men, by the way, find this trait very attractive, in contrast to vomitatious eating disorders, which no one finds appealing. Try to Know What the Kids are Up To Let's face it: you will grow old no matter how much Retin-A you slather on at night, no matter how many alpha- and beta-hydroxy acids there are in your moisturiser, or how many vitamin pills and raw vegetables you eat each day. And you will start to wonder how it is that teenyboppers and their assorted idols seem so much stupider/ louder/more obnoxious than you ever were. You will think that when you were young, you had ideology and hope, but today's kids just have idiocy and despair. Worst of all, they seem to like it like that. You will tell yourself that, somehow, if you really think about it, Duran Duran was meaningful and 'N' Sync is not. You will remember a time when MTV was - yes - subversive. Once you are done being disgusted with their "music", you will then be baffled by the aesthetic choices of the younger generation. You will find green hair and eyebrow rings and those bovine nose hooks increasingly repulsive, and wonder why it is that these teenagers want to make themselves look so ugly. Why they can't just wear the belly-baring stretch skirts and layers of black gauze and armfuls of black rubber bracelets like Madonna taught us to do. You will be dumbfounded by the allure of Special K - the horse tranquilliser that gives users a special sense of being trapped in a dark dungeon. In other words, you will be out of it, just like your mother is out of it. You will occasionally pull out Never Mind The Bollocks just to prove to yourself that it was not always thus, that once you were a kid who wanted to destroy passers-by. But essentially, you will not have a clue. Styles come and bands go, and hemlines go up and down; only the generation gap persists. But that does not mean you can't at least know a little bit about Limp Bizkit. I myself must confess that I did not know until recently that Sean "Puffy" Combs and Puff Daddy were one and the same; but now I know. You don't have to know who pulled an AK47 on whom. You don't have to see I Know What You Did Last Summer or any Wes Craven movies at all. But you do need to understand why 12-year-old girls are cuckoo about Leonardo DiCaprio. Because as bleak as this stuff looks now, our kids are going to get into death-metal music and snuff movies that will be way worse than anything that is produced today. Outrage only knows how to get more outrageous. But people also tend to outgrow outrage, which is why few rock bands have extensive careers while Merle Haggard and Frank Sinatra go on forever. Does anyone know who Ugly Kid Joe is? And when was the last time you listened to Jane's Addiction? One fine day, you will be sitting in your drawing room, doing needlepoint, watching Wimbledon with the sound off while some peaceful James Taylor, circa 1974, wafts in the background. At the same time, in a room just down the hall, your pubescent son with dirty hair will be banging his head against the wall, to the tune of something very screechy. And at that moment, before you phone up the men in white coats to take him away, it might be worth noting that this is just what the kids do and this too shall pass. Always Keep Your Mind on How You Feel, Not on How He Feels If you are like me, you wander self-consciously through life, wondering what other people are thinking about you, frightened that they are judging you. Since, most likely, all these other people are walking around with the same thoughts, you need not worry what they think about you, because they probably don't. The sooner you realise this, the easier it will be for you to glide through life, unscathed and unconcerned. This preoccupation with what other people think is particularly nefarious when it involves a man. In the beginning of a relationship, you are always walking around with a daisy, plucking at its petals, wondering if he loves you or loves you not. In the meantime, you may very easily lose sight of how you feel about him. Truth is, studying tea leaves, throwing the I-ching, reading the Tarot or talking to a psychic might give you some insight into what is going on - but only into what is going on with you. Barring paranormal powers, you cannot possibly ascertain what he thinks and feels. If he calls and wants to spend time with you, these are pretty good indications that he is at least falling in like with you, but beyond that, things can go any which way. More will be revealed. Meanwhile, every time you find yourself wondering how he feels about you, if he likes you, if he loves you, if he wants you desperately, try instead to start asking yourself how you feel about him. Because that's what really counts. A lot of times, your wondering about his emotions may in fact reflect your own ambivalence: maybe you don't adore him so much. Often we are so eager to be in love and happy that we forget to keep track of what we really think of any one particular guy. Men seem less likely to fall into this trap. For an assortment of biological and sociological reasons - most of which are just plain not fair - men are rarely so eager to get into a relationship that they are willing to overlook some lady's appalling table manners, her affected British accent, and the potently ugly shade of orange eyeshadow that she wears in broad daylight. Women, on the other hand, often seem prepared to believe that Hitler was just an animal-loving vegetarian and ignore the rest. This is a problem. This is how we find our way into relationships that don't work out, but that leave us obsessively self-loathing, wondering, why didn't he like me? Somehow, we forget that he has all the charisma of John Major, that he has all the sex appeal of Boris Yeltsin, that he dances like a white man and that he listens to The Carpenters with no ironic distance. You will, in other words, be obsessed with a man who, by all rights, you should not even like. It is time to stop the insanity. Don't just fall for any old guy who is giving you a hard time on that particular week. In all the time you invest in some loser, you could probably have met 20 people who would make you ready to kick up your heels and jitterbug. Embrace Fanaticism Learn to love things other than boys. Women must learn how to be crazily committed to ideas, theology, interests - anything. We must be positively bonkers about something other than men. Consider this analogy. During the second world war, Winston Churchill spoke of the importance of the government's continued subsidy of the arts, explaining that there was no point sending men out to fight if there was no civilisation worth saving - and worthy of returning home to. Likewise, the point of the sexual revolution was to give women fuller lives; it was not so that we could grimly labour to earn only three-quarters of what men do, and then come home to nothing but housework and screaming children. If women had the kinds of consuming passions that men have - be it watching football or playing golf or drinking with the boys - we would do more to assert our rights than we do by, for instance, filing a complaint with the personnel department when the boss makes some leering comment. "Be drunken, always. That is the point; nothing else matters," wrote Charles Baudelaire, a man who understood too well what it meant to give oneself over to life. "Drunken with what? With wine, with poetry or with virtue, as you please. But be drunken." And women must learn what is meant by these lines, what it means to be besotted with something other than some useless bloke. Unless, of course, that useless bloke is Bob Dylan or Bruce Springsteen, or some other genius with lines, lyrics and chord progressions. Why is it that not only are most musicians male, but even most serious fans are men? At secondary school, girls like the bands that their boyfriends like, and usually not even that much. Perhaps one of the reasons I do so much prefer High Fidelity to Bridget Jones's Diary is that Nick Hornby's Rob, pathetic though he may be - completely commitment-phobic and puerile as a newborn - is still a devoted music fan; he's crazy for something other than his own neuroses. I have always felt my life was saved by rock 'n' roll, and I am baffled about why other women don't tend to have deposited their own desperation into such an obvious receptacle. I understand the lack of a female Jimi Hendrix - it's the loser teenage boy mentality that exacts the necessary masturbatory devotion to guitar practice alone in your room - but why are there not more female Jimi Hendrix fans (not to be confused with groupies, another pre-feminist proposition)? In Fever Pitch, Nick Hornby discusses men's ability to completely immerse themselves in football viewing, admitting that, as a result, "they become repressed, they fail in their relationships with women, their conversation is trivial and boorish, they find themselves unable to express their emotional needs, they cannot relate to their children, and they die alone and miserable. But, you know, what the hell?" Somehow, unlike Bridget Jones, Hornby is not afraid of having his carcass half-eaten by an Alsatian. Women who have better things to do than be obsessive stay out of trouble. So just find a way to become fanatical about something, just for fun. Take an interest in horseracing, or read Proust's Remembrance Of Things Past in its entirety, or invest in the stock market, or learn to ski at a late age. It is easy to develop interests - they are called that because they are interesting. The Only Way to Get One Person Off Your Mind is to Get Another One on Your Body Of course, this action could easily backfire, so it is only recommended when you really know what you are doing. This is a situation where ex-boyfriends in good standing can be helpful. But they have to be men you have truly lost interest in. Years ago. You have to pick a man who can still make your heart flutter and your body shiver just a little bit - but not too much. Not enough that you will find yourself - heaven forfend! - wanting to get back together with him the next day. Because if you sleep with one man to get un-obsessed with another man, the last thing you want is two men who give you paroxysms of agony. Your emotional life, in the aftermath of a break-up, will be sufficiently messy that you should only do comforting and nourishing things with yourself. This is a good time for facials and massages, but absolutely no haircuts: women in the throes of heartbreak have been known to enter a salon with long, lovely locks - and to exit it looking like Johnny Rotten, circa 1978. If there is some guy out there who can be of any aid to you in your delicate condition, by all means use him as a resource, exhaust his energy until he has completely sapped yours. Fuck your brains out in the bed you used to share with your boyfriend, and think ha ha ha ha ha the whole time. But know thyself - and, for that matter, kid thyself not. If you feel even sort of like you are about to be inhaled into a situation that might go from bad to weird, do refrain. Do Nothing This is a really hard one. It is hard because it is about cultivating a deep passivity in your emotional life - a tender calm that would probably be very detrimental to other aspects of your existence. So don't start thinking that doing nothing is about whiling away the hours sitting on your settee and eating bonbons. Doing nothing is not the same as being a lazy, useless bum. Doing nothing is about making a conscious decision to not accelerate the drama. It means not booking a flight to Morocco - because good sources have reported that there is no such thing as pain in Marrakesh - when you know you have neither the money nor the time to make this excursion. It means not calling various people in your life to threaten suicide when you know perfectly well that's not what's going to happen. Doing nothing means calmly asking for help when you need it. Doing nothing is opting for the sweetness of stillness. It is about just sitting with your loneliness, making some effort to accept how bad you feel. It is about taking long, contemplative walks through the park, meeting girlfriends for tea and reading silly self-help books. It means checking out the horoscopes in Elle and Vogue and Marie Claire, and comparing them for common and inconsistent predictions. It is about not pursuing histrionics and hysteria, it is about knowing that only time and peace of mind will make things better. And doing nothing is not just something you must try in the case of a broken heart. It is the operative rule with office altercations, screaming fights with your mother and unpleasant tiffs with friends and lovers. If you try to force a resolution to some situation that needs only to be left alone to diffuse, you are only going to worry a wound. In a perfect example of stuffy, sensible and unmistakably British wisdom, Dame Rose Macaulay once noted that, "It is a common delusion that you can make things better by talking about them." So don't pick up the phone so that you can add one last word. Don't go running through the streets late at night, and ring your boyfriend's doorbell with a floral peace offering because you cannot bear the thought that he might never speak to you again. All this activity is simply unnecessary, tiresome and cloyingly manipulative. I feel it is only right for me to confess here that learning to do nothing has pretty much saved my life. I feel a bit hypocritical telling anyone not to get drunk and drugged and disorderly, or not to go too far, because, God knows, at times that has been the story of my life. But it was exhausting and taxing and eventually enough became enough. In the time I have wasted making matters worse, I could have easily raised six children. Without a father. Without even a nanny. So just believe me: don't do something about whatever crazy feelings are boxing in your head until you have first tried to just do nothing. You will be amazed to discover that feelings are not facts, and feelings can be trusted to go away. They always do. Enjoy Your Single Years Do not view the years between school and marriage - and I hope we are talking years and not months, or heaven forbid, days - as one long preamble to real life. Worse still, do not view the years between kindergarten and marriage, between your first Oasis concert and marriage, between losing your virginity and marriage - as life in abeyance. Do not think that the whole point of being single is getting married; men don't think this way, and neither should you. Your single years are not to be traded for the Taj Mahal or the Hope diamond or anything - and do not let your grandmother tell you otherwise. Because, if you marry too young, you will always wonder. Wonder about the boyfriends you will never have and about the singular solo personality that you will never develop, and about the trashy, flashy outfits that you will never get to wear because you are a nice married lady. Even if you are happy with your husband and think he is the greatest thing since bread pudding, you will wonder what you are missing. By the time we are little old ladies, all of us will be living to the ripe old age of 200, settled in colonies on the moon, and living on a steady diet of Ovaltine and Tang. Given this situation, it seems like a good idea to choose wisely when seeking out the man with whom you want to spend a gravity-free old age. These days, until death do you part is a very long time, and despite the prevalence of divorce, I do believe that all of us still wish to wed only once. It is not a bad idea to grow into yourself just a wee bit before you try to blend in with someone else. Now, I know that, after 16, boyfriends and 60 one-night stands, you start to wonder when - or if - it will ever end. But you must endure. Somewhere, in the pile of debris that you will accumulate for the rest of your life, is a point to every misbegotten rendezvous, every bad sexual encounter where some guy mistook your clitoris for an elevator button and you faked an orgasm just to make it end; someday, I promise, you will be able to plot these points on a spreadsheet, and the sensible curve that is your life will become clear, inevitable - you will see all these events for just what they were, and you will know that it could not have happened any other way. Sometimes, after one too many dry-mouthed Sunday mornings with a bad headache, you may start to wish that you had been betrothed at birth to the boy next door. It may start to seem like every man you meet is your last chance. It may seem like every guy you come across is the only person left you haven't already met, that you have not already spent a bad, boring night with. But this isn't true. You are never too old, jaded, wasted and used by the world to once again feel young, dreamy and amazed by life and love once again. You should not give up five minutes before the miracle is about to happen. And besides: you must take your chances. You must even take your chances that you will never find someone to marry. This won't happen, by the way, but you are better off living with that possibility than hiding from life. Because it's fun to be single and to live in a place that belongs to you and only you, that is decorated the way you like, with Oriental rugs that you carried back from Turkey yourself. It's fun to do almost everything by yourself. Certainly, I think it extremely ill-advised either to have children alone or climb Mount Everest on your own - which is why at least the latter is prohibited by Nepalese law. But - like everyone else on this planet who is born alone and will finally die alone - you must cultivate the ability to enjoy your own company. Until you overcome any silly inability to be alone, you should recognise that you are also completely unsuitable for the married life of togetherness. You are not, for thatmatter, suitable for much of anything. In short: Don't even think of getting married until you are quite certain that you've outgrown your little-girl days of being a whiny, needy pain in the ass. Very rarely has anyone's life actually been ruined by the stupid things they have done when they were young and dopey (Princess Diana may be the glaring exception). And really, that is the secret to this whole business of life: you must cultivate the dignity to walk away before they make you run. People who behave in a silly way do not end up with limited lives of no substance - on the contrary: the miserable fate of having nothing ever happen to you is reserved for those who never do anything. So do dumb things and do them with impunity. Spend you nights crying on the bathroom floor, and your icky, incandescent early mornings searching for the last traces of cocaine on the white tile. Sleep with married members of Parliament. Male and female. Look back laughingly on youthful folly. Just so long as you outgrow it. But Do Settle Down Because having a family is a happy thing. After you have swung from the best Waterford crystal chandeliers that someone else's money can buy; after you have been through the combined humiliations of being duped and dumped for your much-less-attractive best friend; after you have travelled through the Balkans with nothing but a schoolgirl knowledge of French to get you between youth hostels; after you have, just once, enjoyed a New Year's Eve when you didn't have a boyfriend and you were not so drunk or high or wired that you were vomiting out the window of some stranger's noisome party, but instead were able to spend a relatively quiet night with a few truly dear friends; after you have done those things, and somewhere between satiation and saturation you have achieved the occasional state of grace, then you are ready to call it quits. Enough is enough. Now it is time to collect your bag of party favours, and move on. You've been single long enough. It's time to settle down. So find some good man and just do it. Just like that. And don't worry: when you are good and ready, the right man will just show up. He just will. Unplanned but entirely expected, like a dandelion growing on the front lawn, there he will be. If I can pass on just one thing, I hope it will be that when you take care of yourself and tend to your garden like Voltaire instructed us, life will do its part to take care of you. And the truth is, when you are ready to settle in and settle down, the hard part will be avoiding your life-partner, the challenge will be the millions of tricks that you will treat yourself to in an effort to thwart this inevitability, to stop true happiness as it greets you. The temptation to run from that which you have always hoped for - particularly if happiness has always been a stranger to you - may well be your predominant impulse in the face of true love. But you are just going to have to get a grip. Don't postpone, deny or derail joy. Because at a certain point you actually will become sufficiently fucked up to get in the way of life's inevitable, happy flow, you really can start doing the kinds of things that will mess you up for good. If you have played out your days as a single girl, and a good person comes along offering you his heart and all you do is skewer it to bits, you are going to start becoming an actually troubled person, as opposed to just an evolving woman who is figuring things out. While the occasional Isaac Newton among us is going to be satisfied by a life under the apple tree without any of the Andrews Sisters or anyone else for company, for most of us the abstract beauties of the world mean little with no one to share them with. The corniness of purple-pink sunsets and the starkness of starry nights and the pristine purity of white, white snow and the hallucinatory pleasure of red, red wine are lonelier than a Roy Orbison song when you are all alone. You've got to give it time but sooner or later, you will be needing to find your special one. There are exceptions to this rule, but I have never met any of them. Most of us need the conventions of coupledom, family and stability to be happy, need to give of ourselves body and soul and heart and spirit to our own true love to know the selfish joy of selflessness. So do not despair of the miserable example of your own childhood and choose not to have a family of your own. Do not be denied by fear. No matter how much shit was visited upon you when you were young - so much bad that it occasionally seems like the best you will ever manage to do is hate so much that it hurts - I still believe we all ought to take the chance, the huge and potentially devastating chance, that we will be rewarded by loving that much. As was pointed out by Albert Einstein himself: "People like us, who believe in physics, know that the distinction between past, present, and future is only a stubbornly persistent illusion." If you correct your past with good choices made in the present, then when all these different time zones smash together, they will turn into a happy future. Clearly, the family structures that we were born into were less than ideal, or they would not have resulted in a 50% failure rate. It is now up to us to make and model our own family moulds. It does not have to be like our parents were. It does not have to be the way it ever was. A family is whatever works. I think of the opening scene of Wim Wenders' 1987 film Wings Of Desire, when the angel lands on earth and peers into all the different windows in Berlin buildings, and at all the solitary lives that go on in each apartment, all these people living as close together as neighbours in urban centres do, with women crying and men yelling, and everybody so all alone. Here are all these people, in such close physical proximity, each one of them desperate and in need of an angel to save his heart or her soul from this desolation, and yet none of them can know or help each other. None of them can reach through the walls to touch anyone else's loneliness, and so the angel watches all of them through the glass panes of their lives, and he is horrified by the alienation he sees. And just like in the movie, all over the world there are people torn apart before they have even had a chance to be together, and there are people who are just dying of loneliness. Fortunately, you are not going to be one of them. © Elizabeth Wurtzel, 2000 This is an edited extract from The Bitch Rules, by Elizabeth Wurtzel, published by Quartet on May 8, at £6

fields.headline: Avid for annotation
fields.standfirst: The music and resonance of William Empson's poetry still work on us, says  Robert Potts
fields.trailText: The music and resonance of William Empson's poetry still work on us, says Robert Potts
fields.body:
The Complete Poems of William Empson
edited by John Haffenden
Allen Lane, £30, 512pp
Buy it at BOL

William Empson was one of the more influential, if puzzling, figures in 20th-century literature. Praised (and published) by TS Eliot, he was, at least for a while, an idol of FR Leavis and the Movement poets. His seminal volume of criticism, Seven Types of Ambiguity, was published in 1930, when he was only 24.

A year earlier he had gained a first with special distinction in part one of the English Tripos at Cambridge (having, unusually, been permitted to switch from his highly successful mathematical studies), and been awarded a bye-fellowship. He was not able to take this up, however; he was "sent down" a month later, when a college porter discovered contraceptives among his possessions. Magdalene College had expelled one of the greatest talents of a generation.

Empson's criticism - founded on exhaustive close reading, an alertness to allusion and a desire to squeeze all possible meanings from his chosen texts - fed into the New Criticism advocated by his friend and tutor, IA Richards. Although the idea that one might read texts attentively and analytically is out of favour in some English departments these days, it was for several decades an orthodoxy. Even as a student, Empson had stressed his desire to bring to criticism "all possible attitudes, to turn upon a given situation every tool, however irrelevant or disconnected, of the contemporary mind". This attempt to synthesise, or at least aggregate, the various disciplines of contemporary thought can also be found in his poetry.

The critic whose Cambridge career was cut short by condoms went on to a brilliant academic career in Japan, China, and England. But the poet - whose early work was admired by Wittgenstein and the Bloomsbury group and seemed to occupy a space between TS Eliot's trail-blazing modernism and the political poetry of the Auden-MacNeice gang - did not write very much after the war; although he did not die until 1984, the poetry had basically finished by 1949. Empson's poetic output occupies about 100 pages. John Haffenden's excellent edition of the Complete Poems weighs in at around 500 pages, and the apparatus is not wasteful; indeed, it goes some way towards explaining why Empson stopped writing.

One of the most interesting things about this volume is the discovery that Empson's cerebral-looking pieces sprang from quite heartfelt emotions; he describes many of his earliest poems as "boy afraid of girl", and indeed they resemble Donne's work in their apparently incongruous accumulation of analogy and argument to deal with human relationship. Another shock is that some of the more famous and best-loved poems were not rated highly by Empson himself. It is odd to find him surprised by the success of, say, "Let it Go", a short and brilliant piece that one can quote in full:

"It is this deep blankness is the real thing strange.

The more things happen to you, the more you can't

tell or remember even what they were.

The contradictions cover such a range.

The talk would talk and go so far aslant.

You don't want madhouse and the whole thing there."

I had always taken this piece, by far his most direct, as a comment on the impossibility of encompassing everything at once: flooded by information, layered with analysis and the analysis of analysis ("the talk would talk"), one would go mad in the attempt. Martin Amis's Success intelligently alludes to the poem in a remark addressed to a schizophrenic; schizophrenia is in some ways about the breaking-down of our filtering mechanisms, being overwhelmed by sensory data. But Empson's comments on this "hopelessly bad" poem consistently assert that it is about "stopping writing". Perhaps, despite his brilliance as a critic, he was not the best interpreter or judge of his own work.

His poetry, it has to be said, is unusually difficult at first approach. It is densely allusive, not merely to other poetry but to the scientific knowledge of various periods and cultures. The syntax and the grammar are quirky, often condensed, frequently deliberately ambiguous. Yet Empson, for all his delight in the various readings and meanings he found in his critical work, did not want to mystify readers; he provided notes, explaining the odd facts or incidents that furnished him with his metaphors.

There is something oddly comical about these commentaries; they are frequently as oddly or elliptically phrased as the poetry they supposedly illuminate. Taken with the other comments Haffenden has collected, they give the unmistakable impression of a man baffled by his failure to communicate what he meant, despite his zeal in finding so many fertile meanings in other writers' poems.

Even today there is an unease about poems that come with their own notes. Eliot did it with The Waste Land, of course, though he suggested later (whether truthfully or not) that he had had to supply the bogus scholarship simply to bulk the poem out to book-length. Empson remarked as early as 1929 that the absence of common knowledge meant that "poets... have either got to be easier, or write their own notes... some may be pedantic, and some impertinent, but... it really ought to be possible".

Whether or not one feels the poems fail on this basis, the notes are sometimes essential. As Haffenden says of a line in "Advice", "we have to rely on WE's note to communicate to us (as the poem fails to do) that these terms refer to the course of syphilis infection". He then gently suggests that Empson hadn't correctly understood the symptoms of tertiary syphilis anyway.

For the most part, though, the notes are engaging, good-humoured and helpful; and they stem less from snobbery than from a recognition that it is not reasonable to expect your readers to have covered exactly the same ground as you. And at their most successful, the poems have the potent excitement of the Metaphysical writers; a ferocious intellectual curiosity combined with emotional and political engagement.

Empson's "musical line" is one reason these pieces work on us immediately and encourage our attention. His use of the villanelle and variants thereof, or terza rima, or forms recalling poets as diverse as Swinburne or Marvell, is impressive. The villanelle-style poems are the most memorable, partly because repeated lines and refrains stick in the mind, but mainly because he comes up with such resonant lines - "Slowly the poison the whole blood stream fills. / The waste remains, the waste remains and kills"; "It is the pain, it is the pain endures"; "I have mislaid the torment and the fear. / Those that doubt drugs, let them doubt which was here".

Charmingly, he uses Anita Loos's Gentlemen Prefer Blondes for the line "A girl can't go on laughing all the time". Loos, we gather from this volume, was flattered, but said she couldn't study the poem too hard because it might turn her into "a weeper".

Haffenden describes Empson at one point as "avid for annotation. He was positively insistent upon its being done, and done properly". By those standards, Haffenden has done Empson proud; he offers an entertaining biographical introduction, discusses the texts and Empson's views on notes, gives us a timeline and scrupulously traces the allusions and references in the poems that Empson did not spell out himself. Given Empson's wide and eclectic reading, this is a formidable labour of scholarship; but rather than reducing the poet to unrevivable dryness, Haffenden brings him to life, showing us his personality, his foibles, his endearing modesties and concerns. He deserves every congratulation.

One of the most interesting things about this volume is the discovery that Empson's cerebral-looking pieces sprang from quite heartfelt emotions; he describes many of his earliest poems as "boy afraid of girl", and indeed they resemble Donne's work in their apparently incongruous accumulation of analogy and argument to deal with human relationship. Another shock is that some of the more famous and best-loved poems were not rated highly by Empson himself. It is odd to find him surprised by the success of, say, "Let it Go", a short and brilliant piece that one can quote in full: "It is this deep blankness is the real thing strange. The more things happen to you, the more you can't tell or remember even what they were. The contradictions cover such a range. The talk would talk and go so far aslant. You don't want madhouse and the whole thing there." I had always taken this piece, by far his most direct, as a comment on the impossibility of encompassing everything at once: flooded by information, layered with analysis and the analysis of analysis ("the talk would talk"), one would go mad in the attempt. Martin Amis's Success intelligently alludes to the poem in a remark addressed to a schizophrenic; schizophrenia is in some ways about the breaking-down of our filtering mechanisms, being overwhelmed by sensory data. But Empson's comments on this "hopelessly bad" poem consistently assert that it is about "stopping writing". Perhaps, despite his brilliance as a critic, he was not the best interpreter or judge of his own work. His poetry, it has to be said, is unusually difficult at first approach. It is densely allusive, not merely to other poetry but to the scientific knowledge of various periods and cultures. The syntax and the grammar are quirky, often condensed, frequently deliberately ambiguous. Yet Empson, for all his delight in the various readings and meanings he found in his critical work, did not want to mystify readers; he provided notes, explaining the odd facts or incidents that furnished him with his metaphors. There is something oddly comical about these commentaries; they are frequently as oddly or elliptically phrased as the poetry they supposedly illuminate. Taken with the other comments Haffenden has collected, they give the unmistakable impression of a man baffled by his failure to communicate what he meant, despite his zeal in finding so many fertile meanings in other writers' poems. Even today there is an unease about poems that come with their own notes. Eliot did it with The Waste Land, of course, though he suggested later (whether truthfully or not) that he had had to supply the bogus scholarship simply to bulk the poem out to book-length. Empson remarked as early as 1929 that the absence of common knowledge meant that "poets... have either got to be easier, or write their own notes... some may be pedantic, and some impertinent, but... it really ought to be possible". Whether or not one feels the poems fail on this basis, the notes are sometimes essential. As Haffenden says of a line in "Advice", "we have to rely on WE's note to communicate to us (as the poem fails to do) that these terms refer to the course of syphilis infection". He then gently suggests that Empson hadn't correctly understood the symptoms of tertiary syphilis anyway. For the most part, though, the notes are engaging, good-humoured and helpful; and they stem less from snobbery than from a recognition that it is not reasonable to expect your readers to have covered exactly the same ground as you. And at their most successful, the poems have the potent excitement of the Metaphysical writers; a ferocious intellectual curiosity combined with emotional and political engagement. Empson's "musical line" is one reason these pieces work on us immediately and encourage our attention. His use of the villanelle and variants thereof, or terza rima, or forms recalling poets as diverse as Swinburne or Marvell, is impressive. The villanelle-style poems are the most memorable, partly because repeated lines and refrains stick in the mind, but mainly because he comes up with such resonant lines - "Slowly the poison the whole blood stream fills. / The waste remains, the waste remains and kills"; "It is the pain, it is the pain endures"; "I have mislaid the torment and the fear. / Those that doubt drugs, let them doubt which was here". Charmingly, he uses Anita Loos's Gentlemen Prefer Blondes for the line "A girl can't go on laughing all the time". Loos, we gather from this volume, was flattered, but said she couldn't study the poem too hard because it might turn her into "a weeper". Haffenden describes Empson at one point as "avid for annotation. He was positively insistent upon its being done, and done properly". By those standards, Haffenden has done Empson proud; he offers an entertaining biographical introduction, discusses the texts and Empson's views on notes, gives us a timeline and scrupulously traces the allusions and references in the poems that Empson did not spell out himself. Given Empson's wide and eclectic reading, this is a formidable labour of scholarship; but rather than reducing the poet to unrevivable dryness, Haffenden brings him to life, showing us his personality, his foibles, his endearing modesties and concerns. He deserves every congratulation.

fields.headline: Lay your armour down
fields.standfirst: Stuart Jeffries  hits the mean streets with Walter Mosley's Walkin' the Dog
fields.trailText: Stuart Jeffries hits the mean streets with Walter Mosley's Walkin' the Dog
fields.body:
Walkin' the Dog
Walter Mosley
Serpent's Tail, £14.99, 272pp
Buy it at BOL

Books Unlimited author page

The dog's name is Killer. He weighs more than 70lbs and lost his hind legs when he was run over a by a car. Walkin' the dog? It's not as easy as you might think. And yet that's exactly what Socrates Fortlow does, dragging that black biped of a mutt down the mean streets of Watts, day in, day out: "His right biceps bulged as the hot sun came down on his bald black head but Socrates didn't acknowledge the strain of his labours. Killer was the first pet that he'd ever owned. Other men in the penitentiary kept garden snakes, rats and pigeons for pets... But Socrates didn't love in prison. Love was weakness and Socrates' armour had nary a chink."

Killer, then, is a metaphor - for the possibility of love, for the burdensomeness of rage, for the strength this ex-con needs just to get through the day.

Socrates, with his philosopher's moniker and his sonorous, suggestive surname, is nine years out of the pen, after having served 27 years for murder. His anger is an existentially disturbing thing which Mosley describes effectively at the outset. Thus, he's told off by his boss for being late for his shift packing bags at the supermarket: "Fulbright didn't know the meaning of the kind of violence he called up in the ex-con. Socrates couldn't shake the fists out of his hands." Jacob Marley's chains, Lady Macbeth's irredeemably blood-stained hands, and now Socrates's fists.

Walter Mosley made his name with six crime novels about the black private eye Easy Rawlins, but uneasy Socrates Fortlow is a much more compelling hero.

Fought low, can this ageing black man rise and escape the curse of his anger? Can he lay his armour down? It seems unlikely. Yes, he has a lover and a dead-end job, lives in a dump of a squat, and has the respect of every morally substantial person he crosses. His life seems more promising than the one described in the first Socrates Fortlow novel, Always Outnumbered, Always Outgunned. But every day some crime happens in his neighbourhood and the cops try to nail him for it (they even try to serve him for not having a licence for Killer, which seems harsh); every day some young Thrasymachus ill-advisedly thrusts himself into Socrates' face; every day unimpressive white people rub him up the wrong way.

Like his Greek predecessor, Socrates is out of joint with this world, though his critical stance is less academic: "The policeman, the salesman in the store, the newspaperman or the TV anchor, Socrates didn't trust any one of them. He knew their jobs were to hold him down and rob him, and then afterward to tell him lies about what had really gone down."

Like the philosopher, too, he tests his friends' views through close questioning. This Socrates, though, asks not only what justice is, but whether such a thing is possible in his neighbourhood.

And other questions besides, each one with ethical import. What social responsibilities does a fallen man have in a broken world? Is privacy essential to him, or should he get a phone? Will being promoted to store manager in the supermarket really do him any favours or will it lose him freedom? He asks not only what the good life is, but whether it is possible for the likes of him. Can this once bad man become good? Walkin' the Dog is about insisting on one's own moral character in tough circumstances.

Mosley's prose here seems affectless, the book apparently devoid of a plot. The 12 chapters could be read as short stories, each one with a Socratic question at its core. The novel nonetheless has a momentum that creeps up like a two-legged mutt, unprepossessing at first, seemingly dopey and a bit simple, but ultimately very powerful. Only a histrionic LA riot - unwittingly sparked when Socrates protests against a corrupt, racist policeman - strikes the wrong note.

Appealingly, though, by the end love turns out not to be a weakness in Fortlow's difficult world, but a responsibility. For a white biped of an Englishman, being dragged around on Socrates Fortlow's chain turns out to be unexpectedly rewarding.

fields.headline: Code words
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  goes in search of his own DNA in Matt Ridley's Genome
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard goes in search of his own DNA in Matt Ridley's Genome
fields.body:
Genome: The Autobiography of a Species in 23 Chapters
Matt Ridley
(Fourth Estate, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

It looks deliberately, depressingly gimmicky: the author's magnificent chromosomes are punched into the cover of the book, his face peeping through the stencilled holes. A couple of pages into the preface we read: "I genuinely believe that we are living through the greatest intellectual moment in history. Bar none." And the very first sentence of the preface made my eyes glaze over. ("The human genome - the complete set of human genes - comes packaged in twenty-three separate pairs of chromosomes."

Reader, do not be put off. There is a fair amount of what looks to me like science, but Ridley explains it very well. He is particularly good at analogy, of a kind that soothes the scepticism you might feel at the idea of a comprehensible science book (if I can understand it, it can't be science). "Imagine that the genome is a book," he says; "There are twenty-three chapters, called CHROMOSOMES. Each chapter contains several thousand stories, called GENES... each word is written in letters called BASES."

What he is explaining is also important: he is explaining to us the wobbly, water-filled bags that serve as the temporary storage space for the precise sequence of chemicals that make us up. Are we destined to contract cancer due to the arrangement of our proteins? Or fated to be good at tennis, remembering phone numbers, or having affairs? Prions, death, cloning, eugenics - Ridley threads it all into a compelling, convincing narrative string.

Now, lord knows there are enough books out there that try to get us to understand DNA, and I've read quite a few of them, but this is one that actually works like philosophy - you lift your eyes up from it and look out at a tree, a sheep, or another person, and you say: "Blimey, so that's what it's all about then."

Of course, a book that can make you think such thoughts should also make you suspicious. I showed the chapter on Chromosome 10 to a friend who happens to be a consultant neurologist, and he blew up when he saw the word "Psychoneuroimmunology", which is basically the idea that high levels of stress can make you ill. This is a fairy-tale as far as many doctors are concerned (although my neurologist friend then got into a blazing row about it with his wife, who is a GP). Anyway, the gist of his argument seemed to be: "Watch out for assertive statements which may be based on contradictory data." (His wife's was: "From what I've seen, there may be something in it.")

What we are dealing with here, you might say, is a belief system, as far as most of us are concerned. I have no more direct and personal evidence that the genome is what matters most, than I do that (say) moving the telly to the other side of the room will improve my flow of chi energy.

One answer to that is that this book is the condensed and simplified work of thousands of people in white coats peering down powerful microscopes for years and being very scrupulous about their findings. Not the work of some fraud with a nose-stud whose only ultimate interest is the contents of my wallet. Besides, if Steve Jones says it's brilliant, that's good enough for me. That is a dry example, but there is much else to go on; this is a code that, were it reproduced at one letter per millimetre, would still be the length of the Danube.

fields.headline: Glorious spectres
fields.standfirst: Claire Messud  admires Michael Ondaatje's long-awaited new novel, Anil's Ghost
fields.trailText: Claire Messud admires Michael Ondaatje's long-awaited new novel, Anil's Ghost
fields.body:
Anil's Ghost
Michael Ondaatje
Bloomsbury, £16.99, 311pp
Buy it at BOL

Early in Michael Ondaatje's Booker Prize-winning novel The English Patient , the thief named Caravaggio inquires where he might find a Canadian nurse called Hana and is told she is in a nearby villa. "It's one they say has a ghost in the garden..." he learns. "She's got her own ghost, a burned patient." The book, as it unfolds, chronicles many things, but central among them is the history of Count de Almásy, Hana's ghost retrieved for humanity.

Ondaatje's long-awaited new novel, set half a century and half a world away from its predecessor, is, nevertheless, its close thematic relation: Anil's Ghost is also the story of a woman's attempt to piece together the lost life of a man who has been ravaged by war. It's just that, in the end, Anil has more than one ghost to contend with.

Anil Tissera, 33 years old, is the orphaned daughter of a respected Sri Lankan doctor who returns to her homeland in the early 1990s under the auspices of the Centre for Human Rights in Geneva. A strong-willed forensic specialist fresh from the killing fields of Guatemala, she has lived in Europe and North America for 15 years; part of her journey here is a rediscovery of lost places and "buried senses from childhood". But the country of her youth is now ravaged by civil war, a nation of hidden enmities and brutal disappearances, mutilated corpses killed by unknown murderers for unknown reasons.

Anil finds herself paired in her work with a reticent archaeologist in his late 40s called Sarath Diyasena, a man of whom she observes that "most of what [he] wished to know was in some way linked to the earth. She suspected he found the social world around him irrelevant". He, meanwhile, is as nonplussed by their partnership as the reader is: "A forensic pathologist, an archaeologist, odd pairing, if you want my opinion."

Troublingly serendipitous, it constitutes the moment in the novel at which the reader must take a leap of literary faith. Ondaatje demanded a similar leap in The English Patient - after all, did the gathering of his characters in the Villa San Girolamo not seem a trifle too convenient? Yet it is impossible not to forgive his God-like manipulations of coincidence. Anil and Sarath must be united in order that Sarath's study of ancient bones from "a sacred grave for monks" near Bandarawela may yield fragments of a contemporary skeleton that will pique Anil's forensic interest. The grave site is in a restricted zone to which only government employees have access; the recent skeleton they find, therefore, has been dumped there by some official employee and is, logically, the victim of a government killing.

It becomes imperative to Anil to identify this skeleton. This will prove, publicly and for the first time, that the government has been involved in the rampage of killings across the island. Sarath, throughout, remains less certain of their enterprise: "There were dangers in handing truth to an unsafe city around you. As an archaeologist, Sarath believed in truth as a principle. That is, he would have given his life for the truth if the truth were of any use."

The first half of the novel, then, weaves its strands in the manner of a deft literary thriller, as Anil and Sarath - whose unity of purpose remains always in question - pursue the identity of the skeleton from Bandarawela. They name it Sailor and sequester it in their laboratory on a disused passenger liner berthed in an unused quay at the north end of Colombo harbour. Tantalising questions about Sarath arise (and remain): is his wife alive or dead? What is the role of his cousin in the government? Where does he go when he disappears for days at a time? Above all, can Anil trust him? But then again, what choice does she have?

It is Sarath who leads her to his former teacher, a now-blind epigraphist called Palipana who "made his name translating Pali scripts and recording and translating the rock graffiti of Sigiriya". His more recent scholarship, apparently falsified, has led to his ostracisation and he has retreated, hermit-like, to a remote and abandoned forest monastery where he is cared for by his niece. He in turn sends them to find an artificer, a man who paints the eyes on statues of the Buddha in accordance with ancient ritual. The man he recommends, Ananda Udugama, has been reduced to working in the gem mines and is now a hopeless drunk; but it is he alone, Palipana insists, who will be able to reconstruct a human head from Sailor's skull.

Ananda is duly found, and the trio - Sarath, Anil and Ananda - retreat with the skeleton to "a walawwa in Ekneligoda, the house belonging to a family named Wickramasinghe, who had lived in it for five generations". Now, however, the house is abandoned and in questionable repair; there is mysterious writing on the walls. It is this section of the book - in which Sarath, Anil and Ananda hover around Sailor the way Hana, Caravaggio and Kip hovered around the burned husk of a man - that most powerfully echoes The English Patient. In both instances the sputtering war drawing to a close in the world outside becomes something more personal within the odd, artificial community of these isolated characters.

It is also by this point that the novel has ceased to resemble a thriller, and gives rein instead to its more oblique and subtle explorations. Although Sailor will, against all odds, be identified, that identification comes to seem almost irrelevant. (Which is not to say that this identification will not have consequences, and serious ones.)

We are instead embroiled in the delicate and agonising histories of the maimed men who surround Anil: Ananda, who has lost his wife and seeks to die; Sarath, who has lost his also and may, indeed, share Ananda's impulse; and Sarath's strange, fierce younger brother Gamini, a doctor in the emergency services whose isolation in the madness of war is all but complete. Strung out on speed, barely sleeping or eating, his marriage long over and his relationship with his brother tense at best, Gamini is so fully in the arms of the dead and dying that he is all but untouchable. And yet it is with him rather than with his brother that Anil forges a bond; and it is he who will prove war's true survivor.

What is most striking about Ondaatje's vision in Anil's Ghost is its terrible isolation. No man or woman lives in community: all are depicted as fully and fundamentally alone, sealed off from their fellows no matter how they try to transcend the barriers between them. Often, indeed, they take pleasure in those very barriers.

Anil's former lover and her best friend in the United States are both lost to her; Sarath and Gamini are brothers, but cannot share their hearts. The small grouping around Sailor, in which all are together and yet so alone, is emblematic of this inescapable solitude. It would seem that human relations are always an incomprehensible war, whether in the pampered comfort of North America or the unsettled brutality of war-torn Sri Lanka. It is only Palinapa, the blind near-prophet alone in the wilderness, who seems close to finding peace in this novel; and that only because he has renounced the world.

This powerful sense of isolation is reinforced, too, by Ondaatje's particular literary form. In the glory of his images and inventiveness of his prose, he is ultimately a lyric writer. Impatient with the banalities of scene-setting, he writes in fragmented tableaux: static, isolated moments from which a sense of continuity is only implied. There is much to astonish, to disturb and to admire in this dense book, which demands the reader's fullest engagement. Ondaatje's ability to create deeply moving fictions through indirection is a rare triumph: a poet in the skin of a novelist, he makes the mysteries of silence speak with the force of his words.

It is this section of the book - in which Sarath, Anil and Ananda hover around Sailor the way Hana, Caravaggio and Kip hovered around the burned husk of a man - that most powerfully echoes The English Patient. In both instances the sputtering war drawing to a close in the world outside becomes something more personal within the odd, artificial community of these isolated characters. It is also by this point that the novel has ceased to resemble a thriller, and gives rein instead to its more oblique and subtle explorations. Although Sailor will, against all odds, be identified, that identification comes to seem almost irrelevant. (Which is not to say that this identification will not have consequences, and serious ones.) We are instead embroiled in the delicate and agonising histories of the maimed men who surround Anil: Ananda, who has lost his wife and seeks to die; Sarath, who has lost his also and may, indeed, share Ananda's impulse; and Sarath's strange, fierce younger brother Gamini, a doctor in the emergency services whose isolation in the madness of war is all but complete. Strung out on speed, barely sleeping or eating, his marriage long over and his relationship with his brother tense at best, Gamini is so fully in the arms of the dead and dying that he is all but untouchable. And yet it is with him rather than with his brother that Anil forges a bond; and it is he who will prove war's true survivor. What is most striking about Ondaatje's vision in Anil's Ghost is its terrible isolation. No man or woman lives in community: all are depicted as fully and fundamentally alone, sealed off from their fellows no matter how they try to transcend the barriers between them. Often, indeed, they take pleasure in those very barriers. Anil's former lover and her best friend in the United States are both lost to her; Sarath and Gamini are brothers, but cannot share their hearts. The small grouping around Sailor, in which all are together and yet so alone, is emblematic of this inescapable solitude. It would seem that human relations are always an incomprehensible war, whether in the pampered comfort of North America or the unsettled brutality of war-torn Sri Lanka. It is only Palinapa, the blind near-prophet alone in the wilderness, who seems close to finding peace in this novel; and that only because he has renounced the world. This powerful sense of isolation is reinforced, too, by Ondaatje's particular literary form. In the glory of his images and inventiveness of his prose, he is ultimately a lyric writer. Impatient with the banalities of scene-setting, he writes in fragmented tableaux: static, isolated moments from which a sense of continuity is only implied. There is much to astonish, to disturb and to admire in this dense book, which demands the reader's fullest engagement. Ondaatje's ability to create deeply moving fictions through indirection is a rare triumph: a poet in the skin of a novelist, he makes the mysteries of silence speak with the force of his words.

fields.headline: Small Press Corner
fields.trailText: A look at the history of Zimbabwe through the eyes of a teacher in the days before independence
fields.body:
Beloved African
Jill Baker
(Covos Day, £19.95)

In Zimbabwe today, it's all coming down with history - to use Northern Irish poet Paul Muldoon's description of another troubled territory - and a closer look at that history might help us understand what is taking place right now.

Beloved African is the story of one man's work as a teacher in the then Rhodesia, from 1910 till shortly before the Unilateral Declaration of Independence in 1965. As Principal of Tjolotjo School, John Hammond taught at a place that fostered some of the future leaders of the independence movement, including Joshua Nkomo, who himself later helped to teach carpentery at Tjolotjo. A useful historical resource, the book is told mainly through the reminiscences of Hammond's wife, Nancy.

South African publisher Covos Day (UK distributors Verulam Publishing, 01727 872 770) publishes a variety of Rhodesian memoirs. Many of the others are by anti-insurgent soldiers and policemen.

webTitle: Zen and the art of serial thrilling

fields.headline: Zen and the art of serial thrilling
fields.standfirst: Michael Dibdin tells Nick Wroe about his debt to Sherlock Holmes stories
fields.trailText: Michael Dibdin tells Nick Wroe about his debt to Sherlock Holmes stories
fields.body:
The crime writer Michael Dibdin is an unlikely adornment to the Irish literary tradition. He was born in Wolverhampton, lives in Seattle and made his name writing about a detective in Italy. But his formative years were spent in 1950s and 1960s Lisburn in Northern Ireland, where he received an early crash course in narrative skills. "Most people then didn't have televisions, and pubs didn't even have jukeboxes. So people would talk and tell stories and try to top the last story with a better one. If your story was no good you would find out real fast. It was a great education."

This was a time before Northern Ireland become interesting, he says. "As far as I was concerned I grew up in a rather boring provincial town. So I read everything that came my way: classics, modern novels, non-fiction, poetry, plays. I just gobbled it all down."

As for crime fiction, the decisive discovery was "the inevitable Conan Doyle". Dibdin was given a 1930s set of Sherlock Holmes stories owned by his grandfather when he was 14. "It's the absolute best age to read to them," he says. "I believed it all, and for months I lay trembling in bed at the thought that murderous Mormons would come into the room and write 'Two more days to go' on the wall in blood or something."

His grounding in the minutiae of Baker Street ultimately fed into his first novel, The Last Sherlock Holmes Story, in which Holmes takes on the Jack the Ripper case. Its publication in 1978 was a good news/bad news story, according to Dibdin. "Much to my amazement and delight it was published by Jonathan Cape," he explains. "But then it sold 13-and-a-half copies, and the only interest people had in anything else I might do was a sequel. I didn't want to spend my life writing Sherlock Holmes pastiches. But on the other hand I didn't know what else to do."

He ended up teaching English in Italy, where eight years later he did write another Victorian pastiche, this time about the Brownings in Florence. "The low point in my career was when I moved back to England after the five years in Italy and my American publisher turned the book down. I really thought 'That's it, my career has hit a reef.' But guess what? It has just been published in America and has sold 35,000 copies. I just knew it would do well! But would anyone believe me?"

Dibdin then wrote Ratking, the first outing for Italian detective Aurelio Zen, although at that stage there was no inkling that he would feature in another six books. "To be perfectly frank, I was so depressed about my career, I wasn't presumptuous enough to think that it could become anything like a series." Ratking won the 1988 Crime Writers Association Golden Dagger award, and people started asking when the next Zen book was due.

While he has written four other one-off novels in the meantime and is currently working on another, Dibdin admits to relishing his series. "You have to pay attention to all the people who may, or may not, have read the previous books. You have to be consistent with all problems that had happened to your character. There is a satisfying sense of follow-through that isn't there in one-offs. The problem is that it can degenerate into simply replication. But frankly I get bored if I'm not doing something new, so I come up with new stuff as a way of keeping myself interested."

He says he is surprised that the series is so little used in mainstream literary fiction. "Trollope did it all the time, but now it is fairly rare outside of genre." Dibdin operates very much at the literary end of the crime genre, and his work has a stylish intelligence that puts a lot of supposedly more literary fiction to shame. So how irksome to him is it that even the best crime fiction gets limited critical acclaim?

"I remember what Oscar Wilde said about moral or immoral books - they are either well written or badly written. Whether it's crime fiction or mainstream fiction, the good stuff survives and the other stuff doesn't. There is a nice little party game when you name 10 Booker-shortlisted writers and ask what they have in common. Most people's first reaction is to say, 'Who the fuck are some of these people?' "

The paperback of the seventh and latest Aurelio Zen book, Blood Rain, is published this month. In it the ageing and increasingly world-weary detective turns up in Sicily. While it seemed inevitable that Zen would one day face the Mafia, Dibdin was always conscious of the pitfalls.

"I was writing about a very violent island where a lot of extremely heroic people have gone to their death because they tried to do something right. I just thought it would be a little bit cheap, aesthetically and morally, to have my fictional detective go in there and come away without a scratch on him. It would look a little bit too easy, like Rambo sorting out the problems of east LA with two hand guns and a fast car."

But as to how scratched Zen gets, you'll have to find out for yourself. Dibdin's cleverly layered prose ensures that by the conclusion of the novel everything remains possible. "The shadow hanging over the death of my character is precisely the same as the shadow hanging over my own inevitable death. You know that sooner or later it must end, but to be honest, it's not something I think about all the time."

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: A great book for quiz masters, plus Negative Space and Deeper Into Movies
fields.body:
Hong Kong's Heroic Bloodshed
(Pocket Essentials Film, £2.99)

What film writing is now - factoids bolted together to make toys for boys. True, these are top Tonka-quality factoids, but written in presentation-speak prose - vocabulary more ritualised and fake-tough than a martial-arts academy. The authors' concept of Hong Kong, too, is Rough-Guide phoney cool - no feel for where or how John Woo and Wong Kar-Wai etc grew up, what their movies synthesise, what they mean. In the Pocket Essentials philosophy, feelings, like meanings, are for wimps; films are to be consumed, rather than enjoyed, and the details of their creation traded like Pokemon cards. Useful if you want to win quizzes; no bloody fun, though.

Negative Space
Manny Farber (Da Capo Press, £12.95)
Buy it at BOL

Now this really is tough - ie hard-thought-out: the film reviews of a painter and lover of pop culture. Farber perceives meaning in what he sees onscreen: how faces, gestures, and lighting have a language that communicates directly with the subconscious. Which makes him sound pretentious, when he ain't. Nor is he imposing his own personality; he just wants to inspire you to look harder. He's brave: who else, while always respecting the movie skills of Scorsese and Schrader, would logically demolish Taxi Driver and its dodgy gun obsessions, or remark that the real Bonnie Parker would have served languid Faye Dunaway on toast with a side order of hash browns?

Deeper Into Movies
Pauline Kael
(Marion Boyars, £14.95)
Buy it at BOL

Her reviews on the verge of the 1970s: includes Bogdanovich's The Last Picture Show - savour how Kael explains that even the boring movies showing in its oil-and-dust Texas town were an escape from a "level of dissatisfaction which is part of the truth of American experience". We weren't just enticed to look harder into films by reading Kael. Since they are her core metaphor for life, and her main understanding of the world - her religion - we learned from her how criticism is context, exploration, making connections between an art, especially a pop art, and lived experience. Read her on The Godfather, and get closer to the spirit of 1972 than political history could take you.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Extreme writing from the anatomist of pain, plus The Leper's Companions, The White Bone, Boxy an Star
fields.body:
Everything You Need
AL Kennedy
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Reduced to the level of plot, this massive novel sounds unpromising: an island community of self-obsessed, masochistic writers, a daughter who doesn't know that her mentor is also her father, an editor drowning in booze and self-loathing. But pain is Kennedy's specialist subject, and her determination to dissect it unwavering. As we follow Nathan Staples on his quest for redemption, we move from hideous gallows humour to mawkish tragedy, from confusion and ignorance to a semblance of clarity. This is extreme writing, and Kennedy occasionally chances her arm. For the most part, thankfully, the risks pay off.

The Leper's Companions
Julia Blackburn
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

At the beginning of this disquieting novel, a grief-stricken woman decides to conjure up an imagined world in order to soothe her pain. On that overtly flimsy basis, Blackburn takes us back to the 15th century, to mermaids washed up on beaches, omens and portents, and pilgrimages to the Holy Land. Fanciful though this might sound, Blackburn is a skilful and subtle enough writer to pull it off, and her tale of journeys - both literal and metaphysical, inward and outward - is an arresting one. Fittingly for such a daring novel, it speaks volumes about the power of the imagination to transform an unbearable reality.

The White Bone
Barbara Gowdy
(Flamingo, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Gowdy has always been a somewhat surreal writer - her excellent novel Mister Sandman featured a mute little girl who conducted much of her life from the inside of a cupboard. Here, she turns her attention to the elephant kingdom, telling the story of Mud, an orphan member of the tribe who is blessed with visionary powers. The novel ranges across the east African plains, as the elephants flee the "hindleggers" and struggle to survive in the face of terrible drought. It may all sound a little whimsical, but Gowdy is a strong writer, and she introduces several compelling strands exploring the power of memory and language to bind a community together.

Boxy an Star
Daren King
(Abacus, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

"I reckon all memories are gone rotten these days coz no one can remember nothin." So says the teenaged Bole, in this futuristic tale of fourth-generation drug-users. Written entirely in a broken-down, spaced-out demotic, Boxy an Star tells the story of Bole, his lover and their drug-dealer, and the permanent, meandering quest for the next hit. Such is the strength and originality of King's narrative voice, however, that this book escapes the narrow confines of the druggy novel to become a powerful and tender depiction of juvenile emotion that veers wildly between farcical comedy and desperate melancholy.

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.trailText: Imagine reading Elmore Leonard for the first time; add a zest of Quentin Tarantino and John Woo and you might get an idea of the flavour of Douglas Winter's Run...
fields.body:
Imagine reading Elmore Leonard for the first time; add a zest of Quentin Tarantino and John Woo and you might get an idea of the flavour of Douglas Winter's Run (Canongate £9.99), a unique novel which transcends the hardboiled genre by a meaty mile. Burdon Lane looks like an unassuming traditional Washington DC businessman, but the appearance is skin-deep; he is actually a professional arms dealer, deadly when crossed. His weekend gun-run should be business as usual, riding the Iron Highway from Dirty City to Manhattan with his usual crew of friendly psychopaths, but once in New York all hell is set loose in an orgy of gunfire and flames.

Lane has to hunt down the reasons and the men responsible, and he himself is forced to go on the run with the most improbable rap gangsta companion from the opposing team. His epic quest through the underbelly of American crime culminates in a church with an orgiastic display of gunpower, guts and blood. Winter's street-smart prose creates an unrelenting pace, crisscrossed by an unerring touch for gun fetishism and popular culture. The debut of the year, this book has all the ingredients of a future classic. And the biggest surprise of all? Winter is not some 20-year-old punk straight up from the mean streets but a fiftysomething white Washington attorney.

It has been almost 20 years since screenwriter Marc Behm made a similarly awesome impact with his The Eye of the Beholder (recently reissued by No Exit Press at £6.99). After retiring to France, the eight novels written since only appeared locally in translation. Afraid to Death (No Exit Press, £6.99) is the first to surface in his native language, and is a fascinating counterpart to his earlier masterpiece.

Whereas the private eye of the earlier twice-filmed novel was obsessed by a younger woman and pursued her across the vast American continent, this time around the protagonist is a teenage boy who becomes similarly captivated by a mysterious young woman who he first observes on the other side of the lake in his hometown. Every sighting of the woman is followed by a death, and soon he has convinced himself that she is none other than the angel of death. At the first opportunity he leaves home and goes on the run in order to avoid a future meeting that could prove fatal. As he grows older he finds himself unable to settle down, convinced that she is about to find him again. Wonderfully disturbing.

A highly popular series reaches its ninth instalment with Donna Leon's Friends in High Places (Macmillan, £15.99), featuring the engaging Commissario Guido Brunetti of the Venice police force. Once again Leon offers a bitter-sweet view of her adopted city through the investigations of her dogged policeman, walking a dodgy tightrope between crime-fighting and local politics. Carefully plotted and full of colourful as well as sinister characters, this is crime writing of the highest order: powerful, relevant and all too full of human failings.

fields.headline: Fossil fools
fields.standfirst: Tim Radford  learns history's lessons in Stephen Jay Gould's penultimate collection of essays, The Lying Stones of Marrakech
fields.trailText: Tim Radford learns history's lessons in Stephen Jay Gould's penultimate collection of essays, The Lying Stones of Marrakech
fields.body:
The Lying Stones of Marrakech: Penultimate Reflections in Natural History
Stephen Jay Gould
Jonathan Cape, £17.99, 372pp
Buy it at BOL

If the past is another country, we should go there more often: we might learn something. Sometimes we might learn how far we have moved on, sometimes how little. The lying stones of Marrakech, for instance, are fake fossils sold to tourists. A palaeontologist will see them as fakes straight away, but they remind Stephen Jay Gould, science historian, curator and palaeontologist, of Dr Beringer of Wurzburg, who in 1726 was taken in by remarkable "fossils" of lizards in their skins, birds with beaks and eyes, spiders with their webs, bees feeding on flowers, the crescent moon, the sun with a human face, and even the Hebrew letters YHVH that spell out the name of God.

Anyone now could see that such things had to have been faked (as indeed they were, by malicious colleagues). But in 1726, many scholars believed that organisms arose by spontaneous generation: if heat and light could magic living flesh from nothing, then it could also act upon "lapidifying forces" to conjure up stony little jests, sports of nature, testaments to God's mysterious ways. For a Christendom that believed the world to be 6,000 years old, created in seven days and washed clean by Noah's Flood, it seemed the only sensible explanation for stark ribcages or huge jawbones enclosed in limestone rocks. Humans have a way of seeing only what their world prepares them to see, which is why fossil fraud still flourishes.

So far, Gould has composed 290 essays in more than a dozen collections over more than two decades, most of them taking a sympathetic view of bygone error. The latest opens helpful windows onto a world of Lamarck, Lavoisier and Britain's JBS Haldane.

His tolerance falters when it tackles more enduring folly. Early in the 20th century, some Americans became troubled at the "floods" of asylum seekers and economic migrants reaching Ellis Island. To the poet of the Statue of Liberty they might have been teeming millions yearning to breathe free, but to Charles Benedict Davenport of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, home of American eugenics, they were the bearers of genetic traits for "nomadism" and "feeble inhibition". (Davenport carefully distinguished this from the nomadism shown by his own migrant ancestors, blessed instead with a gene for "enterprising restlessness".)

Wanderlust, Davenport conceded, was a fundamental instinct which was typically "inhibited in intelligent adults of civilised peoples". Davenport was thinking explicitly of the "hordes of Jews... with their intense individualism and ideals of gain at the cost of any interest". He contrasted this with "the early English and more recent Scandinavian immigration, with their ideals of community life in the open country, advancement by the sweat of the brow, and the uprearing of families in the fear of God and the love of country".

This wasn't a National Front pamphlet but a leading textbook called Heredity In Relation To Eugenics (1911). Such thinking hasn't gone away. History, Gould says, "shows a consistent linkage between the genetic claims cast in this mould and conservative political arguments for maintenance of an unjust status quo of great benefit to people currently in power". Need anyone mention Jack Straw at this point, or Ann Widdecombe? Gould promises to stop after 300 essays, hence the word "penultimate" in the subtitle. It suggests a baton, waiting to be picked up.
