fields.headline: Experiments in exile
fields.standfirst: Hype notwithstanding,  Ian Sansom  salutes Aleksander Hernon's The Question of Bruno
fields.trailText: Hype notwithstanding, Ian Sansom salutes Aleksander Hernon's The Question of Bruno
fields.body:
The Question of Bruno
Aleksandar Hemon
Picador, £12.99, 240pp
Buy it at BOL

In conversation, and in publishing, people overstate: we expect this, and we enjoy it. Who but the critic and the cynic would not thrill to the words "I love you", or "This is the best meal I have ever eaten", or "He writes with a wit and elegance and lightness of touch that will ensure him a place alongside Nabokov and Kundera"? This is usually called a willing suspension of disbelief, but given the recent history of literary excitements and enthusiasms we might also call it the Sebald Effect. The Sebald Effect, named after WG, is what happens when an individual becomes an idol. We lose all sense of perspective, as though blinded by love, unable to acknowledge our beloved's obvious faults.

Thus, Aleksandar Hemon. Readers have been encouraged to line up in awe to anticipate the publication of Hemon's debut, The Question of Bruno, a collection of short stories. And a wonderful collection it is too: the book is undoubtedly beguiling. Hemon, born in Sarajevo, half Serbian and half Ukrainian, emigrated to America in 1992. He has apparently been writing fiction in English only since 1995, and it shows. His prose is at times extraordinarily delicate and at times impossibly crude. His sentences are often smothered in adjectives and metaphors, as when people who've never had Marmite before lather it on like jam.

"Under the wave-throbbing, ochre and maroon island of vomit, a school of aluminium fish gathered and nibbled it peevishly." But then who among us is not guilty of overwriting, if only in the signature flourish in our chequebooks? Skill is a profundity only among plumbers; writers are allowed the occasional risk, and the inevitable failure.

Hemon has been compared to Nabokov, presumably because English is not his mother tongue, but lots of writers in English started out life in other tongues. He is actually more like Thomas Hardy. Substitute his name for Hardy's in this passage from Virginia Woolf's "Personalities": "No one has written worse English than Mr Hardy in some of his novels - cumbrous, stilted, ugly and inexpressive - yes, but at the same time so strangely expressive of something attractive to us in Mr Hardy himself that we would not change it for the perfection of Sterne at his best. It becomes coloured by its surroundings; it becomes literature."

And so to the stories, or almost. First, there are the photos. As with the immaculate Sebald, the text is prefaced by blurry black and white uncaptioned photos, which do their necessary work: softening up the reader, reminding us that we we were not there and couldn't possibly know, that what follows is history and memory. Like a catch in the throat or a misty eye, they announce the book as elegy.

The first story, "Islands", establishes the theme of exile and loss: "We got up at dawn, ignored the yolky sun, loaded our navy-blue Austin with suitcases and then drove straight to the coast, stopping only on the verge of Sarajevo." If you really want to be honest about the effect of that opening sentence, replace that ultimate S-word with, say, "Melton Mowbray".

There is simply more history and more drama - there are more events - in Hemon's short stories than in a shelf and a half of the usual dayglo Anglo-American entertainment: the Ukrainian uncle who had been in one of Stalin's camps in "Islands"; the imaginary account of the assassination of Archduke Ferdinand in "The Accordion".

But history is only raw material; it is to Hemon's great advantage therefore that he's not merely in earnest, but also very sophisticated. Like Sebald or Hardy, or Raymond Carver - a palpable influence - what impresses in Hemon's work is both the extreme guile and the obvious sincerity (obvious sincerity, of course, being a product of extreme guile). Thus Hemon jostles the reader - "But lo!, dear reader, while we were up to our waists in Pronek's stream of consciousness, fly-fishing for the psyche, the world did not stop revolving, the clock did not stop ticking" - and generally monkeys around: "Most of this story is a consequence of irresponsible imagination and shameless speculation." The two best stories, "A Coin" and "Blind Josef Pronek and Dead Souls", use every trick in the book.

Most winningly of all, his cleverness is set off by a rather modest, shy and even prim narrative voice, which occasionally allows itself to slip into moralising and whimsy. In "Exchange of Pleasant Words", Hemon writes of the experience of exile that "we have to live these half-lives of people who cannot forget what they used to be and who are afraid of being addressed in a foreign language, no longer able to utter anything truly meaningful." With this, to a greater or lesser extent, we are all familiar.

fields.headline: Home alone
fields.standfirst: Riccardo Orizio goes in search of the people left behind by colonialism in Lost White Tribes
fields.trailText: Riccardo Orizio goes in search of the people left behind by colonialism in Lost White Tribes
fields.body:
Lost White Tribes: Journeys Among The Forgotten
Riccardo Orizio
Secker & Warburg, £15.99, 270pp
Buy it at BOL

Some years ago Molly Dineen made a wonderful documentary called Home From The Hill. It charted the homecoming of Hilary Hook, who for 40 years had served as a colonial administrator in the highlands of Kenya. Now, returning from the tropics to a north London suburb, he floundered about his kitchen struggling to work out how to use a tin opener. Profumo, pop music, non-stick frying pans - all these had passed him by. He was home, but not at home.

Younger viewers in particular, who thought of colonialism as a backdrop to the costume dramas of the early 1980s, found it strange to watch someone who was both a product and an agent of such an antique world order. Here was a man, charming and intelligent, who saw modern life as a foreign country: this twinkling octogenarian came across as a time-traveller. After all, doesn't colonialism belong to some other, long-gone universe?

Not according to Riccardo Orizio, the Italian journalist who has produced Lost White Tribes, a superb and beguiling work in which he travels in search of the long-forgotten descendants of those Europeans who voyaged to the colonies and, unlike Hook, never came back. These include Dutch burghers in Sri Lanka; German workers and acrobats who sailed to Jamaica after Abolition and ended up as slaves themselves; American confederates from Texas and Alabama who fled to Brazil after the Civil War hoping to fashion a new Dixieland out of the cotton and slaves available to them there; and Polish soldiers sent to quell the slave rebellions in the French colony of Saint-Domingue at the start of the 19th century, and who ended up fighting on the side of the insurgent Haitians.

Most of these groups are missing from both hipster tour guides and the colonial archive. Often they've become apocryphal creatures within their own countries, mistaken for missionaries or dismissed - correctly, in the case of the Blancs Matignon in Guadeloupe - as incestuous peasants. They're torn between the desire to be heard - to reach out to a wider world that might rescue them from penury - and a survivalist suspicion that their long-guarded secrets may be exploited by novelty-chasing outsiders. So they teeter on in straitened circumstances: many Germans died from disease or malnutrition when they first arrived in 19th-century Jamaica, and their descendants, still straggly and emaciated, were deemed just right to play prisoners when the film Papillon was shot there.

This is emphatically not a history of the white colonial elites. Orizio's white tribes may live in the shadow of opulent resorts or Great House plantations, but their own communities can often be reached only by pot-holed mud tracks. The Poles in Casales live in dried mud houses on a treeless mountain. They have no electricity, running water or school; their church collapsed years ago. Now that their skin is as dark as Haitians', all the ancestry they have left is the hint of Slavic cheekbones and a dance they call the polka - and a framed photo of the Pope, who visited the island 20 years ago and who they still dream will rescue them.

Orizio finds that these dispersed communities have much in common, chiefly a fear of extinction (the Basters of Namibia have had their land confiscated and are forced to speak English rather than Afrikaans at school) and an ambivalence towards miscegenation (the Germans in Jamaica look askance at marriage to black islanders, while the Confederates in Brazil reserve their scorn for those who marry native Indians). An ambience of embattled loneliness hovers over most of them.

Orizio does not try to weave these disconnected peoples' complex political and historical trajectories into a single grandiose theory: he's fascinated by poignant specificities, the enigma of each arrival. Warmly solicitous but never sentimentalising, the book bears comparison with such masterpieces about migration as Nicholas Lemann's The Promised Land and John Berger and Jean Mohr's A Seventh Man.

"How does one distinguish between a slight story that never made any headlines and a great adventure that deserves the status of history?" Orizio never answers his own question. Yet while individually his subjects are small fry, their lives shed light not only on a cruelly overlooked residue of colonialism, but on the bravery and utopian resilience that fuels those millions of people who, today, uprooted by war and poverty, trek across China, sub-Saharan Africa and the Balkans in pursuit of a better life. The Martiniquian poet Aimé Cesaire once wrote: "Hurrah for all those who have made nothing!" Lost White Tribes eschews that kind of cheerleading. Nonetheless, it will embed the lives of those nothing-people in the imaginations of the wide readership it deserves to win.

fields.headline: Shades of doubt
fields.standfirst: Yasmin Alibhai-Brown falls into the gap between punditry and analysis in Who Do We Think We Are?
fields.trailText: Yasmin Alibhai-Brown falls into the gap between punditry and analysis in Who Do We Think We Are?
fields.body:
Who Do We Think We Are?
Yasmin Alibhai-Brown
Allen Lane, £18.99, 336pp
Buy it at BOL

In the middle of the 18th century, Ignatius Sancho, a well-known black African settler in Britain, wrote of his life in London: "I am only a lodger, and hardly that." Devoted to his wife, running a successful shop in Westminster and acquainted with some of the major figures of his time, he nonetheless did not feel fully a part of the London society he admired.

Over 200 years after Sancho wrote those words, novelist Andrea Levy stakes a claim for a way of being that allows a simultaneous blackness and Englishness when she says: "You can't allow Englishness to be linked to ethnicity because that would be tacit agreement with the idea of racial purity." So does this mean that we have made significant progress in thinking about race and belonging?

Newspapers and broadcasts give contradictory impressions of what is happening today in multicultural, multi-ethnic Britain; headlines denouncing "bogus" asylum seekers and unworthy "economic" refugees sit uneasily alongside truisms about our exciting and culturally diverse society. These seemingly odd juxtapositions are not new: Sancho and others noted how sympathy and an apparently warm reception went hand in hand with hostile curiosity and physical and verbal abuse.

In the academic world there has been a longstanding debate on "race" and cultural identities. Some would argue that the work is too difficult or too obscure to be of use to anyone outside academia, but there is also much of value which deserves wider circulation. A number of academics, myself included, are called upon to "translate" what we do into terms more readily understandable by a wider audience. Some of us do this with mixed feelings: complex situations and problems require complex solutions which aren't easily explicable in media-friendly soundbites. This problem is even more acute for black intellectuals, who often have a hard time getting their work taken seriously.

However, Alibhai-Brown's attempt in Who Do We Think We Are? to act as an interpreter of the works of those she names as "our brilliant leaders" - Stuart Hall and Sivanandan, for instance - only serves to show up the distance between journalistic punditry and carefully considered, thoroughly researched intellectual analysis.

Alibhai-Brown passionately argues for a change in our habits of thinking about race. The switch she calls for is difficult to visualise; it's even more difficult to think about how to achieve it. That's partly because her method of presenting evidence is flawed: she will quote a distant uncle or unnamed researcher in a way that cannot be challenged because they are presented as "authentic" subjective accounts of personal experience and opinion. Sometimes it is not clear when the respondents made the comments they did, as when a police officer discusses the impact of Margaret Thatcher's views on policing the "enemy within". Was he speaking to Alibhai-Brown back in the 1980s? The 1990s?

Her knife is sharp as she castigates elitist academics, various sections of the media and assorted feminists and politicians for their inability and/or reluctance to engage with the full implications of multicultural Britain in a principled, imaginative way. But some of her barbed comments are misplaced. For instance when she criticises those "sanguine, metropolitan adventurers" (Mike Phillips, Darcus Howe and Philip Dodd of the ICA) who she claims discuss hybridity as though it were a given, I'm not even sure from her account if they were discussing hybridity or multiculturalism.

Multiculturalism implies the juxtaposition of different, fixed cultures, whereas hybridity is concerned with the fluid and shifting base of cultures and their interaction. It is perfectly possible for a society to live with hybridity and to be segregated at the same time.

Alibhai-Brown warns us not to homogenise communities, but harks back to the "halcyon days" of anti-racist struggle when Thatcher was prime minister. Yet some of "us" were in thrall to Thatcher then, some dissociated themselves from anti-racist struggles, and many were uneasy even in the 1970s about being named "black" (as she does later admit). I suspect this longing for the past is based on a retrospective sense of certainty about the justice of anti-racist struggle, which helped to smooth over the schisms that are as abundant in the black community as elsewhere.

Perhaps it's unfair to complain about methodological weaknesses in a non-academic text. But the register is sometimes an academic one and, with its copious footnotes, the book feels as though it ought to be more rigorous than it actually is. She also has an irritating habit of gushing about the writers and intellectuals to whom she refers (Michael Ignatieff is a "contemporary prophet and intellectual giant", who "with proud free will, stands up to be counted").

There are, however, some interesting sections summarising key moments in Britain's long and tangled history of 20th-century black migration; there are moments of eloquence and insight, as when she tackles the shortsightedness in both black and white communities in failing to anticipate the pitfalls and potential advantages of racial interaction. The book is at its best when giving straightforward accounts of contemporary issues.

 Lola Young is professor of cultural studies at Middlesex University and project director of the National Museum and Archives of Black History and Culture.

Alibhai-Brown passionately argues for a change in our habits of thinking about race. The switch she calls for is difficult to visualise; it's even more difficult to think about how to achieve it. That's partly because her method of presenting evidence is flawed: she will quote a distant uncle or unnamed researcher in a way that cannot be challenged because they are presented as "authentic" subjective accounts of personal experience and opinion. Sometimes it is not clear when the respondents made the comments they did, as when a police officer discusses the impact of Margaret Thatcher's views on policing the "enemy within". Was he speaking to Alibhai-Brown back in the 1980s? The 1990s? Her knife is sharp as she castigates elitist academics, various sections of the media and assorted feminists and politicians for their inability and/or reluctance to engage with the full implications of multicultural Britain in a principled, imaginative way. But some of her barbed comments are misplaced. For instance when she criticises those "sanguine, metropolitan adventurers" (Mike Phillips, Darcus Howe and Philip Dodd of the ICA) who she claims discuss hybridity as though it were a given, I'm not even sure from her account if they were discussing hybridity or multiculturalism. Multiculturalism implies the juxtaposition of different, fixed cultures, whereas hybridity is concerned with the fluid and shifting base of cultures and their interaction. It is perfectly possible for a society to live with hybridity and to be segregated at the same time. Alibhai-Brown warns us not to homogenise communities, but harks back to the "halcyon days" of anti-racist struggle when Thatcher was prime minister. Yet some of "us" were in thrall to Thatcher then, some dissociated themselves from anti-racist struggles, and many were uneasy even in the 1970s about being named "black" (as she does later admit). I suspect this longing for the past is based on a retrospective sense of certainty about the justice of anti-racist struggle, which helped to smooth over the schisms that are as abundant in the black community as elsewhere. Perhaps it's unfair to complain about methodological weaknesses in a non-academic text. But the register is sometimes an academic one and, with its copious footnotes, the book feels as though it ought to be more rigorous than it actually is. She also has an irritating habit of gushing about the writers and intellectuals to whom she refers (Michael Ignatieff is a "contemporary prophet and intellectual giant", who "with proud free will, stands up to be counted"). There are, however, some interesting sections summarising key moments in Britain's long and tangled history of 20th-century black migration; there are moments of eloquence and insight, as when she tackles the shortsightedness in both black and white communities in failing to anticipate the pitfalls and potential advantages of racial interaction. The book is at its best when giving straightforward accounts of contemporary issues.  Lola Young is professor of cultural studies at Middlesex University and project director of the National Museum and Archives of Black History and Culture.

fields.headline: War crimes
fields.standfirst: A just war, or moral imperialism? A critical look at Nato's Kosovan war in Masters of the Universe?
fields.trailText: A just war, or moral imperialism? A critical look at Nato's Kosovan war in Masters of the Universe?
fields.body:
Masters of the Universe? Nato's Balkan Crusade
edited by Tariq Ali
Verso, £15, 240pp
Buy it at BOL

This book will make numerous powerful men in western chancelleries exceedingly cross, and is likely to garner some dismissive reviews from big-name journalists. The eclectic group of contributors have contrived between them to take on just about everyone involved in the promotion of Nato's first war: some of those people may, with hindsight, be rather embarrassed by their collective excitement over the novel idea of a humanitarian war, a war with no casualties (on our side), which they sold to western public opinion.

"Good has triumphed over evil, justice has overcome barbarism, and the values of civilisation have prevailed," declared Tony Blair when the Nato airstrikes were suspended. This was typical of the overblown cant with which the Nato leadership justified their attack on a sovereign state, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.

Given that the action had no backing from the United Nations and was thus illegal in international law, it is astonishing that so many thinkers were prepared to go along with it. Alex Callinicos's essay "The Ideology of Humanitarian Intervention" quotes Jurgen Habermas, leading philosopher of the western left, as arguing that the Nato action represented "a step on the path from the classical international law of nations towards the cosmopolitan law of a world civil society". Behind such an attitude is the presumptuous idea that Blair and his friends in Nato should be the arbiters of what constitutes goodness, justice and the values of civilisation (Anthony Barnett coined the phrase "moral imperialism" for such British arrogance).

In his vivid, idiosyncratic "Open Letter from a Traveller to the President of the Republic", Regis Debray describes his travels in Serbia and Kosovo, some of it in the company of Paul Watson of the Los Angeles Times (the only correspondent of a western paper who remained there during the war, and who has now won a Pulitzer Prize). In the first three days of bombing the Serbs retaliated with burning, looting and murders; but after that Watson saw no trace of crimes against humanity. Debray observed Albanians returning to Pudajevo and Serbian soldiers guarding Albanian bakeries in Pristina.

"What happened was the imposition of an international air war on an extremely cruel civil war... Judging that they could not fight on two fronts the Serbs seem to have decided to expel manu militari Nato's 'fifth column' or 'land forces', in other words the KLA, especially in the villages where it was impossible to distinguish its members from the rest of the population." There is not, he writes, the slightest doubt that it was the Nato attack that started the humanitarian catastrophe snowballing.

Debray ends with de Gaulle's definition of Nato: "'An organisation imposed on the Atlantic Alliance which is no more and no less than the military and political subordination of western Europe to the United States of America'... I must confess to feeling a bit humiliated when, on asking a member of the Serbian democratic opposition why his president had rushed to meet some American personality before a French one, I received the answer: 'Look, it's always a better idea to talk to the organ grinder than his monkey.' "

The relationship between the US and the rest of Nato is explored in depth, notably by Peter Gowan, in an attempt to explain where the eagerness for the war came from. The Pentagon knew it would not work militarily; Congress was against it; the American public, as Clinton memorably said, would have needed to get out their atlases to know where Kosovo was. The pressure, Gowan writes, came from an anxiety to ensure US credibility with its Nato allies. "The US should not allow the emergence of a unified west European political will to emerge, autonomous from Washington. Instead it had to find a way to rebuild US political leadership above whatever integration went on in western Europe."

Noam Chomsky has written his own book on this war, The New Military Humanism: Lessons from Kosovo, which explores all these issues. His essay in this book, "The Kosovo Peace Accord", details the key issue of the Rambouillet Agreement and its controversial Appendix B, the virtually unknown peace plan produced by the Serbian National Assembly on March 23. It shows clearly that there was an alternative to war: negotiations. Chomsky underlines the ideological imperative which selected Yugoslavia as the site of this first "humanitarian war" rather than, say, Turkey, whose crimes, he writes, took place within Nato itself and with massive support from the US. Don't ask us to believe in the New Humanism.

fields.headline: How's your father?
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: William begged me for £2.49 today. He wants to buy a booster pack of Pokémon cards. When I refused, he burst into tears and threw himself down on the kitchen floor.
fields.body:
Monday, April 17, 2000, Arthur Askey Way

William begged me for £2.49 today. He wants to buy a booster pack of Pokémon cards. When I refused, he burst into tears and threw himself down on the kitchen floor. Glenn came in and said, "You've gotta give 'im the money, Dad, he's lost respect in the playground."

Apparently, there are 151 characters in a set and William has only collected 37 of the most common. Glenn said, "It's like, you know, wearing Marks & Spencer's trainers, Dad?" Glenn has never forgiven me for making him go to school in my M&S trainers when his own Nikes disappeared. He still wakes in the night sweating and crying out for the NSPCC.

Tuesday, April 18

Tania rang at 10.30 this morning to tell me that my father had fallen off a ladder while trying to construct a pagoda in their garden and had injured his back. He was waiting for an ambulance, she said. I could hear my father groaning in the background and the sound of splashing and birdsong.

I left William and Glenn next door with the Ludlows and hurried off to The Lawns. My father was lying half in, half out of the Koi carp pool and appeared to be in agony. Tania was squatting by his side, instructing him to "breathe the pain away, George". The ambulance took another hour to arrive, having been misdirected by the computer to The Lawns Lunatic Asylum in Rutland. The ambulancemen, Derek and Craig, were remorselessly cheerful. It was their fifth gardening incident in two days. They blamed Alan Titchmarsh for the recent alarming rise in accident and emergency admissions. Tania stayed behind to calm the carp and pack a bag, and I went in the ambulance with my father. To take his mind off his pain, I tried to engage him in conversation about Charlie Dimmock, but he wasn't interested.

At 2 o'clock in the afternoon he was diagnosed as having two cracked vertebrae, a fractured shoulder and a deep cut in his left thigh caused by the Homebase Spend & Save card in his trouser pocket. At 8.30pm he was finally taken up to Bevan Ward and put into a bed. Without his teeth, and with his grey hair sticking up around his head, he looked every one of his 56 years. He is lying flat on his back and is unable to do the slightest thing to help himself. "So, not much change there, then," said my mother, his ex-wife, when I rang to give her a progress report.

Query: Where can I buy two Pokmon Easter eggs?

Wednesday, April 19

When I visited my father today I found him in considerable distress. The hospital has lost his teeth. "Not that it bloody well matters," he gummed, "I couldn't reach my bleedin' food anyway." Apparently, his breakfast tray had been placed 6in out of reach of his good arm, 2in nearer than the emergency call button. He is worried about Tania's reaction when she sees him for the first time without his teeth. Apparently, she is under the impression that his teeth are his own.

Pamela Pigg rang to tell me that she wants to renew our relationship. She has bought the boys two Pokmon Easter eggs. I said yes.

Sunday, April 23, Easter Day, St George's Day

I didn't know which trousers to put on today, or what to have for breakfast. Am I suffering from the modern illness Choice Overload Syndrome? I just can't decide. Somebody has written N F R O T H in red pen on my father's notes. I asked a junior doctor what it stood for. "Not for resuscitation, over the hill," she said and hurried away. I hope this was a joke. When I wished Pamela a happy St George's Day this morning, she accused me of "celebrating fascism". We are doomed. Doomed.

fields.headline: Eastern Europe invades London
fields.trailText: Aleksander Hernon and Victor Pelevin swing into town, plus electronic entries and putting Tolstoy in his place
fields.body:
 A wave of East European chic has drenched the London literary party scene, as émigré Bosnian Aleksandar Hemon and Russian Victor Pelevin both arrived in town to promote their new books.

Only one of them really looked the part, though: Pelevin attended his soirée, held in a dank upper room, wearing aviator shades, smoking an outsized cigar and sipping enigmatically from a teacup. Quite possibly he was in disguise, on the run from an enthuasiastic audience member at the Oxford Union, who had charged him with the serious task of saving a new generation of Russians. Pelevin, who is of the opinion that there are political commentators paid far more than him to do that kind of thing, declined the offer.

 Take it from the Loafer, literary prize dinners are gruesome affairs, particularly when they have the word "Gala" in front of them. On the other hand, as pointed out in recent months, the Irish are very good hosts. Even so, offering two tickets to the IMPAC Award (that's IMAPC, according to the organisers' press release) knees-up to members of the public who can answer five questions (about the Award itself) is hopeful verging on self-deluded. But maybe I'm just jaded: if you fancy a go, you can enter electronically. You have until May 17 to bone up on your knowledge of this prestigious gong.

 Our search for unusual and diverting books is bearing more fruit than the produce aisle at Waitrose. We pass, this week, over Radical Forgiveness: Making Room for the Miracle and Think Like a Shrink, in favour of a submission from the delightfully named Grumpus Books.

Confessions of a Literary Heretic by DG Thom has the advantage of a self-explanatory title, but here is a taste in case all is not clear: "The tedium of Anna Karenina is matched only by its voluminousness, consisting as it does almost entirely of the sexual shenanigans of society bores whose only interest, because only capacity, is small-talk and blood-sports." Ha! Tolstoy - that told you. Those wondering about the pedigree of the author will be interested to hear that other available titles include Portrait of a Mind-Suicide and Chocolate Eclairs of the Soul.

 Stop press: Frances Coady, the editorial whizz who was unceremoniously made redundant from a flagging Granta last July, is to head off to pastures new, becoming Vice-President and Publisher of Picador USA. News of shocked reactions next week.

fields.headline: The soul of a migrant
fields.standfirst: Michael Ondaatje had a shattered childhood, torn first from his parents and then from his homeland, Sri Lanka. But he flourished as a writer in Canada, land of newcomers. Now, in his new novel, he returns to the country lost to him more than 40 years ago
fields.trailText: Michael Ondaatje had a shattered childhood, torn first from his parents and then from his homeland, Sri Lanka. But he flourished as a writer in Canada, land of newcomers. Now, in his new novel, he returns to the country lost to him more than 40 years ago
fields.body:
Eight years ago, Michael Ondaatje was doing pretty well. He was feted at home in Canada as a poet and novelist, and revered in the wider literary world. Then came The English Patient, his tale of romance in the Sahara and wartime intrigue in a Tuscan villa. It was his third novel: it co-won the Booker prize in 1992 and four years later was adapted into the Hollywood movie starring Ralph Fiennes and Kristin Scott-Thomas. The film was a huge box office success, won nine Oscars, and dragged the intensely private author into clamorous celebrity. Since then, worldwide English-language sales of the book have topped 2 million.

Ondaatje is a man who works at his own pace. The English Patient was his third novel in 25 years; Anil's Ghost, his latest, took seven years to write. It has a familiar luminous intensity that blurs the boundary between prose and poetry, but it offers little of the epic passion viewers of the film might seek. Though it too charts intimate lives in wartime, it is set in the near-present amid the bloodshed of Sri Lanka, the birthplace Ondaatje left as an 11-year-old child.

He is ambivalent about the fame The English Patient brought him. On the other hand, "Even if people expect you to write romance, it gave me the freedom to write anything I wanted."

His first impulse was to return to poetry, with Handwriting (1998). This was set entirely in Sri Lanka, which he began to revisit only in his 30s. Though his initial trips spawned the quasi-memoir Running In The Family (1982), his 10 other poetry volumes and his fiction gave few clues about the island of his birth. Handwriting, together with Anil's Ghost ("the two books go hand in hand"), complete a journey back to his source.

His first two novels are set in North America, and it is that part of his life and work that came to mind when we met in a downtown skyscraper on a Toronto street leading to Lake Ontario. The neon-lit artery was memorably fixed in the novel, In The Skin Of A Lion (1987), which mapped and mythologised the author's adopted city: the dashing neighbourhood thief Caravaggio has "a parting in his dark hair like Yonge Street at midnight". And Ondaatje's rapid but softly elided speech recalls another character in the book, Patrick Lewis, whose "conversations lost some of their syllables out of shyness, vagueness, uncertainty". Voluble on writing and his other arts - theatre, film, photography - Ondaatje shrinks from personal inquiries. He prefers to write from anonymity, from a watchful invisibility, maintaining the unmediated bond between writer and reader.

Ondaatje was born in 1943 in Colombo, the capital of the British colony of Ceylon, the youngest of four. Of Tamil, Sinhalese and Dutch descent - an inheritance seen in his blue-eyed gaze - he is often taken to be a member of the closed Dutch-descended Burgher community, although his ancestry is perhaps more mixed than that. According to family lore, a Tamil forebear came from south India in 1600 as a doctor, healed the Dutch governor's daughter and was rewarded with a Dutch wife and spelling of his name. When his wife died, he married a Sinhalese woman. "My background is a real salad, so it's difficult to know who I am," Ondaatje laughs.

His earliest years were spent on the Kutapitiya tea estate ("the most beautiful place in the world") in the last era of colonial Ceylon, before the estates were nationalised. Though his memoir depicts the halcyon days of a westernised elite, where "nobody really had to grow up; they remained wild and spoiled", he describes his family as "on the edge of hard times". His brother Christopher, a businessman and explorer, thought his memoir romanticised. Ondaatje says, "It was probably an easier childhood for me than for my brother and sisters, being the youngest."

His mother, Doris Gratiaen, was given to dancing in the style of Isadora Duncan. His father, Mervyn Ondaatje, was in the Ceylon light infantry and supervised a tea plantation before losing jobs through alcoholism ("My father was in tea and alcohol; he dealt in tea and he drank the alcohol"). In one poem Ondaatje wrote of the "terrifying comedy" of his father's life: "My mother divorced him again and again./He would rush into tunnels magnetised/by the white eye of trains".

Ceylon gained independence in 1948. It was a tumultuous time for Michael, too. His parents separated when he was five. Then, when his mother went to England the following year with Christopher and his sister Janet, he was left behind with relatives. "My memory is very vivid, of being quite solitary, though not alone - I was scattered with uncles and aunts." Five years later, aged 11, he followed his mother to London. She was seeing her children through school by working in hotels and living in bedsits. They were, says Ondaatje, "rough times".

At school in Dulwich College, his initial trauma was having to relinquish the sarong. "I had to dress differently. I'd never seen a tie before. It was all very new." Though his school was "in retrospect a haven for young writers" (he was preceded by PG Wodehouse and Raymond Chandler, and followed by his friend Graham Swift), he remembers being more keen on sports. He is amused that a former teacher was quoted in the Times as praising Swift for winning the Booker while expressing surprise that Ondaatje should do the same since he had "always seemed more interested in cricket".

Feeling lost and an "outsider" created a gulf between him and his relatives. "There was a romance about England among the uncles; nostalgia for their years abroad. It was confusing. You don't know if you're responding to England as a weird, tough time because you're a teenager - every teenager is lost and at war with everything." In any case, at 19, he left for Canada, where his brother was living in Montreal. And it was at university in Quebec and Toronto that he first began to write poetry. "In Canada you felt you could do anything. I wouldn't have been a writer if I'd stayed in England. I met young writers and editors" - including at the small press Coachhouse, whose board he still sits on. "It wasn't like England, where you feel, what right do you have to do this because of John Donne and Sir Philip Sidney. England felt repressive in the 50s."

Much of Ondaatje's early poetry was about his new land of Canada. The Collected Works Of Billy The Kid (1970) was something different: mongrelising genres, blurring fact and fiction in an imaginative collage, he dissected a legend of his boyhood. It ends with a photograph of him as a child in Wild West gear. "It grew out of my childhood fantasies, wanting to be a cowboy," he says. "It was an unofficial version - improvised. I just took the facts that he died at 21 and killed 21 people and went underground with it. We've only had the clichés, but I wanted to write something ominous and dangerous and fresh. I'd been a poet, and half way through the book I switched, rearranging scenes, using poetry, prose, white space, song, photography." He even invented a diary. "The book was a fake documentary. My favourite review was by a Texan who said: Why was a Canadian given the right to edit the journals of Billy the Kid?"

"Fiction," Ondaatje says, "is the most conservative of genres - still mostly handcuffed to realism." But he sought new ways of telling. A "child of the movies", he relishes the influence of other arts, whether Henri Rousseau paintings, Diego Rivera murals, Sri Lankan temple sculpture or jazz. Coming Through Slaughter (1976), his first prose work, fictionalised the life of the jazz pioneer Buddy Bolden, the cornetist in turn-of-the-century New Orleans who went mad on a public parade. It shows the background of brothels and knife-fights in which jazz flourished, and its syntax carries the music. "Of all the arts, jazz is the one I envy the most," he says. "It's communal, free, you can improvise. If I could be Fats Waller, I wouldn't be writing."

Ondaatje is a migrant of the imagination, crossing borders all the time, creatively and geographically, from prose to poetry to film. The novel moves with the suspense of a mystery, yet with breathtaking grace. Its sleuth is Anil Tissera, a forensic anthropologist who left Sri Lanka for London at 18 and has returned from the US 15 years later, on behalf of a human rights body, to identify a skeleton as a victim of government "counter-terror". Like her creator, she speaks vestiges of Sinhala (Ondaatje also grew up speaking some Tamil); he insists that Anil is not autobiographical.

"I remember leaving Sri Lanka and being devastated by leaving her," he says sadly. "When I went back she'd died."

Though the novel contains love and passion: "Subliminally or unconsciously, everything in the book became about one thing: separations. It's a very celibate book - everything's in the past or repressed."

While Running In The Family noted the condescension of European travellers to Sri Lanka, such as Edward Lear and DH Lawrence, the dangers of political tourism are spelled out in Anil's Ghost. As one character snorts: "American movies, English books - remember how they all end? The American or the Englishman gets on a plane and leaves. That's it. The camera leaves with him . . . It's probably the history of the last 200 years of western political writing. Go home. Write a book. Hit the circuit."

So how does any writer from abroad avoid that approach? "I don't know," Ondaatje says. "I'm as guilty as anyone else. I didn't want to go in and make assured judgments - 'clean up your act'. That would be incendiary and facile." The solution was partly to be open on his visits. "I was learning a lot just by being passive in the way I listened. It's more rewarding than trying to go out and grab the truth, as we do in the west, as though we know how to solve this problem, how to fix it. It's more complex than that."

Though he describes himself as a Canadian writer, Ondaatje is clear: "I don't think I'm a north American solely; Sri Lanka is a place I love and feel very much part of." He put his Booker winnings into the creation of the Gratiaen prize (named after his mother) for Sri Lankan writers based on the island; recent winners include a "lost classic" by Tissa Abeysekara. His own uprooting has been matched by a restless creativity. "Moving, you learn twice as much; it doubles you in some way, like living three or four lives," he says. "There's a parallel between the writer and the migrant: in a way, writers are immigrants if you're writing about a new place. It's exciting and terrifying to start anew in a new land, with a new language and new rules."

While Running In The Family noted the condescension of European travellers to Sri Lanka, such as Edward Lear and DH Lawrence, the dangers of political tourism are spelled out in Anil's Ghost. As one character snorts: "American movies, English books - remember how they all end? The American or the Englishman gets on a plane and leaves. That's it. The camera leaves with him . . . It's probably the history of the last 200 years of western political writing. Go home. Write a book. Hit the circuit." So how does any writer from abroad avoid that approach? "I don't know," Ondaatje says. "I'm as guilty as anyone else. I didn't want to go in and make assured judgments - 'clean up your act'. That would be incendiary and facile." The solution was partly to be open on his visits. "I was learning a lot just by being passive in the way I listened. It's more rewarding than trying to go out and grab the truth, as we do in the west, as though we know how to solve this problem, how to fix it. It's more complex than that." Though he describes himself as a Canadian writer, Ondaatje is clear: "I don't think I'm a north American solely; Sri Lanka is a place I love and feel very much part of." He put his Booker winnings into the creation of the Gratiaen prize (named after his mother) for Sri Lankan writers based on the island; recent winners include a "lost classic" by Tissa Abeysekara. His own uprooting has been matched by a restless creativity. "Moving, you learn twice as much; it doubles you in some way, like living three or four lives," he says. "There's a parallel between the writer and the migrant: in a way, writers are immigrants if you're writing about a new place. It's exciting and terrifying to start anew in a new land, with a new language and new rules."  Anil's Ghost is published by Bloomsbury on May 8, at £16.99. fields.headline: Diana lives, in a shabby sports jacket
fields.standfirst:
Voters go weak at the knees when they meet Ken Livingstone, an old-style politician whose campaign is anything but

The London mayor: special report
Frank Dobson
Ken Livingstone
Mayor for London
fields.trailText: There are tried and tested ways of fighting British elections, honed by decades of experience and superstition. You try to canvass every household. You meet as many people as possible. You put yourself about, whenever and wherever. You tickle the media's fancy with daily stunts - and if a radio station with an audience reach of three asks you to jump through a wheel of fire at 4am, you do it. You leave questions of governance until after the election. And you permit nothing whatever to be done or said that might frighten a single soul.

There are tried and tested ways of fighting British elections, honed by decades of experience and superstition. You try to canvass every household. You meet as many people as possible. You put yourself about, whenever and wherever. You tickle the media's fancy with daily stunts - and if a radio station with an audience reach of three asks you to jump through a wheel of fire at 4am, you do it. You leave questions of governance until after the election. And you permit nothing whatever to be done or said that might frighten a single soul.

For today, we will leave aside the question of whether the very nice young people in lilac fleeces on the Ken4London bus are enchanting or frightening. All I know is that one of them, a girl with raven hair and a black beret, was guarding the exit from one of the hustings on Wednesday and I thought we had all been kidnapped by a 1970s underground movement.

Yesterday the bus had gone south-east, to Pratts Bottom, and Ken Livingstone hadn't. He spent the morning in his office, emerged for two private business meetings and a semi-public hustings, then went back again. He met hardly anyone else until evening.

Headquarters

He did, though, go to Romney House, a fairly dismal ex-government building in a Whitehall sidestreet. This is London's new headquarters, currently being renovated - a workman was still staining the rather cheapo new door into the mayor's office yesterday. Mr Livingstone was not impertinent enough to go in there. But he did meet London's putative civil service - the senior officials of Glatt: the Greater London authority transitional team, which will be taken over by the new mayor on an interim basis pending the full takeover on July 3.

This was rather odd. Such a meeting never happens at a general election. Some people have been confused by the new facilities for voting a week in advance - perhaps Mr Livingstone was confused too, and thought he had won already?

No. Both the candidates and the civil servants were most anxious to stress that he was doing nothing that was not available to all the mayoral contenders. Many of the 11 on the ballot paper have been there, including some whose chances of returning as mayor are zero.

But this was the fourth Livingstone visit; he had lengthy discussions; he is due back again early next week; and he walked through the corridors with the air of a purchaser who has already exchanged contracts.

Officials have also learned to be very respectful to the young man with an earring, leather jacket and blue denims who walked alongside him. He is Simon Fletcher, the mayor's putative chief of staff.

"Tony Blair didn't do this before he was elected, did he?" I asked.

"Tony Blair walked into a 400-year-old functioning bureaucracy," Mr Livingstone replied. "Usually there's a year to set up a new authority. We've got 10 weeks, and the job adverts have to go in the papers on Monday week.

"The agenda for the mayor in the first two weeks is so intense that you're not going to be able to learn on the job. So many decisions have been put off. For instance, the annual increase in taxi fares hasn't been agreed yet. They've held it back so the mayor can be unpopular."

But shouldn't he be out in Pratts Bottom, handing out leaflets? Some Livingstonians think that idea is primitive nonsense, left over from the old politics. "The others are still trying to fight this by ringing up people on the register of electors," one aide insisted. "They're going round in silly dark suits doing photo-ops. Bloody mad. That's all gone now."

Extraordinary

The man himself, though, is steeped in the old politics. "Where was Frank? Hornchurch station? If I had a party machine, I'd be out there, doing what I've always done. But I don't have the people on the ground. There are 60,000 Labour members in London. That's a tremendous resource. That's why I'd rather be the Labour candidate."

It is not that easy to spot Ken Livingstone in the street at this stage of the campaign. But when people do, they react in the most extraordinary fashion. They grin spontaneously, almost going weak at the knees. From his increasingly rare trips on the campaign bus, there are reports of passers-by breaking into jigs. "They go away," said a member of the priesthood, "with a beautiful warm feeling inside." It is as if Diana lives, reincarnated in a shabby check sports jacket. If he ever did get to Hornchurch or Pratts Bottom, he could probably heal the sick simply by touch. He chose instead, before Romney House, to visit the London Ambulance Service. He arrived by tube, unaccompanied, carrying a strange-looking blue umbrella - 35 minutes late. This is not a man ideally suited to making London more punctual.

Ambulances are not even going to be the mayor's responsibility. But he told the service chiefs that he liked what happened in Seattle and wanted to match it. I assumed he meant smashing up the world trade talks. It turned out he was talking about cardiac arrest: anyone whose heart stops in London has a 1.5% chance of being revived. In Seattle every schoolchild is trained in resuscitation techniques and there is suitable equipment all over town. Chances of survival: 19.5%.

The ambulance people were enthused by his enthusiasm. He also talked about his Healthy London campaign. "Basically I stole the idea off Frank. There's no point in not stealing ideas. I stole Jeffrey Archer's idea about high-speed buses. He won't be needing it now."

Then he went down into the control room and posed for a picture with the headphones on. It's a terrifying thought, Ken as ambulance control man: "Be with you in 45 minutes, an hour, probably, could be two..." Candidates are supposed to do daft things for photographers, but the only one present this time was from the in-house magazine.

So he goes on serenely, surreally, disarmingly, semi-detached now from the other pretenders, mind already three-quarters focused on the business ahead. But still there is that nagging hint of politician's doubt.

"You're in, Ken, don't worry," said one passing enthusiast.

"I do worry. All the time."

"Nah, you're all right. I'll betcha."

"Make sure you vote."

"Well..."

"You see," mused Mr Livingstone afterwards, "he'll bet me but he probably won't vote." New politics be blowed: he shares the conventional political wisdom that absence of organisation will cost him 10 percentage points next Thursday. None the less, he is mayor-apparent and mayor-presumptive. The people of London have not quite spoken, but they are clearing their throats. Lord alone knows what they think they are going to get, but I hope he still realises he is not Princess Diana.

fields.headline: Guardian cleared of sex bias
fields.trailText: The Guardian was yesterday cleared of an allegation of sexual discrimination by an employment tribunal.
fields.body:
The Guardian was yesterday cleared of an allegation of sexual discrimination by an employment tribunal.

Anne Reckless, 41, who began work as a casual sub-editor at the newspaper in 1997, claimed that she had been discriminated against when she was not offered a fixed-term contract last year.

Her claim was rejected by the tribunal at Stratford, east London, although it upheld two out of three allegations of victimisation which related to a later period of reorganisation at the newspaper. This reorganisation led to a reduction in the number of casual staff employed by the Guardian.

Ms Reckless claimed that she was not offered casual shifts during this period because she had made the discrimination claim. This was rejected by the tribunal.

However, it upheld her allegation that she should have been given severance pay and that she was refused a reference due to her allegation. A settlement of £4,250 was agreed.

A spokesperson for the Guardian said last night: "We are delighted that the substantive allegation of sexual discrimination was thrown out and that the claim brought by Ms Reckless that she was offered an insufficient number of shifts was also rejected.

"The settlement of £4,250 in respect of her other claim is modest by any standard. The Guardian began a wide ranging review of procedures before the case was brought with a view to improving practices wherever necessary, and that review continues.

"Traditionally, within Fleet Street, there is an imbalance of male to female staff but, like many other newspapers, we are struggling to correct this. The Guardian has a low turnover of staff. People retain a fierce loyalty to the paper and tend to stay longer as a result, which means the challenge to redress the gender imbalance is a greater challenge for us."

webTitle: RUC badge may escape reform axe

fields.headline: RUC badge may escape reform axe
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A bitter row was brewing last night after it was revealed that legislation to reform the Royal Ulster Constabulary was back-pedalling on the recommendation to scrap the force badge.
fields.body:
A bitter row was brewing last night after it was revealed that legislation to reform the Royal Ulster Constabulary was back-pedalling on the recommendation to scrap the force badge.

Although leaks of the 50-page bill confirmed the government's intention to scrap the name of the 78-year-old outfit, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the chief constable, is to be consulted about the replacement of the crown and shamrock emblem. It may signal a reprieve for the symbol, which adorns the gravestones of many of the 302 officers murdered in the Troubles.

Ulster Unionists, who say they will refuse to return to government with Sinn Fein unless the RUC name is retained, have won a concession on the controversial suggestion of district policing boards raising money through the rates for extra police services.

That was seen as giving rise to the potential of paramilitary involvement in policing, but the boards are now to have a merely consultative role. They will have no immediate fundraising powers.

But Ulster Unionists felt the concessions failed to offer sufficient cover to re-enter the power-sharing executive with republicans. They want the RUC's name retained for at least two years.

Nationalists were unhappy at the move on the badge. They felt it represented slippage away from the minimum they would accept in the peace negotiations.

fields.headline: Washington orders Microsoft break-up
fields.standfirst:
Washington orders Microsoft break-up

E-finance: special report
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: The US government called for Microsoft to be broken up yesterday in a hard-hitting proposal designed to stop the company abusing its stranglehold on the world's computer market.
fields.body:
The US government called for Microsoft to be broken up yesterday in a hard-hitting proposal designed to stop the company abusing its stranglehold on the world's computer market.

Microsoft will be broken into two separate companies - one to develop the Windows operating system and the other to run all other applications such as Office - under proposals filed to the US district court by the justice department and various states last night.

Bill Gates, whose stake in the company he founded 25 years ago had made him until recently the world's richest man by a wide margin, would be forced to choose which company to invest in under the proposals, while other shareholders are likely to receive a share in both. The company accused the government of "indefensible, radical and extreme" proposals yesterday. Mr Gates said: "Microsoft would be greatly damaged by any kind of split."

The government's proposals, filed after the New York stock market closed last night, will be considered by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson alongside those of the company before he delivers his own verdict on an appropriate remedy later this year.

Earlier this month, he ruled that the Seattle-based company had broken the law with its anti-competitive behaviour. Any break-up plan, even if agreed by the judge, is likely to be some years off because of the company's plans to appeal. However, yesterday's filing also included several tough restrictions on the company's behaviour as well as a 10-year bar on any future merger of the two separate groups. The restrictions include making Microsoft offer uniform pricing for the leading computer manufacturers as well as barring any attempt to penalise competitors who gave evidence during the trial.

Joel Klein, assistant attorney general, said the restrictions "can and should go into effect immediately" and should last until a break-up of the company is complete. Mr Klein, who has led the government's efforts as head of the anti-trust division at the justice department, said a break-up was the best way to improve competition in the software industry.

"Under our proposals, neither the heavy hand of ongoing government regulation nor the self-interest of an entrenched monopolist will decide what is in the best interests of consumers. Consumers will be able to decide for themselves in a fair and competitive marketplace, which is the over-riding purpose of America's anti-trust laws."

Legal experts and analysts said the plan, if backed by the judge, would be as significant as the break-up of Standard Oil in 1911 or that of AT&T in 1984.

Mr Klein used the example of the break-up of AT&T for improving competition in the telecommunications industry in the US. Bill Kovacic, a law professor at George Washington university, said: "This case will define the rules by which dominant firms must play."

Microsoft has already been badly damaged by the case. The company's stock market value has fallen by more than 40% since the beginning of the year when it was the world's most highly valued group. Mr Gates has seen his net worth shrink from more than $100bn to about $60bn.

Janet Reno, the US attorney general, said: "This is the right remedy at the right time to stimulate competition, promote innovation and give consumers more choice." Until this week, most analysts had expected the government to propose so-called conduct remedies based on Microsoft changing its behaviour rather than a structural remedy.

Microsoft yesterday blamed the government's extreme stance for the breakdown of settlement talks before the judge announced his verdict earlier this month.

webTitle: European trio left at the altar in London-Frankfurt wedding

fields.headline: European trio left at the altar in London-Frankfurt wedding
fields.trailText: The Frankfurt bourse and London's stock exchange have decided to merge as equal partners into a London-based exchange barring any last-minute hurdles, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The Frankfurt bourse and London's stock exchange have decided to merge as equal partners into a London-based exchange barring any last-minute hurdles, it emerged last night.

Deutsche Börse sources announced the finalisation of the deal after a meeting of the Ger man exchange's management and supervisory boards to discuss the merger negotiations.

"The plan is supported by the majority of the board members," one Börse insider said.

The exchanges will seek formal approval for the merger deal next week. A stock exchange spokesman in London declined to comment, saying it had nothing to add to a previ ous statement and planned no announcement today.

A London-Frankfurt merger, for which preliminary talks began earlier this month, would create Europe's biggest bourse, eclipsing newly created rival Euronext, which groups together the Amsterdam, Paris and Brussels stock markets.

The merged stock exchange will be based in London and will later float its shares, Börse sources said.

Blue chip stocks would be transferred to London, with growth stocks and futures situated in Frankfurt.

"The [German-listed] stocks which are traded today in euros will be traded in euros after the merger, and the same will be the case for [London-listed] shares traded in pounds.

"The long-term goal seems to be to trade all shares in euros," the Börse insider said.

It was not clear yet if the US Nasdaq market would be involved in the merger, but co-operation discussions are still going on.

The merger of Europe's two largest exchanges would be the latest consolidation among the region's stock exchanges as electronic upstarts wait in the wings ready to claim a stake of huge and growing pan-European share trading volumes.

The Frankfurt exchange's clearing system, Clearstream, will not be included in the deal and will remain responsible for growth stocks and futures based in Frankfurt. The stock exchange's Crest will handle shares traded in London.

The future of Microsoft: special report

fields.trailText: The US government yesterday called for Microsoft, the world's largest software company, to be broken up in a proposal likely to have enormous consequences for the future of the industry.
fields.body:
The US government yesterday called for Microsoft, the world's largest software company, to be broken up in a proposal likely to have enormous consequences for the future of the industry.

The department of justice and most of the 19 US states that brought the landmark legal case against the company agreed that splitting Microsoft into two parts was the only way to prevent further abuses of its monopoly position. One part of the new company would be based on the Windows operating system, the other would incorporate everything else.

Legal experts and analysts said the plan, if backed by a US judge, would be as significant as the break-up of Standard Oil in 1911 or that of AT&T, the US telephone monopoly, in 1984.

Bill Kovacic, a law professor at George Washington university, said: "This case will define the rules by which dominant firms must play."

Microsoft has been damaged by the case, even though an actual break-up might never happen. The company's stock market value has almost halved this year and Bill Gates, the company's founder, has seen his net worth shrink from over $100bn to about $60bn.

Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who has ruled that Microsoft had broken the law, is to hear its case before announcing his decision later this year.

webTitle: Couple jailed for cash theft from Stone's stud farm

fields.headline: Couple jailed for cash theft from Stone's stud farm
fields.trailText: The manager and the book-keeper of a stud farm owned by Rolling Stones drummer Charlie Watts and his wife were yesterday jailed for stealing thousands of pounds from the business.
fields.body:
The manager and the book-keeper of a stud farm owned by Rolling Stones drummer Charlie Watts and his wife were yesterday jailed for stealing thousands of pounds from the business.

Paul Atkinson, 49, who was sacked by Shirley Watts last year as the £40,000 a year manager of the Halsdon Arabians stud at Dolton, Devon, was jailed for three months at Exeter crown court. Atkinson, from Riddlecombe, Devon, was found guilty by a 10-2 majority on three charges of theft involving £6,404, relating to a stay at a four star hotel and work on land he owned.

He was acquitted of three charges involving a total of £3,512, relating to the purchase of a cooker, showers and a trailer for personal use.

His wife, Joan, 52, the stud's book-keeper, was jailed for a year. She admitted 10 charges of theft and two of false accounting, and asked for 13 similar offences to be taken into consideration.

Recorder Stephen Parish told her that she was in a position of trust as the book-keeper and over two years stole more than £24,000.

The court was told the offences included payments from the stud accounts to their joint bank account, a private trip to France, champagne and cognac. Joan Atkinson was "motivated by greed not need", said the recorder, adding that the effect of the offences on the victims was not as great as on others less fortunate.

Roy Amlot QC, for Paul Atkinson, said he was going to lose the position he valued most in the world - the authority he enjoyed in the equine world.

Mr Amlot said Mrs Watts lived in the very best style when she went abroad on stud business. It was easy to see how that sort of existence was tempting.

Sarah Munro, for Joan Atkinson, said she was bitterly sorry, had tried to take her own life since the offences came to light, and was on medication for depression. Earlier, Andrew Oldland, prosecuting, said she told police she was lonely because Mrs Watts did not want her going to the stud and her husband was often away.

In 1998 Mrs Watts became concerned at the rising costs of the stud and Paul Atkinson's "cavalier" attitude to finance, he said.

The couple were dismissed in February last year.

webTitle: Tonsils research finds no evidence of CJD epidemic

fields.headline: Tonsils research finds no evidence of CJD epidemic
fields.standfirst:
The CJD Surveillance Unit
The BSE Inquiry
Dept of Health Survey Findings
What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Tests on more than 3,000 tonsils and appendixes stored after routine operations have left scientists no wiser as to the number of Britons who are infected with new variant CJD, the human form of mad cow disease.
fields.body:
Tests on more than 3,000 tonsils and appendixes stored after routine operations have left scientists no wiser as to the number of Britons who are infected with new variant CJD, the human form of mad cow disease.

The government's chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, admitted yesterday that although there was no trace of the prion protein - which some think is the infective agent - in any of the preserved tissue examined at hospitals in Edinburgh and Plymouth, no news was not necessarily good news.

"This doesn't take us any further forward on the size of the epidemic," he said in a briefing yesterday. "We have still to rely on the very wide estimates scientists have made."

These have ranged between a few hundred and several hundred thousand infections. So far, 53 people are confirmed to have died from the disease, which has no cure; two are suspected to have died from it but await postmortem examinations; and 12 are ill.

Yesterday's announcement of a negative result in the early stages of the retrospective population study was partly an attempt to dampen speculation about a CJD epidemic. The scientists will eventually examine 18,000 samples removed in routine operations from the late 1980s.

The exercise is something of a stab in the dark. The prion protein was found in late 1998 in the appendix of a man who had developed vCJD. In February last year, Professor John Collinge of St Mary's hospital, Paddington, found the abnormal protein in the tonsils of patients who had died of vCJD.

But scientists have no idea at what stage in the incubation of the disease the abnormal prion protein might show up in lymphatic tissue such as tonsils and appendixes.

Prof Donaldson said: "We do not even know whether any individuals who were found positive would necessarily go on to develop the disease. These research findings are another contribution to increasing our understanding of this complex and mysterious disease."

Les Borysiewicz, professor of medicine at the University of Wales college of medicine and chair of the scientific committee that is reviewing the tissue analysis, pointed out that the sample is relatively small, and of 4,166 specimens only 3,170 were appropriate for analysis.

fields.headline: Olympic shooter kills two bandits
fields.trailText: In an increasingly violent country, Colombia's Olympic sharpshooter Bernado Tobar had few hesitations when confronted by two armed assailants. He whipped out his target pistol and killed them both.
fields.body:
In an increasingly violent country, Colombia's Olympic sharpshooter Bernado Tobar had few hesitations when confronted by two armed assailants. He whipped out his target pistol and killed them both.

Mr Tobar, 49, who is in training for this summer's games in Sydney, was returning home from the range late on Thursday night with his wife and two children when the two men blocked the road near Jamundi, in the south-west of the country.

After they pointed their guns at his family and fired at his son, Tobar grabbed his .22-calibre target pistol and shot both men, he told Columbian police. Officers later confirmed the dead men's weapons had been fired.

"We don't know if it was an abduction or if they were going to steal the car," Mr Tobar told a radio station. "We had to defend ourselves and unfortunately it fell to me."

Mr Tobar, who has been released pending an investigation, has been a consistent top-10 finisher in Olympic rapid-fire pistol shooting since 1984.

The country's national sports committee has warned that the Copa America football championships, due to be held in Colombia next year, are under threat because of the violence.

 At least 26 inmates died in fierce fighting between rival gangs in Modelo prison, Colombia, yesterday following clashes between paramilitaries and ordinary criminals.

webTitle: Livingstone will apply to rejoin Labour after mayoral election

fields.headline: Livingstone will apply to rejoin Labour after mayoral election
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone again put the Labour hierarchy on the back foot yesterday when he revealed that he plans to apply to rejoin the party after next week's London mayoral contest, saying he hopes to be "back in the fold and the party reunited in the run-up to the general election".
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone again put the Labour hierarchy on the back foot yesterday when he revealed that he plans to apply to rejoin the party after next week's London mayoral contest, saying he hopes to be "back in the fold and the party reunited in the run-up to the general election".

He told BBC News Online: "Clearly, Tony Blair will want to wait and see for a couple of months how I'm performing, but then, provided I haven't scared the chickens, they will probably consider what to do about conference time."

A Labour spokesman dismissed the suggestion, insisting there was no question of anyone who had stood against an official party candidate being readmitted for at least five years. "Ken Livingstone knew the rules when he chose to leave the Labour party."

But the independent frontrunner's move to emphasise his Labour credentials in the countdown to next week's poll highlighted the problems Mr Blair will face if, as expected, Frank Dobson is defeated and Mr Livingstone becomes London's first elected mayor next Friday morning.

The prime minister has already declared that he will work with whoever is elected - even if allowing the former Greater London council leader back in the party may prove more difficult to swallow - and an early meeting between the two is expected.

But there was no let-up in the Labour onslaught on Mr Livingstone yesterday as Gordon Brown denounced him for being "anti-jobs and anti-business", while the Brent East MP in turn demanded that the chancellor use his £22bn mobile phone windfall to fund the modernisation of the tube.

Mr Livingstone, who is anxious to encourage Labour figures to back a second preference vote for him, also faced accusations yesterday from the Tories' London spokesman, Bernard Jenkin, that those behind the anti-capitalist demonstrations planned for Monday were "Livingstone's louts".

But Mr Livingstone called on his supporters not to join the protests because of the risk of violence and urged them to join trade union-organised events instead.

Mr Dobson, meanwhile, is trying to boost his flagging campaign by becoming the first British politician to use online advertising.

With adverts on sites such as thisislondon.com (the Evening Standard's website) and Capital Radio's capitalfm.com, Labour's candidate follows in the footsteps of the US presidential candidates John McCain and George W Bush, who used targeted political ads to great effect in the primaries.

Mr Dobson has hired the San Francisco internet consultants Aristotle.com, who worked for both Republican candidates, to manage this phase of his online strategy. Aristotle created banner ads that successfully targeted Virginians to "put McCain on the ballot" by clicking and registering.

Mr Dobson's ads are far simpler: carrying only the familiar Frank logo, his "Beware the cost of Livingstone" slogan, and allowing users to click through to his website. An Aristotle spokesman said that by UK standards "Frank is cutting edge".

fields.headline: Zimbabwe agrees to election monitors
fields.standfirst: Farmers and squatters agree deal ending violence but allowing veterans to stay on land already occupied Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean government gave ground yesterday by agreeing to allow a Commonwealth team to monitor the elections promised by the president, Robert Mugabe.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill and  Gary Younge in Harare
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean government gave ground yesterday by agreeing to allow a Commonwealth team to monitor the elections promised by the president, Robert Mugabe.

A Commonwealth team is to travel to Zimbabwe as early as next week on a reconnaissance mission aimed at establishing the number of monitors that would be needed.

In another move that appeared to ease the crisis, Zimbabwe's white farmers and those leading the land occupations yesterday clinched a deal which they claimed would end the violence on occupied farms but allow squatters to stay on land that has already been seized.

The latest developments are typical of the bewildering speed at which Mr Mugabe engages in diplomatic manouevring: a hard uncompromising approach one day, often followed by a softer line the next.

The Foreign Office urged caution on the deal struck between the white farmers and those leading the land invasion: "Let's wait and see what happens on the ground." The British government's fear is that there was a large element of intimidation in the deal, with a hidden threat that the white farmers should not provide any support to the opposition Movement for Democratic Change.

The Foreign Office was more enthusiastic about Harare's decision to accept Commonwealth monitors. Britain had been pressing for two months for Mr Mugabe to accept European Union monitors but a Foreign Office spokesman said it would be satisfied with a Commonwealth team.

Mr Mugabe has still to set an election date. He promised last month it would be held in May but that timetable now looks unlikely. Under the constitution, it has to be held by August.

In African elections last year, the Commonwealth provided 23 monitors for Nigeria and 10 for both Mozambique and South Africa.

Harare's concession came less than 24 hours after talks between the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and a Zimbabwean delegation, including the foreign minister, Stan Mudenge, collapsed in failure.

Mr Mudenge met the new Commonwealth secretary general, Don McKinnon, in London yesterday afternoon. At an impromptu press conference outside the Commonwealth secretariat after the hour-long meeting, Mr Mudenge was asked how many monitors Zimbabwe was prepared to accept. "The more the merrier," Mr Mudenge said.

Mr McKinnon expressed optimism that the situation might be easing: "Seeing will obviously be believing. Certainly, I am getting the kind of messages we want to hear."

In Zimbabwe, representatives of both the farmers and the "war veterans" hailed their agreement as a major breakthrough although it was condemned by the leader of the main opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, Morgan Tsvangirai.

The unspoken understanding underpinning the deal is that the farmers would end their support for the MDC and not allow any MDC activity on their land.

The war veterans leader, Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi, blamed the violence on a "criminal element" among the veterans and insisted that henceforth those who committed violent acts would be dealt with severely. "All violence must end," he said. "However, veterans will stay on the farms but they will not interfere with any farming activities."

This is the second public announcement of an agreement between squatters and farmers in just over a week. Given the volatility in the rural areas, the most recent spate of political violence by supporters of Zanu-PF against members of MDC and the invocation of special police powers to ban political gatherings, the agreement was greeted with cautious optimism in Harare.

Insiders in the farmers' union said they believed the war veterans were sincere this time. But the private agreement to stop the MDC from campaigning on white land brought a sharp rebuke from Mr Tsvangirai. "The farmers and the farming leaders are wrong to be negotiating with outlaws," he said.
