webTitle: Tears and cheers as workers vow to fight on

fields.headline: Tears and cheers as workers vow to fight on
fields.standfirst:
Rover in crisis: special report
BMW Group
Alchemy Partners
Rover Cars
fields.trailText: Another bombshell, more uncertainty, more worry. But the men (and women and children) outside Q gate at Longbridge on the south-west edge of Birmingham yesterday were laughing, cheering, crying and shouting.
fields.body:
Another bombshell, more uncertainty, more worry. But the men (and women and children) outside Q gate at Longbridge on the south-west edge of Birmingham yesterday were laughing, cheering, crying and shouting.

Alchemy had been stuffed and that was judged good news. It was like a carnival: the Rover flags flew bravely and cars (mostly Rovers) roared by with horns braying.

"We won't go away! We won't go away!" sang an impromptu male voice choir of about 50 relieved voices. "Why do you think I'm beaming all over my face?" asked Anon, a Rover man for five years. "Of course we feel optimistic.""BMW now has two options: either close the place down and pay everyone off, or do the honourable thing and give the property to John Towers [who heads the Phoenix consortium wanting to buy Rover] and so get public opinion off their backs."

David Campbell, who has worked at the plant for 10 years, said: "This is all because BMW didn't know what to do with Rover. They are all right at building nice big cars and making lots of money. But when it comes to good quality, run-of-the-mill cars they haven't got a clue."

"When BMW took over, all they wanted to do was to get rid of a competitor," added Anon, twitching the lead of his dog Hannah. "I used to call her a German shepherd. Now I call her an alsatian." He may well rename her Rover.

A few yards away stood Nicola Whittaker, with her husband Steven, a Rover man, and children Lee and Amy. "We said when BMW came in that this was going to happen," said Mrs Whittaker.

"The way this has been done has been bloody awful, abominable."

"Now we've had a bit of a breakthrough," said her husband. You can say that again, said the mates around him.

The shop stewards were there too, including Alan Bradshaw from MSF. "The fear has gone now," he said. "Alchemy were being paid to dissolve most of this site and most of the workforce with it. We believe we can carry on producing mass-production quality cars. And we have the British public behind us."

His colleague Richard Howell was in Munich on Thursday as a member of a small delegation of officials who told BMW bosses to trust Phoenix. "I'm pleased to hear that Alchemy have pulled out. But I'm keeping my feet on the ground. We have a long way to go because we need a couple of new models."

Carl Chin, social historian and passionate Brummie, was a member of the delegation. It was he who stirred 80,000 local citizens to march in support of the Rover workers.

Yesterday he was in tears as he embraced some of the men whose jobs he wants to save.

"We are very happy," he said. "But we are not foolish - although we are enjoying this moment.

Now we are saying to BMW: 'Do not contemplate closure because we will continue to fight.' This is a very emotional time because the livelihoods of men and women are at stake. My city and my region would be devastated if Longbridge closed."

On a nearby mound stood John Bull, with mutton chops, union flag waistcoat and cut -out bulldog. He was impersonated by Ray Egan, a retired police officer, who had added his patriotic might to the Rover campaign.

"It's cost me a few quid," he said. "But today every penny I have spent has been worth it. And now I'd better go home and get the washing off the line before it rains."

He climbed into his maroon Rover Metro, honked his horn and chugged up the road.

Now we are saying to BMW: 'Do not contemplate closure because we will continue to fight.' This is a very emotional time because the livelihoods of men and women are at stake. My city and my region would be devastated if Longbridge closed." On a nearby mound stood John Bull, with mutton chops, union flag waistcoat and cut -out bulldog. He was impersonated by Ray Egan, a retired police officer, who had added his patriotic might to the Rover campaign. "It's cost me a few quid," he said. "But today every penny I have spent has been worth it. And now I'd better go home and get the washing off the line before it rains." He climbed into his maroon Rover Metro, honked his horn and chugged up the road.

webTitle: Tests leave scientists in dark over CJD epidemic

fields.headline: Tests leave scientists in dark over CJD epidemic
fields.standfirst:
The CJD Surveillance Unit
The BSE Inquiry
Dept of Health Survey Findings
What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Tests on more than 3,000 tonsils and appendixes stored after routine operations have left scientists no wiser as to the number of Britons who are infected with new variant CJD, the human form of mad cow disease.
fields.body:
Tests on more than 3,000 tonsils and appendixes stored after routine operations have left scientists no wiser as to the number of Britons who are infected with new variant CJD, the human form of mad cow disease.

The government's chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, admitted yesterday that although there was no trace of the prion protein - which some think is the infective agent - in any of the preserved tissue examined at hospitals in Edinburgh and Plymouth, no news was not necessarily good news.

"This doesn't take us any further forward on the size of the epidemic," he said in a briefing yesterday. "We have still to rely on the very wide estimates scientists have made."

These have ranged between a few hundred and several hundred thousand infections. So far, 53 people are confirmed to have died from the disease, which has no cure; two are suspected to have died of it but await postmortem examinations; and 12 are ill.

Yesterday's announcement of a negative result in the early stages of the retrospective population study was partly a bid to dampen speculation about a CJD epidemic. The scientists will eventually examine 18,000 samples removed in routine operations from the late 1980s.

The exercise is something of a stab in the dark. The prion protein was found in late 1998 in the appendix of a man who had developed vCJD. In February last year, Professor John Collinge of St Mary's hospital, Paddington, found the abnormal protein in the tonsils of patients who had died of vCJD.

But scientists have no idea at what stage in the incubation of the disease the abnormal prion protein might show up in lymphatic tissue such as tonsils and appendixes.

Prof Donaldson said: "We do not know at what point in the incubation period tissues such as tonsils or appendices would turn positive, how long the incubation period would be, or even whether any individuals who were found positive would necessarily go on to develop the disease.

"These research findings are another contribution to increasing our understanding of this complex and mysterious disease."

Les Borysiewicz, professor of medicine at the University of Wales college of medicine and chair of the scientific committee that is reviewing the tissue analysis, pointed out that the sample is relatively small, and of 4,166 specimens only 3,170 were appropriate for analysis. Because the samples are preserved, only limited tests can be carried out on them. He added that new tests were being developed.

More enlightenment may flow from the prospective study that Prof Collinge is now carrying out. He is looking for the prion protein in samples of fresh tissue, donated immediately after an operation, on which a wider range of tests can be done. The government meanwhile is exploring ways of safeguarding the population from a risk whose size they can only guess at.

Prof Donaldson said yesterday that they were investigating the benefits of disposable surgical instruments to avoid any possibility that infection could be passed on from a patient in the operating theatre incubating vCJD.

fields.headline: Hand-picked to halt Ken
fields.standfirst:
Blair's chosen candidates for the Greater London assembly have but one purpose

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: On Thursday, I shall enter a polling station in a positive mood, for I shall have an opportunity to vote against the awfulness of Blairism. I refer not to the election of the London mayor but to that of the Greater London assembly, a tiny body which will be elected under a system nobody understands.
fields.body:
On Thursday, I shall enter a polling station in a positive mood, for I shall have an opportunity to vote against the awfulness of Blairism. I refer not to the election of the London mayor but to that of the Greater London assembly, a tiny body which will be elected under a system nobody understands. There will be 25 members, hardly an assembly at all, you might think; but under the Criminal Justice Act, I think a gathering of more than four constitutes an illegal demonstration. In any event, some members of this assembly will be elected by constituencies and some from a proportional top-up list.

The first candidate on the list for the London Socialist Alliance is Guardian columnist Paul Foot, whose election would be a delight. Compare his record of crusading for truth and justice with the career of the first candidate on Labour's list, Trevor Phillips, who has made telly programmes starring Richard Littlejohn. Trevor has the distinction of being hand-picked by Tony Blair, like all the candidates on the list, but unlike Labour's constituency candidates who were merely vetted and screened in order to guarantee prostrate obeisance. In common with all Labour's candidates, Trevor's history suggests that he will do what he is told, namely constrain Ken Livingstone.

So anyone who has hopes for Livingstone's mayoralty must hope that Labour does badly in the assembly elections and the LSA does well. Now, some will say with unfailingly flawed logic, "So you want the Tories back, do you?" which obviously I don't. However, since the assembly will have no power to put people in camps or put guns in the hands of every trigger-happy nutcase who thinks a video is worth more than a human life, there won't be a great deal to distinguish the Tories from Labour in the GLA.

Moreover, the time is over when socialists could be scared into loyally supporting Labour with the threat of what the Tories might do. The Tories are only going so mental because they can't bear the idea that Labour could move to the right of them. Labour says vouchers and dispersal, Tories say detention camps. I fail to see how anyone who saw Jack Straw, playing at being an immigration officer searching in the backs of lorries for a photo opportunity, could vote Labour next week without their breakfast rebelling.

None of the mayoral candidates has departed in a serious way from the government's horrible asylum agenda. Even Livingstone has joined in with the paranoid nonsense about beggars. All the main candidates refer to the positive contributions made by immigrants who arrived in the past, with the implication that that's quite enough of that. By contrast, all the LSA candidates have used their platforms to say that refugees are welcome here, and they have met with loud applause at dozens of meetings all over London

A Labour vote is a vote for racist asylum policy. It is also a vote for the Private Finance Initiative, the outrageous corporate welfare scam that Dobson saw as a boon for the health service. In the constituency of Barnet and Camden, voters can choose between the LSA's Candy Udwin and Labour's Helen Gordon. Both work at University College Hospital where Udwin campaigns vigorously against the privatisation plans that imperil 122 beds and hundreds of jobs and offer a beanfeast for private-sector parasites. As a result she is facing disciplinary proceedings. The personnel director doing the disciplining is Helen Gordon.

Privatisation plans for the tube have meant £108m of our money (twice what's needed to fix the escalators) given to consultants, at the behest of millionaire businesswoman Nicky Gavron. She is Prescott's chief privatisation quango-crat, and a councillor in Haringey, where she voted for the sell-off of the education authority and PFI in schools. She is Labour's GLA candidate for Enfield and Haringey.

In London North East, New Labour devotees can vote for Meg Hillier. In 1998, she was elected as a councillor in Islington by seven votes, promising to keep an old people's home open. Two weeks later she voted to close it. Shortly afterwards, she supported the decision to sack 11 housing workers. In February, an industrial tribunal unanimously accused the council of direct and indirect racism and sexism, victimisation and wrongful dismissal. Fortunately, socialists in the constituency can vote for one of the sacked black women, Cecilia Prosper, who is standing for the LSA.

It is the same all over London. The LSA is fielding public sector workers and trade unionists, anti-racists, community activists and campaigning pensioners. Labour is fielding ghastly Blairites dedicated to running down public services. I'm sorry to end this column on an uncharacteristically cheery note, but it will be such a pleasure to vote socialist against New Labour.

webTitle: Tight squeeze when security hits the roof

fields.headline: Tight squeeze when security hits the roof
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: In a city whose 24-hour soundtrack is the head-splitting car alarm alternating with the screeching siren, the biggest menace to the law-abiding is, of course, not the thug rumoured to be lurking on every street corner but the policeman or the private security goon.
fields.body:
In a city whose 24-hour soundtrack is the head-splitting car alarm alternating with the screeching siren, the biggest menace to the law-abiding is, of course, not the thug rumoured to be lurking on every street corner but the policeman or the private security goon.

They're worse than cockroaches, and they're everywhere. In every supermarket, theatre, or cinema. In every park, on every street, in every restaurant and bar.

The krysha (roof) is the protection racket. They're supposed to be the bad guys. The okhrana is the security outfit, official or unofficial. They're supposed to be the good guys. Try telling the two apart.

Security is modern Moscow's obsession. From the uniformed hooligans stalking you round a grocery to the licensed robbery of the ubiquitous traffic cops, there's no escape from the macho chaps bent on ensuring your safety.

Take the Praga restaurant, a canary-yellow wedding cake of a building straddling the Novy Arbat,which sweeps down to the Kremlin.

Leonid Brezhnev had these drab high-rises built as a showcase for communist consumerism back in the heady days of the 60s, when Russia still fondly imagined it would "overtake" the west.

The Praga became a favoured haunt for upwardly mobile apparatchiks, visiting VIPs, and wedding parties. These days the car park full of Range Rovers, Pajeros, and Mercedes betrays a clientele of nouveau riche thugs and politicos.

In Moscow the divide between the two is largely theoretical. Official statistics released this week includes the finding that four out of five organised-crime bosses in Russia have contacts with government officials. The Praga is Mayor Yury Luzhkov's favourite restaurant.

Or rather, restaurants. There are nine themed restaurants in the mock palace, all marble, statuary, gilt and draped curtains. And there are as many security staff tracing your every step as costumed waiters and waitresses trying to serve you.

There are security checks, the occasional body search, a metal detector encased in green marble. You expect to be clapped in handcuffs as you're escorted to your candle-lit table with a fine view over the city. The Praga spares no expense. Not that you would dream of eating there, at around £200 for two for extremely mediocre fare.

The precautions are symptomatic of a city where security must be the biggest growth industry, a job creation scheme for hordes of loutish young males transformed into power-crazed bullies by donning a uniform and being handed a weapon.

When buying, say, a bottle of wine it is not uncommon to be shadowed by a chap who sees what you pick, watches you pay for it, and demands to inspect your receipt before letting you leave the shop.

In a supermarket across from the Kremlin, your bags are inspected on entry and exit. You may be told to leave your coat at the entrance.

Then there's the Big Brother industry: shops doing a brisk trade in firearms and phone bugs, closed circuit TVs and flak jackets, videophones and steel helmets.

Everything for the budding Robocop. The biggest such store - blacked out windows, furtive types shuffling around inside - is, appropriately enough, across the street from the police ministry.

webTitle: Can Phoenix rise from Rover ashes?

fields.headline: Can Phoenix rise from Rover ashes?
fields.standfirst:
Alchemy Partners has failed to turn the base metal of an ailing car plant into gold. What are the other options?

Rover in crisis: special report
BMW Group
Alchemy Partners
Rover Cars
fields.trailText:
Closure
Under the terms of the now collapsed Alchemy deal up to 5,000 jobs, just over half the workforce, would have faced redundancy as the venture capital group moved towards concentration on the MG marque and abandoned volume production. But as the statement from BMW yesterday made clear, the closure of Longbridge is now one of the options being considered.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Nicholas Bannister and Mark Milner
fields.body:
Closure
Under the terms of the now collapsed Alchemy deal up to 5,000 jobs, just over half the workforce, would have faced redundancy as the venture capital group moved towards concentration on the MG marque and abandoned volume production. But as the statement from BMW yesterday made clear, the closure of Longbridge is now one of the options being considered.

If that happened the fallout for the West Midlands would be even worse than has so far been envisaged. And closing Longbridge would threaten the future of the Swindon plant, which provides body panels for models across the Rover range and which employs another 2,700 people.

The German carmaker has said that selling the plant remains an alternative and there is a bid - from the John Towers-led Phoenix consortium - on the table on which the workers are pinning their hopes. But that is very far from a done deal while the prospects of another buyer emerging for Longbridge at this stage must be uncertain at best.

Yet Longbridge is a key component of the West Midlands economy, which has already seen the loss of more than 30,000 manufacturing jobs since September 1998. According to the interim report of the Rover taskforce the Rover Group, which includes the plants at Swindon and Cowley, Oxfordshire, as well as Longbridge, supports some 50,000 jobs in the region. Longbridge alone supports 24,000. Nor does that figure include jobs that might go at firms tipped over the edge by the loss of Rover business.

Rover contributes between £1.6bn and £1.8bn to regional gross domestic product, with, again, a big chunk coming from the big car plant. On average Longbridge workers are paid around 25% more than the average for the region - £25,000 against £20,000.

But the loss of the Longbridge plant would have an incalculable impact on the local community beyond the stark economic numbers. Almost all of the plant's workforce lives within a 10-mile radius of the plant, concentrating the impact on a relatively small area, around Longbridge itself, Northfield and Bromsgrove.

Then there is the structure of the workforce. A series of previous redundancy programmes during BMW's ownership has meant that most older workers have already left. For most of the current workforce early retirement is not an option.

Then there is the damage to the skills base within the region. As the taskforce pointed out: "It is already clear that other employers within the automotive sector, and from other sectors, will see major opportunities to employ skilled workers from the Rover Group and the supply chain. This can clearly be beneficial to those workers, but there will also be a tendency for those skills to 'leach away' from local communities through migration."

Alchemy
For Alchemy Partners, the Rover deal is dead and buried. BMW has made it clear in the bluntest possible way that it is no longer interested in doing a deal.

The Alchemy view is that BMW's strategy has changed at the highest level yet again. It does not believe that the German carmaker's board would risk yet another volte face to bring Alchemy back to the negotiating table.

However, the London venture capitalist firm will not be junking all its work on Rover. It believes that Rover's Longbridge plant is now doomed, if not this year then within the next couple of years. "We will be watching the situation with interest and if an opportunity arose to do something with MG, for example, we might be interested," an Alchemy source said.

Alchemy's now discarded plan was to turn Rover into the MG Car Company, making between 50,000 and 100,000 sports cars or sports saloons at Longbridge, with a greatly reduced workforce.

Any attempt to use political pressure to persuade Alchemy to reopen negotiations with BMW would get short shrift. Ministers and Labour MPs have given the company a rough ride over its bid for Rover and deliberately encouraged others to mount a counter-bid.

Money too is not an issue. The shortfall that emerged after BMW imposed its last- minute demands is far too big to be bridged by state aid, even if that was allowed under EU competition policy.

If BMW had not pulled out, Alchemy's Rover deal could still have broken down. Alchemy had not yet submitted its own list of final demands.

The key to the success of a venture capital firm such as Alchemy is the ability to look at deals, decide whether they are viable, and walk away if they are not.

The Rover affair has raised Alchemy's profile and increased the number of propositions it is receiving.

Phoenix
If John Towers' group can rescue Longbridge and secure the jobs of the bulk of its 9,000-strong workforce, it will deserve its slightly grandiloquent title - the Phoenix consortium.

Despite the enthusiasm of the workforce the ashes are looking a little cold. BMW has said it will look at Phoenix's bid but only after having earlier pushed it aside on the grounds that it did not provide sufficient detail on the way in which it would be financed. It said it would provide Phoenix with the financial information it has been requesting in order to tie in the bid's financial backers.Observers in Germany say BMW remains unenthusiastic about the Phoenix offer. That should not be too surprising. Mr Towers' group is planning the continuation of volume car production at Longbridge, which is one reason why the deal is popular with the workforce, but which has proved beyond the German carmaker.

According to industry sources the plan is said to require up to £700m of public money, a scale of support from the public purse which the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is unlikely to countenance despite the £22.5bn raised from the sale of third-generation mobile phone licences.

The consortium's plan has won the enthusiastic support of the Rover workforce, local politicians, ministers and unions because it envisaged about 3,000 fewer Longbridge redundancies than the Alchemy scheme. But in private union officials recognise that Phoenix's achilles heel has always been the difficulties it would face raising the necessary finance.

Although a number of the Midlands businessmen behind Phoenix are millionaires in their own right, they do not have the huge sums that will be needed to fund Rover's losses of £2m a day, let alone the £500m or more needed to develop and produce a new car.

The big investors and lenders needed to get the Phoenix deal off the ground will be all the more cautious now that Alchemy has failed to clinch a deal with BMW.

Other options
BMW's chances of selling Rover Car Operations will depend heavily on what exactly is for sale.

As it stands the Longbridge plant, which was to have gone to Alchemy, is unlikely to attract the attention of the world's big-league carmakers.

"The European, American and Japanese car manufacturers already have all the [European] factories they need," said one observer. "But one of the smaller Asian makers might be interested. For, say, £50m they would get a manufacturing base in Europe and 1% of the European car market."

Tata is one name that has been mentioned, although the Indian industrial group, which already includes Tetley tea, has denied any approach to BMW. Malaysia's Proton is another company that experts believe might be interested.

The Rover brand name might also spark interest from outside the automotive industry, but a buyer without an existing carmaking arm could face problems - particularly if the plan were to maintain Rover as a volume carmaker.

The intriguing question is where Rover's Cowley plant will fit into the equation. Under the Alchemy deal Cowley would have stayed with BMW and continued to produce the top-of-the-range Rover 75 for Alchemy. Production of the new Mini is also scheduled to take place at Cowley. Although yesterday's statement did not define exactly what Rover Car Operations includes, it is understood to exclude the Cowley factory and the pressing plant at Swindon. One theory gaining ground yesterday was that BMW might have a buyer lined up for Cowley, including the Rover 75 and the Mini.

Any buyer for part of the Rover business, however, will have to battle against the problem that has bedevilled all BMW's efforts to turn Rover round: the strength of the pound. The German car group is losing £2m a day at Rover and has made no secret of its belief that at least half that figure is due to sterling's strength on the foreign exchanges.

Other carmakers with UK manufacturing operations are understood to be pressing the government over the strength of the pound, including at a recent meeting between representatives of the car industry and the prime minister. With sterling now standing at euro 1.7160, around DM3.40, the exchange rate will be a key factor in the calculations of any potential buyer.

Almost all of the plant's workforce lives within a 10-mile radius of the plant, concentrating the impact on a relatively small area, around Longbridge itself, Northfield and Bromsgrove. Then there is the structure of the workforce. A series of previous redundancy programmes during BMW's ownership has meant that most older workers have already left. For most of the current workforce early retirement is not an option. Then there is the damage to the skills base within the region. As the taskforce pointed out: "It is already clear that other employers within the automotive sector, and from other sectors, will see major opportunities to employ skilled workers from the Rover Group and the supply chain. This can clearly be beneficial to those workers, but there will also be a tendency for those skills to 'leach away' from local communities through migration." Alchemy For Alchemy Partners, the Rover deal is dead and buried. BMW has made it clear in the bluntest possible way that it is no longer interested in doing a deal. The Alchemy view is that BMW's strategy has changed at the highest level yet again. It does not believe that the German carmaker's board would risk yet another volte face to bring Alchemy back to the negotiating table. However, the London venture capitalist firm will not be junking all its work on Rover. It believes that Rover's Longbridge plant is now doomed, if not this year then within the next couple of years. "We will be watching the situation with interest and if an opportunity arose to do something with MG, for example, we might be interested," an Alchemy source said. Alchemy's now discarded plan was to turn Rover into the MG Car Company, making between 50,000 and 100,000 sports cars or sports saloons at Longbridge, with a greatly reduced workforce. Any attempt to use political pressure to persuade Alchemy to reopen negotiations with BMW would get short shrift. Ministers and Labour MPs have given the company a rough ride over its bid for Rover and deliberately encouraged others to mount a counter-bid. Money too is not an issue. The shortfall that emerged after BMW imposed its last- minute demands is far too big to be bridged by state aid, even if that was allowed under EU competition policy. If BMW had not pulled out, Alchemy's Rover deal could still have broken down. Alchemy had not yet submitted its own list of final demands. The key to the success of a venture capital firm such as Alchemy is the ability to look at deals, decide whether they are viable, and walk away if they are not. The Rover affair has raised Alchemy's profile and increased the number of propositions it is receiving. Phoenix If John Towers' group can rescue Longbridge and secure the jobs of the bulk of its 9,000-strong workforce, it will deserve its slightly grandiloquent title - the Phoenix consortium. Despite the enthusiasm of the workforce the ashes are looking a little cold. BMW has said it will look at Phoenix's bid but only after having earlier pushed it aside on the grounds that it did not provide sufficient detail on the way in which it would be financed. It said it would provide Phoenix with the financial information it has been requesting in order to tie in the bid's financial backers.Observers in Germany say BMW remains unenthusiastic about the Phoenix offer. That should not be too surprising. Mr Towers' group is planning the continuation of volume car production at Longbridge, which is one reason why the deal is popular with the workforce, but which has proved beyond the German carmaker. According to industry sources the plan is said to require up to £700m of public money, a scale of support from the public purse which the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is unlikely to countenance despite the £22.5bn raised from the sale of third-generation mobile phone licences. The consortium's plan has won the enthusiastic support of the Rover workforce, local politicians, ministers and unions because it envisaged about 3,000 fewer Longbridge redundancies than the Alchemy scheme. But in private union officials recognise that Phoenix's achilles heel has always been the difficulties it would face raising the necessary finance. Although a number of the Midlands businessmen behind Phoenix are millionaires in their own right, they do not have the huge sums that will be needed to fund Rover's losses of £2m a day, let alone the £500m or more needed to develop and produce a new car. The big investors and lenders needed to get the Phoenix deal off the ground will be all the more cautious now that Alchemy has failed to clinch a deal with BMW. Other options BMW's chances of selling Rover Car Operations will depend heavily on what exactly is for sale. As it stands the Longbridge plant, which was to have gone to Alchemy, is unlikely to attract the attention of the world's big-league carmakers. "The European, American and Japanese car manufacturers already have all the [European] factories they need," said one observer. "But one of the smaller Asian makers might be interested. For, say, £50m they would get a manufacturing base in Europe and 1% of the European car market." Tata is one name that has been mentioned, although the Indian industrial group, which already includes Tetley tea, has denied any approach to BMW. Malaysia's Proton is another company that experts believe might be interested. The Rover brand name might also spark interest from outside the automotive industry, but a buyer without an existing carmaking arm could face problems - particularly if the plan were to maintain Rover as a volume carmaker. The intriguing question is where Rover's Cowley plant will fit into the equation. Under the Alchemy deal Cowley would have stayed with BMW and continued to produce the top-of-the-range Rover 75 for Alchemy. Production of the new Mini is also scheduled to take place at Cowley. Although yesterday's statement did not define exactly what Rover Car Operations includes, it is understood to exclude the Cowley factory and the pressing plant at Swindon. One theory gaining ground yesterday was that BMW might have a buyer lined up for Cowley, including the Rover 75 and the Mini. Any buyer for part of the Rover business, however, will have to battle against the problem that has bedevilled all BMW's efforts to turn Rover round: the strength of the pound. The German car group is losing £2m a day at Rover and has made no secret of its belief that at least half that figure is due to sterling's strength on the foreign exchanges. Other carmakers with UK manufacturing operations are understood to be pressing the government over the strength of the pound, including at a recent meeting between representatives of the car industry and the prime minister. With sterling now standing at euro 1.7160, around DM3.40, the exchange rate will be a key factor in the calculations of any potential buyer.

webTitle: Hague puts Tories back in tune with the Sun

fields.headline: Hague puts Tories back in tune with the Sun
fields.standfirst:
How the opposition leader won back the 'tough on crime' mantle from Tony Blair, wearing liberal disapproval as a badge of honour

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: "When Richard Littlejohn says jump, William Hague says 'how high?'" a disgruntled Labour spin-doctor was heard to mutter this week. The Conservative leader, relishing the unfamiliar glow of being feted by the Sun's rottweiler columnist, will be unconcerned at the intended insult. For Mr Hague, hoping for a much-needed upturn in Tory fortunes in next week's local elections, suggestions that his party and the nation's top selling daily tabloid are back in tune can only be a compliment.
fields.body:
"When Richard Littlejohn says jump, William Hague says 'how high?'" a disgruntled Labour spin-doctor was heard to mutter this week. The Conservative leader, relishing the unfamiliar glow of being feted by the Sun's rottweiler columnist, will be unconcerned at the intended insult. For Mr Hague, hoping for a much-needed upturn in Tory fortunes in next week's local elections, suggestions that his party and the nation's top selling daily tabloid are back in tune can only be a compliment.

Conservative strategists are this weekend congratulating themselves that a headline-grabbing foray into the politics of a householder's right to defend himself and his property has secured their leader both media coverage and significant support.

If the Sun and the Daily Mail like what they hear, and readers' polls show huge support, the Tories believe they can afford to wear as a badge of honour the disapproval of the "liberal establishment" over Mr Hague's seizing of the case of Norfolk farmer Tony Martin, who was convicted of murder for shooting dead a teenage burglar on his land.

The perceived success of the Tory leader's interventions over reform of self-defence laws, following the similarly received demands for tightened restrictions on asylum seekers, will set the tone for future Conservative attempts to end opinion poll flatlining and seize the agenda in the run-up to next year's likely general election.

Next month, Mr Hague will make a set piece speech on crime and punishment to the Police Federation, a platform strategists intend to use again to play on public fears over their own safety and concern that offenders are not adequately punished. More opportunities to talk tabloid-pleasing "common sense", as the Tories' policy document has it, will be seized on as events like the Martin trial arise.

The tactics of Mr Hague and his advisers have drawn sharp criticism not only from the Labour party and the liberal press but from more traditional Conservative quarters. Times columnist Peter Riddell warned Mr Hague against "trying to be a tabloid columnist", arguing that "the leader of a party aspiring to be the government should not fan public prejudices with kneejerk reactions".

Other commentators, as well as reacting with distaste to apparent jumping on bandwagons by the Tories with no care for the dangerous tensions such moves might provoke, pointed out that several of Mr Hague's prescriptions for "rebalancing" the justice system were ill-informed, impractical and simply wrong.

For Labour, the Conservatives' tough talk on asylum and law and order is merely an attempt to claw back the "tough on crime" reputation lost when one Tony Blair took over as shadow home secretary. "With this and with his anti-Euro rhetoric Hague is pitching to his heartland," a Millbank source said. "This is about reuniting the Tory tribe fractured at the last election by the Referendum Party and UKIP."

Labour strategists maintain that, by seizing populist right-wing issues, Mr Hague is confining his target to some 30% of voters - a so-called Tory hard core.

If they, at least, turn out on polling days, Mr Hague has calculated his own leadership will be secure, though his party will inevitably lose the general election, Labour's election planners say.

The Conservatives, looking forward to successes in next week's local polls and expecting a likely byelection hold in Romsey, reject the analysis. One Central Office insider de nies the party can simultaneously be accused of being both rightwing and populist. "Issues such as the Tony Martin case worry people of all persuasions and really do cut across party lines.

"We are taking a pragmatic approach, and pragmatism inevitably means we will be on the side of the majority. If these are majority issues, ours cannot be an extreme position."

Charges of bandwagon jumping are also firmly rejected, though Tory sources do acknowledge that Mr Hague took the decision to speak out over self-defence this week in the wake of the Martin case. The bones of the argument, they claim, were in place beforehand, following feedback from the public via the Tories' nationwide Listening to Britain tour and the Save the Pound roadshows in market squares around Britain.

It is Mr Hague himself, inspired by encounters with voters while on the road, who has marked out the party's stances on asylum and crime, insiders say. At Wednesday strategy meetings and daily policy meetings at Central Office, Mr Hague, together with the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, and the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, plus policy advisers, have hammered out the "common sense" approach pioneered at last year's European elections and now moving towards top gear.

The formula is "a combination of pre-planning and seizing the moment", a senior Tory source said, rejecting suggestions that the party makes up policy on the hoof.

"This is actually the antithesis of knee-jerk responses," an insider said. "Common sense fits in directly with the traditional idea of Conservatism being all about the wisdom of the ages and the idea that two heads are better than one. We have these responses to these issues because we have been brought up to respond to them in a particular way."

The goal is less to win votes on particular issues than to create a party which voters believe reflects their general concerns and values, sources said.

The headline grabbing may appear to be underpinned by a philosophy, but to many observers - including the dwindling band of cautious voices within Mr Hague's party - the strategy appears to amount to an underlying decision to tune in to the public's first responses, then wait for an issue sufficiently clear-cut to wade into with all guns blazing.

Much to Labour's frustration, however, it is likely to have had some effect - at least in the imminent elections. With the asylum and crime speeches, backed by anti-Euro rhetoric and a dash of anti-gay scaremongering over section 28, Mr Hague has at least succeeded in setting an agenda, dragging Labour from its own efforts to stress delivery on health, education and the economy.

"This kind of stuff makes the micro-climate of campaigning very unpleasant," said a Labour source, acknowledging that the government has been forced to respond to the Tory lead. "We have to keep making the argument that this is a real issue."

At Central Office, such responses are met with scoffing. "What can the government do?" a source said. "They can't go to the right of us on asylum, but they can't stay left either. So they're left with either keeping quiet or just abusing us. That's when we know they're worried."

Mr Littlejohn, setting Tory policies which in turn are dictating Labour ones, must be grinning more broadly than ever.

fields.headline: The capital's choice
fields.standfirst:
London's mayor will blaze a trail for others

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: On Thursday voters in London will become the first Britons to elect directly their own executive mayor. It is a moment campaigners for urban renewal and for local power have long dreamed of. For this is not just a breakthrough for the capital, but for the whole country. At last a big city will be able to take a direct hand in governing itself, in the form of an individual with a real mandate and transparent accountability.
fields.body:
A long and novel experience in British public life is about to reach its climax. On Thursday voters in London will become the first Britons to elect directly their own executive mayor. It is a moment campaigners for urban renewal and for local power have long dreamed of. For this is not just a breakthrough for the capital, but for the whole country. At last a big city will be able to take a direct hand in governing itself, in the form of an individual with a real mandate and transparent accountability. If the mayoralty works in London, then Britain's other great cities may follow. London is taking a step into the unknown, but it is a move this newspaper has long urged.

The conventional wisdom is that this new institution has had an awkward birth. There was the agony over the Conservative nomination, as Jeffrey Archer was forced to withdraw in disgrace, and there have been serious Labour pains. The Ken and Frank show struck many, especially those outside London, as a ludicrous pantomime. Indeed our ICM poll this month, showing a deep slump in support for the mayoralty idea across Britain, suggests the London follies have put people off an innovation they once liked. It has also failed to live up to the expectations of the man who made it happen. Tony Blair thought a mayoralty would attract a new kind of elected official: a chief executive, perhaps from business, who would win power on a promise of managerial expertise rather than ideology. That has not materialised. Instead it has seen three veteran politicians and one wanna-be slug it out for the first four places in the contest. It is a shame that this new prize did not attract a wholly different kind of animal; perhaps we can can keep that hope alive for next time.

For all that, this race has generated a level of public interest that is unusual for politics - especially unusual for local government. It has created a welcome buzz in the capital: if that translates into a healthy turnout on Thursday, then we should be particularly grateful.

So much for the campaign to get the job. What's needed now is a good person to do it. Which of the people on offer is the right one? A couple of the outsider candidates have acquitted themselves well: Ram Gidoomal of the Christian People's Alliance has won some new friends, as has the Green, Darren Johnson. But no one is under any illusion that either will win. Instead the best way to approach the matter may be to decide what one wants from a mayor. If one is looking for a candidate with management experience, but with a feel for the rough-and-tumble of politics, then Steve Norris has some obvious appeal. He has impressed with his grasp of transport questions and his feel for the ethnic make-up of London. He has forged what may be a vote-winning brand of Toryism: tough on economic questions, liberal on most (but not all) social ones. He has run transport in London already, as a minister. What may give some voters pause is not just Mr Norris's hardline stance on abortion, the death penalty and asylum, but the prospect of rewarding the current Conservative party with a victory in London, giving them the momentum they are going to need as they go into the campaign for the next general election.

Frank Dobson has been ill-served by this campaign. Labour's determination to shoe-horn him into the party's nomination served to transform him from a political heavyweight into a stooge. He has been parachuted down from the Cabinet, rather than bubbling up from London. That is quite the wrong dynamic for the debut mayoralty. Still, if one believes that, given the way the job is structured, the key task of any mayor will be to work with central government, then Mr Dobson has an advantage. The mayor cannot raise his own taxes; he will have to prise money from the wallet of Gordon Brown. Labour will surely do that more readily for one of its own than for anyone else.

If one believes a combination of arms-length independence and managerial competence is required, then Susan Kramer will look like the answer. A Lib Dem mayor would ensure some creative tension with the Labour government, while Ms Kramer would also bring real financial expertise to the job. It could only be healthy for British politics if such a high-profile job were filled by a woman.

Others looking for independence may want something else as well: political experience and a track record on London. They may also want a mayor with charisma, telegenic charm and enough flair to ensure the new office does not fade into civic tedium. If those are the criteria, then Ken Livingstone would be the obvious choice. Voters who can overlook Mr Livingstone's tendency to shoot his mouth off - and the distrust he engenders in those who know him best - will know that, with him, London life would at least be exciting. This is a far from perfect field, but this is the choice the capital faces. Londoners have until Thursday to decide what quality matters most for a mayoralty that will not only serve the capital but set a pattern for the country. It is a great opportunity: we hope every Londoner will take it.

fields.headline: A crisis cooked to order
fields.standfirst:
Can there be fair elections in Zimbabwe?

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The ruthless determination of President Robert Mugabe to cling to power in Zimbabwe at almost any cost is now plain for all to see. Though there is now agreement that the elections, if and when they come, will be monitored by Commonwealth observers, it is hard to see how, given the intimidation which has occurred already, they can ever now be rated "free and fair".
fields.body:
The ruthless determination of President Robert Mugabe to cling to power in Zimbabwe at almost any cost is now plain for all to see. The failure of this week's talks in London to persuade his government to halt the farm occupations and the spreading political violence in return for land reform aid was predictable. Mr Mugabe has cast Britain in the old, familiar role of colonial oppressor. He was never likely to allow Robin Cook the chance to claim a diplomatic breakthrough and may now be expected to use this collapse for further empty castigation of Britain. Though there is now agreement that the elections, if and when they come, will be monitored by Commonwealth observers, it is hard to see how, given the intimidation which has occurred already, they can ever now be rated "free and fair". They will proceed only when Mr Mugabe judges that his systematic intimidation of his opponents, both black and white, is complete. At this point, Mr Mugabe simply does not want a solution to a crisis he has engineered.

Mr Mugabe's slash-and-burn strategy has gradually become clear since the Zanu-PF party "summit" which he convened after last February's surprise referendum defeat. To win elections he suddenly feared he might lose, he reverted to the emotive issue of land reform, which he has consistently mishandled during 20 years in power. He sanctioned the invasion of white-owned farms by bogus "war veterans" and ignored court orders to halt the trespass. He encouraged violence against farmers and their black workers. These brutal, often fatal attacks have since been extended to all suspected supporters of the popular multiracial opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change, in rural areas and townships.

As part of this strategy, he has vilified his opponents as stooges of foreign pow ers, especially Britain. He has tampered with the constitution to justify land seizures, has increased police powers to suppress dissent, and intimidated independent media. He shows disdain for the rule of law and democratic pluralism. He offers no apology for the corruption, economic chaos, and military adventurism which have robbed and bled his people. And he looks down with barely concealed contempt at South Africa's President Thabo Mbeki and less established regional leaders who have timidly begged him to see reason.

Most unforgiveably of all, he has blatantly stoked the fires of racial division, describing white Zimbabweans as "enemies of the state". This is the kind of regressive, bigoted despotism from which, it was hoped, modern African countries had largely escaped. Whatever may be said about past wrongs and historic injustices - and the pattern of land ownership, no doubt about it, is a justifiable grievance - there can be no excuse for racism. Mr Mugabe's naked defence of personal power is now on embarrassing display. It is, crudely, viciously, all about one man's hubris.

All of which is no reason to give up on Zimbabwe itself. Quite the opposite. International pressure for free, monitored elections must increase. The opposition must be urged not to repay violence with violence but to stick, despite provocation, to the democratic path. In particular, prevaricating regional leaders like Mr Mbeki must now actually show some leadership. Britain can and must keep trying. The Commonwealth needs to play a much more active role. But at bottom, Mr Mugabe is an African problem. Indeed, in many ways, he is the problem, and he does his brothers a great disservice. Africa, in its own interest, must bring him to heel or cast him out.
fields.bodyText: The ruthless determination of President Robert Mugabe to cling to power in Zimbabwe at almost any cost is now plain for all to see. The failure of this week's talks in London to persuade his government to halt the farm occupations and the spreading political violence in return for land reform aid was predictable. Mr Mugabe has cast Britain in the old, familiar role of colonial oppressor. He was never likely to allow Robin Cook the chance to claim a diplomatic breakthrough and may now be expected to use this collapse for further empty castigation of Britain. Though there is now agreement that the elections, if and when they come, will be monitored by Commonwealth observers, it is hard to see how, given the intimidation which has occurred already, they can ever now be rated "free and fair". They will proceed only when Mr Mugabe judges that his systematic intimidation of his opponents, both black and white, is complete. At this point, Mr Mugabe simply does not want a solution to a crisis he has engineered. Mr Mugabe's slash-and-burn strategy has gradually become clear since the Zanu-PF party "summit" which he convened after last February's surprise referendum defeat. To win elections he suddenly feared he might lose, he reverted to the emotive issue of land reform, which he has consistently mishandled during 20 years in power. He sanctioned the invasion of white-owned farms by bogus "war veterans" and ignored court orders to halt the trespass. He encouraged violence against farmers and their black workers. These brutal, often fatal attacks have since been extended to all suspected supporters of the popular multiracial opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change, in rural areas and townships. As part of this strategy, he has vilified his opponents as stooges of foreign pow ers, especially Britain. He has tampered with the constitution to justify land seizures, has increased police powers to suppress dissent, and intimidated independent media. He shows disdain for the rule of law and democratic pluralism. He offers no apology for the corruption, economic chaos, and military adventurism which have robbed and bled his people. And he looks down with barely concealed contempt at South Africa's President Thabo Mbeki and less established regional leaders who have timidly begged him to see reason. Most unforgiveably of all, he has blatantly stoked the fires of racial division, describing white Zimbabweans as "enemies of the state". This is the kind of regressive, bigoted despotism from which, it was hoped, modern African countries had largely escaped. Whatever may be said about past wrongs and historic injustices - and the pattern of land ownership, no doubt about it, is a justifiable grievance - there can be no excuse for racism. Mr Mugabe's naked defence of personal power is now on embarrassing display. It is, crudely, viciously, all about one man's hubris. All of which is no reason to give up on Zimbabwe itself. Quite the opposite. International pressure for free, monitored elections must increase. The opposition must be urged not to repay violence with violence but to stick, despite provocation, to the democratic path. In particular, prevaricating regional leaders like Mr Mbeki must now actually show some leadership. Britain can and must keep trying. The Commonwealth needs to play a much more active role. But at bottom, Mr Mugabe is an African problem. Indeed, in many ways, he is the problem, and he does his brothers a great disservice. Africa, in its own interest, must bring him to heel or cast him out.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: One year and one day after talks began, venerable Grindlays, banker to the nation's senior civil servants, is out of the clutches of Australia's ANZ bank and in the arms of an outfit with which it has much more in common, Standard Chartered. The marriage scotches any suggestion that a deal would have foundered on ill-feeling between Standard chief executive Rana Talwar and his opposite number at ANZ, John McFarlane, given the former is widely believed to have blocked the latter's progress when they were both at Standard. They get on well, we hear, and the deal was mooted over a friendly dinner. Buying Grindlays will bolster Standard's presence in India, although some of us have always felt the magnificent Paris branch near the Opera justified Grindlays's existence all by itself.

One year and one day after talks began, venerable Grindlays, banker to the nation's senior civil servants, is out of the clutches of Australia's ANZ bank and in the arms of an outfit with which it has much more in common, Standard Chartered. The marriage scotches any suggestion that a deal would have foundered on ill-feeling between Standard chief executive Rana Talwar and his opposite number at ANZ, John McFarlane, given the former is widely believed to have blocked the latter's progress when they were both at Standard. They get on well, we hear, and the deal was mooted over a friendly dinner. Buying Grindlays will bolster Standard's presence in India, although some of us have always felt the magnificent Paris branch near the Opera justified Grindlays's existence all by itself.

 On a Gallic note, we turn to folie des grandeurs - not actually proper French, but never mind - with a possible addition to that long, long list of red alert warnings signs - company helicopter, publicity crazed chief executive - that tip the wink to the wily investor that a company's shares ought to be sold right now, at market. ITV is launching a "major initiative", the "year of promise". Companies pay £25, make a promise they intend to keep, and both their corporate names and their promise "will be physically inscribed" on one of a series of landmarks "for future generations to see". Given the short lifespans of most companies this is tempting fate somewhat. And those already lining up for a place on one of ITV's menhirs are seen to be promising to negate the effects of their own commercial activities. BP pledges "to encourage the use of solar power", Center (sic) Parcs (sic) promises to set up nature reserves in its parcs (sic, sic, sic) while Yorkshire Electricity pledges it will encourage environmental awareness. Vauxhall's promise is the most eccentric: "To encourage people to be more responsive when driving, particularly at night". Responsive to what? The Vauxhall patrolman on your tail, perhaps?

 Across the Atlantic US taxpayers have been making midnight flits to the nearest postbox in order to meet the annual tax return deadline imposed by the internal revenue service. This fiscal hit squad makes our own dear tax collectors look, by comparison, like the Care Bears. According to one Arkansas newspaper, however, the deadline is good news for the US post office, which has seen a sudden leap in demand for a series of stamps depicting wildlife, including insects. The stamp of the black widow spider, apparently, was especially popular among those posting their tax returns. We really cannot imagine why.

 Also out of America comes Isabel, daughter of the late Robert Maxwell, making a rare public appearance in London earlier this week when she spoke to internet networking group First Tuesday - Miss Maxwell lives in silicon valley and runs email firm Commtouch. Her basic message to start-ups was "go global or go home", precisely the sort of big thinking of which her old man would have approved. Asked how she saw the British internet scene, she said: "It's very much alive here, although the culture is still the same. It still helps if you are educated at Eton rather than in Leicestershire". Miss Maxwell turned to business failure, a topic close to the Department of Trade and Industry's collective heart: "If you fail here people look down on you, but in the US is it seen as a badge of honour." Brother Kevin would presumably rate a chestful of medals for his own now discharged record bankruptcy. "The culture here needs to shift significantly if you are going to let people get up again." To be fair to hidebound old Blighty, Kevin has got up again, albeit in New York.

 Back home, Scott Bell, head of Standard Life, will not let his May bank holidayweekend be spoiled by carpetbagger Fred Woollard. He will be at Murrayfield, currently waterlogged, for the first ever appearance of the rugby league final, more usually a sport for English in the north. After that? A round of golf before resuming his fight on Tuesday.

 Finally, to the office for national statistics - which on Thursday was hosting a team of official number-crunchers from China just as the boys back in Beijing were uttering blood-curdling threats to Taiwan, threatening the country with "disaster". The ONS was helping the Chinese to improve their official statistics - a process that, if successful, may spare us in future much of the guff about "tomorrow's economic giant" we have suffered now for at least the last quarter of a century. We must hope that the "disaster" does not deprive us of the enjoyment of this respite.

webTitle: How the Alchemy deal fell apart

fields.headline: How the Alchemy deal fell apart
fields.standfirst:
Venture capitalists blame 'unacceptable' BMW demands

Rover in crisis: special report
BMW Group
Alchemy Partners
Rover Cars
fields.trailText: Sipping champagne and nibbling carrot cake yesterday, Jon Moulton looked as if he had just bought Rover rather than lost the car company.
fields.byline: Kevin Maguire, Nicholas Bannister  and Mark Milner
fields.body:
Sipping champagne and nibbling carrot cake yesterday, Jon Moulton looked as if he had just bought Rover rather than lost the car company.

The venture capitalist had been confident on Thursday that within 24 hours, Alchemy Partners would pull off Project Crufts, their audacious takeover of Longbridge. A chairman had been appointed, the board was in place and Mr Moulton was looking forward to renaming his acquisition the MG Car Company.

But yesterday the champagne was for a staff birthday in his Covent Garden offices. The jaw-dropping announcement that the deal was off yesterday caught everyone by surprise, not least Alchemy.

When they filed into the of fices of the City law firm Norton Rose on Thursday afternoon, Alchemy's team, led by Graham Hallworth, finance director of the fledgling MG company, were expecting to dot the i's and cross the t's.

Nearly six weeks of negotiations with BMW's lawyers were expected to end with Longbridge going to Alchemy, which would sack most of the 9,000 workers and build sports cars.

But the Norton Rose lawyers handed over a file that was to signal the end of the Alchemy bid and plunge Rover into a new round of uncertainty.

Alchemy claims about a dozen "totally unreasonable demands" were imposed by BMW for the first time, ratcheting up the cost of Longbridge by "hundreds and hundreds of millions of pounds."

The venture capitalists were not prepared to pay more than £50m for an operation losing BMW £2m a day. The German giant was willing to write off £2bn - including £500m to cover "restructuring" - to rid itself of what it dismissively calls "the English Patient".

Yet Alchemy insists the new demands would have made the MG company bankrupt before it had sold a car. According to Alchemy, it would have had to pick up the tab to compensate franchised dealers - that alone could cost £500m.

Then there would be claims from suppliers over terminated contracts, redundancy payments of up to £40,000 a worker and a pensions bill that wilder estimates have put at £600m.

"This was a polite way of telling us it was off - one of their lawyers was giggling," said a senior source close to Alchemy. "When we saw the requests it was mission impossible. We did not negotiate. It was a deliberate attempt to scupper the deal."

Despite his boast last Tuesday that it was "very nearly a done deal", when he heard about the BMW demands Mr Moulton knew the game was up. He rang BMW's Munich headquarters to check there was no mistake. There wasn't.

Some close to Alchemy mutter darkly that BMW must have a new buyer lined up and pulled the plug because it will get a better offer if it sells Longbridge and its Cowley plant as a package.

That may be so, though BMW was giving little away yesterday. A statement announced that there was no agreement - and warning ominously that a decision on Longbridge's future will be taken next month.

The answer could be more straightforward. The limitations of BMW's management have been evident since it gazzumped Honda six years ago to buy Rover.

On Wednesday BMW declared that "negotiations with Alchemy Partners will continue in a straightforward manner", yet Alchemy claims new conditions were attached on Thursday, following a BMW board meeting.

Was it not until then that its directors realised if it was to ditch Longbridge, there was no point being left liable for huge sums of money?

After issuing their statement on the failed sale, BMW officials would only add there was a disagreement on the "financial framework" with Alchemy.

But Germany's respected Suddeutsche Zeitung newspaper accused BMW of failing to put up enough money to secure a buyer.

"BMW's legendary success in the past 30 years has been rooted in being successful and building cars for the successful", the paper said. "But the way that BMW is presenting itself nowadays is putting its image in grave danger. The firm is ending up the loser because its managers are making foolish mistakes"

BMW will now begin discussions with Phoenix, even though the company had to virtually batter down Munich doors to see key executives.

Despite public support in the West Midlands and government backing, Phoenix could not replace Alchemy as favoured suitor after the venture capitalists signed an "exclusive" deal that even now will not leave them out of pocket.

Phoenix was told a few days ago by BMW that its rescue plan did not "constitute a basis for entering negotiations."

The government, taken by surprise in March when BMW decided to offload Longbridge, was again caught unaware. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, had given up hope that Phoenix would win more time to put its case.

Yesterday he was ringing the Rover chief, Professor Werner Samann, to find out what was going on. Mr Byers' fear must now be that the Phoenix bid will also fail and Longbridge will close completely.

Longbridge's workers were ecstatic at the news, hoping Alchemy's downfall will let in Phoenix to retain jobs and mass production.

Terry Reilly, 46, who has worked at the plant for 11 years, said: "It's absolutely superb news. We have always said Alchemy was bad news for this plant - they are asset strippers who intended to sell off the best bits and leave people out of work."

As he left his office to go home to Sevenoaks in Kent, Mr Moulton had little comfort for the workers so happy to see his bid rejected. "We thought we were going to preserve quite a number of jobs," he said. "There's a good chance that there will be no jobs at the end of the day at Longbridge."

Timetable of a company in crisis

March 14 News emerges that the board of BMW is considering breaking up its loss-making subsidiary.

March 15 Alchemy Partners tipped as favourites to buy Rover.

March 16 The BMW supervisory board meets in Munich and agrees to sell Land-Rover to Ford.

March 17 Jon Moulton, managing partner at Alchemy, gives details of his plan to buy Rover cars and produce sports models under the MG badge, at a press conference in London; a task force is set up to help regenerate the west Midlands after expected job losses at Longbridge. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is criticised for being "complacent" over the future of Rover.

March 19 A boycott of BMW cars is called for by union officials.

March 22 Rover dealers say they will demand compensation from BMW.

March 23 Mr Byers travels to Munich to press BMW to help regenerate the west Midlands after the Rover sale.

March 22 John Hemming, a businessman from Birmingham, says he plans to launch an alternative bid for Rover.

March 23 Chris Woodwark, former chief executive of Rolls-Royce Motors, is named by Alchemy as chief executive of its planned MG Car Company.

March 28 Commons trade and industry select committee launches inquiry into the Rover sale; BMW's annual results show heavy losses at Rover, which had cost the firm £2.85 bn in six years.

March 29 BMW official Werner Samann tells the select committee that unsuccessful efforts had been made to sell Rover to Ford, General Motors, Volkswagen and Toyota.

April 1 Tens of thousands of people turn out for a rally in Birmingham to support the Rover workers.

April 5 Byers is questioned by the select committee. Tony Blair publicly backs his handling of the crisis.

April 6 Phoenix, a consortium headed by former Rover executive John Towers meets with BMW.

April 13 Mr Byers is cleared by the select committee over his role in the Rover sale.

April 17 Alchemy announces its plans for Rover, including using Longbridge to build a family of MG sports cars.

April 26 The government announces £10m for suppliers after task force warns that Rover sale will hit thousands of jobs in the west Midlands.

April 27 BMW rejects rival bid from the Phoenix consortium stating its failure to provide details of financial backing as the reason.

April 28 Alchemy pulls out of talks. The deal is off.

webTitle: Putin's youth marching to a vapid tomorrow

fields.headline: Putin's youth marching to a vapid tomorrow
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: A successor to the Komsomol youth movement was launched in Russia this week, dedicated not to communist ideology but to the support of Vladimir Putin.
fields.body:
A successor to the Komsomol youth movement was launched in Russia this week, dedicated not to communist ideology but to the support of Vladimir Putin.

The movement has already been sneeringly dubbed Pusomol - Putin's Union of Youth - but organisers yesterday responded to jibes by unexpectedly declaring themselves entirely satisfied with this title.

"The name Pusomol is not a bad one because we have supported and we will continue to support Putin," said member of parliament Alexandra Burataeva, who has recently been appointed youth leader.

Traditions familiar to former members of the communist youth league are to be resurrected for the new movement. Organisers will create teams of student volunteer labourers to work on state building projects, as well as motivating young people to devote their Saturdays to sweeping neighbourhood streets and performing tasks for the good of society.

The organisation will be the official youth section of the amorphous pro-Putin political faction Unity (also known as Medved, the Bear) which was hastily thrown together before last December's parliamentary elections in a shrewd and hugely successful bid to wrest votes from anti-Kremlin parties. Organisers hope ultimately to attract a membership of millions of Russians aged between 14 and 30.

Despite winning nearly a quarter of seats in the elections, Unity's ideological stance was - and remains - unclear. The creation of a youth movement comes as the bloc struggles to define itself as a political force before its first party congress at the end of May.

Political analysts in Moscow yesterday described the formation of the youth movement as a dress rehearsal for the establishment of a strong nationwide Unity party structure, soon to be set up in support of the president.

"This is a clear attempt to instil political ideas into the mass consciousness of society - using the not yet quite forgotten traditions of the communist era," said Kiril Kholodkovsky. He said the movement's launch was the first step in an attempt to transform Unity from a synthetic, cynical creation into an active political body.

Mr Putin was not present at the movement's inaugural assembly this week, but a letter underlining his warm support was read out.

In the nostalgic environment of Moscow's Palace of Youth - where Komsomol meetings once took place - newly appointed regional leaders expressed a range of somewhat confused ideas about the rationale behind the youth movement.

"Why have we set up this movement? For unification!" one man said, declining to elaborate further. "We aren't trying to create a bright new future, we want to live now," another speaker declared.

Ms Burataeva had another, equally vapid, explanation. "We need to form a new generation of socially active people," she said. "We want help every young person to become the person he wants to be, from president of Russia, to world champion."

She admitted that the movement had much to learn from the heritage of the Komsomol, which was launched in the aftermath of the revolution as part of a mass mobilisation drive for the Communist party.

Describing the aims of the movement, one of the Komsomol pioneers said: "We must rescue children from the harmful influence of family life... We must nationalise them... From the earliest days of their little lives, they must find themselves under the influence of Communist schools."

Ms Burataeva shied away from such an all-encompassing approach, and said that Unity Youth members would not be forced to join, nor would they be coerced into taking part in Soviet-style choreographed marching processions. Instead of Komsomol anthems, members would be encouraged to sing Russian pop songs. The old Komsomol insignia has been abandoned, and a nationwide contest has been launched among members for new slogans and badges.

In the same way that ambitious Komsomol members could launch themselves on the political ladder while still at school, so too can Unity Youth members boost their career prospects by diligent activity in the movement. "We want to nurture a new generation of competent, energetic politicians who will be ready to take over from us," Ms Burataeva said.

Political analysts in Moscow yesterday described the formation of the youth movement as a dress rehearsal for the establishment of a strong nationwide Unity party structure, soon to be set up in support of the president. "This is a clear attempt to instil political ideas into the mass consciousness of society - using the not yet quite forgotten traditions of the communist era," said Kiril Kholodkovsky. He said the movement's launch was the first step in an attempt to transform Unity from a synthetic, cynical creation into an active political body. Mr Putin was not present at the movement's inaugural assembly this week, but a letter underlining his warm support was read out. In the nostalgic environment of Moscow's Palace of Youth - where Komsomol meetings once took place - newly appointed regional leaders expressed a range of somewhat confused ideas about the rationale behind the youth movement. "Why have we set up this movement? For unification!" one man said, declining to elaborate further. "We aren't trying to create a bright new future, we want to live now," another speaker declared. Ms Burataeva had another, equally vapid, explanation. "We need to form a new generation of socially active people," she said. "We want help every young person to become the person he wants to be, from president of Russia, to world champion." She admitted that the movement had much to learn from the heritage of the Komsomol, which was launched in the aftermath of the revolution as part of a mass mobilisation drive for the Communist party. Describing the aims of the movement, one of the Komsomol pioneers said: "We must rescue children from the harmful influence of family life... We must nationalise them... From the earliest days of their little lives, they must find themselves under the influence of Communist schools." Ms Burataeva shied away from such an all-encompassing approach, and said that Unity Youth members would not be forced to join, nor would they be coerced into taking part in Soviet-style choreographed marching processions. Instead of Komsomol anthems, members would be encouraged to sing Russian pop songs. The old Komsomol insignia has been abandoned, and a nationwide contest has been launched among members for new slogans and badges. In the same way that ambitious Komsomol members could launch themselves on the political ladder while still at school, so too can Unity Youth members boost their career prospects by diligent activity in the movement. "We want to nurture a new generation of competent, energetic politicians who will be ready to take over from us," Ms Burataeva said.

webTitle: Plan to split opens gulf between government and industry

fields.headline: Plan to split opens gulf between government and industry
fields.standfirst:
What difference would splitting Microsoft into two make? The possibility, which was brought closer yesterday, has provoked different answers and opened up a gulf between the US government and the software industry and many on Wall Street, writes Jane Martinson

E-finance: special report
The future of Microsoft: special report
www.microsoft.com
fields.trailText: The department of justice and the 19 states that brought the historic legal action against the world's largest software company believe that splitting the company into two will increase competition.
fields.body:
The department of justice and the 19 states that brought the historic legal action against the world's largest software company believe that splitting the company into two will increase competition.

Their case, successful to date, has rested on proving the harm done to consumers by Microsoft's abuse of its monopoly position. By forcing Microsoft to separate its Windows operating system from all other applications, the federal government believes that the company will no longer be able to bully manufacturers into taking its new products by threatening to withhold a licence for Windows.

The government believes that the two resulting companies, dubbed Baby Bills after Microsoft founder Bill Gates, may even compete against each other.

In addition the companies would have an incentive to develop products for rivals. What would stop the manufacturer of Office from producing software to run on the increasingly popular Linux operating system, for instance, if the company had nothing to do with one of Linux's most bitter rivals?

Herbert Hovenkamp, a professor at the University of Iowa who has advised the government, has said: "The role of the remedy in a case like this is not to punish Microsoft but to restore competition."

Increased competition itself is proving divisive, with many Wall Street analysts denying that breaking up the company will benefit consumers.

Andrew Roskill, industry analyst at UBS Warburg, said: "The irony is that breaking up the company horizontally like this does not really solve any of the problems. There will still be one company with a dominant position in operating systems and one with a dominant position in the desktop publications business. It's ridiculous."

Both Windows and Office, the software "shell" for programmes such as Excel and Outlook, are established market leaders.

Windows has provided about 40% of Microsoft's annual revenues of $19.7bn. The two Baby Bills are also expected to share Microsoft's $21bn cash hoard, leaving them free to buy rivals unless restricted from doing so by the courts.

Legal experts have said that the government moved towards a break-up because it did not believe other so-called conduct remedies would be effective. But Bill Kovacic, a professor of law at George Washington University, said that yesterday's proposals were unlikely to end the government's involvement in the case, even if approved by the judge.

"A break-up will not be an antiseptic in avoiding subsequent oversight responsibility," he said.

Although it will take some time for analysts to work out the ramifications of any break-up, many were turning to precedent yesterday. Since the 1890 Sherman Act on monopolies 34 companies have been broken up because of abuses.

But the two most significant cases were the 1911 break-up of Standard Oil and the 1984 settlement with AT&T which saw the telephone monopoly divided. Microsoft is considered different because there is unlikely to be a settlement and because of the nature of the fast-changing software industry.

However, some analysts believe that the fast-changing nature of the industry is exactly what makes the government's view moot.
