webTitle: Main players: Leading lights in the drama that is Rover

fields.headline: Main players: Leading lights in the drama that is Rover
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText:
The Quant family
Crucial to the future of Rover and BMW will be the attitude of the seriously rich Quandt family - Johanna, now in her seventies, and her two children Susanna and her younger brother Stefan.
fields.body:
The Quant family
Crucial to the future of Rover and BMW will be the attitude of the seriously rich Quandt family - Johanna, now in her seventies, and her two children Susanna and her younger brother Stefan.

They own around 48% of BMW - the legacy of Susannah's husband Gunther who put together a financing package for BMW in 1959 after shareholders had turned down a takeover bid from Daimler Benz.

The family has since shown every indication of wanting to maintain BMW's independence. A number of carmakers have made approaches to BMW in recent years only to be rebuffed. Speculation that the Quandts may yet sell out refuses to go away, however.

The family is said to take a hands off approach to the day-to-day running of BMW but is believed to be concerned about the scale of the Rover losses.

John Towers
John Towers, chief executive of Rover at the time it was sold to BMW, was well cast as its potential saviour. He had opposed the sale to BMW and resigned over the way the company was being managed by its new owners.

During his eight years at Rover he improved industrial relations and worked closely with Honda to provide the group with new technology and models.

On leaving he joined Concentric, a struggling Midlands engineering group and Rover supplier.

Mr Towers, 52, gave industry credibility to the Rover counterbid by the Phoenix consortium of Midland businessmen, internet millionaires and Rover dealers. He is also head of a consortium seeking a licence for a west Midlands radio station.

Stephen Byers
Just when beleaguered Stephen Byers must have thought things can only get better, they took another turn for the worse.At home for the May bank holiday weekend, the collapse of Alchemy's bid again caught the trade and industry secretary on the hop.

The Rover crisis is only one of many during recent months that have severely dented his reputation.Rows over shipbuilding, Ford, manufacturing jobs, the Post Office, "rip off" Britain, utilities' regulation, coal and employment rights have dogged him.

Even his parliamentary supporters concede that the impeccably Blairite North Tyneside MP, once tipped as a future prime minister, is in political trouble.

Mr Byers, 47, hopes the Towers bid will succeed. With it rests not only the future of thousands of jobs at Longbridge, but to some extent his own.

Jon Moulton
Jon Moulton is as ruthless as Larry the Liquidator, Danny DeVito's asset stripper in the film Other People's Money. The venture capitalist revels in his own tough guy role.

Thick skinned and notorious for his sarcasm, the man Longbridge workers love to hate put on a brave face yesterday afer the collapse of his Rover bid, but inside he will have been hurting.

This would have been by far Alchemy Partners' biggest deal, yet he failed to pull it off.

Mr Moulton, who nearly died from TB and aplastic anaemia, studied chemistry at university before becoming an accountant.He fell out with colleagues at two venture capital groups, Schroder Ventures and Apax, before setting up Alchemy three years ago.

He has a reputation for doing deals his rivals would not touch, buying, selling and shaking up firms.

webTitle: Albright bids maternal farewell to spin doctor

fields.headline: Albright bids maternal farewell to spin doctor
fields.trailText: With a theatrical shrug of her shoulders and the unmistakable trace of a tear in her eye, Madeleine Albright took time off to bid formal farewell to her spin-doctor Jamie Rubin.
fields.body:
"People say that Jamie and I have a mother and son relationship," the first female secretary of state said as she bade formal farewell to her Armani-suited spin-doctor Jamie Rubin, adding: "Oi vay."

With a theatrical shrug of her shoulders and the unmistakable trace of a tear in her eye, Madeleine Albright took time off from negotiations with the Russian foreign minister on missile defence, hugged the son she never had - she has three daughters - and relinquished her seven-year hold on Mr Rubin, who has spun the world's press on her behalf, first at the UN and then for the past three and a half years at the state department.

He left with a distinguished service medal, a few good-natured digs at the press, and a bag of fresh carrots sent over from the White House by Bill Clinton.

The carrots were a joking reference to one of the low points of Mr Rubin's tenure, when President Clinton exploded with anger after Mr Rubin said the administration was offering "a little carrot" to Saddam Hussain in an effort to resolve the latest stand-off over weapons inspection in Iraq.

Mr Rubin is packing his carrots and his bags and moving to London to live with his wife, CNN's British-based roving foreign correspondent Christiane Amanpour.

Married in Italy two years ago, they have just had their first baby, Darius John Rubin, born last month in Washington. Ms Amanpour was on the podium to receive her own farewell hug from her political mother-in-law.

Mr Rubin's departure winds down an era in which state department policy has been expounded as much for the 24-hour news cycle as for the traditionally byzantine and discreet world of the diplomatic press corps.

Yesterday the Washington Post called him Mrs Albright's "finger-wagger-in-chief, highlighting the fact that during their time at the state department Washington has embraced a style of "podium diplomacy" anathema to traditionalists on both sides of the Atlantic.

To the occasional consternation of domestic critics, Mr Rubin has been Washington's arch-exponent of an ethical foreign policy, especially in respect of Kosovo.

His successor is Richard Boucher, who was spokesman under three of Mrs Albright's predecessors: James Baker, Lawrence Eagleburger and Warren Christopher.

He will hold the fort until a new new secretary of state takes over in January, after the presidential election in November.

webTitle: Dying boat people plucked from deserted island

fields.headline: Dying boat people plucked from deserted island
fields.trailText: Nearly 300 shipwrecked Haitians were recovering in the Bahamas yesterday after their boat ran aground on an uninhabited Caribbean island during an ill-fated bid to flee their homeland which cost 14 lives.
fields.body:
Nearly 300 shipwrecked Haitians were recovering in the Bahamas yesterday after their boat ran aground on an uninhabited Caribbean island during an ill-fated bid to flee their homeland which cost 14 lives.

A Bahamian patrol boat, HMBS Bahamas, collected the last 222 survivors off Flamingo Cay in the Bahamas' Ragged Island archipelago, on Thursday night.

A defence force spokesman described them as being in fair condition. A few hours earlier, US coast guard helicopters airlifted 65 of the most seriously ill, suffering from hypothermia and acute dehydration, to hospitals in Nassau and Georgetown. Some of the survivors airlifted to Georgetown were described as comatose and too weak to lift their heads.

"They told us that 14 people had died either during the voyage or on the island," Petty Officer Gibran Soto, of the US coast guard, said. "We are only able to confirm two deaths, of people buried on the island, but they told us that the ones who died during the voyage they buried at sea."

The shipwrecked migrants were spotted on the tiny barren island on Wednesday by the crews of three sailing boats in the area.

The castaways told their rescuers that the 50-ft wooden boat on which they had left Haiti had run aground off Flamingo Cay and broken up. According to some reports the boat's engine had broken down and the vessel had drifted for as long as six days.

It was unclear whether the migrants had been heading for the Bahamas or further, to the Florida coast.

A spokesman for the Royal Bahamas Defence Force said yesterday that the incident was the biggest shipwreck in living memory.

But it is far from an isolated incident. Illegal Haitian migrants are normally deported by the Bahamian authorities, but neither the threat of deportation nor the high risks of the Atlantic voyage has deterred thousandsfrom trying to escape deteriorating political and economic conditions.

"We are being engulfed," Raymond Farqhuarson, a defence force senior commander, told journalists. The Bahamian authorities have deported about 1,600 Haitians so far this year. On the same day that the shipwrecked migrants were discovered on Flamingo Cay, Bahamian marines were called out to assist a 45-ft Haitian sailing sloop which was taking on water. The sloop had 123 migrants aboard, including 13 children.

Over the weekend 224 Haitians were picked up off the Bahamas' Harbour island, where their boat had run aground, and are being held in a prison while an immigration detention centre is being rebuilt after hurricane damage.

Bahamian officials said the flow of Haitian migrants usually peaks at Christmas and Easter."They are probably trying to catch the Bahamas in a festive mood or find us off-guard," Vernon Burrows, the acting director of immigration, told journalists.

Some of the wealthier would-be migrants head for Florida. Fifteen Haitians were arrested on Wednesday night as they were being dropped off near Key Biscayne by a motor boat. They told the border patrol they had paid £2,500 for the trip, but will now face automatic deportation, unlike Cubans who - as a legacy of a cold war era law - are permitted to remain in the US pending an immigration hearing if they manage to reach dry land.

Immigration lawyers in Miami have pointed out that if Elian Gonzalez had been Haitian he would have been immediately returned to his homeland.

No one is sure how many Haitians disappear without trace each year attempting the perilous sea crossing. But judging by the numbers caught on the open seas or washed up on the beaches of Florida and the Bahamas, the exodus is increasing.

The swell in numbers has coincided with rising political violence in the run-up Haiti's much-delayed legislative elections. However, Carol Joseph, the director of the Haitian national migration office, insisted the wave of migration was economically motivated.

"It's a sign of economic despair," Mr Joseph said, pointing out that most of the migrants were subsistence farmers from Haiti's northwest, not from the capital Port-au-Prince, the centre of the political violence.

 In ongoing political violence, attackers armed with machetes burst into the home of a local opposition campaign director, Ducertain Armand, this week and hacked him to death, the Haitian Democratic Christian party said yesterday.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rebels threaten to kill hostages
fields.body:
Rebels threaten to kill hostages

Kidnappers will cut off the heads of the foreigners among their hostages unless foreign ambassadors mediate in talks for their release, a man claiming to be a spokesman for the Abu Sayyaf rebels told a Philippine radio station.

The 21 tourists, including 10 foreigners, were abducted in Malaysia and are now being held in the southern Philippines. Reuters, Zamboanga

Five held over internet fraud

Five people have been arrested in Moscow on charges of stealing credit card numbers from internet retailers and pocketing more than 18m roubles (about £500,000).

Police said that the gang stole the numbers of more than 5,400 cards by hacking into websites, the Itar-Tass news agency reported. AP, Moscow

Bosnian Serb denies murders

The first suspect to be indicted by the UN tribunal for former Yugoslavia, pleaded not guilty yesterday to 80 counts of war crimes including murder, torture and rape. Dragan Nikolic, a Bosnian Serb former camp commander, was arrested a week ago. Reuters, The Hague

Italian PM wins vital vote

Italy's new prime minister, Giuliano Amato, and his centre-left government won a confidence vote in the lower house yesterday.

Mr Amato's predecessor, Massimo D'Alema, resigned after his centre-left coalition fared badly in regional elections. Reuters, Rome

fields.headline: Whites get Mugabe's message
fields.standfirst:
Farmers and workers attend a rally to be lectured on the advantages of staying out of party politicsZimbabwe: special report
Zimbabwe Government
Foreign and Commonwealth Office
Movement for Democratic Change
fields.trailText: Farmers and workers attend a rally to be lectured on the advantages of staying out of party politics.
fields.body:
Word spread quickly yesterday through the Goromonzi district, about 20 miles east of Harare: all commercial farmers and their workers should attend a rally by President Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF party.

The 60 white farmers who gathered on an open field knew what the message of the rally would be: don't support the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) and you will be allowed to continue farming.

Wearing scruffy shorts, baggy shirts and floppy hats, most farmers at the rally housed Mr Mugabe's supporters on their property; some had received death threats, others had had their houses ransacked. All of them appeared worried, even frightened.

Two weeks ago and just 30 miles away, fellow farmer Dave Stevens was dragged from a police station, beaten and shot dead by Mr Mugabe's supporters. Five other farmers were beaten unconscious. The Goromonzi farmers wondered if and when such a fate would befall them.

More than 1,000 farm workers sat in a semi-circle. They had arrived on tractor trailers and many were dressed in their Sunday best, in long trousers and shirts with collars.

There was some desultory singing and sloganeering by the Zanu-PF officials. " Pamberi ne Zanu-PF! Pasi na MDC! " they shouted in Shona (Forward with Zanu-PF! Down with the MDC.) They pointed at groups of the farm labourers who were not enthusiastic and ordered them to sing and shout louder. Soon the Zanu-PF officials began speaking.

"You commercial farmers must make a decision," said Comrade Koche, the Zanu-PF district commissar, wagging his finger and swaggering towards the white farmers. "You can make a decision to be farmers and produce agriculture and make wealth for the nation. Or you can decide to be politicians allied to the MDC. It is your choice."

The white farmers looked at Comrade Koche with stony gazes, but did not protest.

The point was driven home by another party official. "You farmers must accept to redistribute your land to our war veterans and other Zimbabweans," he said. "If you want orderly change then join Zanu-PF. If you want to work for change outside the party and in the opposition, then there will be problems."

A deal has been struck between Zimbabwe's white farmers and Mr Mugabe's party. The farmers can continue to live on their farms if they do not support the MDC. Otherwise they risk the kind of violence that killed Mr Stevens and has seen hundreds of farm labourers beaten and tortured.

Similar rallies have been held across rural Zimbabwe. Farm labourers have had to hand in MDC T-shirts and are issued with Zanu-PF T-shirts with portraits of Mr Mugabe emblazoned across the chest.

webTitle: Hawaii senate legalises medical use of marijuana

fields.headline: Hawaii senate legalises medical use of marijuana
fields.trailText: Hawaii's state legislature this week became the first in the US to pass a bill legalising the medical use of marijuana.
fields.body:
Hawaii's state legislature this week became the first in the US to pass a bill legalising the medical use of marijuana.

The state's senate passed a bill by 15 votes to 10 and Hawaii's governor, Benjamin Cayetano, has indicated that he will ratify the vote. He has already expressed his support for the bill which allows patients with specified illnesses to use the drug legally.

Among those who would qualify are people suffering from Aids, cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy, and people affected by glaucoma or epilepsy. About 300 out of Hawaii's population of 1.2 million are expected to apply and qualify immediately.

The drug's supporters claim it offers more effective pain relief with fewer side-effects than many pharmaceutical drugs.

"Hawaii joins a handful of forward-thinking states that recognise the value and effectiveness of medical marijuana," said Mr Cayetano after the vote. "We look forward to recognition on a federal level to provide relief to those suffering."

Voters in five other states - California, Alaska, Oregon, Washington and Maine - have backed initiatives allowing the medical use of marijuana but they have yet to be ratified by the state legislatives. The medical profession in Hawaii was divided on the issue with nurses generally favouring the move and doctors generally opposing it.

Next month, San Francisco - at the forefront of the debate on medical marijuana - is to issue identity cards to people entitled to possess marijuana for medical use.

The cards will be proof that a licensed medical practitioner has recommended that a pa tient should use marijuana for their illness. "I would like this programme to ensure that a medical-cannabis patient is never confronted by questioning by police," said Mark Leno, a senior city official. The laminated cards will carry a photo and a serial number.

Initiatives to legalise the use of marijuana are being promoted in 11 states. In Michigan, voters will be asked to approve the personal use of marijuana by adults, if supporters can get the 300,000 signatures needed for the question to be put to the electorate.

In Alaska, voters could be asked to remove criminal and civil penalties for the possession of all kinds of hemp, including marijuana. The move would mean that marijuana was regulated in the same way as alcohol, with half an ounce taxed the same as a gallon of wine. In Oregon, a plan to allow marijuana to be sold in off licences is being promoted.

webTitle: Takeover warning as bus-fare riots kill 5 in Guatemala City

fields.headline: Takeover warning as bus-fare riots kill 5 in Guatemala City
fields.trailText: Days of protests and riots against an increase in bus fares in Guatemala City, which have left at least five people dead, have brought the threat of emergency measures and a government takeover of the transport system.
fields.body:
Days of protests and riots against an increase in bus fares in Guatemala City, which have left at least five people dead, have brought the threat of emergency measures and a government takeover of the transport system.

President Alfonso Portillo said in an emergency address that he was prepared to order a crackdown by the security forces. He told the privately owned operators to suspend the 25%-35% increase by noon yesterday, under threat of a government takeover.

Roberto Martinez, 37, a photographer on the leading newspaper Prensa Libre, was shot in the head on Thursday when two private security guards opened fire into a crowd of protesters running amok in a central Guatemala City street.

A police spokesman said that a woman and three other men died from of wounds suffered in the shooting. More than a dozen others, including two more local journalists, were hurt.

Residents said the streets were tense yesterday morning. Bus owners kept their vehicles off the streets for fear of attacks, and businesses stayed shut for fear of looting. Schools and universities suspended classes.

"Everybody is waiting to see what will happen," said Yolanda Reyes, an employee of Prensa Libre, who said that travel in the city was chaotic.

The police said that about 40% of the buses were running, charging the old fares. There is no alternative to buses for the poor, who form the majority of the city's 2m people.

The fares increase, which came into effect on Monday, raised the price of a second class class ticket to 1 quetzal (8p) and a first class fare to 1.5 quetzals.

That night university students began burning buses, and the protests soon developed into running battles with riot police and attacks on local businesses.

Throughout Thursday thousands of protesters clashed with police officers outside the municipal offices. At one point the security forces took refuge in the building.

The fatal shootings occurred in a street leading away from the city hall. The two security guards who opened fire on the crowd were arrested after an angry group gathered, reportedly threatening to take justice into their own hands.

The death of Martinez prompted a director of Prensa Libre, Gonzalo Marroquin, to accuse the national and the city authorities of allowing the dispute to get out of hand because of their political rivalry.

webTitle: US defences remain open to Russian missiles

fields.headline: US defences remain open to Russian missiles
fields.standfirst: Washington says new plan leaves mutual annihilation assured
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration has told the Kremlin that Russia will still be able to "annihilate" the United States with nuclear weapons even if it instals the "limited" national missile defence system which the White House wants to protect the country against attacks by "rogue states".
fields.body:
The Clinton administration has told the Kremlin that Russia will still be able to "annihilate" the United States with nuclear weapons even if it instals the "limited" national missile defence system which the White House wants to protect the country against attacks by "rogue states".

The assurance, remarkable in its apocalyptic frankness, is made in a document setting out in detail the government's missile defence plans, which was presented to Russian negotiators in January and published by the New York Times yesterday.

It contains seven draft protocols which Washington wants attached to the 1972 anti-ballistic-missile (ABM) treaty to allow the administration to go ahead with the limited national missile defence (NMD) system.

The issue has been at the heart of three days of talks in Washington this week between the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, and US officials.

Washington insists that the NMD is intended as a response only to threats from rogue states - which the state department normally lists as North Korea, Iraq, Iran and Libya - and that it does not constitute a military challenge to the strategic balance with Russia: a view which Moscow and many other governments continue to dispute.

"The US NMD system would not be directed against Russia and would not weaken Russia's strategic deterrence potential," the document says.

It says that even if the two countries agree to reduce their stocks of warheads to between 1,500 and 2,000, as proposed in the next phase of nuclear reductions, known as Start III, Russia will still have nothing to fear from the US missile defence programme.

"These strategic forces give each side the certain ability to carry out an annihilating counter-attack," it says.

"Forces of this size can easily penetrate a limited system of the type the United States is now developing."

The American proposals would allow Washington to keep in place the ABM treaty, which Mr Ivanov said yesterday was regarded by Russia as "a cornerstone of strategic stability", while at the same time developing and deploy ing a missile defence system which even the US admits would contravene the existing provisions of the treaty.

The US administration is pressing the Russians to set aside their anxieties about missile defence and make a limited deal with Mr Clinton rather than face the possibility that a future Republican administration would abrogate the treaty altogether and press ahead with a far more extensive system.

Mr Clinton is due to travel to Moscow in early June to meet the newly elected Russian president, Vladimir Putin, and he would dearly love to be able to return with a new arms agreement.

Washington's plans currently envisage building a new defence system with up to 100 missiles and their launchers, as well as new and updated radar systems.

The interceptor missiles, designed to hit any hostile incoming missiles aimed at any part of the US - including Hawaii and Alaska - would be stationed on Shemya island, off Alaska, to counter an attack by North Korea.

Shemya island, one of the Aleutian group, is so far west that it is one of the few parts of the United States to lie in the eastern hemisphere.

It is far closer to continental Russia than to continental United States, and significantly nearer to North Korea - and China - than it is to California.

Washington also wants to build a second phase, to include a further 100 missiles and launchers at a second site, to counter attacks on the US by Iraq and Iran.

Negotiations on this second phase would not begin until March 2001, under a new administration in Washington, the document published yesterday says.

"The US national missile defence system, which will be limited and intended to defend against several dozen long-range missiles launched by rogue states, will be incapable of threatening Russia's strategic deterrence at the level of Start II or Start III (or later)," the document says.

"We also propose steps to ensure Russia's confidence that the US system is in fact limited and deployed within the bounds of the agreed-upon terms of the amended ABM treaty," it states.

webTitle: The show must go Ron Davies

fields.headline: The show must go Ron Davies
fields.trailText: After a respectable time in the wilderness, it appears that the reputation of the man who did more than anyone to deliver the Welsh Assembly may be about to be rehabilitated, although it is debatable whether Mr Davies will see it that way.
fields.body:
It hasn't been the easiest of times for the former Welsh secretary Ron Davies. There was that incident on Clapham Common - his notorious "moment of madness" - which ended in disgrace, resignation and divorce.

Now, after a respectable time in the wilderness, it appears that the reputation of the man who did more than anyone to deliver the Welsh Assembly may be about to be rehabilitated, although it is debatable whether Mr Davies will see it that way.

The Welsh theatre group Volcano is taking its new absurdist show, appropriately called Moment of Madness, to London next month, where it will be staged in a theatre near where Davies met his downfall.

But the writer, Paul Davies - no relation - said that far from setting out to add to the agonies of the honourable member for Caerphilly, the play intends to praise and not to bury him.

"What inspired me was Ron's confession that he suffered from a medical condition where the victim is addicted to putting themselves in risky situations," he said. "I was amazed that there was such a clinical, diagnosable condition, and I thought it would be fun if four other leading Welsh figures should be suffering from it as well."

Davies is cast as a heroic revolutionary figure not unlike Lenin, who is devoted to carrying through a revolution in a reborn, independent Wales.

"Ron may not even recognise himself," said Davies the playwright. "I don't dwell too much on his misdemeanour."

Davies admits that he has based another character on Joanna Western, the controversial chief executive of the Welsh Arts Council. A coffin was symbolically delivered to her office recently after a round of grant cuts.

There was no reply yesterday from the Westminster office of Mr Davies, who did not turn up for the Cardiff premiere of the show.

Moment of Madness opens at BAC in Battersea on May 30.

webTitle: Mbeki treading softly to defuse Zimbabwe crisis

fields.headline: Mbeki treading softly to defuse Zimbabwe crisis
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: South Africa was yesterday intensifying diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis in Zimbabwe before Tuesday's Commonwealth meeting.
fields.body:
South Africa was yesterday intensifying diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis in Zimbabwe before Tuesday's Commonwealth meeting.

Following the collapse of talks in London it has been left to South Africa to take the diplomatic initiative to encourage Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, to end political violence which could spark instability, economic collapse and a flood of refugees across the region.

On Thursday South Africa's former president, Nelson Mandela, said that everything was being done behind the scenes to "cool things down". Like the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, has linked a return to law and order and the holding of free and fair elections to the procurement of more money for land reform.

But South Africa has taken a far less combative approach than Britain to try to end the violence which erupted after squatters began occupying white-owned farms, trying to influence events behind the scenes while expressing qualified support for Mr Mugabe.

After last week's meeting of southern African leaders at Victoria Falls, Mr Mbeki called Mr Mugabe a "champion of the rule of law". But privately he called on Mr Mugabe to stop the occupations, hold elections and tone down his rhetoric in return for a commitment to lobby the west for more money for land reform, and the promise of hundreds of millions of rand in loan financing.

The next day some white farmers returned to their homes. But shortly afterwards Mr Mugabe undermined the leaders' agreement when he switched the target of intimidation to black farm labourers and supporters of the opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change, five of whom were killed this week.

Mr Mbeki, whose reluctance to condemn outright Mr Mugabe has earned him criticism from some quarters at home, cancelled a state visit to Zimbabwe because he did not feel it was appropriate to arrive in the run-up to elections.

But he has generally adopted a softer stance, partly because he sympathises with the complexity of the land issue and partly because he fears isolating Mr Mugabe at this stage could trigger a region-wide crisis.

Unrest in Zimbabwe has already been held responsible for the steep decline in the value of the rand, while the South African electricity provider, Eskom, is owed about £80m because Zimbabwe has failed to pay its bill.

"Our biggest concern is that overseas investors will see this domino effect... and ask 'Is South Africa next?' " said the head of the South African chamber of businesses, Kevin Wakeford. "Whether we like it or not, Zimbabwe will have an impact on foreign perceptions. Unfortunately we can't dissociate ourselves from our neighbours."

Moreover, Zimbabwe's land reform crisis draws attention to the South African government's failure to redistribute land at home. Only 6% of land claims have been settled and less than 1% of the land has been redistributed.

Mr Mandela has insisted that there is no prospect of the Zimbabwe crisis being repeated in South Africa, but one recent opinion poll showed 54% of South Africans supporting the squatters in Zimbabwe - almost double the support in Zimbabwe itself.

South Africa is also concerned that a combination of economic collapse and political violence could push a wave of refugees, as well as economic migrants, over the border.

Zimbabwe's opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, yesterday expressed his support for Mr Mbeki's approach, saying: "The South African president has made a significant contribution to trying to resolve the situation here and we are confident that he will continue to do so. We have always favoured an African solution."

Mr Mbeki does have some leverage to encourage Mr Mugabe to comply. He could, for example, threaten to pull the plug on Zimbabwe's electricity supply unless the president makes good on the agreement made at Victoria Falls. But this is unlikely as it could trigger the very economic collapse he is attempting to avert.

That leaves diplomatic pressure, which insiders say will continue through the weekend, to persuade Mr Mugabe that continuing on his present course will end not only in pariah status for himself but will also bring hardship to the entire region.

Zimbabwe's opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, yesterday expressed his support for Mr Mbeki's approach, saying: "The South African president has made a significant contribution to trying to resolve the situation here and we are confident that he will continue to do so. We have always favoured an African solution." Mr Mbeki does have some leverage to encourage Mr Mugabe to comply. He could, for example, threaten to pull the plug on Zimbabwe's electricity supply unless the president makes good on the agreement made at Victoria Falls. But this is unlikely as it could trigger the very economic collapse he is attempting to avert. That leaves diplomatic pressure, which insiders say will continue through the weekend, to persuade Mr Mugabe that continuing on his present course will end not only in pariah status for himself but will also bring hardship to the entire region. fields.headline: Phew, what a wash-out
fields.standfirst:
Wettest April since 1829 but sun on the way
The weather: special report
fields.trailText: The Met Office has predicted sunshine and soaring temperatures for the bank holiday weekend. This will bring to an end what experts say has been the wettest April since 1829, with an average of 122mm of rain in England and Wales.
fields.body:
The Met Office has predicted sunshine and soaring temperatures for the bank holiday weekend.

This will bring to an end what experts say has been the wettest April since 1829, with an average of 122mm of rain in England and Wales.

Forecasters have earmarked central England for the best of the weekend weather with temperatures on Sunday and Monday topping 20C - six degrees higher than the seasonal average.

Although Scotland will have some rain, Met Office officials say there will not be a repeat of the downpours that caused widespread flooding across eastern Scotland.

With the prospect of improved weather, AA Roadwatch has given advance warning of congestion on coastal routes

But a spokesman said the biggest jams were expected on Monday evening with holidaymakers keen to make the most of the weather returning home at the last minute.

Last night the atmosphere at the Eurotunnel terminal in Folkestone was described as hectic with only limited availability on trains bound for France.

London is expected to see some travel disruption following warnings by police of anti-capitalist protests which culminate in a rally in Parliament Square and a mass bicycle ride on Monday.

The AA warned that protesters had kept their plans secret to maximise disruption. Rioting brought chaos to the City on June 18 last year, and trouble returned on November 30 at Euston station during a day of action against the World Trade Organisation.

One of the biggest events this time is expected to be the "guerrilla gardening" action, in which groups including the anarchist organisation Reclaim the Streets will make an attempt to cultivate Parliament Square.

webTitle: Shotgun farmer begins appeal court battle

fields.headline: Shotgun farmer begins appeal court battle
fields.standfirst: The Tony Martin murder case: special report
fields.trailText: Solicitors acting for Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer jailed for life for shooting dead a teenage burglar, have lodged an appeal against his conviction for murder.
fields.body:
Solicitors acting for Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer jailed for life for shooting dead a teenage burglar, have lodged an appeal against his conviction for murder.

In a petition faxed to the appeal court, Martin's solicitors claim that a fair trial was not possible because of the "atmosphere of intimidation of both witnesses and the jury", and that the judge failed to properly instruct the jury on several key points.

Martin was jailed for life earlier this month for the murder of Fred Barras, 16, and for wounding another burglar, Brendon Fearon, 30.

Details of the petition were posted on the solicitors' website yesterday.

In a further development, Norfolk police denied claims by Martin's legal team that two potential witnesses had complained to the police of intimidation and death threats.

A report in one newspaper yesterday claimed that two of Martin's neighbours had received death threats last autumn from people they thought to be travellers, and that as a result they had declined to give evidence.

Defence solicitor Michael Ballinger said: "One of these men was close enough to Martin to be identified, and this [the intimidation] was reported to police at the time."

Norfolk police however rejected this claim.

"Officers close to the case received no complaints of witness intimidation at any time, prior too or since the case," said a source.

Martin's solicitors also said that they may seek an injunction against Norwich crown court after receiving reports that court staff were discouraging trial witnesses and jurors from contacting the defence team.

A court official said they had not been contacted by Martin's solicitors and declined to comment further.

Earlier this week the Lord Chancellor's office said claims that jurors had been intimidated were unfounded.

Despite widespread reports that jurors had felt threatened by members of the public during the trial, no complaints had been received.

Publicist Max Clifford, who is acting on Martin's behalf without charge, has acknowledged that he helped stoke publicity for the farmer.

Support for Martin in Norfolk is still strong, and yesterday friends and supporters of the farmer were working to fortify his home, Bleak House at Emneth Hungate.

Contractors will work over the weekend fitting steel shut ters and an alarm system to the dilapidated farmhouse where Barras was killed last October.

Supporters fear the house could be the target for a revenge attack, and want to ensure that if Martin is released he will still have his home.

The work, costing £6,000, is being funded with money raised after the verdict.

A friend who visited Martin in the hospital wing at Bullingdon prison, Oxfordshire, said he was in good spirits.

"His mental state is very good but he is being kept in the hospital wing for assessment.

"Reading between the lines, it is for his own safety."

Relatives of Fred Barras, speaking for the first time since Martin's conviction, described Martin as "the devil" and condemned his image as a rural hero.

"It should never have happened," said one family member.

"That man should have kept Fred there until the police came instead of taking the law into his own hands... It has put all Gypsies in mortal fear of going near a farm."

webTitle: Bogus homebuyer with gun abducts family

fields.headline: Bogus homebuyer with gun abducts family
fields.trailText: Police were yesterday hunting a man believed to be the bogus homebuyer who abducted a family at gunpoint after keeping an appointment to look round their house.
fields.body:
Police were yesterday hunting a man believed to be the bogus homebuyer who abducted a family at gunpoint after keeping an appointment to look round their house.

Detectives want to question Peter Robert Hughes, 58, whom they describe as dangerous. They are urging the public not to approach him. He was released earlier this month after being jailed in 1994 for 10 years for a similar offence.

The incident has revived memories of the case of estate agent Suzy Lamplugh who disappeared in 1986 after making an appointment to take a man to view a house. Police said they had not ruled out a link between the two cases

Hughes is described as 5ft 9in, with greying hair in a ponytail. He has a moustache and a tuft of beard.

On Wednesday evening, a man kept an appointment at the £250,000 home of Marilyn Rowell in Horsforth, Leeds. She gave him a tour of the house while he apparently awaited his wife, supposedly staying at a nearby hotel.

Ms Rowell, 46, eventually agreed to help him find his wife. She got into the family Volvo with her children, Gabby, 11, and Gregory, eight, and their friend, Dawn Birks, to search for his wife. The man sat next to her in the passenger seat and subjected them to a 45-minute ordeal at gunpoint.

"We had driven a few yards when he suddenly pulled out this gun," said Ms Rowell. She was then forced to drive to her crystal wholesale business in Horsforth and take £60 from petty cash before taking him to a bed and breakfast in Headingley to collect his suitcase. "By this time he was getting very agitated. Suddenly he pointed the gun down and it went off. He was so highly strung I thought he might shoot us all," she said.

"I just cannot sleep because all I can see is his face."

The family were dropped off at Burley railway station in Leeds while the man escaped with their car.

Asked about links with the Suzy Lamplugh murder, Detective Inspector Steve Payne of West Yorkshire police said he was not ruling out anything and would be contacting other police forces. "We believe the man is dangerous and appeal to the public not to approach him," he said.

"The man we would like to question is known to us as Peter Robert Hughes, but we also believe he uses the name of Bob Cahill. He has connections in London and Surrey."

He said the family's white Volvo 940 GL estate car, registration J629 MRT, was missing.

Following the disappearance in 1986 of Ms Lamplugh, whose body was never found, concerns about the safety of estate agents emerged again in 1992 when Birmingham estate agent Stephanie Slater was kidnapped by Michael Sams. He was later sentenced to life for the murder of Julie Dart.

Suzy Lamplugh's mother, Diana, founder of the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, said: "The estate agents should have been there, they should have checked out the man's background and found out exactly who he was." But Mrs Lamplugh believes Hughes may be too old to have been involved in the murder of her daughter.

David Maltby, managing director of Whitegates estate agents, which arranged the viewing, said: "We always offer to accompany clients to viewings. We take a telephone number and address and we check it out before we arrange a viewing. If we are suspicious, we will arrange for two people to show them around."

He said the company would be reviewing its security procedures.

fields.headline: Nintendo accused of price-fixing
fields.trailText: Nintendo video games fans have been systematically ripped off by the Japanese company and its sole UK distributor John Menzies, which have been operating an illegal price-fixing cartel for at least five years, the European Commission alleged yesterday.
fields.body:
Nintendo video games fans have been systematically ripped off by the Japanese company and its sole UK distributor John Menzies, which have been operating an illegal price-fixing cartel for at least five years, the European Commission alleged yesterday.

A subsidiary of Edinburgh-based John Menzies called The Games has, the commission claims, deliberately conspired to prevent Nintendo products being imported into the UK at low prices.

A five-year investigation by the commission revealed that prices for Nintendo products can vary by as much as 100% within Europe. UK consumers could, for example, be paying twice as much as their Italian counterparts.

Nintendo, the second largest producer of video games in the world, stands accused of operating similar "cartel-like" practices in at least eight other European countries.

The allegations centre on the popular Nintendo 64 games consoles and the pocket versions called Game Boys, to gether with the accompanying games cartridges.

The N64 may sell for £64.99 now but at the height of its popularity it retailed for £400, while games can still cost up to £50 apiece. The commission's allegations, if proven, could be damaging for Nintendo, which is planning to launch its new games console, codenamed Dolphin, next year.

They could also cost the companies concerned dearly, since the commission could technically fine them as much as 10% of their global annual turnover. Nintendo's turnover in 1998 was some £2.4bn, while the comparable figure for John Menzies was around £1.2bn.

Nintendo and its European distributors now have two months to put together a written defence and can also opt to request a special hearing to plead their case.

A John Menzies spokesman confirmed yesterday that the allegations had been received in writing. He refused to comment further, however. Calls to Nintendo's European headquarters in Frankfurt went unanswered.

fields.headline: Longbridge: Phoenix or ashes?
fields.standfirst:
Uncertainty will damage BMW

BMW Group
Alchemy Partners
Rover Cars
fields.trailText: BMW's exit strategy from Rover is a mess. The deal with Alchemy has collapsed, and the only other offer on the table is the bid led by former Rover executive John Towers, about which - at the risk of understatement - the German car maker is on the cold side of lukewarm.
fields.body:
BMW's exit strategy from Rover is a mess. The deal with Alchemy has collapsed, and the only other offer on the table is the bid led by former Rover executive John Towers, about which - at the risk of understatement - the German car maker is on the cold side of lukewarm.

Whether BMW can strike a deal offering a future for Longbridge or whether it will have to close the plant down will be decided during the next month which, even allowing for £2m a day losses, might seem rather hasty.

Either way the continuing uncertainty will reflect badly on BMW. At present its approach can be most kindly described as dithering.

The trade and industry select committee hit the nail on the head earlier this month when it criticised the German group for "the manner of its disposal of Rover on grounds of incompetence and excessive secrecy".

If the endgame gets any messier - and more costly in terms of jobs, not only at Rover but at components suppliers - the criticisms will grow sharper still, especially if BMW is seen to have been in any way at fault over the breakdown of the Alchemy deal.

Given BMW's continued involvement in the British car industry - it is at present looking for a new home for Rolls-Royce - it has some serious bridge-building to do.

But although the ongoing saga is a painful embarrassment to BMW and, despite yesterday's apparent sense of relief in some quarters a continuing cause of concern for the thousands of workers whose jobs hang in the balance, the government must wish as fervently as anyone else that Rover's future was in some way settled.

As long as the drama continues to unfold it will prove a constant reminder of the problems facing UK manufacturing industry. Whatever difficulties Rover had - and there were plenty - they have been compounded by the strength of the pound. As long as BMW is on the hook the government, too, will be wriggling.

End of an era

Malaysia's Mahathir Mohamad could be forgiven a quiet chuckle. So, too, could John Major and Norman Lamont. George Soros, the man who helped blow sterling out of the exchange rate mechanism in 1992 and whom Mahathir blamed for the Asian financial crisis five years later, is having to bow to the judgment of the markets.

With his Quantum Fund down 20% this year Mr Soros has decided to "restructure". Big hedge funds are not the best way to make money, he told shareholders. Smaller, nimbler, funds are to be the order of the day.

Now Mr Soros has decided that waving billions at the markets is not the way to behave any longer there are those - himself included - who talk of the end of an era. Others will savour the spectacle of a humbler George Soros.

But before the schadenfreude takes over, it is worth taking a moment to reflect. Mr Soros has not always made the correct calls. Black Monday in 1987 was hardly a shining episode, and there were heavy losses on the yen in 1994. Yet overall he has a pretty good track record, so when he talks about markets becoming "extremely unstable" and about the "historical measures of value" no longer applying it is probably worth taking notice.

Money talks

Standard Life has an uphill battle ahead if it is shoo off the carpetbaggers urging it to float on the stock market.

Scott Bell, the managing director and lifelong Standard Life employee, knows the core of the struggle will be long term rationale over short term greed.

He can argue powerfully that he and his team have been able to develop Standard Life's business more efficiently than a public company because he has £10bn of embedded capital free of charge as he has no shareholders to reward with dividends.

Unlike other some other mutual life insurers that have cast off their status, Standard Life is strong - one of the most robust in the world. It is able claim a top notch triple-A rating.

If the demutalisation were merely about money Mr Bell should be one of the strongest proponents - in the great world of the plc he and his board would be able to command vast awards of share options to puff up their wallets before retirement. True, there is probably an element of pride involved, given that the demutualisation vote is being forced on Standard Life, but this seems more than a face-saving exercise.

Mr Bell and his team appear to believe in their cause and are embarking on what promises to be one of the most professional anti-carpetbagging campaigns ever waged. Policyholders should listen hard and scrutinise the comparisions of "before" and "after", and should certainly not be in any rush to take the money.

webTitle: Toy shop bans Pokemon after raiders grab cards

fields.headline: Toy shop bans Pokemon after raiders grab cards
fields.trailText: "This Pokémon thing has got out of hand," said a toy shop owner yesterday after a gang broke into her store, ignored the expensive designer toys and grabbed her entire stock of Pokémon cards.
fields.body:
"This Pokémon thing has got out of hand," said a toy shop owner yesterday after a gang broke into her store, ignored the expensive designer toys and grabbed her entire stock of Pokémon cards.

Rachel Cardwell, owner of Asnew Toys and Togs in Staple Hill, Bristol, said she would no longer stock the cards after the break-in last Sunday. The thieves ignored Beanie Babies and the latest Toy Story 2 merchandise. They took about £300 worth of the cards, based on the Nintendo game, which had been hidden under the counter.

"I can't believe they made such a mess of my shop for those cards," she said.

"They walked straight past some of the most expensive items."

The thieves are believed to be small because they appeared to have entered the shop by crawling through a small panel in the bottom of the door which they had knocked through.

 Two 13-year-old boys, who cannot be named for legal reasons, appeared at Swindon youth court yesterday charged with street robbery of Pokémon cards. It was alleged they had taken 54 cards worth £15 from two 10-year-old boys in Stratton, Swindon, at knifepoint.

In Cowling, North Yorkshire, parents are being invited to a self-help night to learn about the Pokémon phenomenon.

webTitle: Fall in output triggers call for interest rate standstill

fields.headline: Fall in output triggers call for interest rate standstill
fields.trailText: Manufacturers slashed output in the first three months of the year, causing a dramatic slowdown in the pace of economic growth, government figures revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Manufacturers slashed output in the first three months of the year, causing a dramatic slowdown in the pace of economic growth, government figures revealed yesterday.

The damage to exporters, following the rise of sterling, sparked calls for a freeze on interest rate rises.

The economy expanded by just 0.4% in the first three months of the year after growing by 0.8% in the final quar ter of 1999, according to figures released by the office for national statistics. This is the slowest rate of growth since the first quarter of last year and means the economy is now growing at below its long run average rate.

The ONS said its early estimates suggested that industrial output had shrunk by around 0.5% over the quarter. The services sector grew by 0.8% over the same period.

Yesterday's figures highlight the dilemma the Bank of Eng land faces with the two parts of the economy taking different paths. While manufacturing contracted, the service sector is still expanding at a pace which is too fast for some members of the monetary policy committee.

Industry leaders said yesterday's data underlined why the Bank must not raise interest rates next week. "The message the Bank must send to the markets is that rates have peaked," said the British Chambers of Commerce.

The ONS said that rapid growth in high- tech manufacturing which had kept industry out of recession for most of last year had now slowed. Last month's figures showed that 11 out of 14 sectors in manufacturing were cutting output for most of last year.

Analysts expect that next Thursday's rates decision will be finely balanced despite yesterday's numbers. Some members of the MPC are worried that spiralling pay pressures may spill over into the rest of the economy, pushing inflation above the Government's 2.5% target.

Andrew Milligan of Morley Fund Management said the figures were likely to encourage some members to vote to leave rates unchanged.

Neil Parker, senior European economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland, said: "To raise rates now would be a very, very bad public relations exercise." The data showed the extent to which the strength of the pound against the euro was damaging manufacturing.

"I think this data is very concerning. One can only say that it argues for the Bank of England to hold off raising interest rates again," he said.

A further rate rise would boost sterling's already giddy levels against the currencies of the UK's main trading partners. On Thursday the euro sank to a record low against the pound, taking sterling to the equivalent of DM3.40, its highest level for 14 years.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Star Wars strikes again
fields.body:
Star Wars strikes again

Character Group yesterday became the second British company to fall victim to the menace of Star Wars when it issued its second profits warning in four months. The merchandiser said demand for products from the science fiction film had been significantly less than expected. The news wiped 26% off the value of Character shares and came in the wake of a similar warning from publisher Dorling Kindersley, which recently admitted it had over-ordered Star Wars books. Character had hoped the recent video release of the Star Wars film The Phantom Menace would rekindle demand for products, but this failed to materialise. Its shares yesterday hit a new low of 88.5p, valuing the group at £20m.

Ericsson sales rise 42%

Ericsson, the Swedish mobile phone manufacturer, yesterday provided further evidence of its recovery with a 42% rise in sales and a near fourfold increase in profits during the first quarter. The company said it had shifted 10.5m handsets, achieving sales of £4.2bn and pre-tax profits of £630m. Last year the company suffered a succession of profit warnings, the departure of its chief executive and a worldwide restructuring which led to thousands of job losses.

Stepstone loses euro 18.3m

Stepstone, the online recruitment firm, yesterday announced a jump in first quarter revenues but dramatically higher losses.

The Anglo-Norwegian business, which was listed in Oslo and London in March, recorded a net loss of euro 18.3m compared with a loss of euro 1.7m for the same period in 1999. But chief executive Giles Clarke said a sharp jump in revenues from euro 2.1m to euro 7.3m made StepStone the largest player in Europe.

He warned that losses were likely to widen as StepStone continued to invest heavily as part of plans to expand in Britain, Germany and France and move into Finland, Spain and Austria.

Mr Clarke is also looking at adding life-long learning products and hopes to carry the European Commission's online job advertising.

Bupa buys 21 new hospitals

Bupa, the private health care provider, has agreed to buy Britain's fourth largest operator of commercial hospitals, Community Hospitals, for £230m, it emerged yesterday. After several weeks of talks Community Hospitals has recommended a 650p a share cash bid. The deal adds 21 hospitals providing cosmetic surgery and acute medicine to Bupa's existing 37-strong facility network.

fields.headline: Editorial chief leaves thestreet.co.uk
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Thestreet.co.uk yesterday parted company with editor-in-chief, Martin Baker, less than three months after the launch of the online financial news service.
fields.body:
Thestreet.co.uk yesterday parted company with editor-in-chief, Martin Baker, less than three months after the launch of the online financial news service.

Claudia Jay, the managing director, said Mr Baker has left by "mutual agreement" and denied rumours of poor morale at the organisation. His departure follows the resignation of Guy Dresser, the former City editor of the Birmingham Post, who is joining Sunday Business.

Hugh Fraser, who joined from BBC Worldwide, has also left the company.

Ms Jay said: "This is an incredibly competitive market for financial journalists but the business is on track and we are feeling very confident."

She said registrations had reached about 70,000, with page impressions running at 1m a week.

Mr Baker previously worked at The Independent and The Times, and was associate editor of Sunday Business just before joining TheStreet.

The online service is one of a clutch launched in the UK to target private investors.

Backing of £10.6m has been provided by a group of investors including Chase Capital Partners and Barclays Private Equity. The US parent, TheStreet.com, is not putting in any cash but retains more than half of the business.

The promise of wealth for journalists who accepted stock options in the company when they joined has been depressed by the poor performance of its US affiliate. Shares in the US parent, which traded at up to $70 over the past year, are now changing hands for about $6. Yesterday the company reported a first-quarter net loss of $13.88m (£9m), up from $7.17m in the year-earlier period.

Mr Baker will not be replaced directly, with City editor Nils Pratley - who also joined from Sunday Business - and news editor Ian Griffiths taking responsibility for editorial content.

webTitle: Facing up to a new D-Day

fields.headline: Facing up to a new D-Day
fields.standfirst: Blue Circle
fields.trailText: Lafarge may not have been in a position to make its £3.65bn bid for Blue Circle Industries had it not been for the efforts of its intended prey in 1944. Blue Circle provided the cement for the 3m tons of concrete used to build the artificial harbours towed to France after D-Day to help keep the invasion force supplied with men and materials.
fields.body:
Lafarge may not have been in a position to make its £3.65bn bid for Blue Circle Industries had it not been for the efforts of its intended prey in 1944. Blue Circle provided the cement for the 3m tons of concrete used to build the artificial harbours towed to France after D-Day to help keep the invasion force supplied with men and materials.

The Blue Circle brand name was the idea of General Critchley, a Canadian-born soldier who was the youngest brigadier general during the first world war. It was one of the first suggestions he made on joining the board of Associated Portland Cement Manufacturers, the unwieldy group that had sprung from the 1900 merger of 27 cement makers.

When Critchley arrived, APCM's constituent companies were still competing against each other by selling cement under their original brand names. He recommended the adoption of a single brand - Blue Circle.

Cement has been around for centuries. But Portland cement, so called because it was similar to Portland stone in colour, was patented by Joseph Aspdin, a secretive Leeds bricklayer, in 1824. His son's Kent cement company was part of the APCM merger. It had supplied cement to Brunel for his Thames Tunnel.

Most of the firms which merged to form APCM were situated on the banks of the Thames and Medway rivers in Kent where the basic raw materials, chalk and clay, were readily available and where coke for the kilns could be brought in by barge.

The driving force behind the creation of APCM was Henry Osborne O'Hagan, a colourful financier and share pusher, best known for floating tram companies, colleries and breweries. But the share sale was a disaster -not least because of a stock market panic.

The shares fell to a fraction of the £10 offer price, even though the group controlled nearly 70% of Britain's cement manufacturing capacity.

The original 27-man board included 11 managing directors, all of whom were prepared to fight the corner of the firm they came from.

The makers of Blue Circle cement had never been afraid to throw their weight about. The company, soon known in the trade as "the combine", be came involved in numerous price cartels. But its product was widely used.

In 1906, its Gillingham plant sent cement to San Francisco to help rebuild the city after the devastating earthquake. Cement from APCM companies was used to build the Forth Bridge and the Eddystone lighthouse.

Wartime requests for a camouflage paint led to the devel opment of Snowcem. This was followed by Sandtex, though the textured paint was improved later by taking over a superior competitor.

When APCM was formed, the men who dug clay from the saltings and loaded it onto barges were paid 4d a ton for the backbreaking work. They were regarded as being relatively well paid. More than 70 years later the company was accused of paying below poverty line wages to black employees in South Africa.

APCM was floated on the London stock market in 1953, becoming one of the original members of the FT 30 ordinary share index, the key market barometer until the intro duction of the FTSE 100. It became Blue Circle Industries in 1978, dropping its cumbersome title in favour of its long standing trade mark. It started to expand overseas and diversified.

In 1994 Blue Circle returned to its north Kent roots to co-develop the Bluewater regional shopping centre, one of Europe's largest retail and leisure projects.

Blue Circle's chances of remaining independent are now finely balanced. Lafarge increased its bid last week and secured a bridgehead by buying 20% of Blue Circle shares. The French group will be as hard to dislodge as the Allied troops on D-Day.

webTitle: Serb refugees resort to holiday homes in Montenegro

fields.headline: Serb refugees resort to holiday homes in Montenegro
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Milena Radevic sits on the terrace of her room in the holiday resort, dressed as always in black. The buildings are dilapidated, and this is no holiday. She and 30 other families of Serb refugees from Kosovo have been squatting in the forlorn seaside camp for the past three weeks, since they were evicted from a nearby hotel when its owners, Elektro-Serbia, obtained a court order.
fields.body:
Milena Radevic sits on the terrace of her room in the holiday resort, dressed as always in black. The buildings are dilapidated, and this is no holiday. She and 30 other families of Serb refugees from Kosovo have been squatting in the forlorn seaside camp for the past three weeks, since they were evicted from a nearby hotel when its owners, Elektro-Serbia, obtained a court order.

Montenegro has one of the most stunning coastlines on the Adriatic. Until 10 years ago it thronged with holidaymakers from all over Yugoslavia and western Europe.

But the four Yugoslav wars and the collapse of the Balkan economies have sapped its life. Luxury hotels stand closed and shuttered.

Even the Belgrade middle class do not come in sufficient numbers to warrant reopening these concrete and glass palaces of despair, except for a few weeks at the height of summer.

The lower end of the market is not doing much better, and Rooms to Let signs hang on the balconies of villas which in the 1980s would have been booked solid.

A few companies still keep holiday homes and hostels for their staff, in the communist tradition of Eastern Europe and the Balkans. So it made sense that when Serbs were forced to flee Kosovo last summer by the returning Kosovan Albanians, several thousand went to the Montenegrin coast.

To Serbs and Gypsies from the cities of Pec, Decani, and Djakovica in western Kosovo, Montenegro was nearer than Serbia itself. Some knew the coast from better days. They occupied state-owned holiday homes, hoping to be welcomed by their government.

"We went to the hotel in Becici because Elektro-Serbia is a company in Kraljevo, a town in central Serbia," Mrs Radevic says.

"They took us to court, but eviction was delayed five or six times while we argued against it. When we were thrown out, we slept for five days in the street and in our cars before coming here. This camp is owned by a Serbian company from Kosovo."

Her black clothes are a reminder of a double bereavement. "I will tell you my story. It is just one that a thousand other Serb mothers could tell you," she says as she launches into her narrative.

Her 25-year-old son was one of six people killed when unknown terrorists, assumed to be Albanian, threw a grenade into a crowded cafe in Pec in December 1988. In June last year, when Italian soldiers from Nato arrived, her husband was abducted by Albanians in front of her eyes, and has not been seen since.

The illegal occupation of holiday homes is an embarrassment to the Montenegrin government, which does not want to evict squatters.

"We have to observe the law," says Djordjije Scepanovic, the refugee commissioner. "The people moved in without our agreement, but the owners have to go to court and follow the correct procedure. In some cases we offered to pay the displaced people's costs as well as rent, but the owners did not always accept."

In Sutomore, the Serbian company which owns the Hotel Zlati bar signed a deal with the refugee commissioner last week. About 250 Serbs and Gypsies have lived in the building for months. They get food from the International Committee for the Red Cross and an Italian charity.

"We will pay the Serbian company four deutschmarks per person per day," Mr Scepanovic says.

"For a family of four that works out at DM480 (£160) a month, which is a lot when you realise that the average monthly salary in Montenegro is only about DM170.

The seaside refugees are the most expensive the Montenegrin government has to cope with. Fortunately, about three-quarters of the 31,000 refugees from Kosovo are living with relatives or in private rented flats, where the UN High Commissioner for Refugees helps. The UNHCR's office refuses to become involved while legal disputes are unresolved.

Besides the Kosovans, Montenegro has 28,000 refugees from the wars in Croatia and Bosnia, making 10% of the population of 600,000 asylum seekers: a proportion which puts richer countries in northern Europe to shame.

webTitle: The pipe dreams of currency traders

fields.headline: The pipe dreams of currency traders
fields.trailText: The ECB finally managed to get internal consensus together this week and raised rates to 3.75% from 3.5%. Essentially the bank was in a lose lose situation. If they raised rates it could be seen as panic induced by the weakness of the euro. A decision not to raise rates would have been interpreted as central bank indifference to the currency and called into question the ECB's anti-inflation credentials, given that March saw Euroland inflation exceed the ECB's year-on-year upper limit of 2%.
fields.body:
The ECB finally managed to get internal consensus together this week and raised rates to 3.75% from 3.5%. Essentially the bank was in a lose lose situation. If they raised rates it could be seen as panic induced by the weakness of the euro. A decision not to raise rates would have been interpreted as central bank indifference to the currency and called into question the ECB's anti-inflation credentials, given that March saw Euroland inflation exceed the ECB's year-on-year upper limit of 2%.

The move did nothing to alleviate the pressure on the beleaguered currency. Why are investors so anti-euro? Surprisingly, we haven't yet heard the French complain of a British conspiracy to undermine the currency, but surely that can only be a matter of days away.

One of the key problems for the euro is that everybody has an opinion and a desire to express it. Euroland politicians and ECB officials have regularly clashed in public over statements on the "correct" level of the euro. Even within the ECB there are tensions over who should say what with regard to the currency. This lack of clarity over the official line has undermined the infant unit.

From an economic point of view a weak euro is just what the doctor ordered. It helps to underpin the incipient recovery within the Eurozone (as evidenced by German export orders which are up 16% year-on-year), and shouldn't really be massively inflationary given the slack within the economies of Europe - after all Eurozone unemployment still stands at 9.5%. Until we see faster growth in the Eurozone, the euro looks fated to remain out of favour.

But the euro cannot be looked at in isolation. The flip side of its weakness has been sterling and dollar strength. According to the Bank of England index, sterling is at a 15-year high, while using the Fed's nominal measure of the value of the US dollar, the greenback is close to all-time highs.

Economists are generally unhelpful when it comes to forecasting future exchange rates. The standard model they use goes by the grand name of uncovered interest parity (UIP). Say UK one-year interest rates are 7%, and Eurozone one-year interest rates are 4.5%, the UIP model says that sterling is expected to depreciate by 2.5% over the year. If that didn't happen you could make money by borrowing in euros and depositing in sterling.

The goods news for you and the bad news for economists is - in general you can! UIP simply doesn't work. In fact the evidence actually shows that the opposite of UIP tends to occur - that is, currencies with higher interest rates tend to rise.

So when economists stand up and say that sterling is some 30% overvalued, it is not terribly helpful. Just because a currency is called overvalued by economists doesn't mean that it is about to collapse, much to the chagrin of the bears.

Those who have continually attacked the US stock markets valuations have often cited a dollar collapse as the trigger for an equity market crash. The US is borrowing about $1bn a day from the rest of the world - what happens when overseas investors stop funding the US consumption habit? The dollar would collapse, imported inflation would soar, bond yields would rise dramatically, consumption and investment would suffer a major setback, plunging the US economy into a recession. The stock market would get a double whammy - rising bond yields undermining valuations and an appalling earnings outlook. This is the stuff of nightmares.

Thankfully, investors can rely on the Sandman to make them sleep tight. Back in 1985, Paul Krugman devised a sustainability test to see if a currency was overvalued. The test essentially came down to a race between improvement in the trade deficit (as the currency declines) against the increasing burden of interest payments on external debt.

Investors need not worry about the details, but they should be able to take comfort from the results. Applying the Krugman test to both sterling and the greenback shows both currencies can sustain the levels they are at given current real interest rate differentials. Stories of the impending collapse of both the US dollar and sterling are the pipe dreams of market bears.

Of course, currencies and exchange rates are not the exclusive province of fund managers and investors. They matter in the real world too, and UK manufacturing will have to come to terms with the strength of sterling. The simple truth is that current trends in the exchange rate markets look set to continue for some time.

James Montier is global strategist at Albert E Sharp Securities
