One of the key problems for the euro is that everybody has an opinion and a desire to express it. Euroland politicians and ECB officials have regularly clashed in public over statements on the "correct" level of the euro. Even within the ECB there are tensions over who should say what with regard to the currency. This lack of clarity over the official line has undermined the infant unit. From an economic point of view a weak euro is just what the doctor ordered. It helps to underpin the incipient recovery within the Eurozone (as evidenced by German export orders which are up 16% year-on-year), and shouldn't really be massively inflationary given the slack within the economies of Europe - after all Eurozone unemployment still stands at 9.5%. Until we see faster growth in the Eurozone, the euro looks fated to remain out of favour. But the euro cannot be looked at in isolation. The flip side of its weakness has been sterling and dollar strength. According to the Bank of England index, sterling is at a 15-year high, while using the Fed's nominal measure of the value of the US dollar, the greenback is close to all-time highs. Economists are generally unhelpful when it comes to forecasting future exchange rates. The standard model they use goes by the grand name of uncovered interest parity (UIP). Say UK one-year interest rates are 7%, and Eurozone one-year interest rates are 4.5%, the UIP model says that sterling is expected to depreciate by 2.5% over the year. If that didn't happen you could make money by borrowing in euros and depositing in sterling. The goods news for you and the bad news for economists is - in general you can! UIP simply doesn't work. In fact the evidence actually shows that the opposite of UIP tends to occur - that is, currencies with higher interest rates tend to rise. So when economists stand up and say that sterling is some 30% overvalued, it is not terribly helpful. Just because a currency is called overvalued by economists doesn't mean that it is about to collapse, much to the chagrin of the bears. Those who have continually attacked the US stock markets valuations have often cited a dollar collapse as the trigger for an equity market crash. The US is borrowing about $1bn a day from the rest of the world - what happens when overseas investors stop funding the US consumption habit? The dollar would collapse, imported inflation would soar, bond yields would rise dramatically, consumption and investment would suffer a major setback, plunging the US economy into a recession. The stock market would get a double whammy - rising bond yields undermining valuations and an appalling earnings outlook. This is the stuff of nightmares. Thankfully, investors can rely on the Sandman to make them sleep tight. Back in 1985, Paul Krugman devised a sustainability test to see if a currency was overvalued. The test essentially came down to a race between improvement in the trade deficit (as the currency declines) against the increasing burden of interest payments on external debt. Investors need not worry about the details, but they should be able to take comfort from the results. Applying the Krugman test to both sterling and the greenback shows both currencies can sustain the levels they are at given current real interest rate differentials. Stories of the impending collapse of both the US dollar and sterling are the pipe dreams of market bears. Of course, currencies and exchange rates are not the exclusive province of fund managers and investors. They matter in the real world too, and UK manufacturing will have to come to terms with the strength of sterling. The simple truth is that current trends in the exchange rate markets look set to continue for some time. James Montier is global strategist at Albert E Sharp Securities

fields.headline: Beryl McBurnie
fields.standfirst: Dance pioneer embodied the art of Trinidad - and understudied Carmen Miranda
fields.trailText: In 1948, while visiting Trinidad, the great American actor, singer and activist Paul Robeson laid the cornerstone of the Little Carib Theatre. It was a place and a movement whose driving force came from Beryl McBurnie, who has died aged 85. Making a reality of the Little Carib was to occupy McBurnie, educationalist, choreographer and pioneer of Caribbean dance, for the next three decades.
fields.body:
In 1948, while visiting Trinidad, the great American actor, singer and activist Paul Robeson laid the cornerstone of the Little Carib Theatre. It was a place and a movement whose driving force came from Beryl McBurnie, who has died aged 85. Making a reality of the Little Carib was to occupy McBurnie, educationalist, choreographer and pioneer of Caribbean dance, for the next three decades.

The theatre, which she had initiated in her mother's backyard in Woodbrook, Port of Spain, was part of the new movement that flowed through her homeland even before full independence in 1962. McBurnie embodied the spirit of a Trinidad and Tobago intent on promoting its own culture at a time when music, dance and drama were seen as coming from other countries. Nothing Caribbean was respected, or acknowledged.

Born in Woodbrook, she was educated at Tranquillity Girls' Intermediate school in Trinidad, and the Trinidad teachers' training college. She began teaching, but within a couple of years realised that her overwhelming interest was in Caribbean folk dance.

So McBurnie started saving, and, backed by her family and friends, headed for New York, where she enrolled in the Academy of Allied Arts's Evelyn Ellis School of Drama at Colombia University. There she was taught by Martha Graham - and first met Paul Robeson.

It was the late 1930s, and she also got a Broadway job, understudying for Carmen Miranda, who was then at the peak of her fame. "La Belle Rosette" as McBurnie was billed, even took the Brazilian star's role for a time.

In 1940, she returned to Trinidad and it was then that I first met her. At home, she launched a group of amateurs - civil servants, teachers and clerks - in the highly successful A Trip Through The Tropics. In those days Trinidad's folk dance and steel bands were frowned on as the stuff of the underclass. McBurnie, out on a limb, saw the recognition of the two indigenous art forms as a step towards national pride. In that spirit she went on to promote the Invaders steel band. She taught dance, but there was little money and still no fixed venue for the Little Carib. Teaching took place in open air, on the family patio, under the coconut trees.

In 1948, the Trinidadian actor and singer Edric Connor came back from England, where plans for the Festival of Britain were taking shape. With his encouragement, she helped the Trinidad All Steel Orchestra perform at the 1951 Festival.

In 1952, McBurnie performed in Paris, and her Little Carib company went to Puerto Rico on its first overseas tour. In 1955, it visited Jamaica as part of the island's tercentenary celebrations.

The story of the company in those times was of small events, and many of them - but in 1957, she and the company were invited to present a lecture demonstration to a summer school in creative arts at what was then the University College of the West Indies in Mona, Jamaica. It was an acknowledgement of the group's status, and led to McBurnie lecturing at universities all over the United States, laying foundations for the international acceptance of Caribbean dance.

In 1971, McBurnie made her first trip to Britain. She was raising money to complete the building of the Little Carib Theatre. The London-based Trinidadian carnivalist Peter Minshall designed and costumed a spectacular fundraising show, which she directed, at the Commonwealth Institute.

Back home, McBurnie enlisted the help of Trinidadian architect Colin Laird, and it was he who finally designed the Little Carib - for a song. In 1975, 27 years after Robeson's foundation stone, the theatre finally opened.

McBurnie's dream, realised, became the focus for Trinidad's dance and drama. It was there that many of Nobel prize winner Derek Walcott's early works were premiered. He was just one of her many supporters. Another was Rex Nettleford, vice-chancellor of the University of the West Indies. McBurnie, he said, showed that Caribbean dance had its own inner logic, consistency and aesthetics.

Generous, unselfish, McBurnie had a great humility of spirit. Last October, Geraldine Connor's Carnival Messiah went on at at the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds. Based on Handel's Messiah, it married two great traditions, from Europe and the Caribbean. It was inspired, said Connor, by the work of McBurnie.

She did not marry because she was married to the theatre.

 Beryl McBurnie, dance pioneer, born November 2 1914; died March 30 2000

fields.headline: Tim Stead
fields.standfirst: Wood artist whose patrons included galleries, castles, cathedrals and the Pope
fields.trailText: The wood artist Tim Stead, who has died aged 48 of pneumonia following multiple myeloma, believed that the barriers between art, craft and design are artificial and limiting, and that the utilitarian could be beautiful and as expressive of ideas as fine art.
fields.body:
The wood artist Tim Stead, who has died aged 48 of pneumonia following multiple myeloma, believed that the barriers between art, craft and design are artificial and limiting, and that the utilitarian could be beautiful and as expressive of ideas as fine art.

Working in the Borders of Scotland, his projects have ranged from high art to public seating, sometimes combined. Largely unrecognised by the English art world, his work sits in thousands of homes throughout Europe.

Stead made furniture for galleries, castles, cathedrals and even for Pope John Paul II for his visit to Murrayfield in 1981, yet it was the open intuitive, untutored response of ordinary people that most nourished him. People delighted in his work's warm honesty and wanted to live with it.

Three of his most powerful pieces relate to architecture. The rood screen and furniture for the North Sea Oil Industries Memorial Chapel in Aberdeen, was commissioned in 1989. The initial letters of the woods used in the chair backs spell out the simple but poignant "We remember yew".

For the Gallery of Modern Art in Glasgow, opened in 1996, Stead made Peephole, an extraordinary tiny space from which one could spy into the gallery below. This cave, whale belly, tomb or hidey hole has a mysterious, unnerving effect on the receptive occupant.

For the Millennium Clock Tower in the Royal Museum, Edinburgh, Stead collaborated with Edouard Bersudsky of Sharmanka Kinetic Theatre, Annica Sandström of Lindean Mill Glass, and Jurgen Tübbecke, of Peebles. Its hourly eruption of movement, sound and magic has proved an exciting and hugely popular event.

Born in Helsby, Cheshire, the youngest of four brothers, Stead was a natural anarchist and a sociable loner. Rebellious at boarding school, The Leys in Cambridge, he achieved first-class honours in fine art at Trent Polytechnic through a clarity of vision and a passionate dedication to unfashionably palpable, narrative work. There Stead discovered wood with the unstinting support of technician Frank Lindlay. In 1975, Stead did postgraduate work at the School of Art in Glasgow, where he met his life partner, Maggy Lenert, a student from Luxembourg, the day before she was about to leave Scotland.

Although Stead's early years in Scotland were single-mindedly devoted to furniture, it was "sculpture in disguise". Through respect for the environment he committed himself to native timbers, specialising in elm so heavily burred that other furniture makers rejected it. Inevitably, the work spawned a host of borrowers from, and imitators of, his style: yet Stead's work is unmistakable: quality will out.

He read widely: genetics, cosmology, archaeology, poetry. Complementing this was his easy way with people, liberally laced with humour but masked a little by shyness and a disdain of small talk.

Following his 1993 Botanic Ash exhibition in Edinburgh, illness increasingly denied him heavy work. Sidestepping, Stead was instrumental in founding the Woodschool in Monteviot, where skilled graduates could learn to design around timber in a sympathetic environment.

Stead extended his exploration of the world through digital photography - the immediacy of which suited his impatience with process and bureaucracy - which he was assembling into a book, with his own prose poems.

Stead paid back some hundred fold his depletion of tree stocks by replanting and founding Borders Community Woodlands. In recognition of his work for the millennium forest of Scotland Tim was awarded an MBE in the New Year honours.

Stead's life and work manifested an integration that defies division: furniture, sculpture, photographs, poems, late nights around the dining-table, each were part of the same life that he grabbed with both hands, wringing out its very essence.

Maggy, their son and daughter, and his workshop team are determined to continue with production, maintaining the highest standards and fidelity to Stead's principle of permitting the wood to speak of its own nature and history. A mighty tree has been felled before its time: but Stead planted seeds for more than trees.

 Tim (Richard Timothy) Stead, wood artist, born March 27 1952; died April 21 2000

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: Gloucestershire
fields.body:
While the rest of the family snoozes, I sneak out of our holiday cottage for a dawn walk. The steep sides of the Wye Valley are cloaked in ancient woodland. Their inaccessibility for both man and machine has protected them from clearance and agricultural improvement. The need for hurdles and other greenwood products has also helped retain the hazel coppices, acres and acres of them rolling down even some of the less steep slopes. It is into this mist-wreathed world that I splash and squelch on my early morning solitary walks. The overnight rain has stopped, and a milky-white mist lies in the valley bottom, its tendrils snaking up the hillside, wisps wriggling through the trees. Over the gate, I stroll across a field so steep it is almost vertical, even the sheep need crampons. Down by the woodland edge a small, two-hole badger sett sits just inside, tunnels dug beneath the fence. There are plenty of field signs, coarse hairs caught in the barbed wire, prints on a clear path along the contour line, a brown scar through the lush green of bluebell leaves and a little further on, a latrine.

Further down, among the hazels, I'm rummaging through the fallen leaves, scraping away with a short stick. I just cannot resist searching for hazelnut shells to see which small mammals have gnawed their way in. I find the split halves of squirrel entry, the bevelled edge left by bank vole and the neat marks of wood mouse, maybe even a yellow-necked mouse. The real gem is a couple of nuts with neat, very round holes edged with a knurling of teethmarks looking machine-made. They were the remains of a dormouse feast. This type of mature hazel coppice is the last bastion for this tiny mammal that spends some seven months of the year asleep (and not necessarily in teapots either).

These two discarded empty nutshells make my day, despite never having seen the creature that left them, nor am I likely to. Not even the mewing buzzards wheeling over the valley as I tramp across from the woodland could displace my nutshell delight.

webTitle: Israel lets in Achille Lauro hijacker turned peacemaker

fields.headline: Israel lets in Achille Lauro hijacker turned peacemaker
fields.standfirst:
A terrorist's trouble-free return signals hope beneath the deadlock

Achille Lauro Hijacking
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Nowhere does politics make for stranger bedfellows than in the Middle East.
fields.body:
Nowhere does politics make for stranger bedfellows than in the Middle East.

The man who plotted the 1985 hijacking of the American cruise ship the Achille Lauro, during which an elderly man in a wheelchair was shot dead and cast into the sea, now argues that such acts of terror are relics of a different era and best forgotten. Almost incredibly, the Israeli authorities seem to agree - up to a point.

Such seismic shifts in policy tell of the changes that the last six years of Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations have brought about. On the face of it, the peace process is in a parlous state. But there is a strong, tacit understanding on security issues.

Since 1998, no Israeli civilian has died due to an act of Palestinian terror, and Israeli security officials publicly give credit for that success to the cooperation of their Palestinian counterparts.

Earlier this week, Israel's minister for internal security, Shlomo Ben Ami, signalled the dismantling of another taboo: Israel would consider releasing all Palestinian prisoners convicted of killing Israelis in terrorist attacks - specifically banned in the 1993 Oslo accords - so long as they affirm support for the peace process.

"There are no terrorists [still in jail] who have not killed Israelis so, as the process with the PLO Authority moves forward, there will be no other alternative than to release security prisoners with blood on their hands," he told Israel Radio.

And so when the mastermind of the Achille Lauro hijacking, Mohammed Abu Abbas, landed at Gaza airport earlier this month, he sailed through the VIP channel straight past the Israeli border guards who serve as the real gate-keepers to the Palestinian Authority; an international arrest warrant, issued by the Italian authorities after he received a life sentence in absentia for the hijacking, was evidently no hindrance.

"Theoretically, any country in the world can arrest me. But everything is political," he said from his faction's office in Gaza. "If anything happens to me, it does not help; the peace process will be shaken. We are fighters but we said yes to peace. Any harm that comes to us, harms the peace process and we will go back to what we did before."

Earlier this week, Abu Abbas tested the limits of peace even farther, travelling to the West Bank city of Ramallah - which is under Palestinian control but surrounded by Israeli troops - for celebrations to mark the founding of his political faction. From there, he says, he may in future hop across to his birthplace in Haifa.

"I want to see if I can drive my car over Israeli land to the West Bank - I mean, our land," he said. "The Israeli rabbis may ask for the courts to arrest me, but the Israelis will refuse to do so. It is a new era now. We forget about what happened before Oslo, and they have too."

Some events defy erasure - particularly those as brutal as the Achille Lauro. But as far as he is concerned, the hijacking of the Italian-flagged cruise liner was an inglorious episode in a career of terror that - despite his present protestations of peace - remains an enduring source of pride.

He describes at length his role in other attacks inside Israel, such as the hostage-taking in the northern town of Kiryat Shmona in 1974 when 36 Israelis were killed, proudly claiming it as the first suicide mission.

The Achille Lauro, however, he says was a failure. "What happened did not go according to plan. It became famous because it failed. All we were trying to do was to get a ship to go to [the Israeli port of] Ashdod - the same as you would hijack a car - and then these difficulties happened."

Although he is anxious to point out that he was not on board the ship, he refuses to express remorse for the American tourist Leon Klinghoffer's death. "It is not a question of regret," he says. "Always when you work, you make mistakes."

In those days, he admits, he could never have imagined visiting Haifa openly, or in cooperation with the Israeli authorities. But the former guerrilla leader calculates that Ehud Barak's government is unlikely to risk antagonising Yasser Arafat, and derailing negotiations which resume in Eilat tomorrow by bowing to those seeking justice for the victims of terror.

Even his enemies grant that time is on his side. "If they are going to allow him to walk all over Israel, then there are absolutely no limits to the freedom that they [will] grant him," said Nitzanit Darshan-Leitner, a Tel Aviv lawyer.

Last October, Israel's supreme court turned down a petition from Ms Darshan-Leitner to try Abu Abbas for murder. Although her clients will be outraged at his audacity in seeking to enter Israel, she says people have grown weary of fighting the by-products of peace. "But the fact is he killed, he murdered, he acted criminally against the Jews and he should not be allowed here."

However, as a signed-up supporter of the peace process, a close associate of Yasser Arafat, and a popular figure among young Palestinians, Abu Abbas is to all intents unassailable. Nowadays, the burly former guerrilla admits that the greatest threat to his freedom comes from the extra kilos that he is carrying on his frame, and a related heart condition.

Having given up violence, he acknowledges that he has embarked on another risky enterprise. "The conflict for the peace is very tough - tougher than war. Going forward is very slow, but we have to recognise that there is progress.

"Now even fundamentalists in Israel do not deny the right of the Palestinians to have a state. It is handcuffed, but it is still a state. This is progress," he says. "Now we have to build bridges between their dreams and ours. If we can do that, it will be a blessing."

But as far as he is concerned, the hijacking of the Italian-flagged cruise liner was an inglorious episode in a career of terror that - despite his present protestations of peace - remains an enduring source of pride. He describes at length his role in other attacks inside Israel, such as the hostage-taking in the northern town of Kiryat Shmona in 1974 when 36 Israelis were killed, proudly claiming it as the first suicide mission. The Achille Lauro, however, he says was a failure. "What happened did not go according to plan. It became famous because it failed. All we were trying to do was to get a ship to go to [the Israeli port of] Ashdod - the same as you would hijack a car - and then these difficulties happened." Although he is anxious to point out that he was not on board the ship, he refuses to express remorse for the American tourist Leon Klinghoffer's death. "It is not a question of regret," he says. "Always when you work, you make mistakes." In those days, he admits, he could never have imagined visiting Haifa openly, or in cooperation with the Israeli authorities. But the former guerrilla leader calculates that Ehud Barak's government is unlikely to risk antagonising Yasser Arafat, and derailing negotiations which resume in Eilat tomorrow by bowing to those seeking justice for the victims of terror. Even his enemies grant that time is on his side. "If they are going to allow him to walk all over Israel, then there are absolutely no limits to the freedom that they [will] grant him," said Nitzanit Darshan-Leitner, a Tel Aviv lawyer. Last October, Israel's supreme court turned down a petition from Ms Darshan-Leitner to try Abu Abbas for murder. Although her clients will be outraged at his audacity in seeking to enter Israel, she says people have grown weary of fighting the by-products of peace. "But the fact is he killed, he murdered, he acted criminally against the Jews and he should not be allowed here." However, as a signed-up supporter of the peace process, a close associate of Yasser Arafat, and a popular figure among young Palestinians, Abu Abbas is to all intents unassailable. Nowadays, the burly former guerrilla admits that the greatest threat to his freedom comes from the extra kilos that he is carrying on his frame, and a related heart condition. Having given up violence, he acknowledges that he has embarked on another risky enterprise. "The conflict for the peace is very tough - tougher than war. Going forward is very slow, but we have to recognise that there is progress. "Now even fundamentalists in Israel do not deny the right of the Palestinians to have a state. It is handcuffed, but it is still a state. This is progress," he says. "Now we have to build bridges between their dreams and ours. If we can do that, it will be a blessing."

webTitle: Prayerful protest Tension at site claimed as holy by Orthodox Jews

fields.headline: Prayerful protest Tension at site claimed as holy by Orthodox Jews
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Black-hatted Hasidic Jews descended on a cave adjoining a private house in east Jerusalem yesterday for a prayer session intended to establish a Jewish beachhead in the Palestinian heartland of the city.
fields.body:
Black-hatted Hasidic Jews descended on a cave adjoining a private house in east Jerusalem yesterday for a prayer session intended to establish a Jewish beachhead in the Palestinian heartland of the city.

As Israeli security forces restrained the angry owners of the home, which uses the cliff as its rear wall, some 30 Orthodox Jews gathered in the cave, choosing to conduct their service at the same time as afternoon prayers on the Muslim sabbath. Muslim men knelt in prayer just outside the enclosure in protest.

The confrontation over the newest patch of sacred ground to inflame tensions in the holy city is part of a wider struggle for supremacy, which is set to intensify when peace talks reopen tomorrow.

With the prime minister, Ehud Barak, reported this week to be considering the surrender of villages adjoining Jerusalem to the Palestinian Authority, settlers groups are determined to stake a Jewish claim to Arab sections of the city. In so doing, they seek to deny the Palestinians a viable state, creating instead a series of disjointed "Bantustans".

"This was a Jewish neighbourhood, and it will be a Jewish neighbourhood," said Benny Elon, an MP for a rightwing settlers' party, who led the charge. "It is just a question of time."

The settlers claim that the cave, which is divided into three man-made compartments, was frequented by the medieval Jewish scholar, Nachmanides and is therefore sacred ground.

Despite its illustrious connections, in recent years it became a haven for vagrants and hashish smokers, and the illegal dumping of rubbish, prompting the Abu Jibne family to win court approval to fence it off.

That is apparently what incensed the settlers. "This has to be an open place where every Jew can come day and night," Mr Elon said.

On Thursday, the settlers won the right to offer prayers at the site. However, the Abu Jibne family have lodged an appeal, which will be heard next week.

Despite Jewish protestations of the sanctity of the site, local people say it had been ignored for years.

"I was born in this area, but this is the first time I heard it was holy," said Rifa'at Nasseruddin. "This is just the beginning. They are doing this so they can have land here."

webTitle: Price rises give hope to farmers

fields.headline: Price rises give hope to farmers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Countryside in Crisis
fields.trailText: The first glimmers of a recovery from the farming crisis are being shown in the prices farmers get for their animals at market or from food processors.
fields.body:
The first glimmers of a recovery from the farming crisis are being shown in the prices farmers get for their animals at market or from food processors.

Some prices for live lambs being sold at markets are the best for nearly three years while pig carcasses are fetching more than 10% more than a year ago and are 60% up on autumn 1998.

But the industry warned that the improvements would have to be sustained for some time to cover many farmers' debts. Many had either gone out of business or switched to other forms of agriculture.

There is also little sign of the beef industry turning the corner. Market prices for steers have barely changed since the link between BSE and the human condition of variant CJD was established in 1996, and they are still running about a third down on pre-crisis levels.

It is unclear how improvements might affect prices in the shops, since supermarkets have been running special promotions for British products and promising farmers a better return in future.

The Meat and Livestock Commission, which monitors livestock prices, said: "Pig producers won't rest easy until we see 100p a kilogram back, and it is debatable when that occurs. It will be a long time before they relax because of the amount of debt."

Pig prices dived as low as 60p a kilo for carcasses in autumn 1998 - about £45 for an average pig - and well below the 95p once considered a break-even price for farmers. This time last year the price had recovered to 84p and now it is nearly 94p. But debts have mounted. The breeding herd has shrunk by nearly 20% in two years and numbers of pigs slaughtered have fallen from 15.7m in 1998 to a forecast 13m this year.

Thousands of jobs are thought to have been lost already and the government is promising funds to help further "decommissioning" of pig farms, with £26m in grants being offered this year alone to demolish buildings or convert them to other uses.

The National Pig Association said the "welcome improvement" in prices needed to be sustained.

John Thorley, chairman of the National Sheep Association, said: "The spirit in the industry is a lot better than it was last year."

fields.headline: Robin Duchesne
fields.standfirst: Soldier and sportsman who loved yachting
fields.trailText: The yachtsman Robin Duchesne, who has died of a heart attack aged 63, was a soldier with a lifetime's hankering to go to sea. He twice skippered a yacht in the Fastnet Race and in 1978 was skipper of the Joint Services entry, Adventure, for the last leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race, from Rio de Janeiro to Portsmouth.
fields.body:
The yachtsman Robin Duchesne, who has died of a heart attack aged 63, was a soldier with a lifetime's hankering to go to sea. He twice skippered a yacht in the Fastnet Race and in 1978 was skipper of the Joint Services entry, Adventure, for the last leg of the Whitbread Round the World Race, from Rio de Janeiro to Portsmouth.

As secretary-general of the Royal Yachting Association and chairman of the International Sail Training Association, Duchesne reduced bureaucracy to the bare minimum, but was a caring executive and a fervent internationalist.

Born in Swanage, Dorset, and brought up in Cambridgeshire and North Wales, he was educated at Colwyn Bay Grammar School and the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst. He joined the Army at 18 after twice trying to obtain entrance to the Royal Naval College Dartmouth, but failing the eyesight test.

Commissioned in the Royal Artillery, he claimed that sailing determined his choice of regiment. It was with the gunners at Sandhurst that he had been able to enjoy his passion for the sport, and there followed a cheerful, albeit fruitless, period at the Royal Military College of Science, where he failed a general science degree but enjoyed "great fun, lots of rugby and lots of sailing".

Duchesne rose to the rank of brigadier, and his commands included a field artillery regiment in Germany. He was an instructor at the Staff College and completed his service as Chief of Staff to the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus: he loved the work because he believed in the UN's ideals.

Duchesne was rugby mad during his early years in the Army and he continued to play into his early 40s, while secretary for both the Royal Artillery and the Sandhurst teams. It was the start of his sports administrative career, which extended into the Tall Ships, one of his passions. He was deputy chairman of the ISTA and became its chairman five years ago.

In 1986, he joined the RYA and among his first tasks was to move it from Woking to larger premises in Eastleigh. He was dedicated to the sport's national authority and represented the interest of all those who go afloat. On his death, the 46 tall ships in Southampton lowered their ensigns to half mast in respect of a man all of their skippers called their friend.

He is survived by his son and daughter.

 Robin Duchesne, yachtsman and soldier, born September 25 1936; died April 14 2000

fields.headline: No strings
fields.trailText: FilmFour is to be congratulated upon its decision to "webcast" the censored scenes in the Danish movie The Idiots (C4 to show banned sex scenes on web, April 27).
fields.body:
FilmFour is to be congratulated upon its decision to "webcast" the censored scenes in the Danish movie The Idiots (C4 to show banned sex scenes on web, April 27).

However, viewers among your readers should be warned that some may find these scenes offensive - not on account of the penetrative sex involved, but because the participants are obviously having a rollicking good time without benefit of emotional commitment.

Sex, in fact, without strings, G or otherwise.
Helen Dunwoodie
Edinburgh

fields.headline: We Bruch no opposition
fields.trailText: So Max Bruch's First Violin Concerto fails to meet with your approval as the number one in the Classic FM Hall of Fame (Please, play something else, 26 April).
fields.body:
So Max Bruch's First Violin Concerto fails to meet with your approval as the number one in the Classic FM Hall of Fame (Please, play something else, 26 April). He was chosen, however, by our listeners from among 70,000 different works by hundreds of different composers that we have played over the past year. Of those, the most frequently heard were in fact Debussy, Copland and Khachaturian, and not Bruch as you suggest. In fact Bruch's concerto has not been played on the station for at least the past three months. Even so, it topped our poll once again. Which just goes to show that the British public knows what it likes - and sticks to it.
Darren Henley
Managing editor, Classic FM

 You display a distasteful form of cultural snobbery not peculiar to England, but which has been refined to a fine art by such as Andrew Clements. I am sure that a decade ago it would have been almost inconceivable to imagine appreciation of classical music managing to reach a relatively mass audience. Now Classic FM has achieved at the very least, a mass platform for the appreciation of classical music, your contributors sniff: "Why darling, those dreadful people who vote in that poll are simply not listening to the right kind of classical music." In an almost laughable caricature of the this type of snobbery, Mr Clements also tells us that while Bruch's Violin Concerto No. 1 is an "undeniably fine work", his Second Concerto "is actually a better piece". Sniff. Sniff.

What the poll shows is simply the enduring quality of the majority of the pieces voted for, but it is both patronising and facile to think that the tastes and preferences of those who voted and who listen to the station do not extend beyond the results of the poll.
Daniel Callaghan
London
indomir@aol.com

 In berating Classic FM's reluctance to broaden its audience's musical horizons Andrew Clements merely confirms his own prejudice. Composers (and radio stations) have, since about 1920, tried to broaden such horizons with progressively diminishing success: whether he likes it or not, the audience for contemporary music is minuscule compared to the audience for "classical" music.

When contemporary composers (such as Lloyd, Arnold or Goldschmidt) dare to write "big, succulent tunes", complete with tonal harmonies, audiences love them for it (though such composers have not always had an representative airing in Britain). And why ever not? Perhaps composers (and critics) should have more regard for what an audience actually wants?

The link between Shostakovitch and Rachmaninov is not so mystifying, either, in terms of chronology, tradition and of musical language: in any case, both composers concerti are arguably more meaningful than anything Boulez has written.
Dr Dalwyn Henshall
Chestfield, Kent
dalwyn@henshalld.fsnet.co.uk

 Andrew Clements forgets that Mozart, Beethoven, Bruch, Verdi, Gershwin et al were immensely popular in their own time because their music had an appeal which had something to do with being able to write a good tune. Well, no radio station is playing "bleeding chunks" from the latest operas by Mark Anthony Turnage or Harrison Birtwistle, which were both recommended enthusiastically by the critics, are they?

It truly mystifies me why the musical establishment regard contemporary composers so highly whilst the concert-going public stay away from concerts that include such music. I've seen and heard Boulez in person; there was me and about a hundred others in a hall that could seat over 2,000.
AS Ward
Loughborough, Leics
A.S.Ward@lboro.ac.uk

fields.headline: Rotor defect grounds Lynx helicopters
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence found itself pitched into another furore over inadequate equipment yesterday after the army and navy were forced to ground more than 50 Lynx helicopters because of problems with the rotor mechanism.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence found itself pitched into another furore over inadequate equipment yesterday after the army and navy were forced to ground more than 50 Lynx helicopters because of problems with the rotor mechanism.

In the latest in a series of embarrassing setbacks suffered by Britain's armed forces, the MoD said it would be two years before the fleet was back to full strength, although junior defence minister Lewis Moonie insisted that only training helicopters would be affected.

The Royal Navy has withdrawn 44 of its 59 Lynx helicopters, while the army has grounded eight that are used in Northern Ireland.

The problem with the rotor hub - the block that holds the blades to the engine - emerged more than two years ago, after the hub on a Dutch naval helicopter fractured before take-off. A detached rotor blade severely damaged the aircraft, injuring one of the crew.

GKN Westland, the company that manufactures the Lynx, issued a warning to the MoD last November, highlighting that under certain operating conditions the lifespan of the hub may be drastically reduced.

Asked why the problem had not been addressed by the MoD then, a spokesman for Westland said: "You will have to take that up with the MoD."

Last night a spokesman for the MoD said he was unable to comment on the November warning because he was unaware of it.

The Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said: "If a warning was in fact issued by Westland last year then the MOD has some explaining to do as to why it did not act upon it."

Earlier Dr Moonie said that while the rotor problem was obviously a difficult situation it was not quite as bad as it sounded.

"It is not a matter of grounding helicopters," the junior defence minister said. "It is a matter of sharing out the number of spare hubs we have available and fitting them on to ensure we do have enough helicopters to maintain our operational capabilities.

"We have a pool of hubs that we can share out between the Lynx helicopters of the army and the navy. It is not a matter of grounding the helicopter, it is a matter of changing the hub."

An army pilot who has flown the Lynx said a failure of the rotor hub during flight is almost certain to be catastrophic. "There is not a lot you can do; you die," he said. "If it was to fail in any way and you were to lose a rotor it would shake the helicopter to pieces."

The safety scare could not have come at a worse time for the MoD. In February it emerged that 300,000 standard issue army rifles were being recalled after evidence showed the weapons were prone to jamming, while a leaked National Audit Office report revealed the RAF came close to running out of bombs during the Kosovo war.

Mr Campbell said: "It seemed that nothing else could go wrong for the MoD, but this news is extremely disturbing.

"Our forces can only act effectively when they have the equipment they need. The period of two years until the problem is resolved seems extraordinarily long.

"Questions must inevitably arise as to what ministers knew and when they knew it."

The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, said: "This case highlights the problem the government now has with overstretch in our armed forces."

Westland said that similar warnings had been sent to the 11 navies around the world who operate the Lynx, and the company is running a programme to replace the hubs on helicopters that may be at risk.

fields.headline: The right to justice
fields.trailText: Hugo Young is right (Comment, April 27) to call for reforms to the inflexible mandatory life sentence for murder, as the sensible and forward-looking response to the Martin case.
fields.body:
Hugo Young is right (Comment, April 27) to call for reforms to the inflexible mandatory life sentence for murder, as the sensible and forward-looking response to the Martin case. Last month, Justice submitted evidence to Lord Justice Auld's inquiry into the criminal justice system, urging exactly this course. The offence of murder covers an exceptionally wide range of circumstances: everything from planned killings for gain to those committed under great pressure in highly charged emotional circumstances. The 1989 House of Lords committee recognised 11 years ago the evident truth that the public reaction in such cases "varies according to the circumstances", and that "the public seems to be well able to recognise powerful mitigation, even in the case of deliberate killing".

We pointed out not only would this be fairer, but it would also save costs and time. At present, many cases are contested, not because the person does not admit the killing, but because there are mitigating circumstances (such as domestic violence, or a death that resulted accidentally from a brawl) which make a life sentence, or a long period of imprisonment, wholly inappropriate and which can only be properly taken into account by the court if the verdict is one of manslaughter, due to diminished responsibility or provocation, rather than murder.

Most senior judges have been arguing this course for years. They know it will allow the courts to deal much more fairly and efficiently with homicide cases. And the public appear to agree with them.
Anne Owers
Director, Justice

 Your correspondent David Enright (Letters, April 27) is wrong to claim that a letter being sent to refused asylum applicants is a "new form of refusal of asylum letter" replacing those providing detailed reasons for refusal. The letter to which he refers is an interim notification, in use since 1996, to advise applicants who stand to lose their social security benefit. The reason legal representatives are receiving more of them is because of the rapid escalation of decision-making on asylum cases, due to more staff and better working methods.

It does not replace the formal notice of refusal of asylum, served by an immigration officer at the applicant's port of entry, once a person's immigration status in the light of the refusal of asylum has been established. fields.bodyText: Hugo Young is right (Comment, April 27) to call for reforms to the inflexible mandatory life sentence for murder, as the sensible and forward-looking response to the Martin case. Last month, Justice submitted evidence to Lord Justice Auld's inquiry into the criminal justice system, urging exactly this course. The offence of murder covers an exceptionally wide range of circumstances: everything from planned killings for gain to those committed under great pressure in highly charged emotional circumstances. The 1989 House of Lords committee recognised 11 years ago the evident truth that the public reaction in such cases "varies according to the circumstances", and that "the public seems to be well able to recognise powerful mitigation, even in the case of deliberate killing". We pointed out not only would this be fairer, but it would also save costs and time. At present, many cases are contested, not because the person does not admit the killing, but because there are mitigating circumstances (such as domestic violence, or a death that resulted accidentally from a brawl) which make a life sentence, or a long period of imprisonment, wholly inappropriate and which can only be properly taken into account by the court if the verdict is one of manslaughter, due to diminished responsibility or provocation, rather than murder. webTitle: Search for IRA victims to resume

fields.headline: Search for IRA victims to resume
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The search for the remains of IRA murder victims buried in Irish Republic will resume next week, John Wilson of the independent commission for the location of victims' remains, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The search for the remains of IRA murder victims buried in Irish Republic will resume next week, John Wilson of the independent commission for the location of victims' remains, said yesterday.

Five sites believed to hold the bodies of six members of the "disappeared" will be investigated by police, starting on Tuesday, he said.

"The searches will be focused and limited in extent and it is not expected that any search will last longer than three weeks, irrespective of the outcome," he said.

"We are confident, however, that, while success cannot be guaranteed, the gardai will spare no effort in bringing these searches to a speedy and successful conclusion."

Seamus McKendry, whose mother-in-law Jean McConville vanished after helping a fatally injured British soldier in 1972, welcomed the news. "I am optimistic that we'll find them this time.

"The Provisional IRA dismembered this family all those years ago. The wait for news is horrendous, but it would be a huge relief to know for certain," he said.

Digging for the bodies of nine identified IRA victims, who vanished over a period dating back to the early 1970s, began last May.

Three bodies were found, but the excavation was suspended in July because of a lack of information.

Last month the commission said the search would restart this year because "sufficient additional information" had come to light.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Charity worker killed with knife

A charity worker was killed in a knife attack at her home early yesterday.
fields.body:
Charity worker killed with knife
A charity worker was killed in a knife attack at her home early yesterday.

Carol Trethewey, 51, a mother of two, who managed the Scope charity shop in her home town of St Austell, Cornwall, was found on the kitchen floor of her home after a phone call from a relative. A man is helping police inquiries.

Two dead in minibus crash

Two women died after a minibus overturned on an Essex slip road. The driver and front seat passenger, both play leaders at the Brooks Road playscheme in Canning Town, east London, had been taking children on a day trip to Clacton.

Headmaster drowns in pond

A headmaster slipped and drowned in his garden pond, which contained just 18 inches of water. Graham Lewis, 48, was knocked unconscious after he slipped and hit his head while pulling weeds out of the pond in East Rudham, near Fakenham, Norfolk. He was headmaster at Terrington St Clement community school.

Twins delivered at roadside

An ambulance operator talked a father through a roadside delivery of his baby twins in Hampshire yesterday. Carol Steward gave instructions over the phone to Gavin McBeath after his wife, Pamela, insisted the babies would not wait until the couple reached Salisbury district hospital. The babies were born in the hamlet of Shipton Bellinger.

fields.headline: Squatter awaits judgment
fields.trailText: A squatter claiming ownership of a £400,000 London house is waiting for a court ruling on his case, after a three day hearing ended yesterday.
fields.body:
A squatter claiming ownership of a £400,000 London house is waiting for a court ruling on his case, after a three day hearing ended yesterday.

Michael Archangel, 58, a Rastafarian performance poet, was taken to court by Lambeth council to regain possession of the Victorian house. But Mr Archangel counter-claimed that he owns the property under squatter's rights, because he has lived there for more than 12 years.

Mr Archangel told Central London county court he has lived in the house in Stockwell for 16 years, after the council forgot it owned it.

But the council argues that for four of the past five years he has lived in Sydney, passing ownership to Rehab II, a charity project he started for the rehabilitation of young people. Yesterday Judge Roger Cooke reserved judgment.

webTitle: Doing good without a dog collar

fields.headline: Doing good without a dog collar
fields.trailText: The humanists were 30 years ahead of the Stapleford Centre (Faith in our schools, Education Guardian, April 25) in wanting moral education to pervade the curriculum. We welcome the pioneering work of St Mary Redcliffe and Temple School in putting academic teaching in a wider framework.
fields.body:
The humanists were 30 years ahead of the Stapleford Centre (Faith in our schools, Education Guardian, April 25) in wanting moral education to pervade the curriculum. We welcome the pioneering work of St Mary Redcliffe and Temple School in putting academic teaching in a wider framework.

The difference between us and many religious educators - and the answer to Alison Farnell's claims that "nothing is value-free" even if it is secular humanism - is that we want to celebrate and teach about the pluralism of our community, opening up options that include humanism and also other key options. Too many of them want to propagate a committed set of views and beliefs, closing down other options.

As to church schools, the government seems hellbent on fostering divisions in society, not just by religion but by race, given that Muslim and Hindu schools will be largely attended by Asian pupils.
David Pollock
Chair, British Humanist Association
robert@humanism.org.uk

 If the Bishop of Oxford believes that all Quakers are monotheists (Try out Judaism, bishop suggests, April 27) he is drawing the wrong conclusion from the fact that the Religious Society of Friends refuses to endorse the Trinity.

I expect some Quakers find the idea of the Trinity helpful, and some find it unhelpful. But our objection is to all dogmatic statements of belief, not just that one. As Quakers our only dogma is that we have no dogma, though we do try not to be too dogmatic about that.
Roger S Wilson
Crosby
trsw@satterth.co.uk

 Suzanne Lord (Letters, April 25) suggests that the church "cannot... 'do good' without the dog collar". May I say that it can and does. If she cares to visit the Blue- water retail complex in Dartford, she may see the workplace chaplain (without a dog collar) listening to anyone wishing to chat, perhaps sharing in a problem or giving pastoral care. She would be welcome and would find that there are no strings attached - all 300-plus workplace chaplains in Britain abide by an agreement not to evangelise, made by the Churches Consortium on Industrial Mission with the CBI and the TUC. They also work totally independently of either side of establishments visited and in strict confidence. They are in great demand in many areas.
John Frew
Reading
johnd.frew@virgin.net

fields.headline: Poor vision
fields.trailText: "Prudence Brown" plumbs the depths of stupidity by putting all of the massive gains from the radio waves sell-off into paying off the national debt (Leader, April 28). Only a political fool would give the Tories the borrowing space to be able to cut taxes and spend.
fields.body:
"Prudence Brown" plumbs the depths of stupidity by putting all of the massive gains from the radio waves sell-off into paying off the national debt (Leader, April 28). Only a political fool would give the Tories the borrowing space to be able to cut taxes and spend, ie he has at a stroke made Haguenomics possible. Ordinary people don't see the national debt but they do see run-down hospitals and schools. Use the money to fund their renewal without the nonsense of the public-private finance initiative, which is piling up as a tax on our futures. Without clause four New Labour lacks distance vision, but here it shows a total absence of peripheral vision with its self-imposed monetarist blinkers.
Mike Stott
Newton Poppleford, Devon mestott@supanet.com

fields.headline: Trading cards are a steal
fields.trailText: Sadly the warnings about the strife caused by Pokemania (Pokemon cards 'exploit children', April 25) reached me too late to take precautions. But I may have inadvertently stumbled upon evidence of a burgeoning international trafficking in Pokemon paraphernalia. On the last day of a week's stay in Barcelona, the Pokemon card collections of both my two young sons disappeared from our hotel room in unresolved circumstances. (One child mislaying prized Pokemons might be dismissed as carelessness, but two is surely more than unfortunate coincidence!)
fields.body:
Sadly the warnings about the strife caused by Pokemania (Pokemon cards 'exploit children', April 25) reached me too late to take precautions. But I may have inadvertently stumbled upon evidence of a burgeoning international trafficking in Pokemon paraphernalia. On the last day of a week's stay in Barcelona, the Pokemon card collections of both my two young sons disappeared from our hotel room in unresolved circumstances. (One child mislaying prized Pokemons might be dismissed as carelessness, but two is surely more than unfortunate coincidence!)

Our suspicions that sinister forces may have been at work were crowned by the fact that a plastic pocket model Pokemon also went missing (the one called Squirtle). Our eldest had insisted on him never leaving the room dur ing the holiday. Cursory interrogation of cleaning staff came to nothing.

Back home my nephews cursed me for not bringing back Spanish Pokemons for them to bargain with, which is when the penny dropped about the scale of their value and how much the craze has set in. Interpol are yet to be informed. Meanwhile it's only a matter of time before we see import/export of Pokemons. If I wasn't so exhausted from my fingertip search of the Spanish hotel, I would set up such a business myself.
Tim Donovan
London
donovans6@btinternet.com

webTitle: Doctor who groped men struck off

fields.headline: Doctor who groped men struck off
fields.trailText: A family doctor who fondled two male patients was yesterday struck off the medical register. Daren Halkyard, of Beeston, Nottingham, was found guilty by the General Medical Council professional conduct committee of groping the genitals of the men as they lay on his examination couch.
fields.body:
A family doctor who fondled two male patients was yesterday struck off the medical register. Daren Halkyard, of Beeston, Nottingham, was found guilty by the General Medical Council professional conduct committee of groping the genitals of the men as they lay on his examination couch.

Halkyard behaved "indecently and improperly" in November 1994 with a patient referred to as Mr A at his Nottingham clinic, and again in November 1997 and August 1998 with another patient, Mr B, at his new surgery in Clowne, Derbyshire.

It also emerged that Halkyard was convicted at Nottingham crown court in July last year of stealing up to £10,000 from his surgery. He was given a 12-month prison sentence, suspended for two years.

Halkyard, who denied serious professional misconduct, claimed that he gave both Mr A and Mr B normal examinations.

fields.headline: Tarbuck to quit Big Breakfast
fields.trailText: The Big Breakfast yesterday announced the departure of yet another female presenter. Liza Tarbuck, 34, will step down as co-host of Channel 4's breakfast programme at the end of August, after a year in the job. A spokesman for the TV programme said it was not yet known who would replace Tarbuck, the daughter of Liverpool comedian Jimmy Tarbuck, after she announced her surprise decision to leave during an online chat with fans yesterday.  He said: "Liza has done a year with the show, and she has said she wants to get back into acting." He could not confirm reports that she was growing weary of the early morning starts.
fields.body:
The Big Breakfast yesterday announced the departure of yet another female presenter. Liza Tarbuck, 34, will step down as co-host of Channel 4's breakfast programme at the end of August, after a year in the job. A spokesman for the TV programme said it was not yet known who would replace Tarbuck, the daughter of Liverpool comedian Jimmy Tarbuck, after she announced her surprise decision to leave during an online chat with fans yesterday. He said: "Liza has done a year with the show, and she has said she wants to get back into acting." He could not confirm reports that she was growing weary of the early morning starts.

Like her predecessor, Denise Van Outen, Tarbuck trained as an actress, making a name for herself a decade ago in the ITV sitcom Watching.

After a stint as a roving reporter on BBC1's The Weekend Show and Channel 4's She's Gotta Have It, she became a co-presenter of DJ Steve Wright's Radio 2 weekend show.

Tarbuck had been tipped to succeed Van Outen on The Big Breakfast two years ago, but was overlooked for the model Kelly Brook. Tarbuck, who eventually replaced Brook, joked at the time: "Getting up at that time in the morning really messes around with your bowels - and I'm a great believer in regular movement."

fields.headline: Sleep rage man gets probation
fields.trailText: A man who threatened to kill the first pilot he saw because he was being kept awake by aircraft noise was put on probation at Gloucester crown court yesterday.
fields.body:
A man who threatened to kill the first pilot he saw because he was being kept awake by aircraft noise was put on probation at Gloucester crown court yesterday.

Stephen Burke, 34, telephoned Staverton airport in Cheltenham threatening to stand in the middle of the runway and stab the next pilot he saw.

But the recorder, Michael Harington, did not jail him after being told he had not intended to carry out his threat.

Penny Wilson, defending, said her client, from Hatherley, Cheltenham, had been extremely distressed about the noise of low-flying aircraft after sleepless nights.

She said: "Although what he did was extremely unpleasant and distressing to those involved... he did not go to the airport and threaten people."

webTitle: Poverty and political violence leave Haiti's poor little choice

fields.headline: Poverty and political violence leave Haiti's poor little choice
fields.trailText: It is a long, expensive and perilous journey by boat from the north coast ports of Haiti to the promised land of Florida, and many of those who set out never make it. The risks are all too well known in Haiti, as is the fact that unscrupulous boat-owners often charge hundreds of dollars only to dump their passengers on some deserted Bahamaian outcrop. A one-way ticket will involve selling everything, leaving behind family and community for an uncertain future in New York or Miami. And yet thousands of Haitians are willing to take their chance each year, fully aware of the odds against them.
fields.body:
It is a long, expensive and perilous journey by boat from the north coast ports of Haiti to the promised land of Florida, and many of those who set out never make it. The risks are all too well known in Haiti, as is the fact that unscrupulous boat-owners often charge hundreds of dollars only to dump their passengers on some deserted Bahamaian outcrop. A one-way ticket will involve selling everything, leaving behind family and community for an uncertain future in New York or Miami. And yet thousands of Haitians are willing to take their chance each year, fully aware of the odds against them.

The latest exodus is nothing new. The boat people phenomenon became an international cause for concern in the 1980s, when a combination of political repression under "Baby Doc" Duvalier and long-standing economic hardship forced boatloads of Haitians on to the open sea. The numbers swelled still further during the politically unstable 1990s as a succession of military regimes ruled incompetently and cruelly in the western hemisphere's poorest country.

The violent overthrow of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in 1991 unleashed a torrent of would-be refugees, whose arrival on the beaches of Florida was a key factor in President Clinton's decision to reinstate Mr Aristide by force of arms. Now it looks as if Mr Aristide will be back in Port-au-Prince's presidential palace early next year with an overwhelming majority in December's elections, for there is simply no credible opposition.

But the political situation, for all its inevitability, has not brought stability or even the glimmer of economic recovery. The current government, widely perceived as a stop-gap before Mr Aristide returns, has presided over an alarming level of violence - both political and criminal, while local elections, currently scheduled for May 21, are likely either to be seriously flawed or not take place at all.

The last vestiges of Duvalierism may have disappeared, but authoritarian politics persist. Mr Aristide's supporters are seemingly impatient for the return of "the Messiah", and recent demonstrations have been threatening. A well-known journalist was recently assassinated, and a report by Human Rights Watch and other organisations has warned of a spiral of politically motivated violence.

Some commentators are concerned that the extreme wing of Mr Aristide's camp may be forming a paramilitary force not unlike the Duvaliers' feared Tontons Macoutes.

But although political fear is certainly a factor, it is sheer poverty that is usually behind any Haitian refugee crisis, and the current exodus is no exception. The country remains stubbornly poor, with average annual income of £320 competing with sub-Saharan Africa in terms of deprivation.

A few thousand, mostly light-skinned families, live the good life, some from import-export businesses, others allegedly from drug-smuggling, but the vast majority of Haiti's 6m barely scratch a living from small farms or, increasingly, in the shanty towns of the capital.

With life expectancy at about 50 and infant mortality rates at 100 per 1,000, Haiti's social indicators are among the world's worst. HIV infection is rife, while rural poverty and land shortages have forced many peasants to cut down any available tree for charcoal, creating an environmental disaster unlike anywhere else in the Caribbean. Overcrowded, impoverished and utterly dependent on cheap food imports, Haiti is the proverbial basket case, its traditional peasant economy ruined by lack of investment and soil erosion.

If Haitian politicians like to blame the US and other donors for slow and inadequate aid, the international community has largely lost patience with Haiti's feuding political class. For more than a year recently, the country had no real government, as its warring political cliques repeatedly rejected President Prèval's nominations for prime minister.

No government meant no aid, and as ever the real losers were Haiti's poor. It is perhaps not surprising that many of them are willing to sell their land or house in a final desperate gamble to reach a better life.

 James Ferguson is the author of A Traveller's History of the Caribbean (Windrush Press)

webTitle: Couple sue US police over child abuse arrest

fields.headline: Couple sue US police over child abuse arrest
fields.trailText: A couple from North Yorkshire who were arrested in Florida when they left their two young children sleeping in a hotel room are suing the city of St Pete Beach for hundreds of thousands of dollars in damages.
fields.body:
A couple from North Yorkshire who were arrested in Florida when they left their two young children sleeping in a hotel room are suing the city of St Pete Beach for hundreds of thousands of dollars in damages.

Philip and Jill Adam, from Harrogate, were charged with felony child abuse after they left their children in their hotel room at the TradeWinds Beach Resort as they watched a firework display in May last year.

The charges were later dropped by the police.

The couple's children, Maisie, five, and one-year-old Daniel were left alone. Maisie was found in a hotel corridor by another guest.

Staff at the hotel called the police and the couple were handcuffed, strip searched and kept in police cells overnight.

John Trevena, their lawyer in America, launched a lawsuit yesterday against the acting chief of police and the city of St Pete Beach. The couple are claiming false imprisonment and battery.

Their complaint also alleges that the officer who arrested them was not properly trained or supervised.

Mr and Mrs Adam are claiming a total of $200,000 damages (£124,000) in their lawsuit.

Mr Trevena said: "These charges, and the international headlines which they made, have impacted terribly on their lives.

"Mrs Adam is a university lecturer in child education and the stigma of having child abuse charges against her has been horrific.

"Even though the charges have been dropped, they want everybody to know that they didn't commit any type of criminal act and they want to clear their names.

"It was absurd that they were charged at all because they never left the hotel. They were only by the pool area watching a memorial day firework display."

Mr Trevena said the hotel has settled a legal claim with Mr and Mrs Adam, but the police were unrepentant about their actions and had not apologised to the couple.

He said Mr and Mrs Adam have suffered embarrassment, emotional pain and suffering and serious financial losses as a result of their arrest.

webTitle: Logging on to the fact that a woman's place is in the IT department

fields.headline: Logging on to the fact that a woman's place is in the IT department
fields.standfirst: The job description for programmers would seem to fit women perfectly, but look around the techies at any company and they are few and far between. Now the shortage is making employers adopt more female-friendly policies. Rachel Spence reports
fields.trailText: The job description for programmers would seem to fit women perfectly, but look around the techies at any company and they are few and far between. Now the shortage is making employers adopt more female-friendly policies.
fields.body:
Are you good at solving problems? Creative? A good listener and a team player? Then Susan Eisenbach has just the job for you.

Ms Eisenbach, director of studies at the Department of Computing, Imperial College, London, knows what makes a good computer programmer. The talents she lists make it sound ready-made for a woman. But how many women are there in your IT department?

Probably not many, perhaps none. Most startlingly, the number of women in IT has actually dropped over the past two decades. In the 60s around 50% of IT workers were female; in the 90s, despite the apparent inroads made by the equal opportunities campaign, the figure has halved and looks set to go on falling. Just 18% of IT students are female and at Manchester's UMIST, which offers one of the UK's top courses, women students comprise just 10%.

Ironically, women started to turn away from IT at exactly the moment when PCs became more accessible. "When I studied in the 60s, IT was too marginal to be affected by social preconceptions," remembers Ms Eisenbach. "But as computers arrived in schools and homes, they fell prey to the mainstream division of labour; basically they were 'colonised' by the boys who generally see technology as their domain. Girls started to see computers as a macho pursuit: machines that boys play war games on."

Her view is supported by Michelle Hawke, a 24-year-old engineer in software company Ensoft and the only woman in a 20-strong workforce. "I went to an all-girls school," says Michelle, "So I never saw it as a 'boy thing'. Consequently, I've never questioned myself as a 'techie'."

Today, the shortage of women IT workers is not only an equal opportunities issue; it poses a threat to the health of an industry currently struggling with a major worldwide skills shortage. In the UK alone, the sector needs to attract 250,000 workers by 2004.

Rebecca George, human resources partner for IBM, comments: "The UK IT industry's failure to attract women will have serious consequences for us vis-a-vis our US competitors, who have better diversity initiatives and consequently a much broader pool of talent to draw upon."

Interestingly, the lack of women extends beyond the technical domain into areas where women usually shine, such as marketing and sales, suggesting that the problem is intrinsic to the culture of the industry. In 1997, when IBM conducted a survey among its own top women executives, three issues emerged: masculine culture, lack of role models and inflexible working arrangements.

Dr Alison Adam, senior lecturer at the department of computation at UMIST and the UK chairwoman of support network and pressure group Women into Computing, says industry should be wary of seeing this as merely a perceptual problem. "IT is genuinely a very masculine, long-hours culture and that's what needs to change. I've watched a number of female students drop out to go into teaching because it offers more flexibility and a less macho environment; just one male student has done that."

Dr Adam worked as a systems analyst before entering academia: "I started in a manufacturing company where I was patronised and passed over for promotion. In a smaller firm, I was resented for my technical expertise. The crunch came when I wanted to have children and they were totally in flexible. As an academic, I'm one of few women, but I have more control over my working patterns.

"If industry wants to attract women, it's no good saying: 'We only want you because we're short of skilled labour.' Women need to be convinced of deeper initiatives: a sense that their expertise is taken seriously and a genuine recognition of work/life balance."

But just how easy is it to work "sensible hours"? Michelle Hawke works long hours regularly, and can't imagine finishing earlier. "Perhaps because we have US clients, but also because the job demands it. I don't resent it because the work is challenging and creative."

Michelle admits, however, that if having a family becomes an issue her priorities must change. "I wouldn't be prepared to put in as many hours and that would affect my ability to do this job."

Fortunately, some companies are becoming more creative in their approach to working patterns. IBM has introduced flexible hours policies and job-sharing schemes and IT consultancy the FI Group are renowned for their flexible culture. But as IBM's Rebecca George puts it: "The number of European woman executives at IBM has tripled in the last three years since we started being proactive on this issue. But it's still only 33%; the culture has to change quickly."

Getting the work-life balance right

Margaret Calder works for the FI Group as an analyst programmer. She has two daughters aged 14 and 15.

"Until I came to FI, women IT managers were thin on the ground. The problems start when women leave to have children and, because technology moves very fast, they have to re-train," she says. "Not all firms will do that, so a lot of women don't come back in. Even if they do return; many firms just aren't flexible enough. I'm not surprised companies are beginning to notice how many good people they've lost.

"When my second child started school, I took a women software engineers Return to Work Course. I applied to the FI Group because I knew they made a policy of being flexible. It's ideal because I work 30 hours a week, over four days.

"Contrary to expectations, programming lends itself to flexible working patterns because it's objective and logic-based, so you can hand over quite easily to someone else. Many projects are modular, so different aspects operate independently. Perhaps women bring different skills; mothers are definitely brilliant at multi-tasking, which is essential to being a good programmer.

"FI have made an effort to let everyone, men and women, work as flexibly as possible. But it's a two-way process: I can work from home sometimes but likewise I'll work extra hours if necessary. Here 50% of managers are women, which is ideal. Frankly, women are still more understanding about practical issues such as having a sick child."

webTitle: Museum celebrates heroine's name with pride

fields.headline: Museum celebrates heroine's name with pride
fields.trailText: Violette Szabo, the young wartime resistance heroine tortured and killed in a Nazi concentration camp, is to be honoured in the English countryside where she played as a child.
fields.body:
Violette Szabo, the young wartime resistance heroine tortured and killed in a Nazi concentration camp, is to be honoured in the English countryside where she played as a child.

A museum is to be dedicated to her this summer in the village of Wormelow, near Hereford. This fulfils a long-held ambition of her admirers and her daughter Tania, who called her "one of those bright beacons that still shines".

Violette, for whom the celebrated second world war poem The Love that I Have was written as an undercover resistance code, was executed at the age of 23. She was awarded a posthumous George Cross, which was presented to the four-year-old Tania in 1946.

Her name first became widely known in 1958 through the British film Carve Her Name with Pride. The actress Virginia McKenna, who played Violette in the film, will open the museum on June 24. It will house her letters and photographs.

The opening will be a reunion of more than 400 wartime special operations staff. They will march to the museum along Violette Way, a specially named path across Wormelow's millennium green.

With a French mother and a London taxi driver father, she was brought up in Brixton, south London. At 19, she married Etienne Szabo, a captain in the French Foreign Legion. He died at El Alamein in 1942.

Her fluency in French and knowledge of France made her a natural for recruitment into the Special Operations Executive to work with the resistance. She became SOE's best shot with a rifle. Her code-master, later the screenwriter Leo Marks, wrote her a poem to use to authenticate her radio messages:

The life that I have

Is all that I have

And the life that I have

Is yours.

The love that I have

Of the life that I have

Is yours and yours and

yours.

She was wounded in a gun battle and caught by the Waffen SS in June 1944, and was shot three months before the German surrender. Her activities helped delay for weeks the regrouping of German troops after the allies' D-Day invasion. The museum will be at Cartref, her uncle's home in Wormelow, where she spent holidays as a girl and unwound with Tania after her first mission.

It took Rosemary Rigby, the retired farmer who now lives there, 10 years to raise £17,000 for the tribute.

fields.headline: Noddy's nice little earner
fields.standfirst: Enid Blyton's wobbly-headed taxi driver is calling at Sotheby's, writes Stewart Dalbey
fields.trailText: Enid Blyton's wobbly-headed taxi driver is calling at Sotheby's, writes Stewart Dalbey.
fields.body:
According to a biographer, Bob Mullan, Enid Blyton was, shortly after her death, the most commercially successful British children's writer of the twentieth century. With over 700 titles and about 500 million sales, at that time, she easily outstripped all rivals.

Extremely prolific, she invented the Famous Five, The Secret Seven and Mallory Towers. The most famous creation by Blyton (1897-1968) was Noddy. Already successful in 1949, she conceived the little carved wooden boy with a nodding head in response to a request from David White, of the publisher Sampson Low, to create a series to rival the work of Walt Disney. White then introduced her to Harmsen van der Beek, a Dutch illustrator, to help visualise her new character. He was succeeded by designers, Robert Tyndall and Robert Lee.

Noddy and Big Ears, Pixie and Mr and Mrs Tubby as well as other denizens of Toyland became extremely popular. The books were translated into 40 languages and sold 200m copies. Noddy remained Blyton's most pop- ular pre-school character and in France was known as Oui Oui.

Despite Blyton's obvious commercial success she provoked much hostility. She was attacked for the banality and repetitiveness of her plots, her lack of imagination, the paucity of her vocabulary but, above all, for her alleged racism: her constant references to golliwogs.

Noddy went out of fashion after his heyday of the 1950s and 1960s. It was not until the 1990s that he regained popularity as marked by the Noddy Magazine, published by the BBC from 1992. In 1998 Noddy was launched in the US with a television series.

The Enid Blyton Company decided to sell the Noddy archive in 1997. The first Noddy sale was held in October 1997 and the second in November 1998. Sotheby's in London is holding a sale, live and online, of the third and final part. This will be the last opportunity (says Sotheby's) for Blyton collectors to acquire a souvenir of childhood.

The bulk of the sale consists of artwork, original pen and ink drawings and watercolours by van der Beek, Lee and Tyndall.

So what is the market for Noddy drawings? In recent years drawings by EH Shepherd, who illustrated AA Milne's Winnie-the-Pooh, have gone through roof. A Shepherd drawing which five years ago would fetch £5,000 would now typically realise £10,000. Some Shepherd drawings have been known to sell for between £50,000 to £100,000. Other well known illustrators, such as Arthur Rackham, Aubrey Beardsley and Edmund Dulac, fetch prices not far below this.

The Noddy illustrators are not as sought after, says Chris Beetles, who runs the Chris Beetles Gallery in London. "The Noddy illustrators are not in the same class as Shepherd or Rackham." He adds there is not the same enthusiasm in the US for Noddy.
