fields.headline: From surfer to easy rider
fields.standfirst: The web led Augusta Winstone to her dream machine - and the finance for it. Rupert Jones reports on a growing trend
fields.trailText: The web led Augusta Winstone to her dream machine - and the finance for it. Rupert Jones reports on a growing trend.
fields.body:
When Augusta Winstone was looking for her dream motorbike - a yellow Harley-Davidson Sportster - she harnessed the power of the internet to track down dealers that might be able to help her. So when she found her wheels, she thought she'd turn to the net to help her finance the purchase.

Ms Winstone needed £5,250 for the bike, so she surfed to see what deals were available. As she banks with Abbey National, she visited www.abbeynational.co.uk.

"It was just so easy. I did it then and there." She filled in her details online, submitted the form, then got an email telling her the loan application had been approved. She was then sent a hard copy of the agreement which she signed and sent back. "The money then went into my account and I paid for the bike on Switch.

"I'm a big fan of the net. I do lots of surfing and make lots of purchases," adds Ms Winstone, who lives in east London and is paying back the loan over five years. Unlike some people, she is not worried about security when arranging her finances online. "It's worked perfectly fine for me. It's so easy - you can do it in your lunch hour at work."

She is one of the growing number who are eschewing walking down the high street or phoning round in favour of switching on to the convenience offered by the net.

Internet banks Egg (www.egg.com) and Smile (www.smile.co.uk) both offer personal loans at fairly competitive rates, and several of the biggest traditional banks and building societies offer loans online, with some giving better rates to internet customers than to people applying in person at a branch or over the phone.

For example, borrowing £2,000 from Lloyds TSB would incur a rate of 19.9 APR at the local branch, but only 15.8 APR at Loansdirect, its internet and phone operation (www.loan-direct.co.uk).

Tesco Personal Finance (www.tesco.com/finance) the joint venture between the supermarket giant and Royal Bank of Scotland, is selling 15% of its personal loans via the internet.

It sometimes offers promotional rates to online customers. "We see it as obviously a very popular channel for customers," says a spokesman.

However, a glance at the latest personal loans data from Moneyfacts magazine reveals that by and large, bricks win over clicks: the best deals tend to come from the more traditional lenders.

For someone borrowing £5,000 over three years who doesn't want to take out repayment protection insurance, Northern Rock offers the best deal: 8.8 APR, which translates into 36 monthly payments of £157.75 (a total outlay of £5,679).

Close behind are Lombard Direct (9.9 APR, £160.11 a month); Vivid, which is funded by Yorkshire Bank (10.5 APR, £161.39); and American Express Bank (10.7 APR, £162.10).

To be fair, Egg, Tesco and Smile all score fairly highly. Egg's rate is 10.9 APR (£162.34 a month), while Tesco's is 10.8 APR (£162.47) and Smile's is 11.9 APR (£164.34).

When looking for a personal loan it's important to shop around, as different providers come out best depending on how much you are looking to borrow.

Remember that while some companies are offering more flexible products, taking out a personal loan can often mean tying yourself into paying back a large sum over quite a long time.

Usually there are penalties (typically a fee of one or two months' interest) for clearing the debt early. You may find that an authorised overdraft serves your needs better.

For borrowing over a shorter period, a credit card may be a more effective tool. Most offer up to eight weeks' interest-free credit before you need to settle the account.

fields.headline: Chain-locked buyers seek bridgebuilder
fields.standfirst: There are few things more frustrating than being trapped when trying to move house. Elizabeth Langton looks for solutions
fields.trailText: There are few things more frustrating than being trapped when trying to move house. Elizabeth Langton looks for solutions.
fields.body:
It is said time and again that moving house is among life's most stressful experiences, but as spring gets under way house hunters are taking to the streets undeterred.

The rush of excitement that follows an offer evaporates all too quickly when buyers and sellers find themselves sitting in a property chain. It may be sunny outside but they're inside - watching the telephone, like teenagers waiting for a date, waiting to hear from dusty solicitors and perky estate agents.

Homebuyers stuck in a chain might think all is lost but chains can be got moving again. More and more people are choosing to sell their property and renting until they find the house they want, says Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy, chief executive of the National Association of Estate Agents. Government-commissioned research on home buying and selling revealed nearly a third of those selling intended to do this.

But some might find the thought of moving a house full of furniture twice too daunting. Also, in today's crazy hot spots, sellers might find they lose out if prices rise in the intervening period between selling and buying another home.

In Scotland, the system is structured to avoid chains. Once a date is agreed for taking over the new property, it is legally binding. The downside is that Scots families may have to stay with friends if there is a gap between leaving their old home and moving into a new one.

In England and Wales, the most well-known means of kick-starting the process is the bridging loan, where home buyers borrow the money to proceed although their home has yet to be sold. But in the past, lenders got their fingers burnt with bridging loans.

When property values fell in the early 90s people who had taken out bridging loans found they couldn't sell or got a greatly reduced price, says Ray Boulger of mortgage brokers John Charcol. He points out that building societies withdrew from the field altogether after a spate of problems.

The Halifax, Britain's biggest lender, refuses to offer any chain-breaking products at the moment. However, the bank hasn't ruled out making them available in the future, says a spokesman. "In the past they were risky because you could end up with two mortgages and a property they couldn't sell. But we will work with the government if there is a need to devise something in the future."

A buyer's own bank should be their first port of call, says Mr Boulger. For a typical bridging loan, borrowers will be charged a 1% arrangement fee and pay 3-4% over the bank base (rate) in interest.

There are two types of bridging loan: open and closed. The first is taken out by borrowers who want to go ahead with buying a new home but who need to continue paying the mortgage on their existing home until it is sold.

Borrowers who have exchanged contracts but have different completion dates on sale and purchase usually take out closed loans. The loan is needed to bridge the gap for a fixed period of time. Both are costly ways out of a jam although open-ending loans are financially riskier and "dangerous in a falling or volatile property market", says Mr Boulger.

When loans aren't an option, members of the chain rely on estate agents to keep the whole thing going. The government research found that chain breakdown is "primarily a result of buyers pulling out of transactions, not of sellers changing their minds".

"The transaction will only move at the speed of the slowest link," says Mr Dunsmore-Hardy. "For sellers, it can be helpful to have someone lined up in case the whole thing falls through.

"Most important is to know through your estate agent who's involved in the chain. Good communication is vitally important and for estate agents to find out at each stage what point the sale has reached," he says.

"Your agent doesn't get paid until the transaction is complete so the agent is the catalyst in the process who will try to speed things up," he adds.

While ministers are happy to see more chain-breaking products, they believe more loans are not the answer for most people. Instead, they argue that proposals for speeding up the process will cut the chances of the chain breaking down.

The seller's information pack will provide most of the information and documents needed by a buyer up front. Faster searches and quicker processing of mortgage applications will also help.

But until the changes are introduced buyers and sellers must hassle estate agents and pray that there's someone with wads of cash or a first-time buyer in the chain somewhere.

webTitle: Only women walk on two legs

fields.headline: Only women walk on two legs
fields.standfirst: "The kiss-and-sell girls are not anti-feminists, but differently-abled feminists. Every army has soldiers who do their best work on their backs"
fields.trailText: "The kiss-and-sell girls are not anti-feminists, but differently-abled feminists. Every army has soldiers who do their best work on their backs"
fields.body:
Sometimes only a good dose of triumphalism will do to get a party going, like Free, by Ultra Nate, and lately it seems to me that feminism has been sadly neglectful of itself in this department. I must have heard a million whither-the-future-of-feminism debates recently, and with a few honourable exceptions (Polly Toynbee on Radio 4's Woman's Hour being the latest) there seems to be a real reluctance on the part of even righteous sisters to say "Yay, team! Way to go!"

Female newspaper columnists, in particular, seem utterly devoted to the idea that feminism has gone down the plughole, though how much of this is sincere and how much a smart career move, is hard to say. For all columnists, cheerily reporting that we're living in the best of all possible times isn't much of a story, hence the Apocalypse-Now-(Please) tone of much of their pontificating - reminding me once again of that great line by Sparks: "My parents say the world is cruel/I think that they prefer it cruel."

Take kiss-and-sell girls; the proud existence of such young women isn't a sign of the death of feminism, but proof that even the sort of woman who once relied on the approval of men in order to make a living (ie, blonde ones with lots of teeth and silicon) would now rather humiliate and exploit men for a living instead, which can only be an improvement. Whereas once, even as recently as the 70s, they would have been silent and grateful for getting a go at the Big Guy's dick, now they are noisy and mocking, and invite television cameras to witness their triumph. These girls are not anti-feminists, but differently-abled feminists, and it ill behoves the rest of us to sneer at them; every army has a certain number of soldiers who do their best work on their backs.

In this very paper recently, the brilliant Shane Watson thanked God she didn't have a teenage daughter, because how could she tell that daughter that she owed it to herself to make the most of her brain via education when the example of Luciana Morad - set up for life after wringing a bit of rancid sperm out of one wrinkly mulit-millionaire - is hung in front of her? Well, for a start, not many girls are as sweet and charitable as Luciana and, no matter what the pay-off, would not dream of letting Mick Jagger anywhere near them. And second, to my way of thinking, one of the many jobs of feminism is to make nasty, sexist men as angry as possible. I don't suppose Mick Jagger gives a toss how many girls go off and use their brains to get good educations and respectable jobs. But he sure as hell yelped when Miss Morad took him to the cleaners, even if he did get off with a measly £12,000 a month. Case closed in favour of Private Morad.

Similarly, the Kept Woman Look currently making itself known in the rag mags isn't an anti-feminist backlash either, but merely fashion being itself again - like with using fur - because the strain of trying to do "integrity" and "intelligence" got too much for it, bless it. The Kept Woman Look on the catwalks doesn't signify the reverse of feminist gains any more than the use of fur means that animal-rights campaigning is undergoing a reversal of fortune. If anything, they are both getting bigger and fiercer; it's just that fashion has the attention span of a gnat.

The difference is that, generally, women are buying the Kept Woman Look with their own money, and wearing it as a sort of fancy dress; whereas in Georgian London, it emerged last week, one in eight women were actually prostitutes - a rather embarrassing fact for right-wing female commentators to deal with, one would think, considering that the sexual degradation of women was meant to have started in the 1960s. One in eight! Just imagine - that means that if Melanie Phillips, Anne Atkins, Mary Kenny, Ann Widdecombe, Janet Daley, Ruth Lea, Barbara Amiel and Jeanette Kupfermann had actually been around in the allegedly well-ordered, pre-feminist days they long for so much, then one of them would be sashaying down Ladies Miles wearing fishnets! Don't all rush at once, girls.

It is proof of the way feminism is still devalued compared with the struggles of other oppressed groups, that we would never dream of asking whether the search for black equality was over, or the struggle for gay rights - even though both of these movements are nothing like the politically coherent, organised movements they seemed to be in the 70s. There are no more Martin Luther Kings or even Malcolm Xs; instead, there is Puff Daddy with his "ghetto fabulous"-ness and friendship with Donald Trump, or a variety of young black men who have made fortunes calling black women bitches and ho's for the delectation of an almost entirely white male audience. (In this, gangsta rap is just the latest twist on the old Southern plantation saying, "A bad nigger makes a good minstrel", just as boxing was before it. Has any group of already demonised people ever done so exactly what society expected from them as the gangstas?). The gay revolution has been similarly consumed by the desire for lifestyle above all else, and its few radical leaders firmly shut out in the wilderness; personally, I have heard Peter Tatchell slandered a hundred times - but only ever by other gay men, who consider him to be a sad, anorak-wearing party-pooper.

The reason there may appear to be less of a women's movement than there was 30 years ago, is because people only look like a homogenous, generic, faceless mass when they are a long way down the pecking order; as women rise closer to the light of power, they will necessarily fragment and look different from each other. There is also the question of women's ridiculous level of modesty; we are brought up to be so much nicer than men that, even while going about our revolution, we will simper, "What, this old thing? I've had it for, oh, about 90 years! It's not even mine - borrowed it off Emmeline. It looked much better on her . . ."

At the end of the day, animals walk on four legs, and men on three - their penises, the poor dears, will always prevent them from thinking clearly. Only women walk on two legs, and on these two legs they will one day walk the earth they have inherited from the lesser species. And on the day we inherit it, do you know what we'll say? "A whole one, just for me ? Oh, I couldn't . You have some - go on! Help yourself!"

And that's why we're so damn cool.

The gay revolution has been similarly consumed by the desire for lifestyle above all else, and its few radical leaders firmly shut out in the wilderness; personally, I have heard Peter Tatchell slandered a hundred times - but only ever by other gay men, who consider him to be a sad, anorak-wearing party-pooper. The reason there may appear to be less of a women's movement than there was 30 years ago, is because people only look like a homogenous, generic, faceless mass when they are a long way down the pecking order; as women rise closer to the light of power, they will necessarily fragment and look different from each other. There is also the question of women's ridiculous level of modesty; we are brought up to be so much nicer than men that, even while going about our revolution, we will simper, "What, this old thing? I've had it for, oh, about 90 years! It's not even mine - borrowed it off Emmeline. It looked much better on her . . ." At the end of the day, animals walk on four legs, and men on three - their penises, the poor dears, will always prevent them from thinking clearly. Only women walk on two legs, and on these two legs they will one day walk the earth they have inherited from the lesser species. And on the day we inherit it, do you know what we'll say? "A whole one, just for me ? Oh, I couldn't . You have some - go on! Help yourself!" And that's why we're so damn cool.

webTitle: A good time to be a child

fields.headline: A good time to be a child
fields.standfirst: "Despite the extraordinary expansion of the internet, there remain huge numbers of people who are excluded from it. This is alarming"
fields.trailText: Alexander Chancellor: "Despite the extraordinary expansion of the internet, there remain huge numbers of people who are excluded from it. This is alarming"
fields.body:
While crawling along the M4 on the way to the West Country for Easter, I switched on the radio in the car to find a discussion going on about the art of grandparenting. I hadn't realised that this was a subject that worried people. Grandparenthood, I had imagined, was just a state of being. I hadn't known it involved any special responsibilities or skills. But here was the distinguished ex-editor of the Guardian, Peter Preston, complaining quite seriously that none of the literature he had read on the subject contained any guidance for grandfathers about their role. There was plenty of advice for grandmothers, he said, but none for people like him.

My wife and I happened to be on our way to stay in Somerset with our daughter, son-in-law, and their three young children, so I began to feel rather guilty that I had never thought about this problem before. But by the time Easter was over, the guilt had lifted. I really couldn't see what the role of a grandfather is except to be friendly and attentive when required.

My main defect as a grandfather has hitherto been to demand from my grandchildren more attention than they have wanted to give; but I have tried to cure myself of this, and it seems to me that a mutually satisfactory balance has now been struck. I hope they agree. I cannot, of course, speak too highly of my grandchildren, who consist of two girls, aged five and six, and a boy, who celebrated his second birthday on Good Friday. They are affectionate, lively, original and nice-looking, which is more than one can say of lots of people. They are also humorous. After the two girls were evicted from our dining-room in London the other day for making a din during lunch, the eldest kept popping her head round the door to tell us to stop talking because we were interfering with their efforts to make a noise in the hall. That was cheeky, but funny.

To the credit of their parents, they are not over-disciplined but are generally well-behaved all the same. They also seem to be particularly happy at the moment. I wonder if this could have anything to do with the fact that their father has banned television from their new home. At the time, I thought this a little harsh, as they had been in the habit of watching Mary Poppins on the video several times a week. I also thought it a little mannered, rather like cutting off the phone or dispensing with electric light in favour of oil lamps. But I am almost converted to the idea now. It's amazing how little you miss television if it's not there.

I won't get rid of my own television set, because I sometimes like watching the news or current-affairs programmes, and television provides undemanding entertainment when you are tired. But then I am a grandfather, not a child. Children don't like current-affairs programmes; and when they are tired, they ought to go to bed. Children are lucky because they are spared the widespread anxieties generated by the technological revolution and the new economy.

Despite the extraordinary expansion of the internet, there remain huge numbers of people who - whether by choice or fear or necessity - are excluded from it. This is more alarming than not having a TV set, of which the only disadvantage is that one cannot understand half of what is written in the newspapers and the magazines; and that doesn't matter very much. But estrangement from the new economy is a different kettle of fish. It means losing contact with how the world works. It can give rise to depression and even panic. Being a journalist, I have had to acquire at least some elementary knowledge of the possibilities of the internet, and I am frankly fascinated by them. But even so, I feel disorientated by the almost limitless amount of unverifiable information available online and by the suspension of traditional economic law in the dot.com universe.

If I find it almost impossible to grasp what is going on out there, at least I am not alone. Traditional businesses do not understand it either. They desperately try to show they are on the ball by setting up online shopping or banking, but then find that their chain stores or bank branches are under threat. They seek new recruits for their internet subsidiaries, only to find that the qualified candidates are in their 20s, wear T-shirts and baseball caps, and demand not only stock options but much higher salaries than their seasoned managers in suits and ties.

American companies such as Ford, Delta and American Airlines have resorted to giving free home computers to all of their employees in order stop the old ones feeling left out. In short, this is a good time to be a child. Children can enjoy innocence now, but will grow up to be natural participants in this brave new world.

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: Speed the plough, says Matthew Fort, but don't hurry the Harrow. It's far too good
fields.trailText: Speed the plough, says Matthew Fort, but don't hurry the Harrow. It's far too good
fields.body:
As I waited for Phineas to come back from a wash and brush-up, I couldn't help but eavesdrop on the conversation at the table behind me. I had noticed two elderly ladies taking up their lunchtime stations just after we had arrived, and assumed they had dropped in for their weekly catch-up on domestic news. You know, how Emily was getting on after her bladder op, what was Kenneth doing about young George, how Bill was getting on after having Marjorie put down and wasn't it awful what had happened to Florence. Instead of which I was treated to a thoroughly illuminating discussion of their e-mail and internet experiences. Blimey, I thought, the rural idyll is taking on a rather different tone in these electronic times.

Rural is where we were, deep in deepest rural Wiltshire, to be precise. So deep, in fact, that it had taken us a good deal longer than expected to track down The Harrow Inn, parked, as it was, up a little back road away from the hustle and bustle of Little Bledwyn. The hustle and bustle of Little Bledwyn amounted to maybe one car every 20 minutes, as far as I could see. And that Tuesday, most cars happened to be mine going backwards and forwards through the village in search of The Harrow.

Mind you, it was worth the effort. The first thing that caught my eye was the wine list, not surprisingly as Phineas and I both needed a quick refresher after our questing. The list wasn't the size of the Domesday Book, or any of that kind of nonsense. It was simply very well structured, sensibly put together, covered a surprising amount of ground, gave unusually useful information written by someone with a distinctive cast of mind, and was very reasonably priced by London standards. So a bottle of Rully Premier Cru, a serious wine with bounce and breadth, was a reasonable £24. I could have drunk for less, but when you come across a fine wine at a price several cuts below the restaurant average, drink it is my view.

With that onerous duty out of the way, I felt ready to settle back and enjoy the agreeable plainness of the room, the sturdy unadorned nature of the tables, the rather comfortable dusty ox-blood colour of the wall, the lack of frills and frou-frou. It spoke pleasantly of common sense and a concentration on the essentials, being decent grub and cheery service.

The grub aspires to more than mere decency. Grilled scallops in their shells with ginger and chilli dressing, fried foie gras with fresh truffle dressing, confit of duck with wild mushrooms or chargrilled fillet of Aberdeen Angus complete with provenance and pedigree speak of a certain ambition; considerable ambition if the price range (first courses were £6-£9, main courses £9-£17) and the weight of fish dishes is anything to go by - 10 dishes out of a total 17.

Phineas was seduced by a sophisticated turf'n'surf variation along the lines of seared scallops and sweetbreads with truffle dressing, which he was keen to precede with fried wild mushrooms, chorizo and spinach. I, too, fell to fish, what with fresh crab timbale and tandoori fillets with mint yoghurt, one of the two dishes of the day. The Indian influence of the tandoor aside, the chef at The Harrow clearly has a questing spirit when it comes to cooking influences, and, for the most part, the skill to pull it off. It wasn't cooking of subtlety. Slam-bang flavours seemed the order of the day, and why not?

We won't examine the pedigree of the "wild" mushrooms too closely. I will only say that virtually all restaurant "wild" mushrooms these days have as much of the field, wood and hedgerow about them as I have. These were as "wild" as any, and copious with it, piled high with the spinach, spiked with lively chorizo. It's a pretty winning combination whichever way you look at it, particularly when immaculately dressed with a glittering vinaigrette.

The crab timbale had me in its thrall, too, but then crab, if it is sweet and fresh, usually does. This may not have been the sweetest, freshest crab I've ever had, but it hadn't been mucked about with too much, came in generous supply, and still provided one of the more delicate and rewarding pleasures of life.

I was more curious about the tandoori seafood fillets with mint yoghurt than really convinced that I would find a compelling version of such a dish in a pub in the middle of Wiltshire. Let's be truthful, you woudn't, either.

I had to eat my thoughts and the dish because it was pretty pukka stuff. I rather doubt that there was an actual tandoor oven in the kitchen, but the spicing on each fish - sea bass, haddock and one I am not quite sure about, was distinctly clean and clear, not killing the flavours of the fish. The mint yoghurt was sharp and cool and gunky, as it should be, nicely offsetting the heat of the spice.

The seared scallops and sweetbreads set an altogether different pace, but was equally well handled. The scallops were sweet as a nut, caramelised top and bottom and just cooked through. The sweetbreads also benefited from well-tempered heat - they are as easy to overcook as scallops. The truffle dressing was more notional than forceful in the flavour stakes, but was a nice thought, and there was enough well-defined dressing to keep Phineas happy.

He was happy to pass on pudding and rest there, having, he told me, a formidable evening ahead, and so tackled a selection of cheeses. They were an exemplary display of very well kept examples of the British and French cheesemakers' art, a sufficiently rare experience even these days as to celebrate. I had a pudding, of which I have a keen sense of pleasure but no detailed memory whatsoever. This is probably unfair on the pudding.

The bill was a distinctly Londonish £83.20, of which booze and other non-food items accounted for some £32.25. This kind of takes it out of the normal gastro-pub realms and into proper restaurant prices. The cooking justifies this. It is confident and distinctive. The wine list and service are, too. It still seems a bit on the pricey side to me, but it didn't look as if the jolly lunchers would mind that much. Of course, whether you mind is entirely up to you

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck falls out of love with Sancerre
fields.body:
Alert readers of this column over the years cannot have failed to notice a certain antipathy mixed with disdain, plus a large measure of disappoinment whenever Sancerre is mentioned. The reasons are sentimental. I discovered Sancerre in the late 60s and fell in love with its concentrated gooseberry richness and distinctive mineral tang. However, by the middle 80s, when the spectacular sauvignon blancs from Marlborough, in New Zealand, first arrived here to redefine the grape's grassy undertone, Sancerre, less concentrated than it had been, had long forfeited my affections. The exceptions were few, and are so today, though the 1998 vintage was the best for a while, and some of the 1999s might appear here in the coming months.

In preparation for this, may I present three sauvingons from the three countries that hold out so much more excietment and good value for this grape? They are all available at Tesco, now the world s leading wine merchant (on the basis that the 150 million bottles of wine it will probably sell this year is more than any other single retailer). From New Zealand, there is Lawsons Dry Hills Sauvignon Blanc 1999 (16.5 points, out of 20, £7.99); from South Africa comes Firefinch Sauvignon Blanc 1999 (16 points, £3.99); from Chile there is Vina Casablanca Santa Isabel Sauvignon Blanc 1998 (16 points, £5.99).

The Kiwi is immensely classy. The fruit coats the taste buds like delicate emulsion: tense, dry, mineralised, and lingering. The Cape wine has an attractive herbaceous richness, yet overall it is very dry and slightly intimidating with its compressed, stalky, under-ripe gooseberry fruit. But it is great with fish, smoked or poached, and superb with shellfish and, frankly, it is an amazing price for such class.

The Chilean is very clotted and forward, but this relents on the finish to provide a measure of crispness. A food wine paramountly - rich scallop and sole dishes spring to mind - it is, the classicist will moan, no Sancerre. To which I am, sadly, forced to respond, 'thank heavens'.

Tesco has a further white wine that will interest serious students of unlikely marriages. It is Nagyrede Estate Barrel Aged Pinot Grigio/Zenit 1998, from Hungary (16 points, £3.99), and a surprising little throat teaser it is, being highly stylised, with rich-going-dry fruit, and a solidly engaging finish. It offers terrific price for the class, even though some might say that the Italian pinot grigio in bed with the local Hungarian grape zenit (itself a crossing of two other Magyar grapes) is a preposterous amalgamation. This chutzpah is part of its charm.

Tesco has recently put on shelf several new reds. Winds Of Change Cabernet/Pinotage 1999 (16 points, £4.99), from South Africa, has superbly jammy richness balanced by dry, earthy tannins providing perfect quaffability. It has a savoury undertone to its exuberance, which keeps it serious, and it's just coming into selected stores now. Carmesi Garnacha/ Tempranillo Calatayud 1998 (16 points, £4.99), from Spain, parades great gobbets of blackcurrant and plum fruit with a summery richness of the earthy variety.

Woolpunda Shiraz 1998 (16 points, £3.99 until May 9), from Australia, has very cushy fruit of no little style and it is wholly without pretension. It has poise to its plummy depths, and most Tesco branches have it. Gouts et Couleurs Premium Cuvée Cabernet Sauvignon Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (16 points, £4.99) pulsates gently with dry, impressively compacted blackcurrant fruit with elegant tannins, and it's at most branches, too.

And finally at Tesco, there is La Sansoure Corbieres Reserve 1999 (15 points, £3.99). It is very soft, very ripely fruity - the Midi does not immediately spring to mind or palate - and it is extremely drinkable and very good value.

Last this week, two golden Aussies at the CWS, on offer until May 7. Jacaranda Hill Semillon 1999 (15 points, £2.99) has fresh fruit and finishes with a good layer of lemon tanginess. Great to quaff and great with fish, it represents a terrific bargain for early season marine barbecues. As does Barramundi Sparkling (15.5 points, £4.49) which is one of the crispest, most entertaining Aussie bubblies around.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Ham it up with bacon
fields.trailText: Ham it up with bacon
fields.body:
The subject
Pickled pork - and if only it were that easy!

The basics
People have always used salt to preserve part of their just-slaughtered pigs. When it's the shoulder or leg, it's ham. When it's the belly or loin, it's bacon. Nowadays, we don't need the preservative action, but we still crave bacon. It's made wherever there are pigs. And where there are not pigs, people try to recreate its flavour using alternative forms of protein.

The details
I hoped you wouldn't ask. For a product that contains just three or four ingredients (pork, salt, some form of nitrate), bacon is horribly complicated. For instance, the pork may be wonderful or woeful, the salt may be a dry cure or a liquid brine (with endless permutations), and there are hundreds of styles to choose from. Bottom line? And the cheapness is an illusion, since the unnatural water just cooks off as a white sludge while preventing proper browning. That's why many people associate baconly beatitude with a dry cure, and why supermarkets are catering for that prejudice. With good results: Safeway's 'The Best', Tesco's 'Finest Sweetcure', and M&S 'Butchers Style' all impressed The Knowledge. But brine cures can, in the right hands, be just as good as dry. Hands that usually belong to smaller producers. A Knowledge-able trio: for dry-cure, Richard Woodall in Cumbria; for brined, from rare breeds of porker, Heal Farm in Devon; for a distinctive rind-less brined version, Ramsay of Carluke.

fields.headline: Sunday School
fields.standfirst: Traditional roast dinner may be an institution, says Robin Stummer, but the Prior family wanted something new. We sent Rosie Sykes, the Kitchen Doctor, to help out.
fields.trailText: Traditional roast dinner may be an institution, says Robin Stummer, but the Prior family wanted something new. We sent Rosie Sykes, the Kitchen Doctor, to help out.
fields.body:
Gerald Prior - father of five grown-ups, grandfather of two toddlers, and erstwhile maker of reproduction Roman oil lamps and food bowls - greeted the arrival of the Kitchen Doctor with mild bemusement. For more years than he cares to remember, Gerald and his wife, Valerie, have had an arrangement: "I open the wine. That's my job. My wife does the cooking."

It's a division of labour they claim has worked admirably, which is just as well, because Sunday lunch at the Priors is a gargantuan affair: their record is 21 people, but most weeks they'll have nine, 10, 12 kith and kin to cater for. This regular, large-scale dining has a purpose beyond mere pandering to gluttony, however. "Sitting down to eat together is the one way we can keep in touch," says Valerie. "None of our children has a house large enough to take us all, so we always eat here!"

"It's the family feast," adds Gerald. "We do other things together, but not en masse . It's been said before, but a family that eats together stays together. My wife's an excellent cook, but we tend to go for roasts." And the family was, by popular agreement, a bit fed up with them. Cue Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, her assistant du jour, Elizabeth, and half a ton of fresh meat and veg. This particular Sunday at the Priors' Edwardian villa in Horndean, just north of Portsmouth, promised to be like no other, not least because, due to logistical factors, it was a Monday. Mere detail - on with the show.

Last things first: dessert. "Middle" son Alex, 24, was seized by the KD and put to work preparing iced chocolate pudding. Within minutes, he was whisking egg whites, melting chocolate and finger-dipping as if he'd never done anything else. He assured Rosie that he worked in the electronic communications industry, but she didn't believe him. By the time his chocolate mix was ready for the freezer, a small crowd - proud mother, beaming grandmother Kitty, sleepy baby niece Becky and big sister Catherine - had gathered around him.

Rosie took over, cackling "Slimmer's delight!" as she slopped big choccy dollops into a tin. Next, she moved on to the pastry for her apple tart. Again, Alex did his bit, inviting more admiration.

Watching the KD at work in one's kitchen is a strange business. As with Rosie's other patients, Valerie was caught between a desire just to let her get on with the job and a powerful instinct to monitor goings-on very closely. "I feel so useless," she said. "I'm not used to watching in my kitchen, but I do want to watch. Normally, for Sunday dinner, I start cooking at 2pm, and it's ready around 6pm. When my mother-in-law came, before she died, we were a perfect team - I cooked and she did the washing-up."

The desserts done for now, Rosie announced the next phase - "This is called orderly baked vegetables!" - and set about hacking the veg into cubes, laying them in regimented lines in a baking dish, and administering the last rites with olive oil and sundry herbs before consigning them to the oven. "Bloody scrummy, isn't it?" said Rosie, lost in a world of her own. No one could argue.

Minds then turned to meat, and a fair-sized mass of beef and chicken (from PR Hatch Family Butchers, of nearby Cowplain) was portioned and sliced, ready for the pan. For Valerie, this was a welcome break from habit: "My father once called me 'a good, plain cook'," she said, laughing and rolling her eyes heavenward. "'You always get a good, plain roast!'" But then three-year-old Matthew, who was going through a Buzz Lightyear phase and would speak only when addressed as "Buzz", entered the fray. Chaos loomed, so Valerie reassumed command of her domain, and made merry with the onion, pepper, chicken and sherry.

There was only one item of unfinished business to attend to. Still glowing from his earlier successes, Alex was singled out to make the caramel. "Don't stir it like that!" cautioned Rosie. "Just watch it!" Alex stared intently at the pan, making sure that its contents didn't catch. Minutes later, the sweet brown goo was poured into two dishes, where it suddenly set rigid, like a freeze-frame in an action movie. Chopped apple was placed on top, then covered in Alex's pastry and baked. Three-quarters of an hour later, four generations of the Prior clan gathered in the kitchen for Alex's supreme moment of glory. Gently, he flipped the tarts and . . . another triumph. Modestly, he brushed aside all praise, contenting himself with an "it was nothing, really" grin.

The herby beef and chicken dishes emerged bubbling from the oven just as yet more slavering Priors arrived at the front door. To avoid being crushed in the throng, KD packed her knives and beat a retreat. One big happy family? You bet.

All recipes serve six.

Braised beef with a crust

50g butter (or beef dripping)

3 large onions, finely sliced

3 sticks celery, diced

2 large carrots, finely diced

3 cloves of garlic, finely grated

2lb beef for braising (topside, silverside or chuck steak are best)

2 tbsp seasoned flour

1 pint stock (beef, preferably, but chicken or veg is just as good)

1 good glug balsamic vinegar

1 good pinch caster sugar

Salt and pepper

1 bouquet garni

1 baguette, sliced

1 small jar Dijon mustard

A little fresh parsley, chopped

Cut the beef into 2cm strips across the grain, and toss in the prepared flour. Melt half of the butter in a large, oven-proof, heavy-based pan, and gently sauté the vegetables, along with the sugar and garlic, until nicely browned, then remove with a slotted spoon. Heat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2.

Add the rest of the fat to the pan, and brown the beef all over. Once all the meat is done, return the veg to the pan, sprinkle over the rest of the flour, stir to incorporate, then pour on the vinegar, stock and enough water just to cover. Add the bouquet garni, cover the pan, and cook in the oven for two to two-and-a-half hours. Stir from time to time.

Slice the baguette into 1cm slices on a slight diagonal, and generously spread one side with mustard. Half an hour before the end of the cooking, remove the lid from the pot, lay the bread, mustard-side down, on top of the beef, covering the whole braise, brush the top with a little butter, then sprinkle over the parsley. When the bread is crisp and golden, the dish is ready to serve.

Orderly baked vegetables

5 red onions, finely sliced

3 red peppers, cored, deseeded and cut into quarters

2 aubergines, cut in half lengthways and then into 1cm slices

3 medium courgettes, cut in half lengthways and then into 1cm slices

4 large waxy potatoes, peeled, cut in half and then into 1cm slices

350g passata

10 tbsp olive oil

2 cloves garlic, crushed

A few sprigs each of mint, parsley, basil, rosemary, roughly chopped

Pre-heat the oven to 190C/375F/gas mark 5. Oil a rectangular dish, cover the bottom with onion, blob about 100g of passata randomly over the top, season generously and add six tablespoons of water. Now place tidy, overlapping lines of each veg on top. Sprinkle basil on the pepper, mint on the courgette, parsley on the aubergine and rosemary on the potatoes, then season.

Mix the garlic into the remaining passata, season, and drizzle over the vegetables, followed by the rest of the oil. Bake for about an hour-and- a-half, basting from time to time - everything should be cooked at the same time - the aubergine will be very soft, but that doesn't matter as that makes it all the juicer. (You could cook this in the same oven as the beef, in which case it'd take about two hours.)

Chicken with sherry

1 large corn-fed chicken (2-2.25kg), jointed

150ml olive oil

5 Spanish onions, peeled and sliced

4 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed

2 green peppers, cored, deseeded and sliced

Salt and pepper

375ml Oloroso sherry (or other dry, full-bodied, dark sherry)

350ml chicken stock

Fresh tarragon

50g pinenuts

50g sultanas

First fry the chicken in the oil until golden-brown in colour, lift it out with a slotted spoon, then sauté the onion, garlic and peppers in the same pan until soft. Return the meat to the pan, add the sherry, and simmer gently until it has reduced by half. Now add the stock, seasoning and a couple of sprigs of tarragon - but not too much, as it can be overpowering. Bring it all to the boil, turn the heat right down and simmer very gently until the chicken is tender. This should take about half-an-hour.

Remove the chicken, place in a warm dish and cover. Reduce the sauce a little over a high heat, then stir in most of the pinenuts and sultanas. Pour the sauce over the chicken, and sprinkle the remaining nuts and sultanas on top. Serve with the mustard-seed potatoes (below) and a green salad.

Mustard-seed potatoes

750g new potatoes

30g grainy mustard

2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed

1 tbsp lemon juice

1 tbsp white-wine vinegar

45ml olive oil

45ml sunflower oil

6 spring onions, chopped

Wash the potatoes, cover with cold water in a pan, season with salt, and bring to the boil. Simmer until just cooked. Mix the mustard and garlic together in a jar, then stir in the lemon juice and vinegar, whisk in the oils and season. Seal the jar until the potatoes are ready. Drain the potatoes and tip them into a warm serving bowl. Give the jar of dressing a shake, pour over the potatoes, toss well, stir in the spring onions and serve immediately.

French apple tart

For the sweet pastry

125g plain flour

55g butter

55g caster sugar

2 egg yolks

2 lemons, zested

For the tart filling

85g caster sugar

80g butter

6 tbsp water

5-6 eating apples (Braeburn's or Cox's English pippins are good, as their ruddy skins look lovely)

Place the pastry ingredients in a blender and whizz until they just come together - over-blending will make the pastry tough. Turn out on to a work surface and knead lightly until you have a smooth dough. Leave

to rest for at least half an hour.

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/ gas mark 6. Now make the caramel: place 60g sugar, 55g butter and the water in a saucepan, bring to the boil and simmer until it starts to change colour. Stir until the caramel becomes golden, then remove from the heat at once, and pour into the base of a tart dish. Swirl it around to get an even layer - you have to do this straight away, or the caramel will set in blobs (in the event of such a disaster, pop the set caramel in the oven for a few minutes to soften, then swirl it again).

Core the apples, cut them into quarters, then slice quite fine. Arrange on top of the caramel, bearing in mind that the tart will be turned out - you want to make sure that the bottom row looks good, as it will be the top of the finished dish. Sprinkle with all but one tablespoon of the remaining sugar and dot with the rest of the butter. Roll out the pastry, and lay it over the apples, covering them completely. Trim the edges, and brush the top with water. Sprinkle over the last of the sugar, and bake for about 40 minutes, until the pastry is crisp. Turn out immediately, and serve with crème frache or Greek yoghurt.

Iced chocolate pudding

For the meringue

2 egg whites

110g sugar

For the pudding

125g dark chocolate, broken into smallish pieces

2 tbsp brandy

2 tbsp water

200ml double cream

30g nuts (I favour hazelnuts, lightly toasted and roughly chopped)

First, make the meringue. Preheat the oven to 135C/275F/gas mark 1. Whisk the egg whites until they are stiff but not dry, add half the sugar and whisk again - the mixture should become shiny. Add the rest of the sugar and whisk again. Spoon or pipe on to a greased tray, and bake for up to an hour-and-a-half, until the meringues are dried out but not brown.

Now make the pudding. Put the chocolate, brandy and water in a pan, and melt over a gentle heat, stirring constantly. Put to one side to cool. Crush the meringues. Lightly whip the cream, fold in three-quarters of the chocolate mixture, and add meringues and nuts. Make sure everything is well incorporated, then swirl the rest of the chocolate through the mix. Pour into a lined loaf tin and freeze for three to four hours, until firm to the touch. Transfer to the fridge 10 minutes before serving.

This is good in summer with strawberries, raspberries, etc, and in winter with a thin coffee or ginger custard.

fields.headline: The Net Addict
fields.trailText: An erotic fiasco
fields.body:
I convinced Migraine Alan to change our love venue to the Cliveden. As a Tory, tradition matters to him, and I was just as happy. Our congress would be the apotheosis of Tony's vision: rich and poor (I earn several K, Alan barely earns one) coming together and sharing the burden: I'd pay for the room, dinner was on him, and we both bought the Big Issue at the traffic lights on the way. Someone told me our bedroom was where Christine Keeler had soothed men exhausted by the weight of Empire. Since Alan only bears the weight of cellular phone price wars, I thought he would be flattered. So, there I was, full of lust, white truffles and Pouilly Fume, waiting in my sheer bra and mini-briefs (www.agentprovocateur.com). Alan came out of the fabulous en-suite, as ravishing as Hugh Grant in his dressing gown and co-ordinated pyjamas (www.hackett.co.uk). He kissed me... Oh! It was heaven, but then... 'Ann... Oh, Ann...' he whispered hoarsely. 'Who is she?' I shrieked. You won't believe this: it turned out he's obsessed with Ann Widdecombe. 'Don't be pathetic,' I hissed. 'Can't help it, I went to boarding school (www.boardingschools.hobsons.com). Please help me,' he sobbed. We talked - and talked. I thought I was going to be Jennifer Lopez but I ended up being Susie Orbach. Enough is enough.

Back at work, the falling price of e-shares kept me busy. At home, I drowned my sorrows in a fabulous Ribera del Duero Ribera del Duero as rich and dark as my thoughts and, at £72 a bottle, much cheaper than my erotic fiasco. I really look forward to my lonely heart replies.

gorgeoustanya@hotmail.com

'Can't help it, I went to boarding school (www.boardingschools.hobsons.com). Please help me,' he sobbed. We talked - and talked. I thought I was going to be Jennifer Lopez but I ended up being Susie Orbach. Enough is enough. Back at work, the falling price of e-shares kept me busy. At home, I drowned my sorrows in a fabulous Ribera del Duero Ribera del Duero as rich and dark as my thoughts and, at £72 a bottle, much cheaper than my erotic fiasco. I really look forward to my lonely heart replies. gorgeoustanya@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Splice of life
fields.standfirst: Now is an excellent time to take cuttings - so go forth, snip and multiply, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Now is an excellent time to take cuttings - so go forth, snip and multiply, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
Soft cuttings root very easily at this time of the year and may be the best way to increase stock. Dahlias are a classic example. You may say it is late for dahlia cuttings, but we shall be taking quite a lot of them early next month, simply because we don't bring our tubers out of storage until early April, and it takes time for them to start sprouting.

Short, stubby cuttings, severed with a sharp blade where they join the tuber, are ideal. Root them in a freely-draining compost in which there is plenty - at least half - sand. When we speak of sand in horticultural terms, we do not, of course, mean fine builder's sand but grit, which is ground up shingle: it drains freely. The cuttings will need close conditions with plenty of light, but not in sunlight, which will wilt them.

The plants made from these late-struck dahlia cuttings will flower in the autumn, looking fresh when much else is tired - always with the hope that early frosts won't strike. Where I am, on a hill, they often hold off till November.

Salvia x superba (1m) is one of my most valued perennials, flowering both in July and again in September, but it makes thick roots that do not at all lend themselves to splitting. Take cuttings of its young shoots, but expect slow and uneven results. It is not one of the easiest, unlike the similar but dwarfer (and less long-flowering) S. nemorosa 'Ostfriesland' ('East Friesland'), which always roots easily. Shrubby salvias came through the winter well, so if you missed propagating them in the autumn, you can do so from young shoots now.

One of the perennials that I always seem to need more of is the cultivar of Campanula lactiflora called 'Prichard's Variety'. It is convenient, 1m tall (the species straight is often 2m), and the deepest, richest campanula blue of any. Again, it has thick, fleshy roots that dislike interference, which is the reasonfor cuttings being the best method of increase.

The old - but now defunct - Christchurch (Dorset) firm of Prichard is also celebrated in one of my favourite cranesbills, Geranium x riversleaianum (try saying that in a hurry) 'Russell Prichard'. A prostrate plant, it has a delightful way of exploring its neighbours by hoisting itself into them; also of surging forwards in a great pool of magenta, over paving or lawn (less popular with the mower). It flowers, non-stop, from late May until October.

There is always a price for such prodigal generosity. Plants do not usually last much above three years; but they can be renewed - from cuttings. Established colonies will have short, woody stems with a tuft of leaves at the crown. These stems can be severed and rooted individually. A number of other geraniums can be increased in exactly the same way, notably, so far as I am concerned, G. cinereum var. subcaulescens . This again is low mat-forming and is not quite aggressive enough to be up to mixed border life; a rock ledge is more suitable. Its flowers, in early summer, are the most dazzling shade of magenta imaginable, this colour being highlighted by a dark eye. If you hate magenta, try this one; it will kill or cure you.

You must surely have that scintillating comfrey, Symphytum x uplandicum 'Variegatum'. Its leaves have a broad cream margin. Clump-forming, it certainly stands out in a crowd. Unfortunately, if you damage its roots in any way, the damaged portion will give rise to plain green leaves, which will have greater vigour than the variegated and will overwhelm them in time.

On a short-term basis, you can remove green shoots as they appear, but in the end you may need new plants, which you can site somewhere different. Cuttings of young, variegated shoots root well. When this comfrey has flowered, cut everything in sight to the ground and, in a few weeks, the plant will have refurnished itself with a crop of young foliage even more spectacular than the first.

The double white Arabis alpina 'Flore Pleno' makes loose, greyish mats that flower in spring with neat rosettes like miniature stock flowers. Between the flowering stems, there are non-flowering shoots, just right at this moment for propagation. All you need to do is to cut them off, say 10cm long, remove the lowest leaves with a sharp blade and dibble them into a light bit of soil outdoors. Some will take, some won't. So the best plan is to bunch three cuttings together into each dibbled hole. Only one needs to root and you'll be well away. Naturally, you must not expose your cuttings to drying wind before inserting them, and you must not only water them in, but remember to water again in dry weather. All this is a part of having green fingers and doesn't need to be said to those who can imagine themselves as plants (or cuttings) and can put themselves in their place.

Sedums are fleshy and the better for not being kept close. Close conditions will tend to rot cuttings made from them. But they don't like hot, wilting conditions either. Best to try for something between, and the lightest of composts to root in. All sand, if you like. When rooted, they can be given a more nourishing compost. The dwarf Sedum 'Ruby Glow' is one that I have done by the hundred in this way. It is a charming late flowerer for a border's margin, with dusky reddish flowers, and won't do anything mischievous such as spoiling the lawn in front. But, like other sedums, it is particularly popular with the maggots of vine weevils - those nasty, squishy, white things, curled up into a C-shape

fields.headline: How to be happy
fields.trailText: Happiness is like a scooter; once you're up and running, you can just scoot along. It's getting up in the first place that's the tricky bit. Happiness needs to be kick started and the secret of doing this is to stop your brain working.
fields.body:
Happiness is like a scooter; once you're up and running, you can just scoot along. It's getting up in the first place that's the tricky bit. Happiness needs to be kick started and the secret of doing this is to stop your brain working: given its head, as it were, the brain likes to prove how intelligent it is by being miserable. (Have you noticed how intellectuals tend to be glum because it looks so much cleverer than walking around whistling like the village idiot?)

Happiness is all about forgetting yourself and realising that it's a beautiful world out there. (Don't confuse this with forgetting things, because if you rush out into the beautiful world and forget your keys, you're not going to be happy for long.) Meeting together with a party of like-minded women to sort out three tonnes of copper collected for charity will get your hands extremely dirty, but half way through, when everyone's working away and the jokes about spending a penny are flowing thick and fast, a lovely feeling will set in. That's happiness.

Music is the food of happiness: if you catch yourself whistling, humming or singing to yourself, you are happy. The best work-out for making yourself happy is to sing songs in the bath at high volume because filling your lungs full of air is a short cut to happiness. Miserable people don't like breathing; they smoke, slump around and mumble. If they were to stand up straight, take big, deep breaths, speak clearly and exercise regularly they would be very happy. They wouldn't have any friends but, boy, would they be happy.

One of the drawbacks of being happy and knowing it is that you feel an urge to clap your hands. Never reply, 'I'm very happy' when someone asks you how you are, as it gives the impression that you are one step away from madness, religious conversion or both. Virtually all behaviour associated with happiness such as whooping, skipping, hugging and whistling is frowned upon in public unless it's been induced by alcohol or by being five years old. That's why train passengers generally look as though they're all off to the annual conference of miserable sods.

The only way you can be sure someone is happy is that they make you feel happy, too, whereas unhappy people make other people unhappy often to prove just how unhappy they really are. Happiness is quietly infectious - it's the virus that dare not speak its name.

webTitle: Dulcie Domum: Travels with one's aunt

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Travels with one's aunt
fields.standfirst: 'The only way I can indulge in heavy petting is by getting a Newfoundland dog'
fields.trailText: 'The only way I can indulge in heavy petting is by getting a Newfoundland dog'
fields.body:
Still haven't confronted ex-Spouse with his adulteries of the previous century. Not the right moment. I quite liked the idea of him spending Easter with egg on his face, but the right moment never came and the terrible knowledge of his past misdemeanours is still a cross I have to bear.

Another is catering. Somehow, we got through the frightful feast of organic lamb, Cornish new potatoes, Simnel cake, and chocolate in the shape of endangered species that were too endearing to eat. I have now vowed never to cook again.

This weekend, Aunt Elspeth is going to visit cousins who live at Uig on the Isle of Skye. Ex-Spouse has agreed to drive her there in a hired car. Hope they will bring back presents, perhaps a bit of mountain. A square yard of highland scree would look cute by the front door.

Henry is off on a rugby end-of-season binge in Bristol. "What about your revision?" I ask feebly. "I've done it," he snaps with a defiant glare. He's gone a bit anti since I told him I would no longer pick up his clothes off the floor. Cannot imagine Jesus going through this kind of phase with Mary.

So I am to be marooned with Harriet. Her hair is 2in long and dyed orange. Tattooes adorn her shoulders and her boots are huge and buckled.

"Mum? I wanna paint my room black for Easter - c'n you, like, help me?"

And I was hoping to start my next novel. Still, it is an educational opportunity, so agree, while pointing out that, first, she must excavate the debris in her bedroom to find that old-fashioned concept - floor -upon which decorators prefer to place stepladders.

Harriet spends the next six hours experimenting with different shades of black, mostly on her eyelids. I try to think of a name for my hero and heroine. Ex-Spouse rings from Stafford to say that aunt has forgotten her echinacea drops, and will I please post them on to Uig or her immune system will plummet. Feel sudden pang of jealousy and wish I, too, was in Stafford - though not with ex or aunt. Stafford a good name. Admire also Dudley and Leicester. Perhaps I was Queen Elizabeth I in a previous life. Maybe that is why I am now so supine - I used up all my imperiousness back then. Interesting new book by David Starkey: "Was QEI a victim of child abuse?" Heavy petting in Sudeley Castle. Realise sadly that, at my age, the only way I can indulge in heavy petting is by acquiring a Newfoundland dog.

"Mum! I'm hungry!" Wielding the mascara wand is exhausting, of course. Suddenly realise there is no food in the house and the shops will close in an hour.

"Let's go to Waitrose!" cries Harriet with almost religious fervour, and within minutes we are entering the hallowed portals. It is only a week or two since I was last here, but so rich and strange is the variety of new products that I feel like somebody who has just emerged from 20 years in jail.

Gaze amazed at Jackdaw and Absinthe Pté from the Ardennes, Titus Andronicus's Roman salad of chopped baby leaves and tongue, and aromatherapy oil of laurel and jasmine. Oil is adorned with lines from Shelley's Ode To The West Wind. He would have been proud.

Harriet grabs luxury items, particularly tropical sorbets and Lewinsky's Chocolate Chip'n'Cuban Cigar ice cream. We then race home eager to gorge. Agonising pause on doorstep while I search for front-door key. Oh no! Key not on key-ring! "I lent it to you, Harriet - this morning!"

"It's not my fault!"

"Not mine either!" Help! The sorbets are melting!

Eventually, encouraged by me, Harriet kicks in a back window and we are reunited with our refrigeration. "See," she says. "It's a good job I got these boots and started kick-boxing classes." I hope a flattened carton taped over the broken window will deter burglars. Shall be awake all night clutching my old tennis racket, though lack confidence to smash burglars. Shall lob them instead.

Ex-Spouse rings to say they are breaking their journey at the Travelodge, Gretna Green. Though there is a literary precedent for Travels With One's Aunt, I'm not so sure about eloping.

fields.headline: The questionnaire: Al Murray
fields.trailText: Al Murray
fields.body:
Al Murray was born in 1968 at Stewkley, Buckinghamshire, and was educated at Oxford. Having developed a comedy show in which he took on the persona of a pub landlord, he performed the show, And A Glass Of White Wine For The Lady!, at the Edinburgh Festival. Last year, he won the Perrier Pick Of The Fringe Award. Married with a daughter, he lives in London. His show is at London's Playhouse Theatre until May 6.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Family and home.

What is your greatest fear?
Losing the above.

Which living person do you most admire?
My partner, Amber.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
I can be vague.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
People not turning up when they say they will.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Takeaway sushi, bottle of Coke, Monday nights.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
Yes - amazing you to have to ask, this is the Guardian, isn't it?

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My paunch.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Not cleaning my teeth nearly enough.

What is your favourite smell?
Bacon.

What is your favourite word?
Sprocket.

What is your favourite building?
The Hoover building on the A40.

What is your favourite book?
The Bridge, by Iain Banks. I have no idea what's going on in it, though.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes. Though, like God, there is little proof of its existence.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
The music of Genesis - the mid-70s line-up.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Fraid so.

What is your greatest regret?
The Thank You letters I haven't written.

When and where were you happiest?
At the birth of my daughter.

How often do you have sex?
Plenty.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Someone to do up my loft.

Do you believe in life after death?
No.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Follow your heart.

fields.headline: The bold and the beautiful
fields.standfirst: The Milan Furniture Fair is a mammoth, daunting event - but when was quantity any guarantee of quality? Luckily for Caroline Roux, the best ideas are shining as bright as ever
fields.trailText: The Milan Furniture Fair is a mammoth, daunting event - but when was quantity any guarantee of quality? Luckily for Caroline Roux, the best ideas are shining as bright as ever
fields.body:
Milan, April 2000. If I never see another injection-moulded polypropylene chair it will probably be too soon. Overload is, of course, what the city specialises in, from fashion to Vespas, and in April it's furniture. The Salone dei Mobili are Milan's biggest event of the year.

What something like a furniture fair will always prove most efficiently - especially one such as this, with literally miles of aisles showing product from just about everywhere - is that there is already quite enough furniture in the world as it is, and that the very few good pieces that do exist are very hard to improve upon. How many chairs does one species need? Even taking into account different climates?

So the task in hand is to isolate the one or two new things that really make the grade. Slip past those endless stands of 19th-century repro heavy with the smell of veneer glue and high-gloss polish, avert your eyes from the over-styled rattan beds, the marble-topped coffee tables and the mirrored wardrobes, and head for hall No20, home of the brave.

Ron Arad is now a name designer of some reknown, and works for all the major Italian furniture manufacturers, but he has battled his way there from an uncompromising past as a maker of oversized, one-off beaten metal pieces and chairs from Rover car-seats that now fetch thousands at auction. He is braver than most.

In Milan, his Victoria & Albert range sits voluptuously on the stand of grand Italian producer Moroso (available in London from Atrium). On a white plinth under the spotlight glare is the matriarch of the range - a voluminous red sofa that is an evenly padded continuous loop curved round to leave provocative empty spaces. This is its grand launch, but from June 12 it will go on show at the Victoria & Albert Museum as part of an Arad retrospective. Arad says it's the result of his dislike of sofas: "They are usually big lumps, taking up a lot of floor space and air room. They are accepted as a comfortable evil."

This is a piece that would fill the void in your 2,000 sq ft loft with sculptural grace. But how many average homes could accommodate it is another matter. This goes for quite a few other exhibits: modern furniture designers seem to be engaged in a competition to design the biggest sofa system, and Matthew Hilton's Converse, at the British company SCP, is another front runner. Organic and asymmetric in form, and upholstered in a sage-green fabric - very now, a sort of furniture equivalent of homeopathic remedies - the Milan version rambled squashily around a corner and could seat, maybe, eight. Next to it, veteran designer Robin Day's new sofa-cum-daybed, also for SCP, looks decidedly small, square and uptight, with its rigidly geometric shapes and perfectly formed cushions.

Those looking for something a little less serious for a trashable bachelor loft might prefer Denis Santachiara's Swing range for Domodinamica. Hybrids have never been more fashionable in Milan (think Miu Miu shoes), and furniture follows suit. The Swing chairs, with their silver moulded plastic bases that rock back, forwards and sideways, look like the seat as trainer. They have the aesthetic of the inflatable, without that same unsettling impermanence. Living Space in N1 was showing interest, so they could find their way to London yet. And for those looking for the absurd, Philippe Starck is once again on hand to save the day. His Bubble sofa, a jokey confectition in pale lemon moulded plastic, might be making use of the very latest technology ("Plastic sofas, a technological miracle!" exclaims Kartell) but even at a risible £250, would you really want to give it house room? The good news, then, is that it doubles as a garden piece.

Cappellini took over a large part of Superstudio, Fabrizio Ferri's famed and rambling photographic studios, for its display. The company is known for being just a little more relaxed than its Italian colleagues - you'd be unlikely to see something like Marcel Wanders perfectly formed sheet-metal occasional tables, photo-engraved with a map of Amsterdam, anywhere else. Or Hella Jongerius's curvy stools clad in three layers of heavy felt.

Cappellini is also the producer of the furniture designed by British minimalist Jasper Morrison for the new Tate Gallery restaurant, at Bankside. It's a set of delicately proportioned, stackable plywood chairs in strong colours - time to chuck out the pastels for rich purples, yellows and blues - and round or square tables that seem to owe their proportions to the 50s kitchen.

Next to these, are shiny new fibreglass chairs by the Bouroullec brothers. The two Bretons based in Paris produce designs that range from art to furniture. A freestanding bedroom, Lit Clos, reached by a ladder and looking suspiciously cage-like, borrows some of the streamlined aesthetics of post-war American design and some of the vocabulary of contemporary art. "The idea is to have a resting place as near to your working place as possible," says Erwan Bouroullec. "It's not a box, it's a personal space."

I'd rather define my personal space with Procter Rihl's jewel-like screen. The London-based architects, who are producing the piece themselves, have worked in Perspex for a while, and this time they've woven it into a piece that literally glows, throwing out coloured light all around it. Slipping gently through three curves, the idea for the screen "comes from a kaleidoscope," says Fernando Rihl. If you have £1,600 lying around, this limited-edition piece wouldn't make a bad investment. Unlike all those polypropylene chairs, you're never going to be in danger of seeing too many of these

fields.headline: Say cheese
fields.standfirst: Martin Parr has made a career of capturing the oddities and personalities of everyday life on camera. But, travelling the world, he took the opportunity to pose himself for any studio photographer he met on the way. Are the results tacky, ridiculous, celebratory or camp? Just what was he aiming for, asks Sam Wollaston
fields.trailText: Martin Parr has made a career of capturing the oddities and personalities of everyday life on camera. But, travelling the world, he took the opportunity to pose himself for any studio photographer he met on the way. Are the results tacky, ridiculous, celebratory or camp? Just what was he aiming for, asks Sam Wollaston
fields.body:
Two things are odd about photographer Martin Parr's new exhibition of photographs. No, that's not true; many more than two things are odd about it. But two things are very odd. First, he didn't take any of the pictures himself. Not a single one. And second - and this is not entirely unconnected to the first - he's in them all. Every single one.

Among the other things you might say is that they are garish and cheap looking, but if you know Parr's work, this is perhaps not so odd. Then there's the fact that, although each was taken in a different place - Abu Dhabi, Minehead, North Korea, Frankfurt airport, that sort of thing - you learn very little about these places from them, at least at first glance. Also odd is that Parr's expression is the same in each picture even though they were taken over a period of five years. That's not to say he looks the same in each one; in some you'd say he was in his early 30s, in others more like his 50s. (Really he's 47.)

Oh, and one more odd thing: they're not very good. Or they're not very good if good means something that has life, or that moves you, provokes, inspires, makes you sad. A smile is probably the most they'll get out of you, possibly a laugh. Which is more than whoever took them got out of Parr - the expression he wears throughout is a nothing expression. Look in his eyes and perhaps there's a hint of a glint of knowing amusement. These are not pictures you would expect to find in an exhibition by a leading Magnum photographer. In fact, you wouldn't be best pleased if they turned up in your Snappy Snaps envelope.

At which point some explanation is required. Whether or not they are good is beside the point. Autoportrait by Martin Parr is a celebration of studio photography from around the world. And that means studio photography in its broadest possible sense - so an automatic photo-booth counts, as does a street photographer, or just a bloke dressed as a centurion outside the Colosseum in Rome. As well as sitting for traditional portraits in a studio, Parr turned himself into a calendar, a body builder, a postcard, an astronaut, a biscuit even. And he had himself eaten by a shark. It started off just being his own little thing - he'd have his photo taken in the places he travelled to as a souvenir. But Parr has always been interested in studio photography and this was a way of collecting trophies of the remarkable studios he'd stumble across. As he started putting them together, they began to make more sense; what he has now, he says, is a collection that "highlights the different ways we have our photo taken in different places around the world". It's a photographer's celebration of his own trade.

Martin Parr is best known for taking candid pictures of people, particularly British people. He takes honest pictures of real people, but pictures that make the ordinary look less ordinary. The most common criticism aimed at his work is that he's making fun, that by making his subjects look more lifelike than life itself, he makes them look ridiculous. He's been accused of sneering at both ends of the class spectrum from the safety of the middle. But if he has mocked before, he's not doing so this time. He admits they're funny at one level. "But I'm not taking the mick - it's a very serious project, about how we have our photographs taken."

So there's a reason why he's got a telephone to his ear in the picture he had done in Dhaka? "In Bangladesh, the phone is seen as a status symbol. So you're invited to have your photograph taken talking on the telephone. You may not have one at home but it does show that you've done quite well for yourself."

Each of these pictures has a story. In North Korea, he found a photographer in a square in Pyongyang. Parr was there as part of a group, so after they'd had the group shot taken he asked if he could have an individual one. They hoped to collect the photos before leaving, but at the end of the week the pictures weren't ready and they had to leave the country without them. "The guy who organised the group does four trips a year to North Korea. So next time he went back three months later, he went to see the photographer in the square to see if he could get the photos. But the photographer had run out of photographic paper - black and white, of course. So the guy says, fair enough, next time I'll bring some black and white photographic paper. And he comes three months later with the paper. Then three months after that he finally delivers the picture." And here it is, carefully hand-tinted.

Parr got his picture of himself in the square in Pyongyang 10 months after it had been taken. In Frankfurt Airport, a machine made a postcard saying "See you soon 2000" with a smiley face in one of the zeros sitting right on top of Parr's unsmiling face. It took about three minutes for the picture to be delivered - a picture, Parr says, that "inspires me because it's so uninspired, so pedestrian".

In many of the pictures, Parr is not alone. At Butlin's in Minehead he has his arm round a tiger, at Madame Tussaud's in Amsterdam it's Arnold Schwarzenegger. In Portugal he's sitting on a horse; then there's that centurion in Rome holding a sword to Parr's belly. He's demonstrating that habit of going some place, finding a familiar icon and having a picture taken in front of it. People don't want a picture of Buckingham Palace, they want a picture of themselves in front of Buckingham Palace. It's the same with the Colosseum in Rome, and if there happens to be a Roman soldier there, too, so much the better. "This happens a lot now. People dress up in some local costume. Like if you go to Cuba and you see some old woman with a huge fat cigar in a tourist street you know that she'll charge you a dollar and you'll be the 30th person that morning to have the photograph of her." Instead of looking down at such practices, Parr has embraced them.

Parr might not have taken any of these pictures but he has to call them his own work, he says. It's clear that it's he who's in control, not the person with the camera. You can see this in the Victorian-looking picture of him in top hat and tails taken in Scarborough. Look carefully and you'll see he's wearing sandals. "I purposefully kept my sandals on just to prove that it's not really a photo taken in Victorian times. When I'm having these photos done I'm making sure that these small details are orchestrated to my advantage."

And then there's the fact that he never smiles: he thinks the best portraits never have a smiling subject. But you can imagine the frustration of the person behind the camera - when there is a person - trying to get this stony-faced man to smile. There's no doubt that this is Martin Parr's show

 The exhibition, Autoportrait, Martin Parr, will be at the Tom Blau Gallery, 21 Queen Elizabeth Street, Butlers Wharf, London SE1, from May 8 to June 2. The book of the same name will be published next month by Dewi Lewis at £12.99. To order a copy at the special price of £10.99, plus UK p&p, freephone Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166102.
