fields.headline: London, Paris, Theddlethorpe (All Saints)
fields.trailText: Thriving Theddlethorpe, indistinct indexes, and "Ann Widdecombe, a hooker?".
fields.body:
One would not normally disagree with the Guardian but I think the assumption that William Hague has landed himself in a major embarrassment with his handling of the Tony Martin issue is wrong. True, he once voted for mandatory life sentences and now thinks they are a mistake, and that is inconsistency. But sticking unswervingly to what you first thought is not sensible politics either - see Thatcher's poll tax. As Emerson wrote: "A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds". Though maybe he changed his mind about that later.

Consistency is certainly not that important for winning elections. Strategies for that have little to do with standing proudly by past undertakings, but everything to do with winning approval from tabloid newspapers. What Hague has now done is to bring not just the Mail (wavery Tory under John Major) on side but the Sun as well. The fact that Labour, the Guardian, the BBC and the Lib Dems were against him showed Hague was right, the Sun said on Thursday. This from a paper which begged its readers to turn out for Blair Labour in May 1997. There are two ways to win round these newspapers. Say what you think and then coax and wheedle, tossing in the odd political bribe, till they come round; or simply endorse what they say. Hague has chosen the latter. With the Martin case, as with asylum before it, it may be a squalid approach but that does not mean it won't work. And New Labour can hardly complain, given the way Blair prostrated himself before the Sun in the spring of 1997, with those pieces about how dearly he loved the pound, and how he thrilled to the very thought of St George.

 The steam engine devised by Thomas Newcomen (1663-1729) worked on the following principle. Water was heated and the steam thus generated passed through a tap into a cylinder. A swinging pump beam was fixed to the wall, with, on its left . . .

Perplexed (Saltfleetby) writes: In recent columns Smallweed has several times referred to Theddlethorpe, Lincolnshire, without ever stopping to signify the Theddlethorpe to which he is animadverting. Does he have in mind Theddlethorpe All Saints or Theddlethorpe St Helen?

Smallweed smilingly replies: Neither. For me, not least because I have never been there, the appeal of Theddlethorpe lies in the euphony of its name, which applies in equal measure to both settlements. I take the same impartial view as the railway, which established a single station for both, calling it Theddlethorpe. There are, by the same token, three Saltfleetbys: St Peter, St Clement and All Saints (where Saltfleetby is pronounced Sollerby, I believe), united by a single Saltfleetby station.

Had the railway system not been vandalised in the middle years of the present century*, I could have left King's Cross station at 8.45 yesterday morning and, by taking a train for Louth, could have been at Theddlethorpe station at 1.32pm, or at Saltfleetby by 1.37. The glory of the Theddlethorpe area, as I understand it, is the church at All Saints, locally called the cathedral of the marsh. The Shell Guide to Lincolnshire is especially pleased by the woodwork, singling out two parcloses to the north and south chapels with excitingly cursive faces - dual designs of dragons, it says, and strange faces back to back, like half moons wearing night caps with long tassels hanging down the front. What a strange and mysterious county this Lincolnshire is! There is even a Newcomen memorial in the church at Theddlethorpe All Saints, but to which Newcomen the book does not say.

Next week, perhaps: How Smallweed journeyed to Stragglethorpe, stopping off for a light ale at Strubby.

 Why do serious publishers of serious books skimp on the indexes? Here is an entry from a book I have just been reading:

Law, Charles Bonar. 4, 221, 275, 281, 297, 343, 381, 392-4, 399, 400, 403, 407, 412, 413 . . . and so on. There are 34 references, all undifferentiated. What is the use of that? What the reader needs is much more specific guidance, as in : birth, 4; education, 221; employed as trapeze artist, 275; fights duel with Alma-Tadema, 281. In any case, this may be the wrong Bonar Law. I was looking for the Tory prime minister, whose first name, all other reference books claim, was Andrew.

Lord J of H (Oxford University) writes: Do you have any details of Bonar Law's duel with Alma-Tadema? I can find no mention of this in any biography.

Smallweed retorts with a knowing smirk: Hushed up, I expect. I bet it was over a woman.

 Since Smallweed's own tastes run to rugby league, I may have been wrong in suggesting that the beleaguered Metroplitan Police rugby XV could improve its chances by installing the shadow home secretary in the second row of its scrum. A more expert judgment has since arrived from Bishop Auckland, challenging this assumption. As a lock, it says (this is the technical term for second rowers), Ann Widdecombe would be required to leap effortlessly skyward, lifted by colleagues at lineouts. This may not, my correspondent suggests, be the best use of her, since "surely her physique and unfailing and unthinking aggression make her one of nature's hookers".

A lawyer writes: I am glad you are planning to make it clear that this term applies exclusively in the context of rugby.

Smallweed replies with appropriate genuflections: But of course.

 My final word, addressed to all my detractors, I leave with the excellent Emerson. "What is a weed?" he wrote. "A plant whose virtues have not yet been discovered." I hope he never wavered from that.

* Like most thinking people, Smallweed intends to remain in the 20th century till the end of this year.

The Shell Guide to Lincolnshire is especially pleased by the woodwork, singling out two parcloses to the north and south chapels with excitingly cursive faces - dual designs of dragons, it says, and strange faces back to back, like half moons wearing night caps with long tassels hanging down the front. What a strange and mysterious county this Lincolnshire is! There is even a Newcomen memorial in the church at Theddlethorpe All Saints, but to which Newcomen the book does not say. Next week, perhaps: How Smallweed journeyed to Stragglethorpe, stopping off for a light ale at Strubby.  Why do serious publishers of serious books skimp on the indexes? Here is an entry from a book I have just been reading: Law, Charles Bonar. 4, 221, 275, 281, 297, 343, 381, 392-4, 399, 400, 403, 407, 412, 413 . . . and so on. There are 34 references, all undifferentiated. What is the use of that? What the reader needs is much more specific guidance, as in : birth, 4; education, 221; employed as trapeze artist, 275; fights duel with Alma-Tadema, 281. In any case, this may be the wrong Bonar Law. I was looking for the Tory prime minister, whose first name, all other reference books claim, was Andrew. Lord J of H (Oxford University) writes: Do you have any details of Bonar Law's duel with Alma-Tadema? I can find no mention of this in any biography. Smallweed retorts with a knowing smirk: Hushed up, I expect. I bet it was over a woman.  Since Smallweed's own tastes run to rugby league, I may have been wrong in suggesting that the beleaguered Metroplitan Police rugby XV could improve its chances by installing the shadow home secretary in the second row of its scrum. A more expert judgment has since arrived from Bishop Auckland, challenging this assumption. As a lock, it says (this is the technical term for second rowers), Ann Widdecombe would be required to leap effortlessly skyward, lifted by colleagues at lineouts. This may not, my correspondent suggests, be the best use of her, since "surely her physique and unfailing and unthinking aggression make her one of nature's hookers". A lawyer writes: I am glad you are planning to make it clear that this term applies exclusively in the context of rugby. Smallweed replies with appropriate genuflections: But of course.  My final word, addressed to all my detractors, I leave with the excellent Emerson. "What is a weed?" he wrote. "A plant whose virtues have not yet been discovered." I hope he never wavered from that. * Like most thinking people, Smallweed intends to remain in the 20th century till the end of this year.
